column3: doc

Five astronauts board Discovery today for a second try at send the hubble Space Telescope into orbit to scan the outermost reaches of the universe for clues to the beginning of time. Astronomers be start to tingle again in anticipation of what the Hubble will be able to accomplish, say Lennard Fisk, head of NASA science activities. Air Force forecasters say there be a 90 percent chance the weather would be favorable for launch the shuttle at the scheduled time of 8:31 a.m. EDT. more than a half million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen be pump into the space ship's fuel tanks after midnight. The astronauts, wear bright orange flight suits, climb into the crew cabin just as dawn be break over the Kennedy Space Center. The $1.5 billion telescope, NASA's costliest cargo, will give astronomers a new set of eyes and ears that we don't have, say William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. It's go to change our perspective altogether. I can't say what we're go to learn, but I'll be astound if we don't learn many new things. Discovery be aim for an altitude of 380 miles, the high a shuttle have ever gone, so the telescope can be place in its proper orbit far above Earth's distort atmosphere. It be the 35th shuttle mission. Columbia, which journey into space next month with the Astro observatory, sit on a launch pad 1.6 miles from Discovery, only the second time both pads have be occupied; the first be in 1986 just before the Challenger explosion. Hubble have be wait to take its place in space since 1983, delay by technical problems and the Challenger accident. The late postponement occur April 10, when Discovery's launch be scrub four minutes before liftoff because of a faulty power unit on the shuttle. The mood at the Kennedy Space Center be considerably less festive than during the first launch attempt, when hundreds of astronomers gather with their families. The day after launch, mission specialist Steven a. Hawley will use the shuttle's mechanical arm to lift the 24,250-pound telescope into space. Veteran spacewalkers Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan will assist if a problem develops. Discovery will follow Hubble from 40 miles away for two days until after its lens cap be opened, expose the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Hubble be not expect to start provide scientific data by satellite for a month or more after liftoff. However, NASA say it will release its first image an open star cluster in the constellation Carina a week after launch. In addition to the $1.5 billion cost of Hubble, $500 million have be spend on spare parts, astronaut training and computer software to operate the instrument. The european Space Agency contribute $250 million for 15 percent of the view time. NASA estimate it will cost $200 million a year to operate and maintain the telescope in space. During its 15-year working lifetime, the telescope will provide astronomers with 10 times good resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories. As a result, they will be able to study stars and galaxies so distant their light have be travel toward Earth for 14 billion years. Astronomers hope to learn whether the universe be create 15 billion years ago as believe and uncover some of the mystery surround galaxies, black holes and quasars. Hubble also be expect to shed light on how and when the universe might end. The telescope be name for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discover during the 1920s that the universe be expanding. His work give rise to the Big Bang theory that the universe be create by a tremendous explosion. In addition to Hubble, Discovery carry a human skull fill with sensors to measure the space radiation that astronauts receive. It be the skull's third trip into space. The shuttle be to end its five-day mission with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Discovery's five astronauts return Sunday for a second attempt to launch the shuttle with NASA's most valuable and celebrate payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Discovery be schedule to lift off at 8:31 a.m. EDT Tuesday. We feel very confident that things be go to go well this time, say Discovery's commander, Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver. We're go to come out OK on Tuesday morning and, if not, we'll just keep try until we do. That's kind of the name of the game here, Shriver said. NASA test director Mike Leinbach say Sunday that the countdown be proceed smoothly and the shuttle appear to be in perfect condition. The countdown get under way Saturday afternoon. A faulty power unit force the first launch attempt to be scrub four minutes before liftoff April 10. The unit be replace with a new one, which test show to be fine. Hopefully, we'll get the shuttle off the pad this time, Leinbach said. A 70 percent chance of favorable weather be expect at launch time, with low clouds be the main concern, say the Air Force's Ed Priselac, shuttle weather officer. A weak cold front from the north be expect to pass through the area by Monday night. The outlook be considerably better for Wednesday and Thursday, Priselac said. As Discovery's astronauts arrive from Johnson Space Center in Houston early Sunday afternoon, the shuttle Columbia be be transport to a launch pad 1.6 miles from Discovery. It be only the second time both shuttle launch pads at Kennedy Space Center have be occupy simultaneously. The first time be in January 1986; 16 days after Columbia lift off, Challenger exploded. Columbia commander Vance Brand say he do not believe the National Aeronautics and Space Administration be move too fast with his shuttle. NASA expect to launch Columbia with an astronomical observatory call Astro no early than May 16, one week later than plan because of Discovery's two-week delay. In some cases, it could be a problem have shuttles on both launch pads, Brand said. In this particular case, everything's fit together. NASA have until Saturday to get Discovery off the ground. After that, all launch attempts must be halt for eight days so hubble's batteries can be recharged. The six nickel-hydrogen batteries will power Hubble from the time it be disconnect from Discovery's electrical system until its two energy-collecting solar panels take over in space. Discovery's payload bay be seal late Saturday night, drastically reduce the risk of contamination to the telescope's finely polish 94.5-inch mirror. Discovery will aim for an altitude of 380 miles, the high a shuttle have ever gone, so the telescope can be place in its proper orbit far above Earth's distort atmosphere. During Hubble's 15-year journey through space, astronomers expect to look back to nearly the beginning of time and solve some of the universe's most perplexing mysteries. Astro will measure ultraviolet radiation undetected by Hubble and thus provide additional targets for the telescope. The $100 million observatory also will focus during Columbia's nine-day mission on Comet Austin, believe to be on its first trip through the solar system. Both Hubble and Astro be schedule for launch in 1986, but be delay by the Challenger accident. The hubble Space Telescope be awaken from its self-induced sleep today but it be still without the use of its high-speed antennas, and its science instruments be on hold, unable to begin any observations. We be out of the `safe-mode' right now, say Steve Terry, a supervisor of the engineers control the telescope. He say the telescope be run on a normal control-all mode, where its own computers and sensors guide where it be pointing. Discovery's astronauts, meanwhile, pack their gear for a return to Earth Sunday, make some last-minute observations of Earth and talk with ground-based reporters about their flight. Pilot Charles Bolden say he be especially upbeat about the widespread public awareness of the telescope, which be expect eventually to look back 14 billion light years nearly to the birth of the universe. It's hard to go somewhere and find someone who have never hear of the hubble Space Telescope, say Bolden. It make little kids' eyes light up. It make little kids want to learn how to add and subtract and study science. The telescope's big eye have remain open, but Hubble have be in a safe mode with all motion stop because of early problems in link the high-speed dish antennas with a relay satellite. The antennas be the primary links for relay scientific data to the ground. Terry say that even in the safe mode, one of the tape recorders in the telescope read telemetry signals from all its systems and that these would be play to Earth and analyze when the antennas be work properly. We expect to use that data to investigate what happened, he said. Engineers be able to send commands to the telescope via its secondary antennas but the communications system be not useful for scientific data, which must be transmit at a high rate of speed. We're put the scientific instruments in a hold mode, in effect a standby mode, he said. shortly after 6 a.m. EDT, controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., complete a series of commands that take the telescope out of its safe mode and then begin to run a 12-hour computer program to monitor Hubble's health. It will take another day before the $1.5 billion telescope be operate the way it be suppose to at this point in the startup process, say hubble deputy project manager Jean Olivier. We're back up to a very deliberate and slow and careful approach to these problems, Olivier say Friday. This be not the time to do anything dumb. The telescope problems have put the flight center several days behind, but the five astronauts who deploy it earlier this week be stick to their schedule. Landing be schedule for 9:48 a.m. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., but flight controllers be keep a close watch on the weather. Winds be predict to be about 20 mph with gusts up to 29 mph. Mission rules dictate that headwinds cannot exceed 29 mph at touchdown. The shuttle carry enough supplies to stay in orbit three days beyond Sunday if necessary, NASA said. Mission Control awaken the crew members at about 1:30 a.m. EDT today by play the song, Cosmos. Thanks for the wake-up music, it's pretty appropriate for today, say Commander Loren Shriver. The song be select in honor of hubble Space Telescope, which be now open for business, say Mission Control commentator James Hartsfield. The astronauts be to finish up their experiments and photography today and pack for the trip home. They also plan to hold a news conference from space with reporters at the Johnson Space Center. Shriver and pilot Charles Bolden be to run through a series of tests to make certain the shuttle's computers and control jets be ready for return to earth. The crew deploy Hubble on Wednesday but they have stay close to the telescope in case there be trouble open the aperture door. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan be prepare to perform a space walk today to crank it open in orbit 380 miles above Earth. But that prove unnecessary when the door be open Friday morning, expose the telescope's finely polish 94.5-inch eye to starlight for the first time. Two of Hubble's four position-stabilizing gyroscopes stop work when the door opened, but engineers later get them back on line. The gyroscopes be knock out by the motion and that, too, keep the telescope in the safe mode, say Dave Drachlis, director of orbital verifications at Goddard. A colleague, Steve Terry, say Hubble's systems be set at conservative limits for the first operations and that cause many malfunctions. There also be two communications outages total several hours. Hubble be design with safe modes so it can be the master of its own destiny in case contact with an orbit communications system be lose for extend periods, Terry said. NASA have plan to release its first test image from the telescope on Tuesday, show an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. But Terry say that would be delay because of the antenna problems. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. The telescope, name for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, will enable astronomers over its 15-year working lifetime to look back 14 billion years and possibly determine the age of the universe. The universe be believe to have be create about 15 billion years ago in a cosmic explosion. Hubble provide the basis for the big-bang theory of creation. He discover during the 1920s that the universe be expand and that the farther the galaxy be from Earth, the faster it be move away. After years of delay and a last-minute snag, the hubble Space Telescope be free from the shuttle Discovery on Wednesday and, glint in the sunlight, drift into orbit on its 15-year search for new worlds. Mission specialist Steven Hawley release Hubble from the end of the shuttle's 50-foot-long mechanical arm after a delay in get one of the telescope's solar wings unfurled. The first of NASA's great observatories be now on station at 330 nautical miles above the Earth, Mission Control's Jeffrey Carr said. The telescope really look great as we fly away from it, and we sure hope it do good work, Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver say later. The $1.5 billion telescope be release at 3:38 p.m. EDT as the shuttle enter its 20th orbit of Earth, nearly two hours and one orbit later than planned. The shuttle then back away. Thank you very much for the ride, say Mike Harrington, director of orbital verifications at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan have be in the shuttle's airlock, ready to walk inspace to free the solar panel. That prove to be unnecessary. Close but no cigar, but good for the Hubble that it go the way it did, Sullivan said. She and McCandless have train for nearly five years to make such a rescue mission. The first solar array unreel from its mast at midday Wednesday as the shuttle pass 380 statute miles, or 330 nautical miles, above South America's eastern coast. It start provide power to the telescope's batteries, which otherwise have only eight hours of charge. Deployment of the starboard panel, however, be more troublesome. It wouldn't budge when latches be first released, then move about a fifth of its 39-foot length, and stop again. A third attempt roll the panel out all the way. Houston, we see motion, Commander Loren J. Shriver reported. Hawley begin the long process of release Hubble shortly after 7 a.m. EDT when he grasp it with Discovery's 50-foot-long mechanical arm and carefully hoist the 12{-ton telescope high above the shuttle. Hubble be take off shuttle electrical power just before it be lift out of the cargo bay and be operate on its own nickel-hydrogen batteries. At one day, seven minutes into the flight of Discovery, Hubble be now on its own internal power, Carr said. The game have begun. The race be on. The clock be ticking. Worries that the telescope's instruments would be starve for electricity ease after the first solar panel be stretch out. Television cameras aboard Discovery show the first array as it be pull from its reel slowly but steadily, the sun reflect off the gold-colored panel and silvery telescope. Discovery be 380 statute miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any shuttle have ever flown. The orbit be dictate by the need to put the telescope above the Earth's distort atmosphere. Discovery's five astronauts be awe by the view. I'd like to pass on the quote of the day from the on-board astronomer something to the effect that the big marble sure look far away today, Shriver say of Hawley. Astronomers have wait seven years for hubble to take its place in space. The telescope originally be schedule for launch in 1983, but technical problems and the Challenger explosion push it back. The mission be delay another two weeks when a faulty power unit on Discovery force the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to halt the first launch attempt four minutes before April 10's schedule liftoff. On Tuesday, Discovery finally blast into space, transport hubble out of this world and in search of others. The telescope's 10-foot aperture door be to be open Friday, expose the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Discovery be follow Hubble in case the door do not open properly. If a problem develops, McCandless and Sullivan will be prepare once again to walk in space. Fred Wojtalik, Hubble project manager, say the telescope would be test Thursday for its ability to maneuever before the aperture door be opened. We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the hubble by put the aperture door close to the sunlight, he said. The telescope cannot focus into the sun because of the sensitivity of its five instruments. If all go well, the crew will land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. NASA expect to release its first image from the telescope of an open star cluster in the constellation Carina on Tuesday. Data will follow in a month or two. Astronomers hope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, study stars and galaxies so distant their light have be travel to Earth for 14 billion years. They expect to determine precisely how and when the universe be formed, currently estimate at 15 billion years ago. The telescope be name for the late american astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discover during the 1920s that the universe be expanding. He also be responsible for help to form the Big Bang theory of creation. Ground controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center finally make contact today with the two main antennas on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope after try for more than six hours to lock on. Applause erupt in the Hubble control center in Greenbelt, Md., as the glitch that mar Hubble's first full day in space be solved. We have confirmation that we have achieve communication with the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite through the high-gain antenna system, say NASA's Dave Drachlis. Engineers have say all along they believe the antennas be work all right and that the problem be in incorrectly point either the satellite or the TDRS, an orbiting communications satellite that act as a switchboard. In the successful attempt, they nearly double the width of the antennas' beam to take in more territory, from a sweep of 6.2 degrees to 10.8 degrees. The telescope's low-gain antennas, which receive and transmit information at a much slow rate and can be use in emergencies, be work well. Space shuttle Discovery be 46 miles away, available to remedy certain problems. The outage be not a problem for which space walkers would have be summoned. The five astronauts be otherwise busy make pictures of storms over Texas from their 380-mile-high perch, and do experiments. Steve Terry, director of a team calibrate various aspects of the telescope, say the first outage be cause by human error and be not a serious problem. It begin between 1 and 1:30 a.m. EDT and last 45 minutes to an hour, he said. The second failure occur at 6:44 a.m. when controllers attempt to send a signal to the telescope's two high-gain antennas through the TDRS. This time it be a pointing problem, say Jim Elliott, a Goddard spokesman. It's a new spacecraft and we think inexperience deal with it be the cause. The telescope, embark on a 15-year search for new worlds, be release from the shuttle's cargo bay Wednesday after a last-minute snag that almost send two astronauts on an emergency spacewalk. Mission Control awaken the crew early today with a loud rendition of the song Shout, a fraternity house favorite. good morning, Discovery. I guess you're awake after that song, say Kathy Thornton, shuttle communicator. There be a lot of happy people down here. We saw a great deploy yesterday and Hubble have a good night while you be asleep. We appreciate the good words from everybody, reply Discovery Commander Loren Shriver. After Wednesday's deployment, Shriver gently back Discovery away from the telescope and put the shuttle through a series of maneuvers, the last one complete this morning, to park Discovery in orbit 46 miles behind Hubble. The telescope really look great as we fly away from it, and we sure hope it do good work, Shriver say Wednesday. Well, it sure be now, Loren, and thanks for all the great work you've done, replied Mission Control. Galileo be real proud of you. Scientists have hail the Hubble NASA's most expensive unmanned spacecraft as the great advance in astronomy since Galileo raise a small telescope to his eyes nearly 400 years ago. Discovery and its five astronauts will follow the telescope while controllers at the Goddard center make sure Hubble be operate properly, such as respond to directional commands. The next milestone be Friday, when the telescope's 10-foot aperture door be to be opened, expose the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. then on Tuesday, NASA expect to release the first image from the telescope: an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Data will follow in a month or two. If the aperture door doesn't open properly, Discovery could return to the telescope so two astronauts could perform a spacewalk to fix it. Hubble project manager Fred Wojtalik say the telescope would be test today for its ability to maneuver before the aperture door be opened. We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the hubble by put the aperture door close to the sunlight, he said. Too much light could damage the telescope's sensitive instruments. On Wednesday, mission specialist Steve Hawley use the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm to gently grasp the 12{-ton telescope and hoist it from the cargo bay. One of the telescope's solar arrays unreel from its mast as expect and start provide power to the telescope's batteries, which otherwise have only eight hours of charge. But there be trouble with the second panel. It wouldn't budge when the latches be released, and then move about a fifth of its 39-foot length and stop again. The panel roll all the way out on the third attempt. By the final attempt, astronauts Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan be in their space suits in the airlock, 30 minutes away from take tools in hand and go on an outer-space maintenance call. Wojtalik say the cause of the problem be unknown. The 8{-hour procedure be perform 380 miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any shuttle have ever flown. The orbit be dictate by the need to put Hubble above the Earth's distort atmosphere. Astronomers hope to use the telescope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, study stars and galaxies so distant their light have take 14 billions years to reach Earth. They hope to determine how and when the universe be formed, currently estimate at 15 billion years ago. The telescope originally be schedule for launch in 1983 but be delay by technical problems and the Challenger accident. Discovery, which blast into orbit Tuesday, be schedule to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Seven years late, the hubble Space Telescope be where it belongs, out of this world and in search of others so distant that they may have be form at the beginning of time. Less than five hours after it ride into space aboard the shuttle Discovery on Tuesday, the $1.5 billion telescope send its first test radio signal. At the sign of life, applause and cheers erupt in Mission Control in Houston. As near as we can tell, everything looks perfect, say astronaut Steve Hawley from the shuttle. Hawley's job on Wednesday will be to drop the telescope overboard for a 15-year stay in space. Discovery, trail an arc of white smoke into a brilliant blue sky, carry the silver-colored telescope to an orbit 380 miles above Earth high by 70 miles than any previous shuttle. There the Hubble will stay to search for yet-unseen wonders of creation with instruments that can look 14 billion years backward in time. Our window on the universe! NASA launch commentator George Diller exult as the Discovery rise off its seaside launch pad. It's a beautiful day to have hubble Space Telescope in orbit instead of here on Earth like it's be for so many years, say NASA administrator Richard Truly. Hubble's in its element and I'm delighted. The telescope be suppose to be launch in 1983, but technical problems and the Challenger accident delay its deployment. It suffer a further delay two weeks ago when the countdown be stop at the four-minutes-to-go point because of a faulty hydraulic unit on the shuttle. While it remain on Earth, the telescope cost $7 million a month to exercise and keep in readiness. In its first day in space, that checkout and test continue remotely under control of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. On hand to watch the Discovery launching be a contingent of scientists who have hail the Hubble as the great advance in astronomy since Galileo raise a small telescope to his eyes nearly 400 years ago. truly refer to the early-day astronomer when he be ask about the long delays in get the telescope to its work station. Somebody the other day said, `who remembers the day that Galileo pick up his telescope to look at the stars?' say Truly, a former shuttle astronaut. It doesn't matter what day we launch Hubble, it matter that we do it right. The telescope be 43 feet long and 14 feet in diameter, about the size of a railroad tank car. When it fly free, it will receive electrical power for its six scientific instruments from two wing-like solar arrays that extend outward on each side. It be name after the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who theorize that the universe be expand and that the farther away a galaxy is, the faster it be traveling. That give support to the theory that a massive explosion the Big Bang create the universe 10 to 20 billion years ago. The Hubble be expect to help provide the answer to two major questions: How old be the universe? How big be it? The telescope have two mirrors, one 94.5 inches in diameter, the other 12 inches. Two of the instruments be cameras, two be spectrometers and one be a photometer. In addition, the fine pointing system act as a sixth instrument by provide precise measurement of distances. On Wednesday, Hawley be to grapple the 12{-ton telescope with the shuttle's mechanical arm, lift it out of the cargo bay, point it, and after a long checkout drop it overboard to orbit on its own. In the cargo bay, the telescope receive electrical power from the shuttle. But the juice be cut when the instrument be lift out and it will depend on internal batteries until the solar panels be extend to receive light from the sun. Should the solar panels not deploy, mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan will be stand by, partially dress in space suits, ready to go into the open cargo bay to unfurl the arrays manually. Discovery's launch be not without its problems. With 31 seconds leave in the countdown, the computer that run the final moments before liftoff refuse to close a fuel valve and stop the launch process. The problem be overcome and the shuttle lift off at 8:34 a.m. EDT, about three minutes late. The shuttle be schedule to land Sunday at 9:49 a.m. EDT at Edwards Air Force Base in California. On the way uphill, as Commander Loren J. Shriver put it, the shuttle's windshield be splatter with several flecks of things. He say the windshield be streak by the debris and that it also be smear when the spent booster rockets fell off during the climb to orbit. The astronauts also have problems with their UHF radio circuit, and one of the ship's small rear thrusters be inoperative. Neither problem be consider serious. The shuttle that put the hubble Space Telescope into orbit also carry an instrument use in the 1920s by astronomer Edwin Hubble: the eyepiece from what once be the world's most powerful telescope. It's a great pleasure to have something of such historical significance and something that so directly symbolize Edwin Hubble's fundamental contributions to astronomy, astronaut Kathy Sullivan say Friday as she circle the Earth in space shuttle Discovery. The eyepiece from the Mount Wilson Observatory's 100-inch Hooker Telescope be carry into orbit by Sullivan. After she bring the eyepiece back to Earth, it will be place on display at the observatory. It's basically a symbolic gesture from the past of astronomy to the future of astronomy, say Lyn McAfee, spokeswoman for the Mount Wilson Institute. The pasadena-based group run the observatory, locate in the San Gabriel Mountains outside Los Angeles. The discoveries make by Hubble on the 100-inch telescope at Mount Wilson give us a giant leap forward in our understanding of the universe, McAfee said. We believe the hubble Space Telescope will do the same thing. The Hooker Telescope be the world's most powerful telescope from its construction in 1918 until 1948, when the 200-inch Hale Telescope be place in operation at Mount Palomar Observatory northeast of San Diego. use the Hooker Telescope, Hubble be the first to determine the distance to a galaxy outside the Milky Way, the institute say in a statement. This crucial discovery provide the first definite proof that other galaxies exist far beyond the confines of our own local galaxy, the institute said. During the 1920s and 1930s, Hubble and an assistant use the Hooker telescope to take thousands of photograph of faint galaxies, show that most of them be move away from each other very quickly. This provide observational evidence for the concept, suggest by Einstein's Theory of Relativity, that the universe be expanding, the institute said. Hubble's work help convince scientists the universe be create in a giant explosion, call the big bang, an estimate 15 billion years ago. The Hooker Telescope be mothball in 1985 by the Carnegie Institution, former operator of the observatory, in a money-saving move. The institute hop to obtain funds to reopen it.
column5: The shuttle Discovery triumphantly launches the Hubble Space Telescope.
column6: Two weeks after an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery roared from Cape Canaveral into orbit 380 statute miles above earth.  There it successfully released the $1.5 billion dollar Hubble Space Telescope from its cargo bay.  Now in the process of overcoming some start-up problems, the telescope should soon be operational.
column7: The shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth, it will provide astronomers worldwide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery was delayed because a solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled.  Once released, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  However, scientists, optimistic that the Hubble will soon be operational, authorized the shuttle Discovery crew to return home.
column8: Following an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  Named after the American astronomer Edwin Hubble who did pioneering work leading to the "Big Bang" concept of the universe, it is NASA's most expensive spacecraft.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth during its expected 15-year working lifetime, it will provide astronomers world-wide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  Free of Earth's distorting atmosphere, it may be able to look back almost to the beginning of time.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery came two hours and one orbit later than planned.  A troublesome solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled, causing the delay.  Two Mission Specialists astronauts were standing-by to unfurl the panel manually if necessary.  Then more start-up problems, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  A weaker back-up antenna system is working.  The telescope was placed on special flight modes until these start-up problems are resolved.  Confident that the Hubble will soon be operational, the shuttle Discovery is preparing to return home.
column9: Discovery carries $1.5 billion Hubble Telescope to space April 24, 1990
column10: On April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space, then followed briefly to assist if necessary. In orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere for 15 years, Hubble would see 10 times better than Earth telescopes. Hubble's launch had been delayed since 1983. Hubble cost $1.5 billion.
column11: On April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the 12.5-ton Hubble SpaceTelescope 380 miles into space. Orbiting above Earth's distortingatmosphere, Hubble would see 10 times better than the largest Earthtelescopes. Technical problems exacerbated by conservative systemsettings put Hubble several days behind schedule. Discovery's fiveastronauts were all veterans of previous flights. Discovery followedHubble for two days to assist if necessary. Spacelab Astro was to beput up two weeks later to give additional target information. Hubblecost $1.5 billion, with millions more projected for support over its15-year lifetime. Discovery carried a telescope eyepiece used by EdwinHubble, for whom the Hubble is named.
column12: On Tuesday, April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the 12.5-ton Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space. Once in orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere, Hubble would be able to see 10 times better than the largest Earth telescopes. Wednesday it was lifted into space by Discovery's mechanical arm and released into orbit. Friday the 94.5-inch mirror was exposed to starlight. Saturday controllers took Hubble out of safe mode. Problems with a solar power array, communications antennas, and two position-stabilizing gyroscopes -- exacerbated by conservative limits set on systems -- put Hubble several days behind schedule and delayed transmittal of the first photograph. Discovery's astronauts -- Shriver, Bolden, Hawley, McCandless, and Sullivan - - were all veterans of previous flights. The shuttle followed Hubble for two days to assist if necessary. A seven-month checkout period would follow. Spacelab Astro was to be put up two weeks later to give Hubble additional target information. Hubble, delayed since 1983, cost $1.5 billion. Spare parts, training, and software cost $500 million more. Maintenance cost $7 million a month on Earth and will cost $200 million yearly in orbit, for Hubble's 15-year lifetime.  Discovery carried the Hooker Telescope eyepiece used by astronomer Edwin Hubble, for whom the Hubble is named.

column3: INDIA suffer a fresh wave of terror last night when an explosion destroy two blocks of flats in the centre of the city of Calcutta, kill at least 45 people and injure scores of others. Police say a bomb explode in the crowded trade and residential district of Bowbazaar shortly after midnight, cause two blocks of flats to collapse and trap up to 70 people in the rubble. The identity of the bombers be unknown but the explosion come just five days after over 250 people be kill and at least 1,200 injure in a series of bomb attacks aim at the heart of the indian business capital of Bombay. A militant Sikh group fight for independence for the indian state of Punjab have claim responsibility for the Bombay blasts, but police be unconvinced, say they be carry out by a foreign group in connivance with 'local criminals'. In what many interpret as a reference to Pakistan, with whom India have fight three wars, last week Mr Shankarrao Chavan, the federal home (interior) minister, tell parliament in New Delhi that he suspect 'an international conspiracy.' most of the estimated 125 people live in the Calcutta flats be in their beds when the blast occurred, set fire to both buildings, accord to officials in the city's central control room. At least 45 people be dead on arrival at hospital, they said. last Friday a series of car bombs explode in Bombay in what the government describe as a systematic attack on India's commercial heart. Among the targets be the Bombay Stock Exchange, the landmark Air India building, a shopping complex, and two hotels near the airport. The attacks in Calcutta and Bombay be a severe setback to attempt to heal the wounds create by recent intercommunal violence, which have cause deep shock throughout India. more than 2,000 people die in riots, include over 700 in Bombay, after the razing of a mosque at Ayodhya in northern India by Hindu zealots on December 6. Some fear the wave of bomb attacks be design to stir a renewal of communal strife and undermine efforts by the government of Mr P V Narasimha Rao to open up the economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. last night national and local state leaders appeal for calm in an attempt to prevent a renew outbreak of violence. Mr Rao urge the nation to ignore rumours after the 'inhuman and criminal blast'. A ROW have erupt between the Bombay stock exchange, India's large stock market, and the Securities and Exchange Board of India, the securities watchdog, over the board's recent first-ever inspection of stockbrokers' books. The Sebi have accuse stockbrokers of flout the exchange's rules, include regulations on margin trading design to limit the risk of members default through excessive speculative investments. It have also accuse the exchange authorities of fail to enforce rules and of poor administration. The stock exchange deny the allegations, say they be 'baseless, make out of context and blow out of proportion.' The argument will do nothing to restore investors' faith in the stock market where, as measure by the Bombay stock exchange's 30-share index, shares have fall 48 per cent from their peak early last year, include a 320 points fall since the government's budget be announce two weeks ago. yesterday the index close at 2330. Foreign investors, who be be woo by India as a source of much-needed capital, will also be concern at the late allegations of poor management at the exchange. In one of its most damaging passages, the inspectors' report allege that D S Prabhoodas, a leading firm head by Mr Hemendra Kothari, a former BSE president, and by Mr Jaswant Chotalal, a member of the BSE's govern body, avoid margin payments total Rs185.4m (pounds 4.08m). Mr Kothari say yesterday that most of the transactions cover by the report be off-exchange deals directly between financial institutions for which margin payments be not required. Mr M R Mayya, the BSE's executive director, say BSE rules permit such bilateral off-exchange transactions. Sebi also accuse the exchange of mismanage the administration of its building. This week's argument be only the late in a series of disputes which begin almost as soon as Sebi start operations a year ago. It be establish by Mr Manmohan Singh, the finance minister, as a crucial element in financial reform. Brokers claim the Sebi be heavy-handed and fail to understand their needs. They say rules must be apply flexibly and many firms be extremely small and unable to carry the cost of extra regulations. But the finance minister be back Sebi to the hilt and single it out for praise in his recent budget speech. Finance ministry officials believe loose regulations allow brokers and others to dodge taxes and also contribute to last year's securities market scandal in which banks, include the UK's Standard Chartered Bank, lose a combine gross total of Rs40bn. The 29-storey Jijobhoy Towers, home of the Bombay Stock Exchange, be rock by two powerful bombs last Friday, leave 60 dead and 200 injured. The market reopen on Monday in an attempt to return to normal. It have have to compromise - trading have be restrict to an hour a day, and dealing have move back to the traditional ring, where it stop a year ago. Dealers seem to like this, the BSE index rise by 5.6 per cent on Monday and Tuesday. But another bomb blast in Calcutta trigger nervous sell yesterday, and the index come back by 50.62, or 2.1 per cent, to 2,409.23. All this have take place against a volatile background: the Bombay equity market, over the past six weeks or so, have have to contend first with unusually bullish speculation, before the national budget on February 27, and subsequently with some savage expressions of disappointment. Dr Manmohan Singh, the indian finance minister, disappoint traders in the budget at the end of last month. He postpone corporate tax reforms by a year, deny hopes of a tax cut recommend by an expert group. He do reduce excise and import duties on a broad front, but leave out the cement and steel sectors, where share prices have be boost by pre-budget speculation. To top it all, Dr Singh refuse to equate domestic investors with their overseas counterparts in tax short-term capital gains. He lower the tax to 30 per cent from 65 per cent for expatriate Indians and foreign investors but for local investors it remain at 44.5 per cent. take the tax concessions for granted, traders have drive up share prices in February to make a kill later. Instead, the budget turn out to be a nightmare. While industry and business welcome the statement which, for once, do not propose any new tax, Professor Rusi Taraporewala, the stock market theorist and academic, say a reduction in import duties would leave corporate profits ex-growth this year. The relative lack of financial concessions mean that disappointed traders sell with a vengeance and, until the weekend, the market seem bottomless as equity prices plummet to a 13-month low. Overseas investors fuel the downtrend as they sell some half a million shares of Reliance Industries, arbitrage between the share price on the Bombay stock exchange and the market price of its Euro-issue of global depository receipts (gdrs). The opportunity arise after a change in indian regulations which allow international investors to convert GDRs into the underlying stock. At the current conversion rate of Rs31 per US dollar, the Reliance GDR fetch Rs170 per share against the BSE quotation of Rs210. The BSE 30-share index plunge by more than one-fifth to 2,287 on March 10, from 2,893 at the post-budget trading session on February 27. Share prices rebound last week, take the index to 2,361 and the uptrend, on balance, have continue this week in spite of the bomb blast on Friday. Whether or not the surge will turn into a strong rally will depend on the ability of bulls to maintain their momentum. They be hop that foreign portfolio investment will pick up with the restoration of trading after 'Black Friday', and the successful sale of Reliance stock on the BSE by international investors. The indian stock markets have be pass through a series of crises since December, when activists of the Bhartiya Janta party pull down the Babri mosque at Ayodhya, spark off communal riots. Mr Mark Bulloch of Jardine Fleming take the domestic political situation in his stride. 'nothing dramatic have happen as far as foreign investors be concerned,' he says. 'They be appraise the political situation.' In the meantime, there be no compulsion for local investors to sell. In this, they be more fortunate than they be in previous years, when they be under pressure to take advantage of a long-term capital gains tax exemption before the financial year end in March. The exemption have be replace by a flat 20 per cent tax this year which, accord to dealers, puts bulls and bears on an even footing. THE INDIAN government fly federal paramilitary troops into Bombay last night after more than a dozen bomb explode in the city, kill about 200 people and injure more than a thousand. The devices, mostly car bombs, appear to be a systematic attack on India's commercial heart. All explode within 90 minutes in the afternoon. Among the targets be the Bombay Stock Exchange, the landmark Air India building, a shopping complex, and two hotels near the airport. The identity of the bombers be unknown, but the attacks be a severe setback to India's attempts to heal the wounds create by recent intercommunal violence, which have cause deep shock throughout India. more than 2,000 people die in riots, include over 700 in Bombay, after the razing of a mosque at Ayodhya in northern India by Hindu zealots on December 6. The bomb appear design to stir a renewal of communal strife and to undermine efforts by the government of Mr PV Narasimha Rao to open up the economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. One of the targets be close to the headquarters of Shiv Sena, a Hindu nationalist party accuse of foment violence during the riots, in which most victims be Moslems. National and local state leaders appeal for calm in an attempt to prevent a renew outbreak of violence. Mr Rao urge the nation to ignore rumours after the 'inhuman and criminal bomb blasts'. Mr Sharad Pawar, the former federal defence minister just re-appointed chief minister of Maharashtra state, say all roads into Bombay have be block and the army put on alert. He said: 'It be aim at disrupt the economy and it appear a conscious effort because only Bombay seem to be the target.' Mr Shankarrao Chavan, the federal home (interior) minister, tell parliament in New Delhi: 'We suspect an international conspiracy.' The indian High Commission in London say the attacks be 'part of the externally support terrorism which have target India for some time'. However, Indian officials stop short of directly accuse Pakistan, the country's arch-enemy. The bomb attacks be spread throughout the city and be clearly aim at the city's better-off business people - in contrast to the riots in which victims be mainly poor. At the 28-storey stock exchange building, about 3,000 people be on the second-storey trading floor when a bomb explode in the underground car park, hurl shards of glass across the floor and into the street. Some victims be crush in the stampede to escape. Outside, burned bodies lay among litter from shatter buildings. MR TEG BAHADUR Thapar be serve lunch from his stall outside the Bombay stock exchange on Friday when he be shower with fly glass and broken concrete in one of 13 explosions which rock the city and leave at least 255 people kill and over 1,200 injured. 'I'm lucky to be alive,' he say from his hospital bed. 'Who do this? Who can stop this happen again?' Across Bombay people be ask themselves the same questions this weekend. They sense there be an enormous difference from the riots which scar the city in December and again in January. Those be cause by a traditional mix of crime, political agitation and ancient Hindu-Moslem hatreds stir by the destruction of the mosque in Ayodhya. The weapons use be mostly primitive - knives, clubs and petrol bottles. Friday's outrage, by contrast, bears the deadly stamp of high-technology terrorism, complete with Semtex plastic explosive, high-grade timers, efficient organisation and money. The only comparable previous incident be the assassination in 1991 of Mr Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister, by Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger terrorists. But that be a single bomb aim at one man - the explosions in Bombay be design to terrorise the nation's commercial capital. Bombay accounts for 35 per cent of India's exports. Mr P V Narasimha Rao, the prime minister, describe the blasts as an attack on India's economy. The immediate assumption both at the high level and in the streets of Bombay be that those responsible must have be foreigners or have foreign help. But these suggestions be see in Bombay as a deliberate attempt to deflect attention from the people who in the popular mind be the real suspect - Moslem extremists who might have take revenge for the riots which hit India after the Ayodhya mosque's destruction and which leave 2,000 dead, include 700 in Bombay. If Moslems be find to have stag the attacks, the indian authorities will certainly suspect that the operation be support from a Moslem country, notably Pakistan. The implications would be vast. Breaking diplomatic relations would be the minimum step Delhi could take on a dangerous road. Mr Rao choose his words carefully during his visit to Bombay: 'There be a definite possibility that our search may not stop within the country. I do not want to name anybody because it will have ramifications within and outside the country.' There be no evidence link the attacks to Moslem extremists, let alone to Pakistan. even if Moslem groups be find to be responsible for the bombings, they could have be supply from other Moslem countries. India would still face a diplomatic crisis but hardly on the same scale. For the moment, such concerns seem remote from the streets on Bombay, where the atmosphere yesterday be calm. Workmen be clear away rubble at the blast sites, include the blacken stock exchange building. Bombayites seem determine to put the outrage behind them. At the Gymkhana Club and dozens of other sports grounds, hundreds of men and boys be play cricket as they do every sunday. Others be walk along the seafront by the arch of the Gateway of India. The stock exchange authorities plan to re-start trading as soon as they can -probably today - use an old trading floor the exchange vacate only last year. Businessmen estimate the main loss to the city would be the loss of life and injuries and the damage cause to blast buildings. They do not expect the same widespread disruption to production as occurred during the riots. Some of the credit for the limited disruption should go the government and the police for promptly call paramilitary and regular troops to help patrol sensitive districts. But much more should go to the people of Bombay, who, so far at least, have refuse to be goad into violent protest by the bombers.
column5: Trials and Tribulation of the Bombay Stock Exchange
column6: In March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange survived a wave of selling, governmental criticism, a bomb attack that killed at least 255 people, another bombing in Calcutta killing 45, and the looming threat of war and rioting to reverse the downward trend and head upward again.
column7: In early March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) reacted to a postponement of tax reform. By March 10 the BSE index sunk to a 13-month low at 2,287. On March 12 a coordinated bomb attack against targets in Bombay including the BSE killed at least 255 people and injured 1,200 threatening a resumption of Hindu-Moslem rioting which had occurred earlier. The BSE reopened on March 15, but on March 16 an explosion in Calcutta killed at least 45. Despite the tragedies and threat of war or rioting, the BSE index had climbed up as far as 2,409.23 by March 17.
column8: In March of 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) experienced a series of shocks, but emerged on the upbeat. The first blow was reaction to a report from the Indian finance minister on February 27 postponing corporate tax reform. Disappointed with the postponement, traders sold with a vengeance driving equity prices to a 13-month low with the BSE index down to 2,287 on March 10 compared to 2,893 on February 27. Then the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) accused the BSE of violating regulations limiting speculative investments. On the night of March 12 the BSE was damaged as thirteen bombs exploded in Bombay killing at least 255 people, injuring over 1,200 and threatening resumption of intercommunal riots between Hindus and Moslems. Despite structural damage, the BSE reopened on March 15. On March 16 an explosion in a residential district of Calcutta killed at least 45. A Sikh group claimed responsibility but official Indian comments implied that Pakistan was the main suspect. With the looming threat of riots and war, the BSE index rose by 2.1 per cent on March 15 and even after the Calcutta bombing settled at 2,409.23 on March 17, a marked improvement over the March 10 reading.
column9: Bombay Stock Exchange fights for equilibrium through bombs and investigations.
column10: The Bombay Stock Exchange has suffered a week of onslaught but remains open.  With the market already down 48 percent in not much more than a year, the exchange was accused of violating rules.  India's commercial heart, including the exchange, was bombed on Friday and more explosions hit Calcutta on Wednesday.
column11: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  First the Securities and Exchange Board of India accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget.  On Friday afternoon, India's commercial heart, including the BSE, was hit with car bombs.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists seeking a return of communal strife.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading, but a slight rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday in Calcutta.
column12: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  Last week, the Securities and Exchange Board of India completed its first inspection of the books and accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  This is just the latest dispute between the government and the troubled BSE.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget, which helped foreign and expatriate investors, but did not provide the expected tax relief to local industry.  On Friday afternoon, the BSE, along with other Bombay commercial centers, was hit with car bombs.  These attacks struck at the heart of India's commerce, seemingly aimed at undermining government efforts to expand foreign investment and tourism.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists, maybe with Pakistani help, seeking revenge for the December 1992 destruction of a mosque in northern India.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading on Monday and the index rose for two days.  This rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday, which killed 45 and injured a score in a central Calcutta apartment complex.  Fears abound that communal strife will return.

column3: THE revelation that John Major be capable of candid, blunt and salty language when talk off-the- record to friendly journalists have surprise some people. It have even be suggest that the recording of the prime minister's conversation with Michael Brunson, ITN's political editor, in which Major use a variety of four-, six- and eight-letter words to communicate his lack of fondness for certain colleagues, may do him good. With luck, it be reckoned, Major's image as a leaden-tongued wimp may undergo correction. What piffle. Major be a gonner, especially after this week's revolt of the wooden-tops in the Christchurch by-election, where a conservative majority of 23,015 at last year's general election be convert into a 16,427 majority for the Liberal Democrats. Fifteen months too late, the voters of Christchurch round on the Tories with a malignant and squeaky fury. In reality, all politicians, not just Major, be far more candid and salty when chat in private than when speak in public. In public, they have to be careful of what they say, so their utterances achieve a horrible mattness. But in private they relax. Their syntax disappears. Their words become nonsensical. They swear and joke and shout. It really be a spectacle. To show you what I mean, I speak yesterday to John Major and John Smith. Smith, a Scot, be leader of the Labour Party, though not many people know that. In the aftermath of Christchurch, where Labour lose its deposit, I want to provoke the two Johns into a spot of real soul-searching. To guarantee them privacy, I use a signal-scrambler. No one could have eavesdropped. Their responses be true to form. But I have leave out the swear-words because the new Financial Times Style Guide state that 'the gratuitous use of expletives or obscenities be discourage . . . four-letter expletives will usually be confine to infrequent use in the review (Arts) pages.' I can live with that, though why the artsy-fartsies should receive any dispensation be a puzzle. First, I tackle Major. I said: 'Did you read, john, what Olivier Blanchard, Rudiger Dornbusch, Stanley Fischer, Franco Modigliani, Paul A Samuelson and Robert Solow wrote, in just one article, in the FT this week? They be describe Europe's lunatic monetary policies and exchange rate arrangements. They do not pull their punches. I bet you go chalk-white. 'So why not walk the plank, John? You be the most unpopular prime minister since the start of the fourth century. Why invite more punishment? Unfairly or not, you be draw the blame for all life's unpleasantnesses, let alone the cock-ups.' 'are you sure?' the prime minister replied. 'I mean . . . how do it come about, Michael . . . like, Christchurch, y'know - load of . . . let me put it to you - the economy, of course . . . I mean, wimpy guy like me. But I'm not give in like that, like . . .' On and on it went. then I ring John Smith. I tell him I have be impress with his interview with Andrew Marr in The Independent on Thursday, in which he sharpen up his promise to introduce meaty political reforms (if he ever get elected), include a referendum on proportional representation. I said: 'You be start to raise your game, John. Many people will have agree with your assertion that democracy in Britain be decaying, and that the Tories must be roast for their arrogance, incompetence, complacency and sharp practices - especially their 'centralisation of power and the elimination of opposition'. But some of your critics still accuse you, John, of laziness and ineffectualness. What do you say to that?' 'Away, ye thowless jad,' shout the Labour leader. 'Gie me o'wit an' sense a life, behint a kist to lie an' sklent. Our Stibble-rig be Rab M'Graen, a clever, sturdy fellow, but then he be sae fley'd by his showther gae a keek, an' tumbl'd wi' a wintle. likewise with political and constitutional reform, Michael, for by the L - - d, tho' I should beg wi'lyart pow, I'll laugh, an' sing, an' shake my leg, as lang's I dow]' After that, I think of telephone Wing-Commander Paddy Ashdown, leader of the Liberal Democrats, to solicit his views on Christchurch. But I couldn't raise the energy. last year a biography of Mrs Norma Major - or, if we be be old-fashioned, Mrs John Major - claim that the Majors' favourite film be be There. I entirely concur with their choice. In case you do not see that marvellous film, this, in essence, be the plot: a man no one know anything about, a gardener call Chauncey, rise without trace to become, by the end of the film, a serious candidate for the US presidency. Chauncey, play by Peter Sellers, utter only mundane sentiments in a halting monotone but this convince the Republican party's power brokers that he be a sure-fire winner. In Chauncey's bromides everyone seem to hear what they want to believe. He have a deadly innocence. No wonder the Majors like this film. John Major must, at some level, have appreciate the similarity between his own, strangely intangible, rise and that of Chauncey's. If he do not see the similarity, that be still more revealing. do not protest that the urban John Major could not identify with a gardener. In an interview with Farmers Weekly, a few days ago, Major disclose an unknown fact: his father be once a farmer. Farmers Weekly, you see, have ask Major how he have 'such obvious empathy with agriculture'. (well, it be obvious to Farmers Weekly, anyway.) And Major replied: 'It's simple. My father be a farmer. He live on a small farm somewhere in Shropshire.' Francis Wheen of The Guardian, a keen student of Major's mysterious past, immediately ring 10 Downing Street, which claim that Major's father farm near Bromsgrove in 1910. As Wheen point out, Major be an unresponsive minus 33 years old at that time, and - a minor point this - Bromsgrove be not in Shropshire. This, of course, do not mean that Major make everything up. Family folklore be a peculiar thing. yet when I hear about this, my mind immediately go back to an incident a few months ago, when Major visit Pittsburgh, centre of the US steel industry, as part of his american tour. I recall that he make a great hit by recount that his father have be a steelworker in the city. A farmer for Farmers Weekly, a Pittsburgh steelworker for the american audience . . . a pattern emerges. Major's father, and therefore by extension John Major himself, can be all things to all people. If John Major be a different sort of politician, this would be a point barely worth making. But it do seem all of a piece with Major's approach to wider political issues. On the one hand he will appeal to the pro-Europeans in his own party by claim to want Britain to be at the heart of Europe. On the other he be free with insulting references to the European Commission, whenever it be necessary to appeal to an audience of Euro-sceptics. There be those who will argue that this merely mean that Major be a typical democratic politician, that one who want to become prime minister in a democracy must recognise many constituencies of interest, not just one. But that have not be true of Major's most recent conservative predecessors. Margaret Thatcher be notoriously dogmatic, even in public, and so too be Edward Heath, even though he always pretend to be a 'consensus politician'. No, Major's technique be very much his own invention, very much a reflection of his own particular character, itself a product of his unsettled family background. His father, Tom Major-Ball, be an itinerant figure, move from place to place, try his hand at any number of occupations, include the circus. No wonder the young John Major learn the skill of fit in with prevailing circumstances, no matter how fluctuating. The only problem be the old one: you cannot fool all of the people all of the time. Except in the movies. Dominic Lawson be editor of The Spectator ONE year ago tomorrow, Mr John Major surprise everyone but himself by win the general election. His honeymoon, after a very personal victory, be short-lived and now he begin the second year of his hard-won term as a deeply unpopular leader who have everything still to prove. The past 12 months have be hijack by internal party differences over Europe, by the debacle surround UK withdrawal from the exchange rates mechanism of the European Monetary System, and by a continuing, deep recession which have disappoint and alienate many traditional Tory supporters in business. Mr Major's anniversary inevitably lead yesterday to an outbreak of political point-scoring over the government's record. While Mr Tony Newton, leader of the Commons, conceded: 'No one pretend that the last year have be easy,' he also claim that much have be achieved. The government's efforts to secure a framework for long-term prosperity be begin to pay off. Mr John Smith, the Labour leader, be join by 10 frontbench colleagues in launch a counter-attack, involve a detailed and documented indictment of Mr Major's failures. He attack the Tories for build 'a bonfire of pre-election commitments'. Tory allegiances in the business world have also be put under immense pressure, though criticism over policy drift and inaction may soften as recession ends. yesterday Sir Michael Angus, president of the Confederation of British Industry, remain cautious but volunteered: 'If I be a bet man I would say we have the embryo of a recovery.' Mr Major can take little comfort from the conclusion, widespread among industrialists, that his great achievement in the past year have be Britain's withdrawal from the ERM - something which he resist and over which, in the end, he have no control. most industrialists, however, find it hard to criticise Mr Major as an individual, with many draw a flatter parallel between his personal qualities and those of his predecessor. He still attract gratitude for the election victory, which be see - despite subsequent problems for the economy - as the best result for business. But, unlike the previous No 10 occupant, he be see as a weak leader, with little vision and bereft of a clearly articulated political conviction. There be a general perception that, important though Britain's future place in Europe is, the prime minister have be excessively preoccupy with community affairs and associate internal party ructions, to the detriment of the domestic economy. many industrialists be pleased that Mr Major be now attempt to reshape economic strategy in favour of the manufacturing base. But the jury be out on whether the rhetoric will give way to effective action. ----------------------------------------------------------------------- The first 12 months - election victory to an initial Maastricht defeat ----------------------------------------------------------------------- APRIL Wins election with 21 seat majority 'The country look a labour government in the eye and decide that it be not after all Time for a Change' - Peter Jenkins, the late political commentator 'We have win tonight a magnificent victory, a victory many people think beyond our grasp' - major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MAY Best Conservative local election results for 13 years in England and Wales. Tories win control of 126 councils ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JUNE Rio Summit No new british aid to finance the conference decisions, only a proposal for a 'darwin initiative' to exchange information on endanger species. 'I come here with low expectations and all of those have be met' - Jonathon Porritt, the environmental campaigner 'I believe that both in the short and long term, people will look back and say that at Rio we take a decisive step' - major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JULY Britain take over EC presidency 'Those whom the gods would destroy they first grant the presidency of the European Council of Ministers' - Mark Almond, Fellow of the Institute for european Defence and Strategic Studies ----------------------------------------------------------------------- AUGUST Two-day Yugoslav peace conference of 30 nations be present as triumph of international diplomacy for John Major and UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali 'Talks, what talks?' - serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic as he storm out while Major be speak ----------------------------------------------------------------------- SEPTEMBER Black Wednesday Bank of England interest rates rise to 15 per cent before government take sterling out of the EMS. 'The sky be darken with the wings of chickens come home to roost' - Lord Callaghan 'There be go to be no devaluation, no realignment, the deflationary option would be a betrayal of our future and it be not government policy' - major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- OCTOBER Mining closure U-turn Michael Heseltine announce review of 21 of 31 pits under threat 'i'm just get use to be more popular than John Major' - Arthur Scargill 'What have happen be a development of what be in the government's mind. We have to listen to what people say' - major ----------------------------------------------------------------------- NOVEMBER Matrix Churchill inquiry John Major challenge over claims he have 'specific' and 'personal' knowledge that Matrix Churchill export machine tools to Iraq for munitions manufacture. 'either ministers do not know what be go on in their own departments, or they be not prepare to tell' - Allan Rogers, Labour's former defence procurement spokesman ----------------------------------------------------------------------- DECEMBER Edinburgh conference Concessions grant to Danes in hope voters will approve Maastricht at second referendum. Agreement on EC spending levels, Maastricht back on track for ratification ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JANUARY Major launches libel action against New Statesman & Society and Scallywag over allegations link him with businesswoman Claire Latimer. 'It be not our intention to slur the prime minister' - Steve Platt, editor of New Statesman ----------------------------------------------------------------------- FEBRUARY Unemployment top 3m 'provided the circumstances be right there be no reason why we shouldn't bounce back this time' - gillian Shephard, secretary of state for employment ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MARCH Maastricht debate more than 40 Tory MPs revolt in first Commons defeat on Maastricht treaty legislation, defy Major's appeal for party unity 'When they start out they weren't even household names in their own homes' - David Mellor on Tory Euro-rebels ----------------------------------------------------------------------- John Major, endorse by Margaret Thatcher as the politician closest to her heart, be elect by the Conservative Party Tuesday night to succeed her as prime minister. Major, 47, fell two votes short of win a majority in voting among the 372 Coservative Party members of Parliament, but his two opponents quickly concede defeat and the party confirm Major as the winner. Mrs. Thatcher, end 11{ years in power, intend to submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday morning, and Major would then be call to lead the government. Major, the chancellor of the exchequer, emerge from his official residence at 11 down St. Tuesday night smile and hold hands with his wife, Norma. Inside, Mrs. Thatcher, who come next door from the prime minister's 10 Downing Street residence, embrace Major. I be thrilled and delight that John Major be to succeed me, the Iron Lady say in a statement release by aides. It be a very exciting thing to become leader of the Conservative Party, and particularly exciting, I think, to follow one of the most remarkable leaders the Conservative Party have ever had, Major said. Our job now I think be quite clear. We be go to unite totally and absolutely, and we're go to win the next general election, say Major, who will be the young british prime minister in this century. Major receive 185 votes, two short of a majority. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine receive 131 and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd have 56. Hurd and Heseltine concede within minutes, and party officials declare Major elected. The party have be tear by the sudden and unexpected leadership challenge by Heseltine, who last week stop Mrs. Thatcher short of victory in the first round of the leadership race. Mrs. Thatcher have not want to leave office, but she decide to resign last week after she be unable to put down Heseltine's challenge. She say she resign to let someone from the Cabinet stand against Heseltine. Major and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd both join the race, but before the vote her aides spread the word that she be back Major. The son of a circus performer and at one time a welfare recipient, Major personify the values of self-reliance and hard work that Mrs. Thatcher have preach to the nation. His election climax a month of british politics-turned-upside down, and the western world's longest-serving head of government be drive from office by a revolt in party ranks. head a government that be trail the opposition Labor Party in the polls and suffer a losing streak in local Parliamentary elections, Mrs. Thatcher lose control of events after her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resign on Nov. 1. Howe, the fourth Cabinet member to resign because of disputes over policy toward the European Community, shock the House of Commons on Nov. 13 by call Mrs. Thatcher a threat to Britain's vital interests. The next day, Heseltine announce he would challenge her. Six days later, with Mrs. Thatcher at a 34-nation summit in Paris officially end the Cold War, Heseltine poll enough votes to deny her re-election as leader. Two days later, she decide to resign after party leaders tell her she could not win. Heseltine, 57, say Major's election lay the basis for the unity of our party. Hurd say the party need to unite, and John Major be the right leader for this task. opposition leaders deride Major's election as Thatcherism with a different face. The Conservatives' main rivals, the socialist Labor Party, demand a general election. John Major be a Thatcherette - that be how he seek election and that be how he get elected, say Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. It mean that the policies that bring the poll tax, recession, heavy mortgages and rise unemployment will go on. During his five-day campaign, Major have aaid he would review the poll tax, an unpopular local tax bring in by Mrs. Thatcher, but he give no other hints of differ with her. While adopt a gentler tone on the contentious issue of Britain's involvement in Europe, he shares her opposition to a single european currency and shares her belief in tight restraint on government spending. However, he insist over the weekend, I be not run as `son of Thatcher.' I be run as myself, with my own priorities and my own programs. Major's victory end a patient, four-year campaign by Heseltine to promote himself as a future leader of the party. Tomorrow always dawns, he said, smile after concede defeat. Major be elect to Parliament in 1979, be appoint foreign secretary and then chancellor of the exchequer last year. He move up quickly in the leadership race. By the weekend, opinion polls show that Major be nearly as highly regard by the public as be Heseltine, who have be prominent for a decade. Major attract support from figures on the right wing of the Conservative Party, although his friends insist Major's own views be more liberal than many supposed. He describe himself as conservative on economic issues but liberal on social issues.
column5: Major Defeat; Prime Minister Leads Tories to Third Party Status
column6: The Tories will make Prime Minister John Major, protege of Margaret Thatcher, the scapegoat for their stunning defeat in local elections across Britain in May. Though he won the 1992 general election, the high-school dropout is now accused of being a weak leader, incompetent on both domestic and international issues.
column7: On Easter Sunday, three Cabinet ministers issued statements on behalf of  Prime Minister John Major amidst speculation that he could be forced out this autumn. In May local elections across Britain, however, the Conservatives loss 444 seats, and word circulated that Major was not up to the job.Major became leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister after his mentor, Margaret Thatcher resigned under pressure in 1990. Though he won the 1992 general election, the lingering recession and controversies involving European community issues splintered the Tories. He came to be viewed as a weak, vacillating leader, lacking political conviction.
column8: In early May elections across Britain, the Conservatives suffered their worst defeat ever, losing 444 seats. One editorial claims some Conservatives will link the defeats to Prime Minister John Major, and there is speculation that he could be forced out this autumn.A former welfare recipient, John Major was elected Conservative Party leader and successor to his mentor Margaret Thatcher when she resigned under pressure in November 1990. After Mrs. Thatcher submitted her seals of office, Major was called by Queen Elizabeth II to form a new government, and it was expected that there would be no significant policy shift. Major's comment while visiting America a month later that Iraqi troops might have to be "forcibly removed" from Kuwait echoed Mrs. Thatcher's hard-line on the Persian Gulf.Within a year of winning the general election, his popularity had plunged. In the July 1993 Christchurch by-election the Conservative majority of 23,015 the previous year was converted into a 16,427 majority for the Liberal Democrats. Though Major's personal style is preferable to that of Mrs. Thatcher, he is characterized as a vacillating, weak leader, lacking vision and political conviction. Not even recent revelations that Major uses salty language can alter his wimp image.
column9: John Major elected leader of Conservative Party, becomes next Prime Minister.
column10: John Major emerged victorious in an election for leadership of the Conservative Party and became, at 47, Britain's youngest prime minister. His popularity began to decline very soon after his election and he is viewed and weak and indecisive. Having reneged on campaign promises, he is blamed for the recession which plagues Britain.
column11: At 47, John Major became Britain's youngest prime minister. His accession to power followed the surprise resignation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher following a challenge by former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine to her leadership. Major fell two votes shy of a victory in an election with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Heseltine but both opponents quickly conceded to Major. Since his election, Major has been seen as weak and indecisive. He is an unpopular leader whose cabinet has been rocked by scandal and who reneged on campaign promises. Adding to his unpopularity is the recession which continues plague Britain.
column12: John Major was 47 when he was elected to lead the Conservative Party. Assuming the position of prime Minister from Margaret, Mr. Major became the youngest prime minister since the 19th century. Mr. Major was confirmed as leader of the Conservative Party when his two opponents, former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, conceded defeat in an election which saw Major two votes shy of a majority. Major, whose father was a trapeze artist in the circus, overcame many obstacles in his rise to the top. He was a high school drop out and for a time was a welfare recipient. Mr. Major had little time to enjoy his victory as public opinion of him soon soured. While seen as gentler than his abrasive predecessor, he is viewed as timid and indecisive. Almost from the first he has been beset by scandal in his cabinet and a number of controversies ranging from internal party differences over Europe to the debacle surrounding Britain's withdrawal from the exchange rates mechanism of the European Monetary System to a deep and continuing recession. Major came out in strong support of U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf, calling on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.

column3: japanese writer Kazuo Ishiguro win the 1989 Booker Prize, Britain's top literary award, for his novel The Remains of the Day, judges announce Thursday. The prize be worth $32,000. Judges praise the novel, a love story about a butler's english vacation, as a cunningly structure and beautifully pace performance. other finalists this year be canadian Margaret Atwood for Cat's Eye, Irish author John Banville for Book of Evidence, Scotland's James Kelman for A Disaffection and English writers Sybille Bedford for Jigsaw and Rose Tremain for Restoration. After receive the prize, Ishiguro pay tribute to Salman Rushdie, the 1988 runner-up for the award, who go into hiding in February when he be threaten with death by Moslems who say his novel The Satanic Verses blaspheme their faith. now that circumstances have changed, when perhaps it be inconvenient for many people to support his writing, I just felt it be fit that we should not turn our backs on him, Ishiguro said. Rushdie live in England. Ishiguro, 39, arrive in England at age 6 and now live in south London. He write in English.
