In announce the winner, the judges said: `the Remains of the Day' renders with humor and pathos a memorable character and explore the large, vex themes of class, tradition and duty. It be narrowly preferred but universally admired. Ishiguro be a finalist for the Booker Prize in 1986 for his novel An artist of the Floating World. The Booker Prize be sponsor by Booker, an international food and agriculture business. After hours of heat delib-eration - under a system describe as 'mad' by one judge - the Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize for fiction last night go to Mr James Kelman for How Late It Was, How Late, publish by Secker and Warburg. The novel, a story of scottish low-life narrate largely in glaswegian dialect, be unlikely to prove a popular choice with booksellers, who have damn all six books shortlist for the prize as boring, elitist and - bad of all - unsaleable. Professor John Bayley, chairman of the Booker judges, acknowledge that Mr Kelman's book in particular might be deem inaccessible. 'We have an extremely difficult final meeting and be very divided,' he say after three hours of debate. Rabbi Julia Neuberger, the only woman on the judging panel, say she be make extremely cross by the decision. 'it's just a drunken Scotsman rail against bureaucracy,' she said. 'my eyes be stretch in disbelief. The voting system be completely mad. Kelman be the least favourite of the three front runners. If it have be a short story it would have be fine.' Mr Kelman's book is, accord to some observers, the most difficult work to have win the prize. In his acceptance speech, Mr Kelman, perceive by some as a scottish isolationist, anticipate the criticism, by declaring: 'my culture and my language have the right to exist.' One guest at the prize-giving dinner at London's Guildhall, Mr Salman Rushdie, who win the prize in 1981 with Midnight's Children, remarked: 'James Kelman be good, but not as good as he think he is.' The Booker prize has, in its 26-year history, always provoke controversy. But this year's row have be of a particularly fine vintage. Prof Bayley go on record with a rouse condemnation of contemporary fiction. Another judge, Mr James Wood, literary critic of The Guardian, be attack for fail to reveal that a young novelist be consider for the award, Ms Claire Messud, be in fact Mrs James Wood. Most damaging of all be the verdict of the booksellers, who dismiss the shortlist as narcoleptic. The other contenders be The Folding Star by Alan Hollinghurst, Beside the Ocean of Time by George Mackay Brown, Paradise by Abdulrazak Gurnah, Reef by Romesh Gunesekera and Knowledge of Angels by Jill Paton Walsh. In spite of heavy publicity, the novels nominate have be sell 50 per cent less than last year's shortlist. last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha, sell 350,000 copies. 'Kelman's novel be unlikely to come anywhere near that,' one bookseller said. Mr Kelman be also shortlist for the prize in 1989 for his novel A Disaffection. It be a sensational shortlist: a bestseller about love and hypnotism, a blockbuster about battles and brides in Ruritania, and a pornographic shocker about teenage sex and baby murder so explicit that only an obscure Newcastle publisher would risk print it. Out be the eminences gris of victorian letters - novels by Thomas Hardy and Mrs Humphry Ward, who advise Gladstone and Roosevelt, didn't make the grade. This week the shortlist for the hypothetical 1894 Booker Prize will be announce by six judges, include biographer Victoria Glendinning and broadcaster Melvyn Bragg. They have avoid dull and worthy classics and choose six books which stir the fin de siecle world and remain compelling today: George du Maurier's Trilby, Anthony Hope's The Prisoner of Zenda, George Moore's Esther Waters, Kipling's Jungle Book, George Gissing's In the year of Jubilee and RL Stevenson's The Ebb Tide. The winner will be reveal on October 15 (four days after the 1994 Booker Prize ceremony) at the Cheltenham Festival of Literature. Like today's Booker Prize, it be a publishing gimmick; Everyman, which be back the spoof award, be a significant publisher of classic victorian novels. But the retrospective Booker be also a fascinating exercise in historical reconstruction. It raise questions about how the relationship between literature and society have change in the past 100 years. First, the similarities. A good yarn be a good yarn. Of the 1894 books, Trilby be the tale of a tone-deaf model who sing like an angel when mesmerise by the sinister hypnotist Svengali, then croak like a crow when he die during one of her concerts. The Prisoner of Zenda tells of an Englishman impersonate the King of Ruritania and rescue him from demons. On the 1994 list Romesh Guneskera's Reef be about a Sri Lankan servant boy and his mysterious master, while Jill Paton Walsh's Knowledge of Angels re-enacts the wolf-child legend. All the books on both lists be grip stories. The lists share key themes. Both, for instance, have books about colonial exploitation - Stevenson's The Ebb Tide and Abdulrazak Gurnah's Paradise, which be set in the First World War in German East Africa. Both provoke in similar ways. The controversial books of 1894 be Trilby, with its louche vie boheme milieu, and Esther Waters, in which a 17-year-old girl be seduced, impregnated and offer the services of a professional baby killer for a fiver. It be now see as Moore's best work, but in 1894 it have problems find a publisher and the powerful circulate libraries refuse to take it. A century on, the relationship between fiction and sexual morality remain vexed. last week, a Times critic complain about the inclusion of Alan Hollinghurst's candid novel of homosexual love, The Folding Star, on the Booker list, because it offend judaeo-christian ethics. But even if Hollinghurst win the Booker, his novel will not become the succes de scandale of Esther Waters and Trilby, which become the bestselling novel of the 19th century. For the great difference between then and now be that in 1894 a Booker Prize be not need to sell fiction. Today, we accept the gap between literary writing, such as Hollinghurst's, and popular bestsellers by writers like Jeffrey Archer and Barbara Cartland. This be the gap the Booker try to bridge by give high-level publicity to works which would not normally reach a mass audience. The trick work - last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha sell 360,000 hardback copies. Before the short-list be announce it sell 10,600. The Victorians, in contrast, be lovers of contemporary fiction. Novels account for 20 per cent of publish books, and no distinction be make between high and low art. In the mid 19th century, Dickens make Pounds 12,000 for Little Dorrit, the equivalent of nearly Pounds 400,000 today. Between 1861 and 1894, when the population of the UK be half that of today and the literate population small still, Mrs Henry Wood's East Lynne sell 400,000 copies. All the 1894 Booker writers be popular names; they be also serious, skilful writers whose books can be reread with pleasure 100 years later. Why be fiction so much closer to the public heart in 1894? Social, cultural and psychological reasons play a part. Socially, the 1890s read public be a vastly more homogenous group than today: a small number of middle class authors write for a middle class audience at a time when to be literate be to belong to an elite. The idea of a two-tier, up and down-market, fiction be irrelevant. Culturally, these writers and readers be certain of their place in the mainstream, and the novel be their political and intellectual forum. Today we no longer share the victorian confidence in the novel as a key genre of our age. Modernism and the overturning of the traditional form by Joyce and Woolf weaken 20th-century belief in the novel and encourage the divergence between highbrow and lowbrow. The dominance of film and television have make novels a more marginal form and perhaps they no longer attract the most creative talents. George du Maurier originally offer the outline of Trilby to Henry James, who he think would write a good novel. Today du Maurier would have sell it to Hollywood or the BBC. The fantasy element of fiction, in which we identify with characters as if we know them, be answer in the 19th century by the novel; in the 20th century we have tv soaps. Just as the tabloid newspapers feature characters from EastEnders, so when Dickens' The Old Curiosity Shop be run as a serial there be widespread press speculation on whether Little Nell would die, and readers write in beg for her to be saved. Sentimentality, accessibility, topicality - what characterise today's soaps be clear features of the novel in 1894. Both In the year of Jubilee and Esther Waters, for example, centre on the burn 1890s debate about marriage, feminism and the 'New Woman', yet both be also tearjerkers which everyone enjoyed. The 1894 books be compel because they prefigure our own times and yet be set back from them. Trilby be a tale of hypnotism and the unconscious a decade away from Freud; The Ebb Tide pave the way for Conrad's Heart of Darkness and the first questioning of colonial oppression. It be unlikely that the 1994 Booker choices will speak as eloquently of new trends today. Whereas the 1894 titles have contemporary settings, many of the 1994 books be historical (such as Paradise) or be drive by nostalgia (such as Beside the Ocean of Time). Which book will win on October 15? Stevenson will get the sympathy vote because he die in 1894 in Samoa, the setting of The Ebb Tide. Jungle Book will get the retrospective vote, because it be the best-known today and have fashionable mythic overtones in the lost paradise of Mowgli's jungle; its position on the list may also rescue it from schmaltzy Disney associations and confirm it as a serious novel about a young man's self-discovery. My vote go to trilby. Soft-focus, ideologically shaky - in its anti-semitic portrait of Svengali - and sometimes sloppy, it be a story of demonic possession and haunt the imagination like a fairy tale long after better-written works have fade from memory. Like Rebecca, the popular novel by du Maurier's granddaughter, it be a natural equivalent of what the current Booker Prize seek to create: a combination of the classic and the bestseller. The shortlist of six for the Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize for fiction, announce yesterday, immediately prompt the question 'Who?' from many in the publishing industry. accord to one insider, some on the list 'are b-team writers at best'. The six include Alan Hollinghurst's The Folding Star (published by Chatto and Windus), a melancholy study of homosexual obsession which be tip as a likely candidate from the initial 'long list' of 15, The Reef (Granta) by young Sri Lankan writer Romesh Gunesekera and How Late It Was, How Late (secker and Warburg) by gritty Glasgow realist James Kelman, which be almost universally well-reviewed. As for the other three - knowledge of Angels (Green Bay) a philosophical fable by children's author Jill Paton Walsh, Paradise (hamish Hamilton) by Zanzibar-born writer Abdulrazak Gurnah and Beside the Ocean of Time (John Murray) by 72-year-old orcadian poet George Mackay Brown - 'frankly, they don't make the grade'. The shortlist for the Booker, the UK's most hype literary prize and one of the most lucrative, be all the more surprising in a bumper year for new fiction fulfil the criteria - english language and non-american - for consideration for the award. Margaret Atwood's The Robber Bride seem an astonishing omission, as do new novels by Peter Ackroyd, Peter Carey, Candia McWilliam, William Trevor and Jim Crace. But if the shortlist of the final six candidates for the prize may be disappointing, the traditional controversy surround the award be as rife as ever. One unsurprising omission from the final selection be When The World Was Steady, a first novel by Claire Messud, which be on the 'long list' before it be point out that the author be the wife of James Wood, chief literary reviewer of The Guardian newspaper and a Booker judge. Professor John Bayley, chairman of the Booker panel and husband of former Booker Prize winner Dame Iris Murdoch, express surprise at Mr Wood's failure to reveal his relationship with Ms Messud. But it be the final list, rather than the controversy, that discredit the award accord to some critics. 'This list,' say one man of letters, 'must have deal a final death blow to the Booker.' The winner, select from an original 130, will be announce on October 11. The Booker Prize be Britain's literary event of the year, guarantee to boost sales of the chosen novel after the award announcement Oct. 16, and dinner in London's ancient Guildhall. The prize to the author be a check for 20,000 pounds (nearly $38,000), sponsor by Booker, an international food and agriculture business. british publishers be very secretive about their sales but we know that when Thomas Keneally win it in 1982 for `schindler's Ark,' his publishers, who have print 15,000 copies, sell 75,000 over the next 23 weeks, say Christine Shaw of Book Trust. The trust be a charity promote reading and books and administer the prize. The prize have become internationally known, and the worldwide demand for the win book, in English and translations, be spectacular, say Shaw. The prize be first award in 1969 after talks between Booker and the Publishers' Association on the need for a significant literary award to encourage and reward good writing. british publishers can submit three new novels by british and Commonwealth writers. There be 110 submissions last year. A management committee of authors, booksellers, librarians and the sponsors choose a jury of five: a writer or two, an academic, a politician interested in literature and a literary editor or critic. Each juror read every book submitted, lists about six favorites and meets the other jurors to select and announce six finalists. As public debate rages over who's in, who's out and who might win, with bookmakers across the country call the odds, the jurors meet again and finally select the winner on the afternoon of announcement day. This year's finalists: Beryl Bainbridge An Awfully Big Adventure, A.S. Byatt Possession, Penelope Fitzgerald The Gate of Angels, John McGahern Amongst Women, Brian Moore Lies of Silence and Mordecai Richler Solomon Gursky Was Here. Six novels have be nominate for the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious fiction award, and bookmakers say the favorite be The Remains of the Day by japanese author Kazuo Ishiguro. The award, to be announce Oct. 26, carry a $31,600 prize fund by the Booker McConnell food company. Oddsmaker William Hill give 7-to-4 odds on Ishiguro's novel about a butler's travel through Britain's West Country and say it be a firm favorite to win. Ishiguro, previously nominate for the award, be beat as the Booker favorite in 1986, which make his chances that much strong this time in our view, say William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe. The other books nominate are: Cat's Eye, a story of painter Elaine Risley and her return to her childhood home in Toronto by Canadian author Margaret Atwood, also a previous nominee. The Book of Evidence, a prison story of kidnap and murder convict Freddie Montgomery by John Banville, literary editor of The Irish Times newspaper. Jigsaw, by Sybille Bedford, an autobiographical novel about an adolescent's travels through Germany, Italy and France. A Disaffection, Scottish novelist James Kelman's story about a school teacher, Patrick Doyle, whose professional frustrations be fuel by a drinking problem and unrequited love for a colleague. Restoration, British author Rose Tremain's story of Robert Merivel, a favorite of King Charles II who marry the monarch's young mistress. We expect more interest in this year's Booker Prize than ever before, partly thanks to last year's controversy over Salman Rushdie's `Satanic Verses,' Sharpe said. Rushdie be nominate for the prize last year but it be win by australian author Peter Carey for his love story Oscar and Lucinda. Rushdie, a british citizen, have be in hide since Feb. 14 when the late iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini order he be kill for allegedly blaspheme Islam in Satanic Verses. This year's six nominees be choose Thursday from 102 books consider by a panel head by David Lodge, a british literary critic and novelist who be nominate for the prize last year for his book, Nice Work. On the day of the Big Event, Ladbroke, the large british betting agency, post the final odds. Brian Moore be the favorite at 7-4, follow by Peter Ackroyd (5-2), Iris Murdoch (3-1) and Chinua Achebe (9-2). The two dark horses, Nina Bawden and Penelope Lively, be each tip at 7-1.you may have notice a distinctly literary tilt to that lineup, an affinity with the bookshelf, not the bookie. All of those people publish new works of fiction here in Britain during the past 12 months. And for the last few weeks, literary punters throughout the british Isles have be place bets on which of those writers would win the Booker Prize, the best-known, best-liked and, almost incidentally, most prestigious fiction award in the land.in recent weeks the Booker contenders have receive almost as much press coverage as the Charles and Di rift. And nearly every article, from book reviews to author interviews, have feature the late odds. The betting be do largely by literary insiders, say Graham Sharpe, who set the Booker odds at William Hill, Britain's other big betting agency. "They read the books, hear the gossip and want to pull off a little coup for themselves," he says.last year's winner, "The Old Devils" by Kingsley Amis, be a 5-2 favorite, but this year, anyone who choose the victor make some dough."when she accept her prize for "moon Tiger," Penelope Lively look surprised and pleased. "I'm not a betting woman, and I have slight reservations about books become a spectator sport," she say in soft Oxbridge tones. "But those who be in the know tell me that 7-1 be an irresistible flutter." Her 65-year-old mother be among those who make a killing.america have the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and the National Book Awards, but in terms of excitement, hoopla and man-on-the-street interest, there's nothing akin to the 15,000-pound ($26,000) Booker Prize. With the possible exception of France's respect Prix Goncourt, there's nothing quite like it anywhere else.Britons wryly compare the Booker to the Academy Awards, and though there's just one prize and no envelope, similarities exist. There's a team of judges and a pool of candidates. This year each british publisher could submit three new titles, for a grand total of 93. As one judge note wearily, "By August, I be in more than a slight panic, sometimes read all day and evening; read while stand at the bus stop, read while cooking, reading, almost, while talk on the telephone."next come the "short-list," the judges' top six, which be announce with great fanfare in late september. This year the works include Brian Moore's political thriller "The Color of Blood" (E.P. Dutton, 182 pages, $16.95); Peter Ackroyd's "Chatterton" (Grove Press, 240 pages, $17.95); Nina Bawden's "Circles of Deceit" (St. Martin's Press, 208 pages, $14.95); Iris Murdoch's 23rd novel "The Book and the Brotherhood" (Viking, 608 pages, $19.95); nigerian writer Chinua Achebe's "Anthills of the Savannah" (Doubleday, 240 pages, $16.95); and "moon Tiger" (Grove Press, 216 pages, $15.95).the awards presentation come on the last Thursday in October, and like any major awards presentation, it come complete with limousines, banquet (salmon mousse, champagne sorbet and English roast beef) and television cameras. The suspense be genuine; the judges choose the winner just three hours before the announcement.to be sure, the ratings for the prime-time broadcast didn't upstage those of "eastenders," Britain's popular soap opera. yet interest be sufficient for Andre Deutsch, "Moon Tiger's" British publisher, to order up an additional 20,000 copies almost the minute Mrs. Lively -- and the nation -- hear the news.by british standards, sales figures for recent Booker winners be stunning, from "The Old Devils" (80,000 hard-cover copies) to Anita Brookner's "Hotel du Lac" (40,000 copies). even Keri Hulme's "The Bone People," a look at Maori culture that most readers find impenetrable, reach a respectable 21,000 in 1985.short-listed authors be just a few paces behind, share the best-seller list with Dick Francis and Scott Turow. Heinemann initially print 3,000 copies of "Anthills of the Savannah," the usual run for contemporary literary fiction. So far, 10,000 copies have sold. "being short-listed probably change the destiny of that book," declare a member of the Heinemann sales staff. Indeed, there's currently talk of initiate a similar prize with a similar purse for the year's best biography.another notable spinoff be the Booker harpies, readers intent on digest all six titles, then vigorously dispute the choices, which never please everyone. This year the Sunday Times offer readers a complete autographed collection of the six books for the equivalent of $112, perfect fodder for the literary cocktail party cot.it wasn't always this way, of course. Headlines be modest back in 1969 when P.H. Newby win the first ever Booker Prize for "something to Answer For." (The wonderfully appropriate name come from Booker-McConnell PLC, the international food and agriculture conglomerate that put up the prize money each year.)the idea be to devise a british equivalent to the Prix Goncourt, and like that august french award, the Booker attract attention the minute it kick up controversy. The early fuss be keep within the literary world, with critics snip over choices and the prize's vary ground rules. The real world take notice in 1974, when Elizabeth Jane Howard, one of the three judges, write a letter to the Times claim that in her opinion Kingsley Amis's "ending Up," one of the short-listed books, be his best ever. As it happens, she be marry to Mr. Amis at the time. He didn't win.but many credit the Booker's current appeal to the 1982 competition and Thomas Keneally's "Schindler's Ark," or "Schindler's List" as it be know in the U.S. Written as a novel, the book tell the true story of a remarkable german who save the lives of hundreds of Jews in concentration camps. But even after it win the Booker, people argue that it wasn't a novel. "the more people question it, the more it sold," say Ion Trewin, editorial director at Hodder & Stoughton. "That be the first year the prize catch the media and public imagination. suddenly the Booker gain inches on front pages."oh yes, "moon Tigers" be a die woman's recollection of her life as a World War II war correspondent and her affair with a young tank officer.--- Ms. Trucco be a free-lance writer base in London. Australian novelist Peter Carey be award the coveted Booker Prize for fiction Tuesday night for his love story, Oscar and Lucinda. A panel of five judges unanimously announce the award of the $26,250 prize after an 80-minute deliberation during a banquet at London's ancient Guildhall. The judges make their selection from 102 books publish in Britain in the past 12 months and which they read in their homes. Carey, who live in Sydney with his wife and son, say in a brief speech that like the other five finalists he have be ask to attend with a short speech in his pocket in case he won. If I'd know I be go to win I think I would have take a bit more trouble with my handwriting, he say as he star down at his notes. He be unsuccessful in the prize competition in 1985 when his novel, Illywhacker, be among the final six. Carey call the award a great honor and he thank the prize sponsors for provoke so much passionate discussion about literature perhaps there will be more tomorrow. everyone who love good books benefits from this, surely, he added. The win novel be a fitting choice for Australia's bicentennial year. It tell of a romance between an English gambler and an australian heiress who meet on a steamship's maiden voyage to Australia in the mid-19th century. The story weave in australian history from its founding in 1788 by british immigrants. Panel chairman Michael Foot, a writer and former leader of the opposition Labor Party, say the judges agree that entries this year have be exceptionally strong and that choose the last six novels be extremely difficult. We hope there will be no criticisms but if there are, then people should start read the books for themselves, Foot said. Carey be the only non-briton in the final six. The son of an auto dealer, he be bear in Bacchus Marsh, Victoria, and attend Geelong Church of England Grammar School, Melbourne, where the Prince of Wales be also a pupil as an 18-year-old in 1966. Carey be an advertising copywriter before turn to write books in 1965. The first Booker Prize be award in 1969. It be administer by Book Trust, an educational charity promote books, and be sponsor by Booker, an international food and farming business. Critic and novelist A.S. Byatt on Tuesday win the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious literary award, for her tale of two young scholars investigate the lives of a pair of imaginary victorian poets. The five judges deliberate two hours before award the $39,000 prize to Antonia Byatt for Possession, one of six finalists in the 21-year-old competition. last year's Booker winner be Kazuo Ishiguro for his novel, The Remains of the Day. Television executive Sir Denis Forman, chairman of the judge's panel, announce the prize at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, seat of the city's Lord Mayor. There be very strong individual support for several books on the short list and finally `possession' by A.S. Byatt be the winner by a majority vote, say the judges. The panel be unanimous, however, in agree that the standard of the other five novels be exceptionally high and this make their decision unusually interesting and unusually difficult. Ms. Byatt, who earlier this month win the $43,000 irish Times-Aer Lingus prize for international fiction for the same work, have publish five novels since 1964. In Possession, she tell how two graduate students piece together the relationship and lives of two imaginary victorian poets from fragments of their letters and by retrace the poets' journey across England and to France. The influence of the past on the living be a theme throughout the book. Ms. Byatt, bear in 1936, be the daughter of a lawyer and sister of novelist Margaret Drabble. Her first novel, Shadow of a Sun, concern the efforts of a woman to escape the shadow of her novelist father. A 1978 work, The Virgin in the Garden, make allegorical allusions to Shakespeare and other English literary geniuses in a tale of a play perform at a country house. Ms. Byatt teach English and american literature at University College in London until 1983, when she quit to write fulltime. other finalists this year be 1979 Booker Prize winner Penelope Fitzgerald with The Gate of Angels, Irish novelist John McGahern's Amongst Women, Canadian-born Mordecai Richler's Solomon Gursky Was Here, Brian Moore's Lies of Silence, and Beryl Bainbridge's An Awfully Big Adventure. They be choose from a list of 113 books publish in the United Kingdom in 1989. The Booker Prize be sponsor by Booker, an international food and agriculture business, and administer by The Book Trust. It be Britain's top literary award. THE annual Booker ballyhoo get go again yesterday when the judges for this year's pound 20,000 prize for british (and Commonwealth) fiction announce the shortlist. The Prize (courtesy of Booker plc, the food and agri-business group) be no longer the rich literary award but it guarantee great prestige, and sales, for the winner, and, say its admirers, helpfully bring The Novel to public attention. Its critics say that the autumn brouhaha distort the annual fiction industry and the intense media hype of the shortlisted authors do a disservice to the hordes of other gift but unlisted writers. This year's shortlist contain no surprises. London's litterati have for weeks be bet on Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient - those of them who have see a proof copy because it be not officially publish until next week. last night the bookmakers William Hill make it the 5-2 favourite. The shortlist is: Serenity House by Christopher Hope (MacMillan pound 14.99). Black comedy by a master South africa-born specialist in the trade. Set in a Highgate 'eventide refuge' where euthanasia be an unspoken word and its senior citizen, Max Montfalcon, turn out to be a geriatric Nazi scientist. The FT review next Saturday will describe it as 'surreal farce .. scabrously enjoyable ..' The Butcher's Boy by Patrick McCabe (Picador Pounds 14.99). An irish murderer, a soft-in-the-head orphan jail for life, recall his life in grisly detail. The FT reviewer say that 'the misery and deprivation of work class life have never be so brutally evoked ..' Black Dogs by Ian McEwan (Secker & Warburg pound 14.99). McEwan's fiction be uniquely disturb - some would say deliberately offensive. He be the novelist of misanthropy. This be the tale of a failed marriage, episodically told, and the black dogs of evil be both metaphorical and literal. The english Patient by Michael Ondaatje (Bloomsbury Pounds 14.99). The Sri Lankan poet and novelist Ondaatje, who live in Canada, have follow 'in the skin of a lion' with an extraordinary book about four characters in a tuscan villa in the closing months of the last war. The central metaphor be bombs - disposal of, and then Hiroshima. The 'english patient' be a central mystery around which the others' stories orbit: he fell out of the sky in flames; who be he? The FT review on Saturday will hail it as a masterpiece. Daughters of the House by Michele Roberts (Virago pound 14.99). The surprise contender because it be not yet published. Roberts come from an anglo-french Catholic background and this inform her new novel with a strong rural-normandy atmosphere. Two cousins, one pious, one worldly. Shades of Saint Therese of Lisieux. Lots of action in the kitchen; something be hide in the cellar. Sacred Hunger by Barry Unsworth (hamish Hamilton Pounds 15.99). Unsworth's massive novel about the 1750s slave trade come out early this year to widespread critical praise. The shipboard detail - the horrors of
column5: A survey of Britain's exciting Booker Prize for fiction novels.
column6: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction is awarded yearly from a long list of novels narrowed down to a final six. A panel of judges selects the winner. Odds are given and literary insiders bet on which book will win. The winner receives a cash award and great prestige and sales.
column7: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction novels is similar to America's Pulitzer Prize and National Book awards but more excitement is associated with it. British publishers each submit three new titles. The total of around 100 books is narrowed down to a final six by a panel of learned judges after they have read all the novels. Odds are given with reviews, and literary insiders bet on which book will win the prize. The winner is announced at a yearly banquet.The Prize is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity, and sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column8: America has the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and the National Book Awards but in terms of hoopla and excitement, there's nothing akin to Britain's Booker Prize. British publishers each submit three new titles for a total of approximately 100. There's a jury of judges, including writers, academics, politicians, editors and critics. Each juror reads every book and odds are given with reviews. The jurors then meet and select six finalists. Literary insiders bet on which book will win the Booker Prize. The winner is announced at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, the seat the city's Lord Mayor, on the last Thursday in October. The authors can win up to $38,000. The event also guarantees great prestige and sales for the winner and brings the novel to public attention.Critics say the brouhaha distorts the annual fiction industry and the intense media hype does a disservice to other gifted but unlisted authors. On one recent occasion following heated deliberation between the judges, the chairman went public with a rousing condemnation of contemporary fiction.The Prize, first awarded in 1969, is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity promoting books. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column9: Booker Britain's Most Prestigious Literary Award. Competition Hot. Wagering Heavy.
column10: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best fictionwork by a British or Commonwealth author. The Booker Company is thesponsor. It is now Britain's most prestigious literary award. Winnersreceive a substantial monetary award. Booker creates interest,motivates bettors, and boost book sales.
column11: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best work of fiction by a British or Commonwealth author. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business. The Booker carries a substantial monetary award, and is now Britain's most prestigious fiction prize. Judges name six finalists, and later select the winner from those six. The competition creates great interest and motivates bettors. It also boosts book sales.Three of the recent winners now live in Britain or a Commonwealth country, but were born elsewhere. Only books written in English can be entered into Booker competition.
column12: The Booker Prize was first awarded in 1969. It honors the best work offiction by a British or Commonwealth author published in Britainduring the preceding 12 months.  The Booker is now the best known andmost prestigious fiction award in Britain. It carries a substantialmonetary prize, and is administered by Book Trust, an educationalcharity. Booker, an international food and farming business, sponsorsthe Prize.British publishers can submit up to three titles forconsideration. Each year a management team selects a new panel ofjudges. They announce a list of six finalists. Bookmakers establishbetting odds, and heavy betting ensues, most of it by literarypundits. Interest builds in the period leading up to the announcementof the winner, usually in October.  The hype that accompanies theselection boosts book sales.Penelope Lively's "Moon Tigers" won in 1987. Peter Carey's "Oscar andLucinda" won in 1988. Kazuo Ishiguro's "The Remains of the Day" won in1989. Antonia Byatt's "Possession" won in 1990. Michael Ondaatje's"The English Patient" won in 1992, and John Kelman's "How Late It Is,How Late" won in 1994. In 1994 the short-list was severely criticized,and a hypothetical 1894 Booker was contested.

column3: Tens of thousands of people chant Freedom! Freedom! trek to a Moslem saint's shrine Saturday to campaign for the secession of Kashmir from India, witnesses and pro-separatist activists said. At least three people die in two separate incidents on Saturday in Kashmir, the center of the four-decade-old separatist campaign, witness said. The deaths bring to 109 the number of people kill since Jan. 20 in the late round of the secessionist violence and the government crackdown. Meanwhile, the president of the Pakistan state of Kashmir say in an interview Saturday that Kashmiris there have begin smuggle arms across the border to Moslem insurgents fight for independence from India. President Abdul Qayyum, speak to a reporter who travel to Pakistan's Kashmir, say the people of his state also have be shelter insurgents since India launch the military crackdown in its state of Jammu-Kashmir last month. In India's Kashmir, the 600-year-old shrine of Shiekh Nuruddin Wali at Charift Sharief, 20 miles northwest of Srinagar, become a sea of humanity as Moslem men, women and children pour in from Srinagar and nearby towns. Vehicles stop 10 miles from the shrine as people throng the roads, say witnesses, who speak on condition of anonymity. Supporters of the militants say they go to the shrine to seek the saint's blessings to liberate Kashmir from India. In Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, residents be tell by Moslem militants to put their clocks back by 30 minutes to correspond with the Pakistan standard time. The militants, lead by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, be demand either independence for Jammu-Kashmir, the only indian state dominate by Moslems. Groups of young Moslem men sit at street corners, stop passers-by and tell them to adjust their watches. At least six fights break out when people refuse to comply, say witnesses who speak on condition of anonymity. On Friday, at least 200,000 people march to the office of the United Nations Military Observers Group in Srinagar, demand a plebiscite in Kashmir, police said. Witnesses claim that more than 600,000 people take part. The U.N. group be post to maintain a cease-fire line drawn between Indian- and Pakistani-held Kashmir after a 1948-49 war over the region. Residents, speaking on condition of anonymity, say security forces fatally shoot two men shout anti-indian slogans at Khrew, 15 miles southeast of Srinagar. In Srinagar, suspect Moslem militants shot and kill Ashok Kumar, a Hindu government employee, witnesses said, also speak on condition of anonymity. Kumar be suspect to be a police informer. India routinely accuse Pakistan of arming, training and support the militants. The government in Islamabad deny the charge but say the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination. An AP reporter who travel to Pakistan's Kashmir last week say state-run banks in the region have begin collections to help the uprising. Signs in dozens of banks call for donations for a holy war against India. Naveed Hussain, a government spokesman in Pakistan's Kashmir, say in an interview that $5,000 have be raise in a week and that the money would be use to train Kashmiri militia groups in territory hold by Pakistan. Kashmir be divide between India and Pakistan after the two countries be partition follow the end of british colonial rule in 1947. Moslems blow up a truck carry security forces Wednesday, kill three soldiers in the few hours the government relax a curfew design to stop the Kashmiri separatist uprising, officials said. In separate incidents, militants shot and kill a Moslem they say be a police informer and a Moslem die after he be catch in an exchange of fire between militants and security forces, officials said. also Wednesday, Moslem snipers fire on security forces in three parts of Srinagar during a five-hour relaxation of curfew, say Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state. There be no casualties, he said. The curfew be relax from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m. to allow people in the city of 1 million to shop for food and other essentials. An around-the-clock curfew be impose Friday after security forces the day before shot and kill 49 Moslem demonstrators march into Srinagar to take part in a pro-independence rally. At least 1 million Moslems demonstrate to demand independence for the predominantly Moslem state; India be predominantly Hindu. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, be the center of the separatist movement. At least 171 people have be kill in Kashmir since a government crackdown on the separatist movement begin on Jan. 20. Leading national parties decide Wednesday to send a high-powered delegation to Srinagar, accord to the Press Trust of India news agency. It do not name the members, but it say they would go Thursday. The decision be take at the end of a daylong multiparty meeting on Kashmir call by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. A joint statement after the meeting say despite their ideological and political differences, (the parties) be one in defend the unity and integrity of the country, the news agency reported. Jagmohan say the truck be drive around Srinagar distribute food to troop on street corners when it be blow up by Moslem militants. He give no further details of the attack. The attacks come amid government claims that security forces arrest at least 12 leaders of the Moslem group Hezbul Mujahedeen. Jagmohan say the militants, from Srinagar and the border towns of Baramulla and Kupwara, have be arrest since Sunday. Hezbul Mujahedeen be one of 30 militant groups fight for secession. It be believe the second most powerful independence group after the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. We be go to hit hard at anti-national elements, there be no way they can get away with what they be doing, Jagmohan said. It may take a month, six months, maybe a year, but ultimately these anti-national elments be go to be neutralized. Jagmohan, a Hindu, be appoint the state governor of Jammu-Kashmir on Jan. 18 in an attempt by the government to control the unrest. Kashmir have be a problem for more than four decades follow the 1947 partition of british colonial India into predominantly Moslem Pakistan and the mostly Hindu India. Jammu-Kashmir, then a princely state, chose to merge with India. Pakistan protested, claim the territory because of its predominantly Moslem population. The two countries have twice go to war over the territory. The Kashmir portion of Jammu-Kashmir be mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu segment be predominantly Hindu. Overall, about 65 percent of the state's 6 million people be Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus account for 82 percent. Exotic Kashmir, a tourist paradise of houseboat hotels and Mogul gardens from whose name the English make cashmere, have become a war zone of separatism and religious enmity. Military jeep carry senior government officials and civil servants around Srinagar in these dangerous days, as soldiers and paramilitary troopers try to stop a campaign of violence by Moslem separatists in the Kashmir Valley. Intelligence officer M.K. Kaul command one of the jeeps. At the beginning of a trip through the city of 1 million people, he turn to the four soldiers in the jeep's rear seats and ordered: Check your weapons. Be ready to fire. Kaul settle into the front seat, a 9mm pistol in his right hand. These be bad days, he murmured. These die-hard terrorists can attack from anywhere. To his men, he said: Shoot them if you see them. On Monday, an around-the-clock curfew be lift from 5 a.m. until noon and stores open to crowds of customers. Soldiers in sandbagged bunkers, arm with light machine guns, guard main intersections. A spokesman for the Jammu-Kashmir state government say the situation be peaceful and absolutely normal in Srinagar, the state's large city. At least 72 people have be kill since the crackdown begin Jan. 20 in an effort to curb attacks on government officials and buildings. most of the dead have be Moslem militants shoot by indian troops. We be neither fight a war nor try to suppress any popular movement, say Jagmohan, governor of Jammu-Kashmir, the only state in predominantly Hindu India with a Moslem majority. We be fight a handful of terrorists who be determine to create a law and order problem, say Jagmohan, a Hindu with a reputation for toughness. other officials in Kashmir say privately the situation be critical, perhaps the most serious threat India have face in 42 years of independence from Britain. It look like everyone here have turn into a fundamentalist with firm belief that the day be not far off when they will become independent, a state police officer said. Kashmir be a separate kingdom, rule by a Hindu maharajah, when Britain relinquish colonial rule on Aug. 15, 1947, and the subcontinent be partition on religious lines into India and Pakistan. The Hindu king opt to join India, not Pakistan, and the dispute over Kashmir have exacerbate relations since. Pakistan take the western part of Kashmir and India the eastern. Each accuse the other of forcible occupation. They have fight wars over Kashmir and the border question remain unresolved. U.N. observers be station on the truce line and the two sides occasionally trade gunfire. Officials will not say how many reinforcements have be send to the Kashmir Valley since Jan. 20, but reports from various sources indicate 30,000-and 40,000 soldiers and paramilitary troops have be deployed. It be the valley's heavily Moslem population that tilt the sectarian scale in Jammu-Kashmir state. Of the state's nearly 6 million people, 64 percent be Moslems and 32 percent Hindus. Most Hindus live in the southern Jammu area. Srinagar have 150 mosques. This be the best breeding ground for Moslem fundamentalism, say a federal official who help coordinate the new security measures. nearly every mosque have a loudspeaker to summon the faithful to prayer and, more recently, to exhort listeners to defend their faith and Kashmir. The residents be constantly bombard with Islamic sermons and be remind that fight a `jihad' (islamic holy war) be the most sacred duty of every Moslem, the federal official said, on condition of anonymity. Electricity be cut off in the city Friday, which be both the Moslem sabbath and India's national Republic Day on India's Republic Day, but many mosque loudspeakers continue operating because militants connect them to car batteries. Intelligence reports suggest the government have an advantage because the separatists be not united. The most powerful group be the jammu-kashmir Liberation Front, but there be several others, include the Allah Tigers, Hezb-e-Mujahed Hezb-e-Islami. India claim the fundamentalists get money and weapons from Pakistan. The Pakistanis deny it. Jagmohan, the governor, insist the main issue in Kashmir be economic development, not separatism. The people do not want violence or the so-called independent Kashmir, he said. The need of the hour be development. Let more tourists come. let new schools be built. Let new hospitals come up. As he spoke, military officers wait in the next room to discuss a new strategy to crush rebellion in what the tourist brochures call Paradise. Right now, Paradise look lost, at least temporarily. The army on Tuesday dispatch tanks and troop reinforcements to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldiers from the two nations have be fight recently, officials and witnesses said. Prime Minister V.P. Singh tell Parliament that Indian arm forces be fully prepare to effectively deal with any eventuality. indian and Pakistani troops clash in a remote border area in the disputed Kashmir region Monday. Singh, who be also defense minister, say exchange of fire also occur Tuesday. In Pakistan, a Defense Ministry spokesman, who cannot be identify under brief rules, say Tuesday that Indian and Pakistani soldiers exchange artillery fire in the Kel sector along the cease-fire line divide Kashmir into Pakistani and indian regions. He say there be no casualties among Pakistani soldiers. The Pakistani official also say that on Monday and Tuesday, Indian soldiers fire on Pakistani civilians travel on a mountain road, injure four people. He also say indian soldiers fire on an ambulance and a bus. There be no report from India on the allege firing. Despite the tension, officials from both sides say the incidents do not appear to be serious. There be no cause for any undue concern since we trust that these localized incidents will be contain and the situation defused, United News of India quote Singh as say in the Parliament. Singh say directors of military operations from both countries be in touch. He do not elaborate. The Pakistani official said: This be not a serious situation. It's just in one sector. It could be just a local incident. We don't know what it will lead to. We'll just have to wait and see. India and Pakistan have go to war twice over Kashmir, in 1965 and 1971. Both sides claim Kashmir, which have be divide into indian and Pakistani sectors. Tensions over Kashmir flare again this summer. India accuse Pakistan of support a Moslem secessionist movement in the indian sector by provide arms and training to Moslem militants. Pakistan, an Islamic state, deny the charge but say it will back any movement for self-determination by Kashmir's people. Jammu-Kashmir state be the only one of India's states with a Moslem majority. At least 1,034 people have be kill in the Kashmir valley since New Delhi crack down on the secessionist movement on Jan. 20. Military officials in Jammu, the summer capital of India-held Kashmir, say Tuesday that tanks and troops reinforcements be dispatch to the border areas. At least 20 tanks and 30 trucks with soldiers leave their quarters at Kaluchak and Baridrahamna for the frontier, say witnesses, who speak on condition of anonymity. indian military officials say the additional troops be send to Rajauri and Poonch sectors, which be the scenes of fierce battles in the wars of 1965 and 1971. Pakistani troops fire on indian security forces who stop a mob of Pakistani protesters from storm across the border into disputed Kashmir, officials say today. At least three demonstrators be kill Sunday night, a Defense Ministry spokesman say in Islamabad. Pakistan's state-run tv say the indian guards kill as many as six. The trouble start after indian border guards open fire on hundreds of Pakistanis who try to cross a cease-fire line separate pakistan-controlled Kashmir from the Indian-held region. A spokesman for the indian Defense Ministry say Pakistani troops then fire about 200 rounds from light and medium weapons at indian border posts in the Uri sector. indian forces return fire and the exchange continue for about half an hour, the spokesman said. No one be hurt. A Pakistani official in Islamabad deny the accusations. Pakistani military authorities and the Foreign Secretary be in touch with indian authorities to remove the misunderstanding, say Additional Foreign Secretary Khalid Mahmood in Islamabad. Pakistan's top diplomat in New Delhi, Bashir Babar, be summon to India's Foreign Ministry on Sunday and today and apprise of India's concern over the events, an indian government spokesman said. A fluid 840-mile cease-fire line separate the indian and Pakistani Kashmirs. Pakistan and indian twice have go to war over Kashmir, in 1948 and again in 1965. On Feb. 5, at least one person be kill and 12 wound when Pakistani mobs try to cross the cease-fire line near Jammu, 95 miles to the south. The two demonstrations at the cease-fire line be to express support for Moslem militants who be fight for independence for the moslem-dominated state from the predominantly Hindu India. On Sunday, the Pakistani mob retreat when soldiers of India's paramilitary border security force open fire, say the Indian spokesman who refuse to be identified. The mob return a second time by which time it have become slightly dark, he said. That be when the Pakistani troops open fire. A Pakistani spokesman, who also refuse to be identified, say Pakistani army patrols repulse a mob of some 1,200 demonstrators. Small groups break away from the crowd and slip into the Indian-held territory, he said. An official of the indian border security force, which normally patrol the border, say the indian army today take control of the cease-fire line. Some men in the intruding crowd be arm with guns which they fire occasionally, he said. It be become very difficult, our troops have to open fire, he said. Farouk Haider, vice-president of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front that be lead the uprising, say in Islamabad after the indian firing that the situation be very confusing. Thirty-one people be wound in the shooting, Haider said. Five be in critical condition in a hospital in Muzzafarabad, the capital of pakistan-controlled Kashmir, he said, add he know of only one death. The 40-year-old conflict over Kashmir flare Jan. 20 after a government crackdown and the arrest of 250 suspect militants. most of them be subsequently released, but the arrests spark widespread violence. At least 85 people have be kill since the crackdown began. most of the victims have be curfew-breaking protesters shoot by security forces in Srinagar. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, have be the center of the secessionist movement that have turn violent in recent years. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front have earlier campaign for union with Islamic Pakistan but have in recent years demand independence and the status of a neutral country. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people be Moslems, make it the only Moslem majority state in predominantly Hindu India's 25 states. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million population. Hindus comprise 82 percent. Troops battle mob of Moslem separatists in the Kashmir city of Srinagar over the weekend, and at least 21 people be kill and 100 wound before the fighting subside Sunday night, police said. Fifteen demonstrators be shoot and kill Sunday, while six be fatally wound late Saturday night, accord to Mohammad Nomani, inspector general of Srinagar police. Militants defy a curfew and continued trading intermittent shots with government forces on Sunday, officials said. Witnesses, speak on condition of anonymity, say the death toll be at least 30, but that figure could not be confirmed. Nomani, speaking by telephone from Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, say the fighting taper off late Sunday afternoon as heavy rains lash the city. But gunfire echo through the deserted streets until evening, one resident said, request anonymity. They (the troops) be shoot at anything moving, he said. It be a disastrous situation out there, say Ramesh Kaul, a hotel receptionist in Srinagar. At least 47 people have be kill in Jammu-Kashmir state since the beginning of the year in violence trigger by Moslem militants demand independence or union with Islamic Pakistan. The separatists, lead by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, have often attack government offices and police officials. The situation be tense and dangerous, the state's chief secretary, Moosa Raza, say in Jammu, the state's winter capital 95 miles south of Srinagar. Nomani say the police dispatch 25 cars with loudspeakers into the city, to appeal to people to obey the curfew. The cars be escort by heavily arm troops from the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force, he said. A 24-hour curfew be impose Saturday in a bid to quell escalate violence and mass anti-india demonstrations in Srinagar and nearby towns. But late Saturday, crowd defy curfew and surge into downtown Srinagar chant indian dogs go back! and Long live Pakistan! local reporters said. They say the paramilitary troops open fire, kill two people instantly and injure 14. Four of them die later. As news of the shootings spread, thousands of Moslem men pour out of their homes, the reporters said. They say protesters recite verses from the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Some take up a chant urge mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, to prepare for the final sacrifice in a showdown with India's Hindu-dominated government. Jammu-Kashmir's former state chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, issue a statement accuse authorities of let loose a reign of terror and repression. Abdullah's Moslem-dominated National Conference Party be closely align with the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, the arch political foe of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Abdullah's government resign Friday to protest the appointment of Singh's nominee as the state's new governor and imposition of governor's rule which amount to tighter federal control over the state. The curfew order be one of the first acts of the new governor, Jagmohan, a tough administrator who have crack down on Kashmiri militants during an early stint as the state's governor. Jagmohan, a Hindu who use one name, take office Friday. Parts of Kashmir region be claim by both India and Pakistan. The dispute start when the state be partition between the two countries when they gain independence from Britain in 1947. Srinagar's 800,000 people be moslty Moslem, as be a majority of population in the Kashmir region. The Jammu region be predominantly Hindu. India have often accuse Pakistan of aid the Kashmiri militants, a charge Pakistan have denied. Jammu-Kashmir be the only state with a Moslem majority in predominantly Hindu India. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state population of 5 million. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus comprise 82 percent. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Thursday accuse India of wag genocide in secession-minded Kashmir and of try to start a war with Pakistan to deflect attention. Her remarks raise tensions further between India and Pakistan, which have be feud over indian-controlled Kashmir. The two countries, which have fight wars over the area in 1949 and 1965, have in recent weeks again build up their military forces near the common border. India be indulge in genocide, Ms. Bhutto say at a news conference Thursday after return from a weeklong tour of eight Moslem countries in the Middle East and North Africa. Islamic scholars be be kill and innocent people be be slaughtered. This be deplorable, say the prime minister. She be refer to the assassination of Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, the top Moslem cleric in indian Kashmir. During his funeral procession Monday, Indian forces shot to death 58 people. Ms. Bhutto return late Wednesday from visits to Iran, Turkey, Syria, Jordan, North Yemen, Egypt, Libya and Tunisia, a high-profile diplomatic offensive to drum up support for Pakistan's stand on the Kashmir issue. Hindu-dominated India accuse Pakistan of arm and train Kashmiri militants fight for secession of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only state with a Moslem majority. Pakistan, which be dominate by Moslems, deny the indian charge. Since the indian government order a crackdown on the militants in late January, more than 400 people have be killed. During her trip abroad, Ms. Bhutto say all her host countries agree that India and Pakistan need to find a lasting political settlement of the 43-year-old dispute. However, she added, If subject to aggression, we would have the full support of the Arab Islamic nations. Pakistan, I be assured, would never be leave alone. We believe the threats to peace be grave, she said. We cannot rule out the possibility of an armed conflict, but we do not believe war be inevitable, she tell reporters. Ms. Bhutto say she oppose an independent Kashmir. She say it be not envision when India and Pakistan gain independence in a 1947 partition. The prime minister again call for talks between Pakistan and India. She also say a neutral body should look into the charges make by both sides. India have already reject both suggestions. Moslem extremists abduct a leading businessman and an educator Friday and threaten to kill them, a day after authorities kill six militants cross into Pakistan for arms and training, police said. Roads be block around Srinagar, where the hostages be seized, and soldiers tighten security around the Kashmir Valley, where the government launch a crackdown Jan. 20 on the Moslem separatist movement. A telephone caller tell a local reporter the abductors be also hold a third hostage and all three men would be kill within 24 hours of a Monday afternoon deadline for release three jailed militants. The caller claim to speak for the Students Liberation Front, a branch of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front fight for autonomy in the predominantly Moslem state. India itself be overwhelmingly Hindu. Police sources, who demand anonymity, and the telephone caller both identify the new kidnap victims as Vice Chancellor Mushir ul-haq of Kashmir University and L.M. Khela, general manager of Hindustan Machine Tools Co. The caller say ul-haq's private secretary also be be hold hostage, but that could not be confirmed. Moslem separatists have warn indian government officials to leave Jammu-Kashmir state before April or face the consequences. Police say the border violence take place in Kupwara district, where at least 20 separatists try to sneak into neighbor Pakistan to receive military training and buy weapons. No details be available. India say Pakistan trains and arms the militants in Kashmir, at the far northern tip of India. Pakistan deny it. India and Pakistan have fight two wars over the region since 1947, when both nations win independence from Britain. Pakistani and indian troops exchange fire for several hours today after a Pakistani soldier become the first military casualty on the troubled Kashmir border, officers and a western observer said. The soldier be shoot in the leg Sunday at a ceasefire line, several miles from the village of Chaukothi, officials say on condition of anonymity. They say there be no reports of casualties from today's firefight at the line, which divide Kashmir between Pakistan and India. The nations have twice go to war over the Himalayan state, in 1948 and again in 1965. The former princely state be divide between the two nations after british colonial rule end in 1947. Relations between the neighbors have become increasingly strained since Jan. 20 when indian troops launch a military crackdown on Moslem separatists in turbulent Jammu-Kashmir. The militants want India's only majority Moslem state to either become independent or join Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir be an aberration in India, where 82 percent of the country's 880 million people be Hindus. The leaders of both countries have try to soothe tempers in the dispute and have say another war over the region be unlikely. However, Pakistani forces have now seal off the border area at Chaukothi, forbid civilians from enter the area. The border crossing be the scene of a bloody confrontation on Feb. 11 between indian troops and Pakistani students, who be march in solidarity with activists in Indian-held Kashmir. Indian troops kill three students and wound several during that confrontation, a Pakistan defence ministry spokesman said. The two armies also exchange gunfire for about 30 minutes before calm be restored. A Paksitan army captain, who say he witness the firefight, say unlike the occasional shootings in the past, indian soldiers appear to be aim at Pakistani troops. The western observer say Sunday's shooting of the Pakistan soldier appear to back up that assertion. In another sign of increased tensions, Pakistani and indian officers be no longer accompany United Nations' military observers as they pass through the borders. It be not a normal situation, the officer said. The border be extremely tense. Pakistan officials say they be take steps to quell what one official call war fever on the Pakistan side. We be try to tie the people down, say Amir Alan Khan, a retired lieutenant colonel who head Kashmir's civil defence. He say hundreds of retired soldiers have approach him to ask for orders to fight the indian army. The bodies of four Moslems be find in a Kashmir town Monday, five days after they be kidnap by Moslem militants agitate for secession from India. The bodies, which have bullet wounds, be find in the town of Sopore about 35 miles northwest of the Kashmir capital of Srinagar, say police officials speak on condition of anonymity. anonymous callers to local newspapers and news agency offices say the four be kill by the Hezbul Mujahedeen because they be police informers. The Hezbul Mujahedeen be one of more than a dozen Moslem organizations fight for independence of the Kashmir valley from India. Police officials also report the death of one soldier in a militant ambush of an army convoy in the district of Baramulla, northwest of Srinagar. At least three soldiers be injured, they said. The deaths raise to 630 the number of people kill since security forces begin a crackdown on the Moslem movement on Jan. 20. The Kashmir valley, most of which fall in the indian state of Jammu-Kashmir, be predominantly Moslem. Jammu-Kashmir be the only indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslem militants earlier have demand union with Pakistan, the Islamic nation on India's western border. But, of late, they have be demand independence and the status of a neutral nation. A leader of the Moslem separatist movement in Kashmir try to hurl a grenade into a police bunker Friday but be kill in a volley of police gunfire. Tens of thousands of Moslems gather later for the funeral. Comrades fire into the air and vow to carry on the fight for independence from India. Ashfaq Majid Wani, 28, be a leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, a leading separatist group. He be the front's area commander in Srinagar. Police say he try to throw the grenade at a police bunker in downtown Srinagar while rid by on a motor scooter. The grenade go off after officers open fire with automatic weapons. Three other people die in the melee, the police said. Hours later, thousands of residents gather near Wani's house in an attempt to hold a funeral procession in defiance of a government curfew. But soldiers and police prevent the procession and take Wani's body to a burial ground in a government ambulance escort by a police jeep. Women wail and beat their chest as Wani's body be take out of the ambulance and place near the grave. Men shouted: Ashfaq's blood will usher independence! A group militants fire pistols and automatic rifles in the air. Witnesses estimate the crowd at 40,000. The firing continue intermittently for more than one hour until the body wa inter at 5 p.m. We will carry forward Asfaq's mission, which be to gain independence, say one militant leader hold a soviet-designed Kalashnikov rifle. He refuse to give his name. The secessionist movement have be alternately simmer and flare since 1948, when the Hindu ruler of the old princely state of Kashmir, face with the option of merge either with India or Islamic Pakistan, choose India. The two countries then be one year old, have be partition from the british colonial India. India and
column5: Indian government battles Muslim insurgents in Jammu-Kashmir on Pakistani border.
column6: The Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir is the scene of continuing violence between the government and Muslim insurgents who are seeking to establish an independent nation.  More the 1,000 have been killed since January.  Since 1947, predominately Islamic Pakistan and Hindu-majority India have fought twice over this Muslim-majority region.
column7: The Indian government has been fighting Muslim insurgents in the state of Jammu-Kashmir for the last seven months.  More than 1,000 people have been killed.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim and the insurgents want an independent nation.  Violence is occurring primarily near Srinagar, the capital, and along the border with Pakistan.  India claims the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges.  The two nations recently exchanged fire, but both say there is no cause for concern.
column8: Fighting has broken out sporadically in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir since January 20.  At least 1,034 people had been killed by late August.  The Indian government is battling Muslim insurgents seeking the formation of an independent, neutral, nation.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim.  Insurgent tactics have included bombings, kidnappings, killings of suspected police informers, ambushes of police vehicles, and attacks on police installations.  Large demonstrations have been held in Jammu-Kashmir and on the Pakistani border.  Indian tactics have include retaliatory fire, arresting and killing insurgent leaders, 24-hour curfews, disrupting and firing on demonstrations, and interfering with funerals of dead insurgents.  The state is now governed directly from New Delhi.In August, India increased border forces and operations and killed 80 infiltrators, claiming the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges but says it does support the Muslims' crusade for "self-determination."  The Prime Minister of Pakistan has sought the support of other Islamic nations.  The two nations have exchanged fire on several occasions, but both say there is no cause for concern.
column9: Moslem separatists exacerbate Kashmir situation; India and Pakistan tradecharges
column10: Moslem separatists in Jammu-Kashmir have turned to violence hoping to gainseparation from India.  Over 1,000 have died in the violence and repressionfrom government forces.  India and Pakistan hurl accusations and somebullets at each other but claim the situation is localized and not serious.
column11: India and Pakistan have feuded over Jammu-Kashmir since the subcontinentwas divided in 1947.  It is India's only predominately Moslem state with 64%of its five million people Moslem.  Moslem separatists began a campaign ofviolence in Jammu-Kashmir hoping initially to lead to union with Pakistanbut later for independence.  Indian authorities began a crackdown in January1990, and by summer, over a thousand people died.  India accused Pakistan ofarming and training the insurgents, a charge Pakistan denied.  Despiteincidences of soldiers firing across cease-fire lines, the two countriessaid the situation was local and not serious.
column12: Kashmir had been a separate kingdom ruled by a Hindu when Britainrelinquished colonial rule of the Indian subcontinent in 1947.   It waspartitioned on religious lines into India and Pakistan and Kashmir's Hinduking opted to be part of India.  The Jammu-Kashmir state is India's onlypredominately Moslem state with 64% of the state's 5 million people Moslem.Jammu-Kashmir has been a contentious issue between India and Pakistan fromthe beginning and the two have fought over it.  In 1990, separatistelements, most prominently the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, began acampaign of violence, including kidnapping, bombings, and assassinations.Initially, the Moslem separatists wanted to become part of Pakistan, butlater hoped to become an independent nation.  The Indian government began acrackdown in January of that year, imposing curfews and retaliating toinsurgent attacks.   By summer, police actions and separatists' violence hadresulted in over a thousand deaths.   India and Pakistan hurled charges ateach other with India claiming that Pakistan trained and armed theinsurgents, a claim that Pakistan denied.  Both nations sent troops to theborder area astride the cease-fire line and some shots were exchanged.Despite the tensions, both countries downplayed the incidents as beinglocalized and not serious.

column3: DOCUMENTS which show for the first time that both Mr Robert Maxwell and his son Kevin be intimately involve in substantial purchases of shares in Maxwell Communication Corporation, one of their own public companies, have be obtain by the Financial Times. Meanwhile, a director of a secretive swiss trust, Mr Werner Rechsteiner, have break his silence and have admit that transfers of MCC shares to his trust, which be at the centre of an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office, be make on the instructions of Robert Maxwell. This be the first time that Mr Rechsteiner have give details of the relationship between his mysterious trust, Yakosa Finanzierungs, and the Maxwell family. The FT have also obtain a letter and have see a corroborating fax which show that Mr Kevin Maxwell be intimately involve in the purchase of 9m shares by Yakosa and a further 16m shares by Servex, another swiss Trust. The MCC purchases by Yakosa and Servex be the object of an investigation by the SFO into an alleged illegal scheme to support the MCC share price. The SFO be also investigate whether Mr Robert Maxwell or Mr Kevin Maxwell breach the Companies Act by fail to disclose the purchases of the shares by the swiss trusts. If either have a financial interest in the swiss trusts, the purchases should have be disclose under company law, because they be both directors of MCC. The documents demonstrate that Bishopsgate Investment Trust, a private UK company control by the Maxwell family, provide Pounds 55.33m on behalf of the two swiss trusts so that they could pay for the MCC shares. Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, act as broker to the deals. Goldman's lawyers be convince that it act properly. Mr Rechsteiner yesterday break the silence he have maintain since Robert Maxwell's death in November on the subject of his relationship with the Maxwell family. He say MCC share purchases have be 'going on for some time' through Yakosa. He deny that the shares be buy for Yakosa's 'own account'. He say the shares be buy for other 'foundations' and then 'held for a certain time.' He also stress that ownership of the MCC shares no longer rest with Robert Maxwell once they have be receive by Yakosa: 'Yakosa be own by the Maxwell Foundation,' he said. Mr Rechsteiner refuse to say who control the Maxwell Foundation, which be base in Liechtenstein, but say it be neither Robert nor Kevin Maxwell. The FT have however obtain documents show that Mr Kevin Maxwell be closely involve in the process of pay for 25m MCC shares on behalf of two swiss trusts, Yakosa and Servex. On May 29 last year, Mr Kevin Maxwell send a fax to Mr Larry Wood, an executive director of Goldman Sachs, tell him that two parcels of 12.5m MCC shares each would be buy by the swiss trusts with Pounds 55.33m provide by BIT, a Maxwell private company. The fax, sign by Mr Maxwell, say that the funds would be remit to Goldman Sachs 'by Bishopsgate Investment Trust PLC from its account at National Westminter Bank plc, 41 Lothbury'. Two other faxes send by Mr Kevin Maxwell to Mr Wood on the same day show that the former be equally involve in the other end of the transaction, the sale of the 25m shares. The swiss trusts buy the shares, use Goldman as broker, from two Maxwell pension funds, Maxwell Communication Pension Trustee (Works Scheme) and Mirror Group Newspaper Pension Trustee (Works Scheme). Each pension fund sell 12.5m shares at a price of 219.78p a share, or pound 27.47m in total. At 6.29pm on May 29, Mr Maxwell send the two other faxes to Mr Wood on behalf of the two pension funds. As a director of MGPT and as a trustee of MCCPT, he tell Mr Wood to pay each pension fund what it be owe to the NatWest account of BIT, which Mr Maxwell describe as 'nominee' for the two pension funds. In other words, he tell Mr Wood that the shares be be buy for the swiss trusts with funds provide by BIT and that these funds should then be send by Goldman back to BIT. In the event, on May 31, Goldman receive the Pounds 55.3m by wire transfer in its account at Barclays. Goldman then levy its commission and expenses on the deal of Pounds 385,000 and wire the remainder back to BIT's NatWest account. Scots bank bows out, Page 8 Claims to Israeli shares, Page 8 Sir Nicholas Lyell QC, the attorney-general, will attempt to stop the curtain rise on Maxwell: The Musical, the West End show chronicle the life and times of the late Robert Maxwell. Fears that the musical might prejudice the criminal trial of the late publisher's sons, Kevin and Ian, have prompt Sir Nicholas to apply to the High Court on Monday for an injunction to halt the production. The musical tell the tycoon's life story through updated versions of familiar tunes from Gilbert and Sullivan. now in rehearsal, the show be due to open at London's Criterion theatre on February 11. The attorney-general's move to close down a west end production before its first night be regard as without precedent. However, it be no more unprecedented, most lawyers say, than the prospect of the Maxwell brothers have to commute to their trial at the Old Bailey past a theatre advertise the story of their father as 'the musical review that will make you laugh, sing - and be angry'. The musical, which have cost Pounds 1.1m to put on, have be produce by Mr Evan Steadman, a former chairman of one of Maxwell's private companies. Mr Steadman indicate yesterday he intend the show to go on and that the attorney-general's application for an injunction would be contested. However, he say he be leave matters in the hands of his lawyers. Press coverage of the late publisher since his death have already cause deep concern to the Maxwell brothers' lawyers . Mr Alun Jones QC, Kevin Maxwell's barrister, lead calls for report restrictions to be place on a recent high Court ruling that Robert Maxwell have be fraudulent in his dealings with shares in Berlitz, the publishing company. turn down his request, the judge ask him: 'Is it go to be your client's defence that Mr Robert Maxwell be not guilty of misappropriation?' At that point, lawyers in court themselves fell about laughing. MR MICHAEL STONEY, a senior executive in a number of Maxwell companies, be name as one of three people primarily responsible for more than Pounds 180m of 'unusual' payments from Mirror Group Newspapers bank accounts during the last financial year, accord to the chairman's statement release with MGN accounts yesterday. Mr Kevin Maxwell and Mr Ian Maxwell, two sons of the late Robert Maxwell, be name as the other two people most involve in these transactions. Mr Kevin Maxwell and Mr Stoney refuse to provide MGN with information, the statement says. Sir Robert Clark, chairman of MGN, list a series of transactions - some of which he stress may have be perfectly legitimate - that take place in the past few months. He say legal action may be take against a number of organisations, include Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, over more than Pounds 40m in transfers from MGN if the bank be aware that they be 'effected for improper purposes'. Notes to the accounts show that MGN make extraordinary provisions of Pounds 421.5m in the year to December 29 1991, include Pounds 208.6m in pension deficiencies and Pounds 122.4m in transactions with maxwell-controlled companies. Sir Robert say that during the year there be at least 28 'unusual' payments for more than Pounds 1m from the group's bank accounts, make a total of more than Pounds 180m. 'some may well ultimately be establish to have arise under legitimate transactions.' Nine of the payments be authorise solely by Robert Maxwell. The others be authorise mainly by Mr Kevin Maxwell, Mr Ian Maxwell and Mr Michael Stoney, he says. One transfer to Goldman Sachs be countersign by Mr Ernest Burrington, former manage director, at the request of Mr Kevin Maxwell on the report instruction of Robert Maxwell. Two authorisations be countersign by Mr Lawrence Guest, former MGN finance director. Sir Robert say the MGN directors do not believe that either Mr Burrington or Mr Guest know there be anything improper about these payments. With these exceptions, 'the independent directors . . . be not involve in, and do not authorise or approve any of these payments,' he says. Sir Robert say the group finance department accept assurances from the treasury department - which be head by Mr Stoney - about 'the nature of certain transactions' include payments to financial institutions which be record as deposits. 'The treasury department arrange for it to appear that sums of interest have be credit to the group in respect of those 'deposits',' he says.
