In his report Sir Robert points to 'certain weaknesses' accept by the MGN board: Internal controls and operating procedures which fail to identify related party transactions and bring them to the attention of independent directors for approval; Bank mandates authorise by Robert Maxwell and Mr Stoney which permit the movement of group funds on the authority of Maxwell or directors who be also directors of Maxwell-controlled companies; The audit committee of non-executive directors, which might have review systems and mandates, but be not convened; The finance department's inadequate authority to verify and record the treasury department's activities. The report details a Pounds 50m loan make by Bankers Trust in London last October which appear to have be use to pay off a loan from Bankers Trust in New York to Robert Maxwell Group, parent of the Maxwell private interests, Separately, the statement highlights three transfers of more than Pounds 40m from MGN to Goldman Sachs - pound 11m of this be transfer on Robert Maxwell's signature to pay for previous dealings in Maxwell Communication Corporation stock. The balance be for foreign exchange trade exposures incur by Bishopsgate Investment Trust and Robert Maxwell Group, it says. He say MGN be inquire to see whether it can establish if Goldman Sachs be 'aware or should have be aware' that the transfers 'had be effect for improper purposes'. If so, he say 'it will be possible to seek orders against them . . . for the sums paid.' He say MGN be consider legal action against professional advisers in relation to property leases, and hop to recover money through claims on insurance policies write on Robert Maxwell's life. ABOUT 20 banks become con-cerned last summer at the behaviour of businesses run by Robert Maxwell several months before he die and his business empire collapsed. Their concern arise when Maxwell Communication Corporation make late payments to them, a Financial Times investigation have discovered. Yet although some banks become alarmed at the implications for the financial health of his empire, they do not discuss their concerns with each other or with authorities such as the Bank of England. Mr Basil Brookes, MCC's former finance director, have describe his shock to the FT at discover last August that MCC have fail to settle foreign currency transactions with about 20 banks on time. start about July 4 1991, MCC's treasury, under the authority of Maxwell and his son, Kevin, have begin to buy and sell enormous amounts of foreign currencies. In these 'spot' transactions, MCC would buy a currency in one financial centre promising to make payment in another centre. On a number of occasions, MCC receive the currency, but do not make the payment - thereby give itself an unauthorised loan. Mr Brookes say about 20 banks, include Lloyds, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Swiss Bank Corporation, be involve in the flurry of foreign exchange deals. At least Dollars 100m (pounds 55m) in unapproved credit be think to have be raise this way. A former Maxwell employee say some appear to have be channel into private Maxwell businesses. One banker say attempts to raise money by make late payments in the foreign market be a relatively well-known ruse with the nickname call 'teaming and lading'. It also emerge yesterday that National Westminster Bank, the big lender to the Maxwell private companies, felt badly let down by Maxwell because he fail to deliver funds on time at the end of July. At a meeting between Maxwell and Mr John Melbourn, a NatWest director, on July 10, NatWest refuse Maxwell's request for a loan of Pounds 45m. NatWest be upset three weeks later when it provide funds - less than Pounds 100m - to the Maxwell empire on the understanding that it would be repay the same day, and then find that repayment be not made. NatWest be force to convert this 'intra-day' transaction into a short-term loan, which be eventually repaid. The bank tell both Robert Maxwell and Mr Kevin Maxwell that it be concern that repayment have not be made, but it do not discuss the problem with other banks or with the Bank of England. Instead, it press on with its policy of reduce the size of its loans to the Maxwell businesses. NatWest's loans to the Maxwell empire now total Pounds 182m, half the level of two years ago. later last year, Robert Maxwell make many repayments to banks by loot pension fund assets and also carry out unusual fundraising exercises with US investment banks, from which tens of millions of dollars be borrow at a high price. They also have say some questionable transactions may have occur after Maxwell's death.;in an interview publish today by the Daily Mirror, Robert Maxwell's London flagship newspaper, Kevin Maxwell be quote as say of the pensioners:;"i be desperately sorry for them. But I have to be honest. The debts be so enormous that when everything be sort out there will be nothing left.";one week ago, the Serious Fraud Office, a government prosecution agency, begin investigate Mirror Group Newspapers PLC's pension fund assets and related matters. The company say about $630 million be take from its pension fund without authority.;kevin Maxwell speak with the Daily Mirror as he fly to New York on Tuesday for talks on the future of the Daily News, which his father buy in March. Kevin Maxwell be now the publisher.;in a report today, The Washington Post quote unidentified sources as say Robert Maxwell never create the pension fund for Daily News managers he promise to start with funding from Tribune Co., which sell the paper to Maxwell. Pension money accumulate before the sale wasn't affected, it said.;Revelations of Maxwell's financial manipulations have lead to numerous newspaper characterizations of him as a crook.;"i have to say to myself that give the sequence of events and look at the whole picture, that a lot of it be fair comment," Kevin Maxwell be quote as say by the Daily Mirror.;Asked how he think his father died, he be quote as saying: "Suicide? not the remote possibility.";maxwell's body be find in the sea off the Canary Islands on Nov. 5. He have be cruise on his yacht. Preliminary findings by spanish pathologists indicate he could have fall into the sea after a heart attack.;kevin Maxwell have be link to transactions of a pension fund management firm at the center of the controversy over the miss money, investigators say. He and brother Ian be under court order to disclose by next week what they know about the affairs of Bishopsgate Investment Management Ltd., one of about 40 companies control by their father.;in another development, The Financial Times say today that documents show creditors face losses of at least $905 million on loans to Robert Maxwell's private companies. Maxwell's death end the reign of a contentious media baron who battle unions, bark out orders in eight languages and bully editors as he build a $2 billion media conglomerate.;"he be large than life . . . the Citizen Kane of his time," say British Conservative Party lawmaker Anthony Beaumont-Dark, refer to Orson Welles' classic movie about a publishing baron, presume to have be William Randolph Hearst. "If you write a film about his life, it would be reject as unrealistic.";a labor union leader once say Maxwell "could charm the birds out of the trees. And then shoot them.";the Czechoslovak-born Maxwell, who escape the Holocaust and emigrate to Britain in 1940, personally run his publishing empire, often make minute-to-minute decisions. Maxwell's sons, Kevin, 32, and Ian, 35, take over run the businesses Tuesday.;"What normal people consider pressure be meat and drink to Robert Maxwell," say Charles Wilson, editorial director of Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers.;His death prompt immediate concern in british financial circles about the future of his debt-laden empire and in New York about the future of the Daily News, one of the nation's large metropolitan papers.;among Maxwell's assets be the Macmillan publishing house in New York, Britain's no. 2 paper, the Daily Mirror, The Daily Record, and The European and British Printing & Communications Corp., Britain's large printing company.;on the steps of Mirror Group Newspapers in London, Ian Maxwell tell reporters the moment be tragic not only for his family but also for Maxwell's thousands of employees. "This paper have lose its publisher and its chairman and its savior.";british Prime Minister John Major call Maxwell "a great character who will be missed.";"maxwell be a passionate friend of Israel, and we be sorry about this heavy tragedy," Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said. "God bless his memory.";his body be find 20 miles northwest of Grand Canary Island after an extensive air-and-sea search, officials at the rescue center in Madrid said. The body be take by helicopter to the Gando air base on Grand Canary Island, where it be identify by Maxwell's wife of more than 40 years, Elizabeth, and their son, Phillip. An autopsy be plan for today, and the cause of death be officially still unknown.;Details of Maxwell's death be sketchy. He be last see alive on the deck of his yacht at 4:45 a.m. EST, Daily News spokesman John Campi said. At 11 a.m., a business call arrive from New York, and the crew discover that Maxwell be not aboard. Campi say Capt. Gus Rankin then radio a distress call. The body be find several hours later.;wilson say there have be no suggestion of foul play. "we can only assume that Mr. Maxwell slip and fell overboard," he said.;his mysterious death come as Maxwell be embroil in an international controversy, something common in a life that have the improbable, extravagant and sometimes mysterious character of British fiction.;maxwell have just be accuse in a book by reporter Seymour Hersh of have close ties to the Israeli secret service.;maxwell have deny the accusations. THE LATE Mr Robert Maxwell like to think of himself as a 'strong ' chess player and there be always a chess set in his suite in his London headquarters. 'There be no evidence to suggest that Maxwell actually be a strong player or that he play in any tournaments,' say Mr Malcolm Pein, international chess master and director of Chess and Bridge, which yesterday take over the business and assets of Maxwell Macmillan Chess and Bridge. There may be doubts about Robert Maxwell's strength as a player but less about his enthusiasm for the game. In 1990, through The European newspaper, he sponsor a section of the World Chess championships in New York. And when Pergamon be sell to Elsevier last year Maxwell keep the chess and bridge publishing businesses. Mr Pein say it have take most of the year since Mr Maxwell's death to prise the businesses, which include Chess Monthly and Bridge Monthly from the administrators to the Maxwell empire. 'Price Waterhouse take months and months to come up with any information about the company,' say Mr Pein. even when the new company have reach agreement to buy the business from Price Waterhouse, administrator to the public Maxwell companies they then run into trouble with Arthur Andersen, administrator to the private Maxwell businesses. Mr Pein say the new company want to use and pay for the premises of Maxwell Macmillan Chess and Bridge - prefabricate buildings in the village of Wheatley, Oxfordshire - until they find permanent premises. However, he say that Arthur Andersen want two years back rent. Despite the year of difficulties, Chess and Bridge be now set up in new premises in Euston Road, London. The company say it have the large collection of chess and bridge books and products in the UK. Two writs have be file allege that Goldman Sachs, the us-based investment bank, assist in divert Pounds 55m from two pension schemes control by Robert Maxwell to ensure its own debts from Maxwell interests would be repaid. The writs be file late last week in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan by trustees for Mirror Group Newspapers Pension Scheme and Maxwell Communication Corpora-tion Works Pension Scheme. The trustees seek more than dollars 100m for the sale of shares plus interest, commission charges and punitive damages from Goldman and Mr Eric Sheinberg, partner in charge of international equities trading. The writs centre on the purchase of Pounds 55m of MCC shares from the pension schemes by two swiss trusts, Servex and Yakosa, which be transact through Goldman and for which the schemes be never paid. The writs allege Goldman be aware the trusts be control by Robert Maxwell. The writs also allege that on May 28 1991 - the same date Mr Kevin Maxwell arrange for the pension fund share transaction to be pay for - Goldman be due to receive Dollars 58.2m for an unrelated transaction sell MCC stock to an unnamed american lawyer 'with close connections to Robert Maxwell'. The writs claim that Goldman be 'competing directly with its customer, the pension fund trustee, for payment'. On April 26 1991, they say, Mr Kevin Maxwell tell Mr Sheinberg to sell the pension scheme shares to the swiss trusts. On May 23 he tell Goldman to remit the proceeds of the sale not to the pension schemes but to Bishopsgate Investment Trust, which Goldman know or should have know be control by the Maxwell family. The writs allege that after the deal be strike Mr Trevor Cook, MGN pension fund administrator, tell Goldman that proceeds of the sale should be pay to the pension scheme, but when Mr Kevin Maxwell order the proceeds to be pay to bit. The writs say that Goldman and Sheinberg 'made no reasonable effort to determine who have actual authority to direct for the pension fund that the shares be sell and where the more than Dollars 47m in proceeds from the transfer of the 12.5m shares should go'. Goldman say it have 'received no money or other benefit from these transactions other than its brokerage commissions of Pounds 110,000 which be substantially less than the amount of the applicable stamp duties pay to the Inland Revenue of Pounds 215,000'. Mirror's flagship publication be the tabloid Daily Mirror, with sales of three million copies daily. last month, in another money-raising move, Mr. Maxwell's Maxwell Communication Corp. sell its Pergamon Press PLC unit for #440 million. In other changes, Mr. Maxwell's son Ian, who have be appoint deputy chairman of Mirror Group, will resign from his post at Maxwell Communication, where he be joint deputy manage director. Maxwell Communication say last month that its management would be take over by Kevin Maxwell, Ian's brother. Robert Maxwell buy Mirror Group in 1984 from Reed International PLC for #113 million. Through staff cuts and heavy spending on print facilities, Mr. Maxwell build Mirror into one of Britain's most profitable newspaper groups. In 1990, Mirror have profit of #37.2 million, or 28.2 penny a share, on revenue of #445 million. Proceeds from the share flotation will be use to strengthen and refinance the group's balance sheet. About #210 million will be use to pay back bank loans and the rest to pay in full a loan from Robert Maxwell Holdings Ltd. Salomon Bros. International be underwrite the international part of the offering, cover approximately one-third of the shares on sale, to be privately place with institutional investors in the U.S., Canada and Europe. The other two-thirds of the shares be to be divide between private and institutional investors in Britain. A relatively low minimum-investment figure of #250 have be set to attract small investors, particularly readers of Mirror publications.
column5: Death of Robert Maxwell raises questions of economic dealings.
column6: Economic confusion surrounds the publishing empire of Robert Maxwell following his death. Maxwell was found dead off the Canary Islands, apparently after having fallen overboard. Maxwell, along with his two sons, Kevin and Ian, and Michael Stone, a Maxwell executive, apparently were involved in the illegal transfer of funds.
column7: Economic confusion surrounds the mysterious death of publishing magnate Robert Maxwell. Maxwell, who put together a publishing empire following his immigration to Britain in 1940, was found dead off the coast of the Canary Islands after apparently having fallen overboard from his yacht. There are allegations that Maxwell, along with two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, and a senior executive in several Maxwell corporations, Michael Stoney, were involved in the illegal transfer of funds to help his publishing empire fend off debt. The scheme used Swiss trusts and a number of institutions, including the U.S. investment bank, Goldman Sachs.
column8: Robert Maxwell has been described as the Citizen Kane of his time. The mysterious death of this larger than life individual on November 5 has left the economic affairs of Maxwell Communications Corporation and Mirror Group Newspapers is a state of confusion. Maxwell was born in Czechoslovakia and immigrated to Britain in 1940 to escape the Holocaust. He put together and personally ran world-wide publishing empire that included Macmillan Publishing House in New York, Britain's Daily mirror, the Daily Record and the European and British Printing Company, and communications Corp., Britain's largest printing company. Improprieties have been alleged in the handling of funds which involve not only Robert Maxwell, but two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, as well as Michael Stoney, an executive in several Maxwell companies. At issue is the alleged improper transfer of funds in an attempt to handle his publishing empire's crushing debts. Among the interests named in the transfer of funds to two Swiss trusts, is the U.S. investment firm Goldman Sachs. Maxwell also is accused of using MCC in an effort to raise funds by making late payments on the foreign market. In doing so, MCC in effect gave itself an unauthorized loan.
column9: British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell and sons guilty of financial fraud.
column10: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation. His sons Kevin and Ian took over the Maxwell business but were soon found guilty along with their father of using illegal financial schemes and looting pension funds to pay off crushing debts.
column11: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, owner of the Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain and publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror and the New York Daily News, died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation.  His sons Kevin and Ian took over the business but were soon implicated along with their father in an illegal scheme to deal with crushing debts. Allegedly, unauthorized loans were acquired by using a Maxwell company to buy currency in one financial center while promising, but often failing, to make payments to another center. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds.
column12: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror, bought the New York Daily News in 1990. He then planned to raise $448 million through the sale of shares in his Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain. He bought Mirror Group in 1984 and turned it into one of Britain's most profitable newspaper groups.A year after the Daily News purchase, he was found dead in the waters off the Canary Island where he was vacationing on his yacht. Investigators say Maxwell siphoned money from his companies in an attempt to deal with crushing debts. Some $630 million was taken from his Mirror Group pension fund without authority. His sons Kevin and Ian, who took over the business, were investigated and found guilty for their knowledge of illegal schemes using two Swiss trusts, a private UK trust company and a US investment bank to support the Maxwell Communications Company (MCC). In a flurry of foreign exchange deals, the MCC would buy currency in one financial center promising, but often failing, to make payment in another center; thus getting an unauthorized loan. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds assets.

column3: Buenos Aires, 23 May (NA) -- today, the Foreign Ministry say that control operations carry out by the corvette Spiro against a korean-flagged [as received] ship fish illegally in Argentine waters be carry out "in accordance with international law and in coordination with the Foreign Ministry." The Foreign Ministry thus approve the intervention by the Argentine corvette when it discover the korean ship Chin Yuan Hsing violate Argentine jurisdictional waters on 21 May. The Argentine Navy report today that the corvette Spiro stay near the Korean ship "given the adverse weather conditions, and fulfil its responsibilities of sea search and rescue." The Korean ship, which have be fish illegally in Argentine waters, be sink by its own crew after fail to answer to the Argentine ship's warnings. The crew be transfer to the Chin Chuan Hsing, which be sail nearby and approach to rescue the crew of the sinking ship. The Navy report that around 15 nautical miles off the coast of Malvinas and "in accordance with bilateral agreements with Great Britain, the Spiro transfer assistance responsibility to british authorities." The Foreign Ministry say "an understanding with the UK for operations in cases of uninterrupted persecution of illegally fish ships be implemented." The Foreign Ministry also say the policy "is in accordance with the grow international opinion currently give priority to the preservation, regulation, and the sustainable use of marine live resources and the effective punishment of violators of national laws on the matter." An Argentine supply ship that run aground off Antarctica sink Tuesday in heavy seas and high winds, the government said, and there be concern oil in its hold could leak and damage the environment. The sinking of the 400-foot Bahia Paraiso follow warnings from the U.S. National Science Foundation that the unspoiled Antarctic could face ecological disaster if the 250,000 gallons of diesel fuel aboard the ship be to spill. No injuries be report in the sinking. Tourists aboard and the crew have be evacuate from the vessel, which be 600 miles south of Cape Horn, the tip of South America. Salvage efforts have be hamper by 50 mph winds. The double-hulled oceanographic ship sank at about 10 p.m., the government news agency Telam said, cite a navy communique. Telam do not say whether the ship break up or if diesel oil spill when it go down. The depth of the water in which the ship sank be not immediately known. The ship have be carry supplies include jet fuel, gasoline and canisters of compressed gases to the Argentine Esperanza station near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, the National Science Foundation say in a statement release in Washington. The ship run aground Saturday about two miles from Palmer Station, a U.S. research facility on the Antarctic Peninsula, the continent's tip. It sustain a 35-foot-long gash in its hull, and some of the 250,000 gallons of diesel fuel begin leaking, wash ashore near Palmer station. The fuel kill some krill, a tiny shrimp-like creature that be a vital part of the Antarctic food chain, and have affect penguins, sea gulls and giant petrel birds, the National Science Foundation statement said. There be no immediate details about the extent of damage to the wildlife in the pristine surroundings. Agency spokesman Jack Renerie say Tuesday before the ship sink that the leak, which be threaten penguins and other wildlife, have stopped. Scientists be concern that some research search projects may already have be affect by the leak, a foundation statement said. It say two Argentine salvage vessels be expect to arrive Thursday or Friday. Before the sinking, Argentine officials have discount a spill. Telam quote Argentine navy sources as saying: The fuel it carried, both for itself and the Antarctic stations, be in steel drums so a spill be practically impossible. The 316 people aboard the ship when it run aground, include 82 passengers and 234 crew members, be rescue by power boats and take to Palmer Station. The passengers and most of the crew be take by cruise ship to the South Shetland Islands, from which they be airlift to the south american mainland Sunday. But 104 crewmen remain at the station, say Renerie. Because the station be equip for only 40 people, food have be ration to two meals a day, a National Science Foundation statement said. Leopold Gratz, the president of Parliament and one of the most powerful politicians in the Socialist Party, resign today over a scandal surround the mysterious sinking of ship 12 years ago. Gratz, 59, be the second senior Socialist official to step down because of his alleged involvement in the so-called Lucona scandal, the subject of a widely publicize investigation by a parliamentary committee. Interior Minister Karl Blecha, like Gratz a onetime protege of former Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, resign Jan.19. Blecha and Gratz have deny wrongdoing or aid Udo Proksch, the prime suspect in the sinking of the ship Lucona in the indian Ocean. Six sailors died. The Lucona's cargo be officially describe by Proksch as for a uranium processing plant and insure for $16 million. The insurance company have never paid, claim the cargo be only scrap metal and allege the vessel be intentionally sunk to collect the insurance money. Proksch, want by austrian justice on suspicion of murder and insurance fraud, have be variously describe to be live in Syria, the Philippines and Latin America. In several interviews, Gratz describe himself as a close friend of Proksch, but when Proksch flee to escape prosecution, Gratz criticize him. Gratz tell Parliament today he would give up his seat in February, hence his post as president, one of the most prestigious posts in Austria. My decision be a personal one and it be politically motivated, Gratz tell the house. If it become impossible for the president to effectively take a stand on significant issues or to speak up on problems of parliamentarism because everybody be only interested in his context in a single other topic, then he cannot serve the National Council (parliament) in such a way as be his duty. In past newspaper stories, Gratz be accuse of provide fabricate evidence from abroad to help Proksch in his claim that the controversial shipment be for a uranium processing plant. Gratz, who deny the allegations, be also accuse of help Proksch in several other ways. Like Blecha, Gratz be to appear before the parliamentary investigation committee. A freighter carry a cargo of beer sank in the North Sea today off the Dutch coast and all nine crew members be rescue from life rafts, a coast guard spokesman said. The ship sink at about 12:45 p.m. in high winds, some 28 nautical miles north of the island of Ameland. It be not immediately clear what have cause the sinking 29 miles off the Dutch island of Ameland, accord to the coast guard spokesman, who be not identified. There be no casualties, he said. The coast guard official, who speak in a dutch radio interview, identify the ship involve as the Finnish-registered freighter Ra and say it have be carry a cargo of beer. He do not give the ship's origin or destination. The nine crew members board two life rafts after the sinking in high winds. They be take ashore by a west german helicopter from the island of Borkum, about 30 miles from the site of the sinking, the official said. A Dutch navy aircraft and two life boats also rush to the scene. Earlier reports have say that the ship be a passenger ferry, possibly one of the Dutch ships ply the frequent ferry lanes between the coastal islands and the Dutch mainland. Freight shipping in the area be also heavy because of its vicinity to the ports of Delfzijl in the Netherlands and Emden in West Germany. A deep-sea inspection of the Bismarck suggest that the most powerful battleship in Adolf Hitler's navy be scuttle by its own crew rather than sink by the british in a celebrated battle, underwater explorer Robert D. Ballard say Thursday. During a 90-minute news conference, Ballard describe how he his ocean-crawling robot locate the Bismarck sit upright and proud two weeks ago. then the american oceanographer, whose father be of british background and whose mother be of german heritage, address himself to the german people in German. I be an underwater explorer, not a treasure hunter, he said, translate himself back into English. We find no human remains. We touch nothing and take nothing. ... The future of the Bismarck be in the hands of the german people. He say he will disclose its exact location only to Germany so germans themselves can decide whether to try to raise the ship, which sink after a battle May 27, 1941. Ballard, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, say structural evidence satisfy him that the Germans scuttle the battleship rather than try to surrender or allow her to be send down by british fire. only scuttle ships tend to make it to the bottom in one piece, Ballard said. It appear the crew open it up along its entire length. It be clearly flooded, stem to stern. maybe the Germans didn't want it take as a war prize, he added. It be know that two years earlier, Hitler order the german pocket battleship Graf Spee scuttle after it be corner in the neutral port of Montevideo, Uruguay, and attack by british ships. Hitler apparently want to keep the british from learn the secrets of the Graf Spee's construction and weapons. In the 1941 battle, the Bismarck's main guns be quickly knock out and the attack british ships be out of range of her secondary guns, Ballard said, so its be helpless and take hundreds of hits its sink clearly inevitable. render unsteerable by torpedoes drop by tiny fabric-covered british biplanes, it be unable to escape. Asked if the german commander couldn't have surrender by cease fire, Ballard say in the fuzz of battle in fierce seas it would have be unlikely that the British would have recognize that the Germans be give up. Again, he speculated, perhaps the Germans do not want the ship's technologically advanced equipment to fall into british hands. The Bismarck be find by Ballard in more than 15,000 feet of water about 600 miles west of Brest, France. He say it be in remarkably good shape, elegant, well preserved. Before the battle, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill have leave convoys unprotected and thrown all his capital ships in pursuit with a ring three-word command: Sink the Bismarck! Of the Bismarck's 2,200-man crew, only about 115 survived. british ships pick up 110 survivors but leave with hundreds of german sailors still in the icy waters after spot what might have be a german u-boat. German vessels later rescue only five more survivors. The story have be recount in books, songs and a movie. The sinking occur only eight days after the Bismarck leave Gdynia, Poland, for her first operation. If unstopped, it could have pose a critical threat to convoy of merchant shipping and undercut british morale at a time when England stand virtually alone against combined german sea and air power. The british send the warship Hood after the Bismarck but within five days of go to sea the Bismarck have sink the Hood in a three-minute engagement, with the loss of all but three of the vessel's crew of 1,419. The Hood be a symbol of British sea power, and its loss stun the british public and the war government and make sink the Bismarck a mission of crucial importance. Ballard say under laws of the sea, the Bismarck remain the property of the german people. The sunken battleship be discover and photograph by the same remote-controlled robot that Ballard use four years ago to find the wreck of the Titanic, the british passenger liner that sink in 1912 after strike an iceberg. A yacht build for Adolf Hitler and sunk with great fanfare to commemorate the voyage of the Damned be mistakenly drop on a delicate coral reef in a shallow shipping lane, officials say Tuesday. They're go to have to move it, say Coast Guard spokeswoman Veronica Cady. The 85-foot Ostwind yacht be suppose to become an artificial reef in 250 feet of water about two miles off the coast. It be sink June 4, 50 years after the U.S. Coast Guard turn away the SS St. Louis as its more than 900 jewish passengers be seek refuge from the Holocaust. The sinking site be suppose to be near where the Coast Guard intercept the St. Louis, whose passengers also be turn away by Cuba and force to return to Europe. Most of the passengers later die in Nazi concentration camps. For unexplained reasons, the Ostwind be push off a barge about a mile north of the site, and be rest in 25 feet of water on a living reef. It be truly an incredible, incredible historic event, and suddenly boom! somebody make a mistake, say Mayor Abe Resnick, a Holocaust survivor and a sponsor of the event. Federal and Dade County officials who allow Resnick to sink the boat be upset about the result. They didn't even come close, complain Susan Markely, an administrator with Dade's environmental department. Coast Guard Lt. Al Crespo say the yacht be balance on a delicate living reef, threaten damage to coral and sponges. It's also close to an anchor spot for freighters and other vessels head to the port of Miami and have be mark with a flashing buoy, he said. It's close enough that if a ship swings on its anchor, it could hit it, Crespo said. The Army Corps of Engineers say the Ostwind must be move or cut to pieces by June 22. If it's not, the government will remove it and bill Resnick. Resnick blame the mistake on A.M. Daly Jr., captain of the tug that tow the yacht to where it be sunk. Daly, however, say Chris Cadley, captain of a passenger boat that accompany him, have agree to lead him to the site. Cadley deny that, say he only agree to meet Daly off the coast. Resnick say someone will have to pay. I think's that's go to end up be decide by attorneys, say Ben Mostkoff, the county's artificial reef director. The Ostwind be build at Hitler's direction, although he rarely use it. After World War II, the badly decay boat wound up in the hands of a Jacksonville marina owner. A Florida couple say their pleasure boat be sink by whales off Costa Rica and they survive 66 days at sea by eat raw fish and drinking purify water, the U.S. Coast Guard report Sunday. William Butler, 60, and Simone Butler, 52, of Miami, be weak but recover at a hospital in Golfito, Costa Rica, after be rescue by a costa rican Coast Guard ship Saturday afternoon, say U.S. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Egbert Vallecillo. The survivors tell authorities they lose about 50 pounds each from the ordeal, say Vallecillo, who speak to the couple by telephone early Sunday. The U.S. Coast Guard's Pacific Command be headquarter in Alameda, 10 miles east of San Francisco. William Butler tell Coast Guard officials their 40-foot pleasure boat Sibonay be attack and sink by several whales on June 15 about 1,200 miles southwest of Costa Rica. They be large, accord to Mr. Butler, Vallecillo said. But he didn't know how many whales. The couple's last radio contact be June 13, when they talk to their daughter in Miami, the Coast Guard spokesman said. Vallecillo say he'd heard of boats run into marine mammals when there's poor visibility, but isn't sure if there be any recorded cases of whale aggression. This happen in the early morning hours with good visibility, he said. This be the first (case) I've documented. As the boat be sinking, the couple said, they grab fish rods and a salt-water purifier and and get into a rubber lifeboat, where they remain for the next two months, Vallecillo said. As the lifeboat drift slowly eastward over two months, the Butlers said, they catch between 400 and 500 pounds of fish and survive multiple shark attacks by seal punctures with a raft repair kit. Butler tell U.S. Coast Guard officials that several times the couple spot merchant ships but be unable to flag them down. On Saturday, a Coast Guard ship make its fisheries patrol about 30 miles off the coast of Golfito spot the raft and rescue the couple. They be sail from Coral Gables, Fla., near Miami, to Honolulu, where they plan to vacation, Vallecillo said. Butler be an experienced sailor, he said. Their daughter, Sally Smith, and son, Bill Butler, be fly to Costa Rica on Sunday evening to be reunite with their parents, Vallecillo said. Greek divers have plunge 162 feet beneath the Aegean Sea and back into history, find a treasure-laden turkish warship sunk by greek revolutionaries in 1822. The remains of the wooden sailing ship be find near the island of Chios in the eastern Aegean at a point where historical accounts place the sinking of the Ottoman ship, accord to Peter Nicolaides, a diver and salvage expert. The Bourloti Seimaz or Explosives Invincible be set afire and sunk by greek Admiral Constantine Kanaris in revenge for turkish killing and loot on Chios. Thousands of islanders die in the Turkish raids, which shock other nations and swung western european countries behind the greek struggle for independence from the Ottoman Empire. Greece win independence in 1830. The french painter Eugene Delacroix produce a famous picture, The Massacre of Chios, base on the raids. It's an incredible discovery, straight out of the history book we use to read in school about the War of Independence, Nicolaides say in an interview Friday with The Associated Press. Nicolaides, who hear about the wreck while teach an underwater archaeology course to local divers last winter, start query fishermen about where their nets snag on seabed obstacles. He pinpoint the wreck on May 3, he said. When I dived, I find ships' timbers stick out of the muddy seabed and dozens of objects Islamic cooking pots, cannon balls, a candlestick, even a chalice from a greek Orthodox church, he said. The ship be obviously cram with loot from Chios. I think there may be gold and silver items as well, he said. I also saw what I recognize as human bones, he added. He say the wreckage indicate the vessel be at least 100 feet in length. accord to historians, more than 1,000 people include 400 greek captives be aboard the ship when Kanaris stag his attack in the early hours of June 7, 1822. The greek admiral sail from the nearby island of Psara, tow a boat stuffed with explosives. Its pointed bow be ram into the mouth of a cannon on the Bourloti Seimaz and a fuse lit. The Ottoman commander, Admiral Kara Ali, be kill in the blast that split the ship. Kanaris and his crew of Greeks escaped. This be a very significant, very emotive find, come from this particular period of history, say George Papathanassopoulos, the Culture Ministry's adviser on marine archaeology. Papathanassopoulos say the 162-foot water depth at the site will make investigation difficult since underwater archaeology rarely be attempt at depths over 113 feet, but he said, This be a ship that must be explored. Nicolaides say he hop it would be possible to tap american and turkish expertise to excavate the wreck as an international project. american experts from the Institute of Nautical Archaeology at Texas A & M University, work in cooperation with turkish divers, have pioneer underwater excavation off the turkish Aegean coast. Greek marine archaeologists focus on locating and survey historic wrecks scatter around the Aegean and rarely carry out excavations. Ferries be among the safe vessels afloat. But, as the tragic sinking of the Estonia with the loss of more than 800 lives demonstrates, when they do go down the toll in human life can be high. As ferries increase in size, so the numbers on board at risk from mechanical failure or a crew error go up. The move to roll-on roll-off ferries with vehicle decks which run the entire length of the vessel have increase the risk that, once the sea penetrate the hold through the bow doors or a gash in the ship's side, it can lead to the vessel capsizing. The United Nations International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and its members, the ship-owning nations, have devote much thought over the past two decades to ship safety. But the sinking of the Estonia should lead to a new review of ferry safety. particularly worry be the eyewitness reports which suggest that water penetrate the bow doors in a manner reminiscent of the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise in 1987. Unlike the Herald, the Estonia appear to have have its doors closed, but ro-ros be undoubtedly very vulnerable to water penetration. Any review of ferry safety should focus on three main issues. First the subject of ferry design should be reconsidered. Additional stability could be provide by the addition of sponsons, stabilising bulges which project from the ship's side just above the water line. Greater resistance to an influx of water could be obtain by instal moveable barriers or bulkheads to break up the large car decks. These proposals be look at by the british government in the wake of the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise. It calculate that it would cost between Pounds 70m and Pounds 85m to improve standards on the 57 vessels in the UK ferry fleet, with a further Pounds 22m in extra annual run costs. high costs would inevitably lead to high fares - unwelcome to ferry operators when, on the short cross-channel routes, they face competition from the Channel tunnel. But the difficulty of push through fare rises would be nothing like as damaging to the ferry companies as another disaster. Second, the IMO and national governments must look closely at how to improve enforcement of exist regulations. The IMO have be try to move enforcement up its agenda, but it depend on the good will and professionalism of governments and shipowners. Third, the IMO should be give support by national governments in its campaign, launch yesterday, to improve crew training. Much of the regulation in recent years have concentrate on improve the ship and its equipment. Above all, if new regulation do turn out to be necessary, it must be introduce speedily. As things stand, it can take years before changes be ratify by enough governments to give them force. The European Union, which Sweden and Finland be get ready to join, could take a lead in speed up the process. Ship safety be not, of course, just an issue for the ferry sector. Five (small) ferries be lose last year, accord to Lloyd's Register. But this figure pal into insignificance compare with the 96 general cargo ships and 12 tankers which also go down. When a cargo vessel with a third-world crew go down in a distant ocean, very little attention be paid. If the loss of a relatively modern passenger vessel in european waters can make shipping safety a high priority for governments and the public, this will be some small compensation for the loss of life from the Estonia. Two sailors be miss Monday evening after a 652-foot freighter en route from Greece apparently sink in rough seas 400 miles southeast of Cape Cod. Twenty-three crew members be rescued. The 23 sailors from the Star of Alexandria be find on a lifeboat and pick up by the merchant ship Ravenscraig, Coast Guard Petty Officer Randy Midgett say in New York. They're all in good shape, some minor cuts and scrapes, Midgett said. The two miss sailors be believe to be on a life raft, which be the object of a hunt Monday evening by the 950-foot Ravenscraig and five Navy and Coast Guard search planes, officials said. The Ravenscraig's crew spot a second life raft, but it turn out to be empty. The cause of the sinking be not immediately known, officials said. The Star of Alexandria have be en route from Athens, Greece, to New York with a load of cement when it begin take on water in 12-foot seas and wind up to 35 mph, Midgett said. The first mayday call go out at 9:05 a.m. A Coast Guard jet from the air station on Cape Cod and a c-130 plane from Elizabeth City, N.C., converge on the ship. The lifeboat be spot around noon. The C-130 be able to drop a radio into the water near the boat carry the 23 crew members and they be able to establish communications, Midgett said. About four hours later, they be rescue by the Ravenscraig. The Star of Alexandria be not spotted, and be presume to be sink or sunk, Midgett said. Visibility in the rough sea be five to eight miles Monday afternoon. The Star of Alexandria be build in 1966, and be register in England. It be design to carry bulk freight, and be own by Caribene Investments Ltd. of Gibraltar, accord to Bureau Veritas, a paris-based shipping registry. The Ravenscraig have be bind for England, but its destination after its rescue mission be not immediately known.
column5: Maritime Losses Continue. Estonia Lost With 800 Aboard. Bismarck Found
column6: Three freighters, two ocean-going yachts, a supply ship, a fishing vessel, and a ferry carrying 800 passengers were some of the maritime losses between 1888 and 1994.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled off France in 1941, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was located in 1988.
column7: Freighters sank off Cape Cod in 1989, and in the North Sea in 1988. A 1989 Austrian scandal grew out of the 1977 sinking of the Lucona. In 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank in Antarctica. In 1994 a Korean fishing vessel was scuttled while fishing illegally near Argentina. The Ostwind, once Hitler's yacht, was purposely sunk off Florida. An American pleasure boat was sunk by aggressive whales. In 1994 the ferry Estonia sank with 800 aboard.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled in 1989, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was found in 1988.
column8: Articles published between 1988 and 1994 demonstrate the widely diverse circumstances that surround the sinking of ocean-going vessels.Some articles addressed the locating of vessels sunk many years earlier. In May 1988 divers located a Turkish ship sunk by the Greek Navy in 1822. The Bismarck, Germany's most powerful battleship was scuttled off France in May 1941, and found in June 1944.The freighter Star of David went down in rough seas off Cape Cod on 17 April 1989. High winds prevailed when a Finnish freighter sank in the North Sea in September 1988. A 1989 scandal that involved Austrian politicians grew out of the mysterious sinking of the freighter Lucona in the Indian Ocean 12 years earlier.The Ostwind, a yacht built for Hitler, came to an ignominious end off the coast of Florida. In the same month whales attacked and sank the American pleasure boat Sibonay off Costa Rica.In January 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank two miles off the Antarctic Peninsula. A Korean vessel, fishing illegally in Argentine waters, was scuttled in May 1994 when apprehended by the Argentine Coast Guard.Eight hundred lives were lost when the ferry Estonia sank in 1994.
column9: Many causes responsible for sending ships to bottom of sea.
column10: Many reasons for ships sinking exist.  Ships that run aground from unseenhazards often sink.  Naval battles generally result in ships being sunk.Faulty design and rough seas may cause a ship to sink.  A crew may scuttleits ship to avoid capture or to conceal illegal activity.
column11: Severe weather at sea, faulty ship design, unseen obstacles, and hostileaction are some of the many reasons that ships sink.  At times, ships aresunk deliberately, by a dishonest owner in an insurance scam or by a navalcrew in wartime to foil an enemy or by a crew to conceal illegal activities.Loss of life very often accompanies a ship=B9s sinking.  Efforts to locatesunken ships are undertaken to determine why the ship went down and,sometimes, in the hope of recovering treasure.  Ships sinking are notuncommon events. In 1993, over 100 vessels went under.
column12: Ships sink for many reasons.  Many because of severe weather conditions atsea, some because they run aground, some because of design faults, some byhostile action, and some smaller vessels sink after encounters with marineanimals. Sometimes a ship sinking is deliberate.  Dishonest owners have sunktheir ships in order to collect insurance money.  Crews have deliberatelysunk their ship to prevent it from falling into enemy hands during wartimeor at other times to conceal evidence of illegal activity.  Older orderelict ships often serve to help establish a coral reef or become amemorial when sunk.  Many ships sink each year.  In 1993, 96 general cargoships, 12 tankers, and 5 ferries went to the bottom.Loss of life, sometimes heavy, usually occurs when a ship sinks.  A ferrysinking in 1994 caused more than 800 deaths.  Sea explorers search forsunken vessels to determine exactly where and often why they sank.  Somehope to recover treasures.Historic events have resulted from ships sinking.  In the 18th century, aship sinking figured in the Greek struggle for independence from the OttomanEmpire.  In the 20th century, two high Austrian government officialsresigned because of a scandal, which involved the sinking of a ship.

column3: John G. Tower have fallen, but the sky have not. For all the forecasts of dire results if the Senate block Tower's path to the Pentagon, business be proceed as usual. President Bush say the case be close and accept democratic assurances of future cooperation. That doesn't undo the resentment among some of Tower's more ardent republican allies in the Senate and in some corners of the White House. Bush lieutenants claim they have hear what sound like assurances of support from a dozen Senate Democrats. They end up with only three Democrats in the close-to-party-line vote against Tower. Nevertheless, a week after the former Texas senator be deny confirmation as secretary of defens, the waters have closed. There will be ripples, and some of them could be wave-sized. The good-behavior rules set in the debate over Tower's drink habits and his lucrative defense consulting business be certain to be invoke as precedents whenever Republicans spot a democratic target. We've establish what will be know as the Tower standards, say Sen. John Warner, R-Va. That argument will be use by House Republicans challenge the financial conduct of House Speaker Jim Wright. But it will be a debate point, not a turn point, in a Wright controversy that be ordain long before the Tower episode. While President Bush be unwavering in his support of Tower, he burn no bridges to congressional Democrats. He insist that Tower be the best man for the job and he speak out repeatedly for his choice, even after it be clear that the nomination be doomed. But he didn't get nasty about it, say there be no point in escalate the fight. That's over, he say 24 hours after the Tower defeat. That's history. And now we be go to go forward. The 53-47 vote against Tower be a setback to Bush in the sense that it always be a defeat when Congress deny a president something he wants. But this denial do not cost Bush a program, or a major campaign pledge, or the support of voters. Indeed, it could turn out that the Senate do the president a favor by send Tower back to Texas instead of to the Pentagon. It be a break Bush could not make with a political ally who have be after the Pentagon job since Ronald Reagan be elect president. Tower have not be a Reagan man he have support Bush for the 1980 nomination. And the Reagan White House go to some lengths to rule the senator out of the job he sought, declare that the new president would not be nominate any Senate Republican for any Cabinet post. After Tower's long wait, Bush display his own loyalty, all the way to a losing vote when the standard, somewhat safe course would have be to withdraw the nominee. Tower not only shun withdrawal; he offer conditions that have to be humiliating, if only the Senate would let him have the job. Tower promise to quit drinking, take the pledge on national television. And when that didn't work, he offer to become the first-ever probationary Cabinet member. Republicans propose that he get the job for a six-month trial and then return for reconfirmation, a gimmick that would have change the system and could have haunt the presidency. No deal. so Tower become the ninth Cabinet nominee ever to be rejected, the first who be a former senator. Bush say he have be fight for the right of a president to appoint his own Cabinet, but he avoid language that would have raise the political stakes. Tower do not restrain himself. Battling for the job, he say withdrawal would damage Bush and rejection would be damn the president's judgment. He say his nomination have be turn into a vehicle for a major presidential defeat. Tower's advocate on the Senate floor say grave constitutional issues be at stake, that the authority of the presidency be on the line, that the Senate will come to rue the rules it write in the Tower decision. But Bush say all along that the outcome, either way, would not hurt on other issues. Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee and the pivotal figure in the Tower defeat, agreed. He tell his Georgia constituents that the Tower rejection would not hurt Bush's leadership. In Washington, `triumphs' and `setbacks' be short-lived, Nunn said, and that's particularly true of the president. Retired Sen. John Tower, the defense secretary-designate, underwent surgery Thursday to remove a colon polyp, a hospital spokesman said. Senator Tower be rest comfortably and be list in fair condition, hospital spokesman Steve Habgood say Thursday night. The senator be expect to make a full recovery. Tower, 63, a U.S. senator from Texas for 24 years, be admit to Baylor University Medical Center on Wednesday after undergo a colonscopy examination last week that reveal the polyp, Habgood said. A preliminary biopsy of the polyp show it be benign, Habgood said, but further results would be announce Friday by Tower's surgeon, Dr. R.D. Dignan, of Dallas. Thursday's surgery take approximately three hours, Habgood said. When Tower undergo the colonscopy examination, a rectal polyp also be discover and removed. Tests of that growth show it to contain some malignant but well differentiated cells, Habgood said. Further explanation of the first polyp removal would have to come from Tower's surgeon, who be unavailable for comment Thursday night, the spokesman said. After leave the Senate in 1985, Tower go into business as a defense consultant. He also serve as an arms negotiator for President Reagan and he head the White House's Iran-Contra investigative panel. President-elect Bush designate Tower as his defense secretary on Dec. 16. The nomination be subject to Senate approval. Defense Secretary-designate John Tower contradict an early sworn statement when he tell the Senate his work for a british firm involve no military matters, accord to reports publish Saturday. Meanwhile, new questions be raise about the thoroughness of the FBI's background investigation of the embattled nominee. The Senate Armed Services Committee have put the nomination of Tower, a former Texas senator and onetime chairman of the committee, on hold while it take a second look at Tower's personal habits, include his use of alcohol, and his links to defense contractors. Tower, who have decline to be interview while his nomination be pending, have deny in his Senate testimony any problem with alcohol or any conflicts of interest concern his business ties. A White House spokesman, Stephen Hart, decline on Saturday to comment on the late reports, say it's (the nomination) before the committee. Tower's designate spokesman, attorney Paul Eggers of Dallas, do not answer a reporter's call Saturday. In write testimony to the Senate panel on Jan. 26, Tower say he could recall no actions in connection with any defense activities in connection with his work for the U.S. subsidiary of British Aerospace, Inc. That statement, accord to two publications, The Los Angeles Times and the Legal Times, do not square with information which Tower provide to divorce attorneys work for his second wife in June of 1987. In the divorce deposition, Tower say he go to work for british Aerospace eight weeks after resign as the nation's chief strategic arms negotiator and advise the company on how to sell train jets, fighter planes and missile systems to the Pentagon, the Los Angeles Times reported. Tower tell the Senate committee he work chiefly on sell commercial aircraft to U.S. airlines and also advise the firm on trade legislation and currency fluctuations. He say he earn $265,000 from the company between June of 1986 and last December. The Legal Times say Tower tell the divorce attorneys that he be retain by british Aerospace for his advice on how to sell weapons systems to the Pentagon, and that he list the various weapons involved. The deposition be never file in court because Tower do not contest the divorce, but a copy be obtain by the FBI, the Legal Times said. It say its reporters be allow by attorneys to read it with the understanding that it not be quote directly. The New York Post report Saturday that the FBI apparently have not bother to talk to Tower's neighbors, examine certain police records or investigate several car accidents involve Tower. The Post, cite syndicate columnist Cody Shearer, say the incidents include an early-morning episode on June 6, 1967, when Tower be trap in his hotel suite in Dallas by a blaze he accidentally set by drop a cigarette on an overstuffed armchair. When firemen break into his room to remove him, he be reportedly in no condition to free himself, the Post said. The newspaper also say Tower wreck his car in two early-morning accidents within weeks of one another in 1970, and, two years earlier, he drive into a bicycle ridden by James Patrick Montoya, son of the late Sen. Joseph Montoya, D-N.M., on his way home from work. The youth be not seriously hurt. FBI spokesman Bill Carter refuse comment on specifics of the Tower investigation, but say We will follow any lead. On Friday, Tower authorize the release of a statement that recent hospital tests show no evidence of alcohol abuse, and Vice President Dan Quayle said, I have never see drink be a factor in John Tower's life other than a social glass of wine. Eggers, meanwhile, acknowledge that there be no question that Tower sometimes drink too much in the early 1970s, but he said: He be not an alcoholic. He's not have a drinking problem for years.
