John Heinz of Pennsylvania and six other people.; Tower, 65, and his daughter Marian, 35, board the 30-passenger, turboprop Embraer 120 in Atlanta and be head to Sea Island, off the Georgia coast, for a party in Tower's honor.; Officials say they do not know the cause of the crash. The plane be descend in clear weather, authorities said, when it go down at 2:47 p.m. about three miles northeast of the runway at the Brunswick-Glynco Jetport.; Witnesses say the plane appear to have fall straight from the sky.; "it just go straight down. There be no cropping of trees," say Lt. Jack Hopper of the Glynn County Police Department, quote witnesses.; "it start in on its nose, and I know it be in trouble," say James Griner, who live a quarter-mile from the airport. "I go to the plane, but I couldn't get to it because of the fire. . . . When I get to it, it look compacted."; Atlantic Southeast's senior vice president, John Beiser, say officials have no indication from the pilot that the flight be in trouble.; Donald Day, the airline's manager of consumer affairs, describe the aircraft as "extremely sophisticated and fuel-efficient, one of the backbones of our commuter fleet." He say the plane be new and have be put in service in December.; The Brazilian-made Embraer 120 be manufacture by Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA. In 1984, an Embraer 110 Bandeirante, an early model of the 120, crash in Jacksonville, Fla., kill 13 people. The Federal Aviation Administration subsequently order an inspection of all Embraers for possible shear or worn rivets in the tail sections.; Tower's death prompt words of grief and praise among his former colleagues on Capitol Hill, even those who help derail his elevation to the Cabinet in 1989.; "I'm deeply sadden by the loss of John Tower, a tough, able friend and patriot," say Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, who break ranks with most Democrats to support President Bush's nomination of the 24-year Senate veteran to be defense secretary. "He be intelligent and have independence of judgment."; Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., who lead the successful fight against Tower's confirmation, said: "America have lose a patriot. . . . He fight for freedom and work diligently to make the world more secure."; "It's so sad," Bush said. "it be a tragic loss." Rep. Larry Combest, R-Texas, issue a terse statement Tuesday support defense-secretary designate John Tower but refuse to comment on a publish report that he tell Senate Armed Services Committee leaders that tower use to drink up to a bottle of scotch at a sitting. An unidentified congressional source tell The Washington Post that Combest's statement about Tower's drink habits in the 1970s come down on Sen. Sam Nunn, the committee chairman, like a ton of bricks and be a factor in Nunn's opposition to the nomination. The newspaper report that Combest later give a different story to the FBI, say that Tower and a group of friends not Tower alone have frequently consume a bottle of scotch. After meet with staff and advisers, Combest, who work for then-sen. Tower in the 1970s, issue a two-sentence statement support his fellow Texan. As a member of Congress, I have tremendous respect and full confidence in the senator and his abilities to lead this country's arm forces. In my judgment, John Tower will be a superb secretary of defense, the statement said. Combest spokesman Rich Adams refuse to comment further, and say Combest be not available to speak to reporters. The Washington Post report that Combest describe for Nunn and Sen. John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, Tower's heavy drinking bouts in the 1970s. A congressional source be quote as say that Combest tell the senators that Tower would drink as much as a full bottle of scotch two or three times a week. Trudi Boyd, Combest's administrative assistant, tell the Post that Combest originally go to Nunn and Warner to tell them Tower have end his previous excessive abuse of alcohol. Boyd also tell the Post that a group of people drink the entire bottle of scotch, not Tower alone. That be the account Combest give the FBI follow his talk with Nunn and Warner, the newspaper said. It say that in that account, Combest say that he have only see Tower drunk on two or three occasions. Tower have acknowledge that he drink excessively in the 1970s, but say he have reduce his intake to wine with dinner. On Sunday, he promise to not drink a drop of alcohol if confirm as defense secretary. Combest, 43, work for Tower for seven years, 1971-1978, as a legislative assistant handle agricultural legislation and policy. Tower serve in the Senate for 24 years, decide not to seek re-election in 1984. He be chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee from 1981 through 1984. The committee, now control by Democrats, vote 11-9 along party lines last Thursday to recommend the full Senate reject Tower's nomination. You would obviously expect Mr. Tower to say no, and he obliges: volubly and passionately. If that be all there be to "consequences," we could scan the dust jacket and invest our savings in local real estate. "Consequences" read a bit like a political Stephen King story as the small senator swell into a Beltway monster. Politics never have be for the squeamish, but the Tower controversy leave a much more disagreeable taste than do the senator's caperings (which mostly take place in the '70s anyway). Were the write less stiff and the narrative technique less choppy, "consequences" might have be a classic case study of late 20th-century politics out of control. Given Mr. Tower's qualifications for the job -- intelligence, patriotism and past chairmanship of the Armed Services Committee -- the nomination should have sail through with fly colors. instead it sink like the Bismarck. Clearly and apparently to his surprise, Mr. Tower have make many enemies since his arrival in Washington in 1961, often rub even supporters the wrong way. The senator from the Lone Star State could be lordly, in his english-cut suits. Once, meeting with the editors of my newspaper which have back him strongly, he think nothing of tilt back in his chair, cross his tiny, well-shod feet atop the conference table. When the Tower hearings opened, all manner of accusations come to public notice. The New Right activist Paul Weyrich claim to have see the senator consort with A Lady not His wife. It be report that Mr. Tower have chase a secretary around his desk and have fondle women at Bergstrom Air Force Base. The second wife, whom the senator have recently divorced, possess a repertory of tales she cheerfully volunteered. At his hotel, Mr. Tower be accord that doubtful tribute to instant-celebrity status, the media stakeout. The nominee issue fervent denials: He drink only wine, have long since swear off scotch; he'd never chase secretaries; his services for defense-industry clients have be proper and modest. none of the charges, at least on Mr. Tower's showing, prove to have the least substance. No use. Dirt be dirty than purity be pure, as one of John O'Hara's characters observes. Sen. Sam Nunn, Mr. Tower's successor as Armed Services Committee chairman, seem initially to smile on the nomination; then the rumor mill start churn and he change fronts. While endeavor to look statesmanlike, Sen. Nunn lean on moderate Democrats who would otherwise have support Tower. Sen. Nunn make the campaign personal, say Mr. Tower -- vote for me or vote for him. most Democrats, in the end, go with Sen. Nunn. What be all this about? Morality? Mr. Tower suggest instead that Sen. Nunn, a presidential hopeful, discover and seize an opportunity to show who be really no. 1 on national defense. Sen. Nunn have every reason to know that the moral and ethical charges level at Mr. Tower, and investigate exhaustively by the FBI, be flimsy. Yet he wave them about anyway. When the media retail lurid and unsubstantiated stories, Sen. Nunn purse his lips like a Georgia Sunday-school superintendent and suggest that a drunken Mr. Tower might accidentally press the nuclear button. "Sam Nunn," Mr. Tower insists, "used the FBI inquiries to discredit me and to strike at the president of the United States. The essential chain of good judgment and goodwill break down during my confirmation process." Sen. Nunn have company on Mr. Tower's dishonor roll. There be Sen. Ernest Hollings ("a study in arrogance and pomposity"), Sen. James Exon ("one of the most excessive regular boozers in the Senate") and NBC's Andrea Mitchell ("the most viciously partisan reporter I've ever seen"), along with the Washington press corps. Sen. John Warner, a Republican, be depict as fall all over himself to stay in good with Sen. Nunn. Mr. Tower feels, not without reason, that he be arraign on morals charges by cynical colleagues and media personages whom no one ever mistake for Southern Baptist deacons. "i don't so much resent my rejection by the Senate," Mr. Tower insists, "as the way it be done." "Tower, you be lynched," Mike Wallace, the CBS correspondent, tell him. Worse yet, the lynch mob remain at large. --- Mr. Murchison be a senior columnist for the Dallas Morning News. The democratic-controlled Senate today reject the nomination of former Texas Sen. John Tower as defense secretary, deliver a major rebuke to President Bush just 49 days into his term. The Senate's 53-47 vote come after a bitter and divisive debate focus on Tower's drink habits, behavior toward women and his business dealings with defense contractors. It be only the ninth time in 200 years that the Senate have vote to reject a president's Cabinet choice and the only time it have do so early in a new administration. Vice President Dan Quayle preside over the Senate during the roll call, underscore Bush's commitment to the nominee. The Senate galleries be pack and virtually all senators be in their seats as the roll be called. The nomination of John Tower to be secretary of defense be not confirmed, Quayle intone after the vote. Kansas GOP Sen. Nancy Kassebaum provide the big surprise of the final hours of debate when she become the sole Republican to declare her opposition. She say her most serious concerns be over Tower's activities as a defense consultant after serve as an arms control negotiator. She also express doubts that he would pay enough attention to ensure fairness for women in the military. Tower's Republican defenders begin to speak of him in the past tense and the nominee also appear to accept defeat, even before the roll be called. Just moments ago I take a call from John Tower, say Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the senior GOP member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. His head be high, his voice be strong, Warner said. He ask me to convey thanks in his words to the troops who rally to his support. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, move to repair damage cause by the bitter struggle to relations between the Senate and President Bush. I know what's in my heart and in my mind, he tell reporters. I want to directly, clearly and unambiguously say that this doesn't represent an effort to be harmful to the president. Dole agree to a late-afternoon vote on the nomination after acknowledge the collapse of a last-minute bid to give Tower an extraordinary six-month trial period as defense secretary to prove he could abstain from drinking. There be no doubt about the outcome as the Senate go through the motions of debate the nomination through the final hours before the roll call. The last few undecided senators declare their positions. Sen. John B. Breaux, D-La., say he would vote against Tower. Sen. James M. Jeffords, R-Vt., say he would support the nomination. Senators from both parties credit Tower's defeat to the decision to oppose him make by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee. When he make his decision all the other Democrats wheel in behind him, say Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I. With the prospect of defeat seemingly inevitable, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, If necessary, we'll come up with a (new) candidate very rapidly. Names most frequently mention in White House speculation as a replacement for Tower if his nomination fail be Sen. Warner, a former secretary of the Navy; former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld; former Rep. Jack Edwards, R-Ala.; and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. Scowcroft reply No when ask this morning if he be in line for the Pentagon job. It must be clear to all that people like the chief of staff and the national security adviser, any number of congressmen and senators and any number of other outside experts have candidates on the tip of their tongue, Fitzwater said. But the time have not come, he added. The time will come as soon as the vote be completed. We will wait until then. The most recent Associated Press survey show 52 Democrats and one Republican commit to vote against Tower or lean strongly in that direction. It show 41 Republicans and three Democrats declare for Tower or lean his way. Nevertheless, the White House say it want to see the nomination go all the way to a vote. Tower, meanwhile, report for work at the Pentagon where he and his three daughters have coffee together. He then continue a review of various administration proposals. I hope and believe we can work together on important matters, Mitchell said. The tension of this issue will have no long-lasting effect on the relationship. I want to say from the bottom of my heart that I hope this will be the case. The already slim chance Tower would be confirm be deal a crush blow on Wednesday as a parade of previously undecided democratic senators announce they would vote no. only Democrat Lloyd Bentsen of Texas say he would vote yes, join just two other Democrats who have make that decision. Sens. Charles Robb, D-Va., Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., and Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., all say they would vote against Tower. Johnston say his reading of the FBI report on Tower leave him with the clear impression that Tower's personality changes when he drink heavily, lead to a recklessness in the social sense entirely different from his behavior when sober.
column5: Former Texas Senator John Tower killed in plane crash.
column6: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in the crash of a commuter plane off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Defense. The Senate rejected the nomination following allegations of problems with alcohol and inappropriate dealings with defense contractors.
column7: Former Texas Senator John Tower and his daughter were killed in the crash of a commuter plane on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of defense, but the nomination was rejected by the Senate on the recommendation of the Senate Armed Services Committee. This was only the ninth time in history that a cabinet nominee has been rejected. The committee recommended rejection after hearing allegations about Tower's use of alcohol and his inappropriate behavior towards women. The committee also questioned his dealings with defense contractors after Tower gave contradictory testimony.
column8: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in a commuter plane crash on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. The crash, which killed everyone on board, also took the life of his daughter, Marian. Tower was recently the center of controversy when his nomination for Secretary of Defense was rejected by the Senate Armed Forces Committee and the full Senate. Tower became only the ninth nominee in history to be rejected. He also was the first nominee ever to be rejected so early in the term of a new presidency. Tower's rejection followed allegations of problems with alcohol. Tower admitted that he had been a heavy drinker in the 70s but that he has since limited his drinking to a glass of wine with dinner. Tower, twice divorced, also was accused of inappropriate behavior towards women. The Senate Armed Services Committee also called into question his contradictory testimony on his dealings with defense contractors. Tower told the committee that his advice to British Aerospace was limited to civil aviation matters while in a 1987 deposition written for his second divorce, he said he advised the company on selling certain systems to the defense department.
column9: Ex-Senator John Tower, rejected for Defense Secretary, killed in plane crash
column10: Former senator John Tower's bid to become Defense Secretary failed on a53-47 vote in the Senate.  Tower's drinking, womanizing, and questionabledealings with defense contractors led to his defeat.  No lasting damage torelations between the Senate and the president are expected.  Tower waskilled in a 1991 plane crash.
column11: President Bush picked former senator John Tower of Texas to be Secretary ofDefense.  His choice was popular with Senate Republicans and he was expectedto win easy confirmation.  However, questions arose regarding Tower=B9s moralcharacter, heavy drinking, womanizing and lucrative dealings with defensecontractors.  Tower said earlier problems with alcohol were behind him, butthere were indications that they still existed. The Democratic controlledArmed Services Committee voted 11-9 against recommending Tower. The fullSenate rejected Tower 53-47 with one Republican voting against him and threeDemocrats for him.   John Tower and his daughter were killed in a planecrash in 1991.
column12: John Tower of Texas served in the US Senate for 24 years, retiring in 1985.President-elect George Bush named him to be Secretary of Defense.  Justbefore Senate Armed Services Committee confirmation hearings began, Towerhad surgery for the removal of a benign colon polyp.  Initially, members ofthe committee and early witnesses had praise for the former senator.However, later testimony suggested that Tower was a heavy drinker andwomanizer.  Tower conceded that years earlier he had problems with alcohol,but said those days were behind him.  Questions continued to surface thatthose days were not that long ago.  The FBI was lax in investigating thoserecent incidents.  An editorial supporting Tower conceded that he hadearlier "boozed it up and fooled around" but said that recent charges didnot have substance.  Tower's testimony that he had not dealt in defensematters when on the payroll of British Aerospace contradicted an earlierdeposition in which he said he did just that.  The committee, controlled byDemocrats, voted 11-9 against recommending rejection of Tower.  The fullSenate rejected Tower 53-47, with one Republican against him and threeDemocrats for him.

column3: President Bush be expect to name a female career diplomat as U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua as that country prepare for a new era under President-elect Violeta Chamorro, accord to inform sources. The sources say Thursday it be virtually certain the appointment will go to Melissa Wells, 57, currently ambassador to Mozambique. They say the administration believe a female ambassador could relate good than a man to Mrs. Chamorro, who take office Wednesday. They also say the administration be eager to have more women in key posts. only rarely have U.S. ambassadorships in Latin America go to women. In choose Ms. Wells, the administration pass over several male career diplomats with long experience in that region, say the sources, who ask not to be identified. Ms. Wells, who be bear in Estonia, have no prior experience in Latin America. Her personnel record indicate she speak Spanish. Wells' name be submit to the White House by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for the Managua post, and approval be consider 99.9 percent certain, one source said. The United States and Nicaragua have not have ambassadors in each other's capitals since July 1988. The sandinista government expel then-u.s. ambassador Richard Melton and seven other U.S. diplomats on the grounds they be interfere in Nicaragua's internal affairs. The Reagan administration retaliate by expel nicaraguan Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann and seven of his subordinates from the nicaraguan embassy here. But a new era in u.s.-nicaraguan relations be expect to open with the inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro, who defeat President Daniel Ortega in elections this February. Vice President Dan Quayle and a large congressional delegation be expect to represent Bush at her inaugural. The administration have ask Congress for $300 million in assistance to Nicaragua, part of which would be use for resettle Contra rebels. But the request have be stall by Senate Democrats, some of whom believe that Eastern Europe have a great claim on U.S. resources than Nicaragua. Wells' nomination as ambassador to Mozambique in 1986 encounter strong opposition from Senate conservatives who hold up the appointment for 11 months in protest against U.S. policy toward that country. The nomination finally be approve in September 1987. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., a leader of the campaign to hold up Wells' nomination, say he want to pressure the administration into deal with rightist guerrillas oppose to Mozambique's Marxist government. Mozambique have since moderate its policies and be now off the U.S. government's list of countries under Marxist rule. The Bush administration be expect to name career diplomat Harry Shlaudeman as the first U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua in almost two years, a U.S. official says. The administration have plan to send another career diplomat, Melissa Wells, to Managua but have a change of heart after conclude she might face a prolonged Senate confirmation fight because she have be a target of conservatives. The administration be eager to have an ambassador in Managua quickly because of the delicate political situation there now that U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro have take over after almost 11 years of rule by the leftist Sandinista party. Mrs. Chamorro face the demanding challenges of revive Nicaragua's bankrupt economy and achieving national reconciliation after long years of warfare. The United States have have no ambassador to Nicaragua since July 1988. At the time, the Sandinista government expel Ambassador Richard Melton and seven others at the embassy on grounds they be interfere in the country's internal affairs. The Reagan administration retaliate by expel eight nicaraguan envoys in Washington, include Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann. Shlaudeman, who have serve as ambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil and Venezuela, be a premier State Department specialist on Latin America and be expect to win easy Senate confirmation. He retire from the foreign service a year ago but be call back to duty last fall to serve as a State Department liaison with the nicaraguan Contra rebels. Shlaudeman, who will turn 64 next week, be approach by a senior State Department official weeks ago about go to Managua but say he be not interested. He tell intimates he would agree to go only if ask personally by President Bush. When Bush telephone him earlier this week, Shlaudeman agree to the appointment, the U.S. official, who speak on condition of anonymity, say Wednesday. In addition to his ambassadorial posts, Shlaudeman be the top Latin America aide to President Ford in the mid-1970s and a diplomatic trouble-shooter in Central America under President Reagan. The U.S. official say Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and several of his conservative allies would not assure the administration that they would not delay Wells' nomination. When Wells be nominate to be ambassador to Mozambique in late 1986, Helms and his colleagues block her appointment for 11 months. They take the action as a mean of express opposition to the Reagan administration's friendship toward Mozambique's Marxist government. Security Council meeting of heads of state, President Bush reaffirm the U.N.'s leading role in peacemaking. The assignment in India could be an important one. India and its neighbor Pakistan remain embroil in a long, bitter feud that have the potential of become one of the world's few remain nuclear standoffs. Mr. Pickering be one of President Bush's first ambassadorial appointments. He serve at the U.N. during the time the administration be involve in the delicate negotiations that lead to the formation of the coalition against Iraq in the persian Gulf War and the U.N. sanctions against Saddam Hussein's regime. But some senior State Department officials have be irritate by what they call Mr. Pickering's propensity for the media spotlight. During the 1980s, when the Reagan administration draw the line against communist-backed insurgences in Central America, Mr. Pickering play an active role in that effort as U.S. envoy to El Salvador. Mr. Perkins be the U.S. ambassador to South Africa in 1986, when the U.S. imposed economic sanctions against that nation's white-minority government to pressure it to end apartheid. Mr. Perkins, who be black, travel widely across South Africa during this period, making sure he be see in black townships, attend church services and funerals, as well as in white communities. Mr. Pickering, reach over the weekend, refuse to comment on his future plans, and Mr. Perkins couldn't be reached. Ronald I. Spiers, a veteran U.S. diplomat, will be the new undersecretary-general for General Assembly affairs, the top-ranking american post at the world body, U.N. officials say Tuesday. Spiers be ambassador to pakistan from 1981-83 and have serve as ambassador to the Bahamas and Turkey. He replace Joseph Verner Reed, a banker who serve in the post from 1987 until leave last winter to become chief of protocol for the United States. Although Spiers' nomination as undersecretary-general for Political and General Assembly Affairs and Secretariat Services have be an open secret for months, secretary-general Javier Perez de Cuellar announce it be effective as of Tuesday. Spiers, 64, be a career foreign service officer, most recently serve as undersecretary of state for management since 1983. Spiers have be a member of the U.S. delegation to the United Nations; be director of political affairs for the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; and be director of NATO Affairs for the State Department. From 1966-69, Spiers be counselor for political affairs in the U.S. Embassy in London. In 1969, he become assistant secretary of State in charge of the department's Bureau of Political-Military Affairs. When the Bahamas become independent from Britain in 1973, Spiers become the first U.S. ambassador to that nation. He become charge d'affaires in London in 1974, and be minister of the U.S. Embassy there until 1977, when he be appoint ambassador to Turkey. In 1980 he return to the State Department as director of Intelligence and Research, and be appoint ambassador to Pakistan in 1981. Joseph B. Gildenhorn, the lawyer and real estate developer name by President Bush as U.S. ambassador to Switzerland, and his immediate family give nearly $230,000 to Republican campaigns since 1984, disclosure statements show. Gildenhorn, accord to Senate sources, be one of several Bush ambassadorial nominees who have be rat unqualified by the american Academy of Diplomacy, an organization compose of former high ranking diplomats, include all living former secretaries of state. One of a lengthy and grow list of Bush supporters and contributors name to diplomatic posts, Gildenhorn give $100,000 during the 1988 presidential campaign to the Republican National State Elections Committee. The gift be not subject to the disclosure requirements of the Federal Election Campaign Act. The 84 contributions make between 1984 and early this year by Gildenhorn and members of his immediate family be be use by Senate Democrats to illustrate their complaint that too many GOP contributors be be give choice diplomatic posts better reserve for Foreign Service professionals. Gildenhorn say Friday he could not comment because he be in a confirmation process. A report prepare by the State Department for the Foreign Relations Committee say Gildenhorn would make an excellent candidate for an ambassadorship because of his solid background in law and management. It also cite another qualification. Mr. Gildenhorn have be a strong Republican supporter be a member of the Eagles and Team 100, the State Department said. The republican Eagles be contributors of $10,000 or more in a single year to the Republican National Committee, while Team 100 designates people who have donate $100,000 or more. Gildenhorn's political contributions be list on a disclosure form submit to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which have set a hearing on the nomination for this week. They total $14,675 in 1984, $17,000 in 1985; $25,469.97 in 1986; $25,250 in 1987; $104,350 in 1988; and $11,000 this year. The total: $197,744.97. Additionally, his wife, Alma Lee, give $20,125 over the six years, include $13,000 in 1988; his daughter, Carolyn, give $2,000; his son, Michael, give $4,050 and his father, Oscar Gildenhorn, give $5,750. That bring the total contributions make by Gildenhorn and his family to the GOP to $229,669.97 since 1984. Gildenhorn give $50,000 during the period to the Republican National Committee or to the Republican Eagles. He give $2,500 in 1985 and $5,000 in 1986 to the Fund for the American Future, a Bush political action committee and contribute the legal limit of $1,000 to the Bush campaign in 1987. Gildenhorn also give thousands of dollars to Republican congressional candidates. include be gifts to the campaigns of Sens. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn.; Bill Cohen, R-Maine; Pete Domenici, R-N.M.; Arlen Specter, R-Pa.; John Warner, R-Va.; Orrin Hatch, R-Utah; Bob Kasten, R-Wis.; and former Sen. Paula Hawkins, R-Fla. Gildenhorn, 59, be a senior partner in Brown, Gildenhorn and Jacobs, a law firm specialize in real estate. He be also president of the JBG Real Estate Associates and JBG Properties Inc. Gildenhorn be also vice chairman of the board of directors of the Sovran Bank here. He be a graduate of the University of Maryland and Yale University Law School. other ambassadorial nominees rat as unqualified by the american Academy of Diplomacy include Florida real estate developer Joseph Zappala, nominate as ambassador to Spain; Melvin L. Sembler, a real estate executive in Florida name to be ambassador to Australia; and Della M. Newman, a Seattle, Wash., real estate broker name to be ambassador to New Zealand. No action have be take by the Senate on any of those nominations. accord to Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., who first raise the issue of political contributions, Zappala and Sembler each contribute more than $100,000 to Republican candidates and causes. Mrs. Newman serve as chairman of the Washington state Bush for President committee. Ambassador David Popper, president of the Academy of Diplomacy, decline to confirm that Gildenhorn and the other three nominees have be rat as unqualified to become ambassadors. But he say the academy do offer such ratings, make its judgments base on a comparison of the nominee's biography and the requirements of the job. He say the nonpartisan academy have no objections to political appointees as such but do believe political nominees should be qualify to run a complex embassy and represent the United States abroad with dignity, respect and ability. Twenty of 29 ambassadorial nomination make by Bush in the first six months of his administration have go to non-professionals, many of them large contributors to Republican causes, committee sources said. Sarbanes say the appointments be lard the diplomatic corp with amateurs reward for purely political services. Political throwaways, Sarbanes call them. I think the time have come, very frankly, to get off the money merry-go-round and ask some very difficult questions, essentially about when extensive political contributions be go to be a sufficient basis to gain an ambassadorial nomination, Sarbanes tell the committee last month. It's not true in every instance, but in most of these cases you seem to have to be over the $100,000 mark in order to make the consideration list, Sarbanes said. Sarbanes say he be not against political ambassadors as such, note that many of them compile distinguish records. It be not the political ambassadors that be the problem, Sarbanes said. It be ambassadors without qualifications. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today endorse the nomination of Michigan Republican activist Peter F. Secchia as ambassador to Italy, but the panel's chairman say he fear Secchia might embarrass the United States because of his penchant for make gross remarks. The committee's vote be 13-0 in favor of Secchia, a former Republican national committeeman for Michigan and lumber industry executive. The chairman, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., vote present, mean they take no position. Pell insert into the hearing record newspaper account contain the distasteful specifics of Mr. Secchia's remarks. At his confirmation hearing earlier this month, Secchia pledge to be far more careful as a diplomat in his use of colorful language than he have be in his different role as a political organizer and enthusiast. But Pell say he be unpersuaded. Tact and careful speech be hallmarks of successful diplomats, Pell said. Mr. Secchia have demonstrate that he would bring opposite qualities to the position of ambassador to Italy. Italian friends of mine telephone me from Rome, aghast at the prospect of have Mr. Secchia represent the United States in their country, the chairman said. I believe that this nomination be a mistake, and in all likelihood Mr. Secchia will be an embarrasment to the administration and the United States, Pell said. But he say that since Secchia be the president's choice he would not try to block the nomination or delay action on it. President Bush have name career diplomat Deane Hinton as ambassador to panama, the White House announce Tuesday. Hinton, currently ambassador to Costa Rica, replace Ambassador Arthur H. Davis, who be recall by Bush in protest of what the administration consider the stealing of the panamanian elections last May by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush send Davis back to Panama City after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama by U.S. forces and installation of Guillermo Endara as president. Independent observers mostly conclude Endara have win the elections by a hefty margin. Bush name Hinton as a recess appointment because Congress be not in session. That mean Hinton can serve until the end of next year before he must go before the Senate for confirmation. The appointment of the 66-year-old Hinton, with his long expierience on latin american issues, be see as a signal of the importance Bush be place on restore normal relations with Panama. Those relations steadily deteriorate after the United States indict Noriega, once a ally particularly of the U.S. intelligence community, on drug trafficking charges in Florida. Hinton have be ambassador to Costa Rica since 1987. Before that he be ambassador to Pakistan from 1983 to 1987, and ambassador to El Salvador from 1981 to 1983. He be assistant secretary of state for economic and business affairs from 1979 to 1981, and before that U.S. representative to the 12-nation european Community, headquarter in Brussels, a State Department adviser on economic affairs, and director and economic counselor of the State Department's Agency for economic Development in Chile and in Guatemala. Davis, a former State Department consultant and former ambassador to Paraguay, be send to Panama by President Reagan in 1986. Bush want to name his own ambassador and the time be appropriate with the installation of a new government in Panama, say one administration official. Officials describe Hinton as an experienced Latin America hand and a good person to have in place with the volatile developments in the south american country. On Capitol Hill, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, call Hinton highly qualify for the post because of his wide-ranging experience and expertise in Central America. However, Mitchell say he hop Bush would send the appointment to the Senate after Congress convene Jan. 23 despite the nature of the recess appointment.
column5: Bush ambassadorial nominees include veteran diplomats and big campaign contributors
column6: Veteran diplomats nominated by Bush as ambassadors included James Lilley (China), John Negroponte (Mexico), Deane Hinton (Panama), Harry Shlaudeman (Nicaragua), Thomas Pickering (India), Wesley Egan (Jordan), and Edward Perkins (UN). Bush also nominated campaign contributors Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland), and Peter Secchia (Italy).
column7: Bush nominated veteran diplomats James Lilley (formerly CIA) to China, John Negroponte (who helped direct CIA aid to Contras) to Mexico, Deane Hinton to Panama,  Harry Shlaudeman to Nicaragua (over Melissa Wells), Thomas Pickering to India, and Wesley Egan to Jordan (interpreted there as signaling Jordanian importance to the US).  Edward Perkins became UN ambassador. Nominees Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland) were said qualified only by large campaign contributions, and nomination of loudmouth Peter Secchia (Italy) was called a mistake. Other nominations included Shirley Temple Black (Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican),  Keith Brown (Denmark), and William Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column8: Bush ambassadorial nominations of veteran diplomats included JamesLilley (former CIA officer) to China, John Negroponte (who asambassador to Honduras helped direct CIA aid to Nicaraguan rebels) toMexico, Deane Hinton (former ambassador to El Salvador and Costa Rica)to Panama following the US invasion, Harry Shlaudeman (formerambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil, and Venezuela) to Nicaragua(over early favorite Melissa Wells, who had no Latin Americanexperience and might have faced confirmation delays), and ThomasPickering (experienced in delicate situations concerning Iraq and ElSalvador) to nuclear power India. Jordan saw the appointment there ofseasoned ambassador Wesley Egan as a signal of Jordan's importance tothe US.  At the UN, Foreign Service Director Edward Perkins replacedPickering as ambassador and Ronald Spiers got the top-ranked Americanpost. The ambassadorial nominations of Joseph Zappala (Spain), MarvinSemble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn(Switzerland) were approved despite charges that their onlyqualifications were large campaign contributions. Senate ForeignRelations Chairman Claiborne Pell called the nomination of PeterSecchia as ambassador to Italy a mistake because of his bigmouth. Routinely approved nominations included Shirley Temple Black(Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican), Keith Brown (Denmark), andWilliam Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column9: President's ambassador selections get Senate committee approval, some narrowly
column10: Most of President Bush's ambassadorial nominees won easy approval in senatecommittee hearings.  A few, however, faced opposition from Democrats incommittee who believed they were nominated only because of largecontributions to the Republican.  But all were finally approved.
column11: Some of President Bush's nominees for ambassadorships have been selected asa reward for large money contributions to the Republican Party, according toDemocratic senators, and some retired diplomats consider a few not to bequalified.   These nominees faced strong questioning from the Democratsduring committee hearings but did manage to get a slim approval from thecommittee.  Conservative senators objected to two of Bush's selections.Most of the president's picks won easy approval.  Two of Bush's picksreceived highly favorable reaction: a Latin American expert for ambassadorto Nicaragua, and the naming of Thomas Pickering, a well-known diplomat, toIndia.
column12: Senate confirmation hearings for President Bush's nominees forambassadorships have shown mixed results for the administration.  Somenominees like Shirley Temple Black the designated ambassador toCzechoslovakia, sailed through the process. The nominees for Spain,Switzerland, Australia, and New Zealand faced strong questioning duringSenate committee hearings but were eventually slimly approved.  Democratsand retired diplomats believed that three of the nominees had no realqualifications but were picked because of large money contributions to theRepublican Party. Democrats also had concern about the nominee to beambassador to Italy.   Senator Jesse Helms and other conservatives objectedto one nominee because he was a Democrat and were thought likely to havesuch strong objections to another that her name was withdrawn.  That womanwas initially picked to be ambassador to Nicaragua since that country was toinstall a woman as president but the potential objections led to a seasonedLatin American expert being named.  The administration picked ThomasPickering, the ambassador to the UN to be ambassador to India.  Thisselection of a well-known diplomat underscores the administration concernregarding the Indian subcontinent where India and Pakistan, both now nuclearcapable, continue to feud over Kashmir.

column3: Police bulldoze unstable brick and mud houses today while those left homeless by an earthquake that kill at least 749 people sought shelter and awaited government aid. Casualty reports continue to trickle in from remote parts of this Himalayan mountain kingdom as relief workers fan out through the foothills and valleys. Sunday's pre-dawn quake strike near the India-Nepal border. Some roads be flood by heavy rains that follow the quake. Others have cracks three feet deep or be block by boulders the size of houses. At least 549 people be kill in Nepal, say Tek Bahadur Thapa of the Home Affairs Ministry. Dharan be hard hit. At least 131 bodies be find in the city of 100,000. indian officials have maintain since Monday that the death toll in their country be 200 or less, but the figure be question by opposition politicians, survivors and the local media, include the Times of India, a newspaper that generally support the government. They put the India death count at anywhere from 400 to 1,500. indian officials say 200 people be injure in the quake. nepalese officials list 752 injured, down from their early estimate of 1,000. In Bhaktapur, a city of 50,000 where seven people die in the quake, 63-year-old Nhuchhe Raj Sakya say his five-story brick and mud house have nearly fall down but that he and his family of 10 be still live in it. What else can we do? the goldsmith said. We have no tent. How can I leave my place? Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha visit Dharan on Tuesday and survey heaps of bricks that be once three-story and five-story houses. This be the big calamity to strike Nepal, Shrestha say as he tour the town. Dharan, 105 miles southeast of Katmandu, sits on a rolling plain at the base of a steep hill. most of the victims die in their houses, which be make of bricks hold together by mud that have loosen during the seasonal monsoon rains. Police Inspector G. Adhikari say bulldozers have demolish more than 50 houses deem too dangerous for habitation. We will continue to demolish houses until we be satisfied (the ones remaining) be safe to live in, he said. Adhikari say local officials have not yet hear from the government on compensation or new housing for people whose homes be demolished. Most of the homeless have move in with neighbors or find shelter in tents erect on the soggy earth. The earthquake, which strike when most people be still asleep, register 6.5 on the Richter scale and be the deadly quake in the region since 1950, when a temblor in the east indian state of Assam kill 1,500 by official count and 30,000 by seismologists' accounts. Aftershocks have persist since Sunday's quake, and rumors of an impending new quake send thousands of people flee into the streets in panic before dawn Tuesday in Katmandu and Dharan. The rumors start with anonymous telephone calls and spread by word of mouth. In Dharan, men run from houses to houses rouse people from their sleep. Rescuers search through debris today for victims of an earthquake that ravage one-third of this country's territory and parts of India, kill at least 650 people and injure thousands. The death toll be expect to climb from Sunday's pre-dawn quake on the India-Nepal border, which trigger landslides and floods and be the mountainous region's deadliest in 38 years. Officials in both countries say they have yet to receive reports from the remote Himalayan areas hardest hit by the temblor, which knock out power and communications and be say to injure at least 3,000 people. Niranjan Thapa, Nepal's minister of state for home affairs, tell a news conference at least 450 be dead and up to 1,000 injured. He say officials expect the numbers to climb. indian officials report at least 200 people dead and more than 2,000 injured, most by debris from collapse buildings. The quake, center almost on the india-nepal border, register 6.5 on the Richter scale. indian television today show the devastation in the indian state of Bihar: crumble buildings, makeshift morgues line with rows of bodies wrap in white shrouds, damage hospital wards pack with survivors. Medical teams in India carry medicine and other supplies to overcrowded hospitals and the army be deploy to help search for victims. But the monsoons, which hit the subcontinent in late June and usually last through September, hamper relief operations. Nepal's Thapa tell a news conference that the rains have be a great hindrance in carry out rescue works. Access to some areas of this mountain country be impossible. He say 21 of the kingdom's 75 districts suffer extensive damage. The hard hit appear to be Dharan, a sparsely populated border region where Thapa say at least 131 people died. Bir Bahadur Shahi, secretary of the home affairs ministry, flew to eastern Nepal on Sunday. He say 50,000 to 60,000 houses be destroy in the Dharan district alone. Ninety percent of the remain houses be cracked, Shahi said, add that most of the damage be to modern houses of stone and old houses from mud and bricks. Wooden houses be not affected, he said. many people be give shelter in schools, guesthouses and public buildings, but most of the people do not want to leave their homes, Shahi said. He say water supplies be still adequate and there be no reports of disease break out. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi fly to Bihar to tour some of the hard hit areas. The government say it would release a detailed report after he return to the capital tonight. Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha of Nepal visit some of the victims at Bir Hospital in his capital, Katmandu. The quake rouse people from their sleep in Bihar and nine other indian states and central and eastern Nepal. It last about a minute and aftershocks continue for about an hour. Rail tracks sink into the soggy ground and bridges over rise rivers cracked, paralyze train service and road travel in many parts of the devastate areas. Parts of northern Bangladesh and the capital, Dhaka, also felt the tremor. There be reports that 50 people be injured, most by jump from their houses during the quake. Witnesses in Darbhanga, an indian city of 800,000 about 45 miles south of the epicenter, say the only warnings be hiss sounds, rattle doors and crack windows. Women begin blow conch shells, follow an ancient tradition believe to appease the weather gods. more than 25,000 houses be flatten in Darbhanga, as well as the districts of Munger and Madhubani, Indian officials said. In Madhubani, the Bhootahi Balan River jump its banks and flood nearly 50 villages. Officials say at least 45 people died, but it be not know whether the deaths be due to floods or collapse houses. It be the bad quake to strike the region in 38 years. A temblor rumble through the indian state of Assam on the India-China border in August 1950. official accounts say more than 1,500 people died, but seismologists say their records show 30,000 be killed. The Richter scale be a gauge of energy release by an earthquake, as measure by ground motion record on a seismograph. Every increase of one number mean the ground motion be 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas. Rescue workers cop with aftershocks and heavy rain today in an effort to reach remote regions of the Himalayas to help victims of an earthquake whose official death toll near 700. Rumors predict another large quake send thousands of panic-stricken people flee from their homes in India and Nepal. Sunday's pre-dawn quake register 6.5 on the Richter scale and claim at least 497 lives in Nepal and 200 in india, government officials said. Officials in both countries say they expect the death toll to climb when reports arrive from regions difficult to reach even in good weather. The quake injure at least 2,000 people in India and 1,000 in Nepal, officials said. In Biratnagar, a city near the indian border 150 miles east of the nepalese capital Katmandu, residents pour into the streets before dawn today as men run from houses to house, shout that a message come from Katmandu that a new quake be expect before dawn. Police in the city of 300,000 people say they receive no such message. I have try to tell them they be make a mistake, but no one will listen to me, say Dabal Singh, an inspector. Anonymous telephone call with similar rumors rouse hundreds of people in Katmandu, also before dawn. Sunday's quake be felt in the capital, but no deaths or serious damage be report in the city. In Patna, India, thousands of people huddle in the rain in open courtyards Monday as rumors swept the city that another quake be imminent. Patna be the capital of Bihar state, the bad hit area in India. A quake register 5.1 on the Richter scale shook eastern Nepal late Monday afternoon, but there be no immediate reports of new casualties or damage. In general, however, the intensity of aftershocks have lessened. Compared to the ones on Sunday and Monday, they have be declining, Madhav Prasad Pandy, senior seismologist at Nepal's Department of Geology, say in Katmandu. He say most aftershocks have decline to a reading of 1 on the Richter scale. Rain continue in quake-affected areas, hamper access on muddy roads already crack by the quake. Landslides block many roads to devastate areas. Railroad track sink into the mud, and the quake also crack bridges over rivers swell by the monsoon. In India, the area with the great damage and casualties be just south of the border in Bihar, India's poor state. News reports say 400 people die in Bihar state, double the indian government's count. Bihar officials say the reports be exaggerated, while opposition politicians in the state accuse the government of suppress information and claim the death toll be close to 1,500. Tremors flatten more than 25,000 houses in India, officials said, and the Bhoothai Balan River flood nearly 50 villages in the Madhubani district. indian army soldiers help with relief efforts, and the navy and air force be put on alert. Nepalese soldiers, police and volunteers join forces in the kingdom's remote mountains and valleys. Niranjan Thapa of the Home Minstry report extensive damage in 21 of Nepal's 75 districts and at least four affected districts report 50 or more deaths. Officials distribute 88-pound bags of rice to families in this kingdom of 17 million people. Government officials say many offers of assistance have come from abroad, but no decision have be make about whether to accept them. A U.S. Embassy official say the embassy have offer $25,000 in immediate aid but have not receive a response. The quake be the bad in the region since a temblor in India's eastern state of Assam kill 1,500 people in 1950, accord to official accounts. Seismologists say their records show a death toll of at least 30,000. The Richter scale measures grind motion as record on seismograph and each number represent aa tenflod increaase in intensity. A quake of 6 on the scale be capable of cause severe damage, while one measure 5 can cause considerable damage. Police bulldoze teeter houses Tuesday to keep people from return to homes leave unsafe by an earthquake that kill at least 731 people in India and Nepal. Officials in both countries expect the death toll to rise as relief workers reach remote towns that have be inaccessible since Sunday's devastate quake. Some roads be flood by heavy rains that continue Tuesday, while others have 3-foot-deep cracks or be block by boulders the size of houses in the Himalayan mountains and valleys. At least 531 people be kill in Nepal, say Tek Bahadur Thapa, additional secretary in the Home Affairs Ministry. Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha visit Dharan, one of the hardest-hit towns, and survey heaps of bricks that be once three-story and five-story houses. This be the big calamity to strike Nepal, Shrestha say as he tour the town. India report an official death toll of 200, but the figure be dispute by news media and opposition politicians who put the indian death count at anywhere from 400 to 1,500. In Darbhanga, India on Tuesday, worshipers offer sweets, milk and coconuts to appease the Hindu god of destruction. Women dress in colorful sari gather at countryside temples in the quake-ravaged areas of eastern Bihar state to pray and present their offerings to Lord Shiva, the god of destruction in the Hindu trinity. If God be pleased, nothing will happen, say one woman, who refuse to give her name. The earthquake, which strike shortly before daybreak Sunday when most people be still asleep, register 6.5 on the Richter scale. It be the deadly quake in the region since 1950 when a temblor in the east indian state of Assam kill 1,500 by official count and 30,000 by seismologists' accounts. Dharan, 105 miles southeast of Katmandu, sits on a rolling plain at the base of a steep hill. At least 131 bodies have be find in the town of 100,000. most of the victims die in their houses, which be make of bricks hold together by mud that have loosen during the seasonal monsoon rains. Police Inspector G. Adhikari say bulldozers have demolish more than 50 houses deem too dangerous for habitation. We will continue to demolish houses until we be satisfied (the ones remaining) be safe to live in, he said. british soldiers from a nearby Gurkha recruiting center pitch in with cranes to aid the demolition. Dharan be in the heart of regional famed for fierce Gurkha fighters who have serve in the british army for more than 150 years. Adhikari say local officials have not yet hear from the government on compensation or new housing for people whose homes be demolished. Most of the homeless have move in with neighbors of found shelter in tents erect on the soggy earth. The hard hit areas in India be in Bihar state just across the Nepalese border. Rescuers in army helicopters search for survivors in Bihar's Darbhanga, Madhubani and Mungar districts. other helicopters ferry medicine, rice, cook oil, clothes and tents to police trap in the most remote regions of Bihar, India's poor state. Heavy rains, overflow rivers and submerge bridges and roads hamper attempts by 1,000 indian soldiers to provide assistance. In Nepal, 88-pound bags of rice be be distribute to families affect by the quake, but officials be unable to give any figures. International agencies operate in Nepal be gear up to contribute supplies or assistance but have not yet hear from the government on what be wanted, accord to several foreign relief workers who speak on condition of anonymity. Shrestha say the mountain kingdom have not seek foreign aid because we be still assess the magnitude of the tragedy. Some supplies, medicine and health workers arrive in eastern Nepal on Tuesday. Donors include UNICEF and the government of Japan and Britain. Nepal be one of the world's poor countries. two-third of the children under age of 5 suffer from malnutrition and life expectancy be 52, accord to UNICEF. A nation of 17 million, Nepal have one doctor for every 22,650 people, compare with 5,000 people per doctor in India and 780 per doctor in the United States. The rumors start with anonymous telephone calls and spread by word of mouth. In Dharan, men run from houses to houses rouse people from their sleep. The parents of a Peace Corps worker learn Thursday that their son, a volunteer in Nepal, be safe follow an earthquake last weekend that kill at least 750 people in that country and neighbor India. They call this morning, that's the first we have hear about anything since the quake, say Arthur Giaquinta, whose 24-year-old son, Peter, live in a village 10 miles north of the hard-hit Dharan Bazar township. Jim Flanigan, a Peace Corps spokesman in Washington, say Peter Giaquinta be fine as far as we know. In Boston, the brother of Peace Corps volunteer Bettyjean Bouffard, 27, say Thursday she call her relatives to say she be safe. The call, say Dave Bouffard, be the first news the family have have of her safety. We're ecstatic, he said, add that his sister have be live with a nepalese family five miles from the earthquake epicenter. Flanigan say the Peace Corps have be able to track down all but three of the 157 volunteers in Nepal. There be no Peace Corps members in India, he said. The three, he said, be from Michigan, Wisconsin and the Philadelphia area; he decline to release their names. We have a problem with roads out, monsoon rains, Flanigan said. In the best of times, reach some of these volunteers be several days. A strong earthquake hit the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal and parts of eastern India on Sunday morning, trigger landslides and collapse buildings. First reports say 100 people may have died. Nepal's Department of Geology say the earthquake strike at 4:54 a.m. (7:09 p.m. EDT Saturday) and measure 5.7 on the Richter scale. The department say the quake be center near Udayapur, a town near the indian-nepalese border and 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal's capital. Officials say the temblor last about 40 seconds. In New Delhi, the Seismologoical Observatory say the quake measure 6.5 on the Richter scale. The state-run Radio Nepal say at least 27 people be kill in the towns of Bhaktapur and Dharan when they be bury by collapse houses. Press Trust of India news agency say that in addition to 100 fear dead in India and Nepal, 1,000 people be injure in the indian states of Bihar, Sikkim and West Bengal. A nepalese journalist in Dharan, 130 miles southeast of Katmandu, say by telephone that 20 people have already died. A large number of injured be be take to local hospitals and a rescue operation be under way. Men of the Royal Nepal Army, police, social workers and other local inhabitants be take part in the rescue operation. The journalist add that 90 percent of the house of Vijapur area of Dharan collapsed. Police report seven people die in Bhaktapur, an ancient town seven miles east of Katmandu, while 20 others suffer injuries. The quake be also felt in the indian capital of New Delhi and Calcutta, but there be no report of any casualties. One hard-hit indian city be Dharbhanga in Bihar state, where 14 children be believe kill when their school hostel collapsed. Dharbhanga, with a population of 200,000, be 550 miles east of New Delhi. Several homes in the residential areas of Dharbhanga have collapsed, kill an unspecified number of people. The Richter scale be a gauge of energy release by an earthquake, as measure by ground motion record on a seismograph. Every increase of one number mean the ground motion be 10 times greater. The death toll from the Himalayan earthquake top 750 on Wednesday as rescue workers hamper by monsoon rains, aftershocks and wash out roads reach remote areas of Nepal and find more bodies. In eastern India, which also be devastate by the quake, cracks be find in the embankments of six rivers in Bihar state, and officials say floods could pose the next threat to the 10 million people. It may be the second coming. All the rivers be in full spate, and if the embankments breach, we be in for serious problems, say Puranman Mittal, the relief commissioner in Bihar state, which suffer the most damage in India. Bihar residents run scream through the streets on Wednesday when a mild tremor rumble through the area. No casualties or damage be reported, witnesses and the Seismological Observatory in New Delhi said. Residents in Dharan, the worst-hit area of Nepal, also race from their homes Wednesday during two aftershocks, officials in Katmandu said. No far damage be report in the city, where 100 houses collapse during the quake. Rescue workers demolish 50 homes in Dharan on Wednesday that be severely damage in the temblor, police inspector G. Adhikari said. We will continue to demolish houses until we be satisfied (the ones remaining) be to safe to live in, he said. This be the big calamity to strike Nepal, Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha, say Tuesday after a tour of devastated areas in his nation. At least 758 people die and 950 be injure in both countries Sunday when the earthquake jolt the mountainous india-nepal border region. It be the deadly quake to strike the subcontinent since 1950, when, by official count, 1,500 people be kill in the eastern indian state of Assam. Indian officials say Wednesday that at least 196 die in India in Sunday's disaster. Officials in Nepal say at least 562 people be kill in Nepal, include 31 people whose bodies be find in remote areas on Wednesday. In India's Bihar state, officials say the water have reach dangerous levels and be still rise in six rivers: the Ganges, the Ghagara, the Burigandak, the Bagmati, the Koshi and the Mahananada. To make matters worse, survey teams find cracks in the embankments of the six rivers, which be swell by monsoon rains that begin in late June. Engineers try to strengthen the weakened embankments with cement, and helicopters make aerial surveys watch for ruptures. As survivors in both countries begin rebuild homes damage or destroy by the quake, medicine, food and financial aid begin arrive from abroad. Elroy J. Carlson, an official at the U.S. Embassy in Katmandu, say the United State offer $25,000 in aid. In New Delhi, U.S. Ambassador John Gunther Dean present the government with a similar amount for indian victims. Michael Hamilton, an official at the british Embassy in Katmandu, say three medical teams have be send to dharan. The teams be carry two truckloads of blood and medicine, Hamilton said. The british army also run a military hospital in Dharan, where at least 100 people be admitted. The government hospital in Dharan treat hundreds of people injure when brick and wood houses collapsed. U.N. agencies and the Red Cross also send medical teams to Nepal, and the government begin distribute 90-pound bags of rice. The relief efforts be hamper in both countries by heavy rains which cut off communications and road links to several of the affected areas. The earthquake hit a wide area, and it be a big job to reach the remote villages. But we be trying, say Mittal, the relief official in Bihar state. An earthquake that devastate parts of Nepal and India earlier this week have kill more than 980 people, officials from the two countries say Friday. Mourners parade through the streets of this medieval town, call for revenge after a former legislator be beat to death by political rivals while he be distribute relief supplies to earthquake victims. Hang the murderers, scores of young men chant as they march in front of a jeep bear the battered body of Karna Hyanju, once a sympathizer of the now-outlawed Communist Party. Witnesses say Hyanju be beat with umbrellas and sticks late Thursday afternoon, then drag through the streets for nearly two hours before police intervened. He die Friday at the Bir hospital in Katmandu, 7 miles west of Bhaktapur. Uttam Dhaubanjar, a 28-year-old bank employee and neighbor of the dead man, say Hyanju have be hand out blankets, milk and other food in Bhaktapur when he be accost by a group of men who accuse him of give relief supplies only to his own supporters. Reports of damage and devastation continue to arrive from remote parts of Nepal on Friday, and the Home Affairs Ministry update its confirmed death toll to 704. In India, the official count rise to 277. But survivors, the news media and opposition politicians say the toll could be as high as 1,500. Sunday's earthquake register 6.5 on the Richter scale, which records energy release by a tremor accord to ground motion measure by a seismograph. A reading of 6 indicate the possibility of severe damage, while 7 signifies a major quake. Dhaubanjar say he saw about 40 people round up by police Thursday night after Hyanju's beat death. He say many belong to the same Communist faction that Hyanju once supported. People start beat him with umbrellas, Dhaubanjar said. There be a lot of scratches on his body, and a lot of blood. It look like one ear be missing. then they make a necklace of their shoes (by tie the laces together), put it around his neck and pull him through the streets. As Hyanju's body be take through the wind streets of Bhaktapur, a 12th-century town of ancient Hindu temples, thousands of the town's 50,000 people jam streets, temple steps and the balconies of brick and mud houses. Pashupati Rana, one of several Cabinet ministers who march in the funeral procession, say several people be arrest in the killing, include the mayor, the deputy mayor and a member of the Rashtriya Panchayat, or non-partisan assembly. Rana, who be minister of local development and legislative, affairs, call Hyanju's death political murder. Hyanju serve in the Panchayat from 1981 until 1986 when he lose the backing of the Communists in Bhaktapur, traditionally a leftist stronghold. The Panchayat, whose members be elect on non-party lines, be create after the late king Mahendra abolish the old Parliament and all political parties in 1960, say a western-style parliamentary system be not suit to his mountain kingdom. Dhaubanjar and a group of young men who gather around him say Hyanju be perceive as a government supporter despite his previous communist leanings. A strong earthquake trigger landslides and destroyed houses in the mountainous india-nepal border region early Sunday, kill at least 237 people and injure more than 1,500, officials and news reports said. Seismologists say it be the deadly earthquake to strike the Himalayan region since 1950. more than 100 people die when the quake rumble through the eastern indian state of Bihar, officials said. In Nepal, authorities say at least 137 people be dead. Officials in both countries predict the death toll would rise after they receive reports from remote areas which be hit harder. The tolls have come in only from urban areas, say V.K. Sharma, deputy secretary in the Bihar government. The temblor also jolt parts of northern Bangladesh and the capital of Dhaka, but there be no immediate reports of casualties or damage. Witnesses say windows and doors rattled, buildings crack and people rouse from their sleep run scream from their homes as objects tumble from shelves and tables. My bed rattled, then it begin swinging, say R.N. Rudra, a resident of Patna, the Bihar capital. My dogs begin bark and I rush out of the house. At least 1,000 people be injure when the quake trigger landslides and house collapses in Bihar and the surround states of Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Orissa, all heavily populated, largely agricultural areas. The quake also be felt in Sikkim and Tripura, locate in the Himalayan foothills, the Press Trust of India news agency said. In Nepal, a Foreign Ministry official, Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya, say more than 500 people be injure and thousands of houses collapse from the quake's impact. most of them (were) bury alive under collapsed houses, say Indra Shrestha, a social worker involve in the rescue operation in Dharan Bazar, a township of about 100,000 people about 18 miles from the indian border. Shrestha say rescue operations be be hamper by the monsoon rains, which hit the subcontinent in late June and usually last through September. Both countries be rush emergency medical teams to the area. The Red Cross of Nepal issue urgent appeals for blood donations. In India's Bihar state, communications with Darbhanga, which appear to be the worst-hit area, be disrupted. The Press Trust of India say a school hostel in the town collapsed, kill at least 17 children. It say more bodies be fear bury under the debris. The quake damage most of the houses in Darbhanga, the news agency said, quote P.K. Patnaik, the top civil administrator in the district. Deaths be also report in the neighboring towns of Munger, Keoti and Narpatnagar. The tremor also be felt in the eastern city of Calcutta, Press Trust of India said. There be no immediate reports of casualties but residents be quote as say windows of several homes vibrate and doors rattled. The Seismological Observatory in New Delhi say the quake hit at 4:40 a.m. (7:10 p.m. EDT Saturday) and be center 40 to 50 miles northeast of the town of Darbhanga in Bihar state, along the india-nepal border. Observatory Director H.N. Srivastava say the quake measure 6.5 on the Richter scale. Srivastava say the quake last about one minute and aftershocks continue for about an hour. Seismologists warn aftershocks could continue for days. The U.S. Geological Survey say its initial seismograph readings place the center of the quake 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, the capital of Nepal. Geological Survey monitors in Golden, Colo., record the earthquake at a preliminary magnitude of 6.7 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale gauge the energy release by an earthquake as measure by the ground motion record on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 6 be capable of cause severe damage. Earthquakes be common in the Himalayan region. On Aug. 6 a quake of magnitude 7.3 shake the states of Assam, Manipur, West Bengal and Bihar. Four people be killed. India's bad earthquake be in 1950, when at least 30,000 people be kill in Assam state.
column5: Strong Himalayan Quake Kills 704 in Nepal; 277 in India
column6: Sunday's strong, Himalayan earthquake, triggered landslides and collapsed houses. Authorities say 704 died in Nepal, 277 in India. Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered search and recovery efforts throughout the quake area. Flooding is possible.Of Nepal' 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers.
column7: The official death toll in Sunday's pre-dawn Himalayan earthquake is 981, 704 in Nepal and 277 in India. Many, especially in Dharan, Nepal, died when brick houses that used rain loosened mud between the bricks, collapsed in the 6.5 (Richter scale) quake. Bihar, India, where authorities say 200 died, is also threatened by flooding.  Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims throughout the quake area. Of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers. The U.S., Britain, and the international community are sending aid to the devastated area.
column8: On Friday, Nepal updated its death toll from Sunday's Himalayan earthquake to 704 as reports arrived from remote area. In India, the official death toll rose to 277, 200 of which were in Bihar, but the press and others claim as many as 1500 may have perished. Bihar is also threatened by flooding from swollen rivers.The quake, measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale, struck at 4:54 a.m. (local). According to Nepal's Department of Geology, it was centered near Udayapur, Nepal. Monsoon rains, overflowing rivers, submerged bridges and roads and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims in throughout the quake area.In Dharan, Nepal, over 131 bodies were found, most in collapsed houses that had used mud, loosened by rain, between the bricks. Karna Hyanju, a former Nepalese legislator, however, did not die in the quake. He was killed after being accused of distributing relief supplies only to his supporters. All but three of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers have been found safe. There are no Peace Corp workers in India. The U.S. is sending financial aid to both counties. Britain, U.N. agencies and the Red Cross sent medical teams to Nepal.
column9: Massive earthquake devastates large areas of Nepal and India.
column10: The worst earthquake in this region since 1950, registering 6.5 on the Richter scale, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 and injuring thousands.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.
column11: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 people and injuring thousands.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi and Calcutta.  The hardest hit areas were Bihar state in India and the Dharan district of Nepal.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.   Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  In Nepal police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.
column12: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950 hit near the Nepal-India border.  At least 750 people died and thousands were injured.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, lasting about 40 seconds and with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi, Calcutta and northern Bangladesh.  The hardest hit areas were the Dharan district of Nepal, where 50,000 to 60,000 houses were destroyed and the Bihar state of India.  With cracks in the embankments of six Bihar state rivers, flooding could be the next threat there.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.  The army, police, and local inhabitants are taking part in rescue efforts in both countries.  Foreign aid began arriving.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Nepalese police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.  Concerned American parents heard from some of their Peace Corps volunteer children in Nepal where all but three volunteers have been tracked down. And in Bhaktapur, Nepal, political rivals of a former legislator accused him of distributing relief supplies to only his supporters and beat him to death.

column3: The actor who play Little Ricky on the I love Lucy show say Wednesday he spend more time with Lucille Ball than he do with his own family in the five years he play the comedian's tv son. Miss Ball die of a ruptured aorta at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles Wednesday morning, hospital officials said. She be 77. She be old and, of course, I know about the heart attack, so I be not shock by her death, say Keith Thibodeaux, who at age 6 begin play Miss Ball's drum-playing son on the comedy series that continue in syndication around the world. I'm sure all this be go to hit me a little late on. Thibodeaux grow up on the set, playing little Ricky from 1956 until 1961 under Miss Ball's watchful eye. I think the thing I remember most about Lucy be that she be very much in control of everything, say Thibodeaux, who begin play the drums at age 2, be a professional drummer at age 4 and be now drummer with David and the Giants, a christian rock group. He live in Jackson with his wife, Kathy, a ballerina. Thibodeaux, 38, say he get his break in show business when big band leader Horace Heidt persuade his father to bring him from Lafayette, La., to California for the Swift Premium Hour, a travel radio show that lead to a string of one-night stands across the country. That lead to an audition for the I Love Lucy role in Hollywood. I remember Lucy saying, `that's him,' and from that time I be little Ricky, say Thibodeaux, who then use the name Richard Keith. I sign a seven-year contract with the studio in 1956 and the first episode I be in be air that December with Bob Hope I just turn 6. Thibodeaux say that during the series' run he spend as much time with Miss Ball as with his own family in Lafayette. And I spend more time with her off the set at her home than at the studio, he said. I remember her as very strict but with a lot of love. She have her ways but despite all, she be a great person, very, very talented. I know everybody remember her as zany and wacky but that be only on the show. Actually, she be just the opposite and be very serious. ... That's what make her a great actress. He say Miss Ball often give him gifts and that he remember spending at least one Christmas at her home. I remember she once give me an indian tepee, then my own dressing room, he said. She give me bicycles and an identical set of drums. As a young girl in western New York, Lucille Ball hawk hot dogs and popcorn at an amusement park as she dream of star in movies, hometown friends recalled. She always talk about be a star, say Pauline Lopus, who go to school with Miss Ball and have keep in touch with her. Miss Ball, bear 60 miles south of Buffalo in Jamestown on Aug. 6, 1911, grow up in nearby Celoron, a rural hamlet on Chautauqua Lake. Mrs. Lopus remember the sitcom star on Wednesday as dare in many ways. She try to get me to run off (to Broadway), Mrs. Lopus added. But I didn't have the nerve. At 15, Miss Ball work as a barker at the amusement park, scream for people to buy popcorn and hot dogs until she lose her voice. Later, she star in high school plays and get her start in front of a large audience on the vaudeville stage at the defunct Palace Theater in Jamestown. Although Miss Ball hadn't visit Jamestown since 1956 and have no family there, she stay in touch with friends. even though she be a big star, she be still just Lucy to us, say Irene Rosseti of Celoron. Mrs. Rosseti say Miss Ball recently send her and her husband a letter on their 50th wedding anniversary. Miss Ball regularly donate money to charities, civic events and Jamestown Community College, say Jamestown Mayor Steven Carlson. On May 20, Miss Ball be to receive an honorary degree from the college and have plan to return to Jamestown, now a city of about 40,000. Residents have put up posters say Jamestown Loves Lucy in storefronts and home windows. After Miss Ball suffer a heart attack last week, residents decide to sign the posters and send them to her as a get-well greeting. more than 150 posters be send with 10,000 signatures. The 77-year-old comedian die Wednesday of a ruptured aorta, the main heart artery, at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she be recover from last week's emergency heart surgery. It be a sad day for all of us, say Nelson Garifi, an organizer of the welcoming event. But I'm sure that feeling be share by many people around the world. Garifi, community relations director for the community college, say the honorary degree will be award posthumously. Future generations in Celoron will have a reminder of their famous resident every time they drive or walk down the street where she grow up it will be rename Lucy Lane. Village officials have plan formal ceremonies rename the street when she be due in the area next month. But it will happen anyway, John Goodell of the village's historical society say Wednesday.
