When the society be form about a year ago, Goodell said: We send an invitation to Lucille Ball to be a member, and she send back a check for $500 for a life membership. It be a check write in a very bold hand with a signature about a half inch high. Bob Thomas have cover Hollywood for The Associated Press for 45 years. Thousands of Lucille Ball's fans shed tears for the woman who make them laugh, as three cities hold memorial services in which the redheaded comedian be remember with prayers and applause. She be a whole package. There never will be another one like her. I love her, say a tearful Carol Burnett follow a memorial Mass in suburban Santa Monica. more than a thousand people who pack the St. Monica's Catholic Church rise to their feet and clap for several minutes after television minister the Rev. Robert Schuller ask them to applaud the Lord for Lucille Ball. About 1,000 people also crowd a church in New York and 200 gather in a Chicago church. All three memorial Masses begin at 8 p.m. Monday, the time Miss Ball's three most popular programs be often broadcast. The 77-year-old comedian who star in one of television's big all-time hits, I love Lucy, die here April 26 of a ruptured aorta, a major blood vessel, eight days after emergency open-heart surgery. Miss Ball, known for her honed comedic timing, wide-mouthed expressions and wacky antics, be popular among generations of fans who watch I Love Lucy as a first-run show in the '50s and in three decades of reruns. She show her love in the only way she know how, by make you laugh, the Rev. James Fox tell those gather for the Roman Catholic Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Broadcaster Diane Sawyer tell the crowd that the death of Miss Ball may have settle a longstanding theological debate over whether there be laughter in heaven. A God who would have create her would never let her laughter be far from Him, say Ms. Sawyer. In Chicago, the Rev. Jack Wall tell people at Old St. Patrick Church that God give the world talents like Miss Ball to show us life be not a tragedy, but a comedy with a happy ending. She teach us that if we could love Lucy, we could love ourselves, Wall said. In announce the services, Miss Ball's family said: Monday night be the time when most of the nation be use to be with Lucy. Two of the three long-running comedy shows in which Miss Ball starred, The Lucy Show and Here's Lucy, air Monday nights. I Love Lucy have start times on Mondays and other days. Lucille Ball give the gift of humor which produce happiness, say Schuller at the Santa Monica service. only God know how many husbands and wives weren't speak and then Monday night roll around. Fans line up to get in the Santa Monica church as much as four hours early. Florists deliver arrangements include a 3-foot heart of red carnations with the words I love Lucy write across. Hundreds of people come forward during Holy Communion to receive blessings from three priests, include a woman wear an I love Lucy T-shirt. I think she would have love it very much, and she live her life for the people who be in that room tonight, say Lucie Arnaz, daughter of Miss Ball and the late Desi Arnaz. Gary Morton, Miss Ball's husband for more than two decades, attend a private service for his wife last month. The actress' remain be bury at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills. Bob Hope keep voluminous files, include the jokes he deliver and people he have perform with, and his first entry under Lucille Ball be an appearance with Hope in 1945 on a show call G.I. Journal. I really can't remember many details about it, say Hope, who pay tribute to his frequent co-star in an NBC special Saturday night. It's call Bob Hope's Love Affair With Lucille Ball. She die in April of this year. That first time together be follow by four movies, frequent visits by Hope on I Love Lucy and regular appearances by Lucy on his television shows. Lucy be a very funny woman, hope said. even in private she could get off a great ad lib. But it's hard to compare her with other funny women. It's like ask who's the best golfer. You have to go to the records. I don't think anyone ever have the success she had. She certainly hold the most records. A secretary dig the details of that first joint appearance out of one of two vaults where Hope keep everything pertain to his long comic career. There be write records of all his shows, copies of all the scripts, monologues and comic routines, audio tapes of his radio shows and thousands of other mementos. G.I. Journal be on May 4, 1945. Hope's file reads: Spot: Lucille Ball ... english play ... For Charity Bazaar. Hope and Ball have actually know each other before they begin work together. In fact, the late Desi Arnaz, her then husband, work for Hope first. He say Ball ask him nearly 50 years ago to find a place on his popular radio show for band leader Arnaz. Stan Kenton be leave as my orchestra leader, Hope said. I give Desi a spot on my show. We also give him some lines to speak. Every time he walk up to the microphone he drop an enchilada. He could hardly talk, let alone get a laugh. When they start `I Love Lucy,' I said, `what's go on? This man be funny.' The night before she die I perform at the Music Center, he said. Lucy be in the hospital and I saw her daughter, Lucie Arnaz, and said, `isn't it wonderful she's do better.' They call me the next day and say she have died. I said, `God have her now, but we'll have her forever.' We'll be watch her performances for a long, long time. Bob Hope's Love Affair With Lucy will include clips from their movies and tv appearances, plus such guest stars as Betty White, George Burns and Danny Thomas. I'm go through everything myself pick out the clips, Hope said. The last time she be on my show be my birthday show two years ago. We sing `i Remember It Well.' Our last time together in public be at the Academy Awards in March. I think I'll do my tribute to her over a shot of that in the background. I think everyone remembers that. She be on his radio show on May 27, 1947, at Detroit. The program notes say, Lucille Ball: New York, clothes, cars, pictures. I could do a fashion show with her walk on stage, Hope say of the show clip he have be watch in prepare the special. She have great gowns and hairdos. When she perform she would use different styles. She'd change the way she read a line. She'd throw a line away one time, then she'd turn around and milk a line for laughs. Hope recall his funny co-star in a sunny alcove in the living room of his Los Angeles home. It overlook the one-hole golf course in the back yard, and he be attire in golf clothes. Occasionally, he call his office in another building on the grounds to check on a piece of information. Soon after the interview, he be aboard a plane for a series of personal appearances around the country. Ball make 22 appearances on Hope's specials and he be on her show 10 or 12 times, he said. In their first movie, Sorrowful Jones in 1949, Hope play a racetrack bookie who's force to become the foster father of a young girl whose real father be kill by gangsters in a racehorse fix. Ball be a nightclub singer who help him look after the girl. It be a remake of Little Miss Marker, which star Shirley Temple in 1934. Next be fancy Pants in 1950, a remake of Ruggles of Red Gap. Ball play a rich rancher who acquire an english butler, play by Hope. Facts of Life be in 1960, with Hope and Ball as married lovers who have a tryst. Their last film be Critic's Choice in 1963, in which Hope be a Broadway critic who have to review a play write by his wife, play by Ball. Someone remind me the other night of a bus tour we do of movie theaters in New York to promote one our of pictures, he said. I think it be `critic's Choice.' I find her very cooperative, very wonderful. We always have a lot of fun together. Lucille Ball, the daffy comedian whose harebrained schemes drive her television family crazy but delighted viewers for four decades, die Wednesday of a ruptured abdominal artery. She be 77. The actress, star of the hugely popular I love Lucy and relate situation comedies see in more than 80 countries, have undergone major heart surgery April 18. She have be recover steadily, get out of bed and joking with the staff, but shortly before dawn Wednesday, she go into cardiac arrest due to internal bleeding and could not be revived, say Cedars-Sinai Medical Center spokesman Ronald Wise. She suffer a complete heart failure at 5 a.m. and 47 minutes of resuscitation efforts prove fruitless, Wise said. There be nothing to indicate this would happen, Wise said. The heart itself apparently be not involve in Miss Ball's sudden death. In the 6{-hour surgery at Cedars-Sinai, doctors replace her aorta and aortic valve. Although the replaced portion of Miss Ball's aorta do not apparently fail, the entire artery be in poor condition when she be operate upon, say Dr. Robert Kass. Kass, who perform the operation, say at the time the tearing in Miss Ball's aorta progress all the way down into her abdomen. Miss Ball, with her fire-engine red hair and siren wail, be consider the queen of situation comedy and a pioneer of the sitcom format. I and 100 million others will miss her, say comedian George Burns. But we haven't lose Lucille Ball because she's still with us on television and we can see her on and on. Lucille Ball possess the gift of laughter. But she also embody an even great treasure the gift of love, President Bush say in a statement. She appeal to the gentler impulses of the human spirit. She be not merely an actress or comedienne. She be Lucy and she be loved. Her red hair, her antics on the screen, her timing and her zest for life make her an american institution, former President and Nancy Reagan say in a statement. Just the mention of her name bring a smile. ... We love Lucy and will miss her deeply. It's a shock after work very closely with her and love her for over 35 years, say Miss Ball's frequent sidekick, Gale Gordon, who be in Edmonton, Alberta. While in the hospital, the comedian be deluge with thousands of cards, letters, flowers and phone calls from fans as far away as Australia and Europe. Miss Ball and her late former husband, Desi Arnaz, star in I love lucy from 1951 to 1957 and have be see since in widely syndicate reruns. The late vivian Vance and William Frawley play their neighbors, Fred and Ethel Mertz. Her split-second timing, wide-mouthed wails and exaggerated pratfalls make the I love Lucy show one of the most popular in television history. Bridge clubs and bowl teams change their meeting nights to watch Lucy and Ethel cook up still another ridiculous scheme that would push their long-suffering husbands to exasperation. Miss Ball's real, onscreen pregnancy mark a milestone in television, and an estimate 44 million viewers more than for the inauguration of President Eisenhower tune in on Jan. 19, 1953, to watch Lucy Ricardo have Little Ricky. The real birth occur just four hours before the previously-filmed show be broadcast. Miss Ball's singularity as a comedian be match by her talent as a show-business entrepreneur. She and Arnaz establish one of TV's first major independent studios. Desilu, as their production company be called, make some of the top comedy shows of the 1950s and '60s, include December Bride, Our Miss Brooks and Make Room for Daddy. As testament to their value as prime-time stars, Miss Ball and Arnaz sign an $8 million, no-cancellation, two-year contract with CBS in 1953 the large in television history at the time and a figure scarcely any tv star can touch today. The couple stop make weekly I love Lucy shows in 1957. Despite riches and two children, Lucie and Desi Jr., their marriage foundered, and the couple divorce in 1960. In 1961, Miss Ball marry nightclub comic Gary Morton, who become her executive producer, and remain on tv for 12 more years in the weekly Here's Lucy and The Lucy Show. Miss Ball be bear Aug. 6, 1911, in Jamestown, N.Y., the daughter of an electrician and a concert pianist. Young Lucy, a brunette, be dazzle by the stage, but her ambitions be discourage by an act school They send my mother a letter say she be waste her money, Miss Ball once say and she turn to model under the name Diane Belmont. Her ads for Chesterfield cigarettes catch Hollywood's eye, and in 1933 she go to California. As a blonde, she appear with the Marx Brothers in Room Service, with Fred Astaire in Follow the Fleet and with Katharine Hepburn and Ginger Rogers in Stage Door. In all, she appear in more than 75 movies. In 1940, her tresses color the fiery trademark red, Miss Ball meet Arnaz, a rumba star. They marry within six months. In 1951, when CBS decide to move her radio series, My Favorite Husband, to television, Miss Ball insist that Arnaz be her co-star. But the network wasn't sure Arnaz would be a hit with the american public. The couple go on a nationwide vaudeville tour and proved audiences would watch a leggy, blue-eyed comedian and a cuban-born band leader with a heavy accent. They also produce their own pilot episode on borrow money. CBS relented, and I love Lucy be an immediate success. The show revolutionize television sitcom production in the days before videotape. It be film in advance before a live audience, employ three cameras instead of the traditional one use for motion pictures. The actress be last see at the 61st Academy Awards ceremony March 29, where the svelte actress receive a stand ovation and laugh freely throughout her brief bit with Bob Hope. Her last series Life with Lucy, once again co-starring Gordon be carry by ABC at the start of the 1986 season. But the show, her first series in 12 years, be cancel after less than two months when it draw spectacularly low ratings. She felt terrible. ... It really devastate her, daughter Lucie Arnaz say at the time. Miss Ball also play a bag lady in the 1985 tv movie Stone Pillow, consider one of the most challenging roles of her career. She be hospitalize for dehydration when it be over, but the movie be a minor critical and ratings success. Just this month, Miss Ball have sign a deal for a report $750,000 with Putnam to publish her autobiography. Said CBS Chairman William Paley: Lucille Ball will always be the first lady of CBS. ... Lucy's extraordinary ability to light up the screen and brighten our lives be a legacy that will last forever. funeral arrangements be pending. An outpouring of sympathy from presidents to childhood neighbors follow the death of Lucille Ball, but many say the queen mother of comedy will live on through television reruns and her influence on comedy. The daffy, redheaded comedian whose harebrained schemes drive her television family crazy and delighted viewers for four decades die Wednesday of a ruptured abdominal artery at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. She be 77 and die eight days after emergency heart surgery. A private burial be planned, reportedly with no funeral services in accordance with Miss Ball's wishes. God have her now, and, thanks to television, we'll have her forever, say comedian and longtime friend Bob Hope. Hospital switchboards be swamp with condolence calls and thousands of cards after Miss Ball's death, spokesman Ron Wise said. Miss Ball's family request that any flowers send to the Medical Center in her memory be distribute to other patients. Miss Ball maintain her sense of humor even when she be critically ill. follow her operation last week, her first words to her daughter, Lucie, were: Wouldn't you know this be the day I be go to get my hair done. Miss Ball have be improve steadily from the heart surgery, so her death come as a shock. She have be walking, her spirits be up. Her family be with her, Wise said. She respond as well as anyone could respond to that kind of surgery. He say she wake up early Wednesday complain about a sudden pain in her back, and in a matter of seconds go into a full cardiac arrest that be cause by a ruptured aorta. Miss Ball and her late former husband, Desi Arnaz, star in I love lucy from 1951 to 1957. In the ground-breaking show, still see in syndication worldwide, the late vivian Vance and William Frawley play their neighbors, Fred and Ethel Mertz. Probably a lot of what she do rub off on what I do, say actress-comedian Jane Curtin, star of the sitcom Kate and Allie. But it couldn't be helped, because I memorize her shows. The show, one of the most popular in television history, be distinguish by Miss Ball's faultless timing, rubber-faced expressions, wide-mouthed wails and extravagant pratfalls. work with Lucy be like receive an M.A. or a Ph.D. in comedy, recall Joan Rivers. What she forget about comic timing and delivery be more than most of us will ever learn in a lifetime. comedian Whoopi Goldberg said: Lucy be great because she represent every person. She show us human foibles and give us a chance to laugh at ourselves. Miss Goldberg say her favorite episode involve a visit by the I Love Lucy characters to Hollywood, where Lucy and Ethel spot actor William Holden in a restaurant. That be how we would all react to see a movie star in a restaurant, Miss Goldberg said. She be look at him in a compact mirror, and try to look at him surreptitiously. And that's just an example of how everyone can identify with Lucy. Bob Rosati, who live down the street from the Beverly Hills home Miss Ball share with husband Gary Morton, say he be watch a rerun of I love Lucy on Wednesday morning when the screen go black and the words In memory of Lucille Ball, 1911-1989 appeared. I felt I have lose someone in my family. I couldn't believe it, say Rosati, 40. I be watch Lucy like I do every morning. She's one of the most-admired ladies in this town. He be among a group of fans who stand reverently outside Miss Ball's home on Roxbury Drive as florists deliver baskets of flowers to the house. Tour vans pass by in a non-stop procession. On Hollywood Boulevard's Walk of Fame, flower arrangements be place on Miss Ball's two star one for her film work, one for television. Budd Friedman, owner of the Improvisation comedy clubs, said, The world of comedy have lose its first lady. Her death be an irreparable loss ... to our industry. Actor Danny DeVito recall get a personal congratulation from Miss Ball in 1981 when he win an Emmy for the tv series Taxi. It make it like it have be blessed, he recalled. Admirers include President Bush, in Southern California at the time of Miss Ball's passing, and former President Reagan. Her red hair, her antics on the screen, her timing and her zest for life make her an american institution, the former president and Nancy Reagan say in a statement. Just the mention of her name bring a smile. ... We love Lucy and will miss her deeply. Lucille Ball possess the gift of laughter, Bush said. But she also embody an even great treasure the gift of love. She appeal to the gentler impulses of the human spirit. She be not merely an actress or comedienne. She be Lucy and she be loved. To baby boomers, a happy chunk of our childhood be missing, say Saturday Night Live comedian Victoria Jackson, who be bear two years after I love Lucy go off the air as a regular series. She didn't make me laugh out loud, I remember, she just make me happy about life. Said comic Tim Conway: We're go to miss this lady, but not really, because she's still here. All those wonderful things they do together ... those wonderful tv shows ... be still available. Although Miss Ball hadn't visit her hometown of Jamestown, N.Y, since 1956 and have no family there, she have stay in touch with friends. Irene Rosseti, who now live in Celoron, N.Y., say Miss Ball recently have send her and her husband a letter on their 50th wedding anniversary. even though she be a big star, she be still just Lucy to us, she recalled. Lucille Ball be mourn Wednesday by the western New York hometown she leave for Hollywood more than half a century ago. It be a sad day for all of us. But I'm sure that feeling be share by many people around the world, say Nelson Garifi, organizer of a homecoming for Miss Ball that be to have be hold next month. She be always so full of life, say Pauline Lopus, who go to school with Miss Ball and have keep in touch with her. It seem like she would just go on forever. The 77-year-old comedian died of a ruptured aorta, the main heart artery, at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she be recover from emergency heart surgery last week. The american Heart Association's Jamestown office be deluge with calls from Miss Ball's fans who want to make a memorial donation, officials said. We just can't process as many memorials as we've received, say office manager Nathan Lax. Miss Ball be bear Aug. 6, 1911, in this city of 40,000 people about 60 miles south of Buffalo, the daughter of an electrician and a concert pianist. She grow up in nearby Celoron, a rural hamlet on Chautauqua Lake. Friends say some of the characteristics of her most famous role the zany, excitable star of television's I love Lucy be evident during her childhood. Mrs. Lopus say Miss Ball dream of fame, either as a dramatic actress in New York City or as a dance girl in musicals. At age 15, she work as a barker at a local amusement park, scream pitches for popcorn and hot dogs until she lose her voice. In high school, she star in high school plays and make her first appearance before a large audience at the now-defunct Palace Theater here. As a model, she catch Hollywood's eye and in 1933, she be off to Hollywood. Although the comedian hadn't visit Jamestown since 1956 and have no family there, she regularly donate money to charities, civic events and Jamestown Community College, say Mayor Steven Carlson. Miss Ball be to have receive an honorary degree from the college at the homecoming schedule for May 20. Residents have hung posters say Jamestown Loves Lucy in storefronts and house windows. After she fell ill last week, residents sign the posters and send them to her as a get-well greeting. They send more than 150 posters with 10,000 signatures. The honorary degree will be award posthumously, say Garifi, who be community relations director at the college. Celoron have plan to rename a street in Miss Ball's honor during her visit, and still plan to rename it as Lucy Lane, say John Goodell of Celoron's Historical Society. Goodell say that when the group be form about a year ago, We send an invitation to Lucille Ball to be a member, and she send back a check for $500 for a life membership. Actor Gale Gordon, a sidekick of Lucille Ball from radio days who appear with her in three television series, recall on Wednesday how the comedian never think of herself as particularly funny. Oh, but when she tell a story or recall an event that happen she always illustrate it with her body and her face, the 83-year-old Gordon say in a telephone interview. She never saw it, but she be extremely amusing. Gordon, who be appear in a play in Edmonton, spend the day in an Edmonton hotel room, mourn the death of Lucille Ball in a Los Angeles hospital Wednesday at age 77 and quietly remember his funny friend. The world will miss her greatly, the actor said. I personally will remember her as the best talent of her kind in the world ... a wonderful, warm friend and a bit of a genius the only one I've ever really known. In his first television series alongside Miss Ball, Gordon be the flustered banker Mr. Mooney in The Lucy Show from 1962-68. The next six years saw him as Harrison Carter on Here's Lucy. They be reunite briefly in 1986 for the short-lived Life With Lucy. Gordon first meet Miss Ball in 1947 on the radio program My Favorite Husband, which later become I Love Lucy on television. I think she be a very good-looking young woman, and very talented, he recalled. She be very pleasant to work with. none of us know what be go to happen television be very young then and it wasn't take too seriously. We never dream it would ever become the power it be ... and the great stars it would produce. Gordon last speak to Miss Ball from Edmonton on his birthday, Feb. 20, when she call to wish me a happy birthday as she have do for years and years. Gordon have do regular stints for years at a chain of edmonton-based dinner theatres call Stage West. He be currently appear with that company's Mayfair Dinner Theatre as a priest in the play Mass Appeal. The play have another month to run and Gordon say that mean he won't be able to attend Miss Ball's funeral. I couldn't do that because it would put people out of work, he said. She would be the first one to scream her head off if I do that. here be highlights of Lucille Ball's career: 1911 Born Aug. 6, 1911, in Jamestown N.Y., the daughter of an electrician and concert pianist Desiree Ball. 1926 Begins career in show business in New York as a chorus girl. 1933 Goes to Hollywood as movie showgirl for RKO, later become a successful actress appear in more than 75 films. 1940 Marries Desi Arnaz, a Cuban percussionist and bandleader when both be make the movie Too Many Girls. 1951 They form Desilu Productions with $5,000 and I love Lucy begin its historic six-year domination of television comedy. Earlier in the year, they have their first child. 1953 I love Lucy episode in which Lucy Ricardo give birth to Little Ricky be telecast the same day that Lucille Ball, in real life, give birth to second child, Desi Jr. 1957 Desilu purchases RKO studios and begins produce other programs. 1960 The Arnazes divorce, with Desi sell his share of the studio to Lucy for $3 million. 1961 Miss Ball marry night-club comic Gary Morton, who become her executive producer. 1962 Miss Ball go solo, return to the airwaves in The Lucy Show. 1967 Miss Ball sell company to Gulf & Western for $18 million. 1968 The Lucy Show be redesign and become Here's Lucy. It run until 1974. 1974
column5: Lucille Ball, TV's comic genius, had major impact on the industry
column6: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77 starred along with her husband Desi Arnaz in perhaps the finest television series, "I Love Lucy". Together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO and produced very popular television shows.  Expressions of sympathy poured in from all over the country.
column7: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long be remembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous and unrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finest series in television, "I Love Lucy".  She starred in the show along with her husband Desi Arnaz, and together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO Studios and television and produced many popular television shows.  The couple had two children and divorced in 1960.  Condolences poured in form all over the country in which she was credited with helping to establish television as the nation's leading entertainment industry.
column8: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long beremembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous andunrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finestseries in television history, "I Love Lucy".  She starred with herhusband, Desi Arnaz, in the '50s show and together they founded DesiluProductions, which eventually took over RKO Studios.  She was anastute businesswoman as well as a talented entertainer and Desiluproduced some of the most popular programs of the '50s and '60s. Balland Arnaz divorced in 1960.  They had two children.  At her deaththere was an outpouring of sympathy from the very famous to thousandsof her ordinary fans.  She was particularly remembered in her hometownof Jamestown New York where she had contributed to local charities,civic events and Jamestown Community College.  Following the breakupof her first marriage, she married Gary Morton, her husband at herdeath.  Miss Ball had a successful career before television, starringin 75 films.  She died in Los Angeles, following emergency heartsurgery.  William Paley, Chairman of CBS said that she helped toestablish television as the nation's leading entertainment industryand that her legacy would last forever.
column9: Everyone loved Lucille Ball, the queen of television comedy.
column10: When Lucille Ball died at 77, fans from presidents to neighbors to co-stars to critics paid tributes to her life, person and comedic skills.  Although she was a chorus girl, model, movie star, and television entrepreneur, she is best remembered for "I Love Lucy," a 1950's show that revolutionized television comedy.
column11: The Queen of TV comedy and entrepreneur, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989 at 77.  Presidents, comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, surviving co-stars, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  More than 2,000 attended three memorial services.  She was a chorus girl, model, and in 75 movies, but is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing evident on television.  She and her husband, Desi Arnaz, revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy," which was filmed before a live audience, becoming a rerun gold mine, still seen world-wide.
column12: The Queen of TV comedy, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989, from a ruptured abdominal aorta.  President Bush, former President Reagan, the president of CBS, American comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  Her burial was private, but more than 2,000 attended three memorial services held on May 8.  Bob Hope, a frequent co-star and friend, created a TV special in her honor.  Two of her surviving TV co-stars, Gail Gordon and Keith Thibodeaux, remembered her fondly.  She is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing.  She was born in 1911 in Jamestown, N.Y., and, after staring in high school plays, became a model and chorus girl, moving in 1933 to Hollywood.  There, she was in over 75 movies, usually playing the second banana.  In 1940 she married Desi Arnaz, and together they revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy" which started in 1951.  Filmed with three cameras before a live audience, it became a rerun gold mine and has been seen in 80 countries.  After her divorce, she remarried and continued to be a successful television entrepreneur and star of television and screen.

column3: hit Baghdad where it hurts, more countries have join a u.n.-sanctioned boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. On Tuesday, countries range from powerful Japan to neutral Switzerland to tiny Cyprus cut off petroleum imports in an effort to convince the Baghdad government to withdraw its troops that invade Kuwait on Thursday. Turkey announce it be shut down the twin Iraqi oil pipelines that run through it to the Mediterranean carry half of Baghdad's crude output and cut off trade with Iraq. Baghdad's only other major pipelines export crude run through Saudi Arabia, where the flow have be drastically reduced. The U.N. Security Council on Monday vote to impose broad economic sanctions against Iraq for invade small oil-rich Kuwait. The measure forbid loans to Iraq or Kuwait and prohibit any activities, include the transfer of money, that would help the two countries export their goods. Sanctions adopt by the european Economic Community on Saturday freeze Iraqi assets and suspend the purchase of oil from the two Arab countries. more than 90 percent of imports from Iraq to the 12-nation EEC be petroleum products. The EEC also suspend arms sales to Iraq. Switzerland, which be not a member of the United Nations, make the unusual move Tuesday of join the U.N. sanctions and ban all trade with Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. In addition, Switzerland prohibit all payments and other financial transfers to Iraq and Kuwait. Denmark, Norway and Sweden also announce embargoes on all trade with both countries. Japan's participation in the U.N. sanctions be see as especially key since Tokyo usually have take a low profile in the Middle East, which supply much of its petroleum needs. Japan import 99 percent of its oil. China join the U.N. decision to embargo arms sales to Iraq, but have be less vocal than other major countries in condemn the invasion. China sell arms to both Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and be a major Iraqi trade partner. Cyprus' sacrifice in join the embargo be to give up 70 percent of its oil imports, government spokesman Akis Fantis said. Cyprus have sufficient oil supplies to last until the end of August, he said, but we be already in the process of take steps to secure alternative sources ... The worldwide closing of ranks against Iraqi oil imports be likely to lead to even high petroleum prices, which have already rise dramatically since the invasion and could have a major impact on the world economy. wholesale oil prices soar to five-year highs in New York on Monday. France will introduce controls Thursday on prices of petroleum products to prevent refiners from use Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as an excuse to raise prices, act Premier Pierre Beregovoy announce Tuesday. An official with the Petroleum Association of Japan say he be unaware of any increase yet in the price of gasoline for consumers. The official, who refuse to be further identified, say it would be at least three months before the sanctions could be expect to force high gas prices in Japan. An Iraqi airways jet carry 78 foreigners and a number of Iraqi citizens arrive today, the first commercial flight allow out of Iraq since it invade Kuwait, a japanese Embassy spokesman said. The mostly japanese tourists arrive at Amman airport at 6:15 p.m. (11:15 a.m. EDT) along with 34 members of an Iraqi football team, say the spokesman on condition of anonymity. It be not immediately know if there be Americans on board. He say that the plane be due to leave Amman for an undisclosed destination. The spokesman say the plane be suppose to land in Vienna, but it be deny land rights. The U.N. Security Council on Monday vote economic sanctions that ban all trade and military ties with Iraq. Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzedine, say earlier today that the U.S. government have ask Jordan to facilitate the entrance from Iraq of American diplomats and their dependents. Izzedine say the request be make through the U.S. Embassy in Amman. Thousands of Westerners have be strand in Kuwait and Iraq since Iraq invade Kuwait on Thursday. They include more than 350 who be on a british Airways flight that be catch in the unrest in Kuwait. A British Airways spokeswoman say today a substantial number of those passengers arrive safely in Baghdad on Monday. Among the passengers be 28 Americans, who also turn up in a Baghdad hotel and appear to be fine, a U.S. official say in Washington. In addition, a Kuwaiti businessman say about 1,000 people a day be flee Kuwait through the desert to Saudi Arabia. The businessman, who arrive in London on a british Airways flight from Bahrain today, say Kuwaitis and expatriates, include Westerners, be join convoys to escape the Iraqi forces. Jordan's borders with Iraq have be close from the Iraqi side since Thursday morning, when Iraq invade Kuwait. The provisional government of free Kuwait set up by Iraq have threaten Sunday to hold hostage citizens of countries impose sanctions on it. A U.S. diplomat say Washington have instruct american citizens live in or visit Iraq and Kuwait to leave when circumstances permit. here be some quotes on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: here be a brief chronology in the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait over oil production and their common border. July 17 Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuse Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flood the oil market and drive prices down, and that the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lose oil revenue. He further charges that arab states in the Persian Gulf be conspire with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. July 18 Iraq accuse Kuwait of steal $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along the disputed border with Iraq and of seek to wreck Iraq's economy by overproduce oil and thus push down prices. July 20 Kuwaiti officials suggest Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence be aim at get its creditors include Kuwait to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. July 24 The U.S. Defense Department announces that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft be hold a short-notice exercise in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 miles southeast of the Kuwait-Iraqi border. Kuwait reinstate a state of alert it declare July 16 and cancel after three days of tension between the two oil-producing countries. July 25 The Iraqi government in Baghdad say that it will not be intimidate by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and Saddams summon the U.S. ambassador for talks. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt say Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia in an effort to resolve their dispute. July 26 OPEC ministers in Geneva agree to halt overproduction in hopes of push up the price of crude oil. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates pledge to abide by the agreement. Analysts say Saddam clearly influence the outcome of the meetings. July 31 Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to negotiate the oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq have mass 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. That number dwarf the Kuwaiti army, which have a total of about 20,000 troops. Aug. 1 Iraq pull out of talks on the 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute with Kuwait shortly before it send its forces to invade the oil-rich sheikdom. Aug. 2 Iraq's powerful army overruns Kuwait before dawn with tank-led troops quickly seize the ruler's palace and other government buildings. THE INVASION: Iraq's troops, lead by about 350 tanks, cross the border at dawn Thursday, and seize the Kuwaiti palace and government buildings 40 miles away. early Friday, the invaders control Kuwait city, the capital. The soldiers be also make sweeps through the southern oilfields, accord to residents and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Diplomatic sources estimate more than 200 Kuwaitis be kill or wounded, mainly from the Emiri Guard which bore the main brunt of the invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-abdullah al-sabah flee to safety in Saudi Arabia. THE FORCES: Iraq, a country of more than 17 million, have the Arab world's most battle-trained army, and have mass more than 100,000 soldiers on the Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, an oil-rich city-state, have 1.9 million residents 60 percent foreigners and an army of 20,300 soldiers. CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accuse Kuwait of steal oil from its territory and force down oil prices through overproduction. Kuwait and U.N. diplomats dismiss Iraq's claim that it invade at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries. REACTION: The U.N. Security Council vote 14-0 to condemn the invasion. President Bush denounce it as naked agression. He freeze Iraq's assets in the United States and block almost all Iraqi imports, include oil. The order also froze Kuwait property under U.S. jurisdiction a move intend to keep Iraq from seize it. The Soviets also condemn the invasion and stop arms sales to Iraq. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador say the nation have ask for american military intervention. A Pentagon source say a U.S. naval group be divert toward the persian Gulf. oil prices soar in frenzied trading amid fears the invasion would reduce the supply of oil. iranian editorial writers be rejoice now that the world be wake up to one of their most hat bogeymen: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A Monday headline: We warn you Frankenstein would torment his own creators. Saddam attack Iran in September 1980 after a series of border skirmishes, spawn a war that drag until an August 1988 cease-fire. The conflict have still not formally ended. Iran's late fundamentalist patriarch, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, vow for years to unseat Saddam. Never at a loss for a vivid phrase, he compare accept the cease-fire with Saddam to drink poison. The status of Great Satan be reserve for the United States, the all-encompassing public enemy no. 1 for the Islamic Republic. Iran frequently accuse both the U.S. and Saddam of try to undermine the Islamic revolution. Saddam conveniently boast of have alone staunch the tide of radical Islam. In fact one of his reasons for invade Kuwait on Thursday, the Iraqi press noted, be its gall in demand back tens of billions of dollars loan to Iraq during the war Saddam say he fight for all Arabs. Over the past six months, successful u.n.-sponsored efforts toward face-to-face negotiations between Iraq and Iran rob iranian newspapers and television commentators of a favorite target. Saddam's overthrow of the emir of Kuwait change all that. Old scores come brim to the surface. Kuwait, after all, reflagged tankers in the United States during the Iran-Iraq war, ushering in the reason for the arrival of the U.S. Navy in the Persian Gulf in force. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency print excerpts Mondya of an editorial from the Ettela'at newspaper that be headlined: Foster child turn rapaciously on nourisher Kuwait. It note that Kuwait have blindly support Iraq, little knowing that it be feed a wild beast in her own neighborhood. Saddam have also be call generalissimo and The Invader. Under the Frankenstein headline, IRNA say in its own commentary: For the time being, tiny Kuwait ... breathe no more. With its sheikh a stateless person, and its powerful dinar which bankroll the Iraqi military mere garbage, Kuwait be a nonentity, swallow up by the dangerous pet it reared. Despite all the attention to the dangerous pet, the Great Satan have not be forgotton. accord to Iran's pundits, the Great Satan plan it all. It want to get the Navy back in the persian Gulf.
column5: Iraq invaded Kuwait August 1990. US sent navy, world imposed sanctions.
column6: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government  installations and killing 200. Saddam Hussain, claiming invitation by revolutionaries, accused Kuwait of driving down oil prices and stealing Iraqi oil. The US sent naval forces to the Persian Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed economic and military sanctions. Oil prices soared.
column7: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq occupied Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government buildings and installations, killing 200, and replacing fleeing Kuwaitis with Iraqis. Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of overproducing to drive down oil prices and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at revolutionaries' request. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because Kuwait pressed for war loan repayment. Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush pledged to defend its Persian Gulf interests and sent a naval group. The US, UN, and EEC imposed widely-supported trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq threatened to hold citizens of sanction-imposing countries hostage. Oil prices soared.
column8: On August 2nd, 1990, 100,000 Iraqi troops massing on Kuwait's border crossed over, occupying the country and destroying all government buildings and installations except for the water system and oil equipment. Over 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded. Iraq facilitated residents' departures then trucked in Iraqis to replace Kuwaitis and change the population's make-up. Thousands fled to Saudi Arabia, including the leadership. Jordan also took in refugees.Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of exceeding OPEC production quotas to drive down prices, and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries who staged a coup, which Kuwait denied. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because it demanded Iraq pay back billions loaned during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq War. Iran rejoiced that the world was waking up to Saddam Hussein.  Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush said the US would take any action necessary to defend its Persian Gulf interests and diverted a naval group to the Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait, supported widely by other countries. The Soviets and China stopped Iraqi arms sales. Iraq rounded up Westerners in Kuwait and threatened to hold hostage citizens of countries imposing sanctions. Oil prices hit five-year highs.
column9: Iraq invades and occupies Kuwait, bringing worldwide anger and sanctions.
column10: With little warning, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2, quickly taking the country.  Many fled as Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals, flying some to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong.  The United Nations' trade and military sanctions are being honored.  Oil prices are soaring.
column11: After two weeks of accusations and maneuvering, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2 with 100,000 battle-trained troops, quickly taking the country.  While the Kuwaiti emir and refugees fled to Saudi Arabia, Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals and repopulating the nation with Iraqi citizens.  Some foreigners were taken to Iraq, while some were flown to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong. The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions and President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests.  Iran rejoiced.  Most nations are strongly enforcing these sanctions as oil prices soar and Iraq begins defensive preparations.
column12: The Iraqi occupation of Kuwait began on August 2 when masses of combat-experienced troops poured across the border, quickly taking the country.  The Kuwait emir fled to Saudi Arabia.  The dispute began in mid-July when Iraq, a nation with 17 million, accused tiny Kuwait of stealing oil and flooding the market.  As Iraqi troops mobilized, efforts to avoid a confrontation failed.  While Iraqi said it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries, a Kuwaiti spokesman called this a false pretext.  President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf.  Iran, which fought an 8-year war with Iraq, rejoiced that the world saw the "Frankenstein" created by the United States and Kuwait.  The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait.  Most nations strongly enforced these sanctions, as oil prices soared.Iraq rounded-up foreign nationals in Kuwait, including passengers of a British airliner, and took many to Iraq.  An Iraqi jet finally brought some to Jordan on August 7.  Refugees poured into Saudi Arabia.  Some reported that Iraqis were moving in and being given Kuwaiti identities.  Iraq began evacuation drills and warned of U.S. or Israeli actions.

column3: Iran be deliberately underreporting the number of casualties from Thursday's massive earthquake out of fear of a political backlash, leaders of a group seek to overthrow the country's Islamic leadership say. The regime be very much fearful of public outrage, say Shahin Gobadi, spokesman for the People's Mojahedin of Iran. They're very much afraid of the political aftershocks. As Gobadi speak Friday, members of the organization denounce iran's government at a noisy rally hold in a park across the street from the White House. Northern Iran be stick Thursday by an earthquake measure between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter Scale. Iran have tell the United Nations that the death toll be at least 36,000, but Gobadi say his organization have receive estimates closer to 100,000. Gobadi say the country cannot properly assist earthquake victims because its treasury have be spend in a war with neighboring Iraq and against internal opposition. They have be very late in assist the people, he said. Sympathy for the earthquake victims be a secondary issue for the chanting, flag-waving rally participants, who also carry signs criticize their native country. Planning for the event begin three weeks before the earthquake, but part of the Friday's activities focus on Iran's stricken residents. Gobadi say shoddy housing in which the government force people to live be the cause for the widespread loss of life. This regime have bring them nothing but devastation and misery. This regime have devote all of its resources to a senseless war with Iraq and to oppression of the people at home, he said. A u.n.-sponsored cease-fire be declare last year after eight years of the Iran-Iraq war. Iran's Islamic republic be establish in 1979 after Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi be depose by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and militants seize the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, take 66 Americans hostage. The United States break diplomatic relations with Iran in April 1980. The shah die in exile in July 1980, U.S. hostages be free six months later and Khomeini die last June. Gobadi say his 25-year-old group have help depose the shah but have no part in organize the Islamic republic. even in this tragedy for which we grieve we cannot trust the regime in Iran, Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., tell an estimate 3,000 people attend the rally. There be many, many victims before this tragedy and there be victims now whose needs need to be address by the people of the United States, he said. Dymally, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, praise President Bush's offer of humanitarian aid to Iran but say Bush must make sure the assistance be channel through non-government groups. The State Department say Friday that Iran be willing to accept earthquake relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian organizations. An anti-american newspaper in Iran say Sunday the United States be partly to blame for the death of tens of thousands of people in last week's earthquake. The criminal role of America in Iran's past become evident once again in the recent earthquake, the Jomhuri Islami say in an editorial report by the official Islamic Republic News Agency. Our people, even under the rubble, chant `death to America' and pray to God to cut off the hands of the United States ... even those hands stretch out to help, it said. It argue that by plunder Iran's oil and other resources for 25 years, the United States have prevent the use of even a small part of the national wealth for urban development projects and advance (anti-seismic) building construction systems. even after its expulsion from Iran, the U.S. government by impose economic sanctions and launch several other plots, halt the renovation of the country, the editorial added. The newspaper be imply that with these actions the United States have block the diversion of funds to earthquake safety measures. If the United States have real humanitarian objectives and intend to help the iranian nation, it should do only one thing, stop hatching plots, the newspaper said. It call on Iranians to reject relief offers by the United States and other governments whose hands be stain with the blood of the iranian people. Iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, have say it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. The two nations have no diplomatic ties. Countries worldwide, both friendly and hostile to Tehran's Islamic government, send supplies, medical personnel and condolences to Iran, where about 40,000 people have die in an earthquake. Iran's deadly earthquake since 1976 jolt the northern part of the country Thursday, devastate towns and injure at least 100,000 people. The United States send a message of condolence and express its willingness to provide humanitarian aid. Iran, which have have no diplomatic ties with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, say it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. Moderate Arab countries with which Iran have have prickly relations Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan also offer their support. An official statement distribute late Friday by the Saudi Press Agency say the kingdom follow with deep sorrow the news of the tragedy. The kingdom of Saudi Arabia ... declare its readiness to help in extend assistance to those harm by the tragedy, wish to help ease the pain of the afflict from among the sons of the iranian Moslem nation, it said. Jordan announce Saturday it be send medical aid to Iran, but details be not immediately clear. King Hussein send condolences to iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Friday in what be believe to be the first direct contact between Jordanian and Iranian heads of state in almost a decade. Jordan back Iraq in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, which end with a cease-fire in August 1988, and at one point send hundreds of jordanian volunteers to fight alongside Iraqi soldiers. Egypt be send two military planes with supplies, the Middle East News Agency reported. President Hosni Mubarak offer the aid in the framework of Egypt's concern to provide help for brothers and friends, especially at times of natural disasters. The official soviet news agency Tass report that a professional lifesaving team from the armenian capital of Yerevan fly Saturday to iran. The team gain experience in the devastating 1988 earthquake in Armenia that kill 25,000 people. Thousands of residents in the predominantly Moslem Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, which border Iran, donate tons of flour, rice and tea, and contribute more than $500,000 to a special earthquake fund, Tass said. The italian Red Cross send a plane to Iran Saturday with relief supplies, include tents, blankets and medicine. In Paris, the French government, which already have send a 200-member civil defense team include rescuers, medical personnel and search dogs say Saturday it would send an entire mobile hospital unit if Iran want it. In West Germany, the Foreign Ministry say that it be send tents, blankets, hospital equipment and cooking equipment to Iran. Eight tons be be ship Saturday and the government have charter a jumbo jet to transport 100 tons of equipment Monday. At the Vatican, Pope John Paul II send aid to earthquake victims and a message of condolence to Iranian leaders. The Vatican say in a statement that the donation of an unspecified amount be to provide for the most immediate needs of the population hurt by this huge earthquake. John Paul also send a telegram to the papal nuncio, or diplomatic representative, in Tehran say the pope be pray fervently for the wounded and the families of the victims. The indian government say it would donate medicine, blankets and other relief supplies worth more than $500,000. China's Red Cross say it be send $106,000 worth of relief supplies, state-run television say Saturday. The polish government be send 5 tons of powdered milk, a ton of bed sheets, a ton of medicine and 3 tons of blankets and clothing, accord to polish media reports. Malaysia be provide more than $90,000 in relief aid. Foreign Ministry Secretary-General Ahmad Kamil Jaafar tell reporters Saturday the money would be use to buy medicine, food, powder milk, tents and other essential items. The earthquake that strike northern Iran bring reminders of another quake that devastate Soviet Armenia in 1988. Like Thursday's earthquake in Iran, the Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake in Armenia kill about 25,000 people. Most die in structures that collapse when the quake hit. It's very similar to what we have in Armenia, say Russ Needham, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey. The armenian quake be measure at 6.9 on the Richter scale, but Thursday's earthquake shake the earth with a magnitude of 7.7 accord to the U.S. Geological Survey. In the iranian quake, the casualty count be push up by the fact that people be indoors and asleep at the time, just after midnight. Many of the victims live in fragile homes build of a ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapse easily. In the armenian quake, a soviet parliamentary report later blame the high number of fatalities on shoddily build buildings. most casualties from earthquakes be cause by something fall on top of you, say Needham in a telephone interview from Golden, Colo. The quake strike an area of Iran where most of the buildings be build on a flood plain of loosely deposit soil that shift in an earthquake and allow structures to collapse, Needham said. The 7.7-magnitude quake be the large ever record in that area, where two major plates of the earth's crust meet, he said. Iran be in a very active seismic region, he said, and that there have be many small quakes. Twelve earthquakes great than magnitude 7 have occur in Iran during the last 30 years, Needham said. A quake of magnitude 7 be consider a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated areas. The earthquake that devastate Iran early Thursday take tens of thousands of lives because people be asleep in fragile homes build on flood plains, an earthquake expert said. most casualties from earthquakes be cause by something fall on top of you, say Russ Needham, a geophysist with the U.S. Geological Survey that monitors grind motion around the world. The quake hit at 12:30 a.m. in Iran, when most of the people be in their homes, Needham say Thursday in a telephone interview from Golden, Colo. At least 25,000 people die and thousands be injure in the quake, which demolish scores of villages and buried thousands of people in the rubble of their homes, iranian officials said. Needham say most structures in that area be build of a ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapse easily. It's very similar to what we have in Armenia, he say of the Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake that kill about 25,000 people. A Soviet parliamentary report later blame the high number of fatalities on shoddily build buildings. The armenian quake be measure at 6.9 on the Richter scale, but Thursday's earthquake shake the earth with a magnitude of 7.7. The shock wave travel through the mountainous section of coastal Iran where most of the buildings be build on a flood plain of loosely deposit soil that shift in an earthquake and allow structures to collapse, he said. The 7.7-magnitude quake be the large ever record in that area, where two major plates of the earth's crust meet, Needhams said. Iran be in a very active seismic region, he said, and that there have be many small quakes. Twelve earthquakes great than magnitude 7 have occur in Iran during the last 30 years, Needhams said. A quake of magnitude 7 be consider a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated areas. The estimated 50,000 dead in the Iran earthquake make it the world's fourth deadly quake in the past half-century. here be a list of the major quakes of the past 50 years. The location be follow by the Richter scale magnitude and the number of dead. Iran, June 21, 1990, 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, 50,000 dead (estimated). Soviet Armenia, Dec. 7, 1988, 6.9, 25,000. Iran, Sept. 16, 1978, 7.7, 25,000. China, July 28, 1976, 8.2, 200,000 officially, 800,000 unofficially. Guatemala, Feb. 4, 1976, 7.5, 22,778. Peru, May 31, 1970, 7.7, 66,794. Iran, Aug. 31, 1968, 7.4, 12,000. Iran, Sept. 1, 1962, 7.1, 12,230. Morocco, Feb. 29, 1960, 5.8, 12,000. soviet Turkmenia, Oct. 5, 1948, (no Richter reading available), 110,000.
column5: Worldwide Response to Devastating Iranian Earthquake
column6: The Iranian earthquake of June 21, 1990 which killed at least 50,000 and left 400,00 homeless elicited an outpouring of aid from around the world, both from countries friendly and from those hostile to Iran's Islamic government. The assistance from the United States was such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80.
column7: An earthquake of magnitude 7.7 hit northwestern Iran on June 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people and leaving 400,000 homeless. The quake occurred when most people were inside asleep and hit a coastal floodplain where loosely deposited soil shifts easily and caused the fragile adobe homes in the area to collapse. The Iranian president appealed for international aid and the response was overwhelming, both from countries friendly to Iran's Islamic government and from those hostile. Assistance from the United States was the first such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Their respective critics blamed the U.S. and Iranian governments for the high death toll.
column8: An earthquake hit northwestern Iran on June 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people and leaving 400,000 homeless. The death toll made this the fourth deadliest earthquake worldwide in fifty years. The quake measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and exacted particularly heavy casualties since it occurred when most people were inside asleep and hit a coastal area of loosely deposited soil that shifts, causing the adobe homes in the area to collapse. The Iranian President appealed for international aid from all countries except Israel and South Africa. Countries around the world, both friendly and hostile to Iran's Islamic government, responded quickly. The aid from the United States, including funds and supplies raised by Iranians in California , was channeled through the Red Cross and Red Crescent. This was a rare example of U.S.-Iranian cooperation after the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Countries as diverse as Egypt, China, India, Malaysia and the Soviet Union sent help. Even Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born author of "Satanic Verses," condemned to death by the Iranian ayatollahs, contributed $8,600. All was not sweetness and light, however. In Iran an anti-American newspaper blamed the high death toll on the United States and in Washington Iranian opposition leaders blamed it on the Iranian government.
column9: Devastating earthquake kills up to 55,000 in mountainous northern Iran.
column10: An earthquake in northern Iran Thursday morning killed as many as 55,000 and injured thousands more. The earthquake measured between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale and is the largest ever recorded in that area. The U.S. will provide aid through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies.
column11: The mountainous area of northern Iran was rocked by an earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale early Thursday morning. Killing as many as 55,000 people and injuring thousands of others, the earthquake occurred as most people were asleep. The United States will be providing $300,000 in supplies through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies. Iran, which broke diplomatic ties with the U.S. in 1979, has welcomed the aid. Russia has begun to airlift supplies into the area and is sending a rescue team from Soviet Armenia, the site of a devastating 1988 earthquake.
column12: An earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale struck northern Iran shortly after midnight on Thursday, killing as many as 55,000 people and injuring 10's of thousands more. The earthquake, which occurred in the mountainous area along Iran's coast, was the worst ever recorded in that area. Humanitarian aid began to pour into the area as the Soviet Union sent a professional life saving team from Soviet Armenia, the sight of a devastating earthquake in 1988. Although the United States broke diplomatic ties with Iran in 1979, Washington was arranging to provide humanitarian relief through the American Red Cross and other U.S. agencies. Iran has said it would welcome such supplies. An opposition group as accused the Iranian government underestimating the number of casualties and of devoting all of its resources to a war with Iran rather than providing adequate housing. On the other hand, an anti-American newspaper in Iran said the U.S. was partly to blame because it caused the Iranians to divert needed cash fromHousing projects and building earthquake resistant buildings. This is the fourth largest earthquake in the world in the last 50 years. The other three were in China in 1976, Soviet Turkmenia in 1948 and Peru in 1970.

column3: Gorbachev be set to board a plane in the Crimea, where he be vacation at the time of Monday's coup, for the two-hour flight to Moscow, say a deputy to Russian Defense Minister Konstantin Kobets. Earlier reports that the plane have already take off be incorrect, officials said.;the soviet leader, in a statement for radio and television, say he be fully in command of the situation and that the coup leaders would bear "full responsibility" for their actions.;in the United States, President Bush hail Gorbachev's return to power and say the coup leaders have "underestimated the power of the people, underestimate what a taste of freedom and democracy brings.";the three-day coup, one of the most tumultuous developments in recent soviet history, unravel in a series of swift and dramatic developments today:;(check) Tanks and armored personnel carriers move away from the russian parliament, scene of the bad violence of the coup. A 2 1/2-milelong column of tanks and trucks head out of Moscow.;(check) The leaders of the national legislature demand Gorbachev's reinstatement. The full legislature nullify the coup leaders' emergency decrees.;(check) Press restrictions be lifted. "I'm sorry, comrades, but I'm very excited!" say a soviet tv announcer, grin broadly after he be allow for the first time to criticize the coup leaders' actions.;(check) The Communist Party, apparently seek to salvage its own image, denounce the takeover.;(check) In the secessionist Baltic republics, which have borne the brunt of the post-coup crackdown, some soviet troops begin return to their permanent bases. Latvia join neighbor Estonia today in declare immediate independence from the Soviet Union.;The coup's failure could deal a fatal blow to organized, high-level efforts to thwart reform drives in the Soviet Union by Gorbachev and Yeltsin and significantly alter the balance of power that have characterize soviet power for the six-year Gorbachev era.;the country's future course depends, however, on who remain in power. Although Yeltsin support Gorbachev during the coup, the two men maintain different approaches to soviet reforms.;yeltsin address the Russian parliament today and say the Soviet Union have just "gone through a most tragic moment in its history, and perhaps the most tragic moment.";gorbachev's foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, who have drop out of sight during the coup, reappear today and call the takeover a page in soviet history that "has get to be turned.";the national legislature invalidate all decrees make by the coup leaders, national lawmaker Yuri Karyakin tell the Russian legislature. Karyakin say the legislature's executive council demand Gorbachev's return to power.;with the coup's demise, the Communist Party move to salvage its own credibility. It call the takeover unconstitutional and demand a meeting with Gorbachev, the party chief, the official news agency Tass said. The party renounce any connection with the coup leaders.;thousands of people have keep up their vigil at the russian parliament building after overnight clashes with soviet troops that leave at least four dead. They cheer when the announcement of the coup committee's departure come over a loudspeaker.;"this show the strength of our democracy," say Leonid Abramtsov, who be march with a band of teen-agers wave the red, white and sky-blue flag of the Russian republic.;the plane reportedly carry the coup leaders be say to be head to the city of Bishkek, formerly call Frunze, the capital of Kirgizia, 2,100 miles southeast of Moscow, accord to Radio Russia, which speak for Yeltsin. It be not immediately know why the coup leaders would travel to Kirgizia.;But sources at the airport tell the Associated Press that only KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov be on a plane, and it be head to the Crimea. He reportedly be accompany by Communist Party no. 2 leader Vladimir Ivashko.;The republic-run russian Information Agency say Vice President Gennady Yanayev, the nominal head of the coup committee, be still in his Kremlin office. The report could not be independently confirmed, and the discrepancies could not be clarified.;despite the force bring to bear by the coup leaders, they be unable to dislodge Yeltsin from the russian parliament, where he rally the opposition, to enforce the curfew, or prevent large demonstrations nationwide.;the state of emergency be declare after hard-line elements in the military and Communist Party oust Gorbachev, declare he be ill.;the junta have seem unable to cope with tens of thousands of people who erect barricades around Yeltsin's stronghold in the parliament.;there be also huge anti-coup demonstrations in Moscow, Leningrad, Kishiniev and other cities, as well as strikes by coal miners in Siberia.;Early today, before the coup fell apart, column of tanks and armored personnel carriers have move around central Moscow. One patrol of the armored vehicles be trap by furious demonstrators just after midnight as it try to break through a barricade.;two people be confirm shot or crush to death as the vehicles try to fight their way through, and witnesses say a third person be killed. A Russian republic official, Col. Viktor Samailov, tell the independent news agency Interfax that four people be shoot or crush to death in the clash. In the United States, President Bush say he speak to Gorbachev and the soviet leader be "calling the shots" again. Bush say the hard-line coup leaders have "underestimated the power of the people, underestimate what a taste of freedom and democracy brings.";the coup, one of the most tumultuous developments in recent soviet history, unravel in a series of swift and dramatic developments today:;(check) Tanks and armored personnel carriers move away from the russian parliament, scene of the bad violence of the coup. A 2 1/2-mile-long column of tanks and trucks head out of Moscow.;(check) The leaders of the national legislature demand Gorbachev's reinstatement. The full legislature nullify the coup leaders' emergency decrees.;(check) Press restrictions be lifted. "I'm sorry, comrades, but I'm very excited!" say a soviet tv announcer, grin broadly after he be allow for the first time to criticize the coup leaders' actions.;(check) The Communist Party, apparently seek to salvage its own image, denounce the takeover.;(check) In the independence-minded Baltic republics, which have borne the brunt of the post-coup crackdown, some soviet troops begin return to their permanent bases. Latvia join neighbor Estonia today in declare immediate independence from the Soviet Union.;The coup's failure could deal a fatal blow to organized, high-level efforts to thwart reform drives in the Soviet Union by Gorbachev and Yeltsin and significantly alter the balance of power that have characterize soviet power for the six-year Gorbachev era.;the country's future course depends, however, on who remain in power. Although Yeltsin support Gorbachev during the coup, the two men maintain different approaches to soviet reforms.;gorbachev's foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, who have drop out of sight during the coup, reappear today and call the takeover a page in soviet history that "has get to be turned.";At a news conference, Bessmertnykh promise that reforms would continue and that Moscow would honor its international commitments.;the national legislature invalidate all decrees make by the coup leaders, national lawmaker Yuri Karyakin tell the russian legislature. He give no details about the vote. Karyakin say the legislature's executive council demand Gorbachev's return to power.;word of Gorbachev's imminent return to the capital come from Lev Y. Sukhanov, a long-time Yeltsin deputy. He say Gorbachev would fly from his vacation retreat in the Crimea to the soviet capital with Vladimir Ivashko, the deputy general-secretary of the Communist Party and other aides.;with the coup's demise, the Communist Party move to salvage its own credibility. It call the takeover unconstitutional and demand a meeting with Gorbachev, the party chief, the official news agency Tass said. The party renounce any connection with the coup leaders.;thousands of people have keep up their vigil at the russian parliament building after overnight clashes with soviet troops that leave at least four dead. They roar with approval when the announcement of the coup committee's departure come over a loudspeaker.;the plane reportedly carry the coup leaders be say to be head to the city of Bishkek, formerly call Frunze, the capital of Kirgizia, 2,100 miles southeast of Moscow, accord to Radio Russia, which speak for Yeltsin. It be not immediately know why the coup leaders would travel to Kirgizia.;The radio say officials of the Russian republic would try to intercept the plane and have its passengers arrested.;but sources at the airport tell the Associated Press that only KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov be on a plane, and it be head to the Crimea, where Gorbachev reportedly have be place under house arrest. He reportedly be accompany by Communist Party no. 2 leader Vladimir Ivashko.;The republic-run russian Information Agency say Vice President Gennady Yanayev, the nominal head of the coup committee, be still in his Kremlin office. The report could not be independently confirmed, and the discrepancies could not be clarified.;bush, in Maine, tell a news conference that Yeltsin tell him in a telephone call that he believe that five of the coup leaders leave Moscow and that one of them, Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov, be in the hospital.;despite the force bring to bear by the coup leaders, they be unable to dislodge Yeltsin from the russian parliament, where he rally the opposition, to enforce the curfew, or prevent large demonstrations nationwide.;the state of emergency be declare after hard-line elements in the military and Communist Party oust Gorbachev, declare he be ill. Few believe it.;the junta have seem unable to cope with tens of thousands of people who erect barricades around Yeltsin's stronghold in the parliament.;there be also huge anti-coup demonstrations in Moscow, Leningrad, Kishiniev and other cities, as well as strikes by coal miners in Siberia.;Early today, before the coup fell apart, column of tanks and armored personnel carriers have move around central Moscow. One patrol of the armored vehicles be trap by furious demonstrators just after midnight as it try to break through a barricade.;two people be confirm shot or crush to death as the vehicles try to fight their way through, and witnesses say a third person be killed. A Russian republic official, Col. Viktor Samailov, tell the independent news agency Interfax that four people be shoot or crush to death in the clash. Gorbachev throw out his foreign minister, Alexander Bessmertnykh, and his acting defense minister, and name a new head of the KGB. And Yeltsin, with Gorbachev's blessing, fire the heads of state-owned media.;the Moscow City Council, meanwhile, order all Communist Party buildings in the capital seal and all telephone service to party and KGB buildings cut. About 2,000 protesters blockade the Communist Party headquarters in Moscow, declare they be try to prevent the removal of documents that might contain evidence link party members to the coup. Some of the demonstrators chanted, "down with the Communist Party!";Yeltsin, who have lead the nationwide resistance to the coup, announce a ban on Communist Party activities in the russian republic, the army, police units of the Interior Ministry and the KGB, which for decades help enforce Communist rule. Some of the many new decrees issue by Yeltsin go beyond the official bounds of his power as russian Federation president.;in his speech before the russian parliament, Gorbachev be compel to affirm as legitimate the decrees issue by Yeltsin during the three-day coup. It wasn't clear whether the Soviet president have intend to back Yeltsin's late decrees, and he balk at proposals by russian deputies to outlaw the Communist Party, say it would divide the nation.;gorbachev tell the deputies that the government would prosecute those responsible for the takeover. "They want to turn us into meat. They want to annihilate us, and for that they must bear the severe responsibility," the Soviet president said.;he accuse the Communist Party Central Committee of panic during the coup. "There be people who lose their heads, all sense of responsibility. You could even call them traitors! Traitors!";At one point during the session, Gorbachev dramatically hold up what he say be the minutes of a secret Cabinet meeting during the coup that reveal who back the emergency decrees. He say many of them "hemmed and hawed," but most vote in support of the takeover.;today's meeting display unprecedented openness in which deputies repeatedly interrupt Gorbachev and argue with him.;gorbachev drew applause from deputies when he announce that the party's headquarters in Moscow be sealed.;the meeting of Gorbachev and Yeltsin be the first since the coup collapse to discuss the takeover and to deal with officials who back the putsch.;in his speech, Gorbachev praise "the outstanding role" of Yeltsin, his sometimes adversary, in halt the hard-line Communist coup. Yeltsin have be a strong foe of Communist Party influence in the country; Gorbachev, however, warn in his speech against "any kind of anti-communist hysteria.";yeltsin often comment during Gorbachev's speech, and Gorbachev defer to him several times on details of what happen during Gorbachev's detention.; stand ovation;The soviet president's open comments draw a stand ovation from the lawmakers in the parliament. Yeltsin lead the opposition to the coup from the parliament building, where supporters rally to build barricades and form a human shield against expect attacks. The coup plotters never dare mount a frontal assault on Yeltsin's headquarters during the standoff.;as the face of the soviet government continue to change in the aftermath of the failed coup, hundreds of angry residents march toward Communist Party headquarters in Moscow intent on prove the party be behind the coup.;in other developments:;(check) only one of the eight top leaders of the coup remain at large early today -- Oleg Baklanov, deputy of the state Defense Committee.;(check) In Kirghizia, Kirghiz President Askar Akaev say the republic would take control of the headquarters of the Kirghiz wing of the Communist Party, as well as the local Lenin Museum. Akaev say the party would be compensated.;publication suspended; In Moscow, Yeltsin today nationalize the hundreds of print plants in the russian republic.;he suspend the publication of six Communist Party newspapers and order new chiefs for the official Novosti and Tass news services, charge they have support the takeover.;the actions by Yeltsin, who quit the party last summer, come amid a grow wave of anger at the Communist Party, six of whose top party officials be arrest for instigate the coup.;in a major blow to the crumble party, the act head of the KGB today affirm Yeltsin's ban on Communist Party activity in the security service, Tass said. A KGB directive also ban any other political parties in the KGB, for decades use by communist regimes to intimidate dissidents and anti-communist activists.; Bold protests; The firing of Bessmertnykh follow criticism of his silence during the coup. Bessmertnykh, 57, be the late official to step down or be remove after the failed takeover. He be not see publicly after the coup began, and he didn't re-emerge until the coup leadership begin to collapse.
