Bessmertnykh say he have be ill and unable to act.;the arrest of the former KGB chief and other Communist Party hard-liners inspired tens of thousands of demonstrators to undreamed-of daring Thursday.;They express their anger and disgust with the organizations responsible for kill millions of soviet citizens and now caught conspire to return to their old dictatorship.;at KGB headquarters on Dzerzhinsky Street, thousands shake fists and shouted, "executioners!" They smear "Down with the KGB!" and a swastika on the front of the building in white paint. The "coup people," as President Bush dub them, could not have miscalculate more profoundly. They think the issue be Mikhail Gorbachev, and apparently believe that by neutralize Gorbachev and threaten everyone else, they could quickly take charge of the country.;but the people of the Soviet Union apparently conclude that the real issue be not Gorbachev himself, but the new political culture of freedom and even democracy that his reforms have created. For the first time in their thousand-year history, Russians assert their independence from autocracy, and the autocrats fell.;there will be much to sort out in the months ahead. But almost certainly the failure of the counterrevolution will accelerate the democratic revolution it try to choke. That revolution will alter the country, create a new, decentralize and probably small Soviet Union much more quickly than anyone anticipated.;gorbachev's own standing also will be transform by these events. It seem unlikely that he can escape the consequences of his own past miscalculations -- especially the miscalculation that lead him to embrace the very men who lead this putsch against his rule. Gorbachev be the most resourceful and creative political leader of the late 20th century, but this week he be trump by Boris Yeltsin, who will now rightly be see as the man who save him.;yeltsin have two talents that Gorbachev lacked. One be the ability to stay close to the russian people as their world be transform by Gorbachev's revolution -- hence his thump victory in this spring's first presidential election in Russia and Gorbachev's abysmal standing in the polls. Yeltsin's second talent be his eagerness to challenge the apparatus of the Soviet Communist Party, the world from which both he and Gorbachev emerged.;gorbachev could never shuck his party apparatchik's skin. instead of reach out to new ideas and new people as Yeltsin has, he surround himself with traditional Communist Party officials and worry about the impact of new schemes and ideas. Gorbachev think Vladimir Kryuchkov of the KGB, Boris Pugo of the Ministry of Interior, Dmitri Yazov of the Red Army and Gennady Yanayev of the Communist Party be necessary bedfellows whose presence in his entourage could protect him from conservative forces that hat his reforms. Instead, they turn out to be mortal enemies.;if they have be only personal enemies, Gorbachev might have be undone by them. But when they close the new, liberal news media and revert to the Stalinist tradition of the big lie, the members of the State Emergency Committee threaten not just Gorbachev but also the new Soviet Union -- a society that offer its citizens an unprecedented opportunity for dignity, self-reliance and freedom. For years, Soviets and western Kremlinologists have debate whether the changes that create this new Soviet Union be irreversible. Tuesday, it become clear that they were.;of course, Gorbachev initiate those changes, and history will credit him for that. He also refuse to acquiesce to the state of emergency that those responsible for the coup apparently ask him to endorse last weekend.;it be intrigue in assess the coup's failure that men train as thugs by some of the most violent and mean-spirited institutions create by any state could not, in their moment of truth, behave like thugs and kill their compatriots. They leave Gorbachev alive and Yeltsin at large; they let the western media report their coup as it unfolded; and they allow foreign radio stations to broadcast news of it back into the country. even their own news media, under strict control, convey the fact that there be widespread resistance to their attempt coup.;by Tuesday night, the Emergency Committee be in a confrontation with the political legitimacy of Yeltsin, and this prove an unequal contest. As Gorbachev have previously discover in his negotiations with Yeltsin over a new union treaty, the legitimacy provide by the 50 million votes that yeltsin receive in the elections for president of the russian federation be a formidable political force.;at first blush, the botching of the coup be surprising -- couldn't the vaunted KGB and its allies run an efficient putsch? But these be representatives of the political class that turn one of the world's rich nations into a basket case. perhaps their coup should be see as a desperate and forlorn effort to deny a truth that prove undeniable -- that the Stalinist system have fail so utterly there be simply no way to redeem it. Gorbachev choose to ignore warnings about the right's impend attempt to seize power. Some warnings come from Gorbachev's liberal advisers, such as Alexander Yakovlev, shortly before the coup. But, incredibly, the clearest signals come from the hard-liners themselves.;a lead conservative journalist, Alexander Prokhanov, know as the "nightingale of the General Staff," publish a transcript of his conversation with the head of the General Staff Academy, the commander-in-chief of the Soviet Navy and Gorbachev's deputy at the Defense Council, Oleg Baklanov. With remarkable candor, Baklanov call for a military takeover as an appropriate step to avert reforms that would result in a fundamental transformation of the union. Needless to say, Baklanov deliver on that warning and join the Gang of Eight.;Gorbachev ignore these warnings.;To some -- an admitted minority -- the thought of a Gorbachev conspiracy be comfortably within the range of the traditional soviet art of deception know as maskirovka. And to laymen, something that odd could make sense in a country where illness can mean anything from the flu to a precipitous fall from power.;the most volatile fuel for the conspiracy theory come directly from Gorbachev himself, in his Thursday news conference in which he describe his three days under house arrest in the Crimea.;Among the questions: If Gorbachev's 32 arm guards remain loyal to him throughout, why be there no conflict with the opposition delegation that notify the president of the coup? Why didn't the coup leaders incapacitate Gorbachev's guards, or at least separate them from him?;if Gorbachev's contact with the outside world be limit to intercept western radio outlets on an ancient shortwave radio, how be he able to describe the news conference give by the collaborators, down to his view of their trembling hands?;it be highly unlikely that the hard-liners have be set up or order by Gorbachev to launch a hopeless coup attempt in order to improve his political standing. Such a scenario would require an unprecedented degree of selfless commitment to Gorbachev on their part.;a more plausible scenario be that Gorbachev be initially a full member of the conspiracy, which, with his participation, could have cling to the fig leaf of constitutionality and would have thwart the new Union Treaty, to have be sign last Tuesday, which provide for transfer of key levers of power from the federal presidency to the leaders of republics.;it be possible that, unwilling to take a huge risk and openly side with the hard-liners at the start of the coup, Gorbachev have decide to become ill and wait out the initial phase under virtually self-imposed confinement in his summer residence.;gorbachev do reveal, however, that two important officials have visit him in Crimea at the outset of the coup. One be head of the KGB department responsible for the security of soviet leaders; the other be V. Boldin, Gorbachev's close aide, by the president's own admission a man of absolute loyalty to him. One can't help but wonder whether these two visitors come to deliver an ultimatum to Gorbachev and put him under arrest in the event of his non-compliance, or to deliver important documents from fellow junta members at the outset of their joint enterprise.;conspiracy theorists grope for motives -- Gorbachev want to ferret out disloyal elements in his government, to make himself a hero and to delay the scheduled signing of a treaty that would have lessen his powers. But there be virtually unanimous agreement on one point. Gorbachev put into power the very hard-liners who front the coup and keep them in power despite their vocal mutterings about him. Cut to a row of dour Communists in ill-fitting gray suits announce Gorbachev's illness and a palace coup. The camera zoom in on the impassive face of the two men last see in Gorbachev's office.;What be go on here?;ok, it's a hackneyed device that would only work in the movies. But then, this week's events in the Soviet Union have all the makings of a spy thriller.;Kremlinologists who dabble in conspiracy theories be work overtime, though they insist that their dark imaginings be clearly labeled "pure speculation.";"once you have a palace coup, the possibilities be endless," say Robert Conquest, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution. "russian politics be full of very strange things.";for all we know, Conquest joked, Gorbachev could be inject with drugs to change his personality or KGB scientists could produce a body-double to impersonate him.;"his friends would know, but would you or i?" Conquest said. "That would be go a bit far.";a more intriguing scenario have Gorbachev conspire with the coup plotters to engineer a transformation of the soviet political landscape. The thinking go like this:;with his popularity at rock bottom, Gorbachev, a lifelong creature of the KGB, hatch a false coup in order to step out of the way while hard-liners and liberals battle each other. The coup fall apart and Gorbachev triumphantly return with a level of legitimacy he never enjoy before.;the theory could explain the apparent bungling of the coup plotters, say author Joseph Finder, whose 1991 novel, "the Moscow Club," foreshadow many of the elements of the current crisis.;finder, who say he do not subscribe to the scenario, nonetheless point out that tanks do not begin to roll until hours after Gorbachev's suppose arrest. Russian President Boris Yeltsin be not arrested, and Leningrad be leave alone.;speculation be not unique to Kremlin watchers in the United States.;Theorizing be rampant in the streets of Moscow on Tuesday, say San Francisco businesswoman Kimberly Getto, who send a long fax detail speculation, fuel by the fact that many of the tanks encircle the russian parliament building have no ammunition. Gorbachev do not want bloodshed, accord to the theory.;the democratic Reform Movement, head by former Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, Gorbachev's longtime ally, float the same possibility in a statement Monday.;"It's highly implausible, but not to be excluded, that Gorbachev himself agree to a withdrawal, think he'd show them they still need him," say Norman Naimark, director of Stanford's Center for Russian and East European Studies. "The degree of connivance be difficult to gauge." At the news conference -- Gorbachev's first since the coup against him collapse on Wednesday -- the 60-year-old leader condemn the takeover as be against "the people, against democracy.";earlier, he tell reporters he would have kill himself rather than submit to any force arrangement with the coup leaders. "I say I wouldn't make any deals," he say then. "otherwise, I would have have to commit suicide.";gorbachev detail his purge of coup leaders, include Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov. He name a new act KGB chief, interior minister and defense minister, and say he would do everything to "drive out the reactionary forces from the Communist Party.";Gorbachev pledge cooperation with russian republic President Boris Yeltsin but say he have no plans to leave the Communist Party.;"I be convince that socialism be correct. I be an adherent of socialism.";when ask if Yeltsin now have more power than he did, Gorbachev said, "We have be bind together by the situation.";looking and sound angry, he describe the plotters as "primitive and crude and crafty" and scoffed at their announcement that he have step aside because he be ill. "their hands be shake the whole time," he say derisively.;despite his display of anger, the Soviet president say the failure of the coup could ultimately help ensure the continuation of his reforms. "We have to see this as an enormous opportunity," he said.;at his news conference, Gorbachev make a point of publicly praise Yeltsin, whose folk-hero stature be enhance during the coup as he rally hundreds of thousands of his supporters to resist.;before dawn today, Gorbachev fly back to Moscow from the Crimea, where he have be confine to his summer home during his brief ouster.;The soviet president, who be report to have sleep for a few hours in his dacha outside Moscow after return from the Crimea, arrive at Moscow's Vnukovo Airport unannounced, under heavy security. He look somewhat disheveled, clad in a windbreaker and a shirt with open collar.;appearing on soviet television after his arrival, Gorbachev look haggard and unshaven, with deep lines around his eyes and mouth. Later, at his news conference, he at first speak haltingly, but then appear to recover his composure and spoke in a forceful voice.;gorbachev say his captors cut off all communication and that his only source of news during the coup have be from foreign broadcasts, include the BBC and Voice of America, receive on a makeshift radio set up by his personal guards.;"this have be a very difficult, an extremely difficult lesson for me. It's my, you might say, my drama," he tell reporters.;"everything be do to weaken me psychologically," Gorbachev said. "it be hard. It be hard to say it now, but that's how it was.";he say that early on in the coup, he try to find out who be behind it.;"i pick up one of the telephones I have and it wasn't working. I pick up a second, a third, a fourth . . . everything be cut off," he said.;"every day, morning and night, I demand . . . that my communication be restore and that an airplane be bring immediately so I could be return to Moscow," he said. He be be hold at his vacation home in the Crimea.;Gorbachev say the coup leaders demand that he resign.;"i said, 'You will never live that long (to see me resign).' ";He call the crisis "one of the most difficult trials of the entire history" of his six-year rule.;gorbachev say his 32-man personal guard stay with him throughout the coup.;the 60-year-old president say the crisis have be difficult for his family, especially his wife, Raisa, who "took it very hard.";"best of all, my granddaughter Anastasia didn't understand anything that be go on," Gorbachev tell reporters. "She want to go to the beach; that's all that concerned her. But the guards wouldn't let her go to the beach; they be concerned something would happen.";when it become clear the coup be failing, Gorbachev say he prepare himself and his family for the possibility that they would be kill by the conspirators.;"you know that it appear as though they might have do something to me. They might have kill me and my whole family and make it look as if . . . they be act in the name" of the act president.;"these people might have do almost anything," he said. Gorbachev tell an audience at the russian parliament that the government would prosecute those responsible for the takeover. "They want to turn us into meat. They want to annihilate us, and for that they must bear the severe responsibility," the Soviet president said.;he accuse the Communist Party Central Committee of panic during the coup. "There be people who lose their heads, all sens
column5: Soviet President Gorbachev survives coup but loses popularity to Yeltsin.
column6: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed. Although the junta couldn't cope with the resistance of thousands of people around the Russian Parliament, the real issue was not Gorbachev but the new political culture he initiated and the popular anti-Communist stand of Boris Yeltsin.
column7: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed, unraveling swiftly as junta was unable to cope with thousands of people who created barricades around the Russian Parliament, Russian President Yeltsin's stronghold. The national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement and the Communist Party, seeking to salvage its image, denounced the takeover.The real issue for the coup failure was not Gorbachev but the new political culture of democracy he initiated. At first Gorbachev and Yeltsin appeared as equals but Yeltsin, who challenged the Communist Party and stayed close to the Russian people, trumped Gorbachev.
column8: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev returned to power as the coup against him collapsed while he was vacationing in Crimea. The coup unraveled swiftly as the junta was unable to cope with thousands of people who erected barricades around Yeltsin's stronghold, the Russian Parliament. The national legislature demanded Gorbachev's reinstatement and nullified the coup leaders' decrees. The Communist Party, seeking to salvage its image, denounced the takeover. The coup people thought they could take over by neutralizing Gorbachev.However, the real issue was not Gorbachev but the new political culture of freedom and democracy his reforms had created. Gorbachev initiated the changes but his standing was transformed when he was trumped by Russia's President Boris Yeltsin who, unlike Gorbachev, challenged the Communist Party and stayed close to the Russian people. Gorbachev and Yeltsin at first appeared as equals while launching a purge of the Communist Party, although Gorbachev balked at Yeltsin's proposals to ban the Communist Party. Later, Yeltsin made it clear in the Russian Parliament that Gorbachev has authority only if agreeing to share power and intensify the march toward a democracy and a free economy.There is speculation that Gorbachev orchestrated the coup in order to ferret out the disloyal.
column9: Gorbachev returns to Moscow after failed coup; Yeltsin key role
column10: The attempted coup in the USSR fell apart three days after the house arrestof President Mikhail Gorbachev in the Crimea.  Thousands of citizens ralliedin support of Boris Yeltsin who led the opposition to the coup.  Gorbachevwas returned to the presidency but Yeltsin was emerging as the new leader.
column11: Soviet hard-liners staged a coup in order to prevent implementation ofGorbachev's reforms. Some viewers suspected a Gorbachev role in the coup asa ploy to solidify his position. The coup ended after three days due mainlyto opposition by Boris Yeltsin who rallied thousands in opposition.  Coupleaders were arrested and Gorbachev was returned to the presidency.Gorbachev still hoped to implement reforms working through the CommunistParty.  Yeltsin, however, had quit the party and wanted to see its influencelessened.  Yeltsin was clearly moving into a greater leadership role in thenew Russia.
column12: Soviet hard-liners attempted a coup in order to thwart the impending signingof the new Union Treaty incorporating the reforms of Soviet PresidentGorbachev.  The coup leaders put Gorbachev under house arrest in the Crimea.Russian President Boris Yeltsin led opposition to the coup, which did nothave popular support, and it was put down after three days.  Gorbachev wasreturned to Moscow and was reinstated as president.  Some observers wonderedabout Gorbachev's actions just before the coup attempt since he had ignoredample warnings that it might happen. Conspiracy buffs even wondered ifGorbachev might have even been part of the planning.Upon his return to power, Gorbachev ordered the arrest of the coup leadersand made new appointments to key positions.  The putdown of the coup meantthat the reforms giving more authority to the republics would go forward.Gorbachev and Yeltsin approached the reforms differently.  Gorbachev wantedto work through the Communist Party, but Yeltsin had quit the party andwanted to see its influence lessened.  Yeltsin was clearly more in touchwith the people.  The two leaders made a joint appearance at the RussianParliament where it became increasingly clear that Gorbachev's authority waswaning while Yeltsin's was ascending.

column3: The arrival Wednesday of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela prompt an outpouring of praise and encouragement from politicians and supporters. A sampling of their comments: In the 15 months since he walk free from prison, Nelson Mandela have play the chief role in talks with President F.W. de Klerk and the white government. He have preside over an african National Congress divide and not yet organize for politics. He have spend his moral capital trying, unsuccessfully, to end the murderous conflict between black political factions.; now Mandela be confront with his wife's conviction for a brutal criminal offense. He have loyally defend her innocence. He have seem to hear no voice to the contrary. But events have catch up.; The radicals in the ANC may well use the trial and conviction of Mrs. Mandela to arouse members against Nelson Mandela's policy of peace and negotiation.; There be rumors that at a national conference next month the radicals will try to move such old leaders as Mandela and Walter Sisulu aside to a nominal senior role.; It be a gloomy picture: an elderly man bear the hopes of peace in South Africa beset by problems, personal trauma on top of political. But I think it would be wrong to conclude that the south african drama be necessarily head toward a tragic end.; One reason for a degree of optimism be the way South Africans on all sides, most of them, have deal with Winnie Mandela's trial: calmly and fairly.; During the years of white supremacy the law have be viciously misused. But from all one can tell, this trial be handle professionally by the judge, Justice Michael Stegmann.; The reaction to the verdict and six-year prison sentence be also mild. Surprisingly few supporters gather outside the court to cheer Mrs. Mandela. The ANC issue a detached statement say that the last word have not be speak in the case. Archbishop Desmond Tutu say "the movement be large than any individual."; A more fundamental reason for hope be that F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela -- and those for whom they speak -- have a common interest in create a new, non-racial South Africa. They need each other. Without their agreement, there can be no solution, no outcome that leave a viable country.; The next step be formal negotiations. They can come only when the government take further steps to meet the reasonable ANC demand for action against violence -- in particular, a ban on the carrying of so-called "cultural" weapons such as spears. How can the government look away when 1,000 Zulus carry spears and machetes slaughter township residents?; The time factor be crucial now. Negotiations must start soon if the moderate center of the public, black and white, be to retain hope for a peaceful solution. World and time press on Nelson Mandela. A 3-year campaign that have succeed in get Northeastern University to award an honorary degree to jail south african nationalist leader Nelson Mandela have raise objections from some faculty and students. Northeastern announce plans to award the degree honor Mandela on May 13, end a long effort by students seek to change a university policy bar honorary degrees for anyone who could not be present at the ceremony. The degree be to be accept by south african Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who be schedule to be in Boston for a benefit dinner. Law students last September begin a campaign of demonstrations and vigils on the campus. They hang a banner from the second floor of the law library that said: Honor Nelson Mandela. Before he be imprisoned, say third-year law student Sarah Ottinger, Nelson Mandela be an ... attorney and an activist who work against apartheid. That's the message we want convey to students. South Africa's white-minority government say it will free Mandela only if he renounce the use of violence by forces seek political power for blacks in the country. Some faculty members and students, include many blacks, have criticize the administration's plan for the event, say no effort be make to include them. I don't even know what office be sponsor it, say Keith Motley, dean and director of the african-american Institute, a student group. We get a memo from the administration say they need six ushers, but that's it. You'd think at least we'd be clue in to what's go on. This start out as something noble, something we've try to have do for three years, say Ottinger. We be very, very sorry it happen this way. It wasn't mean to turn out like this. The trustees decide in January that Mandela should get the honorary degree. Students set up a committee to contact Mandela's family to get their approval. University spokesman Paul Jones say letters be send to Mandela's wife, Winnie, and his two daughters: zenani, a student at Boston University, and Makaziwe, a student at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. However, Northeastern still have not receive approval from the Mandela family, The Boston Globe reported. Unidentified assailants hurl a grenade and fire shots today at the home of relatives of Nelson Mandela, kill a baby girl and injure her parents, police said. African National Congress officials say the dead child and her parents be distant cousins of Nelson Mandela. They deny South african police and press reports that the child be Mandela's great-granddaughter. Police say they do not know who be responsible for the attack. No group take immediate responsibility. Police Lt. Govindesamy Mariemuthoo say the attack occur before dawn at the home of Monde Mandela in the black township of Soweto. The blast badly damage part of the house, knock holes in the wall and cause extensive damage. The police officer say a baby girl be kill and her parents injured. He give no other detail on the victims. He say the room in which the injured couple have be sleep be destroyed. ANC officials say the dead child be the great niece of Mandela's father, make her a distant cousin of Nelson Mandela. The dead girl's father, Monde Mandela, run a small grocery shop. The ANC officials say Nelson Mandela be close to the Monde Mandela family. An ANC statement said, The ANC note the curious coincidence of an attack on a man bear the Mandela name at this time. give the distant connection between Mandela and the family, police say they do not know if the attack be deliberate or just a random attack link to the general violence. Mandela be reportedly attend a political meeting in the eastern province of Natal today. Soweto and other black townships around Johannesburg have be hit by black factional fighting that have kill about 800 people since August. The fighting have pit followers of the ANC against Zulus of the conservative Inkatha group. Mandela have repeatedly accuse security forces of manipulate the violence to derail government efforts to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. The police have deny Mandela's charges. Mandela be release in February after 27 years in jail for oppose the white minority government. He be closely guard by ANC operatives, and there have be reports of threats on his life in recent months. Mandela and other ANC leaders have be negotiate with President F.W. de Klerk to pave the way for full-scale talks on end apartheid, the south african system of racial separation. De Klerk have promise to end white-minority rule. Mayor David Dinkins warn jewish groups against protest the visit of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela to New York City, say the protests might insult the black community, a newspaper say today. The mayor also ask members of the organized Jewish community to dissuade more radical groups from disrupt the visit, the Daily News said. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, will visit eight cities from June 20 to July 1. There be a danger of many people who hold Nelson Mandela in very, very high esteem take great umbrage at any public protest, Dinkins said. I think it's sad and unfortunate and tactically very, very unwise, because this man be an international symbol of freedom and especially so see by persons of color, Dinkins tell the newspaper in an interview. Leaders of several jewish-american organizations plan to meet Mandela on Sunday in Geneva. The organizations want the south african leader to clarify his position on Israel. Mandela have embrace Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in public and have compare the struggle of Palestinians to that of black South Africans. Rabbi Abraham Weiss of the Hebrew Institute announce his coalition of Concern will hold a protest at Mandela's public welcome in New York because of the anti-apartheid leader's unbend anti-israel stance. City councilman Noach Dear and state assemblyman Dov Hikind say if Mandela do not make a strong statement in support of Israel, they would take out ads in newspapers and hold demonstrations. Four imprisoned African National Congress leaders, convict in 1964 with Nelson Mandela, be allow to visit their ANC colleague at his isolated prison house, an activist say today. The four men, all hold at Pollsmoor Prison in Cape Town, be take to nearby Victor Verster Prison on Dec. 23 and spend about six hours with Mandela, say Dullah Omar, an activist and family friend of the Mandelas. Mandela be move to the suburban-style home on the prison ground Dec. 7 after recover from tuberculosis at a private clinic in Cape Town. Mandela's wife, Winnie, say after visit her husband last month that he be be hold practically in solitary confinement at the house. The four men who visit Mandela be Walter Sisulu, Andrew Mhlangeni, Raymond Mhlaba and Ahmed Kathrada. The men be convict along with Mandela and three others at the same trial in 1964. All be give life sentences for their activities with the ANC, the main guerrilla group attempt to overthrow the white-led government. All of them except Sisulu have not see Nelson since 1986, and they be very excite at be able to spend time with him, Omar said. Of the three co-defendants not at the Dec. 23 gathering, two have be release and one remain at the Robben Island Prison near Cape Town. The Prisons Service decline to confirm or deny the visit. A representative of the African National Congress say Saturday the South african government may release black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela as early as Tuesday. There be very strong rumors in South Africa today that on Nov. 15 Nelson Mandela will be released, say Yusef Saloojee, chief representative in Canada for the ANC, which be fight to end white-minority rule in South Africa. Mandela the 70-year-old leader of the ANC jail 27 years ago, be sentence to life in prison for conspire to overthrow the south african government. He be transfer from prison to a hospital in August for treatment of tuberculosis. Since then, it have be widely rumor Mandela will be release by Christmas in a move to win strong international support for the south african government. It will be a victory for the people of South Africa and indeed a victory for the whole of Africa, Saloojee tell an audience at the University of Toronto. A South african government source last week indicate recent rumors of Mandela's impend release be orchestrate by members of the anti-apartheid movement to pressure the government into take some action. And a prominent anti-apatheid activist in South Africa say there have be no indication (mandela) would be release today or in the near future. Apartheid be South Africa's policy of racial separation. The large family group to visit black leader Nelson Mandela since he be jail 27 years ago gather in Cape Town for a meeting Tuesday with the prisoner on his 71st birthday. His wife, Winnie Mandela, arrive Monday night and indicate she do not expect Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, would be free soon. She say that opinion come from her husband, who she visit last week after Mandela's July 5 meeting with President P.W. Botha. That meet spark speculation that Mandela would be free this year. He be serve a life term after be convict of sabotage and plot to overthrow the white-dominated government. Mrs. Mandela, refer to her early visit with her husband, tell reporters: He say from that meeting with P.W. Botha we musn't construe as indicate his release. His release wasn't even there. In fact it be not on the agenda at all. Mrs. Mandela, dress in black as an expression of mourning, speak with reporters at the D.F. Malan Airport. She say the family normally spent Mandela's birthday at home, fasting and praying, but members would visit him this year on his birthday because he have invite us to come and share it with him. The family say 14 relatives, include children from both of Mandela's marriages, would go to Mandela's house at the Victor Verster prison farm in Paarl, north of Cape Town. In addition to Mrs. Mandela the group will include three of Mandela's children, one daughter-in-law, eight grandhildren and a great-grandson. Mrs. Mandela show reporters a huge cardboard birthday card in the black, green and yellow colors of the outlawed African National Congress, the large guerrilla group fight the government. She say the card be make by members of the National Union of Mineworkers. It be very nice but it be also at the same time very sad, she say of the plan birthday celebration. After all, he be not at home. Mandela be allow to meet last Friday with five other ANC members convict with him in 1964 of try to overthrow the government and still imprison in Cape Town, accord to Dullah Omar, a family friend and attorney. Mandela have be in prison since 1962 when he be sentence to five years for leave the country illegally and organize an illegal strike. He be give a life sentence follow the 1964 conviction. Omar say Tuesday's family gathering will be an occasion with a strong theme of sadness because after the reunion they will leave Mr. Mandela to resume his lonely life. Mandela's old grandson, Mandla, 14, arrive Monday even from Swaziland where he be a student at a private school. Mandla be the son of Makgatho Mandela, the prisoner's eldest son by his first marriage to Evelyn Ntoko Mase, who live in the black township of Soweto and be not expect to join the reunion. Makgatho Mandela come to Cape Town with his wife, Zondi, his daughter Indaba and 4-year-old Thembela, Mandela's great-grandson. Thembela be the grandson of Tembikile Mandela. Tembikile, Mandela's son by his marriage to Evelyn Ntoko Mase, die in an automobile accident in 1970. Evelyn Ntoko Mase, the cousin of ANC leader Walter Sisulu who have be imprison with Mandela, marry Nelson Mandela in 1944. They have four children. One of their daughters, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, arrive with her three children from the United States, where she be study for a doctoral degree in anthropology at Amherst College in Massachusetts. She said, He (Nelson Mandela) believe that education be the key to all doors and he would like to see all of his children get an education; in fact all of the black children ... because you cannot claim to want to rule the country and be the leaders of the future if you have people who be untrained and don't have any skills. Mrs. Mandela-Amuah say of her father's possible release, I always firmly believe that you can't predict what the south african government will do.
column9: Mandela released from prison; end of apartheid in South Africa near
column10: Nelson Mandela spent 27 years of a life sentence in prison for conspiring tooverthrow the apartheid government of South Africa. World leaders hailed hisrelease in 1990 and considered him a hero.  His efforts to negotiate an endto white minority rule were complicated by factionalism and the imprisonmentof his wife, Winnie.
column11: Nelson Mandela, a leader in the African National Congress' opposition toSouth Africa's policy of apartheid, spent nearly 27 years in prison.  He wassentenced to life in prison in 1964 for conspiring to overthrow thegovernment.  He became a rallying point for nations that were pressuringSouth Africa to end its all-white government.  World leaders hailedMandela's release in 1990, and he was welcomed as a hero when he traveled,including a visit to New York City.  In-fighting among black elementscomplicated Mandela's role in negotiations to end white-minority rule inSouth Africa.  Also, Mandela's wife, Winnie, was imprisoned, complicatingmatters.
column12: Nelson Mandela joined the African National Congress in 1944 and participatedin black protests and civil disobedience opposing the apartheid governmentof South Africa.  He was arrested several times, and in 1964, was given alife sentence for conspiring to overthrow the government.  Many countriespressured South Africa to end its all-white rule, and Mandela's imprisonmentbecame a cause celebre.  In 1988, Mandela's 70th birthday was celebratedoutside South Africa.  Northeastern University planned to award an honorarydegree to Mandela.  Rumors began to spread that South Africa would releaseMandela to gain international support.  President Botha would do so if herenounced violence.  Mandela refused.Mandela contracted tuberculosis in 1988.  After being cured, he was moved tobetter quarters and was permitted visits from family and even ANC leaders.Mandela was released in 1990, as world leaders cheered.  He visited New YorkCity and received accolades from politicians and black leaders.  However,American Jewish leaders were hesitant since he had compared the Palestinianstruggle to that in South Africa.Mandela was among black leaders negotiating with President de Klerk to endapartheid.  His task was complicated by violent factions among blacks and byhis wife, Winnie, being imprisoned for a violent crime.
column13: Nelson Mandela, leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government, freed from prison after 27 years.
column14: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on February 11, 1990.  From prison, he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  In 1964 he was convicted of conspiracy to overthrow the government and was sentenced to life in prison.
column15: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on 11 February 1990.  From prison he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  He was convicted in 1964 of conspiracy to overthrow the government and sentenced to life in prison.  International pressure had been mounting for his release and many governments had imposed sanctions on South Africa.  He continued the fight for black human rights after his release, but had many problems to overcome including factional fighting between the ANC and the Zulu Inkatha group.
column16: Nelson Mandela, the leading opponent of South Africa's white-led government was freed after 27 years in prison on 11 February 1990.  From prison he had led the fight against the government's policy of racial segregation, apartheid.  He, along with other members of the African National Congress, was convicted in 1964 of conspiracy to overthrow the government.  Over the years, international pressure had been mounting for his release and several governments had barred imports from South Africa or investments in the country.  Upon his release Mandela continued the fight for black human rights, but he faced many problems.  He attempted to negotiate an end to the violence between the ANC and the Zulu Inkatha group, which had resulted in many deaths in the Black townships.  His wife was convicted of kidnapping and sentenced to 6 years in prison.  Nelson joined the ANC when he was 26 and rose to a leadership position. The ANC was outlawed in 1960.   He was sentenced to five years in prison in 1962 for illegally leaving the country and for organizing a strike.  Mandela was highly praised during a visit to the United States after his release, but Jewish groups were critical of his support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

column3: Viktor Alksnis, former USSR Supreme Soviet deputy, today remind us of his existence. [correspondent Irina Zaytseva] Viktor Alksnis, bear 1950, Latvian, former deputy of the Supreme Soviet of the former USSR, soldier, resign from the Army in order to fight for the restoration of the USSR. During the October events he leave the White House with a head wound and be take to hospital. After a long interval Viktor Alksnis hold a news conference today in the Slavjanskaya Hotel. He begin it with a short statement, the essence of which come down to the fact that the adoption of the Latvian citizenship law violate not only human rights, but create the conditions for a conflict similar, in his opinion, to the ones in Yugoslavia and the Caucasus. It be not only the latvian Government Alksnis accuse of this, but also the United States. accord to him, during the late visit to the United States by [latvian President] Guntis Ulmanis, sanction be obtain for the adoption of the aforementioned discriminatory law. [begin Alksnis recording] And thus carte blanche be give for mild ethnic cleansing of the russian speaking population of the republic. [end recording] [Zaytseva] Apart from that, Alksnis added, accord to information receive from reliable sources, certain circles in Moscow want conflict in Latvia. [Begin Alksnis recording] A certain scenario exist to drive a so-called security corridor along the route Daugavpils-Yekabpils-Riga where stringent ethnic cleansing of the latvian population will take place in reply to the mild ethnic cleansing of the russian population in order to bring so-called independent Latvia to its knees. [end recording] [zaytseva] Journalists ask for more precise information about what Alksnis call reliable sources. [begin Alksnis recording] You understand that I cannot name these sources. But I can say that they be fairly authoritative. [end recording] [zaytseva] ask what he intend to do, Alksnis say his opportunities be unfortunately limited, and that be why he be appeal to journalists. In his opinion, only joint efforts can bring this information to the attention of world public opinion, point out the seriousness of this issue, and avoid the come tragedy. Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday propose tough legislation to punish Soviets who seek to kindle ethnic unrest, say nationalist passions benefit opponents of his reforms. The soviet leader tell a meeting of the Communist Party leadership that inter-ethnic relations be worsen in some regions of the country, due in part to active resistance put up to perestroika by corrupt groups. Perestroika, or restructuring, be Gorbachev's program for widespread economic and social change. State-run media also indicate Friday that a crackdown have begin on people in Armenia who continue to agitate for annexation of a mostly armenian enclave in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. The six-month conflict between the two republics over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh district have lead to mass rallies, strikes and ethnic violence since February. The Supreme Soviet Presidium, the government's top executive body, intervene July 18. It reject any change in nagorno-karabakh's status but call for measures to develop the region's economy and culture. The conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh be one of the most rancorous domestic disputes face by Gorbachev since he become Communist Party chief in March 1985. He indicate Friday he want to defuse tensions between ethnic groups, but also to punish those who transform the tensions into a political crisis. Gorbachev speak before a plenary meeting of the Central Committee, the party's policy-making body. A summary of his remarks be distribute by the official Tass news agency. Gorbachev outline the reasons for a current aggravation of tensions between ethnic groups in some regions of the Soviet Union, Tass said. Among the causes, Gorbachev list a lack of concern for many years for the specific requirements of peoples and ethnic groups, inadequate control by the masses over the activities of executive personnel, and active resistance put up to perestroika by corrupt groups. Tass say that after Gorbachev note that nationalist passions benefit all anti-perestroika forces, he suggest increase accountability in soviet laws for kindle ethnic strife. Tass do not give details of Gorbachev's suggestion. At the July 18 Presidium meeting, the soviet leader accuse corrupt conservatives who oppose his reforms of hide behind the Nagorno-Karabakh annexation drive. Gorbachev say the grounds for tough legislation come directly from Article 36 of the 1977 Soviet Constitution, which say the law can punish any advocacy of racial or national exclusiveness, hostility or contempt. Tass say Gorbachev make other proposals on how to resolve ethnic tensions, include an increase in power for each of the country's 15 republics, a law on equal use of the more than 100 languages speak in the Soviet Union and some economic autonomy for the country's republics and regions. In particular, the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, forcibly incorporate into the Soviet Union in 1940, have demand more say in their own economic and government affairs. The labor newspaper Trud say 44 people in Yerevan, Armenia's capital, will face criminal charges follow an incident in which activists seek the annexation of Nagorno-Karabakh attach slogans to their cars and drive around the city. The paper do not give the date or size of the mobile demonstration, but say 155 drivers have have their licenses revoke and 310 be fined. In its July 18th decision, the Presidium also order local law enforcement agencies to ensure order be restore in the Caucasus Mountain region. Tass report Friday that the situation be stabilize in Armenia, but say that at the urging of instigators, some strikes and protests be continuing. The international community be start to look beyond the conflict in the former Yugoslavia, and be become increasingly aware of the true magnitude and seriousness of ethnic and political conflicts in the former soviet Union. The problem be indeed a pressing one. The disputes in the Transcaucasus, central Asia, and elsewhere in the former Soviet Union be cause great suffering for those involved. They be a source of legitimate concern to the Russians, who be worry by clashes close to their borders. They be concern too about the safety of ethnic Russians living in those countries where there be conflicts, and about the economic and social consequences of refugees flee to Russia (whose potential number be estimate at more than 2m). They believe that the problems in some of the former soviet republics be either ignore or misunderstood. The Russians fear that if they do nothing, the conflicts will worsen and probably spread. They argue that they have a legitimate concern in try to resolve conflicts that threaten their security. They ask why, when the international community be engage in peacemaking and peacekeeping in many of the world's trouble spots, similar efforts should not be undertake in the hot spots near them. Equally, these disputes be of legitimate concern to Britain, its western partners and the whole international community, both for humanitarian reasons and because such flashpoints risk provoke regional instability. If uncontrolled, they pose a variety of threats to european security, include increase traffic in drugs and arms as well as international terrorism. Crises in Russia's newly independent neighbours may also complicate Russia's relations with the west: unless they be carefully handled, they risk prejudice the emerge relationship between us. The west be sometimes suspicious of Moscow's attitude. There be no differences about the need to resolve these conflicts: but there be differences over how to go about it. The british government will not underwrite russian involvement unless it be sure that peacekeeping troops will not turn into occupy forces. Nor be countries that secure their independence when the Soviet Union be dissolve keen that the west should concede to Moscow the same role it play in the soviet empire. They fear that this would compromise their sovereignty. When they be willing for russian troops to play a peacekeeping role, they want there to be some form of international monitoring. This have mean that, even though the west lack the resources to engage directly in those trouble spots, it have be wary of appear to endorse russian involvement instead, in case it have imperial tendencies. If we be to fashion a joint approach by Russia and its western partners to the problem of peacekeeping in the former soviet Union, we must address all these concerns. clearly Russia have an important role to play in this area. If the Russians want international recognition and more active support from the international community, the west in turn needs guarantees that Russia will not regard recognition of its involvement as give it carte blanche in the former soviet Union. peace-keeping in the former soviet Union, as indeed peacekeeping elsewhere, must comply with internationally recognise principles. It need to be look at on a case by case basis. Respect for the sovereignty of the newly independent countries must remain paramount. We agree that the principles underlie Russian, CIS or international peacekeeping operations would need to include: strict respect for the sovereignty of the countries involved; an invitation from the government concern and the consent of the parties to the conflict; commitment to a parallel political peace process; a clear mandate set out the role of the peacekeeping forces (which should whenever possible be multinational in character); and an exit strategy for the peacekeeping forces deployed. These principles should help stimulate a dialogue and political settlement between the parties to the conflict, focus attention and, where possible, resources on the settlement of conflicts in the former soviet Union. All this will help enhance russian peacekeeping practices. Although the Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe and the UN lack the resources to put large numbers of peacekeepers on the ground themselves, they may be able to suggest measures to enhance transparency and to monitor the peace process. Extending co-operation within the North Atlantic Co-operation Council, and also co-operation between Russia and Nato, might help improve training for russian peacekeepers. This be an area we shall need to explore further. We also need to put much more emphasis on preventive diplomacy. One of the ways in which we can help prevent conflicts be to strengthen the democratic institutions in the newly independent countries of the former soviet Union. The CSCE and other international institutions can play an important role here, draw the newly independent countries into a more active dialogue on ways of promote democratic values and principles. We discuss ways of strengthen the CSCE's role, include the role of the High Commissioner for National Minorities, at the recent Rome ministerial meeting. We must try to find ways of managing and resolve tensions before they erupt into conflict. It will not be easy, but we must try. Potentially explosive cocktails of ethnic and political animosities could spread the fire of intolerance all too easily to other countries and regions. We need to deal with it together in the spirit of partnership. And we need to deal with it urgently. Our security be indivisible and we must ensure it by vigorous and imaginative efforts aim at promote peace for all as well as rights for all. The authors be UK foreign secretary and russian foreign minister RUSSIA fly 3,000 special forces to halt ethnic fighting in the troubled Caucasus mountains at the weekend, its second troop deployment in a week to support a beleaguered government in its former empire. Russian President Boris Yeltsin send Spetsnaz commando and elite police to Vladikavkaz, capital of the Russian autonomous republic of North Ossetia, 1,100 miles south of Moscow. The troops be send to halt fight between Ossetians and a regional ethnic group, the Ingush, who officials claim be set fire to ossetian-owned homes. Scores be report kill and injure in street fight between Ossetians and Ingush in the past several days. Ingush rebels be report yesterday to have take hostage 80 russian interior ministry soldiers base in the region. A local official say the soldiers be seize on Friday in the Dzhermen settlement, locate near the regional capital, Vladikavkaz, and populate mostly by Ingushis, Mr Felix Gutnov, spokesman for the North Ossetian interior ministry, said. The Ingush, who declare an independent state in June, be demand the return of lands that russian leader Josef Stalin expropriate in 1944 and declare part of North Ossetia. Mr Yeltsin and Russian Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar hold emergency meetings on the crisis on Saturday and yesterday. At the same time, the North ossetian government say it would distribute russian army-supplied automatic weapons to civilian volunteers. 'The russian authorities be strong enough to make all those violate the law respect it,' russian Deputy Prime Minister Georgy Khizha, Mr Yeltsin's specialist on the Caucasus, tell russian television. The russian action mirror recent developments in the former Soviet republic of Tajikistan, where russian troops have also be deployed. The Central Asian nation, which have yet to form its own army since the Soviet Union collapse last December, have also distribute weapons to civilians. On October 26-27 russian soldiers play a crucial role in crush a coup attempt in the Tajik capital of Dushanbe. The Caucasus mountains, which stretch from southern Russia to the borders of Turkey and Iran, be engulf by several conflicts. Among them be Georgia's war with abkhazian separatists, and Azerbaijan's conflict with ethnic Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh. Moldavia, act to defuse one of the Soviet Union's most explosive ethnic conflicts, agree Sunday to comply with a Kremlin order to reconsider its law making moldavian the republic's official language. The republic's parliament act in response to a decree issue on Dec. 22 by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the official news agency Tass reported. Gorbachev also give the republic 10 days to dissolve a new national guard and to come up with measures guarantee equal rights for all ethnic groups within its borders. Tass say the Moldavan parliament agree to disband the nationalguard and to revise a law that Gorbachev say restrict the rights of minorities. Ethnic tension have grip Moldavia, a largely agricultural republic border Romania, during its push for independence from the Soviet Union this year. The unrest turn violent last month, when government troops clash with activists, leave four dead. Gorbachev say the conflicts have reach critical levels, and he put part of the blame on the moldavian Supreme Soviet for enact laws that discriminate against minorities. alarm by rise moldavian nationalism, two of the republic's minority groups have begin their own separatist movements. The Gagauz, a group of about 150,000 turkish Christians, declare a new republic in southern Moldavia. In the eastern part of Moldavia, more than 300,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have join in declare a new republic along the Dneister River. All three groups claim discrimination by Moldavians. In particular, they resent a new law making Moldavian the official language and require people in dozens of jobs range from doctors to hairdressers to pass moldavian language tests by 1995. Tass do not say how the moldavian parliament would modify the law. Moldavian be identical to romanian except for the Cyrillic script Josef Stalin impose on the republic. It be speak by two-thirds of the republic's residents. soviet hard-liners want Gorbachev to impose a state of emergency and presidential rule in trouble zones throughout the ethnically and geographically diverse country. Gorbachev say the declaration of the Gagauz and Dniester republics be illegal under the Soviet and moldavian constitutions, as be elections to form legislatures and any actions by those bodies. The moldavian legislature have also vote to declare the elections null and void. After residents of the Gagauz region begin hold local elections in late October, the moldavian legislature clamp a two-month state of emergency on the region, restrict movement in and out of the area and ban public rallies. Volunteer brigades of college-age Moldavians, who then flock to the region to try to stop the separatist movement, be order dissolve by Gorbachev's decree. The volunteers be organize by nationalist groups, include the moldavian People's Front. A CEASEFIRE in Moldova be threaten yesterday when a truck driver transport militiamen be shoot dead by machinegun fire in the self-proclaimed Trans Dnestr republic, home of the Russian-speaking minority. The shooting come shortly after the ceasefire come into effect between the Moldovan authorities, dominate by ethnic Romanians, and the minority base in the republic on the east bank of the river Dnestr. At least nine people have be kill in clashes over the past week. As in the more severe conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, the underlying tensions be grow and neither side believe it be losing. In other respects, however, the conflicts be quite different and illustrate the complexity of conflict with which the former Soviet Union be now faced. The Trans Dnestr conflict stem directly from the breakup of the Soviet Union while Nagorno-Karabakh have be a source of tension between Azeris and Armenians for centuries. Moldova (formerly Moldavia) be finally take under full soviet control in 1944. The soviet leadership seek to stifle any attempts to preserve its former links with Romania - call Moldovan a separate language from Romanian, and construct a separate history for the Moldovan people. Industry be largely situate on the left bank of the Dnestr, in the sliver of the republic next to Ukraine, and largely staff by Russians and Ukrainians. Ukrainians and Russians together represent some 27 per cent of the population, with Moldovans account for 64 per cent. The little republic (4.5m people) be slow to respond to the stirrings of reform. When it did, in 1989, a language movement quickly put the hardline Communist Party on the defensive and it lose power in 1990 to the present nationalist government, head by President Mircea Snegur, the former secretary of the Moldovan Party's central committee. From the beginning of the nationalist movement, it be clear that the russian and, to a less extent, the ukrainian minorities would be hostile, react to laws establish Moldovan as the official language and to calls for renew union with Romania with strikes and demonstrations, and, finally last year, proclaim Trans Dnestr independent under a russian president, Mr Igor Smirnov. During the August coup last year, the Moldovan government stoutly reject it and the Trans Dnestr authorities welcome it, siding with the soviet army in its brief efforts to impose military rule. Thereafter, the two sides have gather military forces. The Trans Dnestr side have be augment by Cossacks from nearby areas return to their traditional role as defenders of Russia's borders. The daily Izvestia report yesterday that the Cossacks appear to have appoint themselves mercenaries for the Russians (they be pay from Rbs2,000 to rbs5,000 a week by the Trans Dnestr authorities). TROOPS OF the former Soviet Union be order to pull out from the armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh yesterday after they be fire on during clashes between Azeri and Armenian militants. Marshal Yevgeny Shaposhnikov, the Commonwealth of Independent States' defence minister, announce the decision as fight worsen in the disputed territory in spite of efforts to secure a truce. The enclave be administer by Azerbaijan but largely populate by Armenians. The order for the pull-out of the 366th motorise regiment follow the deaths earlier this week of a handful of soldiers catch in the fighting between armenian guerrillas and Azerbaijani forces. fight flare again yesterday in the capital Stepanakert, where the regiment be based. Azerbaijani and armenian officials claim their civilian targets be under particularly vicious attack. Marshal Shaposhnikov, who be also commander-in-chief, have long warn that he would withdraw troops rather than allow them to become targets of ethnic conflicts in the former Soviet Union. No dates have be give for the withdrawal. Troops under fire along the Armenian-Azerbaijani border will also be withdrawn. Commanders of the Trans-Caucasus military district, which encompass Georgia as well as Armenia and Azerbaijan, have be order to rebuff attacks on military installations. Azeri and armenian officials say sophisticated weapons, include combat helicopters, tanks and armoured personnel carriers, be be use by guerrillas on both sides in the four-year-old conflict. armenian militants attack the last Azeri stronghold in Nagorno-Karabakh yesterday, accord to Azerbaijan's interior ministry, which say residents of the town of Shusha flee as helicopter gunships swoop down from snow-covered mountains. Armenians in the enclave want unification with Armenia, but Azerbaijan will not give up any territory. Ethnic violence kill 148 people and wound 885 this month in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, the official news agency Tass say Wednesday. Tass say 748 of the injured have to be hospitalize and say a search be continue for a police officer who vanish June 7. No new outbreaks be report in the region near the border city of Osh in western Kirghizia, where clashes arise from a land dispute begin on June 2 between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both Sunni Moslems. The argument involve allocation of land in a densly populated region where housing be scarce. It be the late in a series of bloody civil conflicts to trouble President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's government. Maj. Gen. Alexander Grienko, chief of the Interior Ministry's Political Department, say that in two years of civil strife mainly ethnic clashes in the soviet Union, about 24,000 people have be arrested. He say in Moscow on Tuesday that ministry troops have to be use in 13 regions of the Soviet Union because of such outbreaks, Tass said. Grienko say 16 ministry soldiers be killed, four be report miss and more than 1,000 wounded. Tass do not quote Grienko on how civilians casualties. The general be quote as say these conflicts be often accompany by riots and pogroms, arson and massacre of innocent people, (and) complete or partial destabilization of the situation. Besides unrest this month in Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, ethnic violence also have be report in recent years in Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Tadzhikistan. The government have decide to give ethnic Germans and Crimean Tatars who be expel from their homelands by Josef Stalin their own autonomous regions but it will take years, Tass report Wednesday. The ice have be broken. A start have be made. We're work on create such autonomy, say Rafik Nishanov, chairman of a chamber of the Soviet legislature, in remarks carry by the official news agency. However, he said, the nuts and bolts of how to create the regions still have to be work out. For example, a 10-year program on resettlement. People can't just be expel from the area for others to move in. The Tatars of the Crimea and the ethnic Germans who live on the Volga River be forcibly resettle during World War II, when Josef Stalin kick peoples out of their homelands on the grounds they could not be trust to occupy strategic areas. The Tatars and Germans, among others, long have be agitate to return from Siberia and Central Asia to their traditional lands, and last month the Supreme Soviet legislature declare that all peoples exile under Stalin should be consider politically rehabilitated. But other people now occupy the lands and houses that belong to the exiles, and re-establishing their dominion in their home regions will not be so simple. The Supreme Soviet take the basic decision that the two autonmous regions should be create on Nov. 28 but keep it quiet, apparently fear explosive reactions from the populations now live in the regions. It be also a potentially dangerous precedent: The Soviet Union be a patchwork of well over 100 ethnic groups, and many of them have outstanding territorial claims. Trouble already have be report between ethnic Germans and Russians in several cities on the Volga. Residents of the Saratov and Volgograd regions have protest the prospect of see many of the nation's estimate 2 million Germans descend on them. Ethnographers estimate there be some 500,000 crimean Tatars in the soviet Union, and another 1 million in Turkey. Their protests near the Kremlin in 1987 demanding to be allow to return to their homeland be among the first tests of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promises of great democracy. Several thousand Tatars have be filter back to the Crimea each year despite the lack of wholesale permission to return. A wave of some 100,000 ethnic Germans emigrate to West Germany this year, but many would probably stay if they could be assure of their own republic, say Irina Ostroukh, a researcher at the Soviet Institute of Ethnography who studies ethnic Germans. The Nov. 28 plan approve by the Supreme Soviet recommend exclude from the german region areas where resistance to german resettlement be strongest in order to avoid ethnic conflicts. The explosive conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over the nagorno-karabakh region have lead to 200 deaths and hundreds of thousands of refugees in the last two years. Both sides claim control over the mountainous enclave. The Supreme Soviet charge the government with create a commmission to determine how to create the regions for the Germans and Crimean Tatars. RUSSIA and Georgia yesterday deploy 'blue helmet' troops to stop ethnic fighting in the disputed region of South Ossetia in the first peace-keeping operation since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Reuter reports from Moscow. Reports from the remote transcaucasian region say hundreds of heavily arm russian troops from the 104th paratroop battalion move into a 7km-wide security zone separate rebel South Ossetia from the rest of Georgia. Georgian national guards occupy similar positions on their side of the border and pull out all their men from the South ossetian capital of Tskhinvali. But Itar-Tass news agency say gunfire overnight near the city kill four civilians and injured two others, underscore the difficulties face the operation. The mission be the first peace-keeping attempt anywhere in the former soviet Union, whose disintegration last year have prompt waves of bloodletting in ethnic flashpoints from the romanian to the Afghan borders. Reports from the former Soviet republic of Moldova say several people have be kill overnight in fresh ceasefire violations between government forces and separatists. In the Transcaucasian republic of Armenia, Radio Russia say five civilians have die overnight in Azerbaijani shelling, the late victims of a four-year undeclared war which have kill 2,000 people. Russia and Georgia be cautiously optimistic that Ossetia could be the first region of the former Soviet Union where arm conflict could be resolve with the help of 'political measures and actions'. South Ossetia be part of Georgia but want to unite with neighbouring North Ossetia, which be assign to russia by Stalin. Hundreds have be kill since 1990 in fight between Georgians and Ossetians. The peace-keepers have be issue with un-style light-blue helmet bands and match chevrons on their sleeves. They will be join later by a multi-ethnic force - Russians, Ukrainians, Ossetians and other mountain peoples - under the nominal command of North Ossetian leaders. The peace-keepers' mission be to form a physical barrier between the two sides, open the way to future talks. The great threat be expect to come from hundreds of armed fighters on both sides, operating independently in a dozen or so bands outside the control of either russian or georgian authorities. Interfax news agency say Russia's Vice-President Alexander Rutskoi, at present on a visit to Moldova, propose a similar peace-keeping operation there.
column9: The collapse of the Soviet Union was accompanied by major civil unrest and ethnic conflict.
column10: The collapse of the Soviet Union was accompanied by major civil unrest and ethnic conflict in the former republics.  The Caucasus, Baltic and Central Asian republics all experienced unrest.  The reasons for the strife included nationalism, ethnic tensions and old grievances.  Gorbachev tried unsuccessfully to hold the Soviet Union together.
column11: The collapse of the Soviet Union was accompanied by major civil unrest and ethnic conflict in the former republics.  The Caucasus, Baltic and Central Asian republics all experienced unrest.  The reasons for the strife included nationalism, ethnic tensions and old grievances.  One of the most serious conflicts was in the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan.  The majority of the population is Armenian and wanted unification with Armenia.  The Baltic republics wanted to be independent and many nationalities were demanding the return of lands taken from them under Stalin. In Moldova, the ethnic Romanian majority wanted to establish Moldavian as the official language.
column12: The collapse of the Soviet Union was accompanied by major civil unrest and ethnic conflict in the former republics.  The Caucasus, Baltic and Central Asian republics all experienced unrest.  The reasons for the strife included nationalism, ethnic tensions and old grievances.  One of the most serious conflicts was in the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan.  The majority of the population there is Armenian and wanted unification with Armenia, Azerbaijan refused.  The conflict between the Azeris and the Armenians has existed for centuries.  Other conflicts were a direct result of the breakup of the Soviet Union.  In Moldova, the ethnic Romanian majority wanted to establish Moldova, which is close to Romanian as the official language.  The Russian minority dissented and demanded its own autonomous republic.  The Baltic republics wanted to be independent nations and many nationalities were demanding the return of lands taken from them under Stalin.  Gorbachev tried to hold the Soviet Union together through tougher legislation and by appeals for support for his reforms.  Following the collapse of the Soviet Union there was even an attempt at peacekeeping in Georgia, using Russian and Georgian troops.  There was even one call for an international peacekeeping mission in some of the hotspots.
column13: Ethnic Fighting Continues. Thousands Killed. Former Soviet States in Turmoil
column14: Ethnic conflicts broke out in the USSR's final years. They proliferated after its dissolution. Russian sent troops to Tajikistan where 100,00 were killed. Destabilization of the states of the states of the former Soviet Union threatened the international community.
column15: Ethnic unrest erupted in the last years of the Soviet Union. The Kremlin dispatched troops to check the violence generated by some of the USSR's more than 100 ethnic groups. The ethnic unrest proliferated after the Soviet Union's demise. Serious ethnic-driven fighting occurred in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Khirghizia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Moldavia, One hundred thousand were killed in Tajikistan. In late 1992 Russia sent troops to the Caucasus and Tajikistan.The international community feared the destabilization of the former Soviet Union. In 1944 there was a call for a restored Soviet Union To deal with ethnicity.
column16: Disputes between ethnic groups broke out in parts of the Soviet Union two years before its dissolution. Gorbachev decried the unrest, but admitted that early Soviet efforts to fashion a unified culture out of a melange of more than 100 ethnic groups using 100 languages was a cause of the current troubles. In the two years preceding June 1990 the Kremlin had dispatched troops to quell fighting in 13 regions. There had been unrest in Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, and serious fighting in Georgia, Azerbaijan and KazakhstanThe demise of the Soviet Union touched off new ethnic conflicts. Those already underway worsened. Armenia and Azerbaijan fought over an enclave of Armenians within Azerbaijan. A group in South Ossetia wanted out of Georgia. Minorities of ethnic Russians and Ukrainians fought for rights in Moldavia.In late 1992 Russia sent specially trained troops to halt fighting in the Caucasus Mountains and in Tajikistan. The dangerous conflicts in the former Soviet Union worried the international community. There was fear that the area would be destabilized.   By May 1994 the number killed in Tajikistan reached 100,00. The Communist Party leader said only a restored Soviet Union could deal with the ethnic fighting.

column3: The chinese government say that 300 soldiers, thugs, bystanders and students have be kill during the martial law occupation of Beijing. But most other estimates of casualties be far higher. State Council spokesman Yuan Mu say on Tuesday that 7,000 people, include 5,000 soldiers, have be injure and 400 other soldiers be miss and may be dead or wounded. non-official sources say Yuan's figures on civilian casualties be far too low, but most have different estimates on the number of victims. They range from 500 to 12,000 people slain. In Washington, U.S. intelligence reports indicate 3,000 people probably be killed, accord to a U.S. official who speak on condition of anonymity. He say estimates of the number of dead could go higher. nearly all of the deaths and injuries occur Saturday night and early Sunday when troops, fire randomly into large crowds, smash through barricades to reach Tiananmen square and attack demonstrators demand democratic reforms. One doctor say Sunday that a quick check of 10 hospitals place the death toll at 500. other sources, compile various reports and surveys, estimate more than 1,000 people have be killed. That number have increase with additional details and rumors of killings. Some officials of China's Red Cross say 2,600 people be kill but Beijing's Red Cross office have refuse to provide any figures. One Hong Kong newspaper report 5,000 deaths and 30,000 injured. An eastern european diplomat, whose country have good relations with China, insist that 12,000 people be slay by soldiers as they attack protesters in Tiananmen Square. That figure be certainly high. probably few than 10,000 people be in the square when the troops move in and most be able to escape unharmed. But students who have join the Tiananmen occupation say hundreds of colleagues from the Academy of Fine Arts who be huddle around their Goddess of Democracy statue in the square be shoot or crush by tanks. Beijing University students say 150 of their fellow students who be in the square be missing. There be rumors that after the square be clear troops burn many corpses in large bonfires and other bodies be remove by helicopters and garbage trucks to minimize the death count. Yuan's statement say only 23 of the 300 people fatally injure be students. The exact number of people kill may never be known. Victims be take to dozens of hospitals, clinics and homes, and there be no indication the government will reveal many details of the tragedy. And the death toll mounts. Troops man checkpoints in central Beijing continue to fire on unfriendly crowd and victims fall. here be a look at key events in the student pro-democracy movement that lead to Sunday's assault by soldiers on protesters in Tiananmen Square: April 15 Former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang dies. Beijing University students put up posters praise him and indirectly criticize opponents who force his resignation after student demonstrations in 1986-87. April 17 Thousands of students march in Beijing and Shanghai, shout Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy! April 27 more than 150,000 students, with wide support from people on the street, surge past police lines and fill Tiananmen Square, chant slogans for democracy and freedom. April 29 Officials meet with student leaders, but independent student groups be not satisfied and continue a class boycott at 41 universities. April 30 Beijing's Communist Party chief, Zhao Ziyang, meets with student representatives. May 4 About 100,000 students and supporters march on Tiananmen Square to celebrate the 70th anniversary of China's first student movement. Demonstrations be hold in Shanghai, Nanjing and other cities. About 300 journalists protest outside the official Xinhua News Agency. May 9 Journalists petition the government for press freedom. May 10 Thousands of students bicycle to major media offices in a press freedom demonstration. Another protest be hold in the provincial capital of Taiyuan. May 13 About 2,000 students begin a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square. May 14 Thousands flock to the square to back the students. The number fast rises to 3,000. May 15 The government deadline for students to leave the square passes. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's welcome ceremony plan near the square must be move to the airport. May 16 Hundreds of thousands occupy the square. Journalists and intellectuals join the protest. May 17 Zhao pleas for students to leave. Students reject his appeal and hold marches that generate 1 million supporters in Beijing. May 18 About 1 million people, include many workers, again take to the streets to show their support for the hunger strikers. Li Peng issues a stern lecture to student leaders and refuse to discuss their demands. May 19 A tearful Zhao visits weaken hunger strikers. Li also visit the students briefly. The students later decide to end the hunger strike. May 20 Martial law be declare in parts of Beijing. Zhao reportedly resign after fail to persuade Li and other hardliners to compromise. Students resume their hunger strike, then abandon it, say they will need their strength for the struggle ahead. May 21 Students claim to reject an order by Li Peng to leave the Tiananman Square or face military action. defy martial law, hundreds of thousands of people remain in the square or block intersections to prevent troops from reach it. May 22 Hundreds of thousands of people again block major roads and senior military leaders say they be resist orders to order their troops on the protesters. At least one military convoy be report to withdraw. May 23 One million people take to the streets to demonstrate for democracy. May 25 Li make his first appearance since declare martial law. state- run radio say 27 of 29 provinces support martial law, and military units announce they support martial law. May 26 Sources say Zhao and another lead liberal, Wan Li, head of the legislature, be under house arrest. May 27 Beijing student leaders propose students end their occupation of Tiananmen Square. non-beijing students resist and the sit-in continues.
