May 28 About 80,000 people, many students from outside the capital, stage a demonstration, but unlike in past rallies few workers participate. May 30 Students unveil their goddess of Democracy, a replica of the Statue of Liberty, on the square. The government call it an insult to the nation. Students rally outside police headquarters to protest the detention of three members of an independent labor union. May 31 The first of several pro-government rallies be stag by farmers and workers in Beijing suburbs. The participants, order to show up, show little enthusiasm. June 1 The Beijing municipal Government warn foreign journalists that under martial law they must receive approval for all press coverage. Coverage of the demonstrations be banned. June 2 more than 1,000 troops appear outside the railway station in a show of force. June 3-4 Tens of thousands of troops make several attempts to move on the square but be drive back by crowd of hundreds of thousands of people support the students. Riot squads beat and fire tear gas at demonstrators. A final push be make the evening of June 3, and soldiers begin fire on crowds. Troops surround and enter the square June 4 in the early morning hours and thousands of protesters flee. Hundreds be wound and many dead. Dawn break Sunday over a battle-scarred Tiananmen Square with tanks and rifle-toting troops rule the vast expanse occupy the day before by students seek a freer society from their communist rulers. A low cloud of smoke cover much of the 100-acre square as bonfires set during the night's confrontation continue to smolder. Hundreds of helmeted troops be deploy on the monument to revolutionary heroes in the square's center and thousands more at important intersections nearby. Tanks move into place on what have hours earlier be a rag-tag squatter's camp of tents for the pro-democracy students. The battle for Tiananmen be primarily fight in the streets lead to the square, where scores of people fell try to prevent column of troops and armored military vehicles from move on the students. Gunfire could be hear from several sides, and tracers zip through the sky above Mao Tse-tung's mausoleum, one of the main monuments to chinese communism in the square. Torched buses and army vehicles on the streets around Tiananmen billow acrid smoke. Troops first enter the square from the south, when a column trot toward the student encampment about 1 a.m. (noon EDT Saturday). They take up positions to the east after a brief skirmish involve clubs and sticks with students. more soldiers be deploy in front of the Great Hall of the People to the west, and a huge convoy with armored vehicles roll down Changan Avenue to the north side. The few thousand students remain in the square stay calm as they quietly gather on the steps of the heroes' monument. I'm not afraid, several say as the heavily arm troops encircled. Hundreds of supporters continue to mill around the square, many dress more for a summer out than a military battle. Loudspeakers blaring government and student announcements engage in a noisy propaganda battle throughout the night. The government be corrupt, you've be tricked, the students roared. The state-run speaker warn that troops would use every mean at their disposal to clear the square and that remain students would bear responsibility for the consequences. At 4 a.m., the lamposts that dot the square go ominously dark, and the student loudspeaker play the Internationale, the socialist anthem. A Taiwan singer stag a hunger strike for democracy take the microphone and proclaimed: We've achieve a big victory. ... We're not afraid to die, but we've already lose too much blood. After the lights go back on a half hour later, a voice vote by the students show most want to leave the square to avoid further bloodshed. They quickly file out under the banners of their schools, carry the quilts and pad jackets that offer warmth during the 22-day sit-in. Neither the students nor the Beijing residents who arrive to show support could control their tears. go with us, they tell their supporters, who applaud the students as they retreated. As they sobbed, many students defiantly shouted: We shall return! and flash V-for-victory signs. Gone from Tiananmen Square be the pro-democracy banners and the tents of China's freedom movement, replace by tanks, arm guards and the chants of drilling soldiers. The army on Thursday allow the people of Beijing their first glance of the 100-acre expanse since the military swept into the capital six days ago, leave hundreds dead and crush a movement for political change. Troops move back their barricades, make it possible for city residents to walk to the edge of the square, which for seven weeks stand at the heart of the movement. Buses and bicyclists today be allow to pass by Changan Avenue, which border the north edge of the square. The spot once occupy by the Goddess of Democracy, a 33-foot-high replica of the Statue of Liberty, be take by a tread-wheeled armored personnel carrier. When students build the statue last week, for a few days it become a symbol of the movement for democratic reforms and an end to official corruption. On Sunday morning, a tank crush it. In all, 80 tanks and 40 armored personnel carriers line the northern part of the square. The Monument to Revolutionary Martyrs, where the students take a final stand early Sunday, be sweep clean. Poems and posters call for a more open China have disappear from its sides. Chinese Red Cross officials estimate 3,600 people be kill and 60,000 injure over the weekend, cite a chinese students' organization, the Union of chinese Students in West Germany. The government say nearly 300 people, mostly soldiers, be killed; diplomats and Chinese say up to 3,000 died. Soldiers drill in Tiananmen's center, their cadenced shout echo around the vast expanse. A crowd of officials stand on the roof of the Great Hall of the People, overlook the square. From this same roof five days earlier officials watch as a jubilant mass of demonstrators envelop 5,000 troops and block their entry to the square. Inside the square, soldiers could be see shuffle about, their uniformed jackets strip off, wash basins in hand. There be a relaxed air of the inside of an army barracks as unarmed troops carry food and walk slowly together, talk and laugh in groups. The area once housing students' tents have become a hold area for a huge fleet of troop trucks. On the southern perimeter, a single line of tanks and a cordon of soldiers block the square from the thousands of bicylists who pedal slowly by, peer into Tiananmen. Near the square, troops place barbed wire in front of one street. Soldiers be billet in a construction site, their laundered fatigues dry on the scaffolding. Next door, troops, their assault rifles sling nonchalantly over their shoulders, stood and chat outside a discotheque. They look like they , say one local resident. I hope they know that we still don't want them here. here be a chronology of events that begin Saturday in Tiananmen Square: 1 a.m. Saturday (12 noon EDT Friday) Tens of thousands of troops enter beijing from the east marching toward Tiananmen Square, China's symbolic political heart. Military units also see approach from the west and the north. 2 a.m. The main body of troops be stopped several hundred yards east of the vast square by thousands of people. 2 a.m. to 9 a.m. Troops straggle away from their positions near the square, walk in small groups follow by watchful residents. 12 noon Two truckloads of People's Armed Police attack crowd outside Beijing Hotel east of the square and up to 30 people injured. 2 p.m. About 5,000 troops emerge from Great Hall of the People on the western side of the square and be surround by crowds. People's Armed Police fire tear gas and use clubs to beat protesters west of the square in a 30-minute attack. 4:30 p.m. Stone- and bottle-throwing demonstrators skirmish with troops outside the Great Hall. Troops swing belts attack crowds. Some soldiers injure by fly debris. 6 p.m. Thousands of residents surround two troop convoys on a main highway in northeastern Beijing. 7 p.m. National television repeat martial law regulations and warn people to stay off the streets and away from Tiananmen Square. 8:30 p.m. Troops retreat into the Great Hall. 9 p.m. more than 20,000 people block a 26-truck convoy about 2{ miles east of the square and thousands of others converge on the square to protect students demand demoncratic reforms. Crowds throw rocks at troop contingent 4{ miles west of Tiananmen. 9 p.m.-10 p.m. Troops hurl tear gas then open fire on the crowds. 12 midnight Armored vehicles break through barricades and about 40 trucks carry military personnel slowly advance toward the square from the west. 1 a.m. Sunday. Troops dash through flames cause by a burning-bus barricade at the major intersection of Xidan west of the square. more people shoot as troops fire at crowds. A small group of about 1,000 military personnel enter the square from the east and shoot erupts. 2 a.m. Thousands of troops arrive at the west side of the square and some of the riflemen open fire. 3:30 a.m. military units surround the square, trap several thousand students inside. 4:30 a.m. Armored personnel carriers enter the square. Students be tell by loudspeaker that troops will move in and clear the area. 5 a.m. Demonstrators, many walk hand-in-hand, begin leave the square, end their three-week occupation. chinese troops storm Tiananmen Square early Sunday, shooting and beat their way through crowd of pro-democracy protesters in clashes that witnesses and doctors say kill at least 32 people. Hundreds be wounded. The troops cut a violent swath through the heart of Beijing to get to the the square, roll through barricades and surge masses on the surround streets. By 3:30 a.m., soldiers and riot police have surround Tiananmen, box off several thousand students and supporters concentrate around a monument to revolutionary heroes in the center. A half hour later, lights be turn out. The square be in darkness. You have to give up all hope, students say over their loudspeaker at the monument. You have to give your life to the movement. Students sing the Internationale, the communist anthem. At 4:30 a.m., armor personnel carriers enter the square and troops begin move slowly toward several thousand students cluster around a monument to revolutionary heroes in the center. Sporadic gunfire could still be hear on the outskirts of the square as troops shoot at crowd of thousands. The death and casualty toll be believe to be mount rapidly. Ambulances and bicycle pedicabs go back and forth haul away the wounded. One man be see shot in the back, another in the head. An official loudspeaker on the square announce that the troops be move in to clear the area as soldiers prepare to advance from all four sides. Ho Te-chien, a taiwanese singer who defect to China in 1983 and have be active in the student movement, urge the students to leave. We're not afraid to die, but we've already lose too much blood, he say over a student loudspeaker. A 33-foot-high replica of the Statue of Liberty, set up by students last week, remain standing. The main streets lead to the Tiananmen, China's symbolic political center, be sealed. Thousands flee from the square, where hundreds of thousands of people have gather to support students in the third week of a sit-in. The assault come two weeks after Premier Li Peng declare martial law in Beijing and send troops to the city. Hundreds of thousands of residents respond by block roads with trucks and their bodies. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III say Saturday the situation in China have become ugly and chaotic. This will disturb the United States government, and will disturb the american people, considerably, he said. The secretary hint that there could be repercussions to the Chinese government's use of violence. The standoff between troops and protesters have be tense but largely peaceful for weeks, with soldiers seemingly reluctant or unable to move against the crowd until the first widespread violence break out Saturday afternoon. A doctor from the Fuxing Hospital in western Beijing, where troops begin fire on street people, say the hospital have take in 15 dead and so many wound they have to be put in garages. A doctor from another hospital say 12 people die there. One soldier be kill when he be run over by an armored personnel carrier rush toward the square, and another man be report shot to death in a street clash elsewhere. A swedish visitor, Tom Hansson, say he saw three people shoot to death in clashes south of the square. The government be fascist! How can they do this to me? How can they do this to the people? cry a 28-year-old man who be shoot in the leg. Most of those shoot on the square be hurl rocks at the troops and people close to their front lines. A government loudspeaker on the square charge the students with counterrevolutionary turmoil and say the military be take necessary means to end their rebellion. Sporadic clashes and dozens of injuries be report on Saturday as soldiers make several attempts to reach the square. They retreat momentarily under barrages of rocks, shoes and other objects, then resume their most violent push at about 8 p.m. Saturday, firing weapons and use tear gas and clubs as they move toward Tiananmen. Thousands of troops arm with rifles march up the east side of the square, beating people who get in their way. Students throw Molotov cocktails and other objects at them. One armored personnel carrier ram into a burn bus on Changan Avenue, the main street run along the square, and be torch by students. Two people inside be drag out by the crowd and beat severely. other armored personnel carriers drive up and down the avenue smash down lane dividers and other barriers set up by citizens to block the army's way. more than 5,000 people chant Freedom will survive! pack a Chinatown park this morning in a memorial service for students slay by soldiers in Tiananmen Square. They then march through the streets in a funeral procession. The gods be cry for what's happen in China today. It's a great tragedy, say Harry Zinn of International Ladies Garment Workers Union Local 2325, address the crowd through a steady rain. Our hearts go out to the people of China. The crowd, which stand respectfully and silently during a traditional funeral ceremony, wave banners and wore buttons honor the martyr of Tiananmen Square and call for democracy in China. After the service and several speeches, the crowd march through the streets of Chinatown, lead by a casket and a traditional chinese funeral bier contain fruit and incense. As they head up Mulberry Street, a major street in Chinatown, they walk beneath a 30-foot black banner strung across the road. This have unite the chinese people for one cause to overthrow the government and establish democracy, say Peter Lee, one of the student organizers of the service. We must never allow them to crush another body. The funeral procession stretch for blocks through Chinatown, tie up traffic. Demonstrators plan another rally later in the day outside the United Nations. here be a look at key events in the student pro-democracy movement, the government crackdown and the fighting between rival army factions: here be a look at key events in the student pro-democracy movement and at events since Sunday's assault by soldiers on protesters in Tiananmen Square:
column5: Tiananmen Square Killings Not Fatal to Pro-democracy movement.
column6: The deadly use of military force against its citizens by the government of China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square June 3-4, 1989 left thousands dead, resulted in great damage to China's repute abroad, exacerbated internal disputes, and was not a fatal blow to the pro-democracy movement in China.
column7: The military assault on pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square onJune 3-4, 1989 cost at least 2,600 lives and perhaps as many as12,000. 2,000 students had encamped in the square and begun a hungerstrike in May and a million citizens rallied to their support. Whenthe declaration of martial law did not intimidate the students andtheir supporters, the government resorted to the use of massiveforce. The pro- democracy movement started after the death of formerCommunist Party chief Hu Yaobang on April 15, 1989 with studentsshouting "Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy!"
column8: On June 3, 1989 at 1 a.m. tens of thousands of troops entered Beijing marching toward Tiananmen Square to dislodge student pro-democracy demonstrators who had  encamped there for three weeks. Within 28 hours the students were dispersed at a cost in lives estimated by the Chinese government at 300-400, by officials of the Chinese Red Cross as 2,600, and by others as between 3,000 and 12,000. The crisis was not at an end, however, as soldiers continued random shooting of civilians and rival factions of the Chinese army started shooting at one another. During June 5-9 governments around the world condemned the brutal suppression advising theirnationals to leave Beijing. Chinese abroad mourned the dead. Anti-government demonstrations spread to Shanghai, Nanjing, and other cities. The pro-democracy movement had its origin with the death of former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang on April 15, 1989. By April 17 thousands of students marched in Beijing and Shanghai shouting "Long live Hu Yaobang! Long live democracy!" The protest movement focused on Tiananmen Square when 2,000 students began a hunger strike there  and a million citizens rallied to their support. When declaration of martial law did not intimidate the protesters the government resorted to the massive use of troops and firepower.
column9: Chinese Troops Crush Student Reformers. Thousand Killed In Tiananmen Square.
column10: Chinese troops fought through crowds of protesters on 3 June 1989, killing thousands as they crushed the reform-minded student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Surviving students fled the square, ending their defiant three-week occupation of the square. Later demonstrations in other Chinese cities protested the Beijing slaughter.
column11: Firing indiscriminately on the crowds as they advanced, Chinese troops broke through barricades of reform-minded protesters late on 3 June1989 and reached Tiananmen Square after being rebuffed in earlier attempts. Early the next day they routed the surviving demonstrators who fled the square that had occupied for three weeks in defiance of government orders. Thousands died in the two days of violence. The bloody weekend was the climax of trouble that had escalated since April.Later demonstrations in other large Chinese cities protested the Beijing slaughter. The United States suspended all military sales to China.
column12: Late on Saturday evening, 3 June 1989, Chinese troops broke through barricades on streets leading to Tiananmen Square. The soldiers fired indiscriminately on the crowds as they scattered resisters. The troops had previously been unsuccessful in reaching the square. By noon on 4 June the troops had crushed the demonstrators for political reform and forced them to flee the square they had occupied for three weeks in defiance of  government orders issued under martial law. The army soon removed evidence of the protest , including the student-built replica of the Statue of Liberty.The bloody weekend was the climax of trouble that had been escalating since April. It had grown tense, but largely peaceful during the three weeks prior to 3 June.The government insisted that only 300 were killed. The Chinese Red Cross said 3,600 died and 60,000 were injured. Most of those killed on 3 and 4 June fell in streets leading to Tiananmen.Demonstrations in Shanghai, Nanjing, and other large Chinese cities on 5 June protested the slaughter in Beijing. The United States suspended all military sales to China. Many foreign embassies urged their citizens to leave Beijing.

column3: Beijing, June 20 (XINHUA) -- Floods continue to have serious effects in Guangdong, Hunan and Jiangxi Provinces and the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in southern China. information from the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters reveal that the flood peak on the Xijiang River today reach Guangdong Province. By eight o'clock yesterday morning, a peak flood water level of 25.91 m [meters] be record at the flood monitoring station of Guangxi's Wuzhou city, 10.91 m above the danger level. Flood water have enter urban and suburban areas of Wuzhou city, and most of its transport and telecommunications with the outside be suspended. This city borders Guangdong and lie on the Xunjiang River, the name for the upper reaches of the Xijiang River. The speed of the flood-water be record as 46,200 cu [cubic] m per second, the most ferocious since the founding of New China in 1949. The flood peak on the Beijiang River in Guangdong Province pass through Qingyuan city by 23:00 hours last night, and the water level be record as 14.72 m, about 4.22 m above the danger mark; the speed be 17,400 cu m per second. Flood control work in the Pearl River (Zhujiang) Delta area be also very intense. The State Council, China's high govern body, recently send a joint work group form by the Ministries of Water Resources, Construction and Civil Affairs to help fight floods in Guangxi and in Guangdong. At 11 o'clock on Saturday, the flood peak on the Xiangjiang River pass through Changsha city, capital of central China's Hunan Province. The water level record at the local monitoring station be 38.93 m, some 3.93 m above danger level. High flood water levels be also record at Hengyang and Xiangtan cities. About 118 towns of eight prefectures and cities along the Xiangjiang River be flooded. Flood water have also enter more than 20 streets and lanes of Changsha, and more than 300,000 city dwellers be affected. more than 400 factories and 5,000 shops be force to stop production or stop business. more than half a million Armymen and local residents, under the leadership of the Hunan provincial party provincial committee and provincial people's government, be go all out to fight the flood. By 22:00 hours last night, the flood peak pass through Nanchang city, provincial capital of Jiangxi. Statistics from the local monitoring station show that the flood water level be 25.42 m, about 2.62 m above the danger mark, and the speed of the flood be 19,100 cu m per second. The Jiangxi provincial party committee and people's government be mobilize local people and the troops station there to combat the floods. The State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters have send special teams of people to help fight floods in Hunan and Jiangxi. Meanwhile, drought be continue to blight most areas of northern China and northeastern China, with about 15.3 million hectares of land affected. In the drought-stricken areas, 12 million people and 12 million head of livestock be short of drinking water, accord to the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters. Comrade Wen Jiabao [member of CPC Central Committee Secretariat] and his party leave Changsha for Zhuzhou and Xiangtan yesterday. He inspect the flooded areas, include Zhuzhou City's Xiawan dike, the Hexi New and High Technology Development Zone, and Linghuayuan and Xiangtan's Yangtianhu, Xingxiadi, Zhoujiangdi, and Shiwandalou, where rescue and relief work be in full swing. After listen to reports submit by the two cities on their efforts to fight the flooding and do relief work, he issue important instructions. Comrade Wen Jiabao fully affirm the initial victories that the two cities have score in their flood fighting and relief work under the leadership of the provincial party committee and government. He said: In fight floods and do relief work, the broad masses of cadres and people in Zhuzhou and Xiangtan sacrifice their interests to rescue a large number of industrial and mining enterprises, the Beijing-Guangzhou Railway, the 107 National Highway, and cities and thus minimize the losses cause by floods. This fully show that, with party leadership and the socialist system, we will be able to overcome all difficulties. regard the work in the next stage, he point out: We should continue to take flood fighting and relief tasks as the focus of our current work and simultaneously do a good job of reform, open up to the outside world, stability, other fields of work, and industrial and agricultural production. He said: After the water recedes, we should firmly grasp the opportunity and repair the damage dikes and embankments. As the high flood season have not yet arrived, we should be prepare at any time to meet new flood peaks head-on rather than slacken our efforts. We should try every possible means to provide food, clothing, and shelter to flood victims, pay special attention to prevent and cure diseases, and concentrate efforts on the resumption of production and the reconstruction of homes. He particularly stressed: The current flooding have reveal problems in the construction of water conservancy facilities and urban flood control. In the past, inadequate consideration have be give to urban flood control and the coordination of urban and rural flood control. In the next step, we should earnestly draw a lesson from this negative experience. Governor Chen Bangzhu urge the party committees and governments of Zhuzhou and Xiangtan to convey Comrade Wen Jiabao's regards and instructions on behalf of the party Central Committee and the State Council for the broad masses of cadres and people to the party committees and governments at all levels as soon as possible, earnestly implement them, and effectively carry out the work of fight floods, do relief work, and help oneself by engage in production. Fuzhou, June 22 (CNS) -- Flood lasting for ten or more days in fujian Province have bring about heavy losses in agriculture there. accord to the late information offer by the Provincial Agricultural Bureau, a total area of 2.465 million mu of crops have be hit by the flood and of which, 446 000 mu of crops will have no yield, 1.957 million mu of grain have be heavily hit and some 300 million kilogram grain be expect to be lost. Among nine cities and prefectures in Fujian, those seriously hit by the flood be Sanming, Nanping, Ningde, Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Putian. Of these, Sanming City be bad hit by the flood. In May, the city be hit by the heavy rainstorm and have big losses and now it suffer again from the flood with some 600 000 mu of crops damage by flood and 200 million kilogram grain expect to be lost. Per caput possession of cultivated land in Fujian be only 0.05 mu. even if in the normal years, grain output there be not self- sufficient. The consecutive flood have make agricultural production situation there more grim. disaster-relief groups have be send to the flood-stricken areas strive for minimize losses. Changsha, June 19 (xinhua) -- This capital of central China's Hunan province have be hit by floods in the wake of a succession of rainstorms on the upper and middle reaches of the Xiangjiang River. The water level of the river, which flow through Changsha, be still rise sharply, accord to local sources. By four o'clock this afternoon the level record at the Changsha monitoring station have rise to 38.93 m, some 0.56 m high than the high figure ever previously recorded. The flood have cause serious losses to people along both banks of the river, especially in Changsha, accord to the sources. In the early hours of yesterday six villages and one fishing ground at Yulushan township be flood when an embankment collapsed. Most of the 15,000 people affect by the flood there have be evacuate to safer places. By six o'clock yesterday afternoon 19 dykes in the Changsha area have collapsed, and a total of 128,000 urban and rural residents have be affected. A partial collapse of the grand Longwangang embankment at the Xihu fishing ground in the Wangyuehu district of Changsha have put the lives and property of 60,000 people in danger. But thanks to the concert rescue efforts of 2,000 local cadres, residents and soldiers there be no loss of life. The city government of Changsha have ask residents within the endanger areas to relocate themselves and remove their property to safer places, in case of the occurrence of more serious flooding. By the early hours of this morning roads and surfaces of bridges in the Wangyuehu district have be inundated. The flood waters have also reach the boulevard along the Xiangjiang River, Xiahe Street and the western part of Zhongshan Street in Changsha proper. So far, more than 500,000 soldiers and local residents have move in to help fight the floods. Meanwhile, the Changsha city committee of the Communist Party have hold an emergency meeting, urge all departments and the people of the whole city to carry forward the spirit of continuous fighting and unite as one in battle the floods. Wang Maolin, secretary of the Hunan Provincial Party Committee, who be now in the province's southern city of Zhuzhou to direct anti-flood efforts there. In a telephone call to the Changsha city government, he call on local officials to adopt effective measures, ensure the safety of the lives and property of the residents of Changsha and make an overall success of the work to conquer the flood. Guangzhou, 19 Jun (XINHUA) -- Jiang Zemin, general secretary of the CPC Central Committee Political Bureau and chairman of the Central Military Commission, and Li Peng, premier of the State Council, be very much concern about floods in Guangdong Province. Recently, they repeatedly inquire about the flood situation in the Zhu Jiang valley, particularly that of Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang. They express their deep concern for the people in the flood-hit areas, as well as extend their warm greetings to the vast number of cadres, officers, and men of the People's Liberation Army; arm police officers; and public security police who battle on the frontline against floods and provide disaster relief. Jiang Zemin and Li Peng give important directives for current flood prevention and disaster relief tasks in Guangdong. They express the hope that under the leadership of the Guangdong provincial party committee and government, the Guangdong army and people would make concerted efforts in disaster relief; earnestly help flood victims solve their living problems; and go all out to battle floods to ensure the safety of the Bei Jiang dike, Guangzhou city, and the Zhu Jiang Delta. Guangzhou, June 23 (XINHUA) -- The high flood peaks on the Xijiang and Beijiang Rivers have passed, say Zhu Senlin, governor of south China's Guangdong Province. While inspect flood control and relief work in Qingyuan city on the Beijiang River yesterday, he attribute Guangdong's success in combat this flood -- almost the big in 100 years -- to concert efforts by the armymen station in Guangdong and local residents. more than 200 people lose their lives in the natural disaster, which destroy 189,000 rooms and ruin crops on 1.2 million hectares. The flood be cause by successive torrential rainstorms in the Xijiang and Beijiang River valleys in early and middle June. Major flood monitoring stations on the two rivers record their high water levels, all four meters above the danger mark. local governments at various levels in the province have pay close attention to flood control work, and leading government and communist party officials of different localities have go to the flood-fighting front. No breaches of major embankments or reservoirs be report despite the most serious flood in a hundred years, effectively protect the safety of the provincial capital, Guangzhou, and the Pearl (Zhujiang) River Delta. But the losses cause by the flood be quite serious, say the governor. accord to him, 11 million people in the province's nine cities and 55 counties be affected, and more than 200 people die in the natural disaster, with 189,000 rooms destroy and 1.2 million hectares of crops ruined. The direct economic losses be set at 10.2 billion yuan. The governor warn that though the flood danger have receded, the determination to fight possible further floods could not slacken, as this be just the beginning: the main flood season, which usually begin in late July and early August, have not yet arrived. He urge local officials to be on constant alert against further possible floods and be meticulous about flood prevention and control measures, while do their utmost to help flood victims, assist them to resume production as soon as possible and maintain social stability. Beijing, June 26 (XINHUA) -- Floods have all recede along Xijiang, Beijiang, Xiangjiang and Ganjiang except at a section of the Xijiang River in Wuzhou city, Guangxi, a spokesman from the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters announce today. The spokesman attribute the fall water level to the major water conservancy projects which help to mitigate losses. Meanwhile, he said, tension have be ease in the Pearl River delta as the late tropical storm have be weaken after land in Yangjiang city, Guangdong Province. Floods hit Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang provinces follow the first heavy rains and floods which typically hit China from the south to the north from June to August. Earlier reports say that successive torrential rainstorms in the Xijiang and Beijiang river valleys in early and mid-june result in a big flood, one of the most serious in 100 years, in Guangdong Province and cause heavy losses. Major flood monitoring stations on the two rivers record their high water levels, all four meters above the warning level. In an urgent conference late yesterday, the Guangdong provincial government urge localities to help flood victims with food, shelter, clothing and medical care so that no one would die of hunger and no epidemic disease would break out in the flooded areas. The province have allocate 300 million kg of grain and 110 million yuan in cash along with over 10 million tons of such farm production supplies as chemical fertilizer and diesel oil to the flood-stricken areas. Meanwhile, 740 million yuan in loans and another 50 million yuan in donations have also be send to flood areas in Guangdong Province. While inspect flood control and relief work in Jiangxi Province, through which the Ganjiang flows, Wen Jiabao, alternate member of the Political Bureau and member of the Secretariat of the CPC Central Committee, say the flooded areas should work hard to mitigate losses through their own efforts and with support from various departments. While inspect Nanchang, the capital city of Jiangxi, and Fengcheng, Xingang, Jian and Taihe, on June 24-26, Wen say the key to mitigate economic losses be to resume production as soon as possible. The localities should waste no time in implement various measures to resume production and rehabilitate their homeland, he said. As one of China's major bread baskets, Jiangxi be of key importance to China in agricultural production, Wen said. It have a direct bearing on the grain supply in south China. He urge the local governments to farmers resume agricultural production. The following be a recorded report file by this station's reporter on the front lines of the province's battle against the flooding yesterday. [begin recording] Dear audience, it be now almost noon on 20 June. I'm reporting in Changshanyuan at the eastern gate of Changsha City. This morning, Provincial Party Committee Secretary Wang Maolin, provincial Governor Chen Bangzhu, and some other provincial party and government leaders arrive here in Changshayuan, on the front line of the province's flood resistance effort, to direct the fight against the flooding. Governor Chen Bangzhu and vice Governor Zheng Peimin just arrive back in Changsha at about 0700 this morning after attend a Beijing meeting. as soon as they step out from the train, they set out for Changshayuan, the front line of the province's flood resistance. I interview Governor Chen Bangzhu here on the spot. [Reporter] How be you, Governor Chen? You have inspect some flood-stricken areas in Changsha City this morning. Will you please tell our audience something about the province's flood situation? [governor] This year, Hunan have be hit by a flood of a severity unseen for the past 100 years in terms of both water level and quantity. Over the past few days, the broad masses of Army personnel and people across the province have be bravely fight the flood and have be make concerted efforts to provide disaster relief to afflict areas, with the result that some of the province's key dams have remain sound and economic losses have be reduce to a minimum. I would like to take this opportunity to extend my warm regards and thanks to the broad masses of Army personnel and people fight in the front lines of the province's battle against the flood. At the moment, the province's flood situation remain very serious, because the water level be still high. accord to weather forecasts and meteorological reports, the province be expect more rain to fall over the next few days. We will definitely encounter more hardships and difficulties. Under the current circumstances, the broad masses of Army personnel and people across the province should far step up their work and devote more energy to flood prevention and disaster relief work, this be an override task at the moment. We be full of confidence that, under the leadership of the CPC Central Committee and the State Council, the broad masses of the Hunan Army personnel and people will be able to overcome the difficulties and hardships cause by natural calamities such as flooding, waterlogging, and so on and will win a complete victory in the on-going flood prevention and disaster relief struggle. [end recording] Beijing, 21 Jun (xinhua) -- accord to the State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters, after the large or the second large flood peaks since the liberation of China occur a few days ago in the Xi Jiang, Bei Jiang, Xiang Jiang, and Gan Jiang rivers, water levels in these rivers be drop slowly; however, high water levels will remain in these rivers for the next few days. Due to interaction of the Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang, the Zhujiang Delta will face a high water-level test. Heavy rainfall over a wide area since mid-june result in the large flood waters since liberation of the country in the Xi Jiang, Bei Jiang, and Xiang Jiang rivers. The flood water in Guangdong's Xi Jiang crest in Gaoyao County on 20 June; the water level in Gaoyao's Xi Jiang drop to 13.37 meters at 0600 today. A flood peak occur in Bei Jiang in Guangdong's Sanshui at 0400 on 20 June, raise the water level to 10.39 meters -- the large flood level ever recorded. The water level droppped to 10.16 meters at 0600 today. Drops in water levels in Guangdong's Bei Jiang and Xi Jiang do not mean that Guangdong's flood situations have eased, because flood waters in the Xi Jiang and Bei Jiang will remain at high levels for quite long a period and will enter the sea after the two flood waters jointly flow through the low-lying Zhujiang Delta. In particular, the sea tide may add to the flood waters on 25 June. With these factors combined, the Zhujiang Delta, which have a developed economy and a forest of factories, will face the most rigorous flood water test since the liberation of the country. The situation in the Xiang Jiang be also not an easy one. The flood peak pass Changsha on 19 June, but the water level at the Changsha Station be still at 25 meters at 0200 today [1800 GMT 20 June]. Because the water level have remain high for a long period, several dangerous situations have occur along the river's dikes. Dike reinforce work needs to be step up. The flood peak in Gan Jiang enter Boyang Lake on 20 June. However, due to continued rains over the last few days, the water level in the upper reach west of Ganzhou have begin to rise again. At 0800 today, the water level at the Ganzhou Station be 100.95 meters, 3.45 meters above the warning level.
column5: Record setting floods ravage much of south China.
column6: Torrential rains have caused the worst flooding in 100 years in many areas of southern China.  Six provinces and many cities are seriously affected.  Government officials provided help with the flood fighting and relief efforts, but noteworthy was the direction provided by Wen Jiabao, member CPC Central Committee Secretariat.
column7: Floods being called the worst in 100 years have hit major parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian and Zhejiang Provinces.  They were caused by torrential rains in the Xiangjiang, Xunjiang, Xijiang and Beijiang river valleys.  Cities most seriously affected where Changsha, Zhuzhou and Xiangtan in Hunan Province, Wuzhou in Guangxi Province and Sanming in Fujian Province. Central Party official Wen Jiabao visited Changsha, Zhuzhou, Xiangtan and Jiangxi cities to offer appreciation, encouragement and guidance for the ongoing flood fighting and relief work, and to direct the resumption of industrial and agricultural production.  He emphasized measures to salvage the rice crop.
column8: Floods being called the worst in 100 years have hit major parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Fujian and Zhejiang Provinces.  They were caused by torrential rains in the Xiangjiang, Xunjiang, Xijiang and Beijiang river valleys.  Cities most seriously affected where Changsha, Zhuzhou and Xiangtan in Hunan Province, Wuzhou in Guangxi Province and Sanming in Fujian Province. At the Changsha city monitoring station, the water level rose to 38.93 meters, some 0.56 meters above the previous record.  500,000 soldiers and civilians fought to contain the floodwaters there.  In Wuzhou city, the Xunjiang River's floodwater speed was recorded at 46,200 cubic-meters-per-second, the most ferocious since the nation's founding in 1949.  In Guangzhou Province 200 people died, 189,000 rooms were destroyed, and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.  Economic losses were set at 10.2 billion yuan.  Many local, provincial and Central Party members provided support and expressed their concern, including Chairman Jiang Zemin and Premier Li Peng.  Noteworthy were the efforts of Central Party official Wen Jiabao.  He visited Changsha, Zhuzhou, Xiangtan and Jiangxi cities to offer appreciation, encouragement and guidance for the ongoing flood fighting and relief work, and to direct the resumption of industrial and agricultural production.
column9: China Floods Receding; 200 Dead in Guangdong; Substantial Crop Losses
column10: Flooding in south and central China provinces due to June storms has subsided, but 200 people died and substantial agricultural losses were recorded. Party officials praised those who battled the floods and assisted victims. Officials urged everyone to work to minimize losses, especially in Jiangxi, one of China's major bread baskets.
column11: Flooding in Guangdong, Hunan, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang provinces that followed after heavy June storms has subsided, but in Guangdong 200 people died and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.  Fujiang also suffered substantial agricultural losses. Wen Jiabo (CPC Central Committee Secretariat member) and other officials toured the flooded areas. They praised the soldiers and civilians who battled the floods, saved key infrastructure and industrial resources and assisted victims. The people were urged to concentrate on recovery efforts and actions to minimize economic losses. Resumption of agricultural production in Jiangxi, one of China's major bread baskets, was of particular concern.
column12: A State Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters spokesman said flooding in central and south China have subsided.Heavy June storms caused flooding in Guangdong, Hunan, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Fujiang and Zhejiang provinces. In Guangdong, the Beijiang and Xijiang rivers peaked at 14.72 meters and 25.91 meters, respectively. The Beijiang level was a record; the Xijiang peak was 25.91 meters above the danger level. Over 200 people died and 1.2 million hectares of crops were ruined.In Hunan, the Xiangijiang River flooded Changsha, affecting over 300,000 residents and closing over 400 factories and 5,000 shops.Jiangxi, a major agricultural province, was flooded by the Ganjiang River, while in Fujian, the floods exacerbated the typically low grain production. Approximately 446,000 mu of crops in Fujiang were lost and 1.957 million mu of grain have been heavily hit.  The Xunjiang River flooded Guangxi's Wuzhou city and its suburbs and knocked out telecommunications. Many officials, including Comrade Wen Jiabo (CPC Central Committee Secretariat member), toured the flooded areas. They praised the soldiers, police officers and civilians who battled the floods, saved key infrastructure and industrial resources, and assisted the victims. The people were urged to concentrate on recovery efforts and actions to minimize economic losses.

column3: public interest in the Earth's trouble climate may be wash away with the heavy rains that be need to end the current U.S. drought, weather experts warn during a drought symposium here. Society tend to flit from hysteria to hysteria, say Pat Michaels, Virginia's state climatologist and moderator of the symposium. He say the 1988 drought, although not as dry as a 1986 drought in many places, have draw much attention because some of the affected areas include large media centers. I'm worry ... that when the next drought happens, we be go to have to rediscover the climate problem, say Michaels, president of the Association of State Climatologists. Experts say Thursday that the greenhouse effect the warming of the Earth's atmosphere have bring need attention to changes in the global climate, even though it be not directly relate to the drought. Many of the 13 climatologists and meterologists at the symposium agree that the Earth's temperature be warming, but they debate whether it be a short- or long-term phenomenon and its impact on Earth. However, Alan Hecht, director of the National Climate Program in Washington, D.C., say the uncertainty mean policymakers should begin to deal with the possible effects, especially undertaking policies that make sense in their own right. Mankind must reduce reliance on fossil fuels, he said, by become more energy efficient, replant forests and investigate alternative energy supplies. Scientists have warn in recent years that Earth's atmosphere be gain in carbon dioxide and other gases, which trap heat and cause the overall temperature to rise. Besides fossil fuels, the depletion of forests in South America have be blame for the increase of carbon dioxide and methane. Some have warn that high temperature will change the character of many countries, for example dry out the U.S. Midwest or melt polar ice caps. The symposium be sponsor by The Weather Channel, an atlanta-based cable network, which broadcast the meeting live. Earlier Thursday, the climatologists be tell the movement of planets and the moon and sunspots may help lead to drought in the Southeast. There be some evidence that as Jupiter go around the sun at its fast point, there be drought conditions in the Southeast in the months of April and October, Georgia state climatologist Gayther Plummer said. However, David Rodenhuis, director of the federal Climate Analysis Center in Washington, say he be skeptical of Plummer's thesis. There's an enormous number of possibilities that one could chase, Rodenhuis said. The next business of the scientist be to ... extend the range of analysis and look for cause and effect. The crippling drought hit North America be expect to reduce world grain stocks to levels that may cause food shortages in many poor countries, the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization report today. The agency projects world cereal production in 1988 to total 1.785 billion tons, only two million tons more than last year's level, which be already below the expect production. If the drought in the United States end now, grain production would fall close to the low levels of 1983, when a drought and farmers' participation in a government crop reduction program decrease output, the agency reported. As a result, world grain stocks be project to fall below 310 million tons, or 17 percent of the level the agency considers necessary to safeguard world food security, the report said. If crop conditions in the United States and Canada continue to deteriorate, the ratio could drop even further. Such a development would have serious implications for the food security, particularly of many low-income, food-deficit countries, the report said. The high grain prices result from a low supply would hit poor, food-importing countries the hardest, the U.N. agency warned. It say the rise prices could also reduce food aid from develop countries. The most severely hit crops be coarse grains mostly maize, barley and oats, the report said. The agency project good harvests in other parts of the world. In Asia the yearly monsoon rains start on time, and production in Europe and the Soviet be expect to be large than last year. Grain production in South America should be slightly lower this year than last. In the Sahel region of sub-saharan Africa, however, locusts flourish in unexpectedly heavy rains have damage this year's harvest. Potential crop losses from the pests could hit 1 million tons, FAO said. Weather experts discuss the drought Thursday and its possible causes and effects, and say they hop to produce a consensus on how much long it will last. All of the speakers at the 1988 Drought Symposium call for more research and study. There's an enormous number of possibilities that one could chase. The next business of the scientist be to eliminate the possibilities of ... and extend the range of analysis and look for cause and effect, say David Rodenhuis, director of the federal Climate Analysis Center in Washington. The symposium attend by 13 state and national experts be sponsor by The Weather Channel, an atlanta-based cable network, which broadcast the meeting live. John Hope, the network's hurricane specialist and a former forecaster with the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Fla., say the drought in the Southeast might be lessen or end in the next few months by a heavy than normal hurricane season. Hope say current weather conditions point to more tropical storms, more of which should become hurricanes, in this hurricane season. He stress that a hurricane's effect on drought be variable, depend on the intensity and speed of the storm. Nevertheless, he said, some Southeastern states get as much as 25 pecent of their rainfall in some months from hurricanes. Georgia state climatologist Gayther Plummer tell the symposium he think the position of the planet Jupiter have something to do with drought in the Southeast. However, Rodenhuis say he be skeptical about Plummer's thesis. It's very necessary to be cautious and analytical about the issue, he said. heavy rain deluge some drought-hit areas as Congress begin work on a package of relief for America's farmers, and farmers in Kentucky today greet the arrival of the first shipment of hay airlift free from Oregon. Everything look so good with a bit of rain over the past 24 hours, farmer Herman Krone say Tuesday at his 2,800-acre farm in southern Illinois, which President Reagan plan to visit Thursday during a tour of the drought-stricken area. However, Krone said, almost one-third of his 1,200 acres of corn already have be lost. Marth Wilkinson, wife of Kentucky Gov. Wallace Wilkinson and business manager of the family's farm, be at Louisville's Standiford Field today for the arrival of the first hay shipment from Portland, Ore. United Parcel Service plan to ship free of charge 20 to 30 tons of hay from Portland to Louisville each day for the next two weeks. The Agriculture Department, meanwhile, issue a report predict severe damage to the harvest from the drought. It estimated, for example, that corn output this year would shrivel to 5.2 billion bushels, down from 7.06 billion last year. The dry weather be the large drought that our nation have ever experienced, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng tell legislators. I think history will show that it's truly more mammoth than any of us have ever experienced. extremely heavy rain fell Tuesday in sections of Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Arkansas. In Texas, more than 6{ inches fell in 75 minutes in Mesquite, wash a pickup truck and several cars into a creek and leave some homes 8 inches deep in water. Water be up to the tops of cars in Garland and street flooding be report in Heath. nearly 6 inches fell in DeQueen, Ark. Showers and thunderstorms be widespread over the Middle Atlantic States, the Tennessee Valley and the Gulf Coast states. Thunderstorms boom today over the Dakotas and Minnesota. In Washington, the House and Senate Agriculture committees begin work on wide-ranging legislation that would provide payments of up to $100,000 each to farmers whose crops have be wipe out by the dry spell. House Agriculture Committee Chairman E. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, call for final action on the measure by mid-august. The drought have dry up pastures, force livestock farmers to go far afield for hay. The hay that arrive in Kentuky today will be store at a fairgrounds, and distribute next week by lottery to farmers, who will pay for the hay, officials said. It seem like everyone in the state want this hay, state Department of Agriculture spokesman Roger Nesbitt say Tuesday. The delay have anger some farmers, such as Bernetta Smith, who expect to run out of hay for her 147 beef cows in one to two days. I don't see any sense in store it because people need this hay. I don't understand it, she said. At least 50 truckloads of hay gather from the Carolinas and Virginia be be ship to Ohio on Thursday in a drive organize by the Charlotte Motor Speedway and the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing. Despite the recent rain, communities with dried-up water supplies continue to restrict water use. Until the drought ends, the 650 residents of Vintondale, Pa., about 50 miles east of Pittsburgh, will have to do without run water from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. every day, Mayor Michael Palovich say Tuesday. Palovich say he be try to arrange for an emergency supply to be truck in. The drought have have a silver lining for anglers in the Reno, Nevada, area. The state Board of Wildlife Commissioners remove the limit on catches at Rye Patch and Lahontan reservoirs because the reservoirs be expect to be dry by the end of summer, leave fish high and dry. here be a state-by-state summary of drought developments Wednesday: Weather forecasters today be offer drought-stricken farmers little prospect of relief in separate outlooks for the next 30 days and three months. A new climate assessment of the ongoing drought say many areas now experience extreme drought have less than a 4 percent chance of recover from the drought within 3 months. The disappointing forecast come as President Reagan head to the Midwest to inspect drought-plagued farms. On Tuesday the Agriculture Department report sharp declines in the outlook for several crops. That be follow Wednesday by a 30-day forecast from the National Weather Service say that drought-stricken areas from the Dakotas east to New York and from the canadian border to Oklahoma, Arkansas and Tennessee be likely to continue to be short of rain. That area, which include the major grain-growing states where crops already be suffering, be give a 55 percent chance of less than normal rainfall. And some states in the center of the area, stretch from West Virginia to Nebraska and from Wisconsin to Missouri, may be even drier. They be give a 60 percent chance of be short of precipitation. A slice of southern California, include Los Angeles, be the dry area in the forecast, with a 70 percent chance of have below normal rainfall. The rest of coastal California also will be dry, the forecast said. The outlook also say there's a 55 percent chance of hot than normal temperatures through the U.S. heartland from New England to Idaho and from the canadian border to Oklahoma. Within that area, the chances of high temperatures be above 65 percent in Wyoming, while central Midwestern states have a 60 percent chance of above average temperatures. Wetter than normal weather be predict for west and south Texas, and parts of New Mexico, Arizona and Utah. Normal precipitation be forecast for the Atlantic and Gulf coast states, along with the Northwest and northern Mountain States. The Weather Service say normal temperatures be expect for the Atlantic states from Virginia south, and for the Gulf Coast states. West Texas and New Mexico may be cool than normal, but the far West be expect to see its normal quota of summer heat. The separate drought impact assessment, issue by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Climate Office, point out that predict an end to the drought be a complex thing, since dry spells have no normal lifetime. The low 4 percent probability of an end within 3 months be base simply on a statistical analysis of past droughts, the agency said. The report note that as of the end of June, 29 percent of the continental United States be experience severe or extreme drought, with parts of 35 states affected. That put the current drought on the same level as the one in 1911, but still less severe than the droughts of 1936, 1931, 1956 and 1934. Kentucky's governor have criticize the federal government for be too slow in deal with the drought, and Iowa's governor warn that farmers in his state still face potential disaster despite up to five inches of rain over the weekend. Crews begin instal pumps on barges Monday to haul fresh water to southern Louisiana towns plague by rise salt levels in the low Mississippi River. Meanwhile, House Speaker Jim Wright say in Washington he hop that a relief package with disaster payments of up to $100,000 for drought-stricken farmers will win committee approval and be ready for floor action in Congress this week. here be a state-by-state summary of the late drought developments: The drought may force the government to ease crop acreage controls next year to help the United States rebuild its grain inventories, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng say Monday. But the United States will continue to be a major player in world agriculture and in 1989 should be able to bounce back from this year's drought losses, he said. Lyng's remarks be prepare for delivery at a meeting of farm magazine, extension, advertising, co-op and broadcast editors. A large portion of the United States suffer from some degree of drought stress in May and June than at any point since records begin in 1895, he said. Moreover, on July 2, about 35 percent of the contiguous United States be in the severe to extreme drought category, he said. In 1934, more than 60 percent be so rated, and in August 1954 more than 50 percent be in that category. Because of the large early season area now experience drought in the U.S., 1988 appear to have the potential to approach or exceed the drought-affected areas of the 1930s and 1950s, Lyng said. even with the severe drought, there will be an adequate supply of food grains and livestock fee grains so that the United States will be able to take care of our domestic needs and our export demand, he said. Lyng say total consumption of 1988 crops will probably be somewhat less than previously estimate because prices be much higher. But it be important to note that we will have no shortages, that we will still be able to accommodate the needs of our overseas buyers, he said.
column5: Worst drought in nearly a century affects major grain growing areas.
column6: The worst drought to hit the United States since 1895, when record keeping began, has damaged grain crops in the major grain growing states and could lead to food shortages in poorer nations. The drought has forced some states to import hay from other states. Communities in many states have imposed tight water rationing.
column7: A severe drought continues to affect large areas of the United States and climatologists warn that the future could see more unless steps are taken to halt the earth's rising temperature. The drought is the worst since records began being kept in 1895 and hasaffected grain production across the nation. Grain supplies are expected to fall to 17 percent of what is required to safeguard world food security. Communities in the areas affected have restricted water use and Oregon has begun to ship hay to Kentucky. Some areas have seen some relief as heavy storms hit large sections of the country.
column8: A severe drought has affected large portions of the United States as rainfall was below normal in major grain growing states. The drought, rated severe by July 2, is the worst noted since the U.S. began keeping records in 1895 and affects about 35 percent of the contiguous United States.  If conditions continue, the areas affect could exceed the 60 percent of 1934 and the 50 percent of 1954. The drought has caused grain and soybean futures to drop and grain stocks are projected to fall below 310 million tons, or 17 percent of what is considered necessary to safeguard world food security. Many poorer nations could face food shortages as grain prices rise. Many communities from Iowa to Alabama face water shortages that leave officials seeking alternate water supplies. Other areas have imposed bans on outdoor water use. Heavy storms which have spread across the nation have brought deluges to Texas and Arkansas, tornados to Kansas, and damaging high winds to Michigan and Indiana but water restrictions will remain in effect for the immediate future. Kentucky received its first of hay from Oregon. Farmers in Kentucky, as in other states, were forced to seek hay elsewhere when the drought dried up pastures.
column9: Prolonged 1988 drought affects crops, livestock, water, jobs; prompts aid
column10: In mid-July, 1988's drought was predicted to continue three months. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage, and lightning-sparked fires. States issued heat alerts. Weather experts attended a Drought Symposium. Grain futures and certain jobs fell. Hay was transported for free. Aid, loans, and reduced controls for farmers were proposed.  Drinking water was short. Livestock sales increased.
column11: In mid-July, 1988's drought looked record-breaking. Further drought was predicted based on past records. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage, and lightning-sparked fires. States issued heat alerts. Weather experts who attended a Drought Symposium urged continued attention to climate and greenhouse-effect reduction. Crop declines were forecast and grain futures fell. Adequate domestic and export supplies were expected. UPS, railroads, and truckers transported hay for free. Federal aid, state loans to farmers, and eased future crop controls were proposed. Reagan visited drought areas. Farmers sued reneging insurers. Drinking water was hauled in and dam flows reduced. Livestock sales increased. Cannery, mill, and  logging jobs fell. Highway projects were accelerated.
column12: In mid-July, 1988's drought looked record-breaking. Predictions were for month-long hot, dry weather in grain-growing states and rain elsewhere, and a 4% chance of three-month recovery based on past-drought analysis. Rain was insufficient. Severe storms brought tornadoes, hail damage to crops, and lightning-sparked forest fires. Temperatures topped 100 and states issued heat alerts. Weather experts attending a Drought Symposium urged continued attention to climate, and energy policies to reduce the greenhouse effect. One theorized a relationship between drought and Jupiter's orbit. Crop declines were forecast and grain futures dropped. Adequate domestic and export supplies were expected. Higher prices would reduce consumption. Poor, food-importing countries would suffer most. Good harvests in Europe and Asia were projected. Georgia itemized hay sources. UPS, railroads, and truckers transported hay to Kentucky and Ohio for free. Congress proposed up to $100,000 aid to farmers. States provided funds for farm loans. President Reagan visited drought areas. Easing of 1989 crop acreage controls was considered. Farmers sued a company reneging on drought insurance. Drinking water was hauled to towns. Dam flow reductions endangered neighbors' supplies. Catch limits disappeared at reservoirs. Gamefish and turkeys were depleted. Livestock sales increased. Cannery jobs fell. Laying off mill workers and banning logging was considered. Few rain interruptions accelerated highway projects.

column3: THE INVASION: Iraq's troops, lead by about 350 tanks, cross the border at dawn Thursday, and seize the Kuwaiti palace and government buildings 40 miles away. early Friday, the invaders control Kuwait city, the capital. The soldiers be also make sweeps through the southern oilfields, accord to residents and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Diplomatic sources estimate more than 200 Kuwaitis be kill or wounded, mainly from the Emiri Guard which bore the main brunt of the invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-abdullah al-sabah flee to safety in Saudi Arabia. THE FORCES: Iraq, a country of more than 17 million, have the Arab world's most battle-trained army, and have mass more than 100,000 soldiers on the Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, an oil-rich city-state, have 1.9 million residents 60 percent foreigners and an army of 20,300 soldiers. CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accuse Kuwait of steal oil from its territory and force down oil prices through overproduction. Kuwait and U.N. diplomats dismiss Iraq's claim that it invade at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries. REACTION: The U.N. Security Council vote 14-0 to condemn the invasion. President Bush denounce it as naked agression. He freeze Iraq's assets in the United States and block almost all Iraqi imports, include oil. The order also froze Kuwait property under U.S. jurisdiction a move intend to keep Iraq from seize it. The Soviets also condemn the invasion and stop arms sales to Iraq. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador say the nation have ask for american military intervention. A Pentagon source say a U.S. naval group be divert toward the persian Gulf. oil prices soar in frenzied trading amid fears the invasion would reduce the supply of oil. Administration and congressional officials agree that the CIA do its job. Since last week, President Bush have be warn by intelligence analysts that what originally look like a military bluff be quickly turn into the kind of troop deployment that could be use to invade Kuwait or even Saudi Arabia. Central Intelligence Agency Director William Webster even hand-delivered certain fresh details on the Iraqi buildup to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. Among the assessments he convey be a conclusion that, by this week, President Saddam Hussein's force would be capable of penetrate Kuwait or Saudi Arabia. The agency lack hard evidence of an intent to invade, intelligence officials say. But as the buildup grew, the CIA become more alarmed, partly because Mr. Hussein be so unpredictable, and partly because, unlike many other arab leaders, he have be know to carry out his threats. Saudi Arabia have be subdue in its reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which place Iraqi forces near the oil-rich kingdom's border. Oil executives say Saudi Arabia have not and will not take the most potent action possible against Iraq close the pipeline that carry Iraqi oil for export across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea. The executives say the Saudis believe this would give Iraq's belligerent president, Saddam Hussein, an excuse to attack and occupy Saudi oil fields 150 miles south of Kuwait, give Iraq control of more oil than any other country in the world. The only direct Saudi statement since the invasion be make by an anonymous government spokesman through the official Saudi Press Agency the day after the Iraqi move. The statement say Saudi Arabia be follow the Kuwait situation with extreme concern and that King Fahd would be seek to calm the situation and to find a solution in a manner ensure the interests of all. The statement do not condemn the invasion. The only tangible help Saudi Arabia give the Kuwaiti government in the wake of the invasion be to shelter members of the ruling family, include the emir, Sheik Jaber al-ahmed al-sabah, and the crown prince. Both nations be tightly run by royal families and have be close allies. The Saudis also allow the Kuwaiti royal family to briefly operate a radio, reportedly from a mobile van, in the area around the Saudi-Kuwait border. But Friday the radio go off the air after a desperate call: The people of Kuwait appeal to you oh brethren, oh Arabs, oh beloved brothers, oh Moslems, rush, rush to their help. It be not know if the radio have be discover by the Iraqis or shut down by the Saudis to avoid provoke Saddam at a time when fears be be express that he might invade Saudi Arabia as well. Saudi Arabia borders Kuwait and Iraq's invasion forces be reportedly near the Saudi border. The Saudis do condemn the invasion as part of a joint statement issue by the Gulf Cooperation Council, in which it be ally with Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain. The six states issue a statement saying, We strongly condemn and be very sorry for this attack that one Arab state take against another arab state. ... We do not recognize anything result from it. Iraq's 1-million-member arm forces be clearly too much for the joint 3,000-member Gulf Cooperation Council force or Saudi Arabia's 65,700-member army. Saudi Arabia be also one of the 14 members of the 21-member Arab League that condemn the invasion in the same terms as the Gulf Cooperation Council. The Arab League, with one-third of its members vote against the resolution or abstaining, be clearly unable to take any direct action. Turkey have also refuse to take action and have not comment about President Bush's suggestion that it cut off Iraq's oil pipeline to the Mediterranean. Two parallel pipelines pump Iraqi crude oil to a terminal at Yumurtalik at the eastern corner of Turkey's Mediterranean coast and constitute Iraq's major oil export outlet. Ruling party members say today that the government, fear a U.S. air attack, be distribute automatic weapons to tens of thousands of supporters and prepare to evacuate the Iraqi capital. A boycott of Iraqi oil force Baghdad today to close one of two pipelines in Turkey that be pump the bulk of Iraq's export oil, turkish officials said. A british official say Iraqi troops round up american and british visitors in Kuwait and take them to iraq. The Foreign Office spokesman say most be passengers from a british Airways flight strand in Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion Thursday. There be no evidence that they be in any way in trouble, the official said. Saudi Arabia be report reinforce its troops along the Kuwaiti border follow concerns Iraq may try to invade it. Pentagon sources say the USS Independence and its carrier battle group be now on station in the Arabian Sea, a position that would allow it to launch fighter planes into the Persian Gulf region. gulf-based diplomats say soldiers from the american rapid deployment force, form to react to crises in the Middle East, have be dispatch to the area. In other developments: The new Kuwait government instal by Iraq hint it might take hostages or seize property of nations that take punitive measures against Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein say the 100,000 soldiers who invade Kuwait begin to pull back Sunday. President Bush say Iraq be lying. Oil prices jump more than $3 a barrel on news Europe and Japan be join the embargo of Iraqi oil. Stocks slump worldwide. Hospital officials say at least 300 Kuwaiti and Iraqi soldiers be kill during the invasion. In London, Kuwaitis arrive on a special plane say 700 Kuwaitis died. The embargo of Iraqi oil grow over the weekend to include Japan and the European Community. Along with the United States, they buy more than half Iraq's export oil, with most of it pump through Turkey. An official of the state-run turkish pipeline company BOTAS say pumping stop at one of the two turkish pipelines at 5 p.m. Iraq reduce flow in the second, wider, pipeline to 70 percent of capacity, they said. There be no comment from Iraq. The two pipelines pump Iraqi crude from Kirkuk oil fields in northern Iraq to a terminal at the northeastern tip of the Mediterranean. They carry 70 million tons of crude annually, provide the outlet for the major share of Iraqi exports. The BOTAS official say all the countries participate in the embargo purchase their Iraqi crude from the turkish outlet. Iraq also exports oil through a Saudi Arabian pipeline and via tankers in the northern Persian Gulf. A Foreign Office spokesman say today as say a total of 366 people have be assemble by Iraqi troops in Kuwait, mostly passengers from a stranded british Airways flight. They be be transport by bus to the Iraqi border. Baghdad do not give any reason for its action. immediately after the invasion Thursday, 11 Americans be round up by Iraqi troops. They turn up safe in Baghdad. The new iraqi-installed foreign minister of Kuwait, Lt. Col. Walid Sa'oud Mohammed Abdullah, warn against further sanctions in a statement broadcast Sunday by Iraqi radio. Countries that resort to punitive measures against the provisional free Kuwait government and fraternal Iraq should remember that they have interests and nationals in Kuwait, he said. Iraqi soldiers invade Kuwait after complain that its violation of OPEC production quotas be drive down world crude prices, lower Iraqi oil revenues. column5: Iraq invades Kuwait. Sanctions Imposed On Iraq. Oil Prices Soaring
column6: Iraq's army quickly overran Kuwait on 2 August 1990. The invasion came after Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a border area, and exceeding OPEC's production quota. The United Nations voted on 6 August to impose broad trade and military sanctions on Iraq. Market price of oil soared.
column7: Iraq's powerful army met little resistance when it invaded Kuwait on 2 August 1990. The invasion came as no surprise. Iraqi President Hussein had accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a border area, and exceeding OPEC production goals.The United Nations Security Council voted on 6 August to impose trade and military sanctions on Iraq. Some major oil importers had already embargoed Iraqi oil. Oil prices soared.The United States moved an aircraft carrier into the Arabian Sea. Iraq warned its people of a possible United States attack. President Bush only said that all options were open.
column8: Iraq's powerful army invaded Kuwait early on 2 August 1990. The small Kuwait army offered little resistance. Kuwaiti government buildings were occupied and 350 Iraqi tanks swept toward the southern oilfields. The invasion followed Hussein's claim that Kuwait stole oil from a disputed border area, and exceeded OPEC production quotas. Kuwait dismissed Iraq's claim that a Kuwaiti revolutionary group invited the invasion. Iraq had signaled the coming of the invasion by moving 100,000 troops to the border, and CIA warned that it might well occur.The United Nations Security Council immediately condemned the invasion, and on 6 August voted 13-0 to impose sweeping trade and military sanctions against Iraq. United States. Japan and the European community had already cut off the importation of Iraqi oil. Oil prices soared. Iraq felt an almost immediate effect, and closed one of the pipelines that carries export oil across Turkey. Iraq retaliated by rounding up westerners in Kuwait, and moving some to Baghdad.President Bush denounced the invasion. A United States aircraft battle group moved into the Arabian Sea. Saddam Hussein warned the Iraqi populace that United States might attack. Bush only said that all options were open.
column9: Iraq invades Kuwait:  U.S.-U.N. demand withdrawal; impose sanctions.
column10: Iraq, after accusing Kuwait of wrongdoing that cost Iraq billions, invaded and overran Kuwait.  A skeptical U.S. and U.N. rejected Iraq's claimed justification for invasion, condemned the action, demanded withdrawal, and threatened sanctions.  After Iraqi intransigence, strong economic and military sanctions were imposed.  Iraq alerted its citizens to a possible U.S. attack.
column11: Iraq, after accusing Kuwait of multiple, harmful wrongdoings, invaded and overran Kuwait.  It claimed to have responded to a request by a Kuwaiti revolutionary group.  A skeptical U.S. and U.N. rejected this justification, condemned the action, demanded withdrawal, and threatened sanctions.  The beleaguered Kuwaiti government requested U.S. military intervention.  Divided Arab nations failed to resolve the crisis. After further Iraqi intransigence, strong U.N. economic and military sanctions were imposed, including a ban on Iraqi oil and imports.  The price of oil soared.  Iraq responded by rounding up foreigners in Kuwait, sending some to Baghdad, and alerting its citizens to a possible U.S. attack.
column12: Iraq ended its 1980-1988 war with Iran in debt for about $80 billion.  On July 17, 1990 Iraq provoked a major crisis by accusing Kuwait of costing it billions by exceeding Kuwait's OPEC assigned oil production quotas, thus driving down the price of oil, by stealing Iraqi oil from a disputed border oil field, and also by demanding repayment of a $15 billion war debt.  After Egyptian and Saudi Arabian mediation failed, Iraq invaded Kuwait with 100,000 troops led by 350 tanks.  It quickly overran Kuwaiti defenses and continued south to the oil fields.  Kuwait leaders, including the emir, escaped to Saudi Arabia.  They appealed for U.S. military intervention.  The Pentagon diverted an aircraft carrier group toward the gulf.  A U.S. led U.N. resolution demanded that Iraq immediately and unconditionally withdraw its forces from Kuwait.  Iraq responded that it invaded at the request of a Kuwaiti revolutionary group that had already overthrown the government of Kuwait and this was not a U.N. matter.  The U.N. rejected this justification as a farce and imposed strong economic and military sanctions after Iraq failed to withdraw.  After a U.S. warning against invading Saudi Arabia, Iraq alerted its population to a possible U.S. attack.
