In between, in 1966, he be a victim ofthe Cultural Revolution purges and be send to a communal farm forre-education.after the June 4, 1989, military crackdown on the democracymovement, Fang and Li obtain refuge in the U.S. Embassy.An anti-american newspaper in Iran saidsunday the United States be partly to blame for the death of tensof thousands of people in last week's earthquake.the criminal role of America in Iran's past become evidentonce again in the recent earthquake, the Jomhuri Islami say inan editorial report by the official Islamic Republic News Agency.Our people, even under the rubble, chant `death to America'and pray to God to cut off the hands of the United States ... eventhose hands stretch out to help, it said.it argue that by plunder Iran's oil and other resourcesfor 25 years, the United States have prevent the use of even asmall part of the national wealth for urban development projectsand advance (anti-seismic) building construction systems.even after its expulsion from Iran, the U.S. government byimposing economic sanctions and launch several other plots,halted the renovation of the country, the editorial added.the newspaper be imply that with these actions the UnitedStates have block the diversion of funds to earthquake safetymeasures.if the United States have real humanitarian objectives andintended to help the iranian nation, it should do only one thing,stop hatching plots, the newspaper said.it call on Iranians to reject relief offers by the UnitedStates and other governments whose hands be stain with theblood of the iranian people.iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure ofhostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, have say it would welcomerelief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitariangroups. The two nations have no diplomatic ties.The earthquake that devastate Iran earlythursday take tens of thousands of lives because people be asleepin fragile homes build on flood plains, an earthquake expert said.most casualties from earthquakes be cause by somethingfalling on top of you, say Russ Needham, a geophysist with theu.s. Geological Survey that monitors grind motion around the world.the quake hit at 12:30 a.m. in Iran, when most of the peoplewere in their homes, Needham say Thursday in a telephone interviewfrom Golden, Colo.At least 25,000 people die and thousands be injure in thequake, which demolish scores of villages and buried thousands ofpeople in the rubble of their homes, iranian officials said.needham say most structures in that area be build of aceramic-type brick or adobe that collapse easily.it's very similar to what we have in Armenia, he say of thedec. 7, 1988, earthquake that kill about 25,000 people.A soviet parliamentary report later blame the high number offatalities on shoddily build buildings.the armenian quake be measure at 6.9 on the Richter scale, butThursday's earthquake shake the earth with a magnitude of 7.7.The shock wave travel through the mountainous section ofcoastal Iran where most of the buildings be build on a flood plainof loosely deposit soil that shifts in an earthquake and allowsstructures to collapse, he said.the 7.7-magnitude quake be the large ever record in thatarea, where two major plates of the earth's crust meet, Needhamssaid.Iran be in a very active seismic region, he said, and thatthere have be many small quakes.twelve earthquakes great than magnitude 7 have occur iniran during the last 30 years, Needhams said.a quake of magnitude 7 be consider a major earthquake, capableof widespread, heavy damage in populated areas.
column5: Iranian earthquake kills thousands; relief flights underway for injured,homeless
column6: The massive earthquake, which struck northern Iran on June 20th, killed anestimated 36,000, injured thousands, and left 400,000 homeless.  Shoddyhousing, which fell apart during the earthquake, was the cause of mostdeaths.  Relief supplies from all over the world, including the US, pouredinto Tehran.
column7: The largest earthquake (magnitude 7.7) ever to strike Iran occurred on June20th.  The Islamic Republic put the death toll at 36,000 and the numberhomeless at 400,000.  The opposition People's Mojahedin blamed thegovernment for shoddy housing that caused the deaths, which they said wereunderreported.  The government, in turn, blamed the US for robbing it of oilresources and leaving too little for developing modern construction methods.Iran said it would accept aid from all countries, even the US, but not fromIsrael and South Africa.  Relief supplies poured into Iran from all over theworld, including the US.
column8: The earthquake that devastated northern Iran on June 20th registered amagnitude of 7.7, making it the strongest ever recorded in that county.Initial estimate of those killed was 25,000 but in the days following, thatwas scaled upward to 36,000.  Iran is in an active seismic region soearthquakes, even major ones, are not unknown.Iran is used to massive tragedies: natural disasters, war, and revolution.President Hashemi Rafsanjani declared a three-day mourning period and thegovernment said it would welcome aid from all countries except Israel andSouth Africa.  A spokesman for the People's Mojahedin accused the governmentof underreporting the number of deaths and pinned responsibility for thosedeaths on the Islamic government forcing people to live in shoddy housing.The government blamed the US for loss of life by earlier plundering Iran'soil thus depriving the country of the means to develop modern constructionmethods.Relief supplies poured into Iran from all over the world including the US.US contributions, including those from the government, were funneled throughprivate relief organizations.  The Iranian community of Orange County wasactive in seeking contributions.  Aid was vital for Iran since thousandswere injured and 400,000 homeless.
column9: Worldwide Response To Devastating Iranian Earthquake.
column10: The Iranian earthquake of June 21, 1990 elicited an outpouring of aid from around the world, including the United States -- the first such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Differences, remained, however with an Iranian opposition group in the U.S. blaming earthquake casualties on the Iranian government and an anti-American newspaper in Iran blaming them on the United States.
column11: An earthquake of magnitude 7.7 hit northwestern Iran on June 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people and injuring 200,000. The quake occurred when most people were inside asleep and hit a coastal floodplain where loosely deposited soil shifts easily and caused the fragile adobe homes in the area to collapse. The Iranian president appealed for international aid and the response was overwhelming, including assistance from the United States, the first such since the hostage crisis of 1979-80. On the negative side, Iranian news media were slow to report on the disaster and the Iranian and U.S. government were blamed by their respective critics for the excessive casualties.
column12: An earthquake hit Gilan and Zanjan provinces in northwestern Iran onJune 21, 1990 killing at least 50,000 people, injuring 200,000 andleaving 400,000 homeless. The quake measured 7.7 on the Richter scaleand exacted particularly heavy casualties since it occurred when mostpeople were inside asleep and hit a coastal area of loosely depositedsoil that shifts, causing the ceramic-type brick or adobe homes in thearea to collapse. The Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani appealedfor international aid and the response was impressive with financialcontributions and relief supplies arriving from the Soviet Union,Mexico, the Vatican, West Germany, Turkey, Spain, India, Austria,France and the United States. The aid from the United States,channeled through the Red Cross and Red Crescent and including fundsand supplies raised by Iranians in California, was the firstbenevolence offered by the U.S. and accepted by the Iranian governmentsince the hostage crisis of 1979-80. Iranian news media reactedsluggishly to the emergency, underestimating casualties and givinglittle detailed or colorful reporting for hours after the quakehit. In Washington Iranian opposition leaders blamed the excessivecasualties on the Iranian government and in Iran an anti-Americannewspaper blamed the United States.

column3: The San Francisco 49ers rout the DenverBroncos 55-10 Sunday in the most lopsided Super Bowl victory ever.the 49ers' win in the 24th Super Bowl make them the first repeatnfl champion in a decade and tie the Pittsburgh Steelers as apinnacle of Super Bowl perfection with four wins in four tries.san Francisco win the National Football League championship gamein 1989, 1985 and 1982. The Broncos, on the other hand, lose thelast four Super Bowl games they have played.san Francisco quarterback Joe Montana make five touchdownpasses, three to Jerry Rice, break a Super Bowl record fortouchdown passes on a day on which he also set a record with 13straight pas completions.he also set five Super Bowl career records, include his thirdsuper Bowl Most Valuable Player award and San Francisco's pointtotal be the most ever. Montana leave the game with nearly 11minutes to play.in four Super Bowls, he have throw 11 touchdowns and nointerceptions.for Denver quarterback John Elway, it be a day of futility,ending with his third Super Bowl defeat. He miss eight of hisfirst 10 passes and be intercept twice and fumble once.by halftime the score be 27-3. With their third loss in fouryears, the Broncos have now be outscore 136-40.san Francisco be boringly perfect, do more than even theexperts who make them favorites by nearly two touchdowns after a14-2 season and a waltz through the playoffs.(box) SEATING CAPACITY: 74,315.; (box) KICKOFF: 3:18 p.m. PacificStandard Time.; (box) PLAYERS SHARE: The winners will get $36,000 per man.the losers will get $18,000 per man.; (box) SUDDEN DEATH: If the game istied at regulation time 60 minutes, it will continue in sudden death overtime.the team score first (by safety, field goal, or touchdown) will win. At theend of regulation play time, the referee will immediately toss a coin atmidfield, in accordance with rules pertain to the usual pregame toss. Thecaptain of AFC team (the visit team) will call the toss. follow athree-minute intermission after the end of the regular game, play willcontinue by 15-minute periods with a two-minute intermission between each suchovertime period with no halftime intermission. The teams will change goalsbetween each period, there will be a two-minute warning at the end of eachperiod.; (box) TROPHY: The win team receives permanent possession ofthe Vince Lombardi Trophy, a sterling silver trophy create by Tiffany &Company and present annually to the winner of the Super Bowl. The trophy wasnamed after the late coach Vince Lombardi of the two-time Super Bowl championgreen Bay Packers prior to Super Bowl V. The trophy be a regulation silverfootball mount in a kicking position on a pyramid-like stand of threeconcave sides. The trophy stand 20 3/4 inches tall, weigh 6.7 pounds and isvalued in excess of $10,000. The words "vince Lombardi" and "Super Bowl XXIV"are engrave on the base along with the NFL emblem.; (box) ATTENDANCE: Todate, 1,953,690 have attend Super Bowl games. The large crowd be 103,985at the 14th Super Bowl at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena.In a dramatic finish, the San Francisco 49ersfootball team win the Super Bowl on Sunday with a 20-16 victory overthe Cincinnati Bengals.Joe Montana's 10-yard touchdown pas to John Taylor with 34seconds left provide the win margin.the victory be achieve through the brilliance of Montana andjerry Rice, the wide receiver who catch 12 passes for 222 yards,both Super Bowl records. Rice be name the game's most valuableplayer.the winning score come at the end of a 92-yard drive, engineeredby Montana, whose touchdown pas give him a Super Bowl record with357 yards passing.it be the fifth straight win for a National Football Conferenceteam, but by far the most dramatic the previous four have be byan average score of 41-14.it also give 49ers Coach Bill Walsh his third Super Bowl win.the game be a defensive struggle in the first half, which endedin a 3-3 tie. Two key players be injure in the first 14 plays,cincinnati's All-Pro nose tackle Tim Krumrie and San Francisco'stackle Steve Wallace.The first touchdown didn't come until 44 minutes into the60-minute game, when Cincinnati's Stanford Jennings take a kickoff93 yards for a score.the game, before a crowd of 75,179 at Joe Robbie Stadium, wentundisrupted by racial tensions in Miami.The beer gridiron be go to be a busy andexpensive place on television this January.The nation's two large brewers, Anheuser Busch Cos. Inc. andmiller Brewing Co., be gear up to sell their beer with bystaging mock football games in television commercials inconjunction with Super Bowl XXIV in New Orleans.Executives from both companies say they're attempt to takeadvantage of the weeks of hype surround the game. Bothbeermakers claim their packages be the large super Bowlpromotions ever, with each planning to spend upwards of $7 million.Anheuser Busch be stag a Bud Bowl II ad campaign thatculminates during the Jan. 28 Super Bowl, with a game featuringanimated teams of Budweiser and Bud Light beer bottles rattlingaround on a pint-sized football field. The first such game wasstaged during the last Super Bowl.We're start a month earlier, we've add an extra promospot and we're go to have a lot more display materials in thestores, say Tom Sharbaugh, group brand director for Budweiser.Miller, base in Milwaukee, won't say exactly how much it isspending on its 12-week, pre-super Bowl campaign center on afootball game between a Tastes Great team and a LessFilling squad.those teams will be make up of current and former NationalFootball League players such as Bert Jones, L.C. Greenwood and JoeKlecko.We're spending more than $7 million, I can tell you that,said Richard Burton, advertising manager for Lite beer. we'retalking about real-life talent.miller's campaign culminate Jan. 14, two weeks before the SuperBowl, primarily because Anheuser Busch buy all the Super Bowltelevision spots allocate for beer advertising.miller's television commercials already have start airing.Anheuser Busch will begin its ads this week with a spot featuringsports announcer Brent Musberger.Both companies also have fan participation promotions.anheuser Busch expect to receive 400,000 to 500,000 scorecardsfrom fans who be be ask to write down the score of the BudBowl after each quarter. Fans who send in their scorecards willreceive a commemorative pin.miller have a consumer sweepstakes offer expense-paid trips tothe Super Bowl.Sports Illustrated be take 300 advertisers to Super Bowl XXI in Pasadena, Calif., this weekend for an all-out bash. Along with get seats for Sunday's game, the guests will brunch at the chic Spago restaurant, take a private tour of Universal Studios and attend a wing-ding at the Century Plaza Hotel. The magazine be just one of hundreds of businesses whose officials and customers will be among the 104,000 fans attend the Super Bowl. And the companies show few signs of cut back on their activities despite the new tax law's tighter restrictions on what can be claim as a business-entertainment expense. Still, the new rules do change things for a variety of Super Bowl entertain -- from an executive sit in a $1,500 seat on the 50-yard line to a businessman hold a Super Bowl party in his living room and hop to write off the costs. One big change under the new law limit business-entertainment deductions for tickets to sport events like the Super Bowl: only 80% of the face value of such tickets can be deducted. If a company purchases a a 50-yard-line seat for $1,500 -- the go rate -- it can deduct only 80% of the ticket's $75 face value, or $60. even to get the 80% deduction, there still must be a "substantial and bona fide business discussion" before, during or after the game, say julian Block, a tax specialist at Prentice-Hall Information Services Inc. To take a client to a game as merely a good-will gesture be no longer enough, Mr. Block says. And if a company want to simply give clients tickets to the game, the business gift carry a total deduction of only $25 for each recipient. The tough IRS rule, however, hasn't slow ticket demand; even end-zone seats be fetch $500 each. "even if it weren't tax deductible, it'd be worth it," say Tom Foley, chairman of Bibb Co., a Macon, Ga., maker of home furnishings and textile products that use the National Football League team logos. Bibb be fly about 20 people -- mostly customers -- to the game. "We get more earnings from the trip than the expense," say Mr. Foley. Some companies say they be make adjustments or at least educate their executives about the new rules. A spokesman for Adolph Coors & Co, the Golden, Colo., brewery, say its tax advisers instruct executives that "this can't be just a fun trip -- we have to discuss business." Air fare and lodging be still 100% deductible, as long as there be a planned business meeting in addition to the game. Meals be now 80% deductible as long as business be discussed. Under the old law, meals be fully deductible and all a company have to do be show a business relationship with the guest. Companies can get a 100% deduction for a pre-super Bowl banquet, since the new tax law have a "banquet meeting exception." such meetings must have at least 40 persons, half of whom be away from home, and there must be a speaker. Executives who bring clients over to the house to watch the Super Bowl on television also face new restrictions on deductions for food and liquor, say William J. Lipton, tax partner of the accounting firm Ernst & Whinney. If a host want to deduct 80% of the bill, he or she must talk business with all of the guests, Mr. Lipton says. One safety measure: make a business-oriented speech, Mr. Block suggests. He also advise party hosts to keep a guest list and note their business connection. That will be a big job for Barron Hilton, chairman of Hilton Hotels Corp., who along with Alex Spanos, owner of the San Diego Chargers, be hold a pre-super Bowl brunch Sunday at the Beverly Hilton Hotel for 1,800 guests include business leaders, entertainment personalities and customers. Allen Hermansen, a Hilton senior vice president, say the bash be tax deductible because "our sales people will be there and business will be discussed." He admits, however, "We're not go to twist any arms. We're there to say thank-you to those who've give us business." An IRS spokesman say more agents will be assign to corporate audits of business-entertainment expenses this year. But IRS enforcement of the rules could be as difficult as block the New York Giants' Lawrence Taylor. "as a practical matter, as long as people say they talk business at a Super Bowl party, how can the IRS dispute it?" say Vickie King, a Price Waterhouse tax official. "the only people who will get into trouble be those who don't keep receipts."president Bush congratulate the San Francisco49ers on Friday and say they rewrite the record books withtheir Super Bowl victory. In turn he be present with twoautographed balls and a jogging outfit.Let me congratulate you also on your victory, quarterback JoeMontana tell Bush at a East Room reception. Montana say beinginvited to the White House mean a lot to all of us and joked:not very often do I get to see these guys in ties.bush, surround by 49ers, tell the team, With this, your thirdsuper Bowl title in eight years, you rewrite the record books andraised the game of football to a new level of excellence.and, to Montana, who drive the team to the win touchdown on a92-yard drive late in the fourth quarter, Bush said: Joe, you onceagain show your grace under pressure. I guess we all wonder why ittook so long.bush be present autographed balls by both Montana and widereceiver Jerry Rice, who win the game's Most Valuable Player award.that's the real thing from the Super Bowl, Rice say of theball he give the president.bush joke that he heard, there be a new tv series come outbased on your Super Bowl performance Miami Rice. Available inevery city in the country except one. Cininnnati, that is.the 49ers beat the Cincinnati Bengals, 20-16, two weeks ago inmiami.team owner Danny DeBartolo tell Bush that he would be presentedwith a Super Bowl ring, size 11, because we want to make you anhonorary member of our team.and outgo coach Bill Walsh give Bush a 49ers jogging outfit,but cautioned, I'm not sure we suggest run in the streets ofwashington, D.C., in this suit....remember the Redskin fans be allaround us.Super Bowl winners be traditionally invite to the White House.The San Francisco 49ers' 55-10 rout of thedenver Broncos be the lowest-rated Super Bowl in 21 years and thethird-lowest ever.the game on CBS average a 39.0 rating and a 63 share, thelowest Super Bowl rating since 1969, when the New York Jets' 16-7victory over Baltimore get a 36.0 on NBC for the bad rating ever,a.c. Nielsen Co. say today.the rating be a percentage of the nation's televisions; eachpoint represent 921,000 homes. The share be the percentage of thetelevisions on at the time.despite the low rating, Sunday's game be see by about 108.5million people, make it the ninth most-watched tv show ever inthe United States behind eight Super Bowls and the final episode ofMASH. The high viewership be make possible by the annualincrease in the number of homes with television.Given the expect blowout, the numbers be completelyunderstandable and we're happy to have a 39, say Susan Kerr,director of program for CBS Sports. It's still a remarkablerating for prime time.the 49ers win by the big margin in Super Bowl history.only the 1969 and 1968 Super Bowls have low ratings; GreenBay's 33-14 victory over Oakland in 1968 get a 36.8. The firstsuper Bowl be in 1967.The highest-rated Super Bowl be in 1982, when the 49ers' 26-21victory over Cincinnati get a 49.1 on CBS.Last year's San Francisco-Cincinnati Super Bowl, win by the49ers 20-16, get a 43.5 rating and be see in 39.3 million homes,according to Nielsen estimates. This year's game be see in about35.9 million homes.viewership of the 5 p.m. game this year peak at a 41.6 ratingand a 69 share from 6 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., drop off as it becameclear that Denver would not rally.the pregame show get a 39.0 rating and a 63 share and thepostgame show get a 22.5 rating and a 35 share.the musical Annie, which be on ABC opposite the game, get a9.4 rating. Life Goes On on NBC get a 6.0 rating and LoveWith a twist on NBC a 7.6.Things be different; He say he only wish the black community couldhave share in some of the considerable profits generate by one of America'sgreatest sports events.; "the Super Bowl be about money," Carley say lastweek. "And last time we be basically onlookers."; Things be a lotdifferent this time around. This year, Carley be the co-chairman of one of thefeatured events of Super Bowl week, the Bambaleo Parade, a Saturdayextravaganza with march bands, a street festival and floats.; The grandmarshal of the parade will be Lee Roy Selmon, a former Tampa Bay Buccaneer.;Other events will include a salute to black sports legends and a DougWilliams golf tournament.; 'much more involvement'; This year, the SuperBowl Task Force, a group head by two of the city's most influential whitebusinessmen, name two black men to head a community-relations committee.;but perhaps most important, Carley said, several minority-owned businesseshave win lucrative contracts from the NFL for the game.; "there's much moreinvolvement this time, black and white," say Carley, who be theaffirmative-action officer for Hillsboro Community College.; "There's beena heighten awareness. In 1984, there be not even a thought give to a blackman."; About 100,000 visitors, many of them corporate and political moversand shakers, be expect to arrive in Tampa this week for the festivitiesleading up to the game Sunday.; The game itself, which be televise to 750million people around the world, be only part of an event whose impact on acity have be compare to that of a national political convention.; Hotels,restaurants and other businesses be anticipate an estimate $125 million inrevenues, with a total economic impact of $200 million.; 'it's a baywindow'; "The Super Bowl introduce you to the world in a big way," saidbarbara Casey, the coordinator of the Super Bowl Task Force. "You don't haveto say Tampa, Fla., anymore."; The Super Bowl also can highlight acommunity's problems, and bring the frustrations of many of its members to thesurface.; "It's more than a window into a town," say Jim Steeg, directorof special events for the NFL. "it's a bay window."; last month, NFLCommissioner Paul Tagliabue say he would stand by his recommendation to movethe 1993 Super Bowl out of Tempe, Ariz., because the state do not have aholiday honor Dr. Martin Luther King.; A week before the Super Bowl inmiami two years ago, the fatal shooting of a black man on a motorcycle by anhispanic police officer in the predominantly black Overtown neighborhood setoff three days of looting and torchings of buildings and cars.; While thedisturbances be not cause by the Super Bowl, the NFL be criticize at thetime for not make enough of an effort to include minority-group members inthe festivities.; "I think Miami be the awakening for a lot of people,"carley said.; In Tampa, Super Bowl XXV bring about the cancellation ofwhat be the big annual event in the city for 86 years: the GasparillaParade, an extravaganza that feature 500 of the city's most powerful menswaggering through the streets dress as gun-toting pirates.; Tampaofficials make the parade part of their pitch to the NFL for the Super Bowl.But after Tampa be award the 1991 Super Bowl, a racial dispute erupt overthe parade, which always have be sponsor and organize by an all-white,all-male private club, Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla.; The club's topofficials refuse the demands of a coalition of black residents, includingcarley, that the club be integrate immediately. Instead, they cancel theparade.; The Super Bowl Task Force have to scramble to put together a newparade, and Carley become the co-chairman of that effort.; SUPER BOWLXXVI; Super Bowl XXVI will be play Jan. 26, 1992, in the Metrodome. It willbe Minneapolis' first time as the host city. The last time the Super Bowl washeld in a cold-climate city be in 1982, when the 49ers beat the CincinnatiBengals 26-21 in Pontiac, Mich.
column5: Commentary on Super Bowl facts, events, and business issues--1989-1993.
column6: The San Francisco 49ers made it four in a row by winning Super Bowl XXIV. Super Bowl XXV will be held in Tampa Stadium and will feature local entertainment designed to resolve area racial disputes. For Super Bowl XXVII, the Rose Bowl is being offered rent free to the NFL.
column7: The San Francisco 49ers won the 1989 and 1990 Super Bowls, marking four out of four wins and setting several players' records. The 1990 Super Bowl was the lowest rated in 21 years, although the most watched TV event of the week.Super Bowl XXV, to be held in Tampa in 1991, will feature local events planned by a committee headed by two black men in order to resolve an area racial dispute. Only 80% of the face value of Super Bowl tickets can be deducted now. The Rose Bowl is being offered rent free to the NFL for Super Bowl XXVII.
column8: The San Francisco 49ers won the Super Bowl in 1989 and 1990 marking the fourth win in four tries. Super Bowl records were set by the 49ers quarterback Joe Montana and wide receiver Jerry Rice. President Bush congratulated the 1989 victors at an East Room reception.Super Bowl XXIV (1990) was the most watched TV event of the week although it was the lowest-rated Super Bowl in 21 years. Anheuser Busch Cos., Inc. and Miller Brewing Co., taking advantage of weeks of hype, staged mock football games in TV commercials using animated beer bottles.Super Bowl XXV will kickoff in Tampa Stadium in 1991. It will feature an extravaganza with marching bands, a street festival and floats. Two black men were named to head a community relations committee in order to resolve a local racial dispute. Several minority-owned business won lucrative contracts with the NFL.New tax lows place higher restrictions on what can be claimed as business-entertainment expense. For Super Bowl events, this means only 80% of the face value of tickets can be deducted. For Super Bowl XXVII in 1993, the Rose Bowl is being offered rent free to the NFL, along with all income from concessions and novelty sales.
column9: Communities Offer Incentives for Super Bowl; 49ers Dominate Decade
column10: The Super Bowl is big. The viewing audience is large, and Beer companies spend millions on game-related ads. Communities offer rent-free stadium use to lure the game. Tighter tax laws haven't diminished corporate attendance. In Tampa 1991, the black community shared in the profits.San Francisco has four Vince Lombardi Trophies.
column11: Super Bowl XXIV gave the 49ers their fourth Vince Lombardi Trophy. Sixty-three percent of TV viewers watched the lopsided game which also featured the conclusion of the "Bud Bowl II," a $7 million Anheuser Bush ad campaign. Though the game can spotlight a community's problems, it also has tremendous economic impact. Communities such as Los Angeles--Orange County, therefore, offer incentives, such as rent-free stadium use, to lure the game to their city. Even with tougher business entertainment tax laws, companies are well represented at the event.Traditionally, the winning Super Bowl team is invited to the White House.
column12: The winning Super Bowl team gets the Vince Lombardi Trophy and is usually invited to the White House. But The Super Bowl is more than a game, it is big business. Though tax laws governing business entertainment were tightened in 1987, corporate ticket purchases are still high. Approximately 100,000 people visit the host city for a week of pre-game festivities, generating approximately $200 million in revenues for the community. Bidding for the game is increasingly competitive. In 1990, for example, the Los Angeles Sports Council, hoping to lure the game to Pasadena, offered the Rose Bowl rent-free for Super Bowl XXVII. Television, of course, is part of the Super Bowl equation. Both Miller Brewing Co. and Anheuser Bush spent over $7million on ads that aired before and during Super Bowl XXIV. That game, unlike the previous Super Bowl that ended in a dramatic 20-16 San Francisco victory over Cincinnati, was a sleeper. San Francisco routed Denver 55-10 in the lowest rated Super Bowl since 1969.Frequently, the Super Bowl will highlight a community's problems. For example, a parade in conjunction with the 1991 Super Bowl in Tampa was cancelled after its sponsor, an all-white, all-male club, refused to integrate.

column3: Authorities charge a 22-year-old ferrycaptain with negligent homicide after the boat, overcrowd with NewYear's travelers, sink off the Caribbean coast. Sixty-seven peopledrowned and 14 be missing.Officials say 46 people survive the sinking of the ferry JustoRufino Barrios II in Amatique Bay on Guatemala's east coast Sunday.Juan Pablo Ezquibel be arrest after authorities determinedthat about 120 people be aboard the 30-ton ferry, which wasauthorized to carry 90, say Capt. Anibal Giron Arreola,second-in-command at the Puerto Barrios naval base.he say by telephone that the ferry run out of fuel midway on a16-mile run across the bay from Livingston to Puerto Barrios andsank after a naval patrol boat try to tow it to port.Officials have yet to determine the exact cause of the sinking,but Giron Arreola say the ferry captain be slow to respond torequests by the skipper of the naval patrol boat to take control ofthe ferry's wheel once it be under tow. He say the patrol boatcaptain believe the ferry's rudder be unman while under tow.esquibel radioed that he have take the wheel just as the boatbegan to capsize, Giron Arreola said.giron Arreola also say that passengers run to one side of theferry while it be under tow just before the ferry sank.it appear the boat ride a wave and that as it be lean thepeople run to one side out of fear, he said. Although seas wereonly 1-to-1{ feet, passengers be not use to travel by sea, hesaid.No Americans be on board, he said.a morgue official say 13 bodies be identified.navy patrol boats, fishing vessels and other private craftsearched for the miss Monday.Puerto Barrios, 187 miles northeast of Guatemala City, thecapital, be Guatemala's main east coast port. There be no roads tolivingston and most travel along the coast be by boat.the Rufino Barrios Maritime Transport firm own the ferry andoperates two other ferries along the Livingston-Puerto Barrios route.an overload ferry take schoolchildren on afield trip capsize and sink in southern China, kill 55 peopleand leave seven missing, the China News Service say in a dispatchseen Sunday.The 183 passengers and four crew members enormously exceededthe ferry's capacity and the ship capsize Wednesday before it hadsailed 200 yards, the report said. column9: Ferry capsizings from overloading, hitting reefs, high seas, etc., kill hundreds
column10: Overloaded ferries capsized and killed many in India, Bangladesh, and China in 1988, and in Guatemala in 1989. Ferries capsizing after striking reefs killed hundreds off Kenya and in the Red Sea in 1991. Other ferry capsizings killed many in India in 1970, twice in China in 1988, off Israel's coast in 1990, and off Kenya in 1991.
column11: In 1988, overloaded ferries capsized in India's Ganges River, killing 400; in Bangladesh's Meghna River, killing 100; off China's Hainan Island, killing 55 students and teachers, and in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, killing 61. An overloaded ferry capsized in Guatemala in 1989,  killing 67. In 1991, ferries capsized after striking reefs off Kenya, killing 180 Somali refugees, and in the Red Sea, killing 352. Other ferry capsizings killed 150 on India's Krishna River in 1970; 133 on China's Min River and 71 on the Yangtze in 1988; 19 sailors off Israel's coast in 1990;  and 11 refugees off Kenya in 1991.
column12: An overloaded ferry capsized in India's Ganges River in August 1988, killing 400, many women and children from the lower deck. In July 1970, 150 died when a boat capsized in the Krishna River. An overloaded ferry sank while turning at a Meghna River junction in Bangladesh in October 1988, killing 100, mostly in the hull. An overloaded ferry capsized and sank off China's Hainan Island in December 1988, killing 55 students and teachers. In September an overloaded ferry sank in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region killing 61. In July a capsized  ferry on the Min River killed 133 and a boat sinking on the Yangtze killed 71. In January 1989, an overloaded ferry sank off Guatemala's east coast, killing 67. It ran out of fuel and its wheel remained unattended while under tow. An Israeli ferry bringing sailors back to the USS Saratoga capsized in heavy seas in December 1990. Nineteen drowned. A ferry carrying 600 Somali refugees sank off Kenya in March 1991 after striking a reef.  180 drowned, mostly from the lower deck. Eleven refugees drowned when a boat capsized in February 1991.An Egyptian ferry returning from Saudi Arabia sank in December 1991 after leaving the channel and hitting a reef. 352 were missing.
column13: Ferry accidents in third world, mainly caused by overcrowding.
column14: Overloading is a major contributor to ferry and passenger boat accidents, particularly in the third world.  Many ferry accidents occurred when the boats were carrying far more passengers than authorized.  Even advanced countries have ferry accidents.  Nineteen U.S. sailors were lost in an Israeli ferry accident.
column15: Overloading is a major contributor to ferry and passenger boat accidents, particularly in the third world.  Ferries in India, Guatemala, Egypt, China and Bangladesh all carried for more passengers than authorized, when they sank.  Many deaths more passenger occur to those below decks than to those above. Captain error also contributed to accidents.  Other accidents have involved poor weather and in one case in Bangladesh, river pirates.  But even advanced countries have ferry accidents.  Nineteen U.S. sailors died when an Israeli ferry sank while returning the sailors to the USS Saratoga.  No cause for the accident was reported.
column16: Overloading is a major contributor to ferry and passenger boat accidents, particularly in the third world.  Ferries in India, Guatemala, Egypt, China and Bangladesh all carried far more passengers than authorized when they sank.  Captain error also contributed to accidents.  In Guatemala, a ferry captain was charges with negligent homicide when his boat which was being towed, sank after he failed to steer it.   A ferry sank off the Egyptian coast after inexplicably leaving standard navigational channels and ramming a coral reef in stormy seas.  In that accident, survivors claimed that crewmembers abandoned ship without helping them.  The ship's engineer denied the charges.  Two boats carrying Somali refugees sank off the coast of Kenya, resulting in more than 140 deaths, although the cause of the sinking was not reported. An overcrowded ferry in Bangladesh sank with almost double the passengers it was authorized.  In a separate ferry incident in Bangladesh, pirates robbed passengers and threw six overboard. In the Indian accident, monsoon rains may have contributed as well as overcrowding.  Even an advanced country such as Israel can experience ferry accidents.  Nineteen U.S. sailors died when an Israeli ferry sank while returning the sailors to the USS Saratoga.  No cause was reported.

column3: John Lennon's worldwide message of peace wasdelivered Tuesday as his song Imagine be play simultaneouslyfor 1 billion people in 130 countries to celebrate what would havebeen his 50th birthday.a dream we dream alone be only a dream, but the dream we dreamtogether be reality. happy birthday, John. The world be bettertoday for share a time with you, Yoko Ono say at a UnitedNations ceremony before the playing of Imagine.The slain former Beatle himself issue a call for harmony in ataped message that serve as an introduction to the music.we all want peace, whatever sort of job we have. ... think ofyour children. do you want them to be kill or don't you? Andthat's the choice we have in front of us. War or peace, saidlennon, whose son Sean turn 15 tuesday.none of the other Beatles be at the United Nations, but atribute come from Lennon's old songwriting partner, Paul McCartney,who release a live version of the Beatles' tune Birthday. Thesong, originally on the White Album, be the firstlennon-mccartney single release since the Beatles break up in1969.the release date and John's birthday be just a happycoincidence, but it's also a nod and a wink to my old mate, saidmccartney, 47.Other observances be hold from Liverpool to Moscow to LosAngeles.In Lennon's hometown in England, fans gather at the formersite of the Cavern Club, where the Beatles be discovered.among those attend be Lennon's 71-year-old uncle, CharlieLennon.When ask how his nephew would have react to the ceremonies,he said: If he have be alive I doubt he would have come and evenif he had, he would sit with me in the pub and have a good laugh.on the West Coast, about 50 people - part of an estimated 1billion people worldwide who have access to the event - stood nearlennon's star on the Walk of Fame and listen to the Imaginebroadcast:Imagine all the people, live life in peaceyou may say I'm a dreamer, but I'm not the only onei hope some day you'll join usAnd the world will live as one.his spirit still live in all of us whose lives have beentouched with him, Ono say of her late husband.i would like us to remember and celebrate his birthday as aday of love, because he be a man of love, and because love be muchneeded at this time in our lives.ono be greet by Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the U.N.secretary-general. During her brief remarks, Ono also quote a linefrom another of Lennon's songs, Happy Xmas (War be Over):Remember, war be over if you want it.more than 1,000 radio stations and networks from 50 countriesbroadcast the 10-minute event. U.S. Armed Forces television andradio beam it to 80-plus other countries. MTV televise theimagine video in 25 countries, say Andrea Smith, a spokeswomanfor the network.in Moscow, about 1,000 Soviets gather at the Moscow ElectricalLamp Factory's cultural hall to listen to Lennon's music, snap uphis albums and posters and reflect on his life.even the staid state television program Vremya get into theact. An anchorman, reporting on the worldwide birthday bash,described Imagine as an anthem of peace. The broadcastended with an instrumental version of Yesterday.Not so long ago, the Beatles' music be ban in the SovietUnion. In 1964, one commentator warn that these bugs canswiftly ignite the very dark and primitive passions.lennon be shoot to death by a deranged fan outside his Manhattanapartment building on Dec. 8, 1980.On the spot where Lenin once spoke, the focustuesday be on Lennon.Official newspapers, which once denounce the Beatles as harmfulpests from the decadent West, join a worldwide celebration andran stories of tribute about the late John Lennon, who would haveturned 50 on Tuesday. State radio broadcast his music andinterviews about him.two concerts devote to the songwriter, guitarist and singer,who be shoot to death in 1980, be hold in Moscow.Even the staid state television program Vremya get into act.an anchorman, more accustomed to read official government news,reported on the worldwide Lennon birthday bash and call his songimagine, an anthem of peace. The broadcast end with aninstrumental version of yesterday playing as temperatures fromaround the nation roll across the screen.the celebration be a dramatic turnabout from Sovietauthorities' repression of Beatles fans and supression of theirmusic in early times. Their music be ban and the Soviet presscondemned them. A 1964 article, for instance, commented, Thesebugs can swiftly ignite the very dark and primitive passions.about 1,000 Soviets, mostly second generation Beatles fans,flocked to the Moscow Electrical Lamp Factory's cultural hall innortheastern part of the city to rejoice in Lennon's music. Aplaque outside the hall remind Beatles fans that Lennon's nearnamesake, Vladimir Lenin, the founder of the Soviet state, hadspoken at the spot in 1917 and 1919.Inside, fans listen to recordings of Lennon's music, attendeda concert of about a dozen soviet rock bands, buy his albums andposters and reflect on his life.he's like a hero, a symbol for every person: a symbol ofhonesty, talent, devotion to his ideals, notion of love, equalitybetween people and goodness, say Irina Dykomkina, the21-year-old secretary of the Sgt. Pepper's Club, a soviet Beatlesfan club form two years ago.lennon's music, she said, crosses borders easily.his music be so sincere, it's so understandable, even topeople who don't know English. They feel the music.andrei Trushkin, a correspondent for Komsomolskaya Pravda - thecommunist Party youth newspaper that devote a full page Tuesday toLennon - say he appeals to soviet youth in part because he be arebel, like many of them, and be a difficult teen-ager.the cops would have lock him up many times, say Trushkin,who help organize the concert.tuesday's concert open in the spirit of a birthday party.Balloons float down from the balconies as a tape of Lennon'ssong, Starting Over, played. The stage be adorn with apainting of Lennon and life-size cardboard cutouts of the Fab Fourin front of the british flag.oorah! Oorah! shout the audience, which include a fewsoldiers in uniform. Onstage, the groups Sprint, Quiet Hour andoptimal Variant play in Beatles style but be join by a groupthat didn't quite fit in the genre, an american-style countryensemble that wear plaid vests and perform Night Train tomemphis.when celebrity biographer Albert Goldman begandigging into The Lives of John Lennon, his first move be tomail a long, reverential request for help to yoko Ono.She be Numero Uno, you've get to start with her. I send her asincere letter, because at that time I be a true believer inrock's great love story. ... I tell her, `i'm in your corner,'goldman recalled.ono never responded. And after 1,200 interviews and 6{ years,the dream be over for Goldman, his mythic view of Lennon the greataltered.expecting the best, Goldman claim to have uncover the worst:a volatile, debauch Lennon who evolve into the Howard Hughes ofrock 'n' roll, tuck in his Dakota bed for days at a time.That vision of the ex-beatle have infuriate Lennon supporters,family and friends and prompt charges of fiction writing; it alsotaught Goldman who say he be a John Lennon fan a hard lesson.it doesn't pay to meet your idols. Just enjoy them; don't tryto see the reality, Goldman said. My books be a cold dose ofreality. You get in the Beatle shower, and suddenly the water goescold.goldman, whose past tell-all biographies deal with ElvisPresley and Lenny Bruce, remain unmoved by the hue and cry fromthe music industry, from Ono and from Lennon's Beatle buddy, PaulMcCartney.My books be bad for business, Goldman say in a phoneinterview from Munich, West Germany. They're bad for Paul'sbusiness, bad for Yoko's business, back for the jive myth of rockbusiness. Those people have to hate me.myth-shattering be a not a bad thing, Goldman said. For example,he cites Lennon's disillusion meeting with Presley at Gracelandin 1965.John be very hooked into Elvis. Elvis be his measure ofsuccess, say Goldman. And the myth of Elvis: awesome. But thereality of Elvis: a mess.goldman also reject the complaint raise by Ono, McCartney,Julian Lennon and others that Lennon be an easy target to defamebecause he's no longer around to answer the allegations.you can't say John lacks for defenders. And Yoko isn't dead.colonel Parker (Presley's manager) isn't dead. ninety-five percentof the people in my books aren't dead. They can do something aboutit, say Goldman, his voice quickening.this business of make it easy for defend myself isinsane. I'm the target of scores of attacks. I can't imagine aharder thing for an author.those attacks don't really bother him, unless they come fromsomeone who hasn't read The Lives of John Lennon, Goldman said.a lot of people already make up their minds. They hear AlbertGoldman, John Lennon, homosexuality bang, let him have it! Iresent people comment on a book they haven't read, includingYoko, the author said.ono's reaction come on a nationally broadcast response to thebook. She label Goldman's version of life with the Lennonstotally fiction and bring out Lennon's sons, julian and12-year-old Sean, to refute the biography.these giant promotions of Yoko be present as honestdocumentaries, when they're in-house documentaries, say Goldman,who compliment Ono on a well-prepared show. She take nochances. This be another no-chance yoko.as for the sensational charges of bisexuality, drug abuse byyoko and John, wild drink binges, anorexia and reclusiveness,goldman say it all fit together with the image of lennonpresented by those who know him.my thesis be John Lennon be a divided mind. He spend so much time with me not just athome, but everywhere, you know.say what you want about Albert Goldman, the author of the new biography, "The Lives of John Lennon" (Morrow, $22.95), but you've get to hand it to him: This guy be one ambitious sleazemonger. most best-selling pop biographers play it safe: They choose a celeb of respectable, not to say pristine, reputation, and then they proceed to blacken it, preferably by recount vaguely sourced tales of sexual excess, chemical dependency, personal unkindness, raw business dealings, even, in some cases, dyslexia. The result portrait of a dissipated ogre who can't spell be duly present in hardback form to the public, which in turn be so shocked and disgust that it force itself to buy the biography by the millions. A can't-miss formula, surely. Albert Goldman's previous victim in the genre be Elvis Presley. now Mr. Presley was, if you'll forgive the expression, a fat target for a writer of Mr. Goldman's methods. His title notwithstanding, the "king of Rock 'n' Roll" be in truth more a creature of the old show biz, a star whose wholesome image, carefully create by P.R. wizards, be ripe for debunking. But in choose Mr. Lennon as his next target, Mr. Goldman appear to be try to debunk the undebunkable. For apart from his puerile politics, Mr. Lennon's favorite topic in the thousands of interviews he give be his own squalid history: His voracious drug use, his perfidy to employees, his unquenchable sexual promiscuity and so on. By his own accounting, then, Mr. Lennon be not about to dethrone Ward Cleaver as the all-american dad. His public love him in spite of it all -- or perhaps because of it all. Mr. Lennon grow to celebrity during a time when such transgressions as intemperance and adultery (quaint terms!) be lose their social sting. His candor -- if that's what it was, and not simple logorrhea -- redeem everything. And so it be on the grounds of insufficient candor that the resourceful Mr. Goldman, hot to debunk, attacks his subject. The leitmotif of Mr. Lennon's confessions be that his bad days be behind him, and that with Yoko Ono he have at last learn to prize the virtues of quietude and domesticity. now Mr. Goldman be here to announce: He didn't tell you the half of it. Hence this 718-page stew of unrelieved sordidness, percolate with the "scoops" that have by now be widely publicize in People magazine, "west 57th" and other scholarly venues: that Mr. Lennon have a thing for young boys; that his marriage to Ms. Ono be pock by the same faithlessness and rancor that characterize his first marriage; that he have a sweet tooth that just wouldn't quit. The squalid revelations dribble out like a chemical leak, slim up every page. Remarkably, then, the sleazemonger's art have triumphed: Mr. Goldman's John Lennon be even bad than John Lennon's John Lennon. A great deal of this muck manage to splash onto Ms. Ono, whom Mr. Goldman portray as a cynical manipulator whose major talent lay in exploit Mr. Lennon to further her own craving for fame and wealth. Mr. Goldman, alas, allow to pass unremarked the obvious irony that this be a rather fine thumbnail sketch of himself as well. The keepers of the Lennon flame have of course be quick to point this out. Ms. Ono and her son have take the path prefer by offend celebrities, they have hit the talk show to display their wounds. And Rolling Stone magazine, long the house organ for the Lennon publicity machine, recently publish an extensive rebuttal to the book, which be undercut by a tone of priggish indignation border on the comic. criticize "the Lives of John Lennon" for insufficient respect to the fall Beatle's legacy be rather off the point -- like condemn Charles Manson for his bad table manners. The book may indeed be inaccurate, as critics have charged. But one can only hope that quibbles about its veracity do not obscure the countless other reasons to hate Mr. Goldman's book. There is, for starters, the sloppy, pompous prose, so suggestive of the grad-school smoking lounge -- Mr. Goldman be the sort of writer who refer to pop songs as "pieces," as though they be concerti. There be his knowing, hipper-than-thou approach -- toward drugs, sex, music -- that give him license to second-guess Mr. Lennon's every move. And there be the awkward organization, in which minor events assume large proportions for the simple reason that they reflect badly on Mr. Lennon, while major events be skip over lightly because -- there go the advance! -- they might reveal Mr. Lennon in a flattering light. All of which indicate why "the Lives of John Lennon" be such a wretched book: not because it make a good man look bad, but because it show no other purpose than to make a man -- whether a good man or a bad one, we laymen will probably never know -- look bad. John Lennon, while he be alive, do enough of that himself to satisfy all but the low appetites. ---mr.
