column5: Ex-Beatle John Lennon remembered by fans for music, promoting peace
column6: John Lennon, the late, ex-Beatle, is remembered by fans worldwide for hismusic and commitment to world peace.  He was murdered in 1980 in New York.His widow, Yoko Ono, keeps his memory alive by marketing Lennon's music andmemorabilia, which some critics believe is crass commercialization.
column7: John Lennon was celebrated in life and death for his music and commitment toworld peace.  He had detractors, namely a celebrity biographer in The Livesof John Lennon.  His widow, Yoko Ono, former wife, and sons refuted thealleged misdeeds contained in that book.  On the 50th anniversary of hisbirth, his song "Imagine" was broadcast worldwide to an audience of onebillion people.  On the tenth anniversary of his murder, admirers gatheredin Liverpool and other locations around the world to pay homage.  Ono haskept his memory alive but many believe she does so for mercenary reasons.
column8: The late, ex-Beatle John Lennon who was murdered in New York in 1980, hadthousands of fans worldwide that loved his music and admired him for hischaritable work and efforts to promote peace. Lennon had conceded problemswith drugs and other misdeeds in earlier years but in The Lives of JohnLennon, celebrity biographer Albert Goldman alleges that Lennon remained adrug user, was bisexual, reclusive, anorexic, and had wild drinking binges.Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, his first wife, Cynthia, and his sons refute thoseallegations and, at least one reviewer trashed the book.Lennon was pretty much out of sight for nearly five years prior to thesummer of 1980 when he returned to the studio and recorded two albums.Musicians said that he never sang better.  On what would have been the 50thanniversary of his birth, and after a brief ceremony at the United Nations,Lennon's song "Imagine" was broadcast for an estimated one billion peopleworldwide.  On the tenth anniversary of his death, observances were held inLiverpool, Moscow, Los Angeles, and New York.Ono has kept Lennon "alive" through a movie, radio, and albums.  However,she is accused of shamelessly exploiting Lennon's memory for personalfinancial gain.
column9: John Lennon's spirit alive worldwide 10 years after his death.
column10: John Lennon's spirit is still alive to adoring fans worldwide ten years after his death.  His 50th birthday was observed with a global celebration of his peace anthem "Imagine".  Lennon acknowledged drug use and sexual promiscuity, but said the worst was behind him.  Lennon was killed by a deranged fan in December 1980.
column11: John Lennon's spirit is still very much alive to adoring fans worldwide ten years after his death.  His 50th birthday was observed with a global celebration of his peace anthem "Imagine" which was played for an estimated 1 billion people in 130 countries.  The song was played following a brief ceremony at the United Nations.  One biographer described Lennon as an anorexic bisexual addled by drugs who raged his way from Liverpool to New York   Family and friends have denounced the book.  Lennon was ginned down outside his Manhattan apartment in December 1980 by a deranged fan at the age of 40.
column12: John Lennon spirit is still very much alive to adoring fans worldwide ten years after his death.  His 50th birthday was observed with a global celebration of his peace anthem "Imagine" which was played for an estimated 1 billion people in 130 countries.  The song was played following a brief ceremony at the United Nations.  Fans also gathered in Liverpool, Moscow, Los Angles and New York to pay tribute to the former Beatle. One biographer described Lennon as an anorexic bisexual addled by drugs who raged his way from Liverpool to New York, but friends and family denounced that version of Lennon's life.  Lennon himself acknowledged his drug use and sexual promiscuity, although he claimed that his worst days were behind him.   His wife, Yoko Ono admitted using heroin for a time.  He had also been portrayed as a dour, shoeless youth with an unfit mother, a description refuted by his half-sister in her book.   Since his death, his wife has kept his legacy alive, issuing new albums of his work and selling memorabilia, featuring his image.  Lennon was gunned down by a deranged fan outside his Manhattan apartment December 8, 1980 at the age of 40.

column3: While Hurricane Hugo's 135 mph windroared outside, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. watch the fury it ventedon his beloved, 300-year-old city.riley, city officials and a few reporters stay in Charleston'shistoric City Hall through Thursday night as the area's worsthurricane in three decades pound the coastal city where the CivilWar began.late in the day, there be hope Hugo might spare Charleston. Butthe storm gather strength and speed as it spin straight towardthis city, which have survive a number of near misses from greatstorms in recent years.From the moment it become apparent Hugo might strike thesoutheast coast, many Charlestonians concede that, this time, theirnumber be up.as Hugo's wind howl outside the plywood boards protect thewindows, reporters wander in and out of Riley's office. On hisdesk several candles burn as insurance against the inevitable lossof power.later there be a sharp crack as a piece of the tin roof rippedoff and water seep down on the burnish wood tables in the CityCouncil chamber. Phone and electric service to the city command postwas knock out.during it all, Riley kept in close contact with the NationalWeather Service. As the eye of the storm passed, he take reportersonto the porch of the 188-year-old brick City Hall to look at thedamage.the initial view, sketch out in the glow of flashlights, wasunsettling: The tin roof be toss in the gutter, slate tiles werescattered on the ground. Bricks, sticks and leaves litter thestreet.this be the eye of the hurricane. I've never be in one and Ihope I'm never in one again, Riley said. It's scarcely a latesummer breeze.As the storm die before dawn, Riley be out on the streets againin a raincoat carry a flashlight to get a good assessment ofthe damage.serious but fixable, the mayor concluded.damage from Hurricane Hugo, which storm through the Carolinas and the Caribbean last week, will reduce third-quarter earnings for several insurers. New york-based American International Group Inc. expect net losses relate to Hugo to reduce pretax earnings between $35 million and $45 million. Analysts say AIG have tell them that it must cover the first $35 million of losses and that its reinsurance agreements will cover the bulk of the remain damages. AIG insure property in Puerto Rico, the eastern Caribbean Islands and the coastal regions of the Carolinas. St. Paul Cos., base in St. Paul, Minn, say the pretax cost of Hugo shouldn't exceed $50 million. That amount take into consideration what St. Paul expect to recover under its reinsurance contracts, the company said. philadelphia-based Cigna Corp. be expect to disclose Hugo's likely impact on its earnings sometime today. Udayan Ghose, an insurance industry analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, estimate that Cigna's third-quarter per-share earnings could be reduce by between 50 cents and 65 cents a share on an after-tax basis. That would wipe out 35% to 40% of his $1.40-a-share earnings estimate for the third quarter. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. say its State Fire & Casualty Co. unit estimate claim payments from Hugo will exceed $400 million in South Carolina alone, far surpass the company's record payout for a single disaster. When damages in North Carolina and Virginia be added, the company said, the payments will exceed $500 million. It say that be more than three times the previous record of $165 million set by Hurricane Alicia, which hit the Houston-Galveston, Texas, area in 1983.Supercomputers, satellites and the expertise ofseveral hurricane forecasters predict the destructive pathhurricane Hugo would follow, give people plenty of time to fleethe South Carolina coast.but hurricane track remain an uncertain science.Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center use computer modelsto track Hugo's path into Charleston, S.C.All the world's knowledge about meteorological conditions andforecasting changes in those conditions be embody in thosemodels, say Thomas Pyke, head of National Oceanic and AtmosphericAdministration's satellite service.pinpointing the exact point of Hugo's landfall be difficult, butforecasters say Friday that the landfall be predict in time forevacuation.overall, I think the tracking models give us a very good ideawhere Hugo would be so officials in South Carolina could act in atimely manner, say research meteorologist Colin McAdie.The real forecasting problem with Hugo be predict theintensity of the storm, which be upgrade to a Category 4 hurricanejust hours before it slam into Charleston.It be very difficult to predict changes in intensity because wedon't have very reliable computer models for that, McAdie said.we really need to improve on our forecast ability of strength.the hurricane specialists be surprise by the last-minuteincrease in wind speed, which be report to them by Air Forcereconnaissance.Hurricane specialist Gil Clark, who have track hurricanes for 35years, say that a couple of decades ago, the only forecasting toolswere reports from aircraft or ships.we have no radar or satellites then, so needless to say ourforecasts be less accurate, Clark said.in the late 1960s, the weather service begin use satellites toobtain a global weather picture. information from the satellite isused to improve the accuracy of the large-scale models thattelevision viewers see every night.using the information from the satellite, supercomputers at thenational Meteorological Center in Suitland, Md., send information tothe hurricane center where a track model constantly change toaccount for current weather conditions and the position of thehurricane.to determine the track of the storm, the forecasters analyzesupercomputer predictions, satellite data, the history of similarstorms and the current path of the hurricane.then they make an educated guess about the landfall.meteorology professor Kerry A. Emmanuel of the MassachussettsInstitute of Technology criticize the current forecasting system.congress and the american people be suffer from thecollective delusion that our data problems have be solve bysatellites and that just isn't true, Emmanuel said.Satellites can give a pretty picture, he said, but not enoughinformation about the wind and temperatures that affect ahurricane's path.most of the information actually use to predict hurricanescomes from fly airplanes into the hurricane, and they do a verygood job, Emmanuel said.Forecasters say the accuracy of satellite pictures be improvingevery year so long-range forecasting should become more precise.We have to remember that those models use be only guidanceproducts, Pyke said, and that it's ultimately the job of theforecaster to predict the storm's path.Residents take forecasters at their wordwhen they warn of Hurricane Hugo's fury, and the low number ofdeaths from the powerful storm can be credit to this healthyrespect, authorities said.the storm, which cause billions in damage, claim 17 lives insouth Carolina, and only two be in the Charleston area, whichbore the brunt of Hugo's 135 mph winds.we just feel very thankful about that, say Mayor Joseph P.Riley Jr. Several thousands of people who be in the sheltersand the tens of thousands of people who evacuate inland werepotential victims of injury and death.riley and other officials credit residents with monitor thehurricane as it spin toward Charleston, and heed evacuationwarnings.the last big storm to hit South Carolina be Hurricane David in1979, which hit the coast after pound southern Florida.Since then several big storms have threaten but veered away,and officials be worried that Charlestonians wouldn't heed Hugo'swarnings.We've have so many close calls, say Gary Garnet, ameteorologist with the National Weather Service.But this storm be very, very strong, he said. This timethey realize it.glen Ellis, a Red Cross official, estimate that 18,000residents in Charleston and the three surround counties headedfor shelters.Tens of thousands more get into their cars and head upinterstate 26 toward Columbia.Mayor John Bourne of North Charleston, where there apparentlywere no storm-related deaths, credit people for heed thewarnings.it be bad, but it could have be a lot worse, he said.you've just get to say nice things about the people.meanwhile, Garnet have some good news for storm-wearycharlestonians: late Saturday the tropics be quiet with no otherstorms brewing.there's nothing to worry about out there, he said.hurricane Hugo strike South Carolina withrenewed fury Thursday after thousands of coastal residents insoutheastern states grab what they could carry and fled inland onjammed highways.this be a disaster star us right in the eye, Mayor JosephP. Riley Jr. say from his City Hall command post in Charleston,where the hurricane down power lines, snap trees and causedutility transformers to explode.all we can do now be pray and hope all the precautions we havetaken have be sufficient, Riley say as Hugo's eye bore in onthe city. I just hope and pray we can get through this without anyloss of life.by midnight, 119 mph winds be report in Charleston. The roofcracked at City Hall, a 188-year-old brick building that haswithstood several hurricanes, and torrents of water pour into thepaneled council chamber. Phone and electric service to the commandpost be knock out.hurricane-force winds first hit the coast by 9:15 p.m. EDT, andabout three hours later the eye of the storm pass over the Isle ofpalms just east of Charleston, say Bob Sheets, director of thenational Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla.The eye be about 10 miles across and top winds be still at 135mph.Hugo be expect to turn gradually to the north, cause severeflooding as it move up the East Coast. The storm pose a 19 percentchance of hit New York City and a 16 percent chance of hittingboston before Sunday night, the hurricane center said.as Hugo near the coast, roads from Hilton Head to Myrtle Beach,200 miles north, be nearly empty, as be the boarded-up resorttowns themselves. Power lines and trees be down in some spotsand water flood roads. Stop lights and neon lights be knockedout in Myrtle Beach.One eyewitness say `It's like a light show,' say AmyGarrison, a reporter at WKZQ AM-FM in Myrtle Beach.In Charleston, the hurricane litter streets with tin roofs,palmetto fronds and chunks of bark. Businesses be closed andclasses at public schools and universities canceled. Riley orderedresidents of one-story homes to evacuate.Hospitals stockpile supplies, discharge any patients wellenough to go and move others to hospitals inland to make room foremergency patients, officials said.about 12,000 people have check into 83 shelters across the stateas of Thursday evening, and more be expected, say bennish Brown,a spokesman for the Emergency Operations Center in Columbia, 220miles northwest of here.we try to close the doors but people be sneak in sidedoors, say Elaine Skelton, a registered nurse work at theconway high School shelter near Myrtle Beach. We try to postguards at the doors, but people be still come in.american Red Cross relief efforts be buckle under the numberof evacuees, say Brian Ruberry, a spokesman in Savannah, Ga., whoappealed for help.right now the Red Cross be shelter tens of thousands ofpeople all along the Eastern seaboard. This of course be at the sametime that we're shelter 25,000 people on Puerto Rico and theother Caribbean islands.we're begin to feel the squeeze. Our resources be verytight. Right now Hugo be shape up to be one of our big reliefoperations of the decade.at midnight, the center of Hugo be near latitude 32.7 degreesnorth and longitude 79.9 degrees west, forecasters said. Thehurricane's speed have pick up to 22 mph from 20 mph earlier.near its center, Hugo's muscle reach winds of 135 mph, up from125 mph earlier in the day and 105 mph the day before. North andSouth Carolina can expect tornadoes link to Hugo for the next twodays, accord to the hurricane center.the coastal area could expect hurricane force winds for 10 to 12hours once the eye come ashore, officials said. A hurricane warningwas in effect between Fernandina Beach, Fla., and Oregon Inlet, N.C.By late afternoon, Hugo be upgrade to a category 4 hurricane onthe Saffir-Simpson scale of strength, the second mightiest category,which indicate it could cause extreme damage.it strengthen more than we think it would, Sheets said,adding that Hugo would cause severe flooding as it move up theappalachians.the timing of the landfall be critical because of the storm'stidal surge, a dome of water 10 to 15 feet high that would fee anormal 5-foot high tide that peaks after 2 a.m.on top of that will be waves, Sheets say earlier, and inmany places on barrier islands the buildings will be swept cleanoff.it's take the devastation cause byhurricane Hugo to stimulate repayment of a 211-year-old debtbetween two cities almost 1,000 miles apart.as a way of repay a kindness date to 1778, Kingston israising money to help Charleston, S.C., recover.after Kingston, then New York's capital, be burn in October1777 by the British, New York Gov. George Clinton receive a letterfrom South Carolina Gov. Abraham Livingston. The letter includednearly 1,000 New York pound to help Kingston residents get throughtheir crisis.this money have be receive for the charitable purpose ofalleviating the distresses of the now-indigent inhabitants of thetown of Kingston, who by the ravages of the enemy be reduce topoverty and want, Livingston write on March 31, 1778.Kingston historian Edwin Ford remember the letter whenhurricane Hugo ravage the Carolinas last week. I figure theyhelped us, we should do something for them, Ford said.on Wednesday, a local Red Cross chapter begin collectingdonations for victims of the hurricane.a lot of people have be calling, ask to send donationsdown there, say Susan Lawlor, executive director of the UlsterCounty Chapter of the Red Cross.On Tuesday, New York state send two airplanes full of food,clothing and water to parts of the Caribbean ravage by Hugo. A NewYork National Guard C-5A cargo plane also leave Tuesday to pick upequipment in Mississippi and take it to Puerto Rico.Another cargo plane be schedule to leave Stewart Air ForceBase in Newburgh, take 70 tons of food, water and other suppliesto Puerto Rico.This historic city have survive theravages of earthquake, battle and storm in its storied300-year-history, but it face perhaps its great test of all inhurricane Hugo.The storm, pack winds of up to 135 mph, rag into CharlestonThursday night.This be a dangerous, killer hurricane, the likes of which fewpeople who have live all their lives in Charleston haveexperienced, warn Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr.Hugo be the first major hurricane to strike Charleston sincehurricane Gracie come ashore 70 miles to the south in 1959.The seaside community have suffer through many disasters, bothnatural and man-made.the worst in recent decades be in 1938 when a tornado torethrough the city, kill 32 people, injure hundreds and causingan estimate $2 million in property damage.charleston, a city of pastel-colored antebellum structures liningquaint streets and alleyways, be where the Civil War begin in 1861.The city have survive the shot and shell of two wars and anynumber of small hurricanes, politely refer to by Charlestoniansof refinement as September gales.but the bad natural disaster to beset the city occur on thehot night of Aug. 31, 1886, when the ground rumble in what somefolks think be a prelude to Judgement Day.The great Charleston earthquake be felt as far away as Chicagoand New York City.Measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion, theearthquake claim an estimate 110 lives, destroy 102 buildingsand toss most of the city's 14,000 chimney into the streets.in recent years, the city have attract millions of visitorsannually who tour its historic buildings and visit its nearby finesand beaches.charleston have receive international acclaim as home to SpoletoFestival U.S.A., found by composer Gian Carlo Menotti. Organizerslike to refer to Spoleto as the world's most comprehensive artsfestival.hurricane Hugo will go down in the record books as the costly storm insurers have face so far, but it won't cause property-casualty premium rates to rise immediately, analysts and company officials say. The property claims service division of the American Insurance Service Group, a trade association, be expect to announce its estimate of total insured losses tomorrow. "Hugo will be the big hurricane loss on record," say one official, far surpass the $752.5 million insurers pay out after Frederick rip through several Gulf Coast states in 1979. The impact on premium rates could be minimal for now, analysts expect, because the big losses will be in the personal insurance area -- for homes and autos. Most companies typically set aside funds from premiums they collect every year to cover claims they might have to pay in the future. In the last three years, hurricane and storm seasons have be relatively mild, so insurers haven't have to dip into these funds. And since Hugo also storm through the Caribbean, foreign insurers be at risk for some of the damage on those islands. Yet, some analysts believe Hugo's huge losses will make a dent in the industry's capital and crimp cash flow; that could make insurers less likely to slash premium rates further in come months. Rates have be fall since late 1986. Udayan Ghose at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. believe these reasons might cause rates to edge high by mid-1990. For the time being, the losses from Hugo "will be substantial, but they won't be something the industry can't handle," say Charles L. Ruoff, director of strategic planning at Fred S. James & Co., a New york-based insurance broker. For instance, State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. estimate it will pay claims total more than $400 million to homeowners and for some small businesses. nationwide Insurance Co., a mutual company base in Columbus, Ohio, say Hugo "is the single large claims disaster" it have see in its 63-year history. The company, which be the large home and auto insurer in North Carolina and no. 3 in South Carolina, have already receive 16,000 claims from the stricken region. Claims could total $100 million, a spokesman said. For some insurers, Hugo be a double-whammy. New york-based Continental Corp., which be a big insurer in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and South Carolinas, say it will take a $50 million pretax charge against earnings this quarter, reflect its net exposure to the damages cause by the hurricane. "hugo will be particularly costly to us," say John P. Mascotte, Continental's chairman. philadelphia-based Cigna Corp., which have extensive domestic, foreign and reinsurance operations in the areas Hugo hit, and USF&G Corp. in Baltimore, a big insurer in the Carolina region, could also be force to take one-time charges against third-quarter earnings, analysts said. Some of USF&G's losses hit very close home -- its Charleston office be destroy by the hurricane. Both USF&G and Cigna decline to predict whether they would take a charge; USF&G say it would be responsible for the first $22.5 million of losses, and its reinsurance would cover the bulk of additional losses. Hugo could have a marginal impact on third-quarter income at Travelers Corp., Aetna Life & Casualty Insurance Co. and Chubb Corp., accord to industry analysts. Mr. Ruoff at Fred S. James believe that even if losses from Hugo total as much as $5 billion, insurers won't feel enough "financial pain, such as not be able to pay shareholder dividends," to compel them to boost premium rates right away. He explain that in the first six months of this year, net income for the industry decline slightly from 1988, but insurance companies be still earn an adequate rate of return on equity. He also note that the industry's aggregate net worth or policyholders' surplus, currently at $125 billion, be also plentiful. Generally, insurers can book about $3 of premiums for every $1 of surplus. Right now, premiums total about $200 billion, he said. An official at Nationwide Insurance note that the company have $1 of surplus for every $2 of insurance that it writes. Insurers also buy protection for themselves through reinsurance by pay another company a portion of the premium to bear some of the losses. Michael Lewis at Dean Witter Reynolds say losses from Hugo could be big enough to "temporarily" increase reinsurance rates. Although reinsurance will limit the exposure of some companies, the losses they must still cover could hurt third-quarter results. Niagara Exchange Corp., base in Buffalo, N.Y., say Monday it will report a loss from operations for the third quarter, and possibly for the year, because of the substantial losses that its Charleston Insurance Co. unit face as a result of the hurricane. State Farm, the nation's large home insurer, doesn't buy reinsurance. It believe its reserves be plentiful enough to absorb its losses, a spokesman said.
column5: South Carolina Coast Evacuation Before "Killer Storm" Hugo Saves Lives
column6: The insurance industry expects Hugo, the Category 4 hurricane that struck the Carolinas and the Caribbean last week, to be the costliest storm ever. Most companies, however, can cover the losses. Because South Carolina residents heeded evacuation warnings from the Hurricane Center, Hugo claimed only 17 lives in the state.
column7: The two largest property insurance companies in the Carolinas, State Farm and Nationwide, estimate Hurricane Hugo losses at $600 million, making it the costliest hurricane ever.Hugo, a Category 4 storm dubbed a "killer hurricane" by Charleston's mayor, struck the city Thursday night. Though there was significant damage, only two were killed in Charleston, 17 total in South Carolina. Officials credit the low number of fatalities to residents who heeded Hurricane Center warnings and evacuated before the storm's arrival.Kingston, New York, assisted by Charleston during the Revolutionary War, is repaying the kindness by sending money to help the city recover.
column8: American Insurance Service Group says Hurricane Hugo, which ravaged the Caribbean and the Carolinas last week, is responsible for record hurricane losses. State Farm Insurance expects claims of approximately $500 million in the Carolinas. Nationwide Insurance is projecting claims near $100 million. Though the Hugo-related losses are substantial, most companies have sufficient funds to cover them. Some companies, however, will reduce third-quarter earnings.Hugo slammed into Charleston Thursday night with top winds of 135 mph. Upgraded to a Category 4 hurricane hours before it struck the historic city, it caused widespread damage throughout the Carolinas. Only two lives were lost in Charleston, however, and only 17 total in South Carolina. Officials credit the low number of fatalities to residents who monitored the hurricane and evacuated.  Computer models at the National Hurricane Center used satellite information to track Hugo's path into Charleston. Before the storm's arrival in South Carolina, the governor declared a state of emergency and National Guardsmen were ordered to assist a mandatory evacuation of coastal barrier islands and shorefront. Thousands fled inland or went to shelters.Kingston, New York, assisted by Charleston during the Revolutionary War, is repaying the kindness by sending money to help the city recover.
column9: Forecasters Saved Lives During Deadly Hurricane Hugo
column10: Hurricane Hugo which hit Charleston, S.C. head-on the night of Sept. 21, 1989 was the costliest storm in the city's 300-year history. Despite widespread devastation (insured losses approached $5 billion) there were only 17 deaths in South Carolina and only two in Charleston itself thanks to accurate forecasting in time for an effective evacuation.
column11: On Sept. 21, 1989 Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, South Carolina head-on with winds at 135 mph causing extensive property damage, but claiming only 17 lives in all of South Carolina and only two in Charleston itself. The relatively low casualties were a result of an accurate prediction of the point of windfall by hurricane forecasters, effective evacuation measures and good response from residents. Total insured losses from Hugo were estimated near $5 billion, by far the costliest storm to ever hit the area, but insurers expressed confidence in being able to satisfy all claims.
column12: Hurricane Hugo approached the Carolina coast on Sept. 21, 1989 with its windspeed up to 125 mph and threatened to hit between Savannah, GA and Charleston, S.C. It hit Charleston head-on with winds of 135 mph and then proceeded northwestward hitting other population centers rather than heading up the coast or out to sea as expected. Fortunately Hurricane forecasters analyzing computer predictions, satellite data, the history of similar storms and the current path of the hurricane made an accurate educated guess as to the point of landfall in time for threatened residents to evacuate. As a result, only 17 deaths resulted in all of South Carolina and only two in Charleston which took the brunt of the storm. Charleston had been through many hard times in its 300- year history, but Hugo was by far the worst hurricane in its experience. Total insured losses from Hugo were estimated near $5 billion but insurers were confident that they could handle all claims. Disaster aid came to Charleston from an unexpected source. Kingston, New York  raised funds to aid Charleston in thanks for 1,000 New York pounds sent by the South Carolina governor in 1778 to help the citizens of Kingston after it was burned by the British.

He be inter follow a service at CherokeeMemorial Cemetery, which several of his relatives attended, she said.fourteen of the wounded students be still hospitalized, butmost be report in improved conditions.at Cleveland School, about three-quarters of the school's 970pupils have return to classes by Friday, about three times thenumber who attend Wednesday, but it be anything but a routineschool day.Counselors and school psychologists be assist teachers inclassrooms, and some parents sit in with their children to comfortand reassure them.one mother, who ask not to be identified, told reporters thather young son, a 7-year-old second grader who be on playgroundwhen the shootings occurred, would only come back to school if shestayed with him.they're make it back, slowly but surely, she said, addingthat she plan to spend Friday as she do Thursday, at her son'sside in the classroom.cleveland School be in the heart of California's third-largestcommunity of refugees from Southeast Asia, and nearly two-thirds ofthe school's population be from Asia. It could happen to anybody, anywhere, anytime. thisis a crazy action from one individual. It be not racism, say AnTran of the Southeast Asian Refugee Resettlement Program.Stockton Police Capt. Dennis Perry also repeat that there wasno evidence that Purdy, who commit suicide after the attack, wasspecifically target Asians.It wasn't any one race or group of people. He hatedeverybody, Perry say of Purdy, who as a child 14 years earlierhad attend Cleveland School.A man fire several dozen shots from anautomatic rifle in an elementary school Tuesday, kill sixchildren, wound at least 35 other people and then shootinghimself in the head, authorities said.we have at least one suspect in custody who have a gunshot woundto the head, Deputy Police Chief Ralph Tribble said.bruce Fernandez, spokesman for the county office of emergencyservices, say six people have died.ellen Rich at St. Joseph's Medical Center say eight victims werebeing treat there, and say the total, include those beingtreated at other hospitals, be 35 wounded.We have at least 30 people that we've send out to areahospitals, say Police Chief Jack Calkins.The attack at Cleveland Elementary School come shortly beforenoon. other children be keep in their rooms, say John Klose,Stockton Unified School District information officer.police Sgt. Everybodywas cry in my class.police say a drifter identify as Patrick Edward Purdy, 26,armed with two handguns and an ak-47 assault rifle, enter theschool grounds around noontime Tuesday and fire about 60 roundsbefore he shoot himself to death.afterward, a large handgun and the assault rifle lay on theground near a pool of blood and the gunman's body. Her teacher toldstudents to get under their desks.the gunfire startle Michael Cuevas, whose first thought be thatthe University of the Pacific fraternities near his house werefiring their miniature cannon again.But the shots repeat too rapidly for a cannon, and the screamof sirens that follow tell him this time be no prank.i never think a tragedy of this magnitude could happen instockton, say Cuevas, a 29-year-old marine clerk at the Port ofstockton who live down the street from the elementary school.it's always in some other town, some other place. It's a shockto my senses. I don't think it's even hit me as hard as it's goingto. You don't know whether to be excited, or confuse or what.police cars and news reporters crowd the street, whichtypically be busy only when parents pick up and drop off theirchildren.why here? say Jeff Russell, 37, who be bear and rear inthe neighborhood. This have always be a sleepy little town. (theshooting) put us back on the map.lutheran and Baptist churches border the school in a neighborhoodof ranch-style homes, postage-stamp lawns and streets line withsycamore and oak trees in this agricultural city of 150,000 people60 miles southeast of San Francisco.The 40-year-old neighborhood near the University of the Pacificis still home to many retired couples who raise their familesthere. But the city have be change with the influx of southeastasian refugees.when school officials call clergy to console grieve families,buddhist priests in sandals and saffron robes arrive along withtheir white-collared Christian counterparts.about 60 percent of Cleveland Elementary's students be ofsoutheast asian descent, say John Klose, spokesman for the StocktonSchool District. The five children who be kill be Vietnameseand Cambodian.This be one of our best neighborhood schools, Klose said.of all of our schools that I would think of something like thishappening, this would be the last one I would think of.Across the street, Sarah Abbott stand astride her bicycle andgazed at the school where she graduate many years ago. Theprofessional nanny say she be at the house of her 97-year-oldgrandfather about a block from the school when the gunman set hiscar on fire before start to shoot.when the car exploded, my grandpa's house just shook, abbottsaid. It scar me. ... It be just too close.the 26-year-old drifter with a long criminalrecord who launch a mute, murderous assault on a californiaelementary school Tuesday be describe by his aunt as a loner andchildhood alcoholic, police said.patrick E. Purdy purchase an ak-47 rifle in this Portland suburbseveral months ago, then return to his hometown of Stockton,Calif., where he use the gun to kill five children and wound 29others, along with a teacher, at Cleveland Elementary School beforetaking his own life, authorities said.purdy, who go by the alias of Patrick West, have live with anaunt and uncle in Sandy from the first of July until late October,said Sandy Police Chief Fred Punzel. He later move to Lodi, Calif.,where he list his mailing address under the name of hisgrandmother, Julia Chumbley, although he do not live with her,authorities said.i'm shocked. It's just horrible. I don't understand why and iprobably won't ever know why, say Ms. Chumbley, a 63-year-oldretired cannery worker.it troubles me to think that such a terrible thing can happen.it's like a nightmare. This sort of thing happens to others, notyou. Your own grandson.stockton be about 15 miles southwest of Lodi.Punzel say Purdy's aunt, Julie Michael, tell me he be a lonerand as a child he be an alcoholic.mrs. Michael say through a closed front door at her residencethat she be too upset to talk to reporters.her next-door neighbor, Pat Thomas, 45, say she meet West when helived with his relatives last summer.he seem like a real nice young man, she said. He be herelooking for work.however, Purdy have an extensive criminal history, mostly inthe Los Angeles area, say lucian Neely, deputy police chief instockton, an agricultural city 60 miles east of San Francisco.Purdy have no criminal record in Sandy, Clackamas County orportland, authorities said.neely say Purdy originally be from Stockton and that he hadpurchased the gun at the Sandy Trading Post Aug. 3.Punzel say Mrs. Michael tell him Purdy leave Oregon for a job asa boilermaker in Texas. That job fell through and he go toMemphis, Tenn.The aunt and uncle last heard from Purdy at Thanksgiving, when hewas in Connecticut, Punzel said.his mother lives in Sacramento, Calif., and his father be killedin 1980 or 1981 when he be strike by a car as a pedestrian, Punzelsaid.State Division of Motor Vehicles records identify Purdy as5-foot-11, 150 pounds, with blue eyes and blond hair, say spokesmandave Davis.
column5: Man fires into California schoolyard, killing five and wounding 30.
column6: On January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy, 24, fired an AK-47 into a playground at Stockton, California's Cleveland Elementary School, which he had attended. He killed five children and wounded 30, then killed himself. The slain children were Southeast Asian. Purdy had drifted around the country searching for work and had a long criminal record.
column7: On January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy fired an AK-47 automatic assault rifle into a crowded playground at Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton, California, killing five children and wounding 30, then killing himself. All the dead were children of Southeast Asian refugees, as were 60% of the school's students. Translators and Buddhist priests assisted families, and returning students received counseling. A South Carolina school where a similar attack occurred sent encouragement. Governor Deukmejian spoke at one memorial service. Anti-racism statements were made. Purdy, 24, attended Cleveland Elementary  through third grade. A loner, he had drifted around the country searching for work and had a long criminal record.,
column8: On Tuesday, January 16, 1989, Patrick Edward Purdy entered the grounds of Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton, California and fired an AK-47 automatic assault rifle into a crowded playground. He killed five children and wounded 29 others and a teacher, then killed himself. All the dead and 19 of the wounded were children of Southeast Asian refugees, as were 60% of the school's 970 students. Translators and Buddhist priests assisted families, who received financial aid from the county victim assistance program. Students returning to school received counseling. A South Carolina school where a similar attack occurred sent encouragement. Governor Deukmejian spoke at one memorial service and was considering a ban on assault weapon sales. Anti-racism statements were made but authorities denied a racial motive in the attack. Purdy, AKA West, 24, blond and blue-eyed, attended Cleveland Elementary  through third grade. He dropped out of high school and took welding classes, then drifted around the country searching for work. He had many LA area arrests for minor offenses, served jail time, and attempted suicide. He had military and white supremacist leanings. He was described as a loner, child alcoholic, dangerous, and mildly retarded. His father was struck by a car and killed in 1981. His mother remained unlocated.
column9: Drifter opens fire in schoolyard, killing five and wounding 30.
column10: Five students of Asian descent were slain in the schoolyard of Cleveland Elementary School shortly before noon. Another 29 students and a teacher were wounded in the attack. Their killer, Patrick Edward Purdy, lay dead nearby of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Purdy was a drifter with a long history of problems with the law.
column11: Five children were slain in the schoolyard of Cleveland Elementary School on Tuesday, the victim of a drifter with a troubled past. Patrick Edward Purdy, armed with an AK-47 and a pistol, entered the crowded schoolyard just before noon and opened fire. When the shooting was over, five students lay dead and 29 others, as well as one teacher, were wounded. Purdy lay dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. Cleveland Elementary School is two-thirds Asian and the five students, one Vietnamese and four Cambodian, as well as 19 of the wounded were all Asian.
column12: Patrick Edward Purdy, a drifter with a troubled past, returned to the elementary school where he attended kindergarten through third grade and killed five children. Armed with an AK-47 and a pistol with victory written on it, Purdy went to Cleveland Elementary School in Stockton and opened fire in the crowded schoolyard at recess. Firing over 100 rounds in a few minutes, Purdy killed five students and wounded 29 others as well as a teacher. He then committed suicide with the pistol. Purdy was described by his aunt as a loner and a child alcoholic. He had a long history of trouble with the law and had served at least two jail terms. Cleveland Elementary serves the third largest Asian refugee community in California and the five students killed as well as 19 of the 29 students were Asian. One of those killed, a Vietnamese student, was buried Saturday following a Catholic mass. Traditional Buddhist prayers were being held for three of the four Cambodian students slain. A community service is being planned at the Stockton Civic Center on Monday. Governor Deukmejian, who will be attending the event, has asked that everyone wear black and white ribbons in keeping with Southeast Asian tradition.

column5: Ohio Flash Flood Kills 21; 14 Still Missing; Dozens Homeless
column6: Thursday night's flood in Ohio left twenty-one dead, 14 missing and dozens homeless. Two creeks outside Shadyside overflowed, knocking homes off their foundations and washing away a bar. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under pressure, creating a "wall of water." Area residents are eligible for federal aid.
column7: The violent thunderstorms that struck central and eastern Ohio Thursday left twenty-one dead, 14 missing, and dozens homeless. Two creeks outside Shadyside overflowed in the heavy rain. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under the water pressure, creating a "wall of water." Homes were knocked off their foundations and a Shadyside bar was swept away. Dog teams assisted in the search for victims. The National Weather Service had not issued a flood warning before the disaster.Gov. Celeste declared a state of emergency. The Federal Emergency Management Agency will open an office in Shadyside to accept applications for aid.
column8: The death toll from last week's floods reached 21 today when a body was pulled from the Ohio River. Hope is fading that the 14 people still listed as missing are alive. Violent thunderstorms swept through central and eastern Ohio Thursday night. The Wegee and Pipe creeks outside the Ohio River village Shadyside overflowed when about 4 inches of rain fell in about an hour. Authorities said dams formed by debris at bridges broke under the water pressure, creating a "wall of water." Homes were knocked off their foundations and a bar in Shadyside was swept away. In Licking and Jefferson counties, about 200 people were evacuated from their homes. Many residents recounted stories of narrow escapes and lost property.Few people carried flood insurance, and homeowners' insurance will not cover the damage. The Federal Emergency Management Agency will open an office in Shadyside to accept applications for aid. The National Weather Service said a flood watch, but not a warning, was issued before the disaster.Gov. Richard Celeste declared a state of emergency. The Shadyside Fire Department established a command center at the Jefferson Elementary School to coordinate rescue efforts. Authorities said dog teams assisted in the search for victims.
column9: Eastern Ohio floods kill 21, some still missing; damage extensive
column10: Eastern Ohio flash floods resulting from 5.5 inches of rain in less thanfour hours killed 21 persons and caused extensive damage. The governordeclared a state of emergency and sent in the National Guard.  Fourteenpersons remain missing a week later.  Few homeowners had flood insurance tocover damage.
column11: The death toll from floods in eastern Ohio rose to 21 and may to highersince 14 persons are still missing.  Torrential rains caused two creeks nearShadyside, Ohio, overflow and create a wall of water 15 to 20 feet high.The flood raged through the valley demolishing a crowded tavern and at least70 houses.  Governor Celeste declared a state of emergency and sent NationalGuard troops into the area to assist.  Dog teams were used to search forsurvivors and bodies.  Few of the damaged homes were covered by floodinsurance so the owners must look to federal assistance.
column12: Flash floods raged through small towns along the Ohio River in eastern Ohioon Thursday.  Death toll from the flood was put at ten initially, but wasraised to 21 as more bodies were found.  The number may still go highersince little hope remains for the fourteen still unaccounted for.  Thefloods hit two creeks near Shadyside, Ohio, about 10 miles south ofWheeling, West Virginia.  Five and a half inches of rain fell in slightlymore than three hours. The flood created a wall of water 15 to 20 feet highas it tore through the area.   The force of the raging water demolished acrowded tavern in Shadyside.  A nine-year-old girl who was swept into thecreek and on into the Ohio River miraculously survived a seven mile ordealby clinging to logs.Ohio Governor Celeste declared a state of emergency after surveying thearea.  The National Guard was brought in to patrol and help rebuild roads.Dog teams from four states were used in searching for survivors and bodies.Few homeowners had flood insurance to aid in rebuilding lost or damagedhomes.  The Federal Emergency Management Agency planned to acceptlow-interest loan and grant applications.

column3: already they're say it's thebiggest happen in astronomy since Galileo put his eye to atelescope.so, step right up folks, and discover the wonders of theuniverse. See how big it is. Learn its age. Look at light created14 billion years ago and arrive at your eye only this instant.ride along to the beginning of everything, almost, to the BigBang of 10 or 20 thousand million years ago. See stars bear and seethem die. Watch galaxies form. Follow the flow of gas into themilky Way's halo. Peer deep into the universe, past so many starsin our own galaxy that it would take a person more than a lifetimeto count, to a hundred billion other galaxies each with about 200billion stars.for scientists, and then the rest of us, all that becomespossible now that the space shuttle Discovery have carry thehubble Space Telescope into the sky to see what no one have seenbefore. The telescope, a silvery tube as long as a tanker truck,has an unmatched ability to detect and capture the faint light.light, speed along at 186,000 miles a second, be themessenger of creation. track the trail of light from today tothe first moments contain all the information we will ever haveabout the creation of the universe.the hubble promises to give science an open window perhaps tothe first echoes of creation. This be a world-class event, even ifastronomy be not your thing.superlatives?in the history of optical astronomy there have be two greatleaps in the resolution of the universe: Galileo's telescope in theautumn of 1609, and the hubble Space Telescope in April 1990. Eric J. Chaisson, a senior scientist at the Space Telescope ScienceInstitute in Baltimore.One more?no one ever make anything that good, James Westphal,California Institute of Technology.Another?Dr. Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist, predict that thehubble telescope will literally be the dawn of a new era inastronomy.Eras rarely can be proclaim in advance. But the HST, namedafter Edwin Powell Hubble, hold that kind of promise.hubble be an astronomer in the first half of the century whoconcluded not only that distant galaxies be move away from Earthbut that the farther away they are, the faster they move. Thetheory of an expand universe support the belief that theuniverse originate in a cosmic explosion and that all matter isstill rush from the site of that so-called Big Bang.Astronomers think the Big Bang occur 12 billion to 20 billionyears ago and send the entire universe fly out at incrediblespeed and heat. eventually matter cool and condense intogalaxies, stars and planets.There be big telescopes than the Hubble, but they be all onearth and all subject to a major limitation the atmosphere which be fine for breathe but lousy for see through.
