column5: How the Hubble Space Telescope Finally Got Into Orbit
column6: After a delay of seven years caused by technical problems and the Challenger accident, the Hubble Space Telescope was launched on space shuttle Discovery on April 24, 1990 and four days later was orbiting on its own 380 miles above the earth's atmosphere. The system still had problems but great potential.
column7: Scientists were elated with the successful launch of space shuttle Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) aboard on April 24, 1990. Deployment of the telescope was originally scheduled for 1983 but was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident.  Although the communications and electronics systems of the HST still presented some problems, by April 28 the telescope was in orbit 380 miles above the earth's atmosphere with the potential of providing 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories. The Discovery astronauts were permitted to return to Earth.
column8: Deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST), originally scheduled for 1983, was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident in 1986 and did not take place until April 1990. The HST had two mirrors, one 94.5 inches in diameter and the other 12 inches. Electrical power was provided by two wing-like solar arrays. It was named after Edwin P. Hubble who discovered in the 1920s that the universe is constantly expanding. Scientists regarded the telescope as the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo, providing 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  A successful launch of space shuttle Discovery with the HST aboard took place at 8:34 a.m. April 24, 1990 and Discovery ascended into orbit 380 miles above Earth. On April 25 the HST was placed in orbit on its own with Discovery trailing behind to provide astronaut assistance if needed. The HST's aluminum aperture door was successfully opened on April 27 exposing the telescope's 94.5- inch mirror to starlight. By April 28 there were still problems with the electronic and communications systems, but procedures were in place to take care of these, the HST was in orbit, and the Discovery astronauts prepared for return to earth on April 29, 1990.

column3: And for the sentimentalists, there will be 83-year-old Johnny Kelleystarting in his 60th Boston Marathon. There have only be 35 editions of thisrace run without him.; The last three Boston marathons have turn intoreckless speed duels. They have produce five of the top 10 times and eight ofthe top 15 in the race's storied history.; They also have result in arace of attrition, with many of the early speedsters burn out completely orfaltering in the late stages.; Along the historic route that begin inhopkinton, west of Boston, and end in Copley Square in the Back Bay sectionof the city, checkpoint records have fall at an alarm rate.; Forexample, all 11 checkpoint records be shatter through the first 20 mileslast year, either by Simon Robert Naali or Juma Ikangaa, both of Tanzania.Neither won.; The winner be 1988 Olympic champion Gelindo Bordin, whooutsmarted the early pacesetters by run a patient, calculate race.;running alone about 200 meters behind a pack of six Africans, Bordin passedthem all by 21 miles and go on to win in 2 hours, 8 minutes, 19 seconds, thesecond-fastest time in the race's history, behind only the 2:07:51 by Rob decastella in 1986.; Ikangaa finish a distant second in 2:09:52. It be histhird consecutive runner-up finish in Boston.; Ikangaa be back again, alongwith several other formidable Africans. They include Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya,the 1988 winner in 2:08:43, the third-fastest time in Boston and one secondahead of Ikangaa; Abebe Mekonnen of Ethiopia, the 1989 champion in 2:09:06,Boston's eighth-best time; Douglas Wakiihuri of Kenya, the 1987 world championand 1988 Olympic silver medalist who be make his Boston debut; and Naali,the third-place finisher in the 1990 Commonwealth Games.; Among thosechasing them will be John Treacy, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist and thethird-place finisher in Boston in 1988 and 1989; Geoff Smith, the Bostonwinner in 1984-85; Ed Eyestone, the top-ranked U.S. marathoner; SalvadorGarcia, the runner-up to Wakiihuri in last year's New York City Marathon; androlando Vera, who finish third in his marathon debut in Boston in 1990.;The women's division also be fill with many respectable entrants.;foremost among them be kristiansen, the 35-year-old norwegian who hold theworld record of 2:21:06 and win in Boston in 1986 and 1989, and Samuelson, 33,the u.s.-record holder at 2:21:21, 1984 Olympic gold medalist and Bostonchampion in 1979 and 1983.; challenge them will be Uta Pippig, WandaPanfil and Kim Jones.; Pippig finish second in Boston last year in acareer-best 2:28:03. Panfil win the London Marathon in 2:26:31, her personalbest, and win the New York City Marathon in 1990.TOMORROW evening, just before the Olympic closing ceremony, the last and oneof the most prestigious events of the Games will be held. It be also withoutdoubt the most gruelling. Run in high heat, high humidity, high pollutionlevels and over an extraordinary course, the Barcelona Olympic men'smarathon will prove one of the most physically demand ever run. There arelots of figures to show why. It be estimate that when the race begin inmataro, a seaside town north of Barcelona, the temperature will be analready-uncomfortable 25`C. Towards the marathon's end, however, radiantheat throw off by buildings could be subject the runners to atemperature of up to 30`C. more debilitating still, relative humidity inbarcelona in August rises as high as 80 per cent. With more than 10kilometres still to go, most of the course be an upward run. The last 4.6km,which take the runners 60m high still to the Olympic stadium at the top ofthe hill of Montjuic, have an average gradient of more than 4.5 per cent, andincludes some sections of 7 per cent, equivalent in ski terms to a steep'red' run. But we do not need figures to convince us of the extraordinarydifficulty of tomorrow's race. last Saturday, in the Olympic stadium, iwatched the final moments and aftermath of the women's marathon, begin atthe same time of day and run in similar conditions. Never in any eventvoluntarily enter into, sport or otherwise, have I see such signs ofphysical and mental distress. The race be win by the Unified Team'sValentina Yegorova in 2 hours 32 minutes, a time considerably slow thanthat achieve by women on less demand Olympic marathon courses in LosAngeles and Seoul. After her near competitor, Japan's Yuko Arimori, camein eight seconds later, they have the energy - between bouts of grimace andlowering their heads to their knees - to embrace each other and smile forthe cameras.it be a different story in the 'mixed zone,' the area under the stadiumwhere athletes recover after their events. As runner after runner stumbledand limp into the room - several be bring in senseless on stretchers -the scene seem to be populate by exhausted boat people rescue afterweeks of exposure and deprivation at sea.As a photographer calmly shoot off a roll of film a foot from her face,manuela Machado of Mexico and another runner stand vomit violently into apotted palm. several competitors lay prone and gasping on the ground aswater be pour over them; others stand hunched over, grasp theirabdomens.if anyone move at all, it be with agonised face and the slow ofhobbles. These be not the sort of scenes likely to promote enthusiasm formarathon run or for the ideals of Olympic competition.chris Brasher, organiser of the London marathon, be on hand to witness thesuffering, and be incensed. Male marathon runners will face the same kindof problems with heat, humidity, and an over-demanding terrain, he said.in his opinion, gear the marathon to prime-time tv viewing and have theevent end at the top of a hill for the sake of stadium spectators wasunjustified and a 'sell-out to commercialism.'to put on the marathon in the late afternoon, rather than first thing inthe morning (the normal practice), and then to make them run 4km up a hillis just criminal in my opinion,' say Brasher, a former Olympic gold medalathlete and note sportswriter.I speak to Britain's Steve Brace, winner of the Paris marathon in 1989 and1990, the Berlin marathon last year and a competitor in the Barcelona event.he agree that the run will be highly demanding, and while he regardsolympic marathon run as a pinnacle of his career, he be cautious abouttomorrow's slog.like almost all the athletes run tomorrow, Brace be a professionalrunner who specialise in marathons. He take an objective, long-term viewof his profession. As an income-earner, marathon running be an activity withliabilities and limitations, and require business management as well asphysical ability.the winner of the London marathon earn a tidy Dollars 50,000 and the NewYork, Boston and japanese runs be all in the same prize-winning category.but these and less financially-rewarding events be physically debilitating,and can only be win if a competitor be in top physical shape.with their careers and financial prospects in mind, top-level runnersnormally only run two marathons a year. As Brace says, when you have onlytwo pay-days out of 365, you choose, plan and train for them with greatcare.brace trains extremely carefully indeed. 'running a marathon be the easypart,' he says. 'The hard part be the lead-up to achieve the performancelevel required.' He start train three months before an event by running80 miles a week and then build progressively. For the last six weeks heruns 120 miles a week.normally he would hope that such a routine bring a pay-off. But the Olympicmarathon be an exception: the only top-level marathon that carry no prizemoney. Brace say that in spite of the prestige and possible financialspin-offs involved, 'it do not necessarily make sense to run to win.'given the highly demanding nature of the course and their desire to preservephysical condition for races that do bring in money, he says, many runnerswill give less than their best effort.nonetheless, there be plenty whose considerations stretch beyond the purelyfinancial. italian Gelindo Bordin, who come first in the 1988 Seoul Olympicmarathon, be a strong contender. So be Djibouti's Ahmed Salah, who camethird in Seoul. Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya and Hiromi Taniguchi of Japan arealso possible winners.none of them, though, will make a molehill out of the steep and formidableascent of Montjuic.A crowd the size of a small city will squeeze past a starting line here March 1 to run 26 miles, 385 yards. And cheer every step of that distance will be more than a dozen corporate sponsors and licensees. Makers of cars, soda pop, sportswear, copiers, computers -- even a hospital -- have tag their names to the Los Angeles Marathon. In the promoter's words, this run be "a market event on legs," reflect marathoning's grow importance in upscale product promotions. Runners, it seems, be a well-heeled lot. A study by Mercedes-Benz find that 42% of family heads make $40,000 a year or more jog regularly. Of potential buyers show up at Mercedes dealers, 47% be joggers. With those numbers in mind, the car maker have become a sponsor of three marathons -- in New York, Boston and Los Angeles -- as well as other run races. Marathons have have corporate backing for some time. But Los Angeles be ahead of the pack in make distance run a commercial spectacle. The city that invent the corporate-sponsored Olympics have create a marathon unlike others -- artfully dress as an olympic-type amateur race, but build from the ground up to make money for the closely hold company that control it -- as well as for the city. "I take air and make an event," say William Burke, the founder and president of Los Angeles Marathon Inc. For a man whose running days end with his high school track team, Mr. Burke be turn a lot of heads in the world of marathoning. last year, its first time out, the Los Angeles race attract nearly 11,000 runners -- four times the number forecast and enough to make it the third -- large race in the U.S. The event also pull in about $4 million in cash and services from its sponsors, leave the organizers with $370,000 in red ink. This year, Mr. Burke and his partner, Marie Patrick, expect to gross about $5 million in cash and services and to break even. Next year, they say, a profit be possible. more than 18,000 runners be expect this year. An audience of perhaps a million and a half or more will line the route, drawn in part by advertisements on 75 million coca-cola cans and 2,500 billboards around the Los Angeles area. market experts say the festive atmosphere of big crowd in the streets make marathons attractive to sponsors. For the cost of a 30-second ad on the Super Bowl, a company can sponsor a marathon and "take over a city," say Lesa Ukman, editor of special Events reports, a chicago-based newsletter. The Los Angeles organizers and sponsors have perhaps do more than their counterparts elsewhere to publicize the event. Los Angelenos be see plugs for the race on millions of grocery bags, milk cartons and loaves of bread, in addition to soda cans, billboards and other sources. The venerable New York Marathon be take note. The New York Road Runners Club, organizer of the race, stop promote the event some years ago because it have all the runners it wanted. Now, Fred Lebow, the group's president, say he be encourage sponsors to promote the race as the Los Angeles sponsors do. The promotion in Los Angeles be unabashed. "We tell people that if they're look for a new way to crack the Los Angeles market, this be it," say Mr. Burke. The pitch have attract the likes of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Los Angeles; Vons Cos., a large supermarket chain; the Los Angeles Times; the Sears Savings Bank unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co.; Eastman Kodak Co., and Tandem Computers Inc. One supporter be Ellesse USA, a sportswear and shoe producer. A $50,000 fee enable the company to use the marathon's name in its ads; Ellesse will spend an additional $100,000 dress race personnel in T-shirts and warm-up suits, show its clothes at the marathon's public "expo" of sponsors' wares, and post a dozen big street banners along the course. The company have rent more than 500 billboards at a cut-rate price of $120,000 from Patrick Media Group, a marathon sponsor. The discount, about 50%, be important. "we couldn't have buy that kind of exposure normally," say Susan Cialone, Ellesse's advertising director. Ellesse, which also sponsor the New York run, find the West Coast event more freewheeling. "They have let us do whatever we want," say Ms. Cialone. For instance, product banners along the route -- almost impossible to arrange in New York -- be a snap in Los Angeles. The city, in fact, be a partner in the race. After competitive bidding, it award an eight-year contract to Los Angeles Marathon Inc. to put on the race. The exclusive franchise call for the race organizers this year to pay a minimum $60,000 fee or 4% of gross cash receipts to the city. The organizers also will pay the cost of city services for the marathon, estimate at $100,000. The race sponsors and city officials be trade freely on the good will generate by Los Angeles's role as host of the 1984 Olympics. The logo of the marathon be a shield with laurel wreath. Some posters show the Los Angeles Coliseum with its torch and giant Olympic symbol. "The World Returns to Los Angeles," proclaim one Mercedes-Benz ad. Race directors be call "commissioners," a term borrow from the 1984 Olympic organization, in which Mr. Burke be commissioner of tennis. And like the Olympics, Los Angeles Marathon Inc., portray the race as a civic celebration, thrives on volunteers. Some 7,500 people will work for free to monitor the course on race day. And two-thirds of the race's office staff work without pay. "i couldn't buy this," Mr. Burke says, gesture around the crowded race headquarters. not everyone work for free. Big-name runners, for instance, want to be pay a lot. And here, the organizers have pinch pennies. While some runners will be pay to appear, this year's field, like last year's, lack some of the superstars who race in Boston, New York and London. Grete Waitz, one of the best woman marathoners, want $100,000 to appear in Los Angeles; she be turn down. Mr. Burke say the australian runner Rob de Castella make it known through his agent that he wouldn't run any marathons in the spring but, for $25,000, he'd be happy to say the Los Angeles event be tempting. Mr. Burke say he slam down the phone. "we won't spend extraordinary amounts of money on any single runner to the detriment of the other runners," he says. Mr. de Castella's agent deny the story entirely. What Los Angeles lack in superstars, it plan to make up for in numbers. This year's race may challenge New York and London as the large marathon ever run. Some 20,500 start the New York race last year. Mr. Lebow, organizer of the New York event, say next year's Los Angeles Marathon will surpass that number. For one sponsor, this may be a mixed blessing. Orthopaedic Hospital, a not-for-profit institution whose sponsorship be part of a publicity campaign, provide emergency care stations along the marathon route. last year, one of every 20 runners need aid. Along with sprains, strains and blisters come more serious cases of exhaustion and hypothermia. A spokeswoman says: "We advise 250 people to quit the race."the Olympic trials, schedule for January, have make Nichols' job mucheasier this year. most top-ranked U.S. women be look for any summer-timemarathon in which to run and the San Francisco version offers excellentconditions.; The hills of San Francisco make this marathon challenging. Theweather, however, make it one of the few enticing races hold from June toseptember. early morning temperatures range in the low 50s in late June.;"This be the only place in the world where you can have a marathon in themiddle of summer," Nichols said.; Defending champ back; last year'swinner, Janis Klecker of Minnetonka, Minn., be entered. The field also boastsjanine Aiello of Albuquerque, N.M.; Michelle Bush-Cuke of Berrien Springs,Mich.; Christine Gibbons of Elmwood, N.J.; Lesley Lahane of Chestnut Hills,Mass.; Julie Shea-Graw of Raleigh, N.C., and Jane Welzel of Fort Collins,Colo.; All seven women have run marathons under the 2-hour, 40-minutebarrier. Klecker turn in a 2:39:52 on the 26.2-mile course.; Welzel isthe 1990 national champion, Gibbons have win 26 marathons, Lahane be a formercross-country national champion and Aiello twice have finish second in SanFrancisco.; A test for Shea-Graw; Shea-Graw, 32, finish third in the 1981New York City Marathon and be consistently rank among the top five Americanrunners throughout most of the early '80s. She be the top qualifier for the1980 Olympics team that miss the Moscow Summer Games because of a U.S.boycott.; This will be Shea-Graw's first race outside of North Carolinasince 1986, when she take time off to have a child.; "i've run some localraces," shea-graw said. "this be go to be a test for me. If it go well,then I'll up the ante and give my train the time that be need to becomecompetitive again."; Shea-Graw's best time be 2:30:11.; "i have somemajor injuries and want to have a child," shea-graw said. "but now it's timeto get on with my career."mr. Kelley be in train for the Boston Marathon -- his60th Boston Marathon. And even at the age of 83, he probablywill finish ahead of a large number of the 13,000 runnersexpected to compete -- officially or unofficially -- on April15.Bill Rodgers, a four-time Boston Marathon winner who plansto run again this year, marvels at Mr. Kelley: "it'sincomprehensible that a man his age be do what he's doing.i'm struggle at the age of 43. . . . This isn't golf."even the thought of run a course of 26 miles and 385yards leave some of Mr. Kelley's rival of yesteryeargasping. "aghast be more like it," say Leslie Pawson, 86, athree-time Boston champion who run against Mr. Kelley half acentury ago. "My doctor says: `No running, whatsoever.' Ican't even remember when I run my last marathon."john Adelbert Kelley be a throwback to a time whenmarathoners do it for glory and cab fare. A two-time winnerin Boston (1935 and 1945) and runner-up seven times, Mr.Kelley be to be the old competitor in the race this year-- as he have be for 15 years.mr. Kelley be such an institution that Hopkinton, Mass.,where the race begins, have make him an honorary citizen.("that mean I don't have to pay taxes there," he jokes.) Twostate troopers will run alongside the 5-foot-6, 130-pound Mr.Kelley into Boston so he won't be trample by "groupies," ashe call them, clamor to shake his hand. last year, fivejapanese runners be wave away by the bodyguards, as theysidled up to the old celebrity during the race. Recalls SuniTomomitsu, one of the runners: "At first we thought, `oh,wow, he's like Mafia man.' then we said, `oh no, this be nicejohnny Kelley.' In Japan, he be awesome."Though he isn't the old person ever to enter the BostonMarathon, Mr. Kelley be the old to run it. Peter Foley,who be bear in 1859, be a regular until he be well intohis 80s. But he walk the course. start at dawn (sixhours before the official noon start), Mr. Foley wouldeventually saunter across the finish line in the moonlight.of course, Mr. Kelley -- not to be confuse with the otherjohn Kelley, who win the Boston Marathon in 1957 -- isn't therunner he be in 1935 when he win the race, in 2 hours, 32minutes, 7 seconds. His best time ever be in 1945: 2 hours,30 minutes, 40 seconds. last year he finish in 5 hours, 5minutes. He hop to do good in 1991. "That's not aprediction, just a goal," he says.when John Kelley first toe the line in 1928, George Bushwasn't yet in kindergarten, Joe DiMaggio be an unknown andnike be the winged goddess of victory, not a running shoe.in those days, Mr. Kelley recalls, he run in black leatherhigh-jumping shoes that he cut open at the toes with a razorblade. "i would have love to run with the bad pair ofsneakers on the market today," he says.back then, the sport didn't have much of a following.today, of course, the Boston Marathon be a big deal, coveredby tv from start to finish and offer $402,000 altogetherin prize money."the winners get a medal and $55,000," say Mr. Kelley. "igot a medal and beef stew. God bless them," he adds. "theydeserve it."the rosy-cheeked, supple Mr. Kelley be a medical wonder.each year, he visit the Cooper Clinic at the Aerobics Centerin Dallas for a battery of endurance tests. "physiologically,whatever that means, I get all A's," Mr. Kelley report ofhis checkup four months ago."What that means," explain Kenneth Cooper, the physicianwho write "Aerobics" and several sequels and be now at workon a book on elderly athletes, "is that Johnny have the bodyof a man 23 years younger. He's go to be one of the starsof my book." Mr. Kelley's rest pulse rate -- 60 beats aminute -- be well below the average person's 72 beats.(that's good.) On the stress test the clinic gives, Mr.Kelley hold the endurance record for his age group.a mechanic for Boston Edison Co. before he retire in1972, Mr. Kelley start run in the evenings after workmore than six decades ago. His only purpose be to relax andhave some fun. "all day long, I do what my bos tell me todo," he recalls. "but when I run at night, I felt free. I rantill I be exhausted."in 1928, when he be 21, he enter his first BostonMarathon but didn't finish. He drop out three-quarters ofthe way through the race. Then, in 1933, he finish 37th ina field of about 200 runners. In all the years since, he hasmissed the race just once, in 1967. (he have competed, alltold, in 112 marathons, include the 1936 and 1948 Olympics.Mr. Kelley well know the jagged course from Hopkinton todowntown Boston:The first challenge come five miles into the race, wherea set of little hills can get a psyched runner to wasteenergy charge up the slopes. A mile and a half later,there's new reason to beware: The smells of Cavanaugh'sBakery can set off hunger pangs.an Exxon station in Wellesley marks the halfway point. Asteep descent into Newton Lower Falls can jar a tiredrunner's bones. Then, at the end of a long column of oak andmaple trees, be Heartbreak Hill, his nemesis. It cost him atleast two victories, he says. And finally there's the HauntedMile, a stretch where many runners have collapsed. Boston'sskyline, 2 1/2 miles in the distance, can seem so far away.Though still go strong, Mr. Kelley acknowledge themarathon get tough each year. To compensate, he trainsharder. He use to start prepare in earnest at the end ofjanuary. "In recent years, I've be in train 12 months ayear," he says, though the serious stuff -- a daily one-hourrun, sprints on the track and long, 2 1/2-hour runs everyother week -- begin in December. (He doesn't count the mileshe put in, as many long-distance runners obsessively do, buthe say he wouldn't object to an estimate of about 50 miles aweek.)mr. Kelley always train at 5 a.m., and alone: "It's aquiet time, no traffic; the air be fresh and sweet." Hisroutes vary. In January, he prefer the frozen sands of thebeach. With the approach of spring, he take to the alder andscrub-pine hills and bluffs where the sun can be see risingover Cape Cod Bay. After his morning run, he spend a coupleof hours paint (still life and Cape Cod scenes), a hobbyhe take up about 25 years ago.unlike many runners, Mr. Kelley doesn't bother withstretching exercises before he run in the morning. "This ismy warm up: I empty the dishwasher, I set up the coffeepot,but I don't plug it in. I set up the breakfast table. then Icheck the outside temperature to see what clothe to wear."he and his wife, Laura, live in a two-bedroom ranch-stylehouse here in East Dennis, with more than 350 trophies,medals and sweat-stained marathon numbers scatter about. Heisn't particular about brands of shoes ("i wear them all") orwhat he eat ("i never eat broccoli, but I love steak and icecream.")mr. Kelley aims to run till he be at least 100 years old."he's a strange man," say Laura Kelley, in awe of herhusband's vigor. The 82-year-old Mrs. Kelley adds, "i justtry to stay in his shadow, but I have a hard time even doingthat."in a rare moment of reflection, Mr. Kelley explain whatmakes him tick: "i paint because I like it. I run because Ilike it. If for some reason I don't finish the marathon, Idon't owe an apology to anyone. But I'll tell you, the BostonMarathon -- with all those people wave -- be good than mybirthday."television watchers of the 19th annual New YorkCity Marathon follow the step-by-step progress Sunday of theleaders, but many spectators on the course scan the thousands ofrunners for a familar face.the winner in the field of 23,478 large ever for a marathon be Steve Jones of Wales, who finish in 2 hours, 8 minutes and 20seconds, only seven seconds off the course record. Grete Waitz ofnorway win the women's division for a record ninth time in 2:28:07.Marybeth Torpe be hop another runner would run fast herboyfriend Tony Giannelli.She and several others have stake out the corner table at arestaurant on First Avenue to get a good view of the runners as theyromped off the Queensboro Bridge.Their hop on see Giannelli depend on how fast the yonkersnative ran. We have to leave this table by 12:30. The manager'skicking us out, say one of Giannelli's friends, Pete Koogan.Torpe be eager for Giannelli to finish, too.i'm go to ask him to marry me today, she said, hold upthe rise she plan to give him.crowds cheer for the those in the lead packs and the also-ranson the warm, sunny autumn day.lynne Avery, a sophomore at Morristown (N.J.) High School, waitedon First Avenue near 60th Street hop to catch a glimpse of herenglish teacher, Robert Paciorkowski. But she be not take anychances on miss him.mr. Paciorkowski tell us if he saw a television camera, he'dwave to us, Avery say as she hold a small portable televisionin her hand.all along the marathon route, volunteers hand drinks torunners, but Rick Fairlamb of Glen Rock, N.J., have prepare aspecial elixir of carrot juice. He hand them out to the 50 or sorunners in the Natural Living run club who pass his tableat 61st Street and First Avenue.Last night I go into Brooklyn and get 500 pounds of carrotsfrom a food co-op. We juiced them start at 5 this morning, hesaid.in Central Park, Richard Borrego stand on the railing with abullhorn, wait for his favorites in the race to pass. He didn'thave any trouble find them.i'm cheer for Grete and Steve Jones, Mr. Borrego said,referring to the winners.they're both so courteous, full of good sportsmanship. Theyalways help other runners. They never knock other runners, Borregosaid. And that's the way it should be.in Washington, D.C., more than 13,000 people from 23 countriesand 49 states run the Marine Corps Marathon, which offer no prizemoney and pride itself on be the people's race.jim Hage, a lawyer from Lanham, Md., who have never win a majormarathon, pull away from two-time champion Brad Ingram in the lasthalf mile to win in 2:21:58.But a unique subset have formed: people who like to do both at the sametime. And to help these folks along, companies arrange tours for marathonvacations. The result? Bangkok in November, London in April and Stockholm inMay.;"Skiers have mountain ranges, tennis players have resorts, why can't arunner take a marathon vacation?" say Thorn Gilligan, president of MarathonTours in Boston. "A runner should be able to enjoy a closed city for a day.it's a celebration for the sport as much as a competition.";gilligan took5,500 people last year on 20 tours to countries from Bermuda to Moscow. Inaddition to air fare and hotel, runners be guarantee spots in restrictedentry races such as the London Marathon. Qualifying times be not required.; London, the most popular european city to visit, hold the world's largestmarathon (April 12 next year). Berlin's race (sept. 27, 1992) have grow withthe demise of the wall.;"most marathons take you through cities, so you geta chance to see things you'd never see on a sightseeing bus," say Fred Lebow,president of the New York Roadrunner's Club and director of the New YorkMarathon. Lebow have run in 32 marathons, include London, Paris, Rome,Stockholm, Iceland, Seoul and Vienna.;"The most exciting thing be the startof the race," he said. "each city have something unique.";the cities aredifferent, but most marathons include a carbo-loading pasta party the nightbefore, medical exams, a post-race celebration, commemorative T-shirts andawards to finishers. Entry fees vary; Brussels be $16, Venice $40.;MarathonTours include the entry price in the package. go to Bermuda, for example,costs approximately $900 from San Francisco. The price include round-trip airfare, four days and three nights at the Grotto Bay Beach hotel (per person,based on double occupancy), full breakfasts and dinners, a welcome cocktailparty and post-race parties and discounts.;england have similarorganizations: Sports Tours International and Keith Prowse, a company thatspecializes in british theater, sports and concert tours.;but it isn'tnecessary to run 26.2 miles to go on a run vacation, especially if it's afamily trip. Some marathons, like Portland's, include additional races: afive-mile run, a five-mile walk and a kids run. Tel Aviv have a half-marathonand a fun run. Budapest offer a half-marathon and a mini-marathon along theDanube.;There be also trips that incorporate run into the sightseeingschedule. Running coach Pat Savage and Hal Higdon, a senior writer forrunner's World, be take a group to Ireland in June. The eight-day trip willleave from Chicago and will include sightseeing, guide runs and a fun runfrom Malahide Castle to swords.;"on a running vacation you plan somethingaround run everyday," Higdon said. "we know the unique scenic routes andput together special runs.";some runs be intrigue because of currentevents. The Tel Aviv Marathon course go past houses hit by Scud missilesduring the Gulf War. The Belgrade Marathon be hold despite Yugoslavia'sturmoil. The Munich course be the same as the 1972 Olympic route and finishesin the same stadium.;running 26 miles just to see a city definitely isn'tfor everyone, but at the very least, it's a way to kill two birds with onestone. In the recent Chicago Marathon, a german man run with a camera,snapping photo every few miles.; IF YOU'RE INTERESTED;If you're interestedin combine a vacation and marathon, here be some firms to contact:;(box)marathon Tours, 108 Main St., Charlestown, Mass. 02129. (617) 242-7845.; (box) Roadrunner Tours, 2815 Lake Shore Dr., Michigan City, Ind. 46360. (219)879-0133.;(box) Keith Prowse, base in England. (8OO) 6my-tour.;(box)sports Tours International, 91 Walkdon Rd., Walkdon, Worslay, Manchester M285DQ, United Kingdom. (061) 703-8161.
column5: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.
column6: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while others attract world-class runners.  Still others are organized simply for the sport.  Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons.  One 83-year old plans to run in the Boston marathon.
column7: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons, such as Los Angeles', concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while other cities such as New York, Boston and San Francisco attract world-class runners.  Still others, such as the Marine Corps marathon which bills itself as the "people's race," are just for the sport.  Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons, offering clients a chance to run in some of the most popular marathons in the world.  Age is no barrier to marathon running.  John Kelley, 83, plans to run in the Boston marathon.
column8: Marathons attract both professional athletes as well as amateur runners.  Some marathons, such as Los Angeles', concentrate on the commercial and moneymaking side of marathons, while other cities such as New York, Boston and San Francisco attract world-class runners.  Prior to the 1992 Olympic trials, topped ranked women marathon runners flocked to San Francisco, one of the only cities in the world suitable for summer running. The 1992 Barcelona Olympic marathon was one of the most grueling ever.  Run in the late afternoon heat and humidity, it featured a course where the last 10 kilometers was mostly uphill.  Other marathons are geared more to amateur runners than professionals. The Marine Corp marathon in Washington D.C offers no prizes and bills itself as the "peoples race". The San Diego marathon in 1990 was won by relative newcomers to long-distance running in what the men's winner described as a "weak field". Tour companies sponsor international trips organized around marathons, offering clients a chance to run in some of the most popular marathons in the world.  Age is no barrier to marathon running.  Eighty-three year-old John Kelley planned to run in his 60th marathon in Boston.  He won the event in 1935 and 1945.
column9: Marathons Popular Worldwide. Thousands Participate. Cities Advertise Attractions. Lure Runners
column10: Nearly all the world's major cities sponsor an annual marathon. They are popular events. Thousands participate over the 26.2 distance. Most marathons offer prize money to winners, but most in the participating throngs run for self-satisfaction. Climactic conditions and a city's beauty and history attract runners.
column11: Marathons are contested over a course that measures 26 miles and 385 yards. They are very popular, and most of the world's major cities organize an annual marathon.. Tour companies even put together "marathon tours" to accommodate runners. Most marathons offer substantial prize money to race winners, but most in the throngs of participants run only for a sense of accomplishment.Each city tailors its marathon to provide the best of its natural beauty and history. London has the largest, and Boston the most storied. San Francisco and San Diego boast of their weather conditions.
column12: The exact distance of a marathon is 26 miles and 385 yards. It is often expressed as 26.2 miles. Marathons are very popular, and major cities of the world organize marathons that draw thousands of participants. London, Berlin, Rome, Paris, Stockholm, Vienna, Budapest, Brussels, Munich, Bangkok and Tel Aviv are some of the cities that organize annual marathons. Tour companies even offer "marathon tours" to distant marathons. Most of the thousands who run do so only for self-satisfaction, but others compete for monetary prizes offered by most marathons. The Marine Corps marathon in Washington, D.C. is one that does not offer prize money.Marathons are usually run in the early morning hours to take advantage of cooler temperatures and cleaner air. The organizers of the 1992 Barcelona Olympics were criticized for contesting the marathon in the late afternoon heat.The London Marathon is the world's largest. The Boston Marathon is the most storied. It goes back almost a century, and in 1992, 83 year-old John Kelley was planning to run in his 60th Boston Marathon. The Los Angeles Marathon is renown as the best-marketed marathon. An Diego and San Francisco pride themselves for providing the most marathon-friendly weather.

column3: Emperor Hirohito leave $13.06 million in taxableproperty, a tax office near the Imperial Palace announce Monday.It be the first time that tax authorities have disclose theamount of an emperor's taxable estate, an official in the KojimachiTax Office said. Until the end of World War II, emperors wereregarded as living gods.hirohito die of cancer on Jan. 7 at age 87. He be succeed byAkihito, his eldest son. Hirohito's wife, Nagako, become empressdowager.Akihito have pay $2.99 million in inheritance taxes on his halfof his father's estate, which he divide evenly with his mother. Theempress dowager, as Hirohito's spouse, be exempt from payinginheritance taxes, Kyodo News Service reported.the japanese constitution, draft by U.S. occupation forcesshortly after the end of World War II in 1945, stipulates theemperor be the symbol of the state and the unity of the people.hirohito's estate include stocks and other personal belongings.three sacred treasures a mirror, sword and jewels which weretransferred from emperor to emperor, be tax-exempt, as be about3,180 items of art own by Hirohito that be donate to the state,the tax office official said.emperor Hirohito have lose nearly 40 pounds in thetwo months since he fell ill and now weigh only 66 pounds, a palaceofficial be quote as say Friday.The 87-year-old emperor's condition weaken Friday, but doctorsspeculated that a scab have stop internal bleeding in his upperintestinal area, say Imperial Household Agency spokesman KenjiMaeda.Hirohito have suffer repeat bouts of bleed but have notdischarged blood in nine days.the emperor respond to queries from aides but be lesstalkative than before, Maeda tell reporters. His normal temperature be about 95.9degrees.Doctors have say he suffer from jaundice and anemia. Maeda saidthe emperor's heart and kidneys be function normally.since Sept. 19, when he be confine to intensive care aftervomiting blood, Hirohito have receive 42 pints of blood intransfusions.palace officials have not give details on Hirohito's illness,and they would not comment on japanese news reports that the emperorhas pancreatic cancer.u.s. prosecutors pressure Japan's wartime primeminister, Gen. Hideki Tojo, into change testimony at his trial toavoid incriminate Emperor Hirohito in war crimes, a televisiondocumentary claims.the British Broadcasting Corp. documentary, details of which werereleased Wednesday by its maker Edward Behr, say the U.S.prosecutors work with the emperor's aides to find a way to avoidputting Hirohito on trial.the documentary challenges Hirohito's image as a peaceful manforced to go along with his generals' plans and allege among otherthings that he:must have know about the massacre of at least 20,000 chinese atnanking in 1937 because he receive regular detailed reports fromthe China front.knew more than a month in advance of japanese plans to attackthe U.S. navy at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941.The BBC will show Hirohito Behind the Myth on Jan. 24.Behr be a paris-based journalist. His biography of China's lastmonarch be use for the award-winning film The last Emperor.It have be report previously that american prosecutors wantedto keep Hirohito out of the war crimes trial and ask Tojo tosuggest the emperor have consent reluctantly to the war on theadvice of the High Command.Gen. Truman and that Tojo's evidence be alteredso the emperor would not be incriminated.to the rest of the world, he be know as EmperorHirohito, but in Japan his give name be seldom used. In Japanesehe be simply call Tenno Heika, mean His Majesty The Emperor.The foreign habit of use his name rankle some Japanese, whofound it impolite, and unnecessary since to them there be only oneemperor. Some japanese complain that after his death it evenbecame inaccurate to call him Hirohito because he have be give theposthumous name Showa.In Japanese histories, he will be record as Emperor Showa, thename he choose for his reign soon after he become emperor in 1926. Itmeans enlighten Peace, and have be succeed by Heisei, orachieving Peace, the name the government choose for the reign ofhirohito's son Akihito a few hours after the emperor die Jan. 7.But for the convenience of the rest of the world, which be not soable to keep track of the person behind the change name, evenofficial agencies have use the name Hirohito in English-languagepublications.The obituary issue in English by the Foreign Press Center, whichis support by the Foreign Ministry, be head His late MajestyThe Emperor Hirohito.English-language newspapers publish in Japan quickly beganusing the name Showa for Hirohito after his death, but it do notbecome truly official until Jan. 31, when Emperor Akihito conducteda ceremony in which Showa become the late emperor's posthumous name.A stone tablet place in his tomb be engrave only with theposthumous name and the dates of his death and burial.the custom of rename emperors after the completion of theirreigns begin after the death in 1912 of Emperor Meiji, Hirohito'sgrandfather.In Japan, years be number accord to the emperor's tenure onthe throne. thus 1926 become Showa 1 as Crown Prince hirohitoascended to the throne on Dec. 25 when his father, Emperor Taisho,died. The year 1927 be Showa 2, and 1989 be Showa 64 untilhirohito's death on Jan. 7. now this year be Heisei 1.The japanese custom of change imperial names be not uniqueamong world royalty, where an individual may have a variety of namesand titles in a royal career. In Britain, Prince Andrew become theduke of York upon his marriage in 1986.Emperor Hirohito's blood pressure and pulse droppedsharply Thursday, but the vital signs later return to normal asthe ail monarch's internal bleeding continued.hirohito, 87, discharge more blood and be give emergencytransfusions, but be rest peacefully by nightfall, an imperialpalace spokesman said.hirohito's blood pressure fell from 132 over 60 in the afternoonto 112 over 50 by evening, and his pulse from 104 per minute in themorning to 84 in the evening, say Kenji Maeda, chief of theimperial Household Agency's General Affairs Division.The emperor's blood pressure have return to what be normalfor him, and the head court physician say he be not worried,maeda said.one of Hirohito's daughters, Atsuko Ikeda, say Wednesday theemperor have cough severely during her visit to him and have hardlyresponded to her.on Thursday morning, Hirohito's two sons, Crown Prince Akihitoand Prince Hitachi, visit him, and he be fully conscious andalert, a senior palace source said.the monarch have be bedridden for a month with an intestinalhemorrhage.there be renew bleed Thursday and the pace of thedischarges be quickening, Maeda said.hirohito have receive nearly 22{ pints of blood since hisillness worsen Sept. 19, and the transfusions have put a strain onhirohito's heart and kidneys, Maeda say without elaborating.the only solid food Hirohito have eat since fall ill be afew spoonfuls of porridge. Otherwise he be be feed intravenously,which give him 600-700 calories a day, say the senior palaceofficial, who refuse to be identified.before his illness, Hirohito be take about 1,300 caloriesdaily, the official said.the emperor complains of fatigue but do not appear to be inpain, he said.crown Princess Michiko, Hirohito's daughter-in-law, scale downcelebrations for her 54th birthday Thursday, cancel atraditional birthday news conference, another palace official said.she plan a quiet gathering with members of the imperial family,the official said.world leaders send Japan messages of condolences and somedeclared states of mourn after Emperor Hirohito's death Saturday,but painful memories of World War II still generate criticism ofthe japanese monarch.president Reagan say Hirohito's 62-year reign span one ofthe most tumultuous, and yet at the same time constructive eras inthe history of mankind.it be also an era of unprecedented reconciliation. His Majestyplayed a truly heroic role in bring hostilities between our twopeoples to an end, Reagan said, refer to Hirohito's decisionto end World War II.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union send hissincere condolences and profound sympathy to the Japanesepeople.His two-sentence telegram make no mention of wartime hostilitieswith what still be know officially as militarist Japan.
