Ruud Boekholt, chairman of the August 15Commemoration Foundation, a group represent 127,000 Dutchcitizens who undergo japanese internment.daily, they still feel the pain of the wartime suffering thatwas inflict on them in the name of Emperor Hirohito, Boekholttold The Associated Press.But Indonesian President Suharto cable his condolences to CrownPrince Akihito, Hirohito's eldest son who immediately ascend thechrysanthemum Throne, and say he will personally pay the lasthomage to Hirohito, presidential spokesman Moerdiono said.pope John Paul II express his condolences and send telegrams tohirohito's family, Vatican radio reported.queen Elizabeth II say she be sadden and Prime MinisterMargaret Thatcher say she shares the Japanese people's sorrow. Butopposition lawmakers say Britain should boycott his funeral.no one should go to that funeral from this country, say RonBrown, a lawmaker of the opposition Labor Party, who denouncedhirohito as a war criminal of the bad kind.it would be a grave insult to the many men and women ...imprisoned in slave camps, he said. Many of them died, but thosewho survive still suffer today.king Juan Carlos of Spain, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and otherpersian Gulf monarchs, King Birendra of Nepal and Sultan MahmoodIskandar of Malaysia also send condolences to Akihito.Brazil call Hirohito a superior symbol of the Japanesenation, its culture and its anxieties in a period of drastictransformations in the world and his country and in a time of gravenew challenges in the world.world leaders from President Reagan to Malaysia's king mournedtoday's death of Emperor Hirohito, who surrender a broken nationto the Allies in World War II but preside over its rise to economicpre-eminence.reaction to Hirohito's death at age 87, however, be decidedlycool in several asian countries, include South Korea, whichendured years of harsh colonial rule by Japan.While South Korea President Roh Tae-Woo send his condolences, agovernment party statement added, We reserve far comment,considering the unhappy past and the current Korea-Japanrelationship.The main opposition party lead by Kim Dae-jung said, We havecomplex feelings at the death of Hirohito in view of Japan's 20-yearrule over Korea during his reign.a lead newspaper in Seoul, The Joong-Ang Daily News, wrotethat Hirohito's death remind all the korean people of a disgracedperiod and ... humiliation. ... Hirohito be the symbolic figure whomust assume most and final responsibility for (japan's) preposterouscrimes to the Korean people.korea be divide into the communist north and the capitalistsouth in 1945, when U.S. and soviet troops end Japan's rule thatbegan in 1910 with Japan's force annexation of the peninsula.there be no official comment from the nationalist Chinesegovernment because of the lack of diplomatic relations betweentaiwan and Japan, but the mass circulation chinese daily UnitedEvening News said:asian people who suffer from the slavery and invasion ofjapan's militarists during World War II may bury their animositywith Hirohito's death. ... chinese suffer the most from thejapanese invasion.it be an irony that while Hirohito apologize to the UnitedStates and Europe for the war, he do not direct a single word tochina to show his sorrow.now, Hirohito have died. We may not want tocollect the reparations, but we shall never forget the painfulhistoric lessions.in the United States, President Reagan say in a statement, HisMajesty's 62-year reign span one of the most tumultuous, and yetat the same time constructive eras in the history of mankind anage of unprecedented economic collapse, a most vicious war,astonishing scientific acheivement, and dramatic political andsocial changes throughout the world.it be also an era of unprecedented reconciliation. His Majestyplayed a truly heroic role in bring hostilities between our twopeoples to an end, Reagan said, refer to Hirohito's decisionto end World War II.In New Zealand, Prime Minister David Lange say Hirohito's deathmarks the end of an era.during his reign he saw the transition from the most turbulentperiod in Japan's modern history to the stability and prosperity oftoday, Lange said.president Corazon Aquino of the Philippines send condolences tothe imperial family and her foreign secretary, Raul Manglapus, ajapanese prisoner of war during World War II, praise Hirohito asa stabilize factor in the creation of a democratic Japan.He provide a figurehead that keep the japanese people firmlycommitted to peaceful means of achieve their national goals,manglapus said.Condolences also come from king Sultan Mahmood Iskandar ofmalaysia to Hirohito's old son, Crown Prince Akihito, whoimmediately ascend the Chrysanthemum Throne.Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia pay his respects in amessage to japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita: Throughouthis long life, the emperor be hold in the high esteem by hispeople. Now, as Japan enter a period of mourn and prepares for anew age, our thoughts be with you.but Bruce Ruxton, an official of the Returned Services League,which represent almost 300,000 australian war veterans, saidthere would not be too many tears shed around the world. Hedescribed Hirohito, whose role in the war have be debated, as oneof the bad war criminals.marine biologists pay homage to another facet of the monarch'slife his 12 books publish on hydrozoa, or sea animals. RobertHessler of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla,Calif., say Hirohito prefer the quiet study to his destine roleas leader.the poor man didn't really get to do what he want to do. Hehad to be emperor first, then second a scientist and normal humanbeing, Hessler said.tokyo (AP Emperor Hirohito will be remember for oneoverwhelming decision during his 62-year reign: Japan must bow todefeat for the first time in its history and end the Pacificconflict in World War II.Shortly after that decision, and for most of his reign, Hirohitobecame a figurehead, isolate from his subjects by tradition andsteeped in his great love, the study of marine biology. He be thelast survivor among the national leaders of the World War II era.but in his first 20 years, the Son of Heaven be worship asa divinity descend from the Sun Goddess Amaterasu.The solitude of animal and plant life under the seas which sointrigued Hirohito be in keep with the character of the man whobecame the 124th occupant of the Chrysanthemum Throne at the age of25 on Christmas Day 1926, designate his reign Showa enlighten peace.the emperor be generally portray as have play nosignificant role in plan or carry out Japan's militaryadventures in the 1930s and 1940s. But it be his first effectivedecision as emperor, and his most courageous, that end the Pacificconflict.On Aug. 10, 1945, four days after history's first atomic bombdevastated Hiroshima and one day after a U.S. bomber drop thesecond atomic bomb on Nagasaki, the generals and admirals ofimperial Japan's wartime government argue for hours in thesweltering bombproof shelter beneath the Tokyo palace.should Japan agree to the Allies' surrender demand, or fight onuntil annihilation?speaking in what some of those present describe as a slow andobviously nervous monotone, hirohito, the spiritual and titularleader, offer his opinion for the first time. He speak of hissorrow over the soldiers and sailors kill in the long war, and offamilies who lose everything in air raids.I cannot bear to see my innocent people suffer any longer, hesaid. end the war be the only way to restore world peace and torelieve the nation from the terrible distress with which it isburdened.then, evoke a memory of his grandfather, the Emperor Meiji,whose reign (1867-1912) saw the end of 250 years of feudal japaneseisolation from the outside world, Hirohito tell the officers:the time have come when we must bear the unbearable.in the days that followed, Hirohito continue his break withtradition. In a national radio broadcast Aug. 15 the first timeordinary japanese ever actually hear his voice he personallyannounced the decision to surrender.he tell the ravaged nation that the war situation have developednot necessarily to our advantage.three weeks later, Hirohito don a silk cutaway coat, stripedtrousers and a top hat to meet the Allied commander, Gen. Douglas A.MacArthur, at the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo. It be the first timehirohito have ever go to see anyone, and the first of several callson the general who have lead the Pacific war against Japan and becameits postwar governor.on New Year's Day 1946, at MacArthur's insistence, the emperorpublicly renounce his divinity. It be a choice that enabledhirohito to remain as the symbolic head of his nation and assuredthat he would not face charges as a war criminal, as some abroad haddemanded.it also be an act that seem to relieve no one as much as thisgentle, shy and retire man who never seem very comfortable as aliving god.the emperor's status in the eyes of many japanese change to thatof a kind uncle.he become a widely respect authority on marine biology. hepossessed rare collections of marine life, discover severalspecies himself and write or co-authored at least 12 books onhydrozoa, or sea animals, his specialty.in recent years, his life have become the subject of a popularcomic book series.still, Hirohito and the imperial system remain important toJapan.A nationwide survey by the daily newspaper Mainichi Shimbun inmarch 1987 indicate more than 80 percent of 2,184 people polledsupported the imperial system, while only 11 percent say it shouldbe abolished. Five percent say the emperor should have more power.from 1946 to 1954, Hirohito tour Japan to encourage the peopleto rebuild.the Imperial Household Agency, which run his affairs, saidhirohito consider the postwar period one of the most fulfillingtimes of his life, in which the nation make a phenomenal recoveryfrom a war that cost 3.1 million japanese lives.Despite the humanization of the Imperial family, hirohitoremained under strict control of the Imperial Household Agency.Protocol be maintain at nearly all times and he be prohibitedfrom speak on any controversial subject.hirohito be bear on April 29, 1901. In accordance with age-oldimperial custom, he be take from his parents as an infant to bereared in isolation by household functionaries and train for onerole, that of emperor.his education come as Japan surge into the modern world. Thefeudal samurai ethic be still strong; when his grandfather died,gen. Maresuke Nogi, the mentor for the 11-year-old prince, calmlycommitted ritual suicide to follow the emperor, his master, to thegrave.hirohito studied government and law with private tutors. When hewas 20, his father, Emperor Taisho, send him abroad the first timeany member of the immediate imperial family be allow outsidejapan.hirohito visit England, Scotland, France, Belgium, theNetherlands and Italy, receive various decorations. He be alsoreceived by Pope Benedict XV.The young man handle money for the first time, pay his ownfare on the Paris subway. He develop a passion for bacon and eggsand it become a lifelong breakfast habit. A palace chamberlain saidin a 1980 interview that Hirohito shun japanese food unless itis force on him by an unwitting host.hirohito also acquire a preference for western clothes. He wasnever see in public wear traditional japanese garb, and a palaceofficial confide that the Emperor of Japan do not even own akimono.hirohito become prince regent on Nov. 25, 1921, after his fatherbecame a mental and physical invalid, become emperor five yearslater and be formally enthrone in 1928.
column5: Asians Cool to Hirohito's Death; U.S. Possibly Helped Emperor Avoid Trial
column6: Japan's Emperor Hirohito, renamed Showa after his Jan. 7 death, reigned for 62 years. He will be remembered for surrendering in WW II. Though mourned by many, Asians often viewed him as a symbol of Japanese aggression. A BBC documentary claims Truman helped Hirohito avoid a war crimes trial.
column7: Japan's Emperor Hirohito, posthumously named Showa, left a $13 milliontaxable estate.  He died of cancer on Jan. 7.Hirohito is remembered for surrendering in WW II. Though many worldleaders mourned his passing, South Korea and others viewed him as asymbol of Japanese crimes against Asian people.Generally portrayed as a peaceful man, a January BBC documentaryclaims that Truman decided not to prosecute Hirohito for war crimes,and that Japan's wartime prime minister was pressured into changinghis testimony to avoid incriminating the emperor.  An LA newspaperpublished a letter to the editor after Hirohito's death alsoquestioning his innocence.
column8: Emperor Hirohito, who died on January 7 of cancer after several months of internal bleeding, left a taxable estate of approximately $13 million. Posthumously named Showa, or Enlightened Peace, the name of his reign, Hirohito will be remembered for his most courageous decision in his 62-year reign: Japan must surrender and end the Pacific conflict in WW II.Though many world leaders mourned his death, painful WW II memories sparked criticism of the monarch. South Korea sent condolences, but a government party statement added, "We reserve further comment, considering the unhappy past." A Taiwanese newspaper noted that "while Hirohito apologized to the United States and Europe...", he did not direct a single word to China..." Generally portrayed as having had no significant role in the war, a BBC documentary by Edward Behr challenged this view, alleging that Hirohito had advance knowledge of the Pearl Harbor attack. The show also claims that President Truman decided not to prosecute Hirohito for war crimes, and Japan's wartime prime minister, Gen.Tojo, was pressured into changing his testimony to avoid incriminating the emperor. A letter to the editor of an LA newspaper after Hirohito's death also expressed doubt that he was blameless.
column9: Emperor Hirohito, controversial World War II  leader of Japan dies.
column10: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87 after a long illness.  He was emperor During World War II and while some regard him as a powerless figurehead, others believe he was complicit in Japan's war crimes.  He is succeeded by his son Akihito.
column11: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87.  He ascended the throne in 1926 and presided over one of Japan's most tumultuous eras.  The last of the World War II generation of leaders, Hirohito was a controversial figure, even in death.  While western leaders generally, Asian leaders whose countries suffered under the Japanese military in World War II were cool.  While some historians regard him as a powerless figurehead, others believe that he was complicit in Japanese war crimes.  Hirohito died of cancer after a long illness and is succeeded by his son Akihito.
column12: Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in 1989 at the age of 87.  He ascended to the throne in 1926 and presided over one of Japan's most tumultuous eras.  The last of the World War II generation of leaders, Hirohito was a controversial figure, even in death.  While many western leaders praised him, many Asian leaders, whose countries suffered under the Japanese military during World War II were cool.  While most historians believe that Hirohito was a powerless figurehead, others believe that he had to have known of the massacre of thousands of Chinese in Nanking and of the plan to bomb Pearl Harbor.  Some believe that the U.S. covered up his complicity in war crimes after the war to avoid unrest in Japan.  After the U.S. dropped the atomic bomb on Japan, Hirohito announced Japan's surrender in a radio address to his nation.  After the war, Hirohito was just a symbol but the imperial system has remained important to the Japanese people.  Hirohito had traveled in Europe and had a preference for Western food and clothes.  With few real responsibilities, he spent much time in the study of marine biology.  He died of cancer after a long illness and  is succeeded by his son Akihito.

column3: The Summer Olympics will be rememberedfor moments of glory like that enjoy by U.S. diver Greg Louganisand the startling moment of disgrace when the gold be strippedfrom canadian sprinter Ben Johnson.The Soviet Union win the first u.s.-soviet Olympic medal contestsince 1976, get 55 gold medals to 37 for East Germany and 36for the United States. Host South Korea rise to fourth in the worldwith 12 golds.the fear of terrorism and massive civil unrest promptedextraordinary security, but neither bogey materialize as nearly10,000 athletes from 160 countries test their mettle in 16 daysof competition end Sunday.As always, there be shin moments of glory, from an openingceremony with exotic dancers and parachutists to a closing withhugs and tears, fireworks and dances, and the mascots of Seoul andbarcelona, the site of the 1992 Games, float together into thestarry night.louganis claim his second pair of gold medals after hittinghis head on a springboard. He say he talk with his coach aboutquitting the Olympics after hit the board and open a cutthat need five stitches to close.we walked and discuss all the things we have go through toget there, he said. I decide to stay in, and I'm glad I did.louganis say Sunday he be retire from dive to begin anacting career.What have be the high moment of the Games Ben Johnsonrocketing to victory over U.S. great Carl Lewis in a 100-meter dashworld record lead to the deep pain when the Canadian be caughtcheating with muscle-building anabolic steroids.twenty years from now, when most of the records set in Seoul arebroken, the impact of Johnson's disgrace will still be felt ifathletes and trainers heed the events here and end doping.there have be high points and some low points, and the mostimportant low point be Ben Johnson, Juan Antonio Samaranch,president of the International Olympic Committee, say today.That be indeed a blow.but catch Johnson and expel him and nine other athleteswith positive drug tests be an indication that we have win thebattle against doping, samaranch said.Sports officials from the United States and the Soviet Union onsunday announce Sunday they would join forces to work towards theelimination of drugs from sport.a statement issue by the U.S. and soviet Olympic committeessaid the groups would investigate use the exchange of testingteams, lab results and technical data; education programs; anduniform penalties.for the United States, a serious problem at the Seoul Games wasa rise tide of anti-american sentiment.it be exacerbate by NBC's coverage, which the Koreans saw asanti-korean and insensitive to local culture; the arrest of severalamerican athletes; and the perceived rudeness of the U.S. team atthe open ceremony.the Soviets, meanwhile, cultivate friendship by bring in thebolshoi Ballet, the Moscow Philharmonic, films, a photo exhibit andcopies of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda.The announcement of an unprecedented sports exchange programbetween South Korea and the Soviet Union and the arrival of thefirst soviet diplomats since World War II also warm relations.soviet athletes, as they do in Calgary, Canada, during thewinter Games, make a special effort to meet with local people.american athletes tend to isolate themselves.All those differences become apparent at the sport events,where Koreans often cheer louder for the Soviets or East Germansthan they do for Americans, despite a close 40-year relationshipwith the United States.Still, there be Louganis and other Americans to unabashedlycheer for like sister-in-law Florence Griffith Joyner and JackieJoyner-Kersee, who lead an assault on the track and field recordbooks, and Louganis.Griffith Joyner win golds in the 100, the 200 and the 400-meterrelay, and silver in the 1,600-meter relay. She set a world recordin the 200 and an Olympic record in the 100. Joyner-Kersee win twogolds, take the heptathlon with a world record 7,291 points andthe long jump with an Olympic mark of 24 feet, 3{ inches.the 1988 Summer Olympics, keep free ofterrorism but taint by drug scandals, close Sunday with thepealing of a medieval bell to symbolize the sorrow of parting. TheUnited States finish third in medals.the 1,000-year-old, 72-ton Emille Bell, which accord tokorean legend have the sad tone of any in the world, tolledfarewell to the more than 9,000 athletes from 160 nations whoparticipated in the 24th Olympiad.The 16-day event, conduct under extraordinary security,wrapped up with the Soviet Union win the lion's share of the237 medals events.the Soviets take home 132 medals, include 55 gold, the mostever in a Summer Olympics without a major-power boycott. EastGermany have 102 medals and 37 gold, and the United States 94 medalsand 36 gold.many felt that the United States be rob of a second-placetie for golds when judges award a bout to a south korean boxerover american Roy Jones in the 156-pound event on the final day ofcompetition.Because of boycott in 1980 and 1984, the Games be the firstmeeting between the Soviet Union and the United States since 1976in Montreal, and matchups between the two nations provide some ofthe Games' highlights.the U.S. men's volleyball team beat the Soviets to defend its1984 Olympic championship, provide consolation for America'supset in the men's basketball quarterfinals. America also defeatedthe Soviets in women's basketball and men's water polo.at least 1 billion people watch the Olympics via a 115-nation,worldwide tv hookup. The Seoul Games have the great number ofathletes (9,633), the most countries, the most gold medals and themost venues (34).communist North Korea, which demand a role in the Games,boycotted them, but the only sports power to follow suit be Cuba.Among the highlights:greg Louganis win the Olympic Spirit Award as top Americanathlete Sunday for win gold medals in platform and 3-meterspringboard diving. He accomplish the same feat in 1980 andbecame the first man to sweep the events twice.the 28-year-old Louganis, who hit his head on the board in thepreliminaries and receive five stitches, announce his retirementfrom diving and say he want to pursue acting.sisters-in-law Florence Griffith Joyner and JackieJoyner-Kersee lead an american assault on the record books in trackand field.griffith Joyner win golds in the 100, the 200 and the 400-meterrelay, and silver in the 1,600-meter relay. She set a world recordin the 200 and an Olympic record in the 100. Joyner-Kersee win twogolds, take the heptathlon with a world record 7,291 points andthe long jump with an Olympic mark of 24 feet, 3{ inches.kristin Otto of East Germany win six golds in swimming.american swimmer Matt Biondi win seven medals, five gold, whilejanet Evans earn three golds in the pool for the United States.Daniela Silivas of Romania dominate women's gymnastics,winning three golds, two silvers and a bronze.west german Steffi Graf complete tennis's first Golden slam,winning the gold medal as well as all four Grand Slam tournaments Wimbledon and the U.S., French and australian Opens in a calendaryear.there be low moments as well.canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, the most prominent of 10 athleteswho test positive for drugs, be strip of his gold medal inthe 100 meters and title of world's fast man, and fly home indisgrace, his career in jeopardy. He be accuse of usingmuscle-building steroids.four other medals two bulgarian weightlift golds, ahungarian weightlifing silver and a british judo bronze also werestripped for drugs, and five non-medalists test positive forsubstances range from caffeine to diuretics.early in the Games, five people connect to the korean boxingteam be suspend for attack a New Zealand referee after akorean lose a decision to a Bulgarian. Another Korean boxer stageda 67-minute sit-in in the ring to protest his loss. AnthonyHembrick, a U.S. boxer expect to win a gold, never get to fight;his coach misread the schedule and he miss the bus to the arena.two gold medal-winning U.S. swimmers be arrest for carryinga stone lion's head out of a hotel bar, but charges be dropped.american runner Johnny Gray kick a taxicab in an argument withits driver. He be arrest and released.security measures against the possibility of terrorism wereextraordinary, include metal detectors, numerous checkpoints andid cards, but except for scattered protests by student radicals,the Games proceed without incident.At the closing ceremonies, before the great torch wasextinguished, Korea pass the Olympic flag to representatives frombarcelona, site of the 1992 Games.Time run out for the U.S. athletes whenthe Winter Olympics end Sunday, with a team head by BrentRushlaw a tick away from a U.S. bobsled medal and Dutch speedskater Yvonne van Gennip a triple gold medalist with time to spare.the best America could do be six medals, its bad winter gamesshowing in 52 years. Two of the six be gold medals, win by BrianBoitano in figure skating and Bonnie Blair in speed skating. Blairalso win a bronze in speed skating, make her America's onlydouble winner.the Olympics wrap up Sunday evening with a rouse closingceremony before 60,000 people in McMahon Stadium. The 250 figureskaters who perform include past and present medal winners aswell as young skaters from Albertville, France, site of the 1992Winter Games, and Seoul, South Korea, site of this year's summergames.athletes march in carry miniature Olympic torches, andbanners read Until We Meet Again in eight languages weredraped along the top of the stands.earlier Sunday, Rushlaw and his three team members missedwinning the first U.S. bobsled medal in 32 years when they wasbeaten by .02 seconds for the bronze.van Gennip take more than six seconds off her own world recordin the 5,000 meters to win her third gold medal. american MaryDocter be 22.87 seconds behind. East Germans finish 2-3 in therace.finland win the hockey silver medal, hand the Soviets theirfirst loss of the Games, 2-1. The Soviets clinch the gold medalfriday night, and America finish seventh for the second straighttime.in 1936, America win just four medals, but only 51 wereavailable then. This time, 138 medals be hand out.the Soviets finish first in both number of gold medals, with11, and total medals, with 29, a record for the Winter Olympics.East Germany's athletes win nine golds, 25 overall; whileswitzerland's team come in third in both gold medals, five, andoverall medals, 15.Four other teams also best the United States in terms ofoverall medals: Austria, West Germany, Finland and the Netherlands.The late Jesse Owens, whose performance at the1936 Olympics put the lie to Hitler's boasts of racial superiority,picked up a fifth gold medal Wednesday for humanitariancontributions in the race of life.president Bush present the Congressional Gold Medal to hiswidow, Ruth Owens, in a ceremony at the White House also attendedby three daughters and teammates of the track legend.this Saturday mark the 10th anniversary of Owens' death at age66.the president later hail Owens's multiple gold medals in theberlin games a victory for humanity in prepared remarks to abanquet sponsor by the U.S. Olympic Committee.The Olympics, like democracy, be a kind of dialogue a waythat nations can converse in the language of friendly competition,not deadly conflict, Bush said.bush call Owens, who be black, an Olympic hero and anamerican hero every day of his life ... bear with the gift ofburning speed.he be always the fastest, say Bush, recall theafternoon in May 1935 when the Ohio State runner break three worldrecords and tie a fourth in the space of 45 minutes.talk about a guy in a hurry, Bush laughed. He be theepitome of that.at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, Owens capture four goldmedals in the broad jump, 100-meter dash, 200-meter dash and400-meter relay.the Berlin Games be to be the showcase of Hitler's theorieson the superiority of the master race until this 23-year-old kidshowed up, Bush said. It be an unrivaled athletic triumph. Butmore than that, it really be a triumph for all humanity.bush, borrow a phrase from Ruth Owens, say it be not thoseathletic feats but his humanitarian contributions in the race oflife that earn Owens the Congressional Gold Medal.Owens devote himself to work with youth and serving as aspecial ambassador for sports, say Bush. He say the athlete'slegacy live on through the Jesse Owens Games, a playgroundolympics; the Jesse Owens International Trophy for amateur athletesand the Jesse Owens Foundation, which award scholarships to needyyouth.despite the many honors, his great satisfaction come fromhis work with youth, say Mrs. Owens, 74.attending the ceremony along with Owens' family be formerOlympians Mal Whitfield, Harrison Dillard and Herb Douglass; formerteammates John Chavers, Samuel Devine and Chester Thomas, and twoohio Democrats, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum and Rep. Louis Stokes, whospearheaded the drive to strike the medal.the silver-haired Mrs. Owens, stand outside the White Houseafterwards, call the event absolutely beautiful. She added:i'm sure with the sun shin straight down, Jesse's watch us,too.the 1984 Summer Olympic Games weren't even over when advertisers begin clamor for pixie gymnast Mary Lou Retton. She go on to grin relentlessly through some $5 million worth of commercial endorsements -- surely an olympic record in itself. But when the 1988 Summer Games end Sunday night, so, too, do the chance for american athletes to follow in her footsteps. Ad agency executives, who spend every fourth year glue to their tv sets, hop to pick out the next star to hawk their clients' products, say that this Olympiad be a dud. "i suspect this will go down as the dullest in the history of the Olympics," say Jerry Della Femina, chairman of ad agency Della Femina McNamee WCRS. "This be the first Olympics without passion, and without passion you don't have testimonials. Without heroes, you don't have anyone that anyone want to emulate." On the surface, the Games seem to offer all the drama that usually make for lucrative endorsement contracts. Who could forget diver Greg Louganis smack his head on the springboard, then come back to win two gold medals? Or flamboyant Florence Griffith Joyner, her two-inch fingernails rake the air as she win the 100-meter sprint? But even these two, along with Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who win the women's heptathalon and the long jump, may find it more difficult than in previous years to turn gold medals into gold in the bank. The fact is, say many marketers, Olympic gold have lose much of its commercial luster. "i don't think it's big money like it use to be," say Michael Goldberg of National Media Group Inc., the New York sports-marketing firm that represent Ms. Retton. "It use to be kind of a knee-jerk reaction to do an ad campaign around an Olympic athlete. It just doesn't happen anymore." Certainly, this year's win Olympians will have no trouble secure contracts from specialize sports-equipment outfitters and speak invitations from obscure trade groups. But the major, high-paying endorsements -- such as those with soft-drink companies and fast-food outlets -- just don't seem to be surfacing, at least not yet. Earlier this year, sports marketers estimate that a gold medal win during the Summer Games could earn a personable athlete more than $1 million in endorsements. Now, marketers say, these medalists will be lucky to pull in $100,000 to $500,000 a year. Advertisers can reel off a litany of reasons why these Olympics aren't ignite much spark. For one thing, they suffer by comparison with the 1984 Summer Games, so exciting because they be hold in Los Angeles and because, in the absence of boycott Soviet-bloc countries, the Americans win 83 gold medals. The 1988 Games, by contrast, be broadcast from halfway around the world, and the Soviets trounce the Americans, 55 gold medals to 36. What's more, marketers say, this year's drug scandals cast a pall over the Games, especially the incident involve canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, who lose his gold medal after test positive for steroids. NBC's tv coverage also get its share of the blame. Marketers say it be so bland and skip so frequently from one event to another that there be little chance for excitement to build. The constant commercial interruptions, which lead to ratings that be much low than expected, didn't help, either. During most of the past Games, "there be enough continuous tv coverage so that, much like a soap opera, it be possible to get involve in the lives and in the competition," say Leigh Steinberg, attorney for ice-skater Brian Boitano, a gold medalist at the 1988 Winter Games. But not this summer, he says. recent changes in Olympic rules, meanwhile, have lead to a glut of Olympians in search of endorsement deals. Before the 1984 Games, most Olympic athletes weren't allow to make commercials unless they give up their amateur status. Now, they can appear in as many ads as they want, but the income must go into a trust fund for train expenses. "every year, more and more olympic people be out there want to do commercials -- basically, everybody be available," say Daisy Sinclair, a vice president with ad agency Ogilvy Group Inc. As a result, while once an "aura" surround an Olympian, now "the bloom be off." Companies also be become more sophisticated in their approach to celebrity endorsements. Increasingly cost conscious, they will no longer hook up with an olympian just because the company president like the athlete's sport. And after years of pay big bucks to Olympic star only to see them fade into obscurity, companies have finally get the hint that olympian fame be of the most fleeting variety. "if you think your phone will ring off the hook if (you win) a gold medal, it isn't go to happen anymore," say Stephen Disson, senior vice president of marketing for ProServ Inc., a Washington sports-marketing firm. Companies now know that "six months from now there will be other heroes from other sport events" for them to consider. Ad agency BBDO Worldwide's attitude toward the Olympics be become typical. It use sports stars in its commercials for Pepsi Light and Oppenheimer Mutual Funds but have no plans to call on any of 1988's Olympians. "I prefer to use athletes who be in the public eye on a regular basis, like football and basketball players," say Charles Miesmer, the agency's executive creative director. "People like Michael Jordan have 10-plus years in their sports careers, all in a row, so I don't have to worry about the public saying, 'Carl who?'" And don't look for any of 1988's winners to start show up on Wheaties boxes, either. General Mills Inc., which have feature Ms. Retton and decathalon gold-medalist Bruce Jenner on its Wheaties boxes in the past, say it look for three qualities in an endorser: career achievement, popular appeal and off-the-field accomplishments. A spokeswoman say that none of this year's crop meet all three criteria. so far, Ms. Joyner-Kersee have have the most visible endorsements. even before the Olympics began, she have make commercials for Primatene mist and 7-up. And, accord to her agent, Pearl Hodge of World Class Management, she be now "in the process" of sign with McDonald's Corp., to work on behalf of its efforts to aid underprivileged children. Ms. Joyner-Kersee's sister-in-law, Ms. Griffith Joyner, may soon take the endorsement lead. Advertisers say with her good looks and fashion flare, she be attract more interest than any of the other medal winners. (The sprinter's manager couldn't be reach for comment.) Another olympian with endorsement potential be swimmer Matt Biondi, who win five gold medals. Mr. Biondi have already sign a swim-wear contract with Arena USA Inc., and Parkes Brittain, his agent at Advantage International Inc., say his client "will definitely be in a high-income ring, the high you can name." then there be Mr. Louganis. Since win two gold medals during the 1984 Summer Olympics, the diver have have little luck with major endorsements. And a few marketing executives say that even his second sweep of the diving events may not up his potential. "when most advertisers be look for the male hero, the word 'macho' trails along very closely," say Marty Blackman of Blackman & Raber, a sports-marketing firm in New York. "I don't find Louganis a macho guy." Still, other marketing professionals say that Mr. Louganis's dramatic recovery after smash his head have secure the diver's future. His manager, Jim Babbitt, won't comment on any contract offers. He will say, however, that his client have "done just fine. He isn't unhappy. He dive to perform; he doesn't dive for dollars." ---winning EndorsementsThere be only one former olympian among the top sports endorsers of last year.athlete: Arnold Palmer (Golf)NATIONAL of Olympic goldturned into disappointment Saturday as East Germany's Katarina Wittwon her second straight Olympic championship and canadian ElizabethManley take home the silver before a crowd of cheer countrymen.it's over. Back to school, say Thomas, who win the bronzemedal despite three faulty landings. I'm not go to make anyexcuses. I be really skate well this week. It wasn't suppose tohappen, I guess. But I tried.while the top two skaters in the world stag a shootout tomusic from Bizet's Carmen, Manley be so sensational in thefreestyle that she finish first with seven judges. combine witha fourth in the compulsory figures and a third-place finish in theshort program earlier in the week, the performance put Manley insecond place.witt, a three-time world champion from East Germany, become thefirst repeat singles champion since Dick Button take Olympic goldin 1948 and '52. Sonja Henie of Norway be the only woman to do itbefore Witt, win in 1928, 1932 and 1936.Thomas, of San Jose, Calif., the first black to win a u.s.figure skate crown and the 1986 world champion, skate poorlysaturday after do well earlier in the Games.By contrast, Manley have the sellout crowd at the OlympicSaddledome enraptured. They cheered, hoot and stamp their feetwhen she finish hit every element of her program.jill Trenary of Minnetonka, Minn., finish fourth. She wasfifth head into the long program, worth 50 percent of theoverall score.thomas' bronze be the third figure skate medal here for theunited States. Brian Boitano win the men's crown, and a bronze inpairs go to Jill Watson and Peter Oppegard.In addition to the three figure skate medals, the U.S. teamhad three speed-skating medals: one each gold, silver and bronze.speed skater Bonnie Blair, America's only double medalist, triedagain Saturday in the 1,500 meters but finish fourth, well offthe pace. She win the gold in the 500 and the bronze in the 1,000meters.As the Olympics wind up its next-to-last day, the Soviet Unionhad 27 medals, include 11 golds, while East Germany in secondplace have 22, include nine golds.florence Griffith Joyner twice smasheda world record Thursday as she blaze to a gold medal in the200-meter sprint.she also stay on target to become the second woman to win fourtrack and field gold medals in a single Olympics.Griffith Joyner dash to her second gold in 21.34 seconds,shattering the world mark she have set just 90 minutes earlier inher semifinal heat. In that race, she run 21.56, eclipse the9-year-old mark of 21.71 set in 1979 by Marita Koch of East Germanyand equal three times since.in her 200 quarterfinal heat Wednesday, Griffith Joyner run anolympic record 21.76 seconds.griffith Joyner, who set an Olympic record Sunday in win the100 meters, have a big lead Thursday as she turn the curve for thefinal 100 meters. She glide to the wire.i know I can run much faster, she said. I felt veryrelaxed. That's the key.griffith Joyner, 28, be schedule to run in the 400-meter relaysaturday and may compete in the 1,600-meter relay that day.noted for her long, paint fingernails and racy, colorfulbodysuits, Griffith Joyner of Los Angeles have a chance to match the1984 quadruple gold medal performance of U.S. sprinter and longjumper Carl Lewis, and by Fanny Blankers-Koen of the Netherlands in1948.tonight in the big stadium in Barcelona the athletics be dominate by thefour relay finals. Tonight it be nation versus nation.What the relays demonstrate more clearly than any other athletics event isthat at the Olympics the race have traditionally go to affluent countries -or to those, rather, that choose to lavish resources on athletes.the US have comfortably win the most relay medals, follow by Britain, theformer Soviet Union, the former West Germany (not even count the six wonbefore 1939), the former East Germany, France and Canada.Britain alone have win more relay medals (23) than all the Caribbean islands(nine) and Africa (four, include one for South Africa). The Dutch, withone, have more relay medals than all the nations of Asia (nil) and SouthAmerica (nil) combined. The Cuban women's 100 metres relay teams of 1968 and1972 be the only women from outside the developed world to have win relaymedals.with a little luck - with their nerve-stretching hand-overs the relaysalways require a little luck - the develop countries will continue thegentle redistribution of medals. But although they have talent, few canmatch the strength in depth of the traditional relay powers.the US 4x400m squad have be weaken by the injury to Danny Everett. Evenso they rest Steve Lewis, the 400m silver medallist, in last night'ssemi-finals. In the 4x100m heats James Jett replace Carl Lewis but Lewisran impressively in last night's semi-final and tonight will pursue hiseighth Olympic gold.one thing that become clear on Thursday, when Lewis win his seventh goldwith victory in the long jump, be that while win at the Olympics maybring other athletes excitement or relief, Lewis simply adore theexperience.when Voula Patoulidou, look up at the giant video screen after thewomen's 100m hurdle final, suddenly realised, to her astonishment, that shehad win a gold medal, she go delightfully and utterly potty, as do theother 25 Greeks in the stadium, include Queen Sofia of Spain.Lewis, on the other hand, seem unsurprised when Mike Powell be unable tooverhaul him in the long jump. even though the long jump have not finishedand even though 5,000m runners be trudge through a semi-final, Lewisbegan at once an extremely hammy lap-and-a-half of honour.he try to orchestrate a mexican wave. This be a man who derive immensepleasure from win in front of a packed house. Lewis will be difficult tosuppress tonight.noureddine Morcelli of Algeria will be hard to beat in the men's 1,500m.Morcelli be one of five Africans in the final striving to increase theircontinent's tally of just three Olympic medals (all Kenyan) in this event.even here there be a US connection: Morcelli attend Riverside CommunityCollege in California, to hone his run on good tracks.on Thursday night, Morcelli cruise through his heat in first place afterthe gentle push on the accelerator. The Moroccan Rachid Al-Basir followedhim down the straight, a respectful step behind, loom over his fellowarab and glance anxiously round like a bodyguard. Morcelli have not beenbeaten in the 1,500m since 1990.
column5: International and Olympic gold eludes or elates competitors and nations.
column6: International athletic competition, particularly the Olympics, can bring glory and wealth to some.  It can also bring disgrace to those caught using drugs.  Nations as well as individuals share the honors.  The former Soviet Union seemed to always top the "most-medals-won" list.  However, the U.S. superstars enjoy the most fame.
column7: In the world of international competition, the Olympics are special.  It is here that national pride is displayed, individual dreams are realized and fame is attained.  The summer Olympics with its gymnastics, track and field, and swimming events will showcase superstars such as Mary Lou Retton, Carl Lewis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Greg Louganis, some of whom capitalize on their fame and glory with lucrative advertising contracts.  The Winter Olympics generally highlight the figure skaters, speed skaters and downhill skiers.  Sometimes an Olympian acquires lifelong fame, as happened to Jesse Owens, who in 1936 soundly defeated Hitler's "master race" competitors.
column8: In the world of international competition, the Olympics are special.  True, world records can be established elsewhere, such as at the World University or the World Cup games.  But consider, in the 1988 Summer Olympics from Seoul, Korea, at least one billion people, via a 115-nation worldwide TV hookup, watched more than 9,000 athletes from 160 countries compete.  Sometimes dreams of Olympic gold are dashed, as happened to U.S. figure skater Debi Thomas, who, expecting gold, only placed third.  National pride is a factor.  The 1988 summer Olympics in Seoul, Korea gave us the first meeting between Soviet Union and United States competitors since 1976.  The Soviets captured most medals, the U.S. third most.  However, among those "third-most" U.S. competitors were superstar gold medalists Greg Louganis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Jackie Joyner-Kersee. Unfortunately, at these games Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson was disgraced by having his gold medal stripped away because of drug use.  The Olympics can lead to material wealth, such as experience by 1984 gymnast pixie, Mary Lou Retton or to long-lasting fame such as that of Jesse Owens, the black American who in the 1936 Berlin Olympics put to the lie Adolph Hitler's theories of a master race.
column9: Olympic Games: Good or Bad, But Always Center Stage
column10: The US has had many Olympic heroes such as Jesse Owens in 1936, and FlorenceGriffith Joyner, Carl Lewis,, and Greg Louganis more recently.  But US teamshave not always won the most medals, losing mostly to the Soviets.  Thegames generate greatest interest in the US when their teams dominate.
column11: The US had its worst Winter Olympic showing in 52 years the1988 Games withfew medal winners.  In the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, the US faired betterbut was still outpaced by the Soviets.  Those games were marred by drugusage and suffered from poor TV coverage.  US medal winners included theflamboyant Florence Griffith Joiner, her sister-in-law Jackie Joyner-Kersee,Greg Louganis, and Carl Lewis.  An earlier Olympic hero, the late JesseOwens was honored with a Congressional Gold Medal.  The more affluentnations continue to dominate in the Olympics, especially in relay events.
column12: The US had its worst Winter Olympic showing in 52 years the 1988 Games.  Theonly gold medal winners were Brian Boitano in figure skating and BonnieBlair in speed skating.  Debi Thomas, the US hope in figure skating had tosettle for a bronze after East Germany's Katarina Witt took gold andCanadian Elizabeth Manley the silver.  The Seoul Summer Games were a muchbrighter arena for the US with multiple gold medal winners, but the Sovietswere the overall winners.  Drug usage disqualified several athletes, mostnotably Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson.  Because the US showing did not equaltheir domination in the Los Angeles Games four years earlier (boycotted bythe Soviets) and because of unimaginative TV coverage, lucrative endorsementcontracts did not appear to be forthcoming for the winners.The late Jesse Owens, hero of the 1936 Berlin Games was honored with aCongressional Gold Medal, which was given to his widow by President Bush.Teams from affluent nations usually dominate Olympic relay events, and thatwas expected to happen in Barcelona in 1992.  The US has an imposing groupof runners in those events.In non-Olympic years, World Cup and World University Games featured manysuccessful Olympic athletes.

column3: Mourners sob and shake their heads in disbeliefsunday as tens of thousands view the flower-draped body of AndreiD. Sakharov in a huge outpouring of grief for the man describe ashis country's conscience.crimean Tatars and jewish refuseniks two of the groupssakharov help join rank-and-file Communists, teachers andengineers in file past the body of the physicist, Nobel PeacePrize winner, human rights advocate and legislator.based on official sources, an estimate 45,000 people filedthrough, and the flow of mourners continue into the night. Afriend of the family, speaking on condition of anonymity, say heheard estimates that 70,000 mourners view the body before it wasreturned to Sakharov's apartment at midnight.my God! Forgive us! one elderly woman cry out as she sawsakharov's body in an open coffin, slop to the floor of thebeige marble Youth Palace in central Moscow. She apparently meantto apologize for not recognize his contributions earlier.a mound of red and white carnations grow steadily at Sakharov'sfeet, and a spotlight be focus on a portrait show Sakharovwith his hands over his mouth, deep in thought. An organ and pianoalternated dirges.sakharov die Thursday alone in his study at the age of 68,apparently of a heart attack, end a three-decade fight againstthe jailing of innocent people, for free emigration, fordisarmament and other causes.sunday be the first of two days of memorial ceremonies, and theoutpouring be remarkable for a man who be once ostracize andcommitted to nearly seven years in internal exile in the remotecity of Gorky.There be signs of grief throughout this snowy capital of 9million people, as though a government leader have died. The hugeline of mourners, sometimes four deep and heavily bundle againstbelow-zero temperatures, stretch a mile from the palace andpoured continuously out of a subway station.so many people want to see Sakharov's body lie in state thatauthorities extend the viewing period by four hours and move thecoffin so two rows of mourners could file past.roald Z. Sagdeyev, a member of the official funeral commission,said about 3,000 people an hour be arrive initially, but theofficial news agency Tass say that rate double later, make fora total of 45,000 by nighttime.police line the sidewalks where people waited. Sakharov's widowyelena Bonner, pleased authorities be not turn people away,praised them for be very democratic.in her first detailed public comments on her husband's death,bonner say she hop he will not be idolized.i would not wish a living person he have live an animated,happy life to be turn into an icon, an icon which could be usedby various forces in their interests, Bonner say in an interviewbroadcast on soviet TV.She said, however, that she hop Sakharov's writings, publishedabroad long ago, will become widely available in his homeland sothere can be a conversation of the people of the future withandrei Dmitrievich.Mourners carry small portraits of Sakharov and red and whitecarnations to place near his coffin. One man, Sergei Kosykh,brought his 7-year-old daughter along.my daughter, who be be bring up with the belief thatthere be nobody great than (soviet founder Vladimir) Lenin, Ihave bring her here today just to show her the person greaterthan Lenin, he said.a middle-aged woman draw from russian literature to reflect onsakharov's contributions.he be like the man from one of Maxim Gorky's tales who usedhis own bleeding and live heart as a torch to lead people tolight and truth, say the woman, a teacher who decline to giveher name.sakharov always be tell the truth and by do so forcedour leadership to do the same, say Boris Sorokin, a 50-year-olddesigner.unofficial shrines sprout outside Sakharov's southeast Moscowapartment, where candles flicker alongside his portrait. Outsidethe offices of the weekly newspaper Moscow News on Pushkin Square,a popular gathering place for political activists, portraits andflowers be displayed.an entry in a notebook for mourners' comments outside Sakharov'sapartment building declared, The conscience of the nation hasdied.moscow News an organ of the official press, which have brandedSakharov an utterly ignorant person take the rare step Sundayof publish a special edition devote to the activist.four pages be fill with pictures of him, condolencetelegrams from exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn and PresidentBush and a text of Sakharov's last public remarks, a speech hedelivered hours before his death in which he say the Soviethierarchy be lead the country to a catastrophe.on Sunday night, Soviet TV's newscast Seven Days also paidtribute to Sakharov, lead the program with a 10-minute report onhim.The Communist Party daily Pravda publish a poem by YevgenyYevtushenko that read in part:history's most peaceful rebel, in dying, do not come downfrom the cross, but leave a horrifying hole in the moral fabric ofthe world.on Saturday, Pravda publish what amount to a public apologyto Sakharov.President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other soviet leaders say inan obituary that Sakharov have be the victim of grossinjustices and praise him as a man of honesty and sincerity.bonner, Sakharov's constant companion and fellow human rightsactivist, sit close to the coffin, clutch a black handbag andperiodically close her eyes. A son and daughter from his firstmarriage and son and daughter of Bonner also attended, along withfour grandchildren.gorbachev be expect to pay his last respects monday, when thefuneral be planned, and on Sunday be represent by Yevgeny M.Primakov, chairman of the funeral commission and a non-votingmember of the country's rule Politburo.The foreign dignitaries expect to take part in Monday'sceremonies include Lech Walesa, head of Poland's Solidaritymovement, who will be make his first trip to the Soviet Union,and former refuseniks Yosef Begun and Vladimir Slepak, who now livein Israel.Israel's best know soviet dissident, Natan Sharansky, wasrefused a visa when he apply for permission to travel to Moscow,said Sharansky's spokesman, Avraham Ben-Yaakov. Begun and Slepaksaid they would lay a wreath on Sakharov's grave in sharansky'sname.soviet media once brand Andrei D. column5: Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov, Soviet human rights activist, died 1989
column6: Andrei Sakharov, Soviet hydrogen bomb developer and prominent 1970s dissident, won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. He was exiled to Gorky from 1980-1986. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but urged improved human rights.  In April 1989 he was elected to parliament. He died in December 1989, aged 68, of an apparent heart attack.
column7: Andrei Sakharov helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb but urged its limitation. He was a prominent 1970s dissident and won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. In January 1980, after criticizing Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Breshnev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev allowed Sakharov and his wife Yelena Bonner's return to Moscow in December 1986. Their apartment became a mecca for aid-seekers. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but urged improvement in human rights and a nuclear testing ban.  In April 1989 he was elected to parliament after Soviet physicists voted secretly to nominate him. Sakharov, 68, died in December 1989 of an apparent heart attack after urging creation of an opposition party.
column8: Physicist Andrei D. Sakharov became the youngest member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb, but urged limiting its production and testing. He was a prominent 1970s dissident and won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. In January 1980, after Sakharov criticized Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Breshnev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev allowed Sakharov and his wife Yelena Bonner to return to Moscow in December 1986. There they lived simply in a two-room, seventh-floor apartment which became a mecca for Soviets seeking aid. Sakharov supported Gorbachev's reforms but called for speedier progress in human rights, political prisoner liberation, and a nuclear testing ban. In November 1988 he visited the US, underwent medical tests, and promoted a world peace foundation. In April 1989, he was elected to parliament after Soviet physicists voted secretly to nominate him. He warned of national economic catastrophe. Sakharov died alone in his Moscow apartment in December 1989 at the age of 68, of an apparent heart attack, hours after urging creation of an opposition party. World and Soviet leaders and press eulogized him as a sincere man who suffered great injustice and helped change Soviet society. 45,000 grievers filed past Sakharov's body. Sakharov had four children and four grandchildren.
column9: Sakharov Dead. Soviet Physicist, Rights Advocate, Nobel Peace Prize Winner
column10: Andrei Sakharov died in December 1989. The Soviet physicist helped develop the hydrogen bomb, but was better known for winning the  Nobel Peace Prize. His advocacy of human rights and criticism of the Kremlin resulted in a seven-year exile. His obituary constituted a public apology for the treatment afforded him.
column11: Andrei Sakharov was a physicist who helped develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb. He later gained widespread fame as a human rights advocate and the 1979 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.His constant criticism irked the Kremlin. In 1980 he criticized the invasion of Afghanistan and Breznev exiled him to Gorky. Gorbachev freed him in 1986. Sakharov praised Gorbachev on foreign affairs, but criticized his economic policies. Sakharov was elected to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies in April 1989.Sakharov died suddenly on 14 December 1989. His obituary, signed by Gorbachev, was tantamount to  public apology.
column12: Andrei Sakharov, 68, a Nobel Peace Prize winner and a human rights activist, died in Moscow on 14 December 1989. Sakharov was a physicist who attained hero status for his work on the Soviet hydrogen bomb. He later made himself a nuisance to the Kremlin with his continual calls for improvement in the rights of the Soviet people. In 1973 the International League for Human Rights gave him an award, but he was not able to accept it until his first visit to New York City in 1989. His humanitarianism won him the 1975 Noble Peace Prize.His gadfly activities throughout the 1970s exasperated the Kremlin. In January 1980, when he criticized the invasion of Afghanistan, President Brezhnev exiled him to the closed city of Gorky.President Gorbachev freed Sakharov in December 1986. He and Yelena Bonner, his wile and fellow activist, settled in Moscow. He praised Gorbachev for the new direction in foreign affairs, but loudly criticized the slow pace of economic reform. In April 1989 Sakharov was elected to membership in the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies.Sakharov's obituary, signed by Gorbachev and published in Pravda, and the outpouring of remorse constituted a public apology for his exile.

If workers in mines not include in current negotiations join in sympathy strikes, a total of 300,000 miners could be on strike, he said. column5: Coal miners strike in major coal regions around the world.
column6: Major strikes, mostly by coal miners seeking higher wages, seriously disrupted industries throughout the world from 1987 to 1994 in South Africa, Poland, Romania, the Ukraine, Siberia and Central Asia in the Soviet Union.  In the United States, coal miners' strikes occurred in Virginia and West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky.
column7: Instances of industrial unrest for wage increases 1987-1994:August 1987:  South African black gold and coal miners strike; August 1988: Jastrzebie, Poland coal miners and port workers strike; June 1989: Virginia, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky coal miners walkout; July 1989 and November 1989: strikes by coal miners and factory workers throughout Ukraine, Siberia and Central Asia; June 1991: coal miners strike in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine spread to all major Soviet Union coal regions; July 1992: Polish copper-producing combine strikes in sympathy with coal miners; August 1993: Coal miners strike in Romania's Jui Valley; June 1994: coal miners strike in Donetsk Region, Ukraine.
column8: Worldwide industrial strikes for wage increases 1987-1994:August 4, 1987:  200,000 South African black gold and coals miners may begin a strike.August 17-18, 1988:  Coalmine workers in Jastrzebie, southwest of Warsaw, went on strike to demand legalization of Solidarity and higher wages.  Szczecin port workers and Morcinek mine workers declared sympathy strikes.June 16, 1989:  Pennsylvania, Indiana and Kentucky coal miners walked out in sympathy for miners in Virginia and West Virginia.July 19-21, 1989:  Strikes in the Soviet Union by coal miners and factory workers have shut down over 200 mines in the country's top coal-producing regions from the Ukraine through Siberia and Central Asia.November 2, 1989:  Miners in the Northern Vorkuta region expanded their strike and blocked coal shipments.June 6, 1991:  A one-day coal miners' strike in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine spread to all major coal regions.July 21, 1992:  A copper-producing combine in Lublin, Poland went on strike as coal-mining unions staged stoppages in a third of the country's pits.August 9, 1993:  Coal miners in Romania's Jui Valley went on strike again.June 29, 1994:  Miners at six coal production associations and pits in the Donetsk Region of the Ukraine went on strike.
column9: Minors throughout the world use strikes for political and economic ends.
column10: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but also to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  In addition to higher wages, miners in the Soviet Union struck for more local control of their industry and in Poland miners struck for the legalization of Solidarity.
column11: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but also to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  Miners in Poland, Romania and in every region of the Soviet Union have struck for higher wages and better living conditions and also and for more local control. In Poland, miners struck for legalization of Solidarity.  In South Africa miners struck for better wages and working conditions and in the U.S. miners walked of f the job in sympathy for fellow miners in a bitter dispute with a coal company.
column12: Miners throughout the world have used strikes not only to achieve economic gains, but to gain greater control over their industries and to achieve political ends.  Miners in Poland struck not only for higher wages, but also for the legalization of Solidarity and the reinstatement of workers fired for union activity.  They also wanted a clear restructuring strategy for their industry.  Coal miners throughout the Soviet Union struck for more local control of their industries as well as better living and working conditions.  The labor unrest was the Soviet Union's worst in 60 years.  Until Gorbachev rose to power in 1985, strikes were not tolerated.  Miners in Kazakhstan and the Ukraine demanded real sovereignty for the 15 Soviet republics as well as a law to allow private ownership of industry and land.  Coal miners in Romania, spearheaded violent anti-reform rampages and well as demand for increased wages.In South Africa coal and gold miners were to begin a strike for higher wages and working conditions.  Coal and gold account for more than half of South Africa's foreign currency earnings.In the United States coal miners in four states walked off the job in sympathy for miners in a bitter dispute with Pittston Coal Group.

column5: Storm causes death and injuries from Midwest throughout East coast.
column6: A powerful storm swept across the Midwest and into the Eastern states leaving 27 dead, hundreds injured, and thousands homeless. A tornado laid waste to Huntsville, AL, killing fourteen. Four people were killed in Palmetto, Georgia, and seven children died in a school in Newburgh, NY when a roof collapsed.
column7: A powerful storm brought tornadoes, high winds, and thunderstorms across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Twenty-seven people were killed, more than 500 injured, and thousands left homeless. The worst hit was Huntsville, AL when a tornado laid waste a wide swath through the city causing the death of at least fourteen people and over 400 injuries. Another tornado killed four people in Palmetto, GeorgiaIn Newburgh, NY, strong winds caused a school roof to collapse killing seven children and injuring eighteen. The storm caused one death in New Jersey and another in New York City.
column8: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, thunderstorms Wednesday and Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast, and Northeast. Reportedly, 27 people were killed, more than 500 injured, and thousands left homelessThe worst hit was Huntsville, AL when a tornado with winds up to 250 mph laid waste a wide swath through the city and caused the death of at least fourteen people and injuries to over 400. Many were trapped for a while in vehicles, apartment complexes and shopping areas. The rubble was 10-14 feet deep and rescuers were hampered by darkness and plunging temperatures. State officials estimated the damage in excess of $100 million. Four people were killed by a tornado in Georgia.Moving north Thursday, the storm caused heavy damage in Illinois, Pennsylvania, Washington, DC, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, Delaware, New Jersey and New York. In Newburgh, NY, a tree crashed through a school roof killing at least seven children and injuring eighteen. One person died in New Jersey and another in New York City. Thunderstorms dropped large hailstones in Indiana and Tennessee. Kentucky and Louisiana were damaged by 65 mph winds. Snow was falling west of a cold front moving east from the Rockies.
column9: Violent storms spawned by cold front ravage the East, 27 dead.
column10: A powerful cold front, spawning tornados, violent thunderstorms and heavy rainfall, moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16.  Twenty-six were killed with injuries or damage reported in 13 states.  Huntsville, Alabama was hit hardest, when a tornado caused $100 million in damage.
column11: A powerful cold front moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16, spawning tornados, violent thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall.  Thirteen states reported deaths, injuries, or damage.  Hardest hit was Huntsville, Alabama, where a tornado leveled a shopping district, apartment development, and elementary school.  Seventeen were killed, 463 injured, and 1000 left homeless.  Damages were estimated at $100 million.  President Bush declared Huntsville a disaster area.  Marilyn Quayle and Alabama's governor and senators toured the area on November 18.  This storm front killed nine others, including seven school children in Newburgh, New York.
column12: A powerful cold front moved through the eastern half of the United States on November 15 and 16, carving a deadly path of destruction.  The abnormally warm air preceding the front spawned tornados, violent thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall.  Tornados struck in at least seven states.Hardest hit was Huntsville, Alabama, where a tornado roared down a major street near rush hour, leveling a shopping district, apartment development, and elementary school.  Seventeen were killed, 463 injured, and 1000 left homeless.  Witnesses recall a huge roar, water and winds, screaming, hiding, and helping others.  Roads were blocked and power and telephone lines were cut.  Rescuers, including National Guard troops, worked all night sifting through the rubble.  Damages were estimated at $100 million, with about $1 million needed to provide emergency clothing and temporary housing.  President Bush declared Huntsville a disaster area.  Marilyn Quayle, wife of the Vice President, toured the area with Alabama's governor and senators on November 18. Near Newburgh, New York high winds caused an elementary school cafeteria to cave in on November 16.  Seven children were killed and 18 injured.  A truck driver also was killed in New Jersey and a woman died in Illinois.  Injuries occurred in five other states.

Larry Seaquist, commander of the Iowa untillast May.The main criticism be that the big gun require gunpowder packedin silk bags to fire 16-inch-diameter shells from its 62-foot-longbarrel. It work like the breech-loaded guns that roar during thecivil War: A shell be place into a barrel and then charge withgunpowder in a separate package.in the Iowa's case, 660 pounds of powder six 110-pound bags be need to fire a projectile weigh up to 2,700 pounds at aspeed of 2,500 feet per second. James Bush of the Center for Defense Information, aprivate think tank often critical of Pentagon policy, say the Iowaexplosion could have be cause by smolder debris, a blowbackor a mishap in the handling of powder.it wasn't unexpected. It wasn't a surprise. This be dangeroustechnology. It's archaic, Bush said. The 20-mile range ofthe 16-inch gun be almost worthless in an era when missiles can befired at much great distances.we can do almost anything with a missile and do it better,bush said.Battleships reach their heyday in World War I and wereintended to fight other ships.the Iowa, first launch in 1942, be the first of an entireclass of U.S. battlewagons build to conquer Japan.It support Marine amphibious landings and shell shoretargets, but the aircraft carrier emerge as the Navy's top weaponbecause naval battles be wag without ships ever see eachother. Fitzgerald, a chaplain, in a service at the Norfolk NavalAir Station.
