column5: Bush Attends Memorial for 47 Killed in USS Iowa Explosion
column6: On Monday President Bush and the USS Iowa commander attended a memorial at Norfolk Naval Air Station for 47 sailors that were killed in an explosion of the battleship's No. 2 gun turret last Wednesday. The Iowa was conducting firing exercises near Puerto Rico at the time. The Navy is investigating.
column7: On Monday President Bush and the USS Iowa commander attended a memorial at Norfolk Naval Air Station for 47 sailors that were killed in an explosion of the battleship's No. 2 gun turret last Wednesday.The Iowa, a WW II battleship returned to duty in 1982, was conducting firing exercises near Puerto Rico at the time. The Defense Department said the blast possibly originated with a gunpowder bag used to fire the one-ton shells. Eleven people inside the turret, all on the lowest deck loading powder, survived. The Navy is investigating the accident. Firings of the 16-inch guns have been suspended.
column8: Relatives of the 47 victims killed in the explosion aboard the Iowalast Wednesday were among the 6000 people who attended a memorial atNorfolk Naval Air Station on Monday. President Bush and Iowa commanderCapt. Moosally attended the service.The USS Iowa, a WW II battleship returned to duty in 1982, wasconducting firing exercises northeast of Puerto Rico when the blastoccurred in the No. 2 gun turret. The Defense Department said itpossibly originated from a 110-pound gunpowder bag used to fire shellsweighing over a ton a distance of 23 miles. Eleven people inside theturret, all on the lowest deck loading powder, survived the Navysaid. The gun had not been fired.  Two of the 11 survivors stood atopthe fire-blackened turret when the Iowa docked at Norfolk Naval BaseSunday.The Navy released a videotape of the explosion made by an officer ofthe Iowa who was recording the firing of the big guns, but it won'tspeculate on the cause of the tragedy.The Navy is investigating the causes of the accident and the SenateArmed Services Committee will hold hearings.The Pentagon ordered a moratorium on firings of the 16-inchguns.
column9: Explosion in WWII-era battleship kills 47 during training exercise
column10: An explosion in a battleship Iowa gun turret on April 19, 1989 during a training exercise killed 47. Investigators say the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit. In Norfolk, thousands welcomed the Iowa home and President Bush spoke at a memorial service. Critics say the WWII-era 16-inch guns are outdated and dangerous.
column11: An explosion in the battleship Iowa's No.2 turret on Wednesday, April 19, 1989, during a training exercise NE of Puerto Rico, killed 47. Naval investigators concluded the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit from a powder hoist. Thousands welcomed the Iowa home to Norfolk on Sunday, with sailors with black arm bands lining the ship's rails and surviving guncrew members standing atop the blackened No.2 turret. On Monday, President Bush spoke to mourners at a Norfolk memorial service. A moratorium was placed on firing the WWII-era 16-inch guns, which are criticized as outdated and dangerous. The Senate Armed Services Committee will hold hearings on the explosion.
column12: An explosion in the battleship Iowa's No.2 turret on Wednesday, April 19, 1989, during a training exercise NE of Puerto Rico, killed 47. Naval investigators concluded the explosion occurred while gunpowder was in transit from a powder hoist. Crew in upper turret chambers died instantly in the explosion and fire while those at lower levels suffocated as the blast sucked out oxygen. Eleven escaped from powder magazines at the turret's base. On Sunday, 3000 family and friends welcomed the Iowa home to Norfolk. Sailors with black arm bands lined the Iowa's rails and two surviving guncrew members stood on the blackened No.2 turret. On Monday, President Bush spoke to 8000 mourners at a memorial service and Iowa commander Capt. Fred Moosally praised the victims. A moratorium was placed on firing the 16-inch guns, which are criticized as outdated and dangerous, using gunpowder packed in silk bags that are rammed into a gun after the shell and ignited by electric spark. Newer guns' powder is packed in metal containers. Missiles have integrated propellants. The four WWII-era battleships came out of mothballs in 1982. Critics say they have outlived their purpose but the Navy disagrees and is keeping them in service. The Senate Armed Services Committee will hold hearings on the explosion.

column3: here be a chronology of Hurricane Hugo's destructive path acrossthe Caribbean into South Carolina:Residents take forecasters at their wordwhen they warn of Hurricane Hugo's fury, and the low number ofdeaths from the powerful storm can be credit to this healthyrespect, authorities said.the storm, which cause billions in damage, claim 17 lives insouth Carolina, and only two be in the Charleston area, whichbore the brunt of Hugo's 135 mph winds.we just feel very thankful about that, say Mayor Joseph P.Riley Jr. Several thousands of people who be in the sheltersand the tens of thousands of people who evacuate inland werepotential victims of injury and death.riley and other officials credit residents with monitor thehurricane as it spin toward Charleston, and heed evacuationwarnings.the last big storm to hit South Carolina be Hurricane David in1979, which hit the coast after pound southern Florida.Since then several big storms have threaten but veered away,and officials be worried that Charlestonians wouldn't heed Hugo'swarnings.We've have so many close calls, say Gary Garnet, ameteorologist with the National Weather Service.But this storm be very, very strong, he said. This timethey realize it.glen Ellis, a Red Cross official, estimate that 18,000residents in Charleston and the three surround counties headedfor shelters.Tens of thousands more get into their cars and head upinterstate 26 toward Columbia.Mayor John Bourne of North Charleston, where there apparentlywere no storm-related deaths, credit people for heed thewarnings.it be bad, but it could have be a lot worse, he said.you've just get to say nice things about the people.meanwhile, Garnet have some good news for storm-wearycharlestonians: late Saturday the tropics be quiet with no otherstorms brewing.there's nothing to worry about out there, he said.this historic city have survive theravages of earthquake, battle and storm in its storied300-year-history, but it face perhaps its great test of all inhurricane Hugo.The storm, pack winds of up to 135 mph, rag into CharlestonThursday night.This be a dangerous, killer hurricane, the likes of which fewpeople who have live all their lives in Charleston haveexperienced, warn Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr.Hugo be the first major hurricane to strike Charleston sincehurricane Gracie come ashore 70 miles to the south in 1959.The seaside community have suffer through many disasters, bothnatural and man-made.the worst in recent decades be in 1938 when a tornado torethrough the city, kill 32 people, injure hundreds and causingan estimate $2 million in property damage.charleston, a city of pastel-colored antebellum structures liningquaint streets and alleyways, be where the Civil War begin in 1861.The city have survive the shot and shell of two wars and anynumber of small hurricanes, politely refer to by Charlestoniansof refinement as September gales.but the bad natural disaster to beset the city occur on thehot night of Aug. 31, 1886, when the ground rumble in what somefolks think be a prelude to Judgement Day.The great Charleston earthquake be felt as far away as Chicagoand New York City.Measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion, theearthquake claim an estimate 110 lives, destroy 102 buildingsand toss most of the city's 14,000 chimney into the streets.in recent years, the city have attract millions of visitorsannually who tour its historic buildings and visit its nearby finesand beaches.charleston have receive international acclaim as home to SpoletoFestival U.S.A., found by composer Gian Carlo Menotti. Organizerslike to refer to Spoleto as the world's most comprehensive artsfestival.supercomputers, satellites and the expertise ofseveral hurricane forecasters predict the destructive pathhurricane Hugo would follow, give people plenty of time to fleethe South Carolina coast.but hurricane track remain an uncertain science.Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center use computer modelsto track Hugo's path into Charleston, S.C.All the world's knowledge about meteorological conditions andforecasting changes in those conditions be embody in thosemodels, say Thomas Pyke, head of National Oceanic and AtmosphericAdministration's satellite service.pinpointing the exact point of Hugo's landfall be difficult, butforecasters say Friday that the landfall be predict in time forevacuation.overall, I think the tracking models give us a very good ideawhere Hugo would be so officials in South Carolina could act in atimely manner, say research meteorologist Colin McAdie.The real forecasting problem with Hugo be predict theintensity of the storm, which be upgrade to a Category 4 hurricanejust hours before it slam into Charleston.It be very difficult to predict changes in intensity because wedon't have very reliable computer models for that, McAdie said.we really need to improve on our forecast ability of strength.the hurricane specialists be surprise by the last-minuteincrease in wind speed, which be report to them by Air Forcereconnaissance.Hurricane specialist Gil Clark, who have track hurricanes for 35years, say that a couple of decades ago, the only forecasting toolswere reports from aircraft or ships.we have no radar or satellites then, so needless to say ourforecasts be less accurate, Clark said.in the late 1960s, the weather service begin use satellites toobtain a global weather picture. information from the satellite isused to improve the accuracy of the large-scale models thattelevision viewers see every night.using the information from the satellite, supercomputers at thenational Meteorological Center in Suitland, Md., send information tothe hurricane center where a track model constantly change toaccount for current weather conditions and the position of thehurricane.to determine the track of the storm, the forecasters analyzesupercomputer predictions, satellite data, the history of similarstorms and the current path of the hurricane.then they make an educated guess about the landfall.meteorology professor Kerry A. Emmanuel of the MassachussettsInstitute of Technology criticize the current forecasting system.congress and the american people be suffer from thecollective delusion that our data problems have be solve bysatellites and that just isn't true, Emmanuel said.Satellites can give a pretty picture, he said, but not enoughinformation about the wind and temperatures that affect ahurricane's path.most of the information actually use to predict hurricanescomes from fly airplanes into the hurricane, and they do a verygood job, Emmanuel said.Forecasters say the accuracy of satellite pictures be improvingevery year so long-range forecasting should become more precise.We have to remember that those models use be only guidanceproducts, Pyke said, and that it's ultimately the job of theforecaster to predict the storm's path.hurricane Hugo strike South Carolina withrenewed fury Thursday after thousands of coastal residents insoutheastern states grab what they could carry and fled inland onjammed highways.this be a disaster star us right in the eye, Mayor JosephP. Riley Jr. say from his City Hall command post in Charleston,where the hurricane down power lines, snap trees and causedutility transformers to explode.all we can do now be pray and hope all the precautions we havetaken have be sufficient, Riley say as Hugo's eye bore in onthe city. I just hope and pray we can get through this without anyloss of life.by midnight, 119 mph winds be report in Charleston. The roofcracked at City Hall, a 188-year-old brick building that haswithstood several hurricanes, and torrents of water pour into thepaneled council chamber. Phone and electric service to the commandpost be knock out.hurricane-force winds first hit the coast by 9:15 p.m. EDT, andabout three hours later the eye of the storm pass over the Isle ofpalms just east of Charleston, say Bob Sheets, director of thenational Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla.The eye be about 10 miles across and top winds be still at 135mph.Hugo be expect to turn gradually to the north, cause severeflooding as it move up the East Coast. The storm pose a 19 percentchance of hit New York City and a 16 percent chance of hittingboston before Sunday night, the hurricane center said.as Hugo near the coast, roads from Hilton Head to Myrtle Beach,200 miles north, be nearly empty, as be the boarded-up resorttowns themselves. Power lines and trees be down in some spotsand water flood roads. Stop lights and neon lights be knockedout in Myrtle Beach.One eyewitness say `It's like a light show,' say AmyGarrison, a reporter at WKZQ AM-FM in Myrtle Beach.In Charleston, the hurricane litter streets with tin roofs,palmetto fronds and chunks of bark. Businesses be closed andclasses at public schools and universities canceled. Riley orderedresidents of one-story homes to evacuate.Hospitals stockpile supplies, discharge any patients wellenough to go and move others to hospitals inland to make room foremergency patients, officials said.about 12,000 people have check into 83 shelters across the stateas of Thursday evening, and more be expected, say bennish Brown,a spokesman for the Emergency Operations Center in Columbia, 220miles northwest of here.we try to close the doors but people be sneak in sidedoors, say Elaine Skelton, a registered nurse work at theconway high School shelter near Myrtle Beach. We try to postguards at the doors, but people be still come in.american Red Cross relief efforts be buckle under the numberof evacuees, say Brian Ruberry, a spokesman in Savannah, Ga., whoappealed for help.right now the Red Cross be shelter tens of thousands ofpeople all along the Eastern seaboard. This of course be at the sametime that we're shelter 25,000 people on Puerto Rico and theother Caribbean islands.we're begin to feel the squeeze. Our resources be verytight. Right now Hugo be shape up to be one of our big reliefoperations of the decade.at midnight, the center of Hugo be near latitude 32.7 degreesnorth and longitude 79.9 degrees west, forecasters said. Thehurricane's speed have pick up to 22 mph from 20 mph earlier.near its center, Hugo's muscle reach winds of 135 mph, up from125 mph earlier in the day and 105 mph the day before. North andSouth Carolina can expect tornadoes link to Hugo for the next twodays, accord to the hurricane center.the coastal area could expect hurricane force winds for 10 to 12hours once the eye come ashore, officials said. A hurricane warningwas in effect between Fernandina Beach, Fla., and Oregon Inlet, N.C.By late afternoon, Hugo be upgrade to a category 4 hurricane onthe Saffir-Simpson scale of strength, the second mightiest category,which indicate it could cause extreme damage.it strengthen more than we think it would, Sheets said,adding that Hugo would cause severe flooding as it move up theappalachians.the timing of the landfall be critical because of the storm'stidal surge, a dome of water 10 to 15 feet high that would fee anormal 5-foot high tide that peaks after 2 a.m.on top of that will be waves, Sheets say earlier, and inmany places on barrier islands the buildings will be sweep cleanoff.Amid the uproar of live coverage by themajor networks and scores of other media organizations, NationalHurricane Center forecasters go about their business of monitoringhurricane Hugo.The whole system look chaotic, but it works, say BobSheets, the center's director.on one side of a large room dominate by a u-shaped bank ofmonitoring equipment be the forecasters, making meticulouscalculations about where the deadly hurricane will strike andgetting emergency operations go in those areas.On the other side be the media a pack of reporters, cameraoperators and technicians, jockeying for seconds of Sheets' time andtidbits of his expertise.in the center be Sheets himself. surround by cameras, wiresand two dozen journalists with pads and telephones, the ubiquitousred-headed meteorologist have appear on television all week next toa large satellite monitor show colorful images of Hurricane Hugo.During prime news time, compete technicians and cameramen shoutand make rude hand gestures for people to get out of their shots ofSheets.At his back, casually dressed forecasters who have be working12-hour days track the storm via computers and satellites.we obviously don't like this and could probably do a betterjob, but everyone knows now because of the media, say hurricanespecialist Max Mayfield. In the Caribbean, we be not so certainthe word get out. But we know the Carolinas have be evacuated.when a hurricane warning go into effect, It's a $50 millionstatement, say meteorologist Joel Cline, refer to the cost ofemergency preparations and evacuation plans that must be implementedwhen the warning be posted.If we weren't here, then you wouldn't know that a storm be outthere, he said. Before the hurricane warn system wasestablished, a storm of Hugo's power would have cost thousands oflives. But early today, after days of warnings and proper evacuationprocedures, there be no immediate reports of deaths despitewidespread damage in Charleston and other coastal areas of SouthCarolina.I like to think that we make a difference a far as human livesare concerned, Cline said.after Hugo's landfall, Sheets and the other forecasters begin towind down from the hectic pace they have maintain for the lastseveral days. But, he warned, the hurricane center still isfollowing three other weather systems that have move into theatlantic between the United States and Africa, and another storm inthe Pacific.I hate to say we're breathe a sigh of relief because peopleare get clobber to death, meteorologist Mark Zimmer say asthe storm pound Charleston, S.C. But we've do all we can.damage from Hurricane Hugo, which storm through the Carolinas and the Caribbean last week, will reduce third-quarter earnings for several insurers. New york-based American International Group Inc. expect net losses relate to Hugo to reduce pretax earnings between $35 million and $45 million. Analysts say AIG have tell them that it must cover the first $35 million of losses and that its reinsurance agreements will cover the bulk of the remain damages. AIG insure property in Puerto Rico, the eastern Caribbean Islands and the coastal regions of the Carolinas. St. Paul Cos., base in St. Paul, Minn, say the pretax cost of Hugo shouldn't exceed $50 million. That amount take into consideration what St. Paul expect to recover under its reinsurance contracts, the company said. philadelphia-based Cigna Corp. be expect to disclose Hugo's likely impact on its earnings sometime today. Udayan Ghose, an insurance industry analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, estimate that Cigna's third-quarter per-share earnings could be reduce by between 50 cents and 65 cents a share on an after-tax basis. That would wipe out 35% to 40% of his $1.40-a-share earnings estimate for the third quarter. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. say its State Fire & Casualty Co. unit estimate claim payments from Hugo will exceed $400 million in South Carolina alone, far surpass the company's record payout for a single disaster. When damages in North Carolina and Virginia be added, the company said, the payments will exceed $500 million. It say that be more than three times the previous record of $165 million set by Hurricane Alicia, which hit the Houston-Galveston, Texas, area in 1983.The greenhouse effect may breed big anddeadlier hurricanes in the future, storm up to 50 percent strongerthan Hugo and last year's record-setting Gilbert, somemeteorologists say.hugo blast the eastern Caribbean and the Carolinas with 135 mphwinds this past week, kill at least 41 people.just before Hugo strike the U.S. coast, its pressure be measuredat 940 millibars. That make it among the 12 strong hurricanesthis century to hit the United States, the National HurricaneCenter's Miles Lawrence say today.gilbert, whose winds reach 180 mph, tear up the Caribbean lastyear, kill 300 and cause $2 billion damage. It be the mostpowerful hurricane ever recorded.gilbert seem to be about the upper limit of a hurricane withcurrent ocean temperatures, say Kerry Emanuel of the meteorologydepartment at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.But if the seas warm up, say by 3 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit, thewind speeds might be 25 percent high which mean the destructiveforce would be more like 50 percent higher, he said.stephen Schneider, deputy director of the National Center foratmospheric Research in Denver, say his research suggest thewarming trend be already here.schneider, an expert on the greenhouse effect and author of a newbook Global Warming, say six of the 10 hot years in thelast 100 occur in the 1980s.He projects that the 1990s will be even hotter.Hugo demonstrate the effect of warm Atlantic waters when itswinds jump from 105 mph to 135 mph as it pass over the GulfStream before hit the East Coast, Schneider said.you'll get bad hurricanes if the Caribbean be warmer, hesaid. And I think there be better-than-even odds that you willhave strong hurricanes.emanuel say if the ocean temperature climbs, moderate hurricanesof the future could grow to Gilbert's strength and future Gilbertswill be even stronger.gilbert be so strong that Bob Sheets, director of the nationalhurricane center, say forecasters may have to use an intensityscale of 1-6 in the future, instead of the current 1-5, with fivethe highest.the computer models schneider use show that in a worst-casescenario, over the next 100 years the world's temperature could jumpby 10 degrees if carbon dioxide and methane gas which bothcontribute to the greenhouse effect continue to pour into theatmosphere unchecked.it be possible that even though the world as a whole heat up,the Caribbean could somehow remain cooler. But he say that isunlikley.that's not what the models be showing, Schneider said. Andthat's another reason I'd like to slow down global warming.
column5: Record damage by 1989's Hurricane Hugo in Caribbean and Carolinas
column6: In September 1989, Category 4 Hurricane Hugo, with 135mph winds, damaged the eastern Caribbean then hit South Carolina, where coastal residents fled inland or into shelters. 17 Carolinians were killed. Satellites, computers, and reconnaissance planes helped forecasters monitor Hugo's progress. Insurance claims broke records. The greenhouse effect could raise future storms' destructive power by 50%.
column7: Category 4 Hurricane Hugo did extensive damage in the eastern Caribbean on Sep 17, 1989, and on the 21st hit Charleston, South Carolina with 135mph winds. It killed 17 in the state. Coastal residents fled inland or crowded into shelters. Satellites, a computerized tracking model, and Air Force reconnaissance planes helped forecasters at the National Hurricane Center monitor Hugo's progress. Pinpointing landfall and intensity were difficult. Billions in insurance claims made Hugo the most expensive storm to date. Ocean warming caused by the greenhouse effect could increase future storms' destructive power, demonstrated by Hugo jumping from 105 to 135mph winds as it passed over the Gulf Stream.
column8: Hurricane Hugo, starting as a wave off Africa on Sep 11th, 1989, grew to a Category 4 hurricane. It did extensive damage in the eastern Caribbean and on the 21st hit Charleston, South Carolina with 135mph winds. The storm claimed 17 lives in the state. Coastal residents fled inland or crowded into shelters. Supercomputers at the National Meteorological Center in Suitland, Maryland sent satellite information on Hugo's progress to the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Florida. There, forecasters aided by a computerized tracking model and Air Force reconnaissance planes that flew into the storm monitored Hugo's progress. Pinpointing Hugo's landfall and intensity were difficult. State Farm and Nationwide, the two dominant insurers in the Carolinas, expect $600 million in claims from Hurricane Hugo. Overall claims will exceed the record $752.5 million after Hurricane Frederic in 1979. Reinsurers will pick up much of the costs.  The billions paid out this year will reduce insurers' third-quarter earnings and cause insurance prices to rise.  Unchecked carbon dioxide and methane gas emissions could create a greenhouse effect that would warm oceans 3-6 degrees, resulting in hurricanes 50% more destructive than Hugo. Hugo demonstrated the effect of warm water when its winds jumped from 105 to 135mph as it passed over the Gulf Stream.
column9: Hurricane Hugo Could Have Been Deadlier. Stronger Storms Forecast.
column10: On Sept. 21, 1989 Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, S.C. head-on causing extensive property damage, but hundreds or thousands of lives were saved by hurricane forecasters and emergency workers who facilitated a massive evacuation before the storm hit. Scientists warn that global warning could cause hurricanes much stronger than Hugo in the future.
column11: After killing 20 and leaving about 100,000 homeless in the Caribbean, Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, S.C. head-on at midnight of Sept. 21, 1989 with winds of 135 mph. Although seventeen were killed in the Carolinas and property damage there exceeded $750 million, hundreds or thousands of lives were saved by advance warning of the storm from the National Hurricane Center and prompt response of officials and the populace. Scientists have warned that if global warning should cause sea temperature to rise 3-6 degrees Fahrenheit, we may well experience future hurricanes with half again the strength of Category 4 Hugo.
column12: September 17-18, 1989 Hurricane Hugo devastated Guadeloupe, Montserrat, Antigua, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico with winds reaching 150 mph, leaving in its wake 20 killed and about 100,000 homeless. It slowed down on Sept. 19 only to pick up strength again on Sept. 21, hitting Charleston, S.C. head-on at midnight with winds up to 135 mph. Moving inland it lost strength and at 6 A.M. Sept. 22, 1989 was downgraded to a tropical storm. Seventeen were killed in the Carolinas and the overall damage to property there was more than $750 million. As the storm proceeded forecasters at the National Hurricane Center with the help of satellites and supercomputers analyzed available data and made an educated guess about the landfall on the U.S. coast. Charleston and the Carolina coast were alerted and a massive evacuation took place. Advance warning, heeded by local officials and the populace, undoubtedly saved hundreds or thousands of lives. Although hurricane forecasting has come a long way it is still not an exact science. Other hurricane research indicates that storms much stronger than class four Hugo may be in the offing. Scientists predict that if  sea temperature increases by 3-6 degrees Fahrenheit, the destructive force of hurricanes would increase by 50 percent.

Aquino succeed Marcos after the 1986 uprising thattoppled his administration and force him into exile in Hawaii.Today, the Manila Stock Exchange's composite index fell to1,084.53 from Thursday's close of 1,102.97. Traders say rumors ofmarcos' death trigger a selling wave shortly before noon.in Honolulu, Marcos aide Arturo Aruiza say Mrs. Marcos plannedto make one last appeal to Mrs. Aquino to allow her husband toreturn home.rafael Ileto, Mrs. Aquino's national security advisor, saidgranting such a request be still an option but, I doubt verymuch that it will be one of the solutions.ileto, who meet with Mrs. Aquino for a half-hour today, saidmarcos no longer pose a threat to the nation but his followerscan cause disruptions of normal functions.ileto, a retired vice chief of staff and former DefenseMinister, say the 160,000-member armed forces be capable ofquelling any unrest by Marcos supporters.the resignation of the land reformsecretary raise doubts about President Corazon Aquino's commitmentto agrarian reform and dramatize conflicts in a governmentcriticized for lack of vision.the controversy climax Thursday with the resignation ofsecretary-designate Florencio Abad, 35, whose nomination wasopposed by the pro-aquino Struggle of the democratic Filipino Party.Handling of the controversy highlight all the inconsistenciesfor which Mrs. Aquino have be criticized: lack of clearpriorities; tactical blundering; and the strong influence of herrelatives over national policy.it also reinforce the suspicion among liberals that for all herrhetoric, Mrs. Aquino do not share the deep commitment to socialchange which they expect when she take power in the 1986 peoplepower uprise against the late Ferdinand Marcos.The sincerity of Corazon Aquino be be seriouslyquestioned, write columnist Ninez Cacho-Olivares in thephilippine Daily Inquirer. Land reform, the centerpiece programof her administration, be dead.abad's troubles begin in February when he try unsuccessfullyto block the lease of government land in Cavite province to Japan'sMarubeni Corp., for an industrial park.Although the deal be approve by the National DevelopmentCorp., Abad, a former congressman, say the land should bedistributed to peasants under the agrarian reform program.the Department of Trade and Industry say the Marubeni deal wascrucial to attract much-needed foreign investment for thegovernment's industrialization program.But the Department of Agrarian Reform say if the Cavite landwas exempted, hundreds of landlords would try to have theirproperty declare as a potential industrial site to avoid losingtitle.the presidential staff finally work out a compromise underwhich farmers would be offer either land or a cash settlement.abad reluctantly agree to the formula under repeat orders frommrs. Aquino.Abad's firm stand, however, alarmed landowners in Congress, whofloated rumors in the press that the agrarian Reform Department wasriddled with Communists.Lawmakers on the Commission on Appointments who belong to thepro-aquino Struggle of the Democratic Filipino Party block Abad'sconfirmation through eight hearings until he finally resigned.despite the party's victory, poltical damage to it and Mrs.Aquino be considerable. The Manila press transform Abad into afolk hero, depict him as the champion of the farmer againstpolitical barons of the Struggle of the democratic Filipino Party,dubbed Landlord-Dominated Party.Worry not about Abad's destiny, Mrs. President, wrotecolumnist Carol Arguillas in The Manila Chronicle. Worry aboutyours and how you blow the last chance for liberal support.mrs. Aquino pledge publicly to work for Abad's confirmation,but her lobbying appear ineffectual. Abad's strong opponentsincluded politicians who consistently support Mrs. Aquino, leadingto speculation she be not disappointed when he departed.abad's opponents include her young brother, Rep. JosePeping Cojuangco, who wield considerable influence ingovernment.There be no way Cory Aquino will challenge Peping, say onewestern diplomat, speak on condition of anonymity.mrs. Aquino come from a landlord family. She and her brothersand sisters be partners in a 14,500-acre sugar plantation intarlac province. Rather than break up the estate, they use a legaloption and create a profit-sharing plan for the tenants.the Abad controversy be the late in a series of blows to theagrarian reform program, once tout as the centerpiece of theadministration.last year, agrarian Reform Secretary Philip Juico resign afterdisclosures that his department pay vastly inflate sums formarginal land.his successor, Miriam Defensor Santiago, be repeatedly rejectedby the Commission on Appointments, only to be reappointed untilmrs. Aquino replace her with Abad on Dec. 31.No reason for the change be given. But Mrs. Santiago claim shedid not display sufficient public loyalty to Mrs. Aquino during acoup attempt in early december.agrarian reform be widely see as a mean for break thepower of landlord families and uplift the livelihood of millionsof peasants. The program be advertise as essential in curb the21-year-old rural-based Marxist insurgency.mrs. Aquino proclaim a land reform program in 1987 but leftdetails to congress. The final bill contain so many pro-landlordloopholes that several of its original sponsors, include Abad,voted against it.president Corazon Aquino have agreedto allow Ferdinand Marcos to return to the Philippines so that thegovernment can try him on charges of steal billions of dollars,newspapers say Saturday.The Manila Bulletin and The Manila Chronicle quote Mrs.Aquino's press secretary, Teodoro Benigno, as say that Mrs.Aquino make the assurance to two swiss lawyers before she visitedswitzerland earlier this month.the reports do not say when criminal charges against Marcos,Aquino's oust predecessor, will be file or when Mrs. Aquino willallow him to return.mrs. Aquino have refuse to allow Marcos into the Philippines,citing security reasons. Marcos live in exile in Hawaii.Mrs. Aquino's government have say it will file criminal chargesagainst Marcos, whom it have accuse of steal up to $10 billionin government funds. But the government have not do so because ofmrs. Aquino's refusal to let Marcos enter the country.philippine law do not allow trial in absentia.swiss lawyers be help the philippine government trace moneythat Marcos and his family allegedly place in Swiss bank accounts.marcos have be live in Hawaii since he be topple by thecivilian-military revolt that sweep Mrs. Aquino to power infebruary 1986.The swiss government have freeze the assets of Marcos and hisassociates and have not release information on them to thephilippine government because of legal challenges pose by Marcos'lawyers and swiss banks.the unidentified swiss lawyers say the information will not beturned over unless and until there be an assurance that formalcharges will be file against him, Benigno be quote as saying.swiss law allow the lifting of banking secrecy laws only incase of criminal prosecution.mrs. Aquino have say she would allow Marcos to return now onlyif he and his family swear allegiance to her government andreturned the money he allegedly steal during his 20-year rule.she say later she would abide by any court decision if Marcos'lawyers in the Philippines raise the matter of his return to thecourts.benigno be quote as say that Mrs. Aquino have to acceptthe possibility of Marcos return home.president Corazon Aquino of thePhilippines on Monday ask government and industrial leaders toexpand economic ties with her nation.mrs. Aquino, on the first stop of her weeklong three-nationeuropean tour, meet with west german President Richard vonWeizsaecker, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and otherofficials.mrs. Aquino, compare the task of strengthen the heavilyindebted Philippine economy to the recovery of West Germany afterWorld War II, ask that Germany share its experience with herhomeland.We have try by sound fiscal policies not to buy recovery atthe price of inflation, nor debt relief at the price of nationalhonor, she say in a speech to the west german Chamber of Industryand Trade.We have pay as careful attention to the consequences ofrunaway inflation and devaluation as Germany in the light of her ownexperiences between the wars, she said.mrs. Aquino say the Philippines' debt be project to increaseto $29 billion by year's end but that much be money that be infact steal by the previous government of ousted dictatorferdinand Marcos.She say that since her government take over in 1986, thecountry's growth rate of minus 10 percent under Marcos in 1985 hadimproved to a rate of plus 6.7 percent by 1988.What we need to complete the equation be two elementsessential to the german recovery debt relief and investments,mrs. Aquino said.during a state banquet in the evening, Weizsaecker tell Mrs.Aquino her visit would far strengthen relations between WestGermany and the Philippines.Weizsaecker say the Philippines have have good results in tradewith West Germany, and assure Mrs. Aquino that the barrier-freemarket the european Economic Community plan for 1992 will not lockout trade with other countries.Mrs. Aquino, who arrive in West Germany on Sunday, will meetwith Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday before depart for Paris.She also be to visit Belgium.President Corazon Aquino on fridayrefused to allow Ferdinand Marcos to return home to die and saidher government won't permit him to be bury here despite a lastappeal from his wife.the 71-year-old Marcos be in critical condition Friday in ahonolulu hospital after emergency kidney surgery. Hospitalofficials say the ousted leader be suffer from renal, cardiacand pulmonary failure.marcos' wife, Imelda, broadcast an appeal Friday to Mrs. Aquinoto allow her husband to die in his homeland, and his supportersthreatened mass protests if the request be rejected.but Mrs. Aquino refuse to withdraw her ban on Marcos, and thephilippine Supreme Court reject a petition from the formerpresident's lawyer, Juan David, to order the return. Marcos haslived in Hawaii since he be oust three years ago in a popularuprising that propel Mrs. Aquino to power.i would like first of all to convey to the family of Mr.Marcos that I do pray that he will still recover from this latestcritical illness, Mrs. Aquino said. I regret very much it isnot possible for us to allow him to return.she say she have say in the past that we will not allow hisremains to be bring back here, and we have already take plans toavoid any untoward incidents.mrs. Aquino, whose government have survive six coup attempts,has cite national security in refuse previous requests.in a statement broadcast by a pro-marcos radio station, Mrs.Marcos say she have try to telephone Mrs. Aquino from Hawaii butwas tell the president be busy.maria Elena Cruz, Mrs. Aquino's daughter and personal secretary,said the president receive no calls from Mrs. Marcos.Mrs. Marcos say she be try to contact the president tomake a last appeal to Madame Corazon Aquino to open her heart andlet Ferdinand come home because he be in very serious condition.my countrymen, I be appeal to each and every one of you topray that, hopefully, Mrs. Aquino will know that bring homemarcos will bring true reconciliation, true peace and unity for ourcountry, Mrs. Marcos said. This be what's best for thecountry.mrs. Aquino have say earlier: I regret to inform Mrs. Marcos,if indeed she be ask me for reconsideration, because as I havesaid in the past, much as I agree that Mr. Marcos have his rights, Istill have to consider also the rights and interests of millions offilipinos.when told of Mrs. Aquino's statement, Mrs. Marcos say We areaware, but I be a believer and I be an optimist. I know miraclescan happen.marcos supporters, meanwhile, announce they would hold ralliessaturday to pray for his recovery. pro-marcos leaders warn theformer president's death in exile would trigger demonstrations.we expect tactical alliances in this nationwide mass action,said pro-marcos lawyer Oliver Lozano. We refer to the tacticalalliances of the military, labor sector and student sector.but the chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, say the armedforces would accept Mrs. Aquino's decision and be prepare toblock any attempts by the opposition to foment trouble.we will do everything in our power to see to it that law andorder prevail, de Villa tell reporters. We will follow anydecision by the executive branch.
column5: President Aquino Survives Controversies and Uprisings; Marcos Unwelcome Dead or Alive
column6: President Aquino, successor to Marcos, has survived two major coup attempts and several mutinies. She has faced political controversies, including opposition to an agrarian reform leader and a split with her Vice President. In 1989 she refused to let Marcos, critically ill in Hawaii, to reenter the country, dead or alive.
column7: With military firepower, President Aquino ended the Oct. 4-6 uprising. She has survived two major coup attempts and several mutinies. Recently, in a reversal of policy, Aquino said she would negotiate with Communist guerillas. Aquino's, political controversies include her opposition to the nomination of agrarian reform leader Secretary-designate Abad, and her Vice President's refusal to condemn an insurrection in 1989.Aquino succeeded Marcos who was accused of stealing billions from the government. In 1989 she refused to let Marcos, critically ill in Hawaii, to reenter the country or to allow him to be buried in the Philippines.
column8: President Corazon Aquino used military firepower to end the military led rebellion on Mindanao. The Oct. 4-6 uprising never spread to other islands. Aquino has survived two major coup attempts and several military mutinies. The current rebellion is the latest of several military mutinies. In August Aquino reversed a long-held policy and said she was willing to negotiate cease-fires with Communist guerillas and former soldiers who have staged coup attempts. In December 1989 a confrontation between pro-coup supporters and Aquino supporters occurred at the Philippine consulate in Los Angeles.Aquino's government has also had its political controversies. Her opposition to the nomination of Secretary-designate Abad raised doubts about her commitment to social reform. In 1989, her Vice President refused to condemn the insurrection that was then unfolding.Aquino rose to power in 1986 after dictator Ferdinand Marcos, accused of stealing billions of government funds, was ousted. June1988 news stories quoted sources saying Aquino would allow Marcos to return to the Philippines to stand trial, but a year later she stated the critically ill Marcos could not return to die, nor could he be buried in the Philippines.Aquino traveled to West German in 1989 seeking economic assistance.
column9: Marcos, military, Communists, agrarian policy, and economy plague Philippine President Aquino.
column10: Philippine President Corazon Aquino was beset with problems from 1988 to 1990.  Ferdinand Marcos plagued the earlier years, even when he became terminally ill.  Economic problems, agrarian reform, overseas Filipinos, Communist insurgents, and the mutinous military tormented her administration.  Coup attempts continued even after she sought reconciliation.
column11: Philippine President Corazon Aquino's administration was beset with problems from June 1988 to October 1990.  Ferdinand Marcos plagued the earlier years.  Swiss bankers required a criminal prosecution to release information on his funds.  His wife, Imelda, and his supporters wanted him to be allowed to die, or at least be buried, in his homeland.  Her agrarian reform policy suffered a number of setbacks.  Economic problems were the focus of her 1989 European trip.  Six military coups and many military mutinies against her government occurred.  Communist insurgents continued their 21-year campaign.  In April 1990, she was willing to negotiate with the insurgents and renegade military.
column12: Philippine President Corazon Aquino's administration was beset with problems from June 1988 to October 1990.  Her predecessor, Ferdinand Marcos was exiled to Hawaii, but had allies in the Philippines and continued to create dissension.  Swiss bankers required a criminal prosecution to release information on the $10 billion he allegedly stole and deposited in Switzerland.  After he became terminally ill, his wife, Imelda, and his supporters wanted him to be allowed to die, or at least be buried, in his homeland.  Aquino refused all requests citing security reasons.  From a landlord family, Aquino's agrarian reform policy suffered a number of setbacks.  Economic problems were the focus of her 1989 European trip, where she touted improvements in the growth rate under her leadership and sought debt relief and foreign investments.  The Philippine military created a continuing problem, leading coups and mutinies.  The December 1989 attempted coup divided Filipinos in Los Angeles and involved Aquino asking for help from United States forces stationed there.  Criticized for past indecisive actions, Aquino quickly ended the October 1990 coup attempt on Mindanao.  Communist insurgents continued their 21-year campaign.  In April 1990, she said she was willing to negotiate with the insurgents and renegade military.

column3: There be plenty of blame to go around at theend of the lengthy and traumatic McMartin Pre-School molestationtrial, but no one be willing to accept it.in the nation's longest and costly trial, Raymond Buckey andhis mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, be acquit Thursday on 52child molestation charges. The jury deadlocked on 13 other charges.afterward, the district attorney who file the case criticizedthe current district attorney. The current district attorney blamedhis predecessor and defense attorneys. And some of the parents ofchildren who attend the school blame everybody.the system be not go to protect children, say JackieMcGauley, a parent who believe her child have be molest butdidn't testify in the case. Life be not fair, say RobertCurry, whose son attend the McMartin school. I tell my childrenall the time ... there be no such thing as fair.the district attorney who originally pursue the case say hewould not have do anything differently.robert Philibosian, now in private practice, angrily dismissedaccusations that he play up the McMartin case in 1984 with thenews media act as eager accomplices to boost his publicprofile as he run for district attorney.i be a professional prosecutor for 16 years before this casewas brought, he said. To have people who know very little aboutprofessional or prosecutorial ethics, to criticize me personallythat I have some political motive be totally unjustified.philibosian instead point the finger at the man who defeatedhim, current District Attorney Ira Reiner. Philibosian say Reinerhurt prosecutor's chances by dismiss charges against five of theoriginal seven defendants and criticize the case in a 1986 60Minutes interview.but Reiner, call his dismissal of charges for lack ofevidence the decision we're proud of, say the trial take solong because of the state's ponderous criminal justice system,delay tactics by defense attorneys and a mess leave behind byphilibosian.this be a case I inherited, Reiner said.in interviews, many jurors say they believe some of thechildren be molested, but the prosecution never establish thatthe defendants be responsible.even if you accept that the children be molested, it didn'tnecessarily mean they be molest at the McMartin Pre-School,said juror Brenda Williams.Jurors in the McMartin Pre-School molestationcase denounce the techniques of a child therapy center and apolice department letter that inflame parents and ignite the case.seven jurors who speak with reporters in a joint news conferenceafter acquit Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartinBuckey, on 52 molestation charges Thursday say they felt somechildren who testify may have be molest but not at thefamily-run McMartin Pre-School.And they say some children may have merely repeat storiestold them by their parents and interviewers at Children's InstituteInternational.The private child therapy center, which specialize in abusedchildren, videotape interviews with children from the McMartinschool after reports of molestations surfaced. Jurors saw the tapesin which interviewers use anatomically explicit puppets andleading questions to elicit descriptions of molestation fromchildren.asked what lead to acquittals, juror Brenda Williams focus onthe taped interviews from the center jurors call CII.The CII interviews I could not accept them, Mrs. Williamssaid. I believe the children believe what they be say wastrue. But at CII, I could not tell if the children be say whatwas tell to them (by interviewers) or if they be repeat whattheir parents have tell them.If the CII tapes have not be enter into evidence and I hadnot see them, I could have believe the children a little more,'mrs. Williams said.the CII tapes do not help me. They give me a lot ofreasonable doubt, agree juror Julie Peters, 47, a supermarketmeat wrapper.the children be never allow to say in their own words whathappened to them. All the questions be leading. They never have achance to tell their stories, say juror John Breese, 51, amedical technician and grandfather of five.i try to believe the children, say juror Daryl Hutchins28, an oil company lease operator. But if the child be socontaminated (by the interviews) I couldn't.equal criticism be aim at a letter send in 1983 by themanhattan Beach Police Department to parents of McMartin schoolchildren. column5: Buckeys acquitted in record trial; rancor remains; more will follow.
column6: The McMartin Pre-School molestation trial ended Thursday without any convictions.  Reactions to the verdict were strong, ranging from tears to finger pointing.  The case began in 1983 and became a media-fed witch-hunt ending with the longest, costliest criminal trial in history.  It will continue to reverberate in civil courts, bookstores and on television.
column7: The longest, costliest, criminal trial in American history, the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, ended Thursday without finding Raymond Buckey or his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, guilty.  The California case began in 1983 and became a frenetic, media-fed, witch-hunt.  Reactions to the verdict included tears, no surprise, disappointment, anger, excuses, and finger pointing.  Jurors criticized elements of the case and said some of the children may have been molested, but the prosecution failed to prove the defendants responsible.  Other parties defended their own roles, but blamed others or the system.  Reverberations will continue in civil courts, bookstores, and on television.
column8: The longest, costliest, criminal trial in American history, the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, ended Thursday.  The jury acquitted Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, on 52 counts and deadlocked on 13.  The case began in 1983 and became a frenetic witch-hunt led by the California media.  At one time, seven defendants, 135 charges, and over 400 children were involved.  Following the verdict, defendants wept, while parents decried the system for failing their children.  The judge was not surprised.  Jurors faulted the children's videotaped interviews, saying the interviewer asked leading questions.  Jurors believed some may have been molested, but the prosecution failed to prove the defendants responsible.  The therapist conducting the interviews defended her technique.  The current and former Los Angles district attorneys blamed each other and denied their ambitions influenced the case.  The pre-school's neighbors were disappointed and concerned about the building.Reverberations will continue.  Several books and television movies are planned, although the response of the networks is not known.  Two civil suits by former defendants are underway and Mrs. Buckey said she plans to sue.  Parents of the children may decide to file civil charges because the burden proof is lower. A harassed minister seeks disability retirement.
column9: A verdict of innocent returned in the McMartin Pre-school trial.
column10: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation trial ended in acquittal for Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. The jury found the McMartins innocent of 52 counts, but deadlocked on another 13, causing a mistrial on those counts. Parents of the children involved in the trial were angry and expressed disappointment with the acquittal.
column11: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation trial, the longest criminal trial in U.S. history, ended with a verdict of innocent for Raymond Buckey and is mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. The jury found the Buckeys innocent on 52 of the charges but deadlocked on another 13, causing a mistrial on those charges. Prosecutors must now decide if they want a retrial on the deadlocked charges. Originally involving 7 defendants, including Raymond Buckeys sister and grandmother, the charges against the sister and grandmother as well as three employees of the school were dropped. Parents of the children involved expressed anger and disappoint at the verdict.
column12: The McMartin Pre-School child molestation case, the longest and costliest criminal trial in U.S. history ended with the acquittal of Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, on 52 charges. A decision has yet to be reached on whether to retry Buckey on the 13 charges on which the jury deadlocked. The case originally involved Buckey and his mother, as well as his sister and grandmother and three other employees of the school. The charges against the sister, grandmother and the three employees were dropped for lack of evidence. In reaching their verdict, the jury said that the videotaped interviews of the child were a factor in finding the Buckeys innocent. The jurors felt the interviewers asked leading questions and never allowed the children to tell their own story. A number of the jurors stated that they believed some of the children had been molested but that the prosecution had not proven that Raymond Buckey was responsible. The verdict was greeted with anger by the parents of the children involved who felt the prosecution and the legal system had let them down. The judge in the case remarked that the case had poisoned everyone it touched.

column5: Iraq invades Kuwait; the world reacts.
column6: Iraq, after first accusing Kuwait of wrongdoing, invaded its oil-rich neighbor with 100,000 tank-led troops.  It quickly overran the Kuwaiti capital and then continued on to southern oil facilities.  The United States led the United Nations in condemning this action and imposing tough economic and military sanctions.
column7: Saddam accused Kuwait of costing Iraq billions by exceeding OPEC production quotas thus driving down oil prices.  He further accused Kuwait of "stealing" Iraqi oil from a common oil field on their border.  He then invaded Kuwait, claiming to do so at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionary coup leaders.  The United States led the western world and the United Nations in calling the coup a sham, denouncing this invasion and imposing strong economic and military sanctions on Iraq in an attempt to get them to withdraw.  Oil prices surged while Saddam warned against foreign intervention.  The U.S. dispatched warships to the area.
column8: It appeared that Iraq's President Saddam Hussein was determined to solve his countries financial problems and territorial ambitions by conquering Kuwait.  Iraq emerged from its 1980-1988 war with Iran with a debt of approximately $80 billion.  Saddam accused Kuwait of costing Iraq billions in oil revenues by exceeding OPEC assigned oil quotas, thus driving down the price of oil.  He further accused Kuwait of stealing Iraqi oil from an oil field common to their border and also of conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq economically and militarily.  Breaking off perfunctory negotiations with Kuwait, Iraq invaded, claiming it responded to a request for help from Kuwaiti revolutionary coup leaders.  Iraq quickly overwhelmed a mismatched Kuwaiti military, captured the capital and continued south to the oil facilities.  The United States called the coup a farce.  Kuwait's U.S. ambassador asked the United States to intervene militarily.  U.S. President George Bush called for an "immediate and unconditional" withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.  Although not willing to publicly discuss military options, Bush said all U.S. options remained open.  His administration led a United Nations embargo of Iraqi exports, including oil, and Iraqi imports.  Iraq retaliated by rounding up hundreds of foreign nationals in Kuwait.
column9: Saddam Hussein Defied United States and United Nations
column10: On August 2, 1990, after Saddam Hussein had charged Kuwait with unfriendly acts, 100,000 Iraqi troops invaded and quickly occupied Kuwait. Despite strong diplomatic moves by the U.S. and the U.N. Security Council, Iraq remained defiant and moved troops toward the Saudi Arabian border. As of August 6, 1990 the situation was ominous.
column11: In July 1990 Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait of violating OPEC production quotas and stealing oil from wells along the Iraq-Kuwait border. The two countries agreed to talks to settle their differences, but on the first day of the talks the Iraqi representatives walked out. The next day, August 2, 1990, 100,000 Iraqi troops invaded and quickly occupied Kuwait. Despite strong diplomatic efforts, Iraq remained defiant, rounding up several hundred Britons, Americans and West Germans in Kuwait and taking some of them to Iraq. As of August 6, 1990 Iraqi troops were massed on the border of Saudi Arabia and the U.S. warned that its vital interests were involved.
column12: On July 17, 1990 Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait of violating OPECproduction quotas and of stealing oil from wells along the countries'disputed border. Tension increased July 24-25 as the U.S. announced a"short-notice exercise" in the Persian Gulf and Iraq said it would notbe intimidated by U.S. pressure. Tension eased when Iraq and Kuwaitagreed to talks, but by the time the parties met on July 31, Iraq hadmassed 100,000 troops on the Kuwaiti border. The next day Iraq pulledout of the talks and on August 2,1990 invaded and quickly occupied allof Kuwait. President Bush froze Iraqi assets in the U.S. and blockedmost Iraqi imports. The U.N. Security Council denounced the invasionand demanded Iraq's withdrawal. The Pentagon stepped up air patrolsand movement of warships into the Persian Gulf. When, on August 6, theU.S.  pushed strong sanctions against Iraq through the U.N. SecurityCouncil, Iraq struck back, rounding up several hundred Britons,Americans, and West Germans in Kuwait, taking some of them toIraq. Iraqi troop concentrations menaced the Saudi Arabian border andthe U.S. warned Iraq of vital American interests in Saudi Arabia, butas of August 6, 1990 it was a stand-off. Iraq was in possession ofKuwait and oil prices soared on the international market.

Onetwister smash into a residential district, a shopping area and aschool, kill at least two people and cause dozens of injuries,police said.southern Illinois be also hard hit by the storms, with onewoman kill by a fall tree, about 20 people injured and powerlines downed.Elsewhere, snow fell from the northern Rockies to the uppergreat Lakes, while unseasonably mild weather continue in the East.People in Alorton, Ill., a village of 2,700 about five milessoutheast of East St. Louis, be injure when trees fell on theirhouses or mobile homes, say Bill Gamblin of the St. Clair CountyEmergency Services and Disaster Agency.At Parks College in Cahokia, Ill., eight miles south of East St.Louis, aircraft hangers be twist and flatten and smallaircraft toss around the airport by high winds, the NationalWeather Service said.Storms in the area generate wind estimate at 80 to 100 mph,the weather service said.the thunderstorms develop along and ahead of a strong coldfront and sweep eastward from Missouri and Arkansas.Thunderstorms cross northeastern Arkansas whip up highwind which blow away metal roof be instal on a high schoolgymnasium at Lepanto and dump hail up to 2 inches in diameter atleachville.heavy thunderstorms, possibly a tornado, strike the northgeorgia town of Palmetto late Wednesday, cause extensive damage,authorities said.in central and southwest ohio, thunderstorms pack wind up to66 mph destroy barns and a trailer home and tear the roofs offseveral buildings. Some injuries but no fatalities be reported.an afternoon thunderstorm in east-central Alabama form atornado which damage at least one home, and the Clay CountySheriff's office say an unknown number of people be injure inone house.Thunderstorms sweep across Tennessee spin off a tornado insoutheastern Madison Country, and drop hail as big as baseballsnorth of Jackson, the weather service said.hail stones as big as tennis balls fell near Huntingburg, Ind.,the weather service said.the heavy rainfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST was1.22 inches at Peru, Ind.Wind up to 65 mph damage roofs, power lines and trees in partsof Kentucky and Louisiana, the weather service said.severe thunderstorms also develop over Alabama and SouthCarolina during the afternoon, and the weather service report atornado north of Greenwood, S.C.Other showers and thunderstorms, with locally heavy rain, werewidely scatter along the northern Atlantic Coast.Light snow associate with an arctic cold front extend fromeastern Wyoming and northeastern Colorado into western Minnesota.Snow also fell across parts of northern Wisconsin and UpperMichigan.As much as 1 to 2 feet of snow be possible by Thursday morningalong the Lake Superior shore of Wisconsin.Strong northwesterly wind usher the cold air into thenorth-central states gusted above 40 mph during the afternoon,creating wind chill readings cold than 25 degrees below zero.snow, high wind and rapidly fall temperatures associate withthe cold front briefly produce near-blizzard conditions innebraska late Wednesday morning.unseasonably warm weather continue in the East with afternoonreadings in the 60s in New England, and in the 80s over Florida,southern Texas and southern Louisiana.Wednesday morning's low for the low 48 states be 9 degreesabove zero at Ely, Nev.
column5: Powerful storm causes death and destruction across the United States.
column6: Tornadoes, high winds, and thunderstorms caused severe damage in Midwestern, Eastern, and Southeastern states. The worst area hit was Huntsville, AL where a tornado killed 14 people. Heavy winds caused the death of seven school children in Newburgh, NY, one person in New York City, and another in New Jersey.
column7: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, heavy thunderstorms, and large hailstones across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Twenty-seven people were killed, more than 500 injured, and hundreds left homeless. The tornadoes struck mostly across Midwestern and Southeastern states. A devastating tornado struck Huntsville, AL laying waste to a wide swath through the city and causing death to 14 people. A tornado killed four people in Palmetto, Georgia.Heavy winds caused the death of seven children in a school in Newburgh, NY, one person in Elizabeth, NJ, and another in New York City.
column8: A powerful storm system brought tornadoes, high winds, heavy thunderstorms, and large hailstones across the Midwest, Mississippi Valley, Southeast, and Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. Reportedly, 27 people were killed, more than 500 injured, and hundreds left homeless. The storms developed ahead of a strong cold front sweeping eastward from Missouri and Arkansas.Tornadoes were reported in Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky, New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi. The worst damage was in Huntsville, AL where a tornado laid waste a wide swath of the city and caused the death of 14 people. Four people were killed by a tornado in Palmetto, Georgia.  Sixty-five mph winds damaged Kentucky and Louisiana.Strong winds and heavy thunderstorms caused heavy damage in Illinois, the District of Columbia, Maryland, Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia. In Newburgh, New York, a tree crashed through a school roof killing at least seven children. One person was killed in Elizabeth, New Jersey and another in New York City. Thunderstorms dropped large hailstones in Indiana and Tennessee.Snow was falling from the northern Rockies to the Great Lakes. Storm warnings were also posted in Pennsylvania and cold weather was expected in the Southeast.
column9: Tornadoes and thunderstorms cause death and destruction in fourteen states.
column10: A series of tornadoes and sever thunderstorms swept through fourteen states and Washington, D.C. causing death and destruction.  At least 27 people have died, more than 500 are injured and hundreds are homeless.  The most severe damage was in Huntsville, Alabama.  The Governor asks that Huntsville be declared a disaster area.
column11: A violent storm spawned tornadoes and thunderstorms across the Midwest and South, then blew north knocking over a school cafeteria wall in upstate New York, killing seven children.  Altogether, fourteen states and Washington D.C. were affected.  The toll from the two-day storm is at least 27 dead and over 500 hundred injured.   Property damage is in the millions.  The worst damage by far was in Huntsville, Alabama where a tornado slammed into a shopping district, a residential area and a school, leaving at least 14 dead and injuring nearly 300.  The Governor called in State Troopers and the National Guard to assist.
column12: A violent storm that spawned tornadoes and thunderstorms across the Midwest and South then blew north knocking over a school cafeteria wall in upstate New York, killing seven children.  Altogether, fourteen states and Washington D.C. were affected.  The toll from the two-day storm is at least 27 dead and over 500 hundred injured.   Property damage is in the millions.  Hundreds have been left homeless and tens of thousands lost electricity.  The worst damage by far was in Huntsville, Alabama where a massive tornado slammed into a shopping district, a residential area and a school, leaving at least 14 dead and injuring nearly 300.  It touched down between 4 and 4:30 p.m. when city streets were filled with rush hour traffic.  Ike Carroll, a real estate broker, said, "It started picking up cars and pushing them around, some of them upside down, some of them strewn around.  Heavy overhead power lines started snapping just like a circus performer would snap his whip."  Governor Guy Hunt called in State Troopers from throughout the state to help.  He is also using the National Guard to assist in the cleanup and to protect against looting.  The Governor plans to ask President Bush to declare Huntsville a disaster area.

Gorbachev asthe Cold War thawed.reagan credit Mrs. Thatcher's resoluteness for play akey role in end the tensions between the Western democracies andthe Eastern Block.She stand up to the Soviets and let them know she meantbusiness, he said.both be ardent advocates of the free market and privateenterprise.while the United States become mire in debt in the era ofreaganomics, the british economy thrive on Mrs. Thatcher's radicalpolicies during her nearly 12-year rule. average earnings be upby nearly one-third and more Britons own their homes during hertenor.like Reagan, however, Mrs. Thatcher be accuse by liberals ofwidening the gap between the rich and poor in her country, and bothclashed with organize labor.for almost a decade, Margaret Thatcher wasregarded at the White House as America's best friend, the trustedally whose strong views reinforce the conservative tone ofadministration policies.Among western allies, she be alone at Ronald Reagan's side in1986 in support the U.S. bombing of Libya. In the persian Gulfcrisis, she boldly join with George Bush in send troops to themiddle East.You always know where she be and what she believed, Bushsaid upon hearing of her decision to resign. She have always beenan outstanding ally of the United States, he said. Mrs. Thatcher wasn't one of theskeptics; she be advocate a similar program at home.they share rocky relations with organize labor. reagansuccessfully fire the nation's air traffic controllers, deal adevastating blow to labor. She, too, smash restive unions.on foreign policy, she frequently be more right wing thanReagan - certainly more so than Bush.Reagan never make any secret of his special affection for thebritish prime minister. At international gatherings, theyusually be side by side.two years ago as they meet for the final time before Reagan leftoffice, the president say he be leave the White House withconsiderable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcherwill still reside at no. 10 Downing Street.She later write him a Dear Ron letter in which she praisedhim as a great president, one of the greatest.like Reagan, she be deeply suspicious of the Soviet Union.Together they advocate a hard line toward Moscow and championedmilitary readiness - even though she be the first to recognizemikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader she could do business with.mrs. Thatcher encourage the huge Pentagon buildup that reagannurtured under the theme of peace through strength. Ronnie side with Margaret.Washington's special relationship with London seem to slipwhen Reagan leave power. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher disagree publiclylast year over her government's decision to deport vietnamese andcambodian boat people who be flee their countries to hongkong.bush, a veteran of world politics, know many leaders around theglobe. Mrs. Thatcher suddenly seem to be just one of the gang.the Berlin Wall be collapse and it appear as if Bush foundgerman Chancellor Helmut Kohl more interesting than Mrs. Thatcher.She be merely one in a parade of foreign dignitaries who get theprized invitation to visit Bush at Camp David this year.nevertheless, Bush say he expect the special relationshipbetween the United States and Great Britain to remain on a steadykeel.mrs. Thatcher do her part, demonstrate her loyalty. Forawhile she and Bush be seemingly alone in their suspicions ofGorbachev's unilateral cutbacks in troops and arms in Europe, andappeared uncertain how to respond.under intense pressure from Congress, Bush begin to warm to thesoviet leader. now they seem almost best of friends.on the persian Gulf, Bush say he would not rule out possiblemilitary force, and order a huge buildup of troops to make histhreat credible. Mrs. Thatcher, characteristically, be tougher.she say that unless Saddam Hussein get out of Kuwait soon, thewest would have to use military force to dislodge him.she call Saddam a loser, and the state-controlled Iraqinews agency reply that she be an old hag.now, she be leaving.
