She have the courage of her convictions,he said.prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel saidafter hear ofher resignation that Israel feel a moment of sorrow because weall know this special personality, Mrs. Thatcher, who do manythings and be an outstanding leader.prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan say the british primeminister be a rare leader of firm convictions who be invigoratedthe United Kingdom and I feel great regret that she have withdrawnfrom the front line.belgium's prime minister, Wilfried Martens, applaud thedetermining role she play during more than 10 years in her owncountry and on the international scene.said Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia, Even those likemyself who have be at odds with Margaret Thatcher on particularissues have admire her courage and tenacity of purpose.whatever the forces array against her, she be alwaysprepared to pursue with the utmost vigor those positions in whichshe believed.dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said, In the many years thatshe place such an important stamp on the policies of the UnitedKingdom, Mrs. Thatcher have show that she do not avoid makingdifficult decisions that she deem to be in the nation's interest.this, too, be such a decision which deserve respect.former french President Valery Giscard d'estaing, now alegislator in the European Parliament, say Mrs. Thatcher'sdecision to quit be dignify and courageous.margaret Thatcher will be see with Winston Churchill as thegreatest british prime minister of the last 50 years. The curtainhas fall on the Iron Lady. She deserve our congratulations.even european Commission President Jacques Delors, Mrs.Thatcher's archenemy in Europe, spoke of his high esteem forher, despite their differences.alfred Dregger, parliamentary leader of Germany's governingchristian Democratic Union, say Mrs. Thatcher play a major rolein secure western solidarity in the historical conflict forfreedom and democracy. We thank her for that.former President Reagan speak with great warmth of his closestforeign ally.margaret Thatcher's resoluteness play a key role in endingthe Cold War, he said. She stand up to the Soviets and let themknow she meant business. Her deep and abide dedication to theprinciples of liberty and democracy serve as an inspiration tooppressed peoples everywhere who know that Margaret Thatcher wouldnever waver in her belief that all men and women be entitle tolive in freedom.margaret Thatcher set the example of what a womancould achieve in british society, but her critics say she didlittle else to help women along.for some, it be enough that her political career reach theheights.one woman write to The Independent newspaper last week that her7-year-old daughter wonder what title Mrs. Thatcher's successorwould hold, since he couldn't be call prime minister, that's agirl's name.emma Nicholson, a Conservative Party lawmaker, say it be onceunthinkable that a woman would ever be a british prime minister.she have break the mold once and forever, Ms. Nicholson say inan interview.mrs. Thatcher, who train as a chemist before study law,said she view herself as prime minister, not as a woman. shebelieved the battle for women's rights have be largely won and wasno believer in feminism.What have it ever do for me? she once asked.mrs. Thatcher, who step down on Thursday, urge women to getinvolved in politics, but do little to pull them up the ladder.several female lawmakers be appoint to junior executiveposts in various ministries, but the only woman to serve in aThatcher Cabinet be Baroness Young, leader of the House of Lordsfrom 1981 to 1983.The truth be that although Mrs. Thatcher be a woman, shedoesn't believe in the advancement of women, Clare Short, a LaborParty lawmaker, say last month.edwina Currie, a former junior health minister, say any otherprime minister would have have several women in and out of thecabinet.it's Margaret's fault that the only people stand (tosucceed her) wear trousers, Mrs. Currie say last week. Trree menare vie to succeed her as Conservative Party leader and thusprime minister in a vote by party lawmakers set for Tuesday.Traditional male attitudes remain strong in Britain, from theupper-crust, all-male clubs of London to the topless women pictureddaily in the tabloid press.Women be pay less than men and be poorly represent inmanagement jobs and in Parliament.However, campaigners for women rights say there be encouragingsigns at the grassroots.the critical mass of women have enter middle management ingovernment and business, say Lesley Abdela, a founding member ofthe 300 Group.The group seek equal representation for women in the 650-seathouse of Commons, which now have 43 female members.Women represent 43 percent of the british labor force in 1988,compared with 40 percent in 1979 when Mrs. Thatcher become primeminister. Britain have a high proportion of work women thanother European Community countries.Though Mrs. Thatcher never make a priority of women's issues,she do introduce some helpful legislation: tax concessions forworkplace nurseries; independent taxation for married women; andlegislation to compel absent fathers to pay child benefits.but as prime minister, she anger feminists by oftenemphasizing women's traditional roles of homemakers andcare-givers.angela Rumbold, the Conservative Party's minister for women'sissues, contend that an enormous amount have be do forwomen during the Thatcher years.I'm not sure what she could have go beyond promote peoplewho be there just because they be women, she say in aninterview. Margaret Thatcher be a great meritocrat. She believesin get people to succeed on their merits.jo Hawkins of the 300 Group, which be seek equal numbers ofwomen in the House of Commons, believe Mrs. Thatcher'sextraordinary abilities make it difficult for her to understand theneeds of the average woman.she would say that anybody can do it, just stick to yourprinciples and get up and do it, Ms. Hawkins said. I thinkbecause of her character, her personality and her amazingself-confidence, she isn't aware of how the normal personstruggles.prime Minister Margaret Thatcher have weaken herposition and kick off the race to succeed her by say she plansto step down after win another term, opposition leaders andpolitical observers said.a pro-thatcher newspaper today say she have merely state theobvious and that her statements be no cause for astonishment.mrs. Thatcher tell The Sunday Correspondent in an interviewpublished Sunday that she hop to lead her Conservative Party to afourth successive election but say it be unlikely she would tryfor a fifth.i think people would think it be time for someone else tocarry the torch, she tell the newspaper.the Sunday Times of London say in a commentary: Mrs. Thatcherhas commit a colossal blunder.she have give the riders for the Tory succession theirstarting orders years in advance of the actual race, thenewspaper said.the next election must be hold by the summer of 1992, but it isexpected Mrs. Thatcher will call it in 1991.Mrs. thatcher, who turn 64 last month, have never previouslymade it clear in public when she plan to retire as party leader.she be elect in 1979, the first female prime minister in Europe,and win re-election in 1983 and in 1987, when she say she plannedto go on and on.earlier this year, Mrs. Thatcher overtake Liberal Lord Asquith's1908-1916 tenure as prime minister to become Britain's longestcontinuously serve prime minister of the 20th century.mrs. Thatcher's popularity be the low of any prime ministersince opinion polls begin in Britain 50 years ago, and seniorcolleagues have publicly admonish her to change her leadershipstyle follow the surprise resignation of her treasury chief,nigel Lawson.Lord Callaghan, former Labor prime minister whom Mrs. Thatcherdefeated in 1979, say her comments have considerably weaken herposition.if her party win the next election, it be expect Mrs.Thatcher would step down before her term end to allow hersuccessor to choose a time to call a new election.my guess be that the Tory party will want someone as leaderwho could take them through the next Parliament, Callaghan said.if Mrs. Thatcher resigns while in office, her successor electedby the party automatically become prime minister with approval ofqueen Elizabeth II, but convention dictates that he or she seek amandate in a general election as soon as possible.the Sunday Times speculate she would step down by 1994. Mrs.Thatcher would celebrate her 69th birthday that year and herhusband, Denis, will be 79 and his age may have be a factor inher decision, the newspaper said.the newspaper predict the opposition Labor Party will try topromote leader Neil Kinnock as the occupant-in-waiting of 10Downing St., who be ready, able and willing to complete a fullterm.kinnock call Mrs. Thatcher's comments the interview ofsomeone prepare herself for quitting. Mentally, Margaret Thatcheris prepare herself for pack her bags.in an editorial today, the pro-thatcher Daily Telegraph saidmrs. Thatcher be merely state the obvious by indicate shewould not seek a fifth term.even be she not to fight a fifth election, Mrs. Thatchercould yet enjoy seven more years in charge, it said.by then she would be in her 70s, and her devoted husband adecade older ... Nonetheless, what other politician would beexpected to entertain an inquiry about his or her intentions inseven years time? And can it really be a cause for astonishmentthat Mrs. Thatcher be unwilling to commit herself to politicalactivity in her mid-70s and beyond?
column5: Britain's Iron Lady, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, resigns on Thursday.
column6: The Iron Lady of British politics, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, retired on Thursday. Her retirement, which took world leaders by surprise, followed a decision by her cabinet members not to support her in an upcoming vote. Mrs. Thatcher served longer than any other prime minister in the 20th Century.
column7: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher resigned on Thursday after her cabinet withdrew its support in an upcoming vote. The move was seen as an attempt to head off a campaign by former defense minister Hazeltine to wrest control of the Conservative Party. The announcement took President Bush, and other world leaders, by surprise. Mrs. Thatcher's special relationship with the Reagan administration was well known. Strong willed, the Iron Lady, was prime minister for over 11 years, longer than any other prime minister of this century. While prime minister, she is credited with turning around the declining British economy as well as helping shape international politics.
column8: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the Iron Lady of British politics, resigned Thursday. Serving for over 11 years, longer than any prime minister in the 20th Century, the announcement of her resignation took the world by surprise. Mrs. Thatcher was the first woman prime minister in Great Britain and is credited with reviving the faltering British economy in the early '80s. Former President Reagan had nothing but praise for Mrs. Thatcher. While he was still in office, the two shared a special relationship, calling each other Margaret and Ronnie and often appearing together at international gatherings. The relationship with American cooled with the coming of the Bush administration but had improved in recent months. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev also had nothing but praise for Mrs. Thatcher and her attitude to the Soviet Union softened after her meeting with him. Her critics were not less vocal. Iraq rejoiced at her departure, while Argentina was guarded it its comments. Critics at home complained about her lack of sensitivity to women's issues. Queen Elizabeth II, awarded Mrs. Thatcher the Order of Merit on Friday while elevating her husband, Denis, to the hereditary title of baronet, dispelling rumors of animosity between the two women.

column3: A ranking member of Chancellor HelmutKohl's party demand the Soviet Union hand over Erich Honecker,who be want by german authorities on manslaughter charges, anewspaper report on Saturday.Federal lawmaker Johannes Gerster say refusal to turn over thedeposed east german leader for trial could burden Bonn andMoscow's outstanding relations, the Neue Osnabruecker Zeitungnewspaper reported.a Berlin court have issue an arrest warrant for Honecker, 78, onthe manslaughter charges. He be accuse of issue shoot-to-killorders to east german guards at the now-fallen Berlin Wall.Honecker have deny all charges against him, include that hewas personally responsible for the estimated 200 people who diedtrying to escape his repressive government.he have take refuge at a soviet military hospital in Beelitz,outside Berlin.Soviet officials have say Honecker be stay at the hospitalfor humanitarian reasons, and german police need permission fromthe Soviets to gain entry.i demand that the soviet government immediately release ErichHonecker and extradite him to german justice officials, theosnabrueck newspaper quote Gerster, a member of Kohl's ChristianDemocrats, as saying.honecker's fate be one of the first issues face Bonn andmoscow since they sign several treaties design to draw the twonations closer together.ousted east german leader Erich Honecker, whois expect to be indict for high treason, be arrest Mondaymorning upon release from a hospital and take to prison, theofficial news agency ADN said.the news agency say the 77-year-old Honecker be arrest afterbeing release from East Berlin's Charite hospital, where he hadundergone surgery for a malignant kidney tumor.honecker be immediately take to East Berlin's Rummelsburgprison, the brief dispatch said. Honecker, 78, be jail for one day injanuary.mielke for years head the dreaded secret police, know asstasi, which build up files on 6 million East Germans and keep atight rein on the population. He be one of Honecker's closestaides.after the popular revolt last fall that oust the Communistregime and open the way to german unification, Mielke and otherformer communist leaders be jailed.mielke remains in custody. Honecker be release from jail forhealth reasons.west german authorities on Tuesday open a criminalinvestigation of Mielke. column9: Honecker, former head of East Germany, arrested and charged following his ouster by pro-democracy forces.
column10: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died in 1994 in Chile.  He had lived there since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker was toppled from power in 1989 after 18 years of his oppressive regime.  Following his downfall, he was arrested and charged with treason, corruption, abuse of power and manslaughter.
column11: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died on 29 May 1994 in Santiago Chile. He had been living there since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker and his regime were toppled in October 1989,  by  pro-democracy demonstrators, leading to the eventual unification of East and West Germany.  He, along with several members of his Politburo, were arrested and charges with treason, corruption, and abuse of power.  Honecker was also charged with manslaughter, stemming from his orders, which resulted in the deaths of East Germans attempting to flee to the West.  Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years by using extreme repression.
column12: Erich Honecker, former head of East Germany, died on 29 May 1994 in Santiago Chile.  He and his wife Margot had been living with their daughter in Santiago since his release from prison in 1993.  Honecker and the Communist regime he headed, were toppled in October 1989 by pro-democracy demonstrators, leading to the eventual unification of Germany.  He along with several members of his Politburo were arrested and charged with treason, corruption and abuse of power.  Honecker was also charged with manslaughter, stemming from his shoot-to-kill order, which resulted in the deaths of East Germans attempting to flee to the West.  Honecker had been seriously ill since his downfall and had spent much time in hospital and under house arrest. Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years using his secret police, known as Stasi, which built up files on 6 million East Germans and kept a tight rein on the population.  As protests gathered strength in the fall of 1989, Honecker "lost touch with reality" according to former members of his regime.  Club swinging police brutally beat demonstrators, when Soviet President Gorbachev was in town to commemorate the country's 40th anniversary.  The uprising was a turning point that speeded Honecker's downfall days later.
column13: The trials and tribulations of East German leader Erich Honecker.
column14: In 1989, former East German leader Erich Honecker was arrested to await trial for treason, corruption, and possible murder charges. Judged too ill for imprisonment, he was placed in an East German hospital. In 1992, he was tried, imprisoned, and released in 1993. He died in Santiago, Chile in 1994.
column15: In October 1989, after being hospitalized for kidney surgery, former East German leader Erich Honecker--along with other Party officials--was arrested and imprisoned to await trial for treason and corruption. Judged too ill from imprisonment, he was placed in a Soviet East Berlin hospital. He also faced a murder charge about his role in killing people trying to escape from East Berlin.In 1992, Honecker took refuge in the Chilean Embassy in Moscow but was soon ordered to leave. In Germany, he was tried, imprisoned and released in 1993. He died in Santiago, Chile in 1994 at age 81.
column16: Former East German leader Erich Honecker was under house arrest outside East Berlin since being ousted in October 1989. Honecker and other party officials have been investigated for corruption and treason. After hospitalization for kidney surgery, he was arrested and imprisoned to await trial. Judged too ill for imprisonment but fit enough for prosecution, he was placed in a Soviet East Berlin hospital.In August, Honecker was interrogated about his role in the killing of some 200 people trying to escape from East Berlin. A murder charge would put him away for life. His trial was delayed because of East German-West German merger negotiations. In December, Soviet authorities refused to return him to Germany claiming it would "burden" Moscow and Bonn's "outstanding relations."In December 1991, Honecker took refuge in the Chilean Embassy in Moscow. Gorbachev was his protector until his political fortunes declined and he ordered Honecker to leave the country. He was tried and imprisoned in Germany in early 1992 but was released in 1993. He traveled to Santiago, Chile to join his daughter who had married a Chilean. He lived with his wife in a wealthy Santiago area where he died in 1994 at age 81.

column3: The expensive practice of use ballooncatheters to force open heart arteries immediately after heartattacks, now routinely do at many large hospitals, be unnecessaryand should be abandoned, accord to a major study release Tuesday.The study find that if heart attack victims quickly receiveclot-dissolving drugs, they usually don't need the extra step of thecommon balloon procedure, know as angioplasty.some experts say the results be good news, because they meanthat most heart attack patients can be treat in communityhospitals, where angioplasty be not available.the study also have an important financial message. Its authorsestimated that if angioplasty be widely adopt after heartattacks, it could raise the nation's annual medical bills by $704million.This trial have settle one of the most important questions inmodern-day cardiology, comment Dr. J. Ward Kennedy of theuniversity of Washington, Seattle.The study be phase 2 of the Thrombolysis in Miocardial InfarctionTrial, or TIMI-II, direct by Dr. Eugene Braunwald of Brigham andwomen's Hospital in Boston.The first phase of the study show that give people aclot-dissolving drug call tissue plasminogen activator, or tpa,immediately after heart attacks dramatically improve their chancesof survival.the late study, present at the annual meeting of the AmericanHeart Association, be intend to see whether people do betterstill if doctors try to clear away any remain blockages aftergiving TPA.At 50 hospitals across the United States, doctors randomlyassigned 1,636 patients to get angioplasty within two days of theirheart attacks if tests show there be any chance they mightbenefit. Sixty percent of them actually undergo the procedure,which temporarily inflate balloons in dangerously narrowed heartarteries to squeeze them open.A comparison group of 1,626 also get TPA. But they be notconsidered for angioplasty unless they have linger heart pain orabnormal exercise tests during their recovery.after 42 days, 11 percent of those in the angioplasty group haddied or suffer further heart attacks, as do 10 percent of thosein the comparison group.a year after the treatment, there be no difference in survival.about 93 percent of both groups be still alive.there do not appear to be any additional benefit fromangioplasty, Braunwald said.dr. Thomas J. Ryan of Boston University Medical Center commented,we have the answer in this trial to a very important question ofhealth care delivery.While small hospitals can give clot-dissolving drugs to heartattack patients, most of them do not have the sophisticated labswhere angioplasty be performed.If the study have find that immediate angioplasty improvessurvival, it would have mean that many more angioplasty labs wouldneed to be establish and more doctors train to give theprocedure.the watch word be watchful wait to see if patients needangioplasty. This ultimately make it possible for patients to betreated in community hospitals and be transfer to terciary carecenters if angioplasty be needed, say Dr. Howard Morgan,immediate past president of the heart association.heart attacks occur when a clot block an artery that feed theheart muscle. The purpose of TPA and similar drugs be to dissolvethese clots before the muscle dies. To be effective, the drugs mustbe give within about four hours of the start of heart attacksymptoms.Experts say that only about 20 percent of heart attack victimsare consider to be candidates for the drugs. many people delaygoing to the hospital until permanent damage occurs. In others, thetreatment may be consider too dangerous because of recent surgeryor a history of strokes.balloon angioplasty be also widely use to treat people withclogged heart arteries who have not suffer heart attacks. Thelatest study do not question the usefulness of this kind ofangioplasty.Deaths from heart and blood vesseldisease drop 24 percent over the past decade, but it remain byfar the nation's big killer, take a life every 32 seconds, theamerican Heart Association say Sunday.The good news be that we continue to see an improvement in thedeath rate from the big killer of our population, say Dr.Bernadine Healy of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, who be presidentof the heart association.those trends be dramatic and don't seem to be reversing, shesaid. The bad news be that heart disease be still kill almost 1million Americans a year, and we've get a long way to go.the association release the statistics at its annual forum forscience writers.Experts attribute the decline in death rates to a combination ofhealthier live habits, include few cigarettes and good food,and improve medical treatment.The public ought to appreciate the progress that have be madein heart disease over the past 20 years, say Dr. Myron L.Weisfeldt of Johns Hopkins University. It's almost unbelievable.There be almost no form of heart disease that we can't approachwithout meaningful treatment.however, Weisfeldt, who be president-elect of the heartassociation, also caution that much work remains, both inimproving care and encourage people to take good care of theirhealth.i believe we can prevent at least 50 percent of the ischemicheart disease in the United States by the year 2000 if we stopsmoking, get cholesterol treat if it's above 220, and identify andtreat hypertension, he said.ischemic heart disease be the clogging of blood vessels that feedthe heart. It underlie most heart attacks, the single most lethalheart ailment.association figures indicate that in 1986 the most recent yearfor which there be statistics an estimate 978,500 Americans diedfrom heart attacks, strokes and other diseases of the heart andblood vessels. Cancer, the no. 2 killer, take 466,000 lives.between 1976 and 1986, the death rate from all forms ofcardiovascular disease fell 24 percent. It decline 28 percent forheart attacks and 40 percent for strokes.the association's figures show that more than one in fourAmericans suffers some form of cardiovascular disease, and almosthalf of those eventually die from it.about 60 percent of the heart attack deaths occur before thevictim reach the hospital. Studies show that about half of allheart attack victims wait more than two hours before get to anemergency room.weisfeldt say a major health goal be get people to go to thehospital within three or four hours of the first sign of heartattacks. During this period, there be still time to give them drugsto dissolve the blood clots that be cause their heart attacks.This treatment can save lives and reduce the disability of heartattacks.other major goals, he said, include find ways to improve theeffectiveness of angioplasty, a technique that use balloons to openclogged heart arteries, and find surgical and medical techniquesto identify and protect people at risk of cardiac arrest.the heart association estimate that cardiovascular disease willcost $88.2 billion this year in medical expenses and lose wages.among other statistics release by the association:the most common cardiovascular disease be high blood pressure,which affect 60 million Americans.About 200,000 of the deaths from cardiovascular disease eachyear occur in people under age 65.There be 1,418 heart transplants in 1987, almost nine times asmany as in 1983.About 2.5 million Americans have angina, the chest painresulting from clogged heart arteries. About 300,000 new cases occurannually.as many as 1.5 million Americans will have heart attacks thisyear.a drug that ease the heart's workload cancut the risk of new cardiac attacks and death by 20 percent inpeople recover from heart attacks, accord to a major studyreleased Thursday.The study, conduct in Denmark, find that the drug Verapamil,known as a calcium channel blocker, be effective for the 1{ yearsafter a heart attack. Calcium blockers be among several classes ofmedicines commonly prescribe to relieve high blood pressure.this be the first trial that indicate that a calcium blockermay be beneficial after an acute myocardial infarction, or heartattack, say Dr. Carl J. Pepine of the University of Florida.Several other studies of calcium blockers, include one largeu.s. study publish last year, fail to find any benefit fromusing the medicines after heart attacks.according to the Danish study, Verapamil be about as effectiveas another variety of blood pressure medicines know as betablockers at protect people after heart attacks.While calcium blockers may not replace beta blockers after heartattacks, the researchers say these drugs still should have a rolein treatment.we feel it be important to have alternatives. many patients donot tolerate beta blockers, say Dr. Kresten Mellemgaard ofcentral County Hospital in Hillerod, Denmark, a co-author of thestudy.beta blockers be generally not recommend for people withasthma and emphysema. This mean the drugs often cannot be give tocigarette smokers, who be frequent victims of heart attacks.In the study, conduct at 20 community hospitals, doctorscompared 897 patients who get Verapamil after heart attack with878 people who take placebos.after 18 months of followup, there be 146 deaths or recurringheart attacks among the Verapamil patients, compare with 180 inpeople who get the dummy medication.we want to see if an effect would be observe withverapamil, say Dr. Forgen Fischer Hansen of Copenhagen MunicipalHospital.If it have an effect, it should be see in the first 12 to 18months, because there be a big increase in mortality in myocardialinfarction in this period, he said. then it levels off. That'swhat we demonstrated. It worked.the researchers believe that by reduce the amount of workneeded by the heart to sustain circulation, calcium blockerslowered the chances of ischemia, episodes in which the heart's ownmuscle be deprive of oxygen.they say they be unsure why early studies fail to showany benefit from calcium blockers after heart attacks. However,they note that some studies enrol patients who be also takingbeta blockers. And this might have obscure any benefits fromcalcium blockers.the results be present at a meeting of the American Collegeof Cardiology. Among other research describe at the meeting:dr. James H. However,like other studies, this one find that aspirin signficantly cutthe risk of heart attacks.dr. Eugene Braunwald of Harvard Medical School say the nextphase of a large study of clot-dissolving drugs will see whateffect they have in unstable angina. This be a condition in whichpeople suffer spontaneous chest pain that be not trigger by workor stress. Until now, the drugs have be use only to treat heartattacks.an intestinal operation to lower the cholesterolof heart attack patients reduce their risk for another heartattack or death from heart disease, researchers say today.the surgery, call a partial ileal bypass, have one significantdrawback: It cause chronic diarrhea that persist for years.in the operation, doctors change the route of the smallintestine so about one-third of it be bypassed. This reduce theamount of cholesterol that be absorb into the bloodstream.the $52 million, 17-year study be conduct on people who hadalready suffered heart attacks. The approach lengthen the livesof people who have very mild heart attacks but not those with moresevere heart damage.during an average of 10 years of follow up, the death rate amongsurgery patients who have sustain minimal heart damage be 24percent. In a comparison group without the intestinal surgery, itwas 39 percent.dr. Henry Buchwald of the University of Minnesota, who directedthe study, say the surgery should be consider along withcholesterol-lowering drugs as a possible standard treatment.it have a role in the management of patients with highcholesterol who have have a heart attack, Buchwald said. It iseminently logical to extend all cholesterol-lowering therapy,including this, to patients with high cholesterol who have not hada heart attack.besides diarrhea, those who undergo the surgery be somewhatmore prone to have kidney stones, gallstones and intestinalobstructions.the study be conduct in Minneapolis, Los Angeles,Philadelphia and Little Rock, Ark., and publish in today's NewEngland Journal of Medicine.Despite wide acceptance of cholesterol lowering, doubts remainabout whether it actually help people live long if they alreadyhave healthy hearts. Although the late study be conductedexclusively on people who have suffer heart attacks, Buchwald saidhe believe the research should settle that question.it offer the strong justification for marked lipid(cholesterol) ineervention that have ever be offered, Buchwaldsaid. It be a very powerful study and should, except for certainpeople who will never be satisfied, end the cholesterolcontroversy.in the study, 421 people who recover from heart attacksunderwent the surgery, while a comparison group of 417 people weretreated with diet alone. At the start of the study, their averagecholesterol levels be 251. The surgery lower people'scholesterol 23 percent.the overall risk of die from heart disease or sufferinganother non-fatal heart attack be reduce 35 percent among thesurgical patients with the healthy hearts. The surgical patientsalso require less than half as many coronary bypass operationsbecause of clogged heart arteries.new treatments that stop a heart attack in itstracks may help victims to get out of the hospital more quicklythan ever before, perhaps even three days after their attacks, astudy publish today concludes.Doctors from the University of Michigan Medical Center studiedthe effects of send a few carefully select heart patients homeearly. They find that these people have no unusual complications,got back to work sooner and have substantially low medical bills.it be an extraordinarily safe strategy, say Dr. Eric J.Topol, the study's director. There be no problems with anyserious events.Topol say the early discharges be make possible by two recentmedical advances tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, andangioplasty.when give quickly after a heart attack, TPA can dissolve clotsin the heart's arteries and minimize damage. Angioplasty canproduce similar results by open up the clogged arteries withtiny balloons.the report represent the late in a steady three-decade trendof send heart attack patients home from the hospital after evershorter stays.however, the study in the New England Journal of Medicine saidmore research be need before the findings be widely adopted.In the 1950s, doctors often recommend that patients stay inbed for one to two months after a heart attack. When PresidentDwight D. Eisenhower suffer an uncomplicated heart attack in1955, he spend seven weeks recover in the hospital.however, doctors learn that long inactivity do more harm thangood. Patients get out of shape, develop blood clots and becamedemoralized.in the 1960s, the stay be shorten to three weeks and in the1970s to two weeks. Now, doctors typically keep heart attackpatients hospitalize seven to 10 days.In their paper, the doctors determine that 80 of the 507 heartattack patients study be healthy enough to be consider forearly discharge. none of them have irregular heart beats, chest painor heart failure. Treadmill test show no signs of heart attackdamage.forty patients be send home after three days, while the reststayed seven to 10 days. After six months of followup, none haddied, and the number of medical problems in both groups be similar.however, people in the early discharge group be able to returnto work about two weeks sooner than the others, and their medicalbills be significantly low $12,546 versus $17,868.The researchers estimate that if 15 percent of all heart attackpatients be discharge after three days, the annual saving wouldbe at least $280 million.in an accompany editorial, Dr. Gregory D. Curfman, a deputyeditor of the journal, caution that the study be not largeenough to spot complications that might result from reducinghospital stays.this single study, he wrote, be not sufficient to justifysweeping changes in current management practices for all patientswho may at first appear to have uncomplicated heart attacks.Doctors should be cautious in prescribe aspirin as a preventer of heart attacks until more research support its value, the Food and Drug Administration said. take aspirin to prevent heart attacks may increase some people's chances of dying of other things, especially hemorrhagic strokes, the agency say in a commentary in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The FDA persuade aspirin makers in March to refrain from promote aspirin as a preventer of first heart attacks, at least for now. A study publish in January indicate an aspirin every other day reduce the risk of nonfatal, first heart attack 47% in 11,000 male doctors over five years, compare with 11,000 who take a non-aspirin substitute. Aspirin tend to promote bleeding by reduce the ability of blood platelets to help form clots. Heart attack usually occur when clots form in the arteries nourish the heart and choke off its blood supply. But aspirin may increase health risks for people who already have clot problems, or for those who have high blood pressure, which put them at increase risk for hemorrhagic strokes, the FDA commentary said. Strokes be the result of brain damage cause by bleed in the brain or by blood clots; hemorrhagic strokes be those cause by bleeding. The FDA commentary point to 10 hemorrhagic strokes record among the 11,000 subjects take aspirin in the recent study, compare with two such strokes among 11,000 subjects take the substitute. Overall death rates for the two groups be the same, though the aspirin group's nonfatal heart-attack rate be much lower. There be 104 nonfatal heart attacks among the aspirin users and 189 in the comparison group. "Physicians, will, for a time, be force to make their professional judgments about aspirin use on the basis of incomplete information," say the FDA commentary, co-written by agency Director Dr. Frank E. Young. "We agree with them completely," say Dr. Julie Buring, a Harvard University researcher who participate in the aspirin study. She add in a telephone interview yesterday that an extension of the study be under way, and researchers expect to report to the FDA in late fall. The commentary note a british study, also release in January, of 5,000 male physicians that find that aspirin fail to protect against heart attacks, and that it be associate with a 2 1/2-fold increase in disable strokes.a drug use to treat patients complainingof chest pain also could help prevent recur heart attacks infour out of five heart patients, accord to a study publish intoday's edition of the New England Journal of Medicine.Surprisingly, however, the study find that the drug, diltiazem,increases the chance of a subsequent heart attack in patients whosehearts pump abnormally, experts said.even so, the results may trigger an increase in the use of thedrug, which be now primarily use to treat angina, doctors said.the drug be test in 38 hospitals in the United States andcanada on patients who have recently suffer a heart attack, saiddr. Arthur Moss, a clinical professor of medicine at the Universityof Rochester and the principal investigator for the study.the results suggest the drug may be quite effective indecreasing the likelihood of a second heart attack in the majorityof patients, Moss said. But the study also surprisingly suggeststhat patients who suffer pulmonary congestion should not be givendiltiazem because the drug increase the chance of a subsequentheart attack.we now know when to prescribe this drug and when not to,Moss said. That's what this study be all about.diltiazem be a calcium entry blocker, the new class of drugsto be introduce in the fight against heart disease. Nitrates andbeta blockers be the other types commonly prescribe by doctors.the study involve 2,466 heart attack patients, who be giveneither 240 milligrams of diltiazem a day or a placebo. Patientswere recruit from 1983 to 1986 and follow for 12 to 52 months.Overall, the drug only decrease additional heart attack 11percent, which be not statistically significant, Moss said.but in patients who have normal or near-normal heart pumpfunction 1,909 patients or 80 percent of the total group diltiazem decrease the chance of another heart attack by 25percent, Moss said.in patients whose hearts have pump problems, the drug not onlydidn't help, but it increase the chance of a heart attack by 25percent.Dr. John Schroeder, a cardiologist and professor at StanfordUniversity, say he be surprise that the drug increase thechance of heart attack in any group and that overall results werenot higher.But the bottom line be that this be the first study to showthat diltiazem can be effective, Schroeder said. I think itwill mean that more patients will be routinely put on this drug ona long-term basis.dr. George Beller, a cardiologist and professor at theuniversity of Virginia, say he be also somewhat surprise aboutthe increase in heart attacks in the group suffer pulmonarycongestion.this be one of the first reports that seem to identifythat, he said.diltiazem and two other calcium entry blockers be introducedin the past decade, Beller said, and research into how effectivethey be in various applications be in its early stages.Nitrates have be use for more than 50 years, and betablockers be develop in the 1960s.Aspirin sales jump 41 percent for a few weeksearlier this year, not because of a rash of headaches.a study of more than 22,000 male doctors have show that take asingle aspirin every other day could cut heart attack risk in half.the study be one of a series of recent reports show for thefirst time that doctors be able not only to treat heart attacks but also to prevent them.in the most recent report, doctors find that one aspirin tabletand a single dose of a clot-dissolving drug give within 24 hourscan dramatically cut the risk of a second fatal heart attack.Without the treatment, patients have a 13 percent chance of dyingfrom a second heart attack within five weeks, the researchersfound. With the treatment, the figure drop to 8 percent.The real discovery be that treatment for patients be go toreduce in-hospital mortality substantially, say Richard Peto ofoxford University, one of the study's authors.heart disease be the nation's lead cause of death, by far.the National Center for Health Statistics reports that 762,820Americans die of heart disease in 1987.To put it another way: Of the 2,127,000 American who die thatyear, more than one in three died of heart disease. (this do notinclude those who die of blood-vessel diseases, such as strokes.)the drugs most responsible for the recent success in preventingheart attacks be the new clot-dissolvers and that old standby,aspirin.the usual cause of heart attacks be a blockage of the coronaryarteries, which supply the heart muscle with oxygen-rich blood. theblockage arise from the buildup of fats, cholesterol and clottedblood.Clot-dissolvers break up clots, thus restore blood flow.aspirin interfere with aspects of the clot process, help toprevent clot formation in the first place.the limited sales of the clot-dissolving drugs in the UnitedStates show that many doctors be still not use them, despitetheir proven success. But that be begin to change.some doctors predict that in the not-too-distant future thesedrugs will be judge so safe that they will be administeredroutinely by paramedics in ambulances before suspected heart attackvictims even reach the hospital.we have to know how to respond quickly, and we have to havethe courage to use these drugs in the absence of definitivediagnosis, say Dr. Burton Sobel of Washington University in St.Louis, a pioneer in the testing of the clot-dissolvers.the most important thing we can do be teach patients inadvance about the value of early treatment, he says.while most public attention have focus on this new ability toprevent heart attacks, researchers have also make importantprogress in speed the recovery of patients who survive heartattacks.Researchers at the University of Michigan recently determinedthat some heart attack victims can be release from the hospital assoon as three days after their heart attacks. most heart attacksvictims be keep in the hospital for at least seven to 10 days.the patients give early discharge be able to return to worktwo weeks sooner than others in the study group. After six months,not one death be record in the early-discharge group. Theresearchers conclude that perhaps 15 percent of heart attacksvictims could be safely discharge after three days.in July, Stanford University doctors find that workers who wentback to their jobs about seven weeks after their heart attack didat least as well as workers who go back after a more typicalconvalescence of about 10 or 11 weeks.all of these advances come at a time when public health expertsare increasingly emphasize the role of good health and goodnutrition in lower heart disease risk.early next year, the American Heart Association seal of approvalwill begin appear on foods that be low in fat and cholesteroland therefore can help reduce heart disease risk.u.s. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop in July issue his firstreport on nutrition, call on Americans to lower theirconsumption of fats and to eat more vegetables, fruits, fish,poultry and whole grains.the report have be liken to the first Surgeon Generals reporton smoking, issue in 1964, which focus public attention onsmoking's hazards. Koop's recommendations largely echo those of theamerican Heart Association, but they should help carry the messageto many more people.progress in research on heart disease be make clear that theheart attack be no longer a mysterious killer that strike withoutwarning and cannot be defend against.much can be do to prevent heart attacks, great improvementsare be make in treatments, and recovery be faster than everbefore.the use of a clot-dissolver and aspirin could, alone, save25,000 live a year in the United States, doctors say.these results, say Dr. Peter Sleight of Oxford University,will change medical practice worldwide.a natural substance call transform growthfactor beta appear to be able to limit damage to cardiac cellsfollowing a heart attack, accord to a study publish in thejournal Science.In a study at the Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, agroup of laboratory rats induce to have heart attacks suffer 50percent less cell damage after injections of transform growthfactor beta than do rat that do not receive the TGF beta.tgf beta be a growth factor that oppose some of the bad guysfollowing a heart attack, say Dr. Allan M. Lefer, a professor atjefferson.lefer say his research team simulate heart attacks in 24 ratsby partially block key arteries in their hearts.in 12 of the rats, the researchers inject a placebo. In theother 12, they inject transform growth factor beta.For those who receive the TGF beta, say Lefer, the damagefrom the attack be much less severe. There be about 50 percentless injury with TGF beta than without it.the extent of heart cell damage be determine by measure theamount of creatine kinase in the heart tissue follow an attack.Hearts damage when the blood supply be interrupted, as in a heartattack, tend to lose creatine kinase, say Lefer. Thus, bymeasuring for the loss of this substance, researchers coulddetermine the amount of heart damage.lefer say the TGF beta seem to block the action of othersubstances, such as tumor necrosis factor, that can cause bloodvessels to narrow follow a heart attack. Narrowed blood vesselscarry less oxygen-rich blood to cells and this cause additionalinjury follow a heart attack.tgf beta be normally present in heart cells, but the studypublished in Science say that it be miss from rat heart cellsdamaged by a simulated heart attack.Though TGF beta be produce naturally in the body, Lefer saidhis research team use a substance produce artificially bygenentech, a California biotechnology firm.lefer say his team be now conduct additional studies withtgf beta and that any experimental treatment of human heart attackvictims with the substance be at least a year away.jefferson Medical College, where the study be done, be part ofThomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia.Science, which publish the study, be the journal of theamerican Association for the Advancement of Science.The experiment also hint that the blood and urine test,which measure the activity of a blood protein call renin,might suggest a new "risk factor" for heart attacks. Abouthalf of the 1.5 million Americans who suffer a heart attackeach year don't have the know risk factors for heartdisease, such as high cholesterol levels, cigarette smoking,obesity and high blood pressure. It be unknown whatdistinguishes these seemingly healthy people from those whodon't suffer heart attacks.the blood and urine test be already be do in manycommercial laboratories but for medical conditions other thanheart attack risk, say John H. Laragh of the CardiovascularCenter at Cornell University and New York Hospital. "In ourhands, it cost about $40 and in other labs it may cost thepatient $40 to $80," he said. Dr. Laragh pioneer theresearch underlying use of the test, which be develop byhis wife, biochemist Jean E. Sealey. The test, which isn'tpatented, be available in kit form to laboratories.the blood portion of the test determine whether thekidneys be release renin into the blood stream and howactive the chemical is. The release of renin be the firststep in a rapid chemical chain reaction that raise bloodpressure. The urine portion of the test tell how much saltis in the bloodstream. A high concentration of salt in theblood also raise pressure.the test be base on the fact that if the saltconcentration in the blood rises, tend to boost bloodpressure, the activity of the renin normally drop to offsetthe effect of the salt.the new experiment be design to test a theory put forthby Dr. Laragh and his colleagues that the activity of therenin in the blood foretell a possible heart attack. Thetheory have provoke sometimes furious controversy for almost20 years.the Cornell cardiologist have argue that in many peoplewith high blood pressure the activity of the renin in theblood be much high than be warrant by the amount of saltin the blood. such "high renin" people be at a high risk ofa heart attack. On the other hand, in other patients withhigh blood pressure, the activity of the renin be much lowerthan be warrant by the degree of salt in the blood. These"low renin" people be at a low risk of heart attack, Dr.Laragh have maintained.in the experiment, blood and urine samples be obtainedat New York City offices and factories from 1,717 worke
column9: New medical advances reduce the number of heart attacks nationwide.
column10: The chances of having a heart attack, the number one killer in the United States, have decreased significantly in the last decade. Leading the fight against heart disease are the new calcium channel blockers as well as new surgical procedures. Even the simple aspirin, taken every other day lowers the risk of a first heart attack.
column11: New medicines and new treatments which have appeared in the last decade have significantly reduced the heart attack rate in the United States. The introduction of calcium blockers such as Diltiazem and Verapamil significantly reduce the damage caused by a heart attack while even the simple aspirin, taken every other day, also reduces heart attack risk.  Aspiring, when taken with clot-busting drugs, has been shown to be especially helpful. Surgical procedures such as balloon angioplasty and ileal bypass also show promise in the treatment of heart disease. Even life style changes like smoking less or a better diet are effective in lowering the risk of a heart attack.
column12: Medical advances combined with lifestyle changes have combined to significantly reduce the number and severity of heart attacks in the past decade. New medicines such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF) and calcium channel blockers such as Diltiazem and Verapamil, when administered shortly after a heart attack have reduced both the heart damage of the attack as well as the likelihood of a second attack. Even the simple aspirin, taken every other day has been shown to significantly reduce the chances of a first heart attack, especially when used in combination clot dissolving drugs. The FDA warns that further tests with aspirin are required. Aspirin may increase the chances of stroke in people with blood clotting problems or high blood pressure. Surgical techniques, such as balloon angioplasty or partial ileal bypass surgery also show promise in lowering the incidence of a second heart attack. Caution has been advised with angioplasty since it appears to be no more effective that clot-busting drugs in reducing the chances of a second heart attack.  Releasing the patient from the hospital as soon as possible, often within three days, also has a positive effect on recovery. Other factors in the reduction in heart attacks are changes in diet and smoking fewer cigarettes.
column13: Treatments lowering heart attack deaths include drugs, surgery and tests.
column14: New treatments are contributing to fewer deaths from heart attacks over the past decade.  Drugs, surgery and tests to determine all show promise.  Aspirin can prevent heart attacks and clot-dissolving drugs and a substance to limit the damage to cardiac cells improve the chances of heart attack victims.
column15: New treatments are contributing to fewer deaths from heart attacks over the past decade.  Drugs, surgery, and tests to determine risk all show promise.  Taking aspirin can cut heart attack risk in half, but can increase the risk of hemorrhagic stroke in some people.  Post-heart drugs dissolve clots and limit the damage to cardiac cells reducing the risk of a subsequent heart attack.  Angioplasty may be needed for fewer heart attack victims with the use of these drugs. Surgery bypassing one-third of the lower intestine lowers cholesterol and tests to determine levels of a blood protein can identify those at risk for a heart attack.
column16: New treatments are contributing to the decrease in deaths from heart attacks over the past decade.  Experts also credit the decline to healthier living habits, including fewer cigarettes and better food.Aspirin has shown great promise, cutting heart attack risk in half, but for people who have clotting problems or high blood pressure, aspirin seems to increase the risk of hemorrhagic stroke.Other promising drugs include, diltiazen, which can reduce the risk of a second heart attack, Verapanil, which cuts the risk of new heart attacks and death by 20% in people recovering from heart attacks and a natural substance known as TGF which appears to be able to limit damage to cardiac cells following a heart attack.Another drug known as TPA dissolves clots in the heart's arteries and is as effective for most patients as angioplasty.  The use of TPA may help heart attack victims leave the hospital in as early as three days.Surgery bypassing one-third of the lower intestine reduces the amount of cholesterol absorbed by the small intestine, reducing the risk of second heart attacks and a blood and urine test, measuring a blood protein called renin, can help to identify those at risk for a heart attack.

Untilvolcanologists' attention be draw to it by a cluster of earthquakes beneaththe volcano this spring, it have not be study well.; other recentvolcanoes that erupt on the same scale be El Chichon in Mexico in 1983 andnevado del Ruiz in Colombia in 1985.; If it do have a massive eruption,pinatubo's primary means of cause death and destruction would be hellishavalanches of hot ash -- 1,000 degrees or more, flowing and billowing at up to100 mph, engulf and sear all in their path.; "In the bad case, areally big eruption, all of Clark Air Force Base could be covered" withglowing ash, Lipman said.; Just be catch in a cloud of ash blow offthe avalanche be fatal. But it quicklyweakened to a tropical storm with 60 mph winds by the time it be centeredabout 70 miles east of the volcano.; Still, heavy rains churn up by thetyphoon drench Manila and the provinces near the volcano, raise fears ofmudflows that could bury whole towns up to 25 miles away.; Meanwhile,President Corazon Aquino dismiss a british newspaper report that Americanshad warn her of possible radioactive contamination if the volcano damagesnuclear storage sites at Clark Air Base, abandon Monday by nearly 15,000Americans.; The U.S. military begin fly home hundreds of the 28,000Americans who crowd onto Subic Bay Naval Base as a bizarre tropical blizzardof thick volcanic ash cause power failures across the base Friday during athird day of increasingly violent eruptions of Mount Pinatubo.; Showers of'mud drops'; "It look like it's snow outside," say military spokeswomancapt. Kim Urie. Headlights and street lamps be turn on at midafternoon asa "dark, black cloud" pass over the giant Navy base and drop a grittyrain of "mud drops," she said.; At least four people have died, 24 havebeen hurt and four have be list as miss since Pinatubo begin eruptingsunday, after lie dormant for six centuries, officials said. About 84,000people, include Americans, have be evacuated.; Police say 12 peoplehad be arrest for loot at Clark.; Five explosions shake the mountainearly today, shower ash over a wide area and provide a spectacularpre-dawn display of nature's fireworks against a backdrop of lightning andrain.; Friday, eight thunderous explosions shoot a cloud of ash and steamnearly 19 miles high.; Friday's eruptions hurl ash over Clark, 10 mileseast of the volcano, and Subic, 25 miles southwest, where the Clark personnelhad be temporarily housed. Gray ash also fell in Manila, 60 miles south.;at Subic, base spokesman Robert Coble say generators have to be shut down fromtime to time to clean out volcanic ash, plunge the base into darkness.;river temperatures rising; Temperatures in local rivers be rise becauseof the volcanic debris, officials said.; After sunset, the volcano spewedtwo streams of orange, glow material from its crater in what scientiststhought be the first appearance of lava during the weeklong eruptions.;raymundo Punongbayan, director of the Philippine Institute of Vulcanology andseismology, say Friday's blasts be part of a single eruption, the largestsince Mount Pinatubo awake Sunday from its 600-year slumber.; A Britishnewspaper, the Guardian, report Thursday that the Americans declare anuclear alert at Clark late Wednesday and informed governments in Manila andhong Kong that "a nuclear accident in the region be possible." But Aquinotold reporters the story be "baseless and purely fabricated."; The UnitedStates refuse to confirm or deny that it stores nuclear weapons in thephilippines.; Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus also say the eruptionshould have no effect on talks on the future of Clark and Subic, where leasesexpire Sept. 16. The talks be deadlocked over compensation and the durationof a new agreement.; Punongbayan say Mount Pinatubo could remain activefor years if it follow the pattern of similar Philippine volcanoes. Thatwould leave Clark unusable.
column5: Recurring Pinatubo Eruptions Cause Havoc. Nearby Clark Air Base Emptied
column6: A series of volcanic eruptions in June 1991 rocked Mt. Pinatubo in the Philippines. Gases, rock and ash shot from the mountain. Ascending clouds blanketed the area. The large U.S. facility Clark Air Base was evacuated. Farm villages were emptied. Experts issued warnings of a more massive eruption.
column7: Mt. Pinatubo erupted on 9 June 1991 for the first time in 600 years. Further explosions continued for five days, with as many as six in a single day. Philippine and U.S. experts said that a more massive eruption could occur. The mountain shot out gases, rock and ash. Clouds ascending from Pinatubo rose to heights of ten miles, turning day into night and covering wide areas in ash. Personnel from the large U.S. facility at Clark Air Base were evacuated to the naval base at Subic Bay, most of them soon after the first eruption.
column8: After slumbering for 600 years, the Mt. Pinatubo volcano erupted in June 1991. Mt. Pinatubo is on the Philippine Island of Luzon. It first erupted on 9 June, and the eruptions continued through the 14th, with as many as six eruptions on one day. The Philippine Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology, and the United States Geological Survey said the volcanic activity was increasing in a way that suggested a more massive eruption would occur. Heavy rain increased the danger of mudslides.The mountain shot out gases, rock and ash. Mushroom clouds ascended to heights of ten miles. The gray-green clouds turned day into night, and covered wide areas with ash. More than 19,000 panicked villagers within a 12-mile radius were evacuated.Clark Air Base, one of the largest U.S. overseas installations, is about ten miles from Pinatubo. Most airmen, dependents and civilian employees were evacuated to the U.S. Naval Base at Subic Bay on the 11th, following the first major eruption. The remaining personnel left a day or two later. Philippine President Aquino dismissed as a fabrication that she had been warned volcanic damage could cause a nuclear incident.
column9: Pinatubo: Four Dead; 84,000 Evacuated. Clark Not A Contamination Threat
column10: Pinatubo began erupting about two weeks ago. Explosions are increasingly severe.U.S. officials denied the possibility of radioactive contamination if volcanic debris hits the weapons depots at Clark AFB, located 10 miles away. Clark was evacuated.Four dead and 24 injured are attributed to the eruptions. About 84,000 have been evacuated.
column11: Pinatubo began erupting about two weeks ago, after six centuries of dormancy. Located 10 miles from Clark AFB, the explosions have become increasingly severe. The U.S. has denied the possibility of radioactive contamination if volcanic debris hits the weapons depots at Clark AFB, which was evacuated a week ago.At least four dead and 24 injured are attributed to the eruptions. About 84,000 have been evacuated. Heavy rains today have raised fears of catastrophic mudflows.According to Foreign Secretary Manglapus, the eruptions should not effect the stalled talks with the U.S. on new Clark and Subic lease agreements.
column12: Since roaring to life about two weeks ago, explosions at Mount Pinatubo, located 10 miles from Clark AFB in the Philippines, have become increasingly severe. The first eruptions shot gas, steam and ash 12,000 feet above the mountain. Today's eruptions spewed matter over 12 miles high, and a possible lava flow was seen for the first time. Clark, evacuated nearly a week ago, is covered in ash, as is Subic Bay naval base, which received the 16,000 Clark evacuees. U.S. officials, while not commenting on whether nuclear weapons are at the abandoned base, denied the possibility of radioactive contamination if molten rock hits the weapons depots. At least four deaths and 24 people injured have been recorded since Pinatubo began erupting after six centuries of dormancy. About 84,000 have been evacuated. Heavy rains today have raised fears of catastrophic mudflows.Pinatubo is in the "Ring of Fire" that circles the Pacific. Mount Unzen in Japan, also in the ring, recently erupted, killing 38.President Aquino toured refugee centers and authorized the release of $1.42 million for relief efforts. According to Foreign Secretary Manglapus, the eruptions should not effect the stalled talks with the U.S. on new Clark and Subic lease agreements.

column5: Clarence Thomas Ran the Senate Judiciary Committee Gauntlet.
column6: Questioning of Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas by the Senate Judiciary Committee Sept. 10 - Sept 16, 1991 became heated at times because of the candidate's reticence, but at the end seemed no threat to the nomination. Meanwhile vigorous lobbying of the entire Senate by pro- and anti-Thomas groups proceeded.
column7: From Sept. 10 to Sept. 16, 1991 the Senate Judiciary Committee questioned Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas. Thomas's refusal to answer certain questions caused complaints, but it appeared early on that the committee would approve the nomination. By the end of the questioning an affirmative vote of 10-4 or 9-5 was predicted. There was media attention to Thomas's wife Virginia. A successful Washington lawyer, she had taken strong conservative positions that antagonized certain groups and the fact that she was white and he black raised questions for some blacks. During the hearings lobbyists on either side worked to influence the ensuing vote of the full Senate.
column8: From Sept. 10 to Sept. 16, 1991 Clarence Thomas, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, underwent five days of intensive questioning by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Although it seemed likely that the committee would vote to confirm the nomination, some members complained that the candidate refused to answer certain questions and seemed to back away from statements that he had made in the past. By the end of the questioning it appeared that Thomas would be confirmed by a 10-4 or 9-5 vote. In the media Thomas's wife Virginia was presented as an issue. Virginia had an impressive career as a lawyer in Washington, often taking strong conservative positions. She is white while Clarence is black. Women's-rights activists objected to her opposition to comparable-worth legislation; some religious groups were wary of her anti-cult activities; and some blacks viewed the Thomases' marriage as indicating his rejection of the black community. Throughout the hearings the entire Senate came under pressure from groups supporting or opposing the nomination. Pro-Thomas groups included the Coalition for the Restoration of the Black Family and Society and the Citizens Committee to Confirm Clarence Thomas. Opposing were the National Abortion Rights Action League and the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.
column9: Thomas' confirmation as second black justice in history of Supreme Court.
column10: Clarence Thomas completed five days of grueling days of testimony, apparently well on his way to becoming the second black justice in the history of the Supreme Court.  Thomas, a federal judge, was picked by President Bush to replace Thurgood Marshall, the high court's only black justice.
column11: Clarence Thomas completed five grueling days of testimony, apparently well on his way to becoming the second black justice in the history of the Supreme Court.  Several committee members say they expect the committee to recommend confirmation.  Thomas, a federal judge, was picked by President Bush to replace Thurgood Marshall, the high court's only black justice.  Supporters and opponents of the nomination representative conservative and liberal camps respectively.  Thomas is supported by conservative groups and opposed by abortion rights and civil rights groups.  He and his wife have opposed affirmative action programs, but during the hearings, Thomas refused to give his views on abortion.
column12: Clarence Thomas completed five grueling days of Senate questioning, apparently well on his way to becoming the second black justice in the history of the Supreme Court.  Thomas, a federal judge was picked by President Bush to replace the retiring Thurgood Marshall, the high court's only black justice.  Several committee members said they expected the committee to recommend confirmation.  Several Democrats accused Thomas of being evasive and of disavowing many statements he made while an official of the Reagan and Bush administration.  Those who support the nomination include conservative groups such as The Restoration of the Black Family and Society and opposition came from women's and civil rights groups such as the national Abortion Right's Action League and the Lawyer's Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.   Thomas and his wife Virginia, who is white, have opposed affirmative action programs.During the hearings Thomas refused to give his views on the 1973 abortion decision based on a woman's right to privacy.  On school prayer, he said "any policy of exclusion should considered inappropriate.  Virginia Thomas has drawn criticism for her lobbying against comparable worth legislation and religious rights groups are troubled by her anti-cult activities following her involvement with Lifespring, a motivational group.

column3: A violent earthquake rock NorthernCalifornia during Tuesday evening's rush hour, caving in a sectionof the San Francisco Bay Bridge, terrify World Series fans incandlestick Park and shake buildings as far as 200 miles away.cbs-tv report one person have be kill on the bridge. Therewere no other immediate confirm reports of deaths or injuries,but ABC-TV and CNN both say some people be injure atcandlestick, where the game be cancel and fans be evacuated.it be not immediately clear how extensive the damage be fromthe quake, which strike at 5:04 p.m. PDT and register 6.9 on therichter scale. It be center near Hollister, 80 miles southeastof San Francisco in San Benito County.The thing struck just as everyone be go home, say TomMullins, a spokesman for the California Office of EmergencyServices in Sacramento. We've get reports come in from SanBenito and Santa Clara counties of heavy damage.cbs say the California Highway Patrol report a J.C. Penneybuilding in downtown Hollister collapse and a bridge on Highway101 in Hollister collapsed.There be unconfirmed reports that a shopping mall collapse insan Jose, 50 miles south of San Francisco.San Francisco Airport be evacuated, and some people there werehit with fall plaster.one major fire be blaze in San Francisco's Marina Districtand another near the library at University of California atberkeley. A huge plume of smoke visible for miles over Berkeley.Hundreds of people flee Bay Area Rapid Transit subway andelevated stations in San Francisco and East Bay suburbs. The systemwas shut down.televised footage of the bridge connecting Oakland and SanFrancisco show that a 30-foot section of the upper deck hadcollapsed, leave two cars dangle between the two levels.Reports say most occupants get out of their cars safely.in Washington, President Bush say the federal government wasprepared to send help to the earthquake area in California and hewas send Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner there to assessthe damage.at City Hall in San Francisco a radio reporter tell listeners,the entire building start to shake ... you could hear peopleyelling and scream all over the building.she say there be obvious problems at the healthdepartment across the street. Water be literally gush out ofthe building from a window on the second floor, the unidentifiedreporter said.Citizens of Marin, north of San Francisco, be warn to shutoff their gas because the smell of gas be all over town.frank Baldwin of U.S. Geological Survey's Earthquake Center saidthe quake's magnitude be 6.9 on the Richter scale. It occur at5:04 p.m. PDT and be center in the Santa Cruz, Calif., area, 75miles south of San Francico on the Pacific Coast.The quake be felt as far away as Reno, Nev., 225 miles to thenortheast.the quake knock out phones and power, include electricity atthe Associated Press bureau in San Francisco.The San Mateo bridge, which cross the bay about 10 miles southof Candlestick Park be close for inspection.san Francisco Police Officer Dwayne Collins say there werereports that buildings and statues in the historic South of Marketdistrict near downtown have collapsed.i think I be lose my balance, then I saw the lamppostsway one foot each direction. then I saw fall glass, brokenglass on the street, but luckily not near me, say Les Galvacswho be walk down Market Street in downtown San Francisco.David Balague, 22, be on the 14th floor of the Bank of Americabuilding. I've never be so scared. column5: 6.9 earthquake rocked Northern California October 17, 1989, at predicted epicenter
column6: A 6.9 earthquake rocked Northern California on October 17, 1989, at a predicted epicenter. The 1906 quake measured 8.3. Poor soil and structural design caused building collapses. Fire swept the Marina District. A Bay Bridge section collapsed. World Series Game Three was postponed. Offers of help were widespread. Charleston suffered comparable damage from Hurricane Hugo.
column7: A 6.9 earthquake rocked Northern California at 5:04pm on October 17, 1989. It lasted 15 seconds, caused $2 billion damage, and killed 60. Candlestick Park shook and World Series Game Three was postponed. Buildings collapsed because of  poor soil and  structural design. The Marina District lost 60 buildings and was swept by fire. High-rises built to strict earthquake codes escaped damage. Part of the Bay Bridge's upper deck collapsed. The 1906 San Francisco quake, measuring 8.3, killed 2500. Tuesday's epicenter was Northern California's most likely spot for a large quake within 30 years. Offers of help were widespread. Charleston, SC,  sympathized, suffering comparable damage from Hurricane Hugo.
column8: An earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale rocked Northern California at 5:04pm on October 17, 1989. Felt 225 miles away, it lasted 15 seconds, caused $2 billion damage, and killed 60. Candlestick Park shook and World Series Game Three was postponed. Buildings collapsed because of poor soil and structural design. Chinatown on firm hills and Telegraph, Nob, and Russian Hills on rock escaped major damage. The Marina District, on landfill dredged from the bay, lost 60 buildings and was swept by fire. Apartment buildings with garages across the bottom were most vulnerable. High-rises built to strict earthquake codes swayed with little damage. Part of the Bay Bridge's upper deck collapsed. The 1906 San Francisco quake, estimated at 8.3, killed 2500. Debate waged over whether northern or southern California was due for the next big quake. A 1988 report targeted Tuesday's epicenter, 75 miles south in the Santa Cruz area, as Northern California's most likely spot, with 30% probability of a 6.5 quake within 30 years. Los Angeles, Los Alamos, Israel, and France offered survivor-search help. British engineers assessed structural damage. Other help came from relief organizations, companies, cities, and the federal government. Charleston, SC, suffering similar yet different damage and disruption from Hurricane Hugo, sent water and sympathy.
column9: Violent earthquake causes extensive damage in San Francisco Bay area.
column10: A violent earthquake Tuesday, registering 6.9 on the Richter scale, caused widespread damage in the San Francisco Bay area. A section of the San Francisco Bridge and the Oakland-San Francisco Bridge collapsed. Swaying stands at the World Series game in Candlestick Park terrified fans. President Bush directed $273 million in aid.
column11: A violent earthquake registering 6.9 on the Richter scale rocked Northern California on Tuesday causing widespread damage throughout the San Francisco Bay area. A section of both the San Francisco Bridge and the Oakland-San Francisco Bridge collapsed. Buildings also collapsed and fans at the World Series game in Candlestick Park were terrified as the stands swayed. A 1988 US Geological Survey predicted the area where the quake actually occurred contrary to studies predicting the next "big one" would be in the Los Angeles area.President Bush directed $273 million in aid although coffers were strained from response to Hurricane Hugo.
column12: A violent earthquake registering 6.9 on the Richter scale rocked Northern California on Tuesday. One report said the quake was centered in the Santa Cruz area 75 miles south of San Francisco. Initial reports indicated widespread damage, especially affecting highways and old masonry buildings. A section of both The San Francisco Bridge and Oakland-San Francisco Bridge collapsed. World Series fans in Candlestick Park were terrified as the stands swayed. Fans were evacuated and there were reports of injuries. The quake shook buildings in Sacramento, 95 miles to the northeast and was felt 225 miles to the east at Reno, NV.Private groups and officials from around the world and the US have offered earthquake relief. President Bush directed $273 million in aid. Federal and private coffers are strained by previous response to Hurricane Hugo. Some buildings in San Francisco collapsed because they were built over landfill or erected before there were earthquake codes.The earthquake was the strongest on the San Andreas fault since the San Francisco quake of 1906. Many scientists' studies led them to believe the next "big one" would be in Los Angles. A 1988 US Geological Survey study predicted the area where the quake actually occurred.

But hepredicted very heavy rains as warm hurricane winds rise into coolermountain air, possibly cause flash floods and mudslides.The Mexican arm forces begin emergency flights Friday of food,medicines and water to Cancun, Cozumel and other disaster sit inthe Yucatan.In many locations, hurricane victims be without food, drinkingwater, electrical power, gasoline and communications sinceWednesday.Thousands of coastal residents frommexico to Louisiana flee to high ground Thursday as fiercehurricane Gilbert send the first of its storms against Texas afterthrashing the Yucatan Peninsula.This be a killer storm, say Gordon Guthrie, director of theflorida Division of Emergency of Management.
