column5: Killer hurricane devastates Caribbean and Mexico, spawns tornadoes in Texas.
column6: Gilbert, the most intense hurricane ever recorded, ripped through the Caribbean, slammed into the Yucatan, then lost it's punch at the Texas-Mexico border.  It has caused massive flooding, took 109 lives, left about $8 billion damage in its wake and destroyed approximately 100,000 of Jamaica's 500,000 homes.
column7: Gilbert, a killer Category 5 hurricane with sustained winds over 155mph and a record low barometric pressure of 26.13 inches, was the most intense hurricane ever recorded in the western hemisphere.  At least 109 people died and damage is estimated at $8 billion.  It caused limited damage in the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba, but extensive death and damage in Jamaica where 100,000 of the country's 500,000 homes were destroyed.  It then inflicted severe damage to the Yucatan Peninsula resort areas of Cancun and Cozumel before weakening and moving on to the Texas-Mexico border.  In Texas it caused flooding and spawned dozens of tornadoes.
column8: Hurricane Gilbert was the most intense hurricane ever recorded in the western hemisphere.  This Category 5 storm, with sustained winds exceeding 155 mph and gusts clocked at 175 mph, had the lowest barometric pressure ever recorded at 26.13 inches.  Massive in size, it had storm winds extending 250 miles north and 200 miles south of its eye.  For one hellish week in mid-September, 1988, it roared through the Caribbean, slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula, and then moved back over water before finally losing its punch at its second landfall at the Texas-Mexican border.  In spite of officials' warnings and both voluntary and forced evacuations from coastal areas, it left a trail of death and destruction in its wake.  At least 109 people died; damage is estimated at $8 billion.  Hundreds of thousands are homeless.  Many survivors are still without food, drinking water and electricity.  The storm caused damage in Haiti, Cuba and the Dominican Republic, but the most severe damage was in Jamaica, where 100,000 of the country's 500,000 homes were destroyed, and then the Yucatan Peninsula where the resort areas of Cancun and Cozumel were hit hard.  The limited damage in Texas was caused primarily by flooding and by hurricane spawned tornadoes.
column9: Hurricane Gilbert abates after ravaging the Caribbean and Mexico's Yucatan.
column10: Gilbert is now a tropical storm, bringing heavy rains, flooding, and mudslides to areas of northeastern Mexico.  Gilbert at one time was the most intense hurricane recorded and brought havoc to the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Cayman Islands, and Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.  Gilbert's center avoided Texas, although it spawned tornadoes along the coast.
column11: Gilbert is now a tropical storm, bringing heavy rain, flooding, and mudslides to northeastern Mexico.  It did not hit Texas as feared, but did spawn tornadoes.  The Hurricane Gilbert formed in the eastern Caribbean and during the last week ravaged the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, and the Cayman Islands.  On Tuesday Gilbert had winds of 175mph and the lowest pressure ever recorded and was upgraded to a Category 5 storm, the highest.  Wednesday it slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula severely damaging the resort areas, severing electricity and communications, and causing widespread flooding.  At least 109 people have been killed and 800,000 left homeless.
column12: Hurricane Gilbert has been downgraded to a tropical storm and is bringing heavy rain, flooding, and mudslides to northeastern Mexico.  Ten policemen were swept away in Monterrey and buses full of evacuees were lost in Matamoros.  Gilbert's feared path onto the Texas Gulf Coast did not materialize, although a number of tornadoes were spawned on Friday and Saturday.  In Mexico, relief operations are continuing in order to bring food, water, and medical supplies to survivors.Gilbert formed in the eastern Caribbean and for the last week rampaged through the Caribbean, bringing destruction to the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, and the Cayman Islands.  Damages in Jamaica, where six were killed, are estimated at $8 billion.  On Tuesday Gilbert was upgraded to a Category 5 storm, the highest category and only the third recorded.  Winds were clocked at 175 mph and the lowest pressure ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere was measured at its center.  Wednesday Gilbert slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula with 160 mph winds, severely damaging the resort areas in Cancun and Cozumel, severing electricity and communications over a wide area, and causing widespread flooding.  Gilbert has killed at least 109 people and left at least 800,000 homeless.

column3: Walk. Sit. Stay. Roll over. Go to court. such be the life of one german short-haired pointer, a show dog bear the name CH. Robin Crest Lorien Corniche. Cory, as he be call for short, isn't any run-of-the-litter critter. The "ch." in his name stand for champion. He have win 245 show awards as Best of Breed and 19 awards as Best in Show. Basically, his problem come from serve more than one master. One of the dog's three owners think the kennel-club world have see enough of Cory, who be four years old. The other two owners think he have plenty of prizes still ahead. In what be fast become a pit-bull match, the one owner, Anthony Attalla, be sue the other two, John and Rita Remondi, charge that they have be show Cory even though he be officially retired (as announce in Dog News). In the suit, file in federal district court in Manhattan, Mr. Attalla says, "Cory have achieve the pinnacle of success . . . and any further competition would only diminish what he have accomplished." Mr. Attalla claim that his work with Cory be no gravy train. In the suit, he say that under the owners' agreement he lay out fees and other expenses for show the animal and he decide when to show -- or to retire -- Cory. So far, Mr. Attalla says, he's spent over $125,000, the amount seek in damages. In return, he be entitle to all ribbons and awards. The Remondis be in charge of care for the dog. Despite the retirement, the suit says, the Remondis show Cory twice recently. (He place fourth and then didn't place at all.) For now, a judge's order temporarily bar them from further shows. In a memo file in court, Mr. Remondi claim that Mr. Attalla retire the dog "simply and solely to better" the chances that Mr. Attalla's agent would win with a rival Rover. The Remondis also say Mr. Attalla have buy a Rottweiler to show in another category and doesn't want to spend money on both Cory and the other dog. They claim that Mr. Attalla have breach the pact by not pay certain expenses. Stud fees be also at issue. The Remondis argue that the retirement "fraudulently" deprive them of their opportunity to show Cory, a dog who they assert "is in the best condition of his life."mcfadden and his wife, Taffe, run their dog handle business in Campbelland do it primarily for the enjoyment and satisfaction it brings. Those whothink you can get rich handle dogs be bark up the wrong tree.; "wemake a good living but the overhead be high and the hours long. Before a showwe sometimes work around the clock brushing and clean the dogs, work ontheir coats," say McFadden. "And breeds such as poodles have to be highlytrimmed."; McFadden say he handle an average of 20 to 25 dogs at eachshow and work around 120 shows a year all over the U.S. The dogs be frequentwinners in best of breed and best of show categories. "We finish with close to100 champions a year," he said.; As a handler, McFadden emphasize that hedoesn't do obedience training. His job be to trim and condition the dogs andprepare them physically and mentally. The aim, he said, be to have a"confident and happy dog" enter a competition.; Over the last sevenyears, McFadden and his wife have show dogs represent approximately 75percent of the 135 breeds of dog. Taffe McFadden, a Vancouver, BritishColumbia native who have be involve in dog handling since she be a child,specializes in poodles. The couple also own two standard poodles and breedwire fox terriers.; McFadden's late product, a Kerry blue terrier namedkerrageen's Hotspur, win the best of show prize at the 81st Golden Gate KennelClub Dog Show hold Feb. 2-3 at the Cow Palace in San Francisco. More than2,000 purebred dogs participate in the national competition.; It be the37th best in show win by Kerrageen's Hotspur, make him the top Kerry blueterrier of all time. The dog be own by Bryan Percy and Judy Hertwell ofSeattle.; Kerrageen's Hotspur be schedule to join McFadden in New YorkCity last week for the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison SquareGarden. Recognized as one of the most prestigious shows in all of dogdom,westminster be also, with the exception of the Kentucky Derby, the longestcontinuous sport event hold in the U.S.With no seats and no food for the guests ofhonor, everyone agree that lunch at Sardi's have go to the dogs.two dogs, to be specific, the city's top police dog and thenation's top show dog.the Dog Fanciers Club organize the event Wednesday to honorchampion Great Elms Prince Charming II, a fluffy little Pomeranian,and Nero, a big, amiable bruiser of a german shepherd.he's a very friendly dog, say Nero's master, Officer JosephFaraguna. In all the arrests I've make with him, he's only bittenfour times.nero specializes in sniff out bombs and narcotics. He hashelped the Police Department make hundreds of arrests and hasapprehended more than 50 felons.nero be keep on his long leather leash while prince emergedfrom his elegant, pad carry case only long enough to pose forphotographers.the Pomeranian be name best in show at the prestigiouswestminister Kennel Club Show in Madison Square Garden last month.prince, long use to be coddle and primped, seem obliviousto all the attention until Nero grow bold enough to prod him on thechin. then he blink and draw back.but neither Nero nor Prince get any lunch from the luncheon atsardi's, a prominent midtown Manhattan restaurant.prince, say his agent and master Skip Piazza, doesn't have avery large diet anyway.woof.; In this house, man and dogs speak as one. Their relationship isunusually tender. One need only listen while Wegman murmur to Fay Ray andbattina, her 1 1/2-year-old daughter.; On Valentine's Day, for example, hesaid, "I'll take them out and play with them longer."; "but I don't want tobe know as a dog zombie," say Wegman, who do go to the Westminster KennelClub Dog Show without the dogs. "I go to movies and have friends and playsports. I swim, play tennis and wind surf."; Battina begs to differ. "WhenBill leaves, Batty howls," say Andrea Beeman, an assistant to Wegman.; Manand dog; Their home be one floor of a former Orthodox synagogue on thelower East Side of Manhattan. During a recent visit, it be possible to seehow the artist get two even-tempered, relaxed, normal dogs to slip intoflorid housedresses or scratch each other's backs. The three simply adore eachother.; "I'd never heard of Weimaraners," say the artist, who be bear 47years ago in Longmeadow, Mass. His life with Weimaraners begin in 1970, theyear he buy a new video camera and Man Ray, a puppy that cost $35.;wegman have never photograph dogs before, but Man Ray be a perfect subject.;"he be gray and neutral," the artist said. "i could do him as a dog, aman, a sculpture, a character, a bat, a frog, an elephant, an Airedale, adinosaur, a poodle. I never get tire of him."; A dog's life; Had hebeen a different breed he would have be a "character actor," Wegman said,"like Lassie."; When Man Ray, who have become world famous, die of cancerin 1981, at the age of 11 years and 8 months, the artist mourned. "i dreamedthat he come back to life," say Wegman, who spend three years live withouta dog. "It be kind of liberating, the years I didn't have a dog."; In1984, however, he get another Weimaraner, which be stolen. yet another dogdied of Parvo, a virus. In 1985, he get Fay Ray, who be now a familiar facenot only among artists but among children who watch "sesame Street."; As abreed, Weimaraners combine "a lap-dog sensibility with a hunt capability,"the artist said. They curl up on his lap, but since they be pointers, theycan hold a pose.; They be also good companions for an artist. They areaffectionate. They do not drool. They have style.; Like world-famousfashion models, these dogs be lean, supple and fit. In Wegman's home, whichcomprises 2,000 square feet with 20-foot-high ceilings, they live a lifeunencumbered -- one assumes -- by thoughts of fame or fortune, and seldomhunger.; Each morning Wegman feed them Eukanuba dog food, which heconsiders the best around. "it's the high in protein." he said. He oftenadds a spoonful of plain yogurt or cottage cheese. The dogs eat again at 6p.m.; The house be design for both human and canine comfort. There isnowhere that Wegman go that the dogs do not. The yard be a run of dirt andconcrete. If their master do not play with them, the dogs just scratch,sniff, get bored and go to the door to wait for him.taking a break from the headaches of thepalestinian uprising and Israel's election campaign, thousands ofisraelis turn out Saturday for a canine beauty pageant.marco, a feisty boxer own by Dov Amir, pad off with thechampion's trophy after beat out 800 other pretty pooches inisrael's dog-of-the-year contest hold in Tel Aviv's ExhibitionCenter.We can find time for other things besides the intefadeh,said organizer Avi Marshak, use the Arabic word for uprise todescribe the 9-month-old wave of palestinian violence aim atending Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.About 20,000 people attend the two-day show, organizers said.israeli couples in cutoff jeans and short-sleeved shirts pushedbaby strollers from ring to ring to view the more than 50 differentbreeds range from tiny lap dogs like the Yorkshire terriers togreat Danes and St. Bernards.Marshak say the contest be sanction by the World Kennel clubbased in Brussels, Belgium, and have judges from the Netherlands,South Africa, Italy and Britain.But although the competition be bill as an internationalevent, organizers concede there be few if any contestants fromabroad. This be in contrast to 1987, before the uprising began,when a World Dog Show competition attract scores of foreigncompetitors to Israel.Even so, we don't feel the intefadeh here, say Rafi Shahaf,a veterinarian, who be interview in the show ring where Conan,his steel gray Mastino Napoletano, have just take a blue ribbon.the show briefly push the Nov. 1 general elections out of thelimelight for the doglovers. Experts say the razor-tight racebetween the right-wing Likud Party and the left-leaning Labor Partycould determine the future of the Israeli-occupied Palestinianlands.
column5: Dog competitions are both entertainment and big business.
column6: Dog competition in national and international events is both entertainment and big business.  Worldwide competitions attract numerous contestants and visitors.  One dog was the subject of a law suit and others have appeared on Sesame Street.  Dog handling can be lucrative, but the hours are long and the overhead high.
column7: Dog competition in national and international events is both entertainment and big business.  Competitions attract numerous contestants and visitors.  In Israel, the dog of the year contest briefly outshone the general election and the uprising known as the intefadeh.Owners of one dog were embroiled in a law suit over whether the dog should be retired or not and a Manhattan artist's Weimaraners have served as both models for his work and appeared on Sesame Street.  Dog handling can be lucrative, but the overhead is high and the hours are long, according to Bill McFadden a professional dog handler.
column8: Dog competition in national and international events is both entertainment and big business.  More than 2,500 dogs, representing 138 breeds competed for prizes at the All breed Dog Show and Obedience Trials at the Los Angeles Sports Arena in 1989.  In 1988, 20,000 people attended Israel's dog of the year contest in Tel Aviv with 800 contestants representing over 50 breeds.  The event briefly outshone Israel's general election and the uprising known as the intefadeh.  The owners of one prize winning dog were embroiled in a law suit over whether the dog should be retired or not.  Stud fees were also at issue.Weimaraners served as both companions and models to a Manhattan artist.  One of the dogs has appeared on the television show Sesame Street and another was world famous when he died at the age of 11.  The Dog Fancier's Club organized an event in New York City to honor the city's top police dog and the nation's top show dog.   Bill McFadden, a professional dog handler for various owners has close to 100 champions a year.  He says he makes a good living, but the overhead is high and the hours are long.
column9: Dog Shows - Bringing Out the Best of "Man's Best Friend"
column10: Dog shows throughout the world bring together hundreds if not thousands of contestants representing the world's 135 dog breeds.  Publicity stunts, professional handlers, sometimes the courts and possibly even violence may be involved.  Awards and glory await the champions.  Occasionally, some dogs manage to gain fame outside of the dog show scene.
column11: From the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Show in Madison Square Garden, to Tel Aviv, Israel's violence threatened show, to the massive 2500 contestant show in Los Angeles, proud owners, or professional handlers such as Bill McFadden, let their pampered pouches strut their stuff for awards and glory.  For some dogs, shows aren't necessary to attain fame.  Police dog Nero, the NYPD's finest, was feted for apprehending more than 50 felons.  And photographer William Wegman's Weimaraners are, through his work, know to artists and children around the world.  And like other international championship events, sometimes lawyers and court are involved.
column12: At dog shows throughout the world, proud owners compete their charges for the awards and glory that await the champions.  Prince, a fluffy, little Pomeranian, after winning at the prestigious Westminster Kennel Club Show in Madison Square Garden was honored at a lunch held at a Sardi's, a prominent New York City restaurant.  However, not all "famous" dogs are show dogs.  Sharing the limelight at Sardi's was Nero, New York City's top police dog.  Nero helped the police make hundreds of arrests and apprehend more than 50 felons.  And one need only look at the renown attained by photographer William Wegman's Weimaraners.  Artists worldwide know his dogs, as do children who watch "Sesame Street".  But it's the show dogs that crisscross the country to strut their stuff, sometimes as many as the 2,500 dogs representing 138 breeds that competed at the All Breed Dog Show and Obedience trials in Los Angeles.  Some may possibly go to Tel Aviv, Israel for its annual show.  Bill McFadden, a professional dog handler, works about 120 shows a year throughout the U.S., showing 20 to 25 dogs at each show.  Among those he shows is Kerrageen's Hotspur, the top award winning Kerry blue terrier of all time.

column3: Spike Lee may have be wear ageorgetown University cap and sweatshirt, but he get a far warmerreception from Syracuse University students than he do fromacademy Award voters.In a lecture and question-and-answer session Monday, leeshrugged off the academy's icy treatment of his late movie, Dothe Right Thing, and blame it on generational politics.the 1989 film, widely hail by critics, receive only twoacademy Award nominations, and isn't be consider for bestpicture or best director.the academy's membership consist mainly of old people, the32-year-old Lee said. He say they be a lot more comfortablewith the black chauffeur in `driving Miss Daisy' than with theangry characters in his film.i still feel we make the best film of the year, he said.asked if racism might have be involve in the academynominations, Lee replied, Racism's involve in everything.Despite the cap and sweatshirt, Syracuse students welcome himas one of their own.he's an african-american, one of the first ones to make it (asa producer and director), and he's address the issues andconcerns affect our community, Syracuse senior Deron Harrissaid. That's why we're so proud of him.What do Charlie Chaplin, Greta Garbo, CaryGrant, Alfred Hitchcock and Steven Spielberg have in common? theyhave never win Academy Awards for their individual achievements.such flagrant omissions be often cite by critics as evidenceof the unfairness of Hollywood's high prize. Oscar's 60-yearhistory be fill with examples of the film world's highestachievers be overlook by the Academy of Motion Picture Artsand Sciences.The late casualties be directors James L. Brown's final line from SomeLike It Hot: Nobody's perfect.the Oscar statuette, one of the mostrecognizable images in the entertainment world, have no copyrightprotection, a federal judge have ruled.the small Academy Award statue be part of the public domain,u.s. But I've never beenthrough an election in Argentina.Dan Lyle, who oversee the Oscar balloting for the accountingfirm Price, Waterhouse Inc., say that there be no guarantee thatacademy members have actually fill out their own ballots.all we know be that a properly number ballot have beenreturned, he said. Members be on the honor system to fill outthe ballot themselves.more than 4,600 members be give ballots this year for the 61stannual Academy Awards, which will be telecast on March 29 from theshrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Academy members vote on their areaof specialty. Ballots be invalidate only if there ismore than one vote in a give category, and only the votes in thatspecific category be not tallied, he said.nominations for acting, directing, art direction and allspecialized categories be handle by select branches and committeescomposed of Academy members.All vote members of the Academy can participate in the bestpicture nominations and may vote for the final awards in allcategories. Winners for best documentary feature, best animatedshort film and best live-action short film be choose by only thosemembers who have see all the nominees.academy constituent Julian Blaustein say that most of hiscolleagues take the voting very seriously. I don't even vote (in acategory) if I'm not familiar with the pictures in that category.... And I've never tell someone to vote for a film, even when I'vedone some of them.meanwhile, other Oscar voting rules be perhaps be broken,speculates veteran Academy member Millard Kaufman. Although you'reasked to vote in the nominations for five pictures, I think a lot ofpeople figure out that they have a good chance if they just votefor their own picture and leave the other four blank, he said.given the tremendous impact both an Oscar nomination and an Oscarvictory have on a film's fortunes, it's not entirely surprising thata certain degree of artifice might surround the Oscars.The last Emperor take in $18.9 million, close to half thefilm's gross, after it win last year's best picture trophy. Morethan 70 percent of the revenues generate by 1986's best picture,platoon, come after the film be nominated. On average, a bestpicture award be worth about $20 million these days.A $500,000 Oscar promotional campaign mount by a studio,therefore, can be a good investment. In the case of this year'sawards, a flurry of academy-oriented newspaper advertisements,banquets, complimentary gifts and photo mailings tie to five latereleases appear to have be remarkably successful.this year, all best picture nominees and the large majority oftop act nominees come from movies release in December: TheAccidental Tourist, Dangerous Liaisons, Rain Man andworking Girl be all release after Dec. 16.While these five movies might be good, the nearly completeexclusion of films from the rest of the year have highlight thestudios' mastery of Oscar marketing.i think the Academy Awards be crap, say Terry Gilliam,director of Brazil and the current The Adventures of BaronMunchausen.It's about sell films be all it's about, he said. It'sone more way of flog some films. When `Brazil' get nominate (in1986), they ask me to be a member of the Academy. And I wouldn'tjoin. I just don't want to be a part of that at all.and at least one prominent Academy member, director Carl Reiner,says that the manipulation of Oscar voters have reach new depths.reiner say that Universal Studios' all-out effort to bag votes forsigourney Weaver, a best actress nominee for Gorillas in themist, could lead him to vote against the film.i have in my house more color reproductions of Sigourney Weaverand a beautiful gorilla than I need, Reiner say of promotionalmaterial sent to his home. We've get to tell the Academy to stopthis advertising. I'm get turn off on the pictures I like.hollywood (AP) Like all great contests, the annual AcademyAwards ceremony have generate a wealth of statistics and triviaover its 60 years of existence, all carefully chronicle by Oscarhistorians.Here, courtesy of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts andsciences, be 20 questions about Oscar:1. Barry Fitzgerald. His 1944 support actor statuette wassubsequently replace by the Academy.17. What performers have refuse their Oscars? George C. Scottand Marlon Brando.18. Who hold the record for the fast televised reading ofthe famed Academy rules? actor-comedian John (Federal Express)Moschitta, 25 seconds, 1983.20. Katharine Hepburn, all four times.spencer Tracy's acting technique be simplyless be better, and that help make him the screen's greatestactor. The Tracy credo be recommend to future producers ofacademy Award shows.wednesday night's orgy of self-congratulation be dazzling,glamorous and all those familiar Hollywood adjectives. also toomuch.too many endless production numbers. Too much forcedconversation between couples. Too many awards with meaning lose tothe general public.the use of couples, co-stars, compadres and companions, aspresenters for the 61st Academy Awards at the Shrine Auditorium wasclever but wearing.the best oscar shows have be emcee by Will Rogers, Bob Hope,Johnny Carson and other funnymen who provide continuity as well asa leaven of pomposity.the bright moments of the 61st Awards come from BillyCrystal, Robin Williams and Bob Hope, but they be all too brief.tom Selleck remark that Douglas Fairbanks Sr. hand out thefirst awards in 1929 in five minutes. The present awards could bestaged in two hours instead of the 3 hours and 15 minutes they tookwednesday night on ABC-TV.But the show will never be shorter. column5: OSCAR WORTH MILLIONS TO STUDIOS, NO COPYRIGHT ON FAMOUS SYMBOL
column6: In its 61-year history, many of Hollywood's highest achievers, among them directors Brooks (1988), Spielberg (1988) and Lee (1989) did not win nominations for the famous, but not copyright protected, award of the Academy of Arts and Sciences. Millions watch the televised presentation of awards worth millions to film studios.
column7: The Oscar nomination and selection process is under scrutiny as studios campaign to influence voting by Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences members. Directors  Brooks (1988),  Spielberg (1988), and Lee (1989) are among the luminaries who were overlooked in the annual voting during the award's 61-year history.Millions watch the televised awards show which can take over three hours. The 1989 show is memorable for the number of films honored and for a musical number that sparked a Disney suit against the Academy.The highly recognizable statue is not protected by copyright. Walt Disney was the most-awarded person (32).
column8: Director Spike Lee, speaking at Syracuse University Monday, shrugged off the treatment of his movie by Academy Award voters. Though praised by critics, his 1989 film was not considered in the best picture or best director categories. The Academy, however, has a history of overlooking achievers. In 1988, directors James Brooks and Steven Speilberg were both passed over.  Selection for the award is under scrutiny as studios mount major campaigns to influence voting. On average a best picture award is worth about $20 million, but there is no guarantee that Academy members actually complete their own ballots.Millions watch the awards presentation. The last awards show took a long three plus hours. The opening number, a song-and-dance routine by Eileen Bowman portraying Snow White, was particularly lamentable and led to a Disney suit against the Academy for its unauthorized use of the character. Though long, the 1989 ceremony will be favorably remembered for the spread of the awards. Ten movies split 17 awards. The Oscar, created in 1928, is one of the most recognizable symbols in the entertainment world and is not protected by copyright. Katherine Hepburn and Walter Brennan are the actress and actor, respectively, with the most awards.
column9: High-stakes Oscar is prized, promoted, presented with pomp, and protected
column10: Oscars increase film earnings, prompting studios to woo votes. The Thalberg award recognizes overlooked giants like Steven Spielberg. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses. Disney sued over an unauthorized Snow White routine, and the academy  sued when other awards resembled the Oscar too much. The gold-plated Oscar is manufactured by R.S. Owens Co.
column11: Oscar nominations and victories increase film earnings, and studios woo academy  members' votes. The Irving Thalberg award is useful for acknowledging overlooked giants. Steven Spielberg received it in 1987. Spike Lee blamed the few "Do the Right Thing" nominations on generational politics and racism. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses. Disney sued when the 1989 program opened with an unauthorized Snow White routine. The academy sued when other awards resembled the Oscar too closely, but a federal judge ruled the statuette was not copyrighted. The academy has tried to block Oscar sales. The gold-plated, 8-pound, 13-inch Oscar is manufactured by Chicago's R.S. Owens Co.
column12: Oscar nominations and victories increase film earnings, and studios woo the 4600 voting members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to get their votes. The annual awards ceremony has generated a wealth of Oscar award trivia. The Irving Thalberg award for consistently high quality has become useful for acknowledging overlooked giants and salving the academy's conscience. Steven Spielberg, never nominated for an individual achievement even though his films are record moneymakers, received it in 1987. 32-year-old Spike Lee blamed the paucity of nominations for his critically acclaimed "Do the Right Thing" on generational politics and racism. Oscar shows have been criticized for their excesses of commercialism, production numbers, and meaningless awards.  In 1989, Disney sued the academy for opening the program with a Snow White routine. The academy closely protects the Oscar's name and image. It sued when a film festival award and an employee-incentive trophy were too similar, but a federal judge ruled that the statuette had no copyright protection. The academy has also tried to block the sale of statuettes. The Oscar, manufactured by Chicago's R.S. Owens Co., weighs 8 pounds and stands 13 inches tall. It is made of Britannia metal and plated with copper, nickel, and gold.

column3: Beverly Sills, Lauren Bacall, Betty Comdenand Phyllis Newman be among performers who will sing, act and makeguest appearances at a birthday bash in August for conductorleonard Bernstein.The Leonard Bernstein Gala Birthday Performance be a benefitconcert schedule for the composer's 70th birthday, Aug. 25, toraise money for the Tanglewood Music Center, where Bernstein gothis conduct start.Sills will be host. Performances will include the BostonSymphony Orchestra, the Boston Pops Orchestra and the TanglewoodFestival Chorus under the direction of some of the many conductorswhose careers have be guide by Bernstein.Bacall and soprano Barbara Hendricks will perform a movementfrom Bernstein's Symphony no. 3, Kaddish. Violin soloist Midoriwill play two movements from his Serenade.The concert will celebrate Bernstein's accomplishments inpopular music with excerpts from West Side Story, On thetown and others. Dame Gwyneth Jones and Frederica von Stade willbe among those perform highlights from Fidelio, Tristanund Isolde and other works to honor Bernstein's landmark operarecordings.tickets start at $20 for a spot on the lawn and run up to $5,000for benefactors, who get a seat in the open-air auditorium.leonard Bernstein, whose 70th birthday in Augustwas mark with a gala at Tanglewood, return to Carnegie Hall withthe New York Philharmonic 45 years after he make his triumphantconducting debut there with the orchestra.and of course, Monday night's program consist of threebernstein compositions that be play shimmeringly well. As wellit should: It be the 1,215th time Bernstein conduct the orchestra.on Nov. 14, 1943, Bernstein, the Philharmonic's then-assistantconductor, fill for an ail Bruno Walter on such short noticethere be no rehearsal. The concert be broadcast nationally onradio. And there be such acclaim that Bernstein, who have never ledthe orchestra in concert until that day, be catapult to fame, atage 25.At intermission, Mrs. Artur Rodzinski, whose late husband be thephilharmonic music's director in 1943 and hire Bernstein as hisassistant, be introduce from a box.violinist Jacques Margolies, who play in the Philharmonic thatsunday, be still a member and be play on Monday night. Eightothers who also be members in 1943 violinist Louis Fishzohn,oboist Albert Goltzer, timpanist Saul Goodman, bassist Homer Mensch,cellist Martin Ormandy, assistant concertmaster Michael Rosenker,and trumpeters James Smith and William Vacchiano go on stage.Bernstein give bear hugs to all nine.i feel old than all of them, say Bernstein.Bernstein be give a silver box engrave with a reproduction ofmonday evening's program cover a caricature of him, with juttingchin, bright eye, flow hair and baton, and reading with loveand thanks of the Philharmonic family to lennie.will this birthday never end?, he tell the audience.monday's concert begin with Bernstein's Chichester Psalms,with the splendid Westminster Symphonic Choir. Todd Caruso, a memberof the american Boychoir whose voice be high, pure and moving, sangthe solo part.violinist Gidon Kremer, a native of the latvian town of Riga inthe Soviet Union, be soloist in Serenade for Violin, StringOrchestra, Harp and Percussion. Kremer's sound isn't warm but histechnique be breathtaking.pianist Krystian Zimerman, who be bear in Zabrze, Poland, oftenperforms with Bernstein in Europe. He be the respectful andthoroughly engage soloist in the final work on the program,bernstein's Symphony no. 2 for Piano and Orchestra, subtitledthe Age of Anxiety after W.H. Auden's poem.all the performers donate their services, with proceedsbenefiting the Philharmonic's efforts on behalf of Americanconductors.For the New York Philharmonic, it be supposedto be a night of Beethoven and Shostakovich. The fates make it anight of Leonard Bernstein.The official catalog of his works say Bernstein lead 74orchestras. But this be HIS orchestra, and the musicians come topay tribute to THEIR laureate conductor, who lead them through 1,244concerts during his 47-year association with the Philharmonic.They let his music do the talking.tonight's concert be not an evening in which we want to dwellon the passing of a giant, but rather what he have leave us, guestconductor Leonard Slatkin tell the audience at Avery Fisher Hall onthursday night.so four nights after Bernstein's death at age 72, Beethoven'sViolin Concerto become Bernstein's Serenade for Solo Violin,String Orchestra, Harp and Percussion (1954); Shostakovich'sSymphony no. 4 become Bernstein's Symphony no. 1(Jeremiah), write in 1942.Also added be his Chichester Psalms (1965) and hisoverture to Candide (1956). The substitute Bernstein programwas be repeat Friday night, Saturday and Tuesday.It be an extraordinary concert.there weren't many smiling face among the audience ormusicians. Slatkin's brief introductory comments, follow by thewhimsical Candide, break some of the tension.then come the eclectic Serenade, which Bernstein's programnotes say be suppose to be base on Plato's Symposium. itbegins with a lyrical praise of the Eros, the god of love. Thepiece be sometimes jocular, sometimes melancholy, sometimesassaulting and sometimes hedonistic. It end in drunken revelry, anintrusion of jazz - as if Bernstein be look down from heavenand tell the audience, It's O.K. to smile tonight.the soloist - concertmaster Glenn Dicterow - play with muchagility, especially through the difficult double stops andespecially consider the lack of preparation time.the mourning return after intermission, but not withoutoptimism.jeremiah begins with suspenseful strings, follow by acantorial french horn, a melodic return to the strings and then aprophetic blaring of brass. The second movement continue thepoint-counterpoint of brass versus strings (jeremiah versus thecorrupt priests, with Nebuchadnezzar loom on the horizon). Inthe third movement, Jerusalem have fall to the babylonian king.judea be exiled. Jeremiah weeps.how she sit desolate -The city once so full of people -She be become as a widow.during her chanting of the prophet's Lamentations,mezzo-soprano Wendy White have to wipe a tear from her eye. S didmembers of the audience.last on the program be another Hebraic elegy, ChichesterPsalms. The New York Choral Artists and a boy soloist join theorchestra.two harpists dominate the center of the crowded stage.awake, psaltery and harp! the choir begin in Hebrew.I will rouse the dawn.in the second movement an angelic 8th-grader, Evan Weber, singsking David's 23rd Psalm, The Lord be my shepherd, I shall notwant.after he finishes, the men's chorus bellows: Why do thenations rage?the piece, however, end in a mahlerian motif and chorusdeclaring a message Bernstein have seek for society:behold how good,and how pleasant it is,for brethren to dwelltogether in unity.to emphasize the point after the final note, Slatkin suspendedhis hand for several long moments of silence. then come thecascade of applause. For Leonard Bernstein.Actresses Lauren Bacall, Betty Comden andphyllis Newman be among performers in the birthday bash beingthrown in August for conductor Leonard Bernstein at the musiccenter where he get his start.the Tanglewood Music Center also be celebrate the 50thanniversary of its Music Shed this summer with a special concert bythe resident Boston Symphony Orchestra feature the same music,beethoven's Ninth Symphony, that inaugurate the building in 1938.The Bernstein weekend alone, with tickets as high as $5,000each, may bring in more than $1 million for the festival'sendowment fund, accord to Caroline Smedvig of the symphony.because Tanglewood be so special for him and, conversely, he'sso special to us, the combination will produce what we hope will bea unique event, she said.the Leonard Bernstein Gala Birthday Performance be a four-dayaffair beginning on the composer's 70th birthday, Aug. 25, to raisemoney for the music center.beverly Sills, who announce last month that she will step downas general director of the New York City Opera, will be the host ofthe event. Bacall and soprano Barbara Hendricks will perform amovement from Bernstein's Symphony no. 3, Kaddish. Violinsoloist Midori will play two movements from his Serenade.Dame Gwyneth Jones and Frederica von Stade will be among thoseperforming highlights from Fidelio and other works to honorbernstein's landmark opera recordings.the concert will also celebrate Bernstein's accomplishments inpopular music with excerpts from such works as West Side Storyand On the Town.The orchestra open the nine-week season with the special July1 concert mark the first half-century of the Music Shed.The season of classical music will be expand with performancesby such popular rock, jazz and folk artists as The Beach Boys,George Benson and Leo Kottke.But the highlight of the new season be the celebration ofBernstein's birthday.the BSO be even bill the birthday party as one of the musicworld's great occasions column5: Classical Music World and Broadway Mourn Lenny, Dead at 72
column6: Internationally acclaimed maestro Leonard Bernstein died on October 14th at 72 of lung failure after a long illness. The New York Philharmonic, which he conducted for 12 years, remembered him with a special all-Bernstein program. A special show at Broadway's Majestic Theater also honored the composer of "West Side Story."
column7: Leonard Bernstein, the beloved internationally acclaimed maestro died on October 14th at 72 of lung failure. Within days, the New York Philharmonic, in tribute to its 47-year association with the brilliant conductor played a special program, as did several other orchestras. Recently, Broadway also honored Bernstein, composer of "West Side Story," with a special show at the Majestic Theater. Several record companies will accelerate re-releases of Bernstein recordings.Bernstein though ill for some time, did participate in his 70th birthday celebrations at Tanglewood and Carnegie Hall. The latter occurred on the 45th anniversary of his directorial debut with the Philharmonic.
column8: The tributes to the musical genius, Leonard Bernstein, who died on October 14th at 72 from lung failure, continue. Thursday, a capacity audience filled the Broadway's Majestic Theater to hear recollections about the man who etched an indelible niche in American popular culture with his composition for West Side Story and to listen to classic Bernstein songs. Four days after his death, the New York Philharmonic, in tribute to the internationally acclaimed maestro who directed it from 1958 to 1969, replaced its regular program with an emotional all Bernstein program. The Los Angeles Philharmonic and the American Youth Orchestra also remembered him with special selections in their programs the weekend after his death. After his death, radio stations featured his work and a special section ran in the New York Times for public condolences. Several record companies announced accelerated programs to re-releases Bernstein recordingsA brilliant conductor, pianist, composer and teacher, Bernstein had canceled public appearances with increasing frequency. He did, however, appear at two 70th birthday celebrations. The first, a four-day event at Tanglewood, was a benefit for the music center. The other, at Carnegie Hall was held on the 45th anniversary of his directorial debut with the New York Philharmonic.
column9: Bernstein, America's Maestro, dead; lauded on 70th Birthday and posthumously.
column10: Leonard Bernstein--pianist, composer, conductor, recording star, teacher, TV personality, liberal, and bon vivant--died October 14 from lung disease.  He was the first American conductor to attain world fame.  Posthumous plaudits have come from everywhere.  Memorial concerts in New York and Los Angles were reminiscent of his 70th birthday celebrations.
column11: America's maestro, Leonard Bernstein died at 72 on October 14.  Suffering from lung diseases since spring, he announced his retirement four days earlier.  "Lenny" was the first American conductor to attain world fame.  He composed both classical and popular music and introduced thousands to classical music on television.  He made more than 200 classical recordings, many now being examined for re-release.  Posthumous plaudits have come from everywhere, with memorial classical concerts in New York and Los Angles, as well as a goodbye from Broadway.  His 70th birthday celebrations had featured all-star fundraising concerts at the Tanglewood Music Center and Carnegie Hall.
column12: Leonard Bernstein--pianist, composer, conductor, teacher, TV personality, liberal, and bon vivant--died at 72 on October 14, just four days after announcing his retirement from conducting.  He had been in failing health since last spring, suffering from a variety of lung diseases, and cut short a Japanese tour in July.  He was buried on October 16.  "Lenny", the first American conductor to attain world fame, was the well-educated son of Russian Jewish immigrants.  A member of the first class at Tanglewood, he achieved instant stardom at 25 as an emergency fill-in to conduct the New York Philharmonic on nation-wide radio.  He conducted this orchestra over 2000 times.  He composed both classical and popular music and introduced thousands to classical music on television.  He made more than 200 classical recordings, many now being examined for re-release.  Plaudits have come from everywhere and the New York Philharmonic presented four all-Bernstein nights of classical selections.  In Los Angles, three orchestras and two radio stations honored him.  On November 14, his career was commemorated at Carnegie Hall and Broadway said goodbye on December 13.  He had savored the celebrations of his 70th birthday, which featured all-star fundraising concerts at the Tanglewood Music Center and Carnegie Hall.

column3: Hurricane Gilbert's growth from a harmless lowpressure zone off Africa to a ferocious killer in the Gulf ofmexico be fuel by a combination of heat, moisture and wind thatbaffles forecasters.it's a matter of get everything together in the rightplace in the right time, Gil Clark of the National HurricaneCenter say Thursday. It doesn't happen very often. How itdevelops, we don't know.gilbert come to the attention of center forecasters Sept. 3 as adry low pressure trough move west out of Africa.We get 50 or 60 of these off Africa every summer. About one ofsix develop, say Clark.By Sept. 8, the system become a depression. It reach tropicalstorm status by Saturday and a hurricane Sunday.A tropical wave become a depression when wind start swirling.when sustain wind reach 39 mph, the system become a namedtropical storm. It reach hurricane status when sustain windshit 74 mph.why Gilbert organize and strengthen while other systemsdidn't be a mystery more or less, say University of Miamimeteorology Professor Rainer Bleck.The first part of the summer we be bite our nails,wondering why these (other) disturbances didn't develop, he saidthursday. That's something meteorologists would like to know moreabout.But the scientists do know what fuel a budding storm oncedevelopment begins. And they know that development be spark whenwinds converge, and that growth be affect by time and place.if that happen in an area where there's plenty of moisture inthe lower atmosphere (the bottom 10,000 feet or so), thisconvergence may lead to upward motion and cloud formation, Blecksaid.If cloud form, the heat of condensation in the cloudsoccasionally provide `positive feedback' to the convergencepattern. That strengthen it, he said, add that storms canbegin bud only off the equator because of the Earth's rotation.eventually, a vortex be created.any time you contract an air mass, they will start spinning.that's what make the tornadoes, hurricanes and blizzards, thosewinter storms, Bleck said.Hurricanes be useful to the climate machine. Their primaryrole be to transport heat from the low to the upper atmosphere,he said. The sun put energy into the water, the top of theoceans and low part of the atmosphere. That have to bedistributed from the bottom to high levels of the atmosphere.when the depression that would become Gilbert neared Barbados,warm Atlantic waters nurture it.this time of year in the northwest Caribbean be best fordevelopment, Clark said.
