The storm rip the roof off houses and cause coastal flooding in Puerto Rico. In the Dominican Republic, all domestic flights and flights to and from Puerto Rico and Miami be canceled. Forecasters say the hurricane be gain strength as it pass over the ocean and would dump heavy rain on the Dominican Republic and Haiti as it move south of Hispaniola, the Caribbean island they share, and head west. "it's still gain strength. It's certainly one of the large systems we've see in the Caribbean for a long time," say Hal Gerrish, forecaster at the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. At 3 p.m. EDT, the center of the hurricane be about 100 miles south of the Dominican Republic and 425 miles east of Kingston, Jamaica. The hurricane be move west at about 15 mph and be expect to continue this motion for the next 24 hours. Forecasters say the hurricane's track would take it about 50 miles south of southwestern Haiti. The hurricane center say small craft in the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico should remain in port until conditions improve. The forecasters say the Dominican Republic would get as much as 10 inches of rain yesterday, with similar amounts fall in Haiti last night and tonight. Hurricane warnings be issue for the south coast of Haiti and Cuba by their respective governments. In Jamaica, the government issue a hurricane watch for the entire island. Tropical Storm Gilbert form in the eastern Caribbean and strengthen into a hurricane Saturday night. In Puerto Rico, besides tear off several roofs, the storm cause coastal flooding and bring down power lines and trees along roads and highways in the west and southwestern regions. Three people be injure in Guayanilla, Puerto Rico, when a tree fell on their vehicle as they travel along Route 97, police reported. Four policemen station on Mona Island, between Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, be strand as a result of the weather.
column5: Baffling, ferocious, Hurricane Gilbert roars through the Greater Antilles and strikes Mexico
column6: Since Saturday, the ferocious Hurricane Gilbert has roared through the Greater Antilles.  Gilbert killed five in the Dominican Republic and hit Jamaica with its full force, killing 19 and causing extensive damage.  Its 160 mph winds pummeled Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, causing flooding and outages.  Forecasters ask why did Gilbert become so intense?
column7: Hurricane Gilbert has cut a destructive swath through the Caribbean.  The third hurricane of 1988 buffeted the southern coasts of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba.  Five were killed in the Dominican Republic.  On Monday, the storm hit Jamaica with its full force, killing 19 and causing extensive damage.  Wednesday, Gilbert hit the resorts of Cancun and Cozumel on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula with winds of 160 mph, causing extensive damage.  Gilbert then headed for the Gulf of Mexico.  Forecasters remain baffled by why Gilbert became such an intense storm, attaining the lowest barometric pressure ever recorded.
column8: Since September 10, Hurricane Gilbert has cut a destructive path through the Caribbean, hitting Jamaica and the Yucatan peninsula of Mexico with its full force.  Gilbert became the third hurricane of the 1988 season on Saturday.  On Sunday, it passed south of the Greater Antilles, causing flooding, power outages, and airport closures, and knocking down trees and tearing off roofs in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba.  In the Dominican Republic, five were killed and 10 inches of rain fell.  The eye of the storm hit Kingston, Jamaica, on Monday, then moved lengthwise across the island, at about 17 mph with sustained winds of 155 mph, causing extensive damage.  Nineteen were killed in Jamaica.  The storm buffeted the Cayman Islands, then struck the resorts of Cancun and Cozumel on the Yucatan with winds of 160 mph.  Power and communications were cut, flooding was extensive, and bands of youths began looting in Cancun.  By midnight, Gilbert was northeast of the Yucatan and heading for the Gulf of Mexico.  Gilbert was an extremely intense storm, attaining the lowest barometric pressure ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere.  Forecasters remain baffled by why this trough became such a ferocious storm.
column9: Record Intensity Hurricane Gilbert Causes Havoc In The Caribbean.
column10: Hurricane Gilbert, a category 5 storm, caused death, massive flooding and damage as it moved through the Caribbean Islands and on to the Yucatan Peninsula.  After skirting several island nations, it caused major death and destruction in Jamaica.  It then pummeled the Yucatan Peninsula before moving out to sea.
column11: Tropical Storm Gilbert strengthened into a hurricane on Saturday night, September 10th in the eastern Caribbean.  It tracked westerly at about 15mph while building in intensity.  After skirting southern Puerto Rico, Haiti and the Dominican Republic, it hit Jamaica with high winds and torrential rains, destroying 100,000 of the countries 500,000 homes and taking nineteen lives.  It then passed over the Cayman Islands before slamming into the Yucatan Peninsula causing heavy damage in the Cancun and Cozumel regions.  Gilbert is the most intense hurricane ever recorded with a record low barometric pressure of 26.31 inches and sustained winds of 179mph, gusting to 218mph.
column12: Tropical Storm Gilbert strengthened into an eastern Caribbean hurricane on Saturday night, September 10, 1988.  Government officials of the island nations in its westerly path issued alerts, warnings and orders to evacuate their southerly-exposed coastal areas.  Puerto Rico, Haiti and the Dominican escaped with only some coastal flooding and a few deaths before Gilbert continued on to strike Jamaica with 110mph winds and torrential rains.  The storm, now one of the largest systems seen in the Caribbean for a long time, slowly traversed the length of the island causing massive damage and nineteen deaths.  100,000 of Jamaica's 500,000 homes were destroyed leaving 500,000 people homeless.  The storm then passed over the Cayman Islands located south of Cuba.  Cuba and our American military bases there both avoided the brunt of the storm before it slammed full force into the Yucatan Peninsula.  By now Gilbert had strengthened into the most severe hurricane ever recorded with barometric pressure of 26.31 inches and sustained winds of 179mph, gusting to 218mph.  Relief efforts for the heavily damaged Cancun and Cozumel areas were hindered due to massive flooding and power and phone outages.  Scientists do not fully understand why some minor tropical storms strengthen into hurricanes, while others do not.

column3: Two corporate executives sit down in an office here last month to talk business with a bunch of clowns. The subject be no laughing matter, but rather the serious endeavor of find South Korea's Ronald McDonald. Seven years after the U.S. hamburger giant first try to bring its Big Macs to South Korea, the golden arches be finally go up. McAhn Industries Ltd. recently open the first of what it expect will be a string of burger outlets in Seoul. The company be a 50-50 joint venture of McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., and an accountant-turned-entrepreneur, Ahn Hyo Young. McDonald's be flourish in 11 other nations in the region. But its entry into South Korea, which have Asia's fastest-growing economy, have be frustrate by its inability to find a suitable partner and to win agreement from Seoul on terms. South Korea may be one of McDonald's most promising foreign markets, business analysts say. The country be develop an essential ingredient for the success of a fast-food enterprise: a middle class. hamburger-related fast-food sales in South Korea total $87.5 million last year, a 30% rise from 1986, accord to the Ministry of Finance. Analysts say this year's rise could be much bigger, help by a 25% increase in wages in mid-1987 and another big pay increase expect soon. The business be likely to profit from the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul in September, and from an anticipate post-olympic economic boom here. However, the competition be heat up, and there be "a good possibility that South Korea already have reach the fast-food saturation point for its current average income bracket," an official for the South Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry says. The competition, besides Wendy's International's 11 shops and six of Burger King, a unit of Pillsbury Co., include home-grown burger chains. McDonald's strategy be to take things slowly, avoid extravagances, Mr. Ahn and Awad Sifri, McDonald's marketing director, say. "we be start small," say Mr. Ahn. "We're hop to open three outlets this year and five next year. After that, we'd like to open five every year." equally modest, he says, will be the initial menu: no breakfast, no Chicken McNuggets and no products tailor to national tastes, as offer elsewhere. The venture be reject television commercials in favor of a cheaper, more oldfashioned approach: a brief advertising campaign in newspapers, distribution of fliers and word of mouth. Mr. Sifri say the emphasis will be on develop McDonald's image as an affordable place for the emerge middle class, rather than as a familiar name for foreigners in South Korea. Attention will be give to attract children, he adds. Mr. Ahn say McDonald's talk to 16 potential partners before choose the harvard-trained accountant in 1984. Two years later, McDonald's and Mr. Ahn each put up $1 million in capital and borrow an additional $4 million to form McAhn. McDonald's struggle with the government over McAhn's royalty payments to the U.S. partner -- the issue be resolve -- and over tight import restrictions on food products. The import question "came down to find a supplier locally who could supply high-quality beef and potatoes at a value," McDonald's said. even McDonald's golden arches symbol run into red tape, since the city regulate the size and color of signs. "it may be against the law, but we're put them up anyway," Mr. Ahn says.mcdonald's hamburgers, fries and goldenarches come to China on Monday when the fast-food chain open itsfirst restaurant in a nation famed for its distinctive cuisine.Hundreds of Chinese wait for hours outside the restaurant inshenzhen, an economic boom town near Hong Kong, for their firsttaste of a McDonald's hamburger, fries or shake.i travel for four hours from a village to get here, saidhuang Rongti, 70, who have lose most of her teeth because of age.you think hamburgers be too challenge for my age?later, after purchase her first big Mac, she inspect itcarefully before take a bite.it taste good, I like it, she announce before slowlyeating the rest.the opening of a U.S. fast-food restaurant in China, wherecooking have long be consider a culinary art, may seem odd togourmets. It be estimate there be more than 5,000 differentchinese dishes.in Canton, 125 miles northwest of Shenzhen, chefs specialize insome of the more exotic chinese dishes, such as cat stew, bearpaws, chicken feet and a famed snake dish - dragon and TigerLocked in Battle - make from three kinds of poisonous snakesstewed with leopard meat, and garnish with 20 spices, lemonleaves and chrysanthemum petals.however, many Chinese, who earn an average $32 a month, arestill unable to afford fancy meals at restaurants.in Shenzhen, a chinese special economic zone where foreigninvestors have build factories, salaries be high and workersearn an average of $53 a month.at the restaurant, a Big Mac cost $1.14, a bag of fries 48cents and a shake 74 cents.another U.S. fast food outlet, Kentucky Fried Chicken, open arestaurant in Beijing in 1987, and it now have four outlets there.mcdonald's hopes to open a restaurant in Beijing later.although Kentucky Fried Chicken have become popular, the averagechinese still regard a meal there as a treat, rather than aconvenience, and McDonald's could face the same problems.the 500-seat McDonald's restaurant in a three-story building isoperated by McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., a wholly ownedsubsidiary of McDonald's Hong Kong. McDonald's Hong Kong be a 50-50joint venture with McDonald's in the United States.It be manage by a chinese national, Chen Tikang, and his son,chen Yin, who be the restaurant manager. The young Chen returnedrecently from a course at McDonald's hamburger university in OakBrook, Ill.Most of the ingredients use at the restaurant be now importedfrom Hong Kong. But McDonald's executives hope eventually to gettheir supplies of beef and potatoes from China.Daniel Ng, chairman of McDonald's Restaurant Shenzhen Ltd., saidit take two years to prepare for the restaurant's opening and hisambition now be to serve 10 million burgers a year.last month, when McDonald's advertize for 240 staffers for therestaurant, it receive applications from more than 9,000 persons,including college graduates, officials said.i feel I have a good job prospect work here, and it paysbetter, say Henry He, 25, who have a master's degree in garmentand textile. He be an assistant manager at the restaurant.a waiter at the restaurant can earn 53 cents an hour.a factory worker, who wait several hours before she be ableto purchase her hamburger, say she like it because of its sweettaste - the result of tomato ketchup, which be not commonly usedin traditional chinese cooking.as THE value of the rouble plunges and potential foreign investors worryabout a host of obstacles to invest in Russia, Russian officials hadseveral reasons yesterday to feel thankful for McDonald's hamburgers.opening the second McDonald's restaurant in Moscow, along with a 12-storeyoffice block, Mr George Cohon, head of McDonald's Canada, could well bedescribed as the russian authorities' idea of a model investor.mcdonald's proven determination 'to be here for the long term' and to serveRussians in their own currency as oppose to the dollars charge by mostother foreign joint ventures be just a couple of reasons for Russiangratitude.Mr Viktor Khlystun, the agriculture minister, praise the fact thatmcdonald's get most of its supplies from inside Russia after set up aDollars 45m processing plant outside Moscow.He also thank McDonald's for provide jobs, a model of western standardsfor the country's decrepit service industry, and finally for what hedescribed as 'the most delicious food'.but despite the jolly open ceremony - with Big Macs, musicians playingthe balalaika, and hundreds of yellow balloons form a giant M - life hasbeen tough for McDonald's since it open its first restaurant in Moscow 31/2 years ago.Although the first Moscow restaurant be the busy mcdonald's in the worldthe plunge rouble, high inflation and constantly change tax rules havebeen a challenge to McDonald's management, who admit that they have noidea of when it could recoup its initial Dollars 50m investment.'it will depend on how rapidly we can open new restaurants, what happen tothe rouble, what happen to raw materials that we buy. We don't have anestimate of how long it will take. There be too many variables,' say MrCohon.Apart from housing the restaurant on the ground floor, the McDonald's officeblock be rent out to western companies in an attempt to generate hardcurrency alongside the mountains of roubles make from sell hamburgers.communism suffer its first big macattack Thursday as McDonald's open a restaurant in Yugoslavia,and police be call in to keep customers who line up for hoursfrom get too unruly under the golden arches.i just want to taste genuine american hamburgers, saidmilica Nikolic, a high school student who wait for three hours totaste her first big Mac.People curiously examine the renovated restaurant's plushinterior and the back-lit signs depict the hamburgers, frenchfries, milk shakes and other fare more familiar in the West. Italso feature amber-colored tables and floors, pastel-coloredupholstery, modern art paintings and discreet illumination.the fast-food outlet, locate on a downtown square, have drawncrowds in recent days, and they begin gather long before itopened Thursday.Police keep watch on the lines of customers snake around theblock, and they regulate the number who come inside to avoidovercrowding.no opening of a restaurant in Belgrade have create such asensation as this one today, one policeman said.i think this restaurant have no competition in Belgrade, saidmilica Danic, a housewife who treat her son to a cheeseburger.it be much cleaner, the service be faster, the interior be nicerand it be not too expensive.the Belgrade media have suggest that the success of McDonald'sin Yugoslavia depend on its acceptance by citizens long accustomedto a hamburger-like fast-food dish call the Pljeskavica: groundpork and onions on a bun.in fact, this be a clash between the Big Mac andpljeskavica, say Vesna Milosevic, an official of Genex, aYugoslav state-run enterprise that have contract a joint ventureagreement with McDonald's.Our aim be not to destroy the Pljeskavica on the Yugoslavmarket, say Predrag Dostanic, manage director of thegenex-mcdonald's. We want to change customs of the local peopleused to completly different eat habits.he say that lounge at tables for a long time after a finishedmeal will draw a warning. Also, smoking be forbidden and alcoholwill not be served.this contrasts sharply with the Balkan and Yugoslav custom ofsitting with a drink in smoke-filled restaurants and chat withfriends after the meal.the Big Mac meal, consist of a hamburger, soft drink andfrench fries cost the equivalent of $2.57, or about as much thesimilar meal would cost in numerous Pljeskavica joints around town.sadik Seljami, a waiter in a small Pljeskavica outlet just a fewhundred yards from the McDonald's, suggest that the Americanrestaurant want to drive Yugoslav fast-food outlets out ofbusiness.However, we will not give up the fight even if we have tolower the prices, say Seljami.Glen Cook, an executive of the McDonald's Corp., say during theopening ceremonies, We be very excited about the opening of thisrestaurant, not only because it be the first one in a communistcountry, but also because it be one of the nice in Europe.McDonald's and Genex contribute $1 million each for the flagshiprestaurant. They will also share the profits equally even though itwill be manage entirely by Yugoslavs.The restaurant have 350 seats and employ 110 people capable ofserving 2,500 meals per hour. In an effort to keep a high level ofservices, the management be entitle to fire any employees who failto perform.the american corporation plans to open five additionalrestaurants yugoslavia in the next five years. The next EastEuropean McDonald's, and the first in a soviet bloc country, be toopen next month in Budapest, Hungary.The communist world get its firstmcdonald's next week, and some people here be wonder whetherits american hamburgers will be as popular as the local fast-foodtreat, Pljeskavica.The long-awaited opening of the restaurant on one of Belgrade'smain downtown squares will take place March 24, the Yugoslav newsagency Tanjug reported, and it will offer Big Macs, fries and theother specialities familiar to McDonald's customers in the West.The Belgrade media have suggest that the success of theamerican restaurant depend on its acceptance by Yugoslavians whoare long accustom to the hamburger-like Pljeskavica.Pljeskavica be make of ground pork and onions, and it be servedon bread and eat with the hands. It be sell at fast-foodrestaurants across the country and costs about a dollar.in fact, this be a clash between the Big Mac andpljeskavica, say an official of Genex, Yugoslavia's largeststate-run enterprise that will operate the McDonald's.John Onoda, a spokesman at McDonald's Oak Brook, Ill.,headquarters, say it be the first of the chain's outlets in acommunist country.the next East european McDonald's be schedule to be open inbudapest, Hungary, by the end of this year, say Vesna Milosevic,another Genex official.Negotiations have be go on for years for expand thefast-food chain to the soviet Union, but no agreement have beenannounced.Thousands of queue-hardened Soviets on Wednesdaycheerfully line up to get a taste of gamburgers,chizburgers and filay-o-feesh sandwiches as mcdonald'sopened in the land of Lenin for the first time.the world's large version of the landmark american fast-foodchain ring up 30,000 meals on 27 cash registers, break theopening-day record for McDonald's worldwide, officials said.the Soviets, bundle in fur coats and hats, seem unfazed,lining up before dawn outside the 700-seat restaurant, the first of20 plan across the Soviet Union. The crush of customers be sointense the company stay open until midnight, two hours laterthan planned.i only wait an hour and I think they serve thousands beforeme, say a happy middle-aged woman who work at an aluminum plant.and it be only 10 rubles for all this, she said. i'mtaking it back for the girls at the factory to try.big Macs be price at 3.75 rubles and double cheeseburgers at3 rubles about two hours' pay for a starting McDonald's stafferor the average Soviet, but much cheap than other privaterestaurants that have spring up recently.the official exchange rate be $1.59 per ruble but foreignvisitors can buy rubles for 16 cents each, about what the currencyis worth on the black market.half the day's sales be donate to the Soviet Children's Fund,which provide medical care and assistance to orphans anddisadvantaged children, Gary Reinblatt, senior vice president ofMcDonald's Canada, say from Toronto.The restaurant, build by the company in a joint venture with thecity of Moscow that begin 14 years ago, bring to 52 the number ofcountries where McDonald's operates.the previous opening-day record for sales be in Budapest,company officials said. Besides its restaurants in the UnitedStates, the lead number of McDonald's be in Canada and Japan,the officials said.Soviets get a first-hand look at such alien concepts asefficiency and fast, friendly service. Normally dour citizens brokeinto grins as they catch the infectious cheerful mood fromyouthful soviet staffers hire for their ability to smile and workhard.Accordions play folk songs and women in traditional costumesdanced with cartoon characters, include Mickey Mouse and BabaYaga, a witch of russian fairy tales.one Muscovite, accustom to clerks who snarl if they sayanything at all, ask for a straw and be startle when a smilingyoung Soviet woman find him one and pop it straight into hisdrink.for most customers, it be their first experience with ahamburger. Sandwiches be serve in the familiar bag mark withthe golden arches, but be pack in wrappers bear Cyrillicletters, approximate gamburger.they try them one-handed. They pick their sandwiches apartto examine the contents. One young woman finally squash herbeeg Mak to fit her lips around it.it taste great! a 14-year-old boy said.it's a lot different from a stolovaya, he continue with asmile, refer to the much cheap but run-down dirty cafeteriasthat slop rice and fat or boil sausage.under the sign of the golden arches, accent by the Soviethammer-and-sickle flag, hundreds line up for the long-awaitedgrand opening at 10 a.m. on Pushkin Square, reach out excitedlyfor McDonald's flags and pins as the hamburger chain's armyfulfilled the Soviet penchant for souvenir with western logos.publicity-conscious managers have the staff shout good morning,america! in English and Russian, for an american tv network.mcdonald's of Canada Chairman George Cohon, the man behind thedeal, say many people be buy multiple orders and therestaurant serve 15,000 to 20,000 people in just the first fivehours of operation.the restaurant limit purchases to 10 Big Macs per customer inhopes of prevent burger-scalping.mcdonald's build its own factory, include bakery, dairy,meat-processing plant and even potato storage yard, to provide itsown guaranteed supplies in a country where up to 25 percent of theharvest rots en route to the consumer.one McDonald's associate say the company wind up importingwooden crates from Finland for store potatoes because when theywent to build crates, they find there be no wood, and no nails.they find you need a permit to buy nails.
column5: McDonald's opens restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China.
column6: McDonald's moved into new markets, opening restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the firstcommunist country to get a McDonald's, the Soviet Union, and China. The opening daycrowds were large and  enthusiastic about the flavor of the Big Mac. The openings cameafter years of negotiations which, in some cases, stipulated that McDonald's buy itssupplies locally.
column7: The Big Mac debuted to mixed review as McDonald's opened restaurants in Korea,Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China. Large crowds stood in line for hours atopenings in Belgrade, Moscow, and Peking. Customers in Yugoslavia, the firstcommunist country to get a McDonald's, and China raved about the taste of the Big Mac.In Moscow, the Russians were less enthusiastic about its taste but gave a thumbs up tothe shakes. The openings came after long negotiations which, in most cases, sawMcDonald's contracting with local farmers for the beef, potatoes and other suppliesneeded for its restaurants.
column8: McDonald's has expanded into non-western markets. After years of negotiations, McDonald's has been able to open restaurants in Korea, Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union, and China. Most significantly, the opening of the McDonald's in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, gave communism its first taste of a Big Mac. Moving into new markets meant that McDonald's had to overcome a number of problems. These problems range from competing with local fast food, such as the Pljeskavica in Yugoslavia, to finding reliable supplies for its restaurants. In the Soviet Union and Korea, finding supplies means contracting with local farmers for beef and potatoes. In Russia, this meant building a 50M supply facility, a cost which had not been recouped at the time of opening of the second McDonald's in Moscow. While the taste of the Big Mac met with approval, its cost could be a factor in its success. In Moscow and Peking, the high cost of a Big Mac, fries, and a shake could mean that McDonald's will viewed as a treat and not a convenience food. In the Soviet Union,  taking a family to McDonald's could cost the average worker two-days wages. Only in Korea, with its middle class, does McDonald's stand a chance of becoming a convenience food.
column9: McDonald's "Golden Arches" Continues Its World-wide Expansion
column10: McDonald's continues its worldwide expansion.  To participate in Asia's fastest expanding economy, came their first restaurant in South Korea.  Moving into communist countries, its opening in Belgrade, Yugoslavia was followed by a record shattering opening of its largest outlet anywhere in Moscow.  Then came Shenzhan, McDonald's first foray into China.
column11: To capitalize on Asia's fastest-growing economy McDonald's opened its first outlet in South Korea.  Moving into communist countries, on March 24, 1988 it opened in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.  There to compete with the locally favored "pljeskavica", a pork and onion sandwich, initial reaction was favorable.  Two years later came its largest outlet to date.  In Moscow thousands lined up for an opening day record of 30,000 meals being served at 27 cash registers.  Next, McDonald's opened in China, where cooking is a culinary art.  McDonald's worldwide restaurants are joint ventures with locals of the country in which they operate.
column12: "Golden Arches" continues its worldwide expansion.  In 1988, seven years after its first attempt to bring a restaurant to South Korea, McDonald's successfully joint-ventured with Ahn Hyo Young, a Harvard schooled entrepreneur. McAhn Enterprises Ltd. had to fight government red tape and develop local suppliers in order to open in Seoul.  That year, Big Mac also braved the communist world.  On March 24, 1988, McDonald's successfully opened in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.  Its local competition was the hamburger-like pljeskavica, i.e., ground pork and onion served on bread and eaten by hand.  Two years later, McDonald's had their most successful opening ever, worldwide.  In Pushkin Square, Moscow, thousands of people waited in line for hours at the largest McDonald's in the world for hamburgers, fries and shakes.  This opening day "Mac attack" resulted in 30,000 meals being served over fourteen hours at 27 cash registers.  Customers were surprised and pleased to find efficient, friendly workers in this country of generally surly service.  And then, China, where cooking is a culinary art.  A restaurant opened in Shenzhen, a special economic zone outside of Hong Kong where the average worker's pay there is considerably higher than in the rest of China.  McDonald's hopes to soon expand into Mainland China.

column3: The mass emigration of thousands of disaffect East Germans have rekindle reunification talk in West Germany, where some legislators plan to begin explore the possiblity of reunite the two Germanys. No one be predict a date for a possible reunification. Proponents acknowledge the risks of assume too much of east Bloc reform trends, and most hedge their thoughts with careful references to Washington and Moscow. Yet grow signs of ferment in East Germany have give Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government reason to consider the possibilities. Eduard Lintner, parliamentary speaker on german affairs for the joint Christian Democrat and christrian Socialist caucus in the Bundestag, say his committee have place reunification on its October agenda. He say the sessions, which will include government officials and outside experts, hopefully can devise reunification models to discuss with West Germany's Western allies, particularly the U.S. "It have become clear to the world that the Communist system in East Germany be in trouble," Mr. Lintner said. "the time have come for us to show our allies, but also reform-minded people in the East, that german reunification be no longer just a theory but a subject require a serious appraisal of how it could come about." "There be still a number of imponderables," Mr. Linter conceded. "for instance, we want the federal government to approach our allies and get their thoughts on the reunification topic." The U.S. ambassador to Bonn, Vernon a. Walters, earlier this month reaffirm Washington's policy of support a german reunification base on free, democratic elections. But Mr. Walters cause a stir by predict that reunion could occur in the relatively near future. Emerging opposition to uncompromising communist rule in East Germany have raise questions on how long East Berlin's leaders can resist the democratic reforms sweep through neighbor East Bloc countries. Reforms in Poland, Hungary and even the Soviet Union have magnify East Germany's Stalinist controls. fledgling protest groups, and the influential Protestant church, have begin press for reforms in East Germany which, if allow to include free elections, could eventually lead to a reunite Germany, accord to some western experts. Dorothee Wilms, Bonn's cabinet minister for inter-german affairs, say in an interview in the newspaper Welt be Sonntag that recent polls show that between 85% and 90% of all West Germans favor a reunifed Germany. "The desire for reunification, a feeling of togetherness, a sense of nationhood -- all this have strongly increase in recent years," Ms. Wilms tell the newspaper. "The recent escape movement from the DDR make especially clear that people of both german states want to live free amongst themselves," she said, but caution that reunification cannot occur overnight. The first step, she added, "is the reform process in the DDR." Most west german governments since 1949 have pay only lip service to the reunification goal set down in the preamble of West Germany's constitution. Political realities have prevent the topic from become a serious issue. Analysts say that four decades of different systems would make reunification difficult. Further, many West german workers worry that a mass influx of East Germans could threaten their jobs. Thousands of East Germans have emigrate to West Germany over the austro-hungarian border since Budapest ignore East Berlin's protests and open its border. Close to 80,000 east german refugees have arrive in West Germany so far this year, either legally or by escaping, and a total of more than 100,000 be expect by December. The Soviets have join East Berlin in criticize Bonn for welcome the east german refugees, and chide Hungary for violate an emigration treaty with East Germany by allow them to leave. Moscow, which have tolerate reforms elsewhere in the East Bloc, be say to be concern by conditions in East Germany, perhaps the most important of its Warsaw Pact satellites. Unconfirmed West german intelligence reports appear in the west german media say Moscow fear a grow dissident movement and mass demonstrations in East Germany by next year. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev accept an invitation to attend East Germany's 40th anniversary celebration, provide an opportunity for serious discussions with Erich Honecker, East Berlin's ail party leader. East Germany's Communist leadership, comment the newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, "has no illusions as to why Gorbachev be honor their 40th anniversary. He certainly will not say 'well done, keep it up.'"the government on Thursday allow for thepossibility of a reunified Germany, but say such a state must beformed gradually and respect Poland's borders.In the Solidarity government's first definitive statement on theissue, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski tell Parliament thetwo German states could be join as part of the process of unitingeurope.he say german reunification cannot go ahead of thereunification of Europe.A reunite Germany will not be create tomorrow or the dayafter tomorrow, Skubiszewski said. Fears and concerns appearingevery now and then, include in Poland, be unjustified, althoughalertness be recommended.asked about german reunification at a news conference in Gdansk,Solidarity labor leader Lech Walesa say he prefer no politicalchanges in Europe, but there should be all kinds of economicintegrations.western european countries have agree to form an economic unionby the end of 1992.Sweeping democratic reforms have take hold in East Germany inthe past several weeks under the pressure of mass protests,spurring talk of reunite the two german states divide at the endof World War II. column5: A concerned world watches a divided Germany unite.
column6: With growing numbers of disgruntled East Germans emigrating to West Germany, the idea of reunification seemed possible and became actively discussed among western leaders.  Some people and neighboring states had concerns about reunification, but after Soviet and East German communists dropped their opposition, things moved quickly to that end.
column7: Political unrest and a collapsing economy prompted tens of thousands of skilled East German workers to rush through recently opened borders to West Germany.  Western leaders saw that a reunified Germany was possible.  The East bloc communists, initially opposed to the idea, softened by urging reunification as a longer-term goal, to be reached in gradual stages.  Serious concerns about the future relations of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the impact a strong, united German state would have on the evolving European integration, trepidation by neighboring states and the fears of Jews world-wide had to be addressed.  Reunification occurred.  It was inevitable.
column8: Democratic reforms elsewhere in the Eastern Bloc magnified the emerging opposition to uncompromising Communist rule in East Germany.  The mass emigration of tens of thousands of skilled East German workers to West Germany led West German officials to conclude that reunification, which was codified in the West German constitution, was possible.  Polls in West Germany supported the idea, as did the U.S. President, George Bush.  Soviet President Gorbachev and East German leader, Erich Honecker, did not.  Eventually, Honecker was arrested for treason and abuse of power and Gorbachev softened his position.  He and interim East German Premier Hans Modrow realized that the East German socialist system had failed and reunion would occur.  However, they envisioned a gradual, no-timetable approach toward confederation while European-wide issues were being worked out.  Of paramount importance to Gorbachev was the effect reunification would have on NATO and Warsaw Pact relationships.  Poland was concerned that a united German might want to recover 40,000 square miles of land that was part of Germany before World War II.  And Jews worldwide feared that a militarily resurgent Germany could inflict another Holocaust.  After Gorbachev abolished the Warsaw Pact things moved quickly.  All European and Jewish issues were addressed.  Reunification occurred.
column9: East's Economy Sagging. Soviets Endorse German Reunification. World Awaits Change
column10: Woeful economic conditions and massive demonstrations in East Germany gave impetusto German reunification. Soviet endorsement of reunification in 1990 made it imminent.Many perceived a strong unified Germany as a danger, but that was accepted as a lesserthreat than East Germany in turmoil.
column11: East Germany was near chaos by the end of 1989. Woeful economic conditionsprevailed. Massive demonstrations for democratic reform swept the nation. The hard-lineCommunist government admitted its failure, giving strong impetus to the Germanreunification movement. The Soviets endorsed it in February as the World War II Alliesdid later. Unification was now imminent.The specter of an economically and politically powerful Germany disturbed many, butparticularly the Poles, Soviets and world Jewry. Despite concerns, reunification would beaccepted as a lesser threat than a chaotic East Germany.
column12: Through the first three months of 1989, 80,00 East Germans fled their country, andmassive demonstrations raised doubts that Erich Honeker the, hard-line Communistleader could resist the democratic reforms sweeping his country. Street demonstrationsoccurred throughout East Germany in November 1989, and the East German CommunistParty was forced to admit the its system had failed.The West German constitution called for a united Germany, but it received little attentionuntil late 1989. The specter of a powerful undivided Germany troubled many, butparticularly the Soviets and Poles.Matters moved quickly in early 1990. Soviet President Gorbachev gave West Germanyan unequivocal promise that German reunification would be honored. Two days later, onthe 12th of February, said that negotiations with East Germany should begin as soon aspossible after the 18 March East German elections. In time the World War II Allieswould endorse reunification.With reunification imminent, world Jewish leaders asked for guarantees that theHolocaust would not be repeated. Most prominent American historians agreed that astable Germany was a lesser threat to stability than the woeful conditions and near chaosin East Germany.

column5: IRA blast kills 10 at Royal Marines School of Music.
column6: A barracks belonging to the Royal Marines Music School in Deal was blown up by the Irish Republican Army on Friday, killing 10 and injuring 22.  The IRA said the bombing was in response to a speech by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment; a speech they considered an act of war.
column7: An Irish Republican Army bomb destroyed a barracks belonging to the Royal Marines Music School in Deal on Friday. The blast killed 10 and injured 22 others and also damaged or destroyed neighboring houses. Neighbors and opposition politicians blamed lax security and condemned the use of private security firms at this and 29 other bases in Britain considered to be low risk. The IRA said the blast was in response to a speech by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment, calling the speech an "act of war." This is the latest of a series of attacks as the IRA seeks the withdrawal of British forces from Northern Ireland.
column8: A barracks at the Royal Marine Music School in Deal was leveled in an explosion on Friday, which killed 10 persons and injured 22 others, 12 seriously.  Responsibility for the blast was claimed by the Irish Republican Army, which said the attack was in response to a recent speech made by Prime Minister Thatcher to the Ulster Defense Regiment. Calling the speech an "act of war," the IRA said such attacks would continue until the British withdrew their forces from Northern Ireland and allow a unification of the protestant Northern Ireland with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. The explosion, which could be heard two miles away, came at 8:30 in the morning, just as the musicians were taking a coffee break. Destroying the barracks, it also severely damaged a number of neighborhood homes, causing minor injuries among their residents. Neighbors of the barracks as well as opposition politicians blamed the use of private security firms, which, they say, caused the security at the base to be lax. Defending the use of the firms, Defense Secretary Tome King issued an alert for all military bases in Britain. The attack is the latest in a series of deadly attacks against British bases in the last 20 years.
column9: 10 Word SummaryIRA Bomb Destroys Barracks in Deal with 10 Reported Dead
column10: The IRA claimed responsibility for a bomb that destroyed a military barracks on 22September. Ten bandsmen of the Royal Marines School of Music were killed.Neighboring homes in Deal were damaged. Government policy of using private securityfirms at some installations, including the School, is being criticized.
column11: An explosion on 22 September destroyed a military barracks in Deal. Ten men assignedto the Royal Marines School of Music were killed. The IRA claimed responsibility forthe bombing, the most devastating attack against the British mainland since 1982.No serious injuries to civilians were reported, but neighboring homes suffered severedamage.Private security firms guard the Music School and 29 other "low-risk" militaryestablishments in Britain. Victims' families and opposition party leaders blamed thedisaster on lax security. Police were seeking three men with Irish accents who lived in thearea for a brief time.
column12: An explosion at 8:28 A.M. on 22 September destroyed a military barracks in Deal, a townsoutheast of London in County Kent. The barracks was home to the Royal MarinesSchool of Music. Ten military bandsmen were killed, and as many as 22 were injured,eight seriously.Neighbors expressed shock at the strength of the blast. No serious injuries to civilianswere reported, but neighboring homes suffered heavy damage.The IRA claimed responsibility for the attack, linking it what they called a warlikespeech delivered by Mrs. Thatcher during a recent visit to Northern Ireland. Investigatorssaid the damage was illustrative of that caused by a bomb. The IRA has a record ofattacking military installations, and this latest attack was the more damaging than any inmore than seven years. The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland have denounced theattack. Police are seeking three men with Irish accents who lived near the barracks for ashort time.Private security firms serve the barracks at Deal and 29 other bases in Britain. Families ofthe victims and opposition party leaders have criticized the arrangement, blaming theattack on lax security because of the private guards.

column3: Insurers face the prospect of pay out billions of dollars for damages cause by this week's California earthquake. get a grip on the extent of the damages be prove a far more difficult task than what insurers face after Hurricane Hugo rip through the Caribbean and the Carolinas last month. The earthquake's toll, include possible deep structural damage, go far beyond the more easily observe damage from a hurricane, say George Reider, a vice president in Aetna Life & Casualty Insurance Co.'s claim division. But investors be bet that the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake, come so soon after the hurricane, will help stem more than two years of intense price-cutting wars among business insurers. Reflecting that logic, insurance-company stocks post strong gains. Aetna and other insurers be hire engineers and architects to help them assess structural damage. most insurers already have mobilize their "catastrophe" teams to begin process claims from their policyholders in northern California. Since commercial air travel be interrupted, Aetna, base in Hartford, Conn., charter three planes to fly claims adjusters into Sacramento and then plan for them to drive to the Bay area. About 25 adjusters be dispatch yesterday afternoon, along with laptop computers, cellular phones and blank checks. Some adjusters, already in other parts of California, drove to the disaster area with recreational vehicles and mobile homes that could be use as makeshift claims-processing centers. Insurers will be advertise 800 numbers -- probably on the radio -- that policyholders can call to get assistance on how to submit claims. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co., the large home and auto insurer in California, believe the losses from the earthquake could be somewhat less than the $475 million in damages it expect to pay out for claims result from Hurricane Hugo. State Farm, base in Bloomington, Ind., be also the large writer of personal-property earthquake insurance in California. Earthquake insurance be sell as a separate policy or a specific endorsement "rider" on a homeowner's policy in California, because of the area's vulnerability to earthquakes. State Farm say about 25% of its policyholders in California have also purchase earthquake insurance. Allstate Insurance Co., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., say about 23% of its personal property policyholders -- about 28% in the San Franciso area -- also have earthquake coverage. The Association of California Insurance Companies estimate damage to residential property could total $500 million, but only $100 million to $150 million be insured, it said. Officials from the american Insurance Association's property-claim service division, which coordinate the efforts of the claims adjusters in an area after a natural disaster, will be fly to San Francisco today. They expect to have a preliminary estimate of the damages in a day or two. Roads and bridges in the Bay area appear to have suffer some of the most costly damage. Highways, such as the section of Interstate 880 that collapse in Oakland, generally don't have insurance coverage. Industry officials say the Bay Bridge -- unlike some bridges -- have no earthquake coverage, either, so the cost of repair it probably would have to be pay out of state general operating funds. However, the bridge, which charge a $1 toll each way, do have "loss of income" insurance to replace lose revenue if the operation of the bridge be interrupt for more than seven days. That coverage be provide by a syndicate of insurance companies include Fireman's Fund Corp., base in Novato, Calif., and Cigna Corp., base in Philadelphia. earthquake-related claims aren't expect to cause significant financial problems for the insurance industry as a whole. Instead, even with the liabilities of two natural disasters in recent weeks, analysts say the total capital of the industry be likely to be high at year end than it be at midyear. Indeed, the earthquake could contribute to a turnaround in the insurance cycle in a couple of ways. For example, insurers may seek to limit their future exposure to catastrophes by increase the amount of reinsurance they buy. such increased demand for reinsurance, along with the losses the reinsurers will bear from these two disasters, be likely to spur increases in reinsurance prices that will later be translate into an overall price rise. Reinsurance be protection take out by the insurance firms themselves. "We be say this be the break point, this be the event that will change the psychology of the marketplace," say William Yankus, an analyst with Conning & Co., a Hartford firm that specialize in the insurance industry. His firm, along with some others, issue new buy recommendations on insurer stocks yesterday. Among the insurance stocks, big gainers include american International Group, up $3.25 to $102.625; General Re Corp., up $2.75 to $86.50; Aetna, up $2.375 to $59.50; and Marsh & McLennan Inc., up $3.125 to $75.875. Still, a few individual companies, most likely small ones, could be devastated. "i think there be a damned good chance someone be go to hit the skids on this," say Oppenheimer & Co. analyst Myron Picoult. He suspect some insurers who have purchase reinsurance to limit their exposure to catastrophes will discover that reinsurance be use up by Hurricane Hugo. British, West German, Scandinavian and other overseas insurers be brace for big claims from the San Francisco earthquake disaster. Although it's unclear how much exposure the London market will face, U.K. underwriters traditionally have a large reinsurance exposure to U.S. catastrophe coverage. Jack Byrne, chairman of Fireman's Fund, say this disaster will test the catastrophe reinsurance market, cause these rates to soar. The catastrophe losses sustain by insurers this year will probably be the bad on an inflation-adjusted basis since 1906 -- when another earthquake spark the Great San Francisco Fire. Orin Kramer, an insurance consultant in New York, estimate that the 1906 San Francisco destruction, on an inflation-adjusted basis, include insured losses of $5.8 billion. He be estimate this week's disaster will generate insured losses of $2 billion to $4 billion, follow about $4 billion in costs to insurers from Hurricane Hugo.The White House be make sure nobody will accuse it of take this crisis lightly. In the aftermath of the California earthquake, President Bush and his aides fly into a whirlwind of earthquake-related activity yesterday morning. Some of it be necessary to get federal help flow to victims, but some seem design mostly to project an image of a White House in action. Mr. Bush and his aides be accuse of respond too slowly after the Exxon Valdez oil tanker split open in alaskan waters and Hurricane Hugo strike the Carolina coast, and they clearly don't want a repeat of those charges now. So the White House announce that Mr. Bush get his first earthquake briefing of the day at 6:30 a.m. from chief of staff John Sununu. By noon, Mr. Bush have take two phone calls from Vice President Dan Quayle, who be in California; make a televised statement of concern; sign a disaster proclamation; receive a write report from the Federal Emergency Management Agency; and visit FEMA headquarters. Mr. Bush himself essentially acknowledge that he and his aides be try to head off criticism. On his FEMA visit, Mr. Bush say that he hop there would be "less carping" about the emergency office's performance this time, add that the agency "took a hit" for its reaction to Hurricane Hugo. The White House already be talk of Mr. Bush visit the California earthquake site this weekend. He visit the Hugo devastation but not until after local leaders urge him to do so.most San francisco-area homeowners mayhave to pay for damage from Tuesday's earthquake out of their ownpockets, while insurance companies may reap long-term benefits fromhigher rates, industry spokesmen and analysts say wednesday.only 15 percent to 20 percent of California homeowners haveearthquake insurance, which typically require a 10 percentdeductible and costs between $200 to $400 a year for a $100,000home, accord to industry spokesmen.the Association of California Insurance Cos. in Sacramento saidthat in the San Francisco area roughly 25 to 30 percent of thehomes have earthquake insurance. The organization estimatedresidential damages from Tuesday's earthquake at $500 million inthe Bay area, with between $100 million to $150 million insured.insured homeowners without earthquake protection will getreimbursed only if their homes be ravage by fire, which iscovered under basic homeowner insurance polices, say Hugh Strawn,director of catastrophe services at the Property Loss ResearchBureau in Schaumburg, Ill.Insurance companies attempt Wednesday to assess the amount ofquake-related damages they're likely to have to pay. In addition tohome damage, the companies likely will get claims for automobiledamage, broken glass, theft and burglary, business interruption dueto electrical outages, water damage and, possibly, workerscompensation.some estimate that insurers might face bills total $1billion or more from the quake. But industry observers say theydon't expect any company to suffer serious financial damage fromquake-related claims.we don't think any company be go to have problems payingclaims, say Elisa Siegal, public affairs manager for theamerican Insurance Association, a washington-based trade group.the insurers actually could benefit. Industry analysts predictedinsurers would be able to reverse three years of decline ratesand win rate hikes from state regulators due to the quake damagesand the estimate $4 billion in damages from Hurricane Hugo, whichhammered South Carolina and other parts of the southeastern unitedstates earlier this month.an increase in insurance rates could translate into greaterprofitability in the long term, the analysts said.there's a perception that this could turn the cycle ... thatthis could be enough to firm pricing, say Gloria L. Vogel, ananalyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. Inc. in New York.Despite their predictions for the long run, the analysts warnedthat fourth-quarter earnings among insurance companies be likelyto be disappointing.it's go to be a meaningful loss, perhaps as big as Hugo,said Robert Glasspiegel, an analyst with hartford-based LangenMcAlenney.On the New York Stock Exchange, some insurance company stockrose on Wednesday. Aetna Life & Casualty Co. rise $2.37{ to $59.50a share; ITT Corp., parent of The Hartford, be up 37{ cents to$59; and the Travelers Cos. rise $1 to $40.87{.reinsurance companies, which absorb risk from policy writers,did especially well. General Re Corp. rise $2.75 to $86.50 andmarsh & McLennan Cos. rise $3.12{ to $75.87{.in California, earthquake insurance be an emotional andpolitically-charged issue. Roughly two-thirds of all insurancepolicies write in the United States be sell in California, wheremany of the nation's most damaging earthquakes have occurred..under a 1985 California law, insurers be require to offerearthquake insurance to homebuyers, but homebuyers be not requiredto buy the coverage.Insurers aren't require to offer earthquake insurance tocommercial property owners, but the percentage of business propertywith the coverage be very high, industry spokesmen said. theyestimated that at least 25 percent, and probably many more,business properties be insured.because of its high costs, earthquake insurance have become atarget of the controversial Proposition 103 approve by Californiavoters last year. The proposition call for a 20 percent rollbackin insurance rates. Insurers and state regulators be battle overthe rates and how they're set.
column5: Responses to the Northern California Earthquake of October 17, 1989
column6: California struggled to recover from the earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989. The Governor called a special session of the legislature to deal with the disaster and despite heavy losses, the insurance industry appeared optimistic. In Washington the White House launched into furious activity to answer critics of its performance in earlier crises.
column7: The California earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989 caused extensive damage. Despite heavy insurance losses, insurance company stocks posted gains as investors bet on increases in insurance rates producing a long-term increase in profits. In Washington, the White House appeared hyperactive, anxious to show its responsiveness to the disaster. In Sacramento, Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the legislature to deal with the crisis. Critics accused him of blaming others for the collapse of freeways and called on him to get on with reconstruction and a temporary increase of the gasoline tax so hundreds of thousands of commuters could get to work.
column8: The northern California earthquake of October 17, 1989 caused extensive damage to buildings and roadways. An official of the California Seismic Safety Commission said that assessing the disaster was "like the blind man trying to feel an elephant." Another on-site observer commented that the quake "was like somebody slugging a punching bag. Usually earthquakes pass, but this one went on and on...It was very very bad." Estimates of the loss to insurers ranged from $2 billion to $4 billion. Ironically, despite the record losses to insurers, insurance company stocks posted strong gains as investors bet that market forces and action by state regulators would result in higher insurance rates and long-term profits. In Washington the Bush White House flew into a whirlwind of activity to show the administration's ability for rapid response. In Sacramento Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the California legislature to deal with the disaster, but was perceived as blaming others for the collapse of freeways. Critics called on him to stop pointing fingers and get on with reconstruction. The Governor had earlier opposed an increase in the gasoline tax intended to augment transportation funding -- a step which appeared highly desirable after the quake left hundreds of thousands of commuters unable to reach work.
column9: Insurers will not suffer financial damage due to California earthquake.
column10: The White House and the California government are provided aid to Tuesday's California earthquake victims. Only 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are insured. Insurers may have to pay billions but no company is expected to suffer financial damage. Insurers price-cutting may end as prices rise from reinsurance investments.
column11: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly to get federal aid flowing. The governor of California assured victims the state also would provide aid. Only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are said to be insured.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy which, in turn, will translate into an overall price rise, thus ending the price-cutting war between them the past two years.
column12: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly--partly to get federal aid flowing--and also to protect an image of the White House in action. The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency were accused of slow response to the Exxon Valdez oil spill and Hurricane Hugo. The Governor of California is assuring victims that the state will provide aid.  Analysts and industry spokesmen say only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area have earthquake insurance.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake.  The damage goes far beyond that of Hurricane Hugo last month.  Insurers are rushing into the area to process claims but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Investors hope the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake will stem price-cutting wars between insurers the past two years. It is predicted that the quake damages may in fact lead to rate hikes. Insurers and state legislators are battling over rates and how they are set. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy, which will translate into an overall price rise.

column3: SAM WALTON be arguably the most important retailer of his generation. Theson of an Oklahoma real-estate broker, he open the first general store inwhat be to become the Wal-Mart chain in Bentonville, in the backwaters ofarkansas, in 1950, writes Martin Dickson.By 1991 the chain's sales have rise to nearly Dollars 44bn, make it theworld's large retailer in terms of revenues, and the Walton familyprobably America's richest.wal-mart now operate in 43 US states, selling goods range from detergentsto golf clubs.the chain's success stem both from Mr Walton's personality andwillingness to challenge accepted retailing orthodoxy.he be a frugal, modest man who work extremely long hours from a spartanroom in his Bentonville headquarters but delight in get out of theoffice to tour stores and meet customers and staff, whom he insist oncalling 'associates.'He would deliver pep-talks to employees extol the virtues of thrift andcustomer satisfaction, long before these become fashionable managementbuzz-words.employee satisfaction - an idea which be only now gain wider acceptancein US service industries - be also a vital ingredient in the Waltonphilosophy.He buoy staff morale with cheer-leading sessions, bonus payments for goodperformance and profit-sharing plans which allow some employees of verymodest means to retire relatively wealthy.eight years ago, when wal-mart's profits be good than expected, he kepta promise to staff by dress in a grass-skirt to dance the hula on WallStreet.Also essential to wal-mart's growth be its pioneering of high volume,cut-price retailing throughout the year, rather than the periodic saleswhich rivals rely on to generate customer loyalty.'low prices always' become Wal-Mart's motto.mr Walton also disprove the conventional wisdom that large discount storescould not operate successfully in the small, rural towns of the US south.it be precisely such locations which become the bedrock of the business,though in the process Wal-Mart put out of business hundreds of small mainstreet stores, prompt bitter resistance in some towns which Mr waltontended to blunt with generous charitable donations.forty years after Sam Walton first hungout his shingle, Walton's 5&10 will reopen to show how a littlerural storekeeper build a discount retail empire.wal-mart Stores Inc.'s Visitors Center open Wednesday in thesame building on the downtown square where Walton first open forbusiness on May 9, 1950.The center chronicle the rise of the nation's fastest-growingdiscount chain, use displays and audio-video presentations. itconcentrates on how the free enterprise system work and howwal-mart thrive when similar companies didn't.the window displays date back to the store's opening, withsimplicity patterns and Johnson's Glo-Coat, a box of Dreft and someivory Snow. Inside, an electronic map details the company's1,500-plus store chain today.also on display at the center be the hula skirt that Sam waltondonned for his dance on Wall Street, which he perform afterchallenging the company to reach a record 8 percent pre-tax profitin 1984. The goal be accomplish and he danced.the old and the modern together reflect the corporate culture ofthe nation's big discount retailer behind K mart Corp. ofdetroit.walton and his brother, Bud, open the first wal-mart DiscountCity in 1962. Both will be on hand for the opening, along with asprinkling of other dignitaries, include Gov. Bill Clinton, thededication speaker.aside from the other displays and presentations, the center alsohas a replica of Sam Walton's original office at the store,including many fixtures he use 40 years ago.also on display be a photograph of young Sam Walton, a fat-facedbaby born in Oklahoma in the 1920s. Typical of the Wal-Martoutlook, Dust Bowl Oklahoma be term a place to grow and todream in a video on the Walton family.after a stint with J.C. Penney Co. and the Army, he open a BenFranklin store in Newport in 1945. He lose the lease on that one,and relocate to Bentonville. That's where the story take off.Sam Walton convince Bob Bogle, then a public health officer, totake over management of his Bentonville Ben Franklin store in 1955.Walton say he want to put in about a dozen stores andneeded someone to tend the shop in Bentonville while he and hisbrother build a chain of Ben Franklins, Bogle say in a recentinterview.that's when Bogle find himself in Walton's learn as you gotraining program.i get home at 10 o'clock that night after scrub and waxingthe floor with Sam, Bogle said.inauspicious first impressions be part of the story. In onevideo, David Glass, who succeed Sam Walton as chief executive ofwal-mart in 1988, recall his impressions after attend theopening of the second wal-mart Discount City at Harrison in 1964.The first store, at Rogers, open two years earlier.i think to myself this be absolutely the bad discountstore, or retail store, I have ever seen, say Glass, who waspresident of a drugstore chain at the time.and Wal-Mart Vice Chairman Donald Soderquist recall that whenwalton take his idea of put discount stores in rural areas toben Franklin headquarters in Chicago, officials there just reallydidn't see a future in it.don Shinkle, Wal-Mart's director of corporate and publicaffairs, attribute wal-mart's success to its associates theterm for employees first coin in 1972 to stress that all Wal-Martemployees be partners in the company and to Sam Walton'sleadership and knack for hire the right person at the righttime.at the start of 1990, wal-mart own 1,402 stores, employed272,000 and list sales of $25.8 billion. Sam's Wholesale clubclosed out the year with 123 units and Wal-Mart announce plans toenter the California market.made IN AMERICA: MY STORYBy Sam WaltonDoubleday, Dollars 22.50. 269 pagesbeing an american folk hero be a tricky assignment, as Ross Perot find out.The problem be that the great american public like its boot-strapentrepreneurs to be very rich and very upright. In a country where businesspractices be not overly genteel, this be a tough combination to achieve. Avast media circus, meanwhile, be quick to expose any flaws.sam Walton, founder of the Wal-Mart chain of discount supermarkets who diedof cancer in April, negotiate these pitfalls much good than most. When,in 1985, Forbes magazine declare him America's rich entrepreneur, thepaparazzi descend on the obscure corner of Arkansas, mainly occupy bychicken farmers, where Walton make his home. What they find be a happilymarried, much-liked billionaire who enjoy quail hunting, breakfast atthe local Holiday Inn, and drive a battered pick-up truck, minus twohub-caps. Folksy be an understatement.since then, some aspects of Wal-Mart's business - its anti-union policies,the impact of its Dollars 40bn annual sales on hundreds of Mom-and-Pop shops -have be subject to critical scrutiny. So, to an extent, have the lesswholesome adventures of the four Walton children. But no one have ever beenable to make Sam himself look bad. The bad that have be say be that hewas rather dull.walton be not about to dash anyone's illusions. Readers will either find hisautobiography lash with 'good ol common-sense and a lot of harmless, ifcharming, anecdotes. Or they will find it dreary and downbeat. Walton makesno excuses: 'I realise this may sound bore to most you,' he write at onestage, 'but one of my best items ever be a mattress pad call a Bedmate .. . .'a few snippets be more revealing about the character. There cannot be manybillionaires who admit that they 'never learn handwrite too well' - andhave the guts to include a photograph which demonstrate the point.meanwhile, the competitive energy which Sam Walton apply to his businessis inescapable. In one of many contributions from friends and family, DonSoderquist, Wal-Mart's chief operate officer, tells of find Sam onesaturday morning on his hand and knees at the local Kmart store, analysinghis rival's stock. And his wife, in a casual aside, notes that when thecouple be on holiday in Italy their luggage vanish while her husband wasoff on a similar scouting mission.but it be David Glass, Wal-Mart's current chief executive, who perhapscaptures the entrepreneurial Walton spirit best. explain the annualcontest in which Wal-Mart executives choose one 'volume produce item' topromote, he recall the time Sam (who usually won) select minnow bucketsfor carry bait. Glass be more happily team with apple juice. 'So Iwould go down to the stores, and get them to take that minnow bucket . . .put ice in it, ice down the juice and give away samples out of his minnowbucket. I particularly do it in stores I know (sam) be go to visit. Itdrove him crazy, and he get off that minnow bucket pretty quick . . . .'but the reader can't help feeling that the cosy yarns tell only half thetruth. Sam Walton be a salesman to the core, and seem to have packagedhimself with all the skill that he once apply to sell a gooey southernsweet call Moon Pies.For the most part, this make for an engaging, if one-dimensional, portrait.occasionally, it just grates. 'I have buy a bank in Bentonville, for aboutabout Dollars 300,000,' Walton remarks, for example, 'just a little old bankwith only about Dollars 3.5m in deposits. But it help me learn a lot aboutfinancing things.' Oh, come on Sam, be that the whole story?the real truth, one suspects, come right at the end of the book - whenwalton admit that 'if I hadn't gotten sick, I doubt I would have writtenthis book'. Given the pleadings of publishers - Doubleday pay about Dollars4m for the manuscript - and a rather natural desire to have a final say, hecan hardly be blame for agree to write it. But these be unlikely to becircumstances which make for the most critical self-analysis. At the end ofthe day, Sam Walton's heritage be in the shopping malls, not the bookstores.the store manager of the Wal-Mart in thiscommunity on the outskirts of Dallas tell a story that give aninsight into the man consider responsible for a retailingphenomenon.manager Don Bost remembers one day last summer when a secretarytelephoned from Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s corporate headquarters inbentonville, Ark. Chairman Sam Walton be about to land at a nearbyairport and the secretary ask if someone could fetch him and bringhim to the De Soto store.paying unexpected calls on stores be one way Walton have keep inclose touch with everyday goings-on. His example be follow byother Wal-Mart executives and most make a point of spend a lot oftime in the field.Says Ed Nagy, district manager for 9 stores in the Dallasmetropolitan area, It's not like `uh-oh, someone's coming,'because they're always out.By all accounts, Sam Walton's personality permeate operationsthroughout the company.everyone, from Wal-Mart President and Chief Operating OfficerDavid Glass down to an hourly store worker, can readily quote thegospel accord to Sam, as he be called.to paraphrase Sam's primary rules of retailing, Rule No.1 isthe customer be always right. Rule No.2 say just in case thecustomer's wrong, revert to rule No.1.If the principles sound old-fashioned and homespun, they arebecause that's the way Sam is, people who know him say.he shun the limelight that his company's success have shed on himand have decide to refuse almost all press requests for interviews.he's happy to chat with folks in his stores, though.he also regularly remind wal-mart associates thathospitality to customers be crucial. He preach it in person or viahigh-tech satellite hookup with his stores.wal-mart employees become know as associates under a companyeffort to prove it care about employees, partly to thwart a unionorganizing effort in the late 1960s.One of the most sensitive subjects for Walton be the fortune he'samassed.a close associate say Sam would probably give anything notto be name on Fortune magazine's list of the country's wealthiestpeople. The magazine have estimate that his immediate family's stakein Wal-Mart stock be worth about $6.8 billion.sam Walton be more interested in his backhand than he be in hisbank account, say Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart spokesman.samuel Moore Walton turn 71 on March 29. He be bear inkingfisher, Okla., and grow up as the son of a farm-mortgage banker.he graduate from the University of Missouri with an economicsdegree in 1940 and join J.C. Penney Co. as a management trainee indes Moines, Iowa. After serve three years in the Army, he go toarkansas and open a Ben Franklin five-and-dime store, eventuallybecoming the company's big franchisee.the seeds of the Wal-Mart empire be sow when Sam and hisbrother James L., or Bud, open the first wal-mart Discount City in1962. The rest will probably earn an entry in the history of U.S.retail trade.bud be a senior vice president and board member of Wal-Mart.Three of the four grown children Sam and his wife Helen have areinvolved with the company in various capacities.sam hasn't slow much, enjoy hunting and tennis as much asever, and be say not to suffer after effects from a bout withleukemia, now in remission. He spend less time in the office sincehanding over most responsiblities to David Glass. Sam be stillchairman of the board.glass doesn't hesitate when ask if Wal-Mart can flourishwithout Sam. The answer be an emphatic yes because, he says, Wehave great people. The Walton family will always be involved, headds.commenting on the future, Glass says: We'll be judge on whatwe produce today. Tomorrow, what we've do in the past won'tmatter.wal-mart founder Sam Waltonpitched in to help check-out clerks at his store in this FloridaPanhandle city when an electronic glitch shut down the cashregisters.the 71-year-old Walton, consider to be one of the world'srichest people, grab a note pad Tuesday evening and startedhand-writing merchandise prices for customers so their bills couldbe tally on calculators quickly.people begin recognize him and come up and greet him,said store manager Paul Sively. He shake their hands and talk toeveryone he could. The registers be out for about 45 minutes, andi don't think we have one customer complain.walton, know for his down-home style, make a surprise visit tothe store that later Tuesday stag a concert by country singer JanaJea in its parking lot. Walton often attend promotional events forhis arkansas-based chain, and sively say he have suspect the bossmight make an appearance.walton continue talk with customers during the concert. Healso join the singer on stage to sing a duet and lead customers inthe Wal-Mart cheer.he be up there saying, `give me a W, give me an A,' and thecustomers go right along with him, sively said. He even gotdown to do a cheerleader's squiggle.'wal-mart: A HISTORY OF SAM WALTON'S RETAIL PHENOMENON' by Sandra S. Vanceand Roy V. Scott Twayne Publishers, New York, Dollars 14.95 240 pagesmany people might be say to be the personification of the american Dream;few be better qualify for that title than Sam Walton.Walton be a character it would be difficult to invent, an all-american boywho become one of the world's most successful businessmen. The church-goingson of a farmer bear in 1918 near Kingfisher, Oklahoma, he found a storechain which make him America's richest man, and which, shortly before hisdeath in 1992, become the world's big retailer.his company, Wal-Mart, make sales of Dollars 55bn last year, and afterwalton's death Fortune magazine report that his wife and four childrenheld between them the second-largest fortune in the world - dollars 23.5bn.What be most startling about Wal-Mart be the speed of its growth. AlthoughWalton build up a small chain of Ben Franklin variety store franchise from1945, it be not until 1962 that he open his first wal-mart discountstore.at the time of its incorporation in 1971, wal-mart have only 38 outlets withsales of Dollars 44m - not enough to earn a place in trade journal DiscountMerchandiser's list of the 71 big US discount retailers. Ten yearslater, with 330 stores and Dollars 1.6bn sales, it be only the 33rd-biggestretailer in the US. Its turnover be only 9 per cent of that of SearsRoebuck, the biggest, and 11 per cent of K mart, the second-biggest. Withinanother 10 years, Wal-Mart have overtake them both.apart from Walton's autobiography complete shortly before his death,however, publish material about the company be curiously scarce. This bookattempts to fill the gap, to provide a 'scholarly account' of the rise ofwal-mart, set it in the wider context of US retailing, and explaininghow it be achieved.one strength the authors identify be wal-mart's ability to copy and adaptfrom other retailers.sam Walton do not invent discount retailing. Rather, he realise the threatdiscounting pose to his own variety store business and study in depthmany of the US's lead discounters of the early 1960s, include Ann andhope, E J Korvette, Spartan's, Fed-Mart, and K mart.Walton learn from them all, but be unique in take his discount storesinto small towns of a few thousand people, where shoppers use to travellinglong distances be delight to have a cut-price store nearby sellingeverything they needed.Another strength be wal-mart's openness to technology. as early as the1950s, Walton realise he be waste too much time travel and buy asmall aircraft to pilot between stores himself - something he continue todo to the end of his life.sometimes, Walton be more reluctant to invest in technology, and have to bepersuaded by colleagues to introduce computers, and scan at check-outs -long before most retailers have recognise their importance - and to investdollars 20m in an internal satellite communications system. This technologyhelped Wal-Mart build one of the most efficient distribution systems of anyretailer. But perhaps the most fundamental reason for its success, the booksuggests, have be Wal-Mart's streamlined and highly responsive managementstructure.regional vice-presidents base at group headquarters in Bentonville,Arkansas, rather than in costly regional offices, be despatch everymonday by aircraft to their regions, spend the week visit stores, workingwith staff and managers, and return for a day-long merchandising meetingevery Friday.They discuss results, problems and suggestions from the week at a 7.30ammeeting on Saturdays and immediately afterwards call district managers torelate the results. District managers hold a conference call with theirstore managers, and before the day be out, the contents of the meeting havebeen communicate to all store department heads.the system mean employees can make suggestions to vice-presidents one weekand, if the idea be accept by the Saturday meeting, see its implementationbegin the follow week.even the world's most successful retailer make mistakes, however. One waswalton's decision to stand down from the chairman and chief executive's rolein 1974 in favour of Ronald Mayer, only to return to both roles in 1976after finding he be incapable of let go of the reins. Another waswal-mart's short-lived Hypermart format, which prove too big even forgigantist America.Then there be Walton's rash promise to do a 'hula dance' on Wall Street ifwal-mart achieve an 8 per cent pre-tax profit margin in 1984. It did, andhe did.the book also cover well the debate over whether wal-mart's impact on theeconomies of small US towns be positive or negative.if there be criticisms, these be that this 'scholarly account' never quitecaptures the sheer excitement of work in the world's fastest-growingretailer.
