Moreover, it make little attempt to predict whether Wal-Mart cancontinue its growth, and conquer the rest of the world in the way itconquered the US.But this be a well-researched and accessible account of one man's success inbuilding his own american dream.he's rank as the rich man in thenation by a lead business magazine, but to folks in Bentonville,a town of about 8,700 people, Sam Walton be just another neighbor.he's just a part of the community, say Curt Loyd, executivedirector of the Bentonville Chamber of Commerce. He's a neatperson. He call Bentonville home, and that be special to us.walton, who prefer bird-hunting, tennis and open new Wal-Martstores to trumpet his personal financial holdings, be againshunning publicity about his third consecutive ranking among theworld's top billionaires. accord to Forbes magazine's July 24edition, the Walton family's estimate worth be $8.7 billion, upfrom its 1988 estimate of $6.5 billion.he be unavailable, say Wal-Mart spokesman Don Shinkle of thesilver-haired founder of the nation's third-largest retail chain,based in Bentonville, about 150 miles northwest of Little Rock.Shinkle say he receive about 10 calls from reporters Mondaymorning, when the Forbes list appear in newspapers. Shinkle saidnews coverage about Walton usually set off a press frenzy forcomments from him. But the 71-year-old businessman decline tocomment.he feels any attention to Sam Walton be to the individual andhe prefers attention to Sam Walton (the founder of) the company,shinkle said.he very seldom schedules interviews about his feelings. It justputs him in a position he doesn't want to be.but Walton occasionally offer peeks that reveal personalmodesty. Just after the 1987 stock market crash, in which walton'sfamily-owned chunk of Wal-Mart stock lose millions in value, hequipped in response to questions at a news conference on anothertopic that it be only paper. Walton then change the subject.walton be first list by Forbes as the nation's richest man inoctober 1985. Three years ago, Forbes also begin list the world'swealthiest people. Walton make that listing as the rich americanevery year since. This year he rank third, behind two Japanesebusinessmen.Shinkle say Walton stay busy visit many of the more than1,400 stores operate by the company he start as a singlefive-and-dime at Rogers more than two decades ago. He be out of theoffice up to four days a week, the spokesman said.he spend most of his time talk to associates andcustomers, Shinkle said, and he always come back with manyideas from them.wal-mart calls its sales help associates instead of employees.when Walton first make the Forbes list of rich americans,recalled Little Rock investment banker Warren Simpson, call come infrom all over about the billionaire from the Ozarks.They want to know about the stock and the company, saidsimpson, who work for Stephens Inc. You'd think that he'd beliving in New York or LA, not Bentonville, Arkansas. But now peoplejust accept it.when it come out now, it's just, `Yeah, he's still there,'simpson said.
column5: Sam Walton, Wal-Mart's multi-billionaire "good 'ole boy", revolutionized American retailing.
column6: Sam Walton revolutionized discount retailing, at the same time becoming the richest man in America.  He took discount shopping to rural America with Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer.  His down-home personality, chronicled in his autobiography and the Wal-Mart visitor's center, permeated the chain's operations.  Scholars also credit his adaptability and responsive management.
column7: Sam Walton, who died in April 1992, revolutionized discount retailing.  Born in Oklahoma, he became the richest man in America. He took discount shopping to rural America founding Wal-Mart Discount City, which became Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer by 1992.  Sam was frugal and homespun and used pop-in visits to test for happy customers and employees.  To preserve his personal legacy, he opened a Wal-Mart visitors' center and wrote his autobiography, filling it with "good ole" anecdotes.  A 1994 book highlighted his ability to copy and adapt, the chain's responsive management, and the chain's impact on Mom-and-Pop stores and anti-union position.
column8: Wal-Mart founder, Sam Walton, who died in April 1992, revolutionizeddiscount retailing.  Born in Oklahoma, the son of a mortgage banker,he became the richest man in America and the second richest in theworld.  After a tour in the army and working in and owning retailingoutlets, he founded Wal-Mart Discount City in 1962.  He took discountshopping to rural America and by 1992 Wal-Mart was the world's largestretailer.  Success can be attributed to Sam's personality.  He wasfrugal, hardworking, old- fashioned, and homespun.  He declared thecustomer always right and continually nurtured employee satisfactionwith bonus payments, profit-sharing plans, and a responsive,streamlined, management system.  He was known for pop-in visits,talking with customers, and personally helping out in an emergency.Sam Walton also worked to preserve his personal legacy.  In 1990 theWal-Mart Stores Inc., Visitors Center opened to chronicle the rise ofthe chain.  He also wrote his autobiography, filling it with anecdotesabout his "good ole" common sense.  A scholarly book was released in1994, which highlighted his ability to copy and adapt and addressedsome of the negative aspects of the giant chain, including itsanti-union stand and its impact on small town Mom-and-Popstores.
column9: Sam Walton dies. Master discounter founded and directed Wal-Mart.
column10: Sam Walton's chain was the country's largest retailer. He was the country's richest man. Wal-Mart grossed 44 billion dollars in the year before he died. Despite his wealth, he lived humbly.He was criticized for anti-union policies, and because his stores in small towns destroyed many small businesses.
column11: Sam Walton relied on his personality, hard work and a willingness to adopt new business practices to build Wal-Mart into the country's largest discount retailer. This made him the country's richest man, but he continued to live a simple life. Identification as the richest man made him uncomfortable. He was criticized for anti-union policies and causing the failure of small town businesses where he located his stores. Walton often visited his workers and kept them happy. Shortly before his death in 1992 Walton wrote a folksy autobiography. There is also a "scholarly study" on his business.
column12: Sam Walton died in April 1992, shortly after his 74th birthday on 29 March. He rose from humble beginnings to become the country's richest man.  He accomplished this by dint of hard work, an engaging personality and willingness to defy accepted retailing practices.After earning a college degree and serving in the army, he opened a Ben Franklin franchise in Arkansas. In 1962 his brother joined him and they opened the first Wal-Mart. When Wal-Mart was incorporated in 1971 there were 38 outlets. Wal-Mart's revenues then were only nine percent of Sears' and 11 percent of K-Mart's. Wal-Mart experienced phenomenal growth. In 1991, the year before Walton's death, Wal-Mart's revenues were greater than those of any other discount retailer. Walton eschewed the publicity that accompanied the annual Forbes' listing of the richest people. He spent most of his time at home in Arkansas, and whenever possible he visited his stores to exchange ideas with his salespeople, or as he called them "his associates".He was criticized for putting his stores in small towns, and causing the failure of many small businesses. He was also criticized for his anti-union policies.

column3: SQUADS of workers fan out across storm-battered Louisiana yesterday tobegin a massive rebuilding effort after Hurricane Andrew have flatten wholedistricts, kill two people and injure dozens more, agencies report fromFlorida and New Orleans.However, local officials in Florida, hit earlier in the week by thehurricane, be critical of what they call a delay in supply food,drinking water and other supplies for thousands of people in need.federal emergency officials acknowledge distribution problems,transportation Secretary Andrew Card yesterday promise 'dramatic'improvements within 24 hours and President George Bush last night orderedtroops to Florida, without specify a number.the government estimate it would cost Dollars 20bn-dollars 30bn to tidy andrebuild in Florida, and to care for residents displace by the storm.louisiana state officials say they have no overall count of storm-relatedinjuries but initial estimates reckon few than 100. The FederalEmergency Management Agency say it be set aside Dollars 77m to helplouisiana recover.most of the storm's fury be spend against sparsely populated farmingcommunities and swampland in the state, spar it the widespreaddestruction cause in Florida, where 15 people died.official estimates in Miami report that the hurricane have wipe out thehomes of one Dade County resident in eight - a quarter of a million people.andrew have become little more than a strong rainstorm early yesterday,moving across Mississippi state and heading for the north-eastern US.Several of Louisiana's main industries be affected, include those ofoysters and alligators. Wildlife and fisheries secretary Joe herringestimated a 50 per cent decline in the alligator industry. The cotton andsugar-cane crops be threatened, the state agriculture department said.most Louisiana oil refineries, however, be barely affect and deliveriesof crude oil be expect to resume yesterday.hurricane Andrew, claim to be the costly natural disaster in UShistory, yesterday smash its way through the state of louisiana,inflicting severe damage on rural communities but narrowly missing thelow-lying city of New Orleans.The storm, which bring havoc to southern Florida on Monday and then headednorth-west across the Gulf of Mexico, have make landfall late on Tuesdaynight some 60 miles south-west of the city in the agricultural Cajuncountry.Although the damage from the hurricane's landfall in Florida on Monday wasmuch great than initially esti mated, insurers' losses there be likely tototal less than dollars 1bn, well below early expectations, a seniormember of Lloyd's insurance market say yesterday.in Louisiana, the hurricane land with wind speeds of about 120 miles perhour and cause severe damage in small coastal centres such as Morgan City,Franklin and New Iberia. Associated tornadoes devastate Laplace, 20 mileswest of New Orleans.Then, however, Andrew lose force as it move north over land. By yesterdayafternoon, it have be down-graded to tropical storm, in that its sustainedwindspeeds be below 75 mph.initial reports say at least one person have died, 75 be injure andthousands make homeless along the Louisiana coast, after 14 confirm deathsin Florida and three in the Bahamas.The storm cause little damage to Louisiana's important oil-refiningindustry, although some plants have to halt production when electricity wascut.the Lloyd's member, in close contact with lead insurers in Florida, saidthat damage to insured property be remarkably small. more than Dollars 15bnof damage may have be cause in all, but be mostly to uninsured property,he said.in north Miami, damage be minimal. Worst affect be one hotel, whosebasement be flooded. Most of the destruction occur in a 10-mile bandacross Homestead, 25 miles to the south of Miami, where a typical housesells for Dollars 100,000 to Dollars 150,000. US insurers will face a billin respect of such properties, but Lloyd's exposure there be minimal.many destroyed power lines be think to be uninsured, as be trees andshrubs uprooted across a wide area. only one big hotel in that area have beenbadly damaged, a Holiday Inn.Across Florida, some 2m people remain without electric ity yesterday andhealth officials be warn the public to boil or chemically treat allwater.hurricane Hugo, which devastate much of South Carolina in 1989, cost theinsurance industry some Dollars 4.2bn. Further uninsured losses may haveraised the total to Dollars 6bn-dollars 10bn.DAMAGE caused by Hurricane Andrew could rise to Dollars 20bn, it wasestimated yesterday, as one of the costly u storms this centurythreatened a further devastate landfall near the city of New Orleans.Government officials in Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas yesterday advisedor order more than 2m people to evacuate coastal areas.the hurricane tear through southern Florida early on Monday morning, causingbillions of dollars of property damage and at least 12 deaths, and yesterdaywas move north-west across the Gulf of Mexico with winds of about 140miles an hour.at least three people die on Sunday when Hurricane Andrew cross thebahamas.ms Kate Hale, director of emergency services in Florida's Dade County, whichbore the brunt of the storm, estimate that Andrew have already causeddollars 15bn to Dollars 20bn (pounds 7.5bn-Pounds 10bn) of damage.however, insurance industry analysts caution that it be too early toassess the costs accurately. The US industry's Property Claims Service, theofficial compiler of disaster losses, have yet to compile a preliminary tallyof the Florida bill.a hurricane warning be in effect yesterday along 470 miles of Gulf coastfrom Pascagoula, Mississippi, to Galvestone, Texas.Several forecasting agencies suggest the likeliest landfall be in centrallouisiana, to the west of New Orleans, possibly late last night or thismorning.new Orleans, with a population of 1.6m, be particularly vulnerable becausethe city lie below sea level, have the Mississippi River run through itscentre and a large lake immediately to the north.much of America's oil refining industry be concentrate along coastal Texasand Louisiana and several refineries be yesterday partially shut down.these include british Petroleum's Belle Chasse plant in Louisiana.In Florida, Andrew cause great havoc in a largely suburban swathe some10-15 miles south of Miami. The town of Homestead, near the centre of thestorm, be largely flattened, include a local air force base.miami's city centre escape with relatively light damage. more than 24 hoursafter the hurricane, some 825,000 households and businesses be stillwithout power.the brunt of insurance claims from the Florida storm will fall on the USindustry, and companies with a heavy local exposure include the State FarmGroup and the Allstate Insurance unit of Sears Roebuck. These be also theleading property/casualty and home insurance groups in Louisiana, togetherwith American International Group.A spokesman for State Farm Insurance say he believe the company hadroughly 20 per cent of the Florida market. The mutually-owned company have noreinsurance. Its size have make obtain reinsurance cover difficult and itsreserves, at about Dollars 24bn, have make it unnecessary.according to Balcombe Group, a uk-based claims adjustment firm, otherinsurers with large exposure in the hurricane-hit area be HartfordInsurance, Aetna and Travellers. Travellers say it have fly 50 claimsadjusters in to Florida late on Monday and be assess losses. About 12per cent of Travellers' home insurance premium income come from Florida lastyear, and 4.6 per cent of its commercial insurance premiums.the last serious US hurricane, Hugo, which strike South Carolina in 1989,cost the industry dollars 4.2bn from insured losses, though estimates of thetotal damage cause range between Dollars 6bn and Dollars 10bn.US CITIES along the Gulf of Mexico from Alabama to eastern Texas be onstorm watch last night as Hurricane Andrew head west after sweep acrosssouthern Florida, causing at least eight deaths and severe property damage.the hurricane be one of the fierce in the US in decades and the first tohit Miami directly in a quarter of a century. In the Bahamas, governmentspokesman Mr Jimmy Curry say four deaths have be report on outlyingeastern islands.mr Justin Balcombe, of uk-based insurance adjuster Balcombe Group, saidtotal losses could exceed Dollars 15bn if business interruption claim weretaken into account. That compare with the Dollars 4bn-dollars 6n (pounds2.1bn-pounds 3.1bn) of insurance industry losses cause by the last big UShurricane, Hugo, which hit South Carolina in 1989.The brunt of the losses be likely to be concentrate among US insurers,industry analysts say yesterday.mr George Lloyd-Roberts, chairman of Lloyd's Underwriters' Non-MarineAssociation, say that, unless damage claims exceed Pounds 3bn, thelloyd's insurance market would feel little impact. Because the reinsuranceof reinsurance risk - know as the retrocession market - have shrunkconsiderably in recent years, US insurers have place far few of theirrisks through Lloyd's.Mr Roger Hill, insurance analyst at Warburg Securities, say he estimatedthat mainline UK insurers face no more than Pounds 75m in damage claims sofar.'at the moment we be relax about it,' he said. The real question, headded, be the level of reinsurance available to the UK underwriters.royal Insurance estimate the company's losses at no more than Pounds 20m.Among other UK insurers, Mr Hill estimate that General Accident may facelosses of up to Pounds 30m, while Guardian Royal Exchange face Pounds 5mand Sun Alliance and Commercial Union Pounds 10m each.however, Hurricane Andrew gather fresh strength as it move across thegulf of Mexico and there be concern last night that it might head towardsnew Orleans, which be especially low lying and could suffer severe flooddamage.Scientists say the storm could make landfall anywhere between the Alabamaport of Mobile and the Louisiana-Texas border, probably tomorrow night orearly Thursday.It could threaten the large concentration of offshore oil productionfacilities in the Gulf of Mexico. Shell Oil be evacuate most of the 900workers on its offshore platforms as a precaution.a substantial part of America's oil refining industry be concentrate on thegulf coast, in Louisiana and Texas, and officials there be reviewingemergency plans to curtail or shut down plant operations.Andrew, the first Caribbean hurricane of the season, hit the eastern coastof Florida early yesterday, gusting up to 165mph. It rip roof offhouses, smashed cars and trucks, snap power lines and uprooted treesbefore head out over the Gulf.A million people have be order to flee their homes in southern Florida asthe hurricane move in from the Bahamas on Sunday. The Florida Power andlight company say that about 1.2m of its customers, or 32 per cent, werewithout power.some of the strong winds be in the affluent suburb of Coral Gables,just south of Miami, where the National Hurricane Center be located. Itsradar and satellite antennae be blow away.president Bush authorise federal disaster assistance for the affected areasand make plans for an inspection tour of the state.picture, Page 14GENERAL ACCIDENT, the lead british insurer, say yesterday that insuranceclaims arise from Hurricane Andrew could 'cost it as much as Dollars 40m.'Lord Airlie, the chairman who be address an extraordinary shareholders'meeting, said: 'on the basis of emerge information, General Accidentadvise that the losses to their US operations arise from Hurricane Andrew,which strike Florida and Louisiana, might in total reach the level at whichexternal catastrophe reinsurance covers would become exposed'.What this mean be that GA be able to pass on its losses to externalreinsurers once a certain claims threshold have be breached.it believe this threshold may be breach in respect of Hurricane Andrewclaims.However, if this happens, it would suffer a post-tax loss of Dollars 40m(Pounds 20m).Mr Nelson Robertson, GA's chief general manager, explain later that thecompany have a 1/2 per cent share of the Florida market. It have a branch inorlando.the company's loss adjusters be in the area try to estimate the losses.their guess be that losses to be face by all insurers may total more thanDollars 8bn.Not all damage property in the area be insure and there have beenestimates that the storm cause more than Dollars 20bn of damage.however, other insurers have estimate that losses could be as low asDollars 1bn in total.mr Robertson said: 'No one know at this time what the exact loss is'.while Hurricane Andrew be wreak havoc across large parts of southernflorida and Louisiana this week, a grade two dollar crisis (on a one-to-fourscale, four be most severe) be blow itself out at the end of atumultuous few days for US and world financial markets.on Wall Street, most of the damage from the currency storm be inflict aweek ago Friday and on the following Monday, when bond yields jump sharplyand the Dow Jones industrial average plunge by more than 75 points.the flimsy walls erect hastily by the Federal Reserve and other bigcentral banks to protect the vulnerable dollar from a tidal wave of sellingon foreign exchange markets fail to hold; and as the sellers pouredthrough the breach barricades, the currency drop to dm1.40. This wasits lowest-ever point against the d-mark.the conditions necessary for a dollar crisis have be build up incurrency markets for some time. Interest rate differentials between US andgermany widen over the summer as the Fed eased, and the Bundesbanktightened, their respective monetary policies.the failure of the US economy to climb out of recession with any vigour wasalso make overseas investors increasingly unhappy about hold thedollar.so, too, be the political hole President Bush have dig for himself in are-election battle that only a year ago be suppose to be a shoo-in for theincumbent.moreover, the fact that almost every central bank worth its salt be in themarkets try to prop up the dollar serve only to convince foreignexchange dealers that the currency be head in one direction - down.while there be plenty of reasons for the dealers to sell the dollar, thelogic for such a strongly negative reaction from bond and stock markets wasless obviously compelling.there be two standard explanations why a weak dollar prompts bond prices tofall. The first be that it raise import prices and, as a result, add toinflationary pressures.the second be that it make it hard for the Fed to engineer another cut ininterest rates to stimulate the flagging recovery, and raise thepossibility that rates may actually have to go up to protect the currency.the first explanation be not particularly convince - imports account fornot much more than 10 per cent of US gross domestic product, so higherimport prices do not greatly effect the overall price level, which be nowaround 3 per cent and head lower.the second explanation carry more weight. Although there be not muchchance, give the present economic and political climate, that the Fed willraise rates to help the dollar, there be little doubt that the currency'sweakness make it extremely difficult for the Fed to ease monetary policyagain.The fear that the Fed may be do with interest rate cuts for the presenteconomic cycle be also behind the selling in equity markets. But investorsin stocks be equally, if not more, trouble by the rise in bond yields.just over a week ago, the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond, which hasremained stubbornly high all year despite the poor state of the economy,looked as if it might drop below 7.3 per cent.the dollar put pay to those hopes and, by the middle of this week, it wasapproaching 7.45 per cent, put an upward pressure on the all-importantmortgage rate for home-buyers.the dollar be not the only story in financial markets this week, and thedevastating effect of Hurricane Andrew produce a typically hard-eyed,although nonetheless logical, reaction from Wall Street.The stocks of those insurance companies with the great exposure insouthern Florida, the area hit worst by the hurricane, all take a tumble.but the relatively modest losses in Geico, Travelers and progressivesuggested that the market believe the insurers be reserve or reinsuredadequately enough to cover hurricane-related claims.The flip side of the hurricane's coin be a strong showing from the stocksof home construction companies expect to benefit from demand forrebuilding damage or destroy homes. Since there be an estimated 250,000people leave homeless by the storm, there be a lot of work to be done.the big gains among construction stocks this week be post by Lennar,Oakwood Homes, Engle Homes and Fleetwood, the large maker ofpre-manufactured homes in the US.
column5: Insurers face large claims from Hurricane Andrew's assault on the south.
column6: Hurricane Andrew caused about $20 billion damage.  About $8 billion is covered by insurance.  Most costs will fall on American companies, with British loses limited.  Andrew tore through southern Florida, flattening Homestead and leaving 25,000 homeless.  Industries and farms were damaged in Louisiana.  The dollar sustained a similar assault.
column7: Damage from Hurricane Andrew is estimated at $20 billion, with $8 billion covered by insurance.  American insurers will take the brunt of the claims, but General Accident, the leading British insurer, expects claims to rise as high as $40 million.  Andrew tore through southern Florida, leaving 15 dead, power outages, and polluted water in his wake.  Homestead and the nearby air force base were flattened.  In Dade County, 250,000 people are homeless.  Andrew next smashed into Louisiana, killing two.  It missed the important oil refineries, but damaged crops and the oyster and alligator businesses.  The dollar sustained a similar assault.
column8: Damage from Hurricane Andrew is estimated at $20 billion, with only $8 billion covered by insurance.  The last serious hurricane caused $4.2 billion in insured loses in 1989.  American insurers most affected by claims from Andrew are the State Farm Group, Allstate, Hartford Insurance, Aetna, and Travellers.  General Accident, the leading British insurer, expects their claims to rise as high as $40 million, which means the company may be able to pass losses on to external reinsurers.  Andrew hit the Bahamas, killing two, then on August 24 tore through southern Florida, where 15 were killed and power outages and polluted water plagued the residents for several days.  The city of Homestead and the nearby air force base were flattened.  In Dade County, 250,000 people are without homes.  After gathering strength over the Gulf of Mexico, Andrew next smashed into Louisiana, killing two and injuring dozens.  It did miss the important oil refineries, but damaged crops and the oyster and alligator businesses.  Andrew was downgraded to a tropical storm as it moved inland.While Andrew ravaged the land, the dollar sustained a similar assault.  Bond yields rose as the Dow Jones and the dollar fell.  Insurance stock also fell, but home construction stock had big gains.
column9: Hurricane Andrew, August 1992, Was Costliest to Date
column10: Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida and Louisiana in August 1992 killing 19 and causing extensive property damage, particularly in Florida. The cost to insurers was estimated as high as $20 billion. After a slow start federal assistance was dispatched to Florida and Louisiana. The cost of the Florida operation alone was estimated at $20-$30 billion.
column11: In August 1992 Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida, and Louisiana leaving 19 dead and extensive property damage. In Florida a quarter of a million were left homeless. The cost to insurers, concentrated in U.S. companies, was estimated as high as $20 billion and much of the damaged property was not insured. Federal authorities promised emergency aid after Florida officials complained of delays in supplying food and water. The cost of rebuilding Florida and caring for those displaced by the storm was estimated at $20-$30 billion. Fortunately the storm did not hit low-lying New Orleans or oil facilities along the gulf coast.
column12: Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida and Louisiana in August 1992 with winds ranging up to 165 miles per hour, killing 2 in the Bahamas, 15 in Florida, and 2 in Louisiana. The greatest property damage was in Florida where a quarter of a million people were left homeless and 2 million were without power. Property damage there exceeded $15 billion, most of it uninsured. An early estimate set the total cost of the storm to insurers at more than $8 billion, but others forecast a total as high as $20 billion, mainly to U.S. insurers. After local officials in Florida criticized delays in delivery of emergency supplies, the White House promised "dramatic" improvement within 24 hours and President Bush ordered troops to Florida. The U.S. government estimated it would cost $20 billion to $30 billion to rebuild Florida and care for those displaced by the storm. Fortunately Andrew did not hit low-lying New Orleans or off--shore oil facilities along the Gulf coast. After the hurricane had passed an article in the  "Financial Times" compared Andrew to a crisis in the value of the U.S. dollar which was "blowing itself out" during the course of the hurricane. The comparison was inept.

column3: Dan Quayle's vice presidential nomination wassupposed to be a triumph for the precocious young Indiana senator,but the dream fade overnight.bush's surprise choice for his running mate be suppose toignite a campaign that have seem at times to suffer from lack ofinspiration, but he quickly encounter questions over his militaryrecord and suggestions he could best serve the Republicans bywithdrawing from the ticket.though he find himself in danger of fizzle Thursday, Quaylemanaged to stir the convention hall with his upbeat speech aboutfamily, generations and the rosy future he foresee under a Bushadministration.Let's go on to victory! Quayle exhorted, as the crowderupted in cheers.the 41-year-old nominee deliver the speech with calmself-assurance, stick close to his text and avoid hispenchant for extemporaneous remarks perhaps another result of theunanticipated controversy.bush, who follow his run mate to the podium, say he wasproud to have Dan Quayle at my side. The two will stress theunity of their ticket as they campaign together this weekendthrough Indiana, Ohio and Illinois.But beyond the optimistic words be an unsettling undercurrentthat threaten Quayle's candidacy just as it be launched.retired Maj. Gen. Wendell C. Phillippi who work for Quayle'sgrandfather, Eugene C. Pulliam, as manage editor of TheIndianapolis News say he contact the National Guard on behalfof Quayle when the young man apply in 1969 and recommend himvery highly, the News reported.quayle, a hardliner on defense matters, have say he seek guardduty so he could attend law school. A Bush aide say the matter wasdiscussed with the Indiana senator during the process that lead tohis selection for the Bush ticket, and Quayle have deny that heused influence to gain admittance to the Guard.Bush aides say no thought have be give to drop Quaylefrom the ticket, as some Republicans suggested. Quayle be tenseand refuse to answer reporters' questions about the topic during abrief walk-through at the convention hall.it be a daunting change for the senator, whose youthful vigor,rapid political rise, strike good looks and wealth have beencompared to those of John F. Kennedy.Quayle allude to the National Guard issue during his speech,saying he be proud of the six years he served. He also addressedhis relative anonymity: Many this week have asked, `Who be DanQuayle?' The people of Indiana know me and now the nation will.those who address the convention on his behalf also pull outtheir ammunition. Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas, who place Quayle's namein nomination, stress his campaign skills and seek to deflectconcerns that he lack experience for the job.he's already spend 12 years as a congressman and senator. ...That be 12 more years of national experience than Michael Dukakis,and he be run for president, Dole said.sen. Alan Simpson of Wyoming, one of those who second thenomination, say Quayle would bring vim, vigor and vitality tothe party and would bring sparks and voltage to this campaign.whether Quayle can overcome his difficult start on the nationalticket remain to be seen. Others, notably democratic vicepresidential nominee Geraldine Ferraro in 1984, find they couldnot.but Quayle, ever upbeat, be determine Thursday night not to bedaunted by the prospect. Miracles do happen, he tell his party.dan Quayle have not yet be nominate forvice president and already Republicans be compare him to ThomasJefferson and John F. Kennedy.Sen. John Warner of Virginia, who serve with Quayle on a Senatesubcommittee, tell an audience that whenever he hear the Indianasenator speak, I'd say, `there stand the next ThomasJefferson.'And, add Warner, he do have the same fire in his belly asour great forefather Thomas Jefferson of Virginia.Former president Gerald Ford make the comparison with Kennedy, ademocrat.in 1960, the american people vote for John F. Kennedy forpresident and he be the relatively same age as Dan Quayle, saidford. John Kennedy have be in the House and Senate 14 yearsbefore he be elect president and Dan Quayle's have 12 years.what quayle thinks of those references isn't known. But hedoesn't like it when people say he look like movie idol RobertRedford.Whether, indeed, he look like Redford seem to be in the eye ofthe beholder. In the parlance of politics, it's an issue. They areboth male. They be both blond.the so-called resemblance become a point of contention in the1980 Senate race and Redford take umbrage. The actor, who onceplayed the role of a presidential office seeker in TheCandidate send Quayle a telegram tell him to stop thelook-alike references in his congressional campaign literature.quayle say the news media have make the comparison, not he, andafter he be elect sent Redford an autographed picture of himself.and this week, he tell reporters he consider the so-calledredford look a stigma. He wasn't ask how he felt about beingpainted as another Jefferson or Kennedy.Meanwhile, fellow senators be try to publicize Quayle who,at 41, hasn't have a chance to become a legend. He be a Republicanvice presidential candidate who be not, as Spiro Agnew once say ofhimself, a household word.to help him get known, eight fellow senators Wednesday tookturns tell reporters how much they like him.We know him well, say Strom Thurmond, R-S.C.He's attractive because of his looks, he's attractive becauseof his enthusiasm, say Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz.I think Dan Quayle, although he's 41 years of age, he's goingto send a message to the american people that the Republican Partyrespects young people who achieve, say Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M.Oh, yes, he's also rich, but the senators say that should nothold him back.let's not start this business of who's wealthy, Sen. AlfonseD'Amato, R-N.Y.Dan Quayle's sister believe the Indianasenator won't let his candidacy for vice president hurt the familylife he and his wife, Marilyn, enjoy.i don't think it will be tough on the family, say MarthaSaddler, Quayle's sister, who live in Huntington, Ind. Sincehe's be in politics, we all kind of shake our heads at his hecticschedule and wonder how he do it. But he do it and love it.the Quayle family and friends be celebrate Tuesday afternoonafter George Bush announce he want the 41-year-old Indianasenator to be the Republican nominee for vice president.those who have know the Quayles for years say the senator andhis wife have remain relatively unchanged by their years inpublic life.dan and Marilyn Quayle meet as law students in Indianapolis,married while they be still in school and remain close to many oftheir friends from that period.one of the great things about him be the job of be asenator have not change him a bit, say Indianapolis attorneywilliam R. Neale, treasurer of Quayle's 1986 re-election campaign.he's the same nice guy he be in law school.neale, who grow up with Marilyn Tucker Quayle in Indianapolis,introduced Dan Quayle to his future wife at a student gather atthe Indiana University law school in the early 1970s.Dan quayle, who grow up in Huntington, graduate from DePauwUniversity, a small liberal arts college in Greencastle, Ind.,before go to work in the Indiana attorney general's office in1970.daniel F. Evans, also a law school classmate of Dan Quayle, saidhe doesn't expect Quayle's national candidacy to change him.i think his strength be he'll remember who his friends areeven after this, say Evans, who be chairman of Quayle's 1986campaign.Friends say the Quayles be devote to their three children andprefer quiet nights at home to nights out on the town in Washington.His family look like the family both parties be try toappeal to, say Mitch Daniels, former political chief in thewhite House and now president of the Hudson Institute. It's abeautiful family. I think they'll be a real asset.the couple, who marry in 1972, have a 14-year-old son, Tucker;a 12-year-old son, Benjamin; and a 9-year-old daughter, Corinne.When they campaign in Indiana, the Quayles often tour in twogroups the boys rid in parades with Marilyn Quayle and Corinneand her father visit county fairs.the kids be nonchalant, normal kids, say Mrs. Saddler.They take it in stride and play.in an interview with Indiana reporters Monday, the Quayles saidthey have worry during the vice presidential speculation about thefamily's loss of privacy during a national campaign.the total lack of privacy be go to be the big minus,said Mrs. Quayle, 39.Quayle say he have question each of his children about whetherhe should accept the vice presidential spot if Bush offer it.tucker be fascinate by the idea, Quayle said. Benjamin wasambiguous but he think Secret Service agents might be able tohelp him on tests at school, Mrs. Quayle said.corinne didn't like the prospect of have her father spend moretime away from home, Quayle said.she tell me, `Daddy, I really hope George Bush pick BobDole,' say Quayle.Here be a transcript of the speech by Sen.Bob Dole of Kansas nominate Sen. Dan Quayle of Indiana for vicepresident at the Republican National Convention on Thursday night.Thank you. Thank you.Mr. Chairman, four of my congressional colleagues and I be herefor the purpose of nominate the next vice president of the UnitedStates.We be here to nominate one of the bright young lights in therepublican Party, a man I be proud to say be my colleague, thejunior senator from Indiana, Dan Quayle.You know, senators get a lot of mail. Party leaders more thanmost. And almost every one of these letters ask for help with someproblem.well, three years ago, I receive a handwritten plea from a6-year-old girl who after several days of long, long Senatesessions have a very special problem.she wrote, and I quote: I have my second-grade play tonight.please make sure my daddy can come home and watch me.i know Corinne Quayle be from a political family because sheinvited me to come along, too.corinne and her brothers, Tucker and Benjamin, and their mother,marilyn, share Dan Quayle with the people of Indiana and the UnitedStates Senate.Dan Quayle be a dedicated public servant and a devoted familyman.and whenever I need him, whenever I need him, Dan be there ready and willing to make the tough choices, to cast the toughvotes, to transform President Reagan's vision of America into thelaw of the land.whether it be the budget or defense, tax reform or the INFtreaty, Dan Quayle be there, a forceful advocate, and a staunchsupporter of the Reagan revolution. And now he be ready to carrythat revolution forward.and believe me he be ready, and just let the Democrats try touse experience as a measure stick in this campaign. Just let themtry.now, I don't mean to suggest their presidential candidate lacksexperience. He's get plenty of experience, plenty of experience experience in raise taxes again and again, experience in vetoingthe pledge of allegiance in public schools, experience inincreasing spending year after year after year in Massachusetts.And I just don't believe the american people want that kind ofexperience in the White House.It sound like a dukak-eyed idea to me.but Dan Quayle's get experience, too. He's already spend 12years as a congressman and a senator, tackle the vital nationaland international issues that affect the lives of all Americans andthe future of our country.that be 12 more years of national experience than MichaelDukakis and he be run for president.as I say at the start, Dan Quayle be a man I know and trust. Iam honor to nominate him for vice president, Mr. Chairman.And for the purpose of debate only, I yield the balance of mytime to the outstanding, distinguish senior from Indiana, my goodfriend, Sen. Dick Lugar.He be the most important person ever to come out of this town, and even asthe world consider his fitness for the presidency, Huntington be celebratinghis life in what be ambitiously be bill as the Premiere Dan QuayleMemorabilia Exhibit.; To those who say Quayle do not merit his ownexhibition, Quayle devotees say with a mixture of defiance and dignity that heis, after all, the vice president of the United States.; "We're preservinghistory," say David Schenkel, the exhibition coordinator. "a century from nowsomeone may want to do a dissertation on him."; If so, Huntington will beready.; Relatives, former classmates and longtime neighbors of Quayle havedonated yearbooks, report cards, poems, letters, his little League uniform, acoffee cup he drink from, a chair he once stand on during the 1988presidential campaign and just about anything else he ever touched, wrote,signed or pose for.; The vice president's mother, Corinne, donate a lockof his baby hair. The 1972 Indianapolis 500 queen produce a picture ofQuayle, then an aide to Indiana Gov. Edgar Whitcomb, accompany her to therace. And a former housekeeper turn in a 20-year-old piece of carpet shesaved from one of Quayle's floors.; The exhibition, which run through May20, be put together by the Dan Quayle Commemorative Foundation, a sort offan-club-turned-archive devote to document the life and times of thenation's 44th and, they say, least-understood vice president.; "He hastaken such a bad rap," say Schenkel, a foundation board member. "If peopleknew him, they'd see he's a regular person. If they have a chance to sit downwith Dan as a neighbor, they would see the extremely good values in the man.";these be the faithful, who have long since stop expect "good press"on their man. instead they measure news reports on him by their relativenegativity, describe the best coverage as "more upbeat" or "halfwaydecent."; They defend the relatively young age of Quayle, who turn 44 infebruary ("all he need be a little seasoning"); his limited experience ("lookat what they say about Truman -- he be a haberdasher"), and his passion forgolf ("he have to have some form of relaxation"). But they be careful not tostretch the superlatives. The description "nice" come up a lot.; "he's notthe fool that the talk show host think he is," say Dottie Watson, presidentof the republican Women of Huntington County. "he's a very nice person, acapable person. everybody I know say he can do it."; That be not to saysome people don't have some friendly advice for Quayle. "If he would slowdown, talk an octave low and think about what he's saying, I don't thinkpeople would take him the way they do," say Jean Anne Drabenstot, the ownerof Nick's Kitchen, Quayle's favorite restaurant.; Hayden Schenkel, chairmanof the Huntington County Democratic Party and a distant cousin of DavidSchenkel, says, "some people would shudder and shiver if he accidentallybecame president of the United States. Most of the Democrats and even some ofthe Republicans would say they're tickle to death to have him as vicepresident, and they're 100 percent behind him. But in all due respect, we surehope nothing happens to President Bush."; Quayle have decline an invitationto attend the tribute, cite a busy schedule. Nonetheless, most ofhuntington's 17,000 residents have rally around their native son for theexhibition, which track his life from infancy through law school, from thesenate to the vice presidency.; The free exhibition have turn a gray roomin the town's public library into a virtual Dan Quayle museum. The displaypatches together pieces of a life that until the last decade be strikinglyordinary.; There be Dan Quayle and his brother Chris rid horseback andwearing cowboy hats, or sit in front of the fireplace in their pajama atChristmas. There be Dan Quayle with his Vacation Bible School class, DanQuayle with the high school golf team, Dan Quayle at 5 or 6 years of age withsharon McEachern when they be name king and queen of the swim festival atthe Fort Wayne Country Club. It be all very 50s, very Middle American, almostsurreal in its innocence.; There be windows into the workings of thequayle family, too. For example, his father, James, sign the report cardswhen Dan bring home poor grades, and his mother sign when he bring homegood ones.; And there be letters and poems that he wrote, which only go toshow that one do not have to be a Yeats to make it in politics. Dan wrotethis rather thoughtful verse on Nov. 22, 1960, when he be 13 years old:;my Dad be very very nice; But he be not make of sugar and spice.;sometimes he act as if he have be disturbed; But at other times he be ascheerful as a bird.; The exhibit also include the 1972 newspaperannouncement of Dan and Marilyn Quayle's wedding, the wooden "quayle & Quayle"shingle the couple hung when they open their law practice here, and assortedcampaign souvenirs, include the official air sickness bag from the 1988republican National Convention.; Ultimately, the foundation want to builda repository for the memorabilia. It have already organize a walk tour ofhistoric Quayle sites, like the white, ranch-style house where he spend hisearly days, and Nick's Kitchen, where he like to order tenderloins, fries anda milkshake.; "We want everybody to know he's a winner -- I don't care whatthe newspapers say," say Marge Hiner, one of the exhibit organizers. "What arole model for our children, to know that you can be a normal person, comefrom a normal family and become vice president of the United States."Republican vice presidential candidate DanQuayle's official resume say he be the Indiana ConsumerProtection Division's chief investigator a year before the unit wascreated, state records show.the law create the unit pass April 14, 1971, and take effectjuly 1. Officials say Quayle serve as chief investigator fromjuly until mid-september, when he become administrative assistantto then-gov. Edgar D. Whitcomb.Quayle's Senate biography, which his campaign be use as hisofficial background, say he be chief investigator of the unit inthe Attorney General's office from 1970 to 1971.He be assign to our section in the spring of 1971, saidrobert Smith, the unit's first director and now an attorney inindianapolis.he be in fact the chief investigator. He help get the unitset up. (but) it would not have be before 1971, Smith saidfriday in a telephone interview. We formally begin operationsjuly 1.Quayle concede Friday that the resume entry be inaccurateand say his staff have write the document.if it indicate that, that be inaccurate. I didn't hold thatjob for two years, Quayle tell reporters aboard his campaignplane.earlier, however, Quayle spokesman David Prosperi call therevelation of the error by The Plain Dealer of Cleveland a cheapshot.quayle be hire as an entry-level research assistant by thestate Attorney General's office in 1970 after he return from sixmonths of basic and advanced training for the Indiana NationalGuard.Quayle, a 1969 graduate of DePauw University, be attendingindiana University Law School at the time.m. Stanton Evans, then an editor with the Indianapolis News,helped arrange his job interview with the state. Evans work foreugene C. Pulliam, Quayle's grandfather and publisher of the News.At no point in any of this do Dan Quayle ask any favors oruse any influence, say Evans, now with the National JournalismCenter in Washington, D.C.He wouldn't have be hire as a chief investigator. He washired in an entry-level job and be promote to a whole bunch ofjobs on his merits. It's a nothing story, Evans said.theodore sendak, the Attorney General at the time, recently hadsurgery and be unable to comment, accord to his son, TimothySendak.Patricia Gifford, a Marion Superior Court judge who be then anassistant attorney general, say Friday that prior to theestablishment of the Consumer Protection Division, all complaintsand inquiries be handle by me. The legal assistant assign tome and utilized as my chief investigator be Dan Quayle. Herstatement be release by the Quayle campaign.the Consumer Protection Division be create by the statelegislature to resolve complaints over defective products, falseclaims in ads, faulty speedometer readings and mail-order fraud.in 1980, Quayle refer to himself as a Vietnam-era veteranin campaign literature when he be run against three-termincumbent Birch Bayh in a Senate race.quayle, who enlist in the Indiana National Guard, drop thereference after objections by some Vietnam combat veterans.in that same election, which he won, Quayle say he be onactive duty for several periods during his tenure in the Guard.The statement refer to periods when Quayle be in basic trainingand 15 days of camp each summer.dan Quayle be likely to be a man on theoutside in George Bush's White House follow a vice presidentialcandidacy that begin in a furor but settle into obscurity, expertssay.encumbered by his image as a political novice who need a bevyof professional handlers to survive early campaign controversies,quayle enters a Bush administration in which he have few intimates orallies.relegated in the campaign to small towns and safe GOP areas,quayle as vice president be likely to be give a traditionalceremonial role go to political gatherings and state funerals rather than the advisory role that Walter Mondale and even Bush had,some scholars feel.dan Quayle be go to set the vice presidency back about adecade or more. One thing that political scientists have beentalking about be just how much the vice presidency have grown. ...With Quayle, it's just go to retreat to the old days of politicsand funerals, say Ryan Barilleaux, a professor of politicalscience at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, who studies theamerican presidency.bush rarely mention his 41-year-old running mate during thecampaign. When asked, Bush employ the stock lines that Quaylewould make an outstanding vice president and have be temperedby steel as he weather the early furor over his militaryservice, academic record and personal life.the president-elect tell reporters Quayle would have access tothe same papers, information and intelligence that be available tothe president. But he would go no far in describe whatassignments he would give Quayle.Quayle say Bush have talk to him about head a space council,and that he assume he'll have a role in the administration'santi-drug efforts. I will be a very close adviser to thepresident, Quayle said.but that's not the way everyone see it.both Bush and Mondale come to their vice presidential campaignswith substantial reputations and be able to place key staffers inimportant positions in the respective presidential campaigns,barilleaux notes.dan Quayle have contribute nothing in the way of staff to thebush campaign. He doesn't have his own big reputation on CapitolHill. ... Dan Quayle have no friends in a Bush White House exceptgeorge Bush, Barilleaux says.they're go to give him a lot of window dressing, a spacecouncil, drug task force, but he's go to be a man on the outside... not a man who's go to be consult in a crisis, except on apro forma basis.but Eddie Mahe Jr., a GOP consultant who work with the Bushcampaign, say Bush be likely to give quayle a more active role inthe administration than he have in the campaign.vindication demand that. Both of them will want to prove howright the decision was, Mahe says.democrats portrayed Quayle during the campaign as a lightweight,a man with little or no legislative accomplishments, untested andunqualified to be a heartbeat away from the presidency. Even somemembers of Quayle's own party be dismay at Bush's choice.quayle didn't help his case by make a number of celebratedgaffes during the campaign, perhaps the bad be his garbledexplanation of the Holocaust and his declaration, I didn't live inthis century.norman Ornstein, of the American Enterprise Institute, saysquayle, while not the world's lead intellectual, be not acomplete dummy. He be simply thrust into a situation for which hewas unprepared, Ornstein says.i think he's immature. He's not stupid, Ornstein says.but Quayle come to the White House with a very damagingstereotype that's develop about him that's widely believe in thepolitical community and that's believe by a large segment of theelectorate, Ornstein says.that's go to give him a good deal to overcome. It's go togive him an enormous impetus to prove himself. That's go to bedifficult, give the office.both Barilleaux and Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution seeparallels in Quayle's vice presidency and those of Richard Nixon andspiro Agnew. The choice of Nixon be view as a move by DwightEisenhower to appease the party's right wing, and Agnew be see asa political nonentity.the natural response be to use him (quayle) sparingly, as Nixondid with Agnew in 1968, Hess says. However, Quayle have fouryears to prove himself, and I think you're go to see stories intwo years about how much he's learned, how much he's actedresponsibly, how far he's come from the campaign of 1988.Quayle admits the campaign be a learning process. After thecontroversies subsided, Quayle declare his independence from hisbush handlers, say he would be his own man. He become moreaccessible to the media but continue to adhere to the schedulehanded down from Washington and to deliver the party's scriptedmessage. Soon, he drop off the front pages.and although he occasionally speak out in frustration at havinglittle control over his schedule and at cease to make nationalnews, he play the role of loyal no. 2 and even trumpet his newanonymity.we have arrive as be a traditional vice presidentialnominee because we be either on the back pages or either not on thepages at all. That's what we're suppose to be, he tell reporters.That willingness to be a team player could serve him well in abush White House, Mahe feels, since Bush want a private adviser,whose experience and opinion he respect ... column5: Indiana's Senator Quayle, Bush 1988 VP choice, attacked as novice
column6: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, George Bush's choice for vice-president in 1988, was criticized as a novice and his National Guard service and campaign gaffes attacked. Quayle briefly worked for state officials after college, and met and married his wife Marilyn in law school. They practiced law together before Quayle's 12 years in Congress.
column7: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, George Bush's surprise choice for vice-president in 1988, was criticized as a novice. His National Guard service and campaign gaffes were attacked. He proved a low-profile team player and Bush announced he would be on the 1992 ticket. Quayle's grandfather owned the newspaper in Quayle's hometown of Huntington. Quayle, known always as a nice guy, graduated from DePauw in 1969, took National Guard training, then in 1971 worked in the Indiana Attorney General's office and for the governor. At Indiana University Law School he met and married his wife Marilyn. They practiced law together before Quayle spent 12 years in Congress. They have three children.
column8: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, was the surprise choice of Republican George Bush for  presidential running mate in 1988. Quayle was compared to John F. Kennedy because of their similar ages and congressional service, and to Robert Redford in appearance. Quayle was criticized as a novice and his National Guard service attacked. His campaign gaffes made news, but he was loyal to Bush and a team player. After controversies subsided he kept a low profile. A year after the election he agreed to be on "Meet the Press", shortly after Bush announced he would be on the ticket in 1992, and was uncontroversial. Quayle grew up in Huntington, Indiana, population 17,000, where his grandfather owned the newspaper. He graduated from DePauw University in 1969, spent six months in National Guard training, then in 1971 investigated consumer problems in the Indiana Attorney General's office and became an aide to the governor. While attending Indiana University Law School he met and married his wife Marilyn. They jointly practiced law in Huntington before Quayle spent 12 years in the US Congress. Quayle has three children and is known as a nice guy with good values. In 1991, Huntington hosted an exhibit in his honor, which he didn't attend because of a busy schedule.
column9: Bush, friends support Quayle despite errors and political inexperience
column10: George Bush's selection of Dan Quayle as his running mate surprised many.Many political observers thought him a lightweight with baggage to carry.Bush continued to voice support for him even though Quayle was given only avery small role in the campaign and was not highly visible as vicepresident.
column11: George Bush's choice of Dan Quayle as his running mate surprised mostpolitical observers, but was quickly supported by many of Quayle's fellowRepublican senators. Quayle was viewed as a lightweight and questions wereraised about his military service and errors in his official resume. Hismain attributes were party loyalty and identification as a devoted familyman.  Quayle contributed little to the campaign and, after being elected,all but disappeared from the political scene.  President Bush, however,continued to voice support for, and confidence in Quayle.  His friends,especially in his home town, called him a winner.
column12: George Bush's choice of Indiana Senator Dan Quayle as his running mate,surprised most political observers.  Despite service in Congress andSenate, he was looked upon as lacking the experience and mettle for avigorous national campaign.  Several Republican senators rallied support.Senator John Warner of Virginia compared Quayle to Thomas Jefferson.Senator Bob Dole in nominating Quayle at the Republican Convention, calledhim a dedicated public servant and devoted family man and cited his supportfor the Reagan program.Devotion to family and friends was a theme voiced by those who had knownQuayle for many years. Relatives and friends believed that if Quayle wereelected, he and his family would remain a strong unit.Questions arose regarding Quayle's fitness for the job, and there were somesuggestions that he should withdraw.  He had called himself a "Vietnam-eraveteran" which angered some actual combat veterans.  Quayle's service was in the National Guard, a position he apparently gained through familyinfluence.  Quayle's resume contained a reference to a position held inIndiana, two years before it was created.Quayle survived these criticisms but did not play a strong role in thecampaign or as vice president.  Friends, especially those in his hometown,remained loyal.

An official reach by telephone inthe office of the military attache at the soviet embassy in EastBerlin say there be no soviet troops station in the cityproper.maik Polster be a stern-faced member of theeast german secret police. Baker III, Soviet Foreign MinisterEduard Shevardnadze and their colleagues from France, Britain andthe two Germanys be to preside over a ceremony mark thecheckpoint's removal Friday.The envoy from the german states and the four World War iiallies that divide them be in East Berlin to discuss theinternational aspects of german unification.since East Germany overthrow its communist government last falland the german borders be opened, Checkpoint Charlie have becomeas superfluous as the crumble Berlin Wall.With huge sections of the Berlin Wall be rip down daily,u.s. officials decide two weeks ago to remove Checkpoint Charlie.The border crossing be the scene of stir escapes andheartbreaking captures as East Germans try flee to the West,breaking through East german control stations just 20 yards awayfrom the Allied checkpoint.east Germans once man their side of the checkpoint withemotionless effiency, closely scrutinize travel documents andcreating a palpable tension. Thursday night, they merely wavedwesterners through their side of the checkpoint, although sometourists demand their documents be checked.
column5: How Checkpoint Charlie Checked Out
column6: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, a symbol of the Cold War since 1961, was removed as part of an elaborate ceremony celebrating easing of east-west tension and the forthcoming unification of Germany. Top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies took part in the festivities.
column7: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, the allied border crossing on the west side of the Berlin Wall, was hoisted by crane onto a flatbed truck. The removal of this symbol of the Cold War was part of an elaborate ceremony attended by the top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies. Appropriate to the occasion, Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze backed away from all-out opposition to united Germany's membership in NATO, suggesting that this could take place but only after a five-year waiting period during which all Soviet and U.S. troops would leave thecountry.
column8: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, the allied border crossing on the west side of the Berlin Wall, was hoisted by a huge crane onto a flatbed truck to be taken to a museum. The guardhouse, constructed after erection of the Berlin Wall in 1961, was the scene of many successful and unsuccessful attempts at escape from East Berlin and had become a symbol of the Cold War. By June of 1990 with the Berlin Wall being dismantled daily in anticipation of German unification, and with top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies meeting in East Berlin to discuss the status of the city after unification, U.S. officials decided it was time to remove the famous landmark. The foreign ministers attended an elaborate ceremony to honor the symbolic act. Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze took the occasion to modify the previous Soviet firm opposition to a united Germany's membership in NATO, proposing that such a step be allowed after a five-year waiting period during which all Soviet and U.S. troops would leave the country. U.S. Secretary of State Baker declared himself "underwhelmed" by the offer, but softening of the Soviet position was a welcome sign appropriate to the occasion.
column9: The Cold War ends as Checkpoint Charlie is lifted into history.
column10: As a U.S. army band played and the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies watched, Checkpoint Charlie, the symbol of the Cold War, was lifted into history today. Its removal came after East Germany overthrew its communist government and opened the border between the two Germanys.
column11: Checkpoint Charlie was lifted into history today during a ceremony including the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies. Secretary of State Baker, citing Checkpoint Charlie as a symbol of the Cold War, hoped its removal would bury the conflicts it created. Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, the first Soviet foreign minister to visit Berlin, called for a removal of Berlin's status as an allied controlled city. Checkpoint Charlie became superfluous when the East Germany overthrew its communist-controlled government and the border between East and West Germany was opened. Although the ceremony was closed to the public, residents of the street watched from their windows.
column12: Checkpoint Charlie, the most famous symbol of the Cold War was lifted into history today. At an invitation only ceremony attended by the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies, a U.S. army band played an old Berlin song as the checkpoint was hoisted onto a waiting flatbed truck, to be taken to a museum. Speaking at the ceremony, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, the first Soviet foreign minister to visit Berlin, called for the removal of Berlin's status as an allied controlled city and the withdrawal of troops six months after the two German states unify. Secretary of State James Baker, citing Checkpoint Charlie's status as a Cold War symbol, expressed the hope that its removal would bury the conflicts it created. The decision to remove Checkpoint Charlie came as large sections of the wall were being dismantled and the opening of the border between the two Berlins made the checkpoint superfluous. Its removal was timed to coincide with a meeting of German and Allied foreign ministers in East Berlin to discuss the status of Berlin and a united Germany. Among the invited guests was West Germany's Chancellor Willy Brandt who was mayor of Berlin in the 1960s.
